Complete or partial duplication of the phalanges of the thumb. Depending on the severity, the appearance on x-ray can vary from a notched phalanx (the duplicated bone is almost completely fused with the phalanx), a partially fused appearance of the two bones (bifid), two separate bones appearing side to side, or completely duplicated phalanges (proximal and distal phalanx of the thumb and/or 1st metacarpal). In contrast to the phalanges of the digits 2-5 (proximal, middle and distal), the proximal phalanx of the thumb is embryologically equivalent to the middle phalanges of the other digits, whereas the first metacarpal is embryologically of phalangeal origin and as such equivalent to the proximal phalanges of the other digits.

ET: Partial duplication of the phalanges of the 2nd finger
DEF: A partial duplication, depending on severity leading to a broad or bifid appearance, affecting one or more of the phalanges of the 2nd finger. As opposed to a complete duplication there is still a variable degree of fusion between the duplicated bones.

ET: Complete duplication of the phalanges of the 2nd finger
DEF: A complete duplication affecting one or more of the phalanges of the 2nd finger. As opposed to a partial duplication were there is still a variable degree of fusion between the duplicated bones, a complete duplication leads to two separate bones appearing side to side (radio-ulnar axis) as seen on x-rays. A duplication leading to an accesory bone appearing in the proximo-distal axis on x-rays, is a different entity called a Pseudoepiphyses (see according terms) sometimes also referred to as Hyperphalangism.

ET: Partial duplication of the phalanges of the 3rd finger
DEF: A partial duplication, depending on severity leading to a broad or bifid appearance, affecting one or more of the phalanges of the 3rd finger. As opposed to a complete duplication there is still a variable degree of fusion between the duplicated bones.

ET: Complete duplication of the phalanges of the 4th finger
DEF: A complete duplication affecting one or more of the phalanges of the 4th finger. As opposed to a partial duplication were there is still a variable degree of fusion between the duplicated bones, a complete duplication leads to two separate bones appearing side to side (radio-ulnar axis) as seen on x-rays. A duplication leading to an accesory bone appearing in the proximo-distal axis on x-rays, this is actually a different entity called a Pseudoepiphyses (see according terms) sometimes also referred to as Hyperphalangism.

ET: Partial duplication of the phalanges of the 4th finger
DEF: A partial duplication, depending on severity leading to a broad or bifid appearance, affecting one or more of the phalanges of the 4th finger. As opposed to a complete duplication there is still a variable degree of fusion between the duplicated bones.

ET: Complete duplication of the phalanges of the 5th finger
DEF: A complete duplication affecting one or more of the phalanges of the 5th finger. As opposed to a partial duplication were there is still a variable degree of fusion between the duplicated bones, a complete duplication leads to two separate bones appearing side to side (radio-ulnar axis) as seen on x-rays. A duplication leading to an accesory bone appearing in the proximo-distal axis on x-rays, this is actually a different entity called a Pseudoepiphyses (see according terms) sometimes also referred to as Hyperphalangism.

ET: Partial duplication of the phalanges of the 5th finger
DEF: A partial duplication, depending on severity leading to a broad or bifid appearance, affecting one or more of the phalanges of the 5th finger. As opposed to a complete duplication there is still a variable degree of fusion between the duplicated bones.
Abnormally small size of the epiphysis of the 1st metacarpal with respect to age-dependent norms.
The presence of short and wide 1st metacarpal which tapers distally (\
Displacement of the big toe from its normal position.
An abnormal morphology of one or more phalanges of the big toe, with a short and wide phalanx that tapers distally. Bullet-shaped phalanges lack the normal diaphyseal constriction.
An abnormal morphology of the firstmetatarsal bone, which is short and wide and tapers distally, and lacks the normal diaphyseal constriction.
A developmental defect consisting in the complete duplication of the first metatarsal bone.
A developmental defect consisting in the duplication of part of the first metatarsal bone.
A conical (cone-shaped) appearance of the epiphysis of the first metatarsal of the foot.
Absence of the epiphyses of the phalanges of the toes.

ET: Contracture of the interphalangeal joint of the hallux
DEF: The interphalangeal joint of the big toe cannot be straightened actively or passively.

ET: Abnormality of the epiphysis of the 2nd metacarpal
DEF: Any abnormality of the epiphysis of the second metacarpal bone.

ET: Abnormality of the epiphysis of the 3rd metacarpal
DEF: Any abnormality of the epiphysis of the third metacarpal bone.

ET: Abnormality of the epiphysis of the 4th metacarpal
DEF: Any abnormality of the epiphysis of the 4th metacarpal bone.

ET: Abnormality of the epiphysis of the 5th metacarpal
DEF: Any abnormality of the epiphysis of the fifth metacarpal bone.
Increased pigmentation, either focal or generalized, of the mucosa of the mouth.
An abnormally low-pitched voice.
Absence or underdevelopment of the diaphragm.

ET: Aplasia/Hypoplasia of the abdominal wall musculature
DEF: Absence or underdevelopment of the abdominal musculature.

ET: Symphalangism affecting the phalanges of the 2nd toe
DEF: Fusion of the interphalangeal joints of the 2nd toe.

ET: Symphalangism affecting the phalanges of the 3rd toe
Symphalangism affecting the phalanges of the 4th toe
Symphalangism affecting the phalanges of the 5th toe
Curved proximal phalanx of the 2nd toe
DEF: A deviation from the normal straight form of the proximal phalanx of the 2nd toe.

ET: Triangular shaped proximal phalanx of the 2nd toe
Curved middle phalanx of the 2nd toe
DEF: A deviation from the normal straight form of the middle phalanx of the 2nd toe.

ET: Triangular shaped middle phalanx of the 2nd toe
Curved distal phalanx of the 2nd toe
DEF: A deviation from the normal straight form of the distal phalanx of the 2nd toe.

ET: Triangular shaped distal phalanx of the 2nd toe
Partial duplication of phalanx of the 2nd toe
DEF: Partial duplication of a phalanx of second toe.

ET: Complete duplication of the phalanges of the 2nd toe
DEF: Complete duplication of a phalanx of second toe.
Reduced length of one or more phalanx of second toe as a result of developmental hypoplasia.

Hermaphroditism refers to a discrepancy between the morphology of the gonads and that of the external genitalia. In female pseudohermaphroditism, the genotype is female (XX) and the gonads are ovaries, but the external genitalia are virilized.
Shortening of the arms predominantly affecting terminal parts of the arm in relation to the upper and middle limb segments.
Shortening of the legs predominantly affecting terminal parts of the leg in relation to the upper and middle arm segments.
Weakness of both lower extremities with sparing of the upper extremities. Paraplegia refers to a severe or complete loss of strength, whereas paraparesis refers to a relatively mild loss of strength.
This term applies if the Epiglottis is absent or hypoplastic.

A soft tissue continuity in the anteroposterior axis between adjacent foot digits that involves at least half of the proximodistal length of one of the two involved digits; or, a soft tissue continuity in the A/P axis between two digits of the foot that does not meet the prior objective criteria.
Absence or underdevelopment of the toenail.

An abnormality of the premaxilla (the embryonic structure that forms the anterior part of the maxilla) causing it to appear relatively small in size compared to the other parts of the maxilla or other facial structures.
A type of nuclear cataract involving congenital dust-like (pulverulent) opacity of the embryonal and fetal nucleus.
Fibrous dysplasia of the bones were lesions are localized in only one bone.
Prominent positioning of the premaxilla in relation to the rest of the maxilla, the facial skeleton, or mandible. Not necessarily caused by an increase in size (hypertrophy of) the premaxilla.
Gentle upward curve of the upper lip vermilion such that the center is placed well superior to the commissures.

JT: 焦点性徐波活動を伴う脳波
DEF: Focal (localized) slow activity reflects focal dysfunction, not diffuse dysfunction (i.e., encephalopathy).
A kind of breech presentation in which the hips are flexed and the knees are flexed.
Atrophy of the cervical segment of the spinal cord.
Absence or underdevelopment of the nasal bone.

A finding of a focus of increased echogenicity upon prenatal ultrasound examination of the fetus. The foci may be present in one or both ventricles. Echogenic intracardiac focus (EICF) is defined as a focus of echogenicity comparable to bone, in the region of the papillary muscle in either or both ventricles of the fetal heart.
A deviation from the normal count of B cells, i.e., the cells that are formed in the bone marrow, migrate to the peripheral lymphatic system, and mature into plasma cells or memory cells.
Slow, creeping onset, slow progress and long continuance of disease manifestations.

JT: ブドウ糖ホメオスターシス異常
DEF: Abnormality of glucose homeostasis.
Agenesis of either mandibular second permanent molar or maxillary second permanent molar.
A spherical hollow structure with a smooth muscle coat, lined by a mucous membrane, and attached to any part of the gastrointestinal tract, from the base of the tongue to the anus.
A type of age-related cataract that primarily affects the nucleus of the lens.
Typical absence seizures starting before the age of 4 years.
Absence or underdevelopment of the eyelid.
Supernumerary ridge or crus of the ear arising from the antihelix.
A type of pulmonary sequestration that occurs within the visceral pleura of normal lung tissue, usually without communication with the tracheobronchial tree.
EEG with sharp waves in the central region, i.e., sharp transient waves of a duration between 80 and 200 msec.

JT: 焦点性棘波を伴う脳波
DEF: EEG with sharp waves in the frontal region, i.e., sharp transient waves of a duration between 80 and 200 msec.

JT: 右単一人字縫合早期癒合
DEF: Premature synostosis of only the right lambdoid suture.
An abnormality of the skin that is restricted to a particular body region.

ET: Incomplete partition of the cochlea type I
DEF: Incomplete partition I is also known as cystic cochleovestibular malformation, where the cochlea has no bony modiolus, resulting in an empty cystic cochlea. This is accompanied by a dilated cystic vestibule with developmental arrest at the fifth week of gestation.
Increased size of the vestibular aqueduct.

JT: 胎児エコーでのソフトマーカー
DEF: An finding upon obstetric ultrasound examination performed at around 16 to 20 weeks of gestation that is abnormal but not clearly identifiable as a fetal anatomic malformation or growth restriction. Such findings are known as soft markers since they are associated with increased risk for fetal aneuploidy or other disorders.
The condition in which both atria are joined to the right ventricle each by its own atrioventricular valve. Usually, the left ventricle is hypoplastic.
An abnormality of the circulatory connection between the ventricles and the pulmonary artery and aorta.
A congenital defect of heart development characterized by origin of both pulmonary artery and aorta from the morphological left ventricle.
Aorto-ventricular tunnel is a congenital, extracardiac channel which connects the ascending aorta above the sinutubular junction to the cavity of the left, or (less commonly) right ventricle.
Chronic supraventricular tachycardia predominantly seen in childhood.

Progressive PR interval prolongation with the subsequent occurrence of a single nonconducted P wave that results in a pause. The pause that follows the nonconducted impulse is less than fully compensatory (less than the sum of two normal sinus intervals).

JT: 房室結節性リエントリ性頻拍
DEF: Accessory pathway-related atrioventricular reentrant tachycardia (AVRT) involves an abnormal electrical conduction of the accessory pathway. The accessory pathway connecting impulses between the atrium and the ventricle can be seen at any site in the AV groove.

Systemic desaturation of a liveborn baby resulting from persistent pulmonary hypertension with a patent ductus arteriosus and patent foramen ovale, such that the circulation in postnatal life follows the fetal course.

JT: 二次性高アルドステロン症
DEF: A form of hyperaldosteronism caused by abnormally increased renin levels.
Absence of the neurohypophysis owing to a developmental defect.

JT: 三次性副甲状腺機能亢進症
DEF: A type of hyperparathyroidism that occurs following kidney transplantation, which is a treatment for secondary hyperparathyroidism. Although kidney transplantation leads to a normalization of serum calcium and parathyroid hormone in most patients. The state of persistent hypercalcemia and hyperparathyroidism is referred to as tertiary hyperparathyroidism.
Increased size of the parotid gland.
H-shaped crease in the fat pad of the chin.
An anomaly in platelet form, ultrastructure, or intracellular organelles.
Abnormal calcification in the cardiovascular system.
Proximal mislocalization of the big toe from its normal position.

ET: Hypersegmentation of proximal phalanx of third finger
DEF: Presence of an additional phalanx-like bone, producing an extra, wedge-shaped bone at the base of the proximal phalanx of the third finger.

JT: 黄体形成ホルモン上昇
DEF: An elevated concentration of luteinizing hormone in the blood.
A type of melanoma that is flat and irregular in shape and color, with different shades of black and brown.
Presence of multiple cystic changes in multiple areas or multiple bones.

JT: ミトコンドリアの形の異常
DEF: An anomaly in the surface contour of mitochondria.
A congenital inclusion cysts that arises from ectodermal cells that normally form skin cells being left behind in the nervous system during development.
Decreased quantity or activity of von Willebrand factor. Von Willebrand factor mediates the adhesion of platelets to the collagen exposed on endothelial cell surfaces.
Atrophy of the cerebral subcortical white and gray matter, termed subcortical atrophy, reflects loss of nerve cells in the basal ganglia or fibers in the deep white matter.

JT: プロトロンビン活性の減少

DEF: Persistence of immune complexes in the blood circulation.
Reduced number of primary teeth.

A type of retinal detachment arising from damage to the outer blood-retinal barrier that allows fluid to access the subretinal space and separate the neurosensory retina from the retinal pigment epithelium.

JT: 薬剤誘発性無顆粒球症
DEF: A type of agranulocytosis related to ingestion of a specific medication.

Inflammation of the flexor digitorum tendon, often associated with the Kanavel signs: (i) finger held in slight flexion, (ii) fusiform swelling, (iii) tenderness along the flexor tendon sheath, and (iv) pain with passive extension of the digit.

JT: D-2-ヒドロキシグルタル酸尿
DEF: An increased concentration of 2-hydroxyglutaric acid in the urine.
An altered ability of any enzyme or their cofactors to act as catalysts. This term includes changes due to altered levels of an enzyme.
Reduced motility through the sphincter of Oddi, resulting in impedance of bile and pancreatic juice flow from the common bile duct into the duodenum.

JT: 慢性呼吸性アシドーシス
DEF: Longstanding impairment in ventilation such that the partial pressure of carbon dioxide (PaCO2) is elevated above the upper limit of the reference range (more than 45 mm Hg), with a normal or near-normal pH secondary to renal compensation and an elevated serum bicarbonate levels (more than30 mEq/L).
The presence of normal overall immunoglobulin levels with deficiency of specific immunoglobulins directed against a specific antigen or microorganism.

A separation of the layers within the wall of the descending aorta. Tears in the intimal layer result in the propagation of dissection (proximally or distally) secondary to blood entering the intima-media space.
An abnormal concentration of chloride in the urine.
Presence of a many diverticula (sac or pouch) in the wall of the urinary bladder.
A type of chronic kidney disease with normal or increased glomerular filtration rate (GFR at least 90 mL/min/1.73 m2).
A type of chronic kidney disease with mildly reduced glomerular filtration rate (GFR 60-89 mL/min/1.73 m2).
A type of chronic kidney disease with moderately reduced glomerular filtration rate (GFR 30-59 mL/min/1.73 m2).
A type of chronic kidney disease with severely reduced glomerular filtration rate (GFR 15-29 mL/min/1.73 m2).
An anomalous build up of copper (Cu) in the brain.
A darker than expected T2 signal on magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the basal ganglia. This term refers to a diffuse hypointensity affecting all of the basal ganglia.
A glial tumor of the retinal nerve fiber layer arising from a retinal astrocyte.
Hearing loss that occurs acutely and resolves completely.

An elevation in the ratio of the diameter of the cup of the optic disc to the total diameter of the disc. The optic disc has an orange-pink rim with a pale centre (the cup) that does not contain neuroretinal tissue. An increase in this ratio therefore may indicate a decrease in the quantity of healthy neuroretinal cells.
Increased bulk of tissue alongside the nose. The fullness can be caused by both bony and soft tissues.
Underdevelopment of the breast on one side only.
A type of cardiomyopathy characterized anatomically by deep trabeculations in the ventricular wall, which define recesses communicating with the main ventricular chamber.
Decreased strength of the vocal fold on both sides.
The localization with respect to the side of the body of the specified phenotypic abnormality.

Epilepsia partialis continua (also called Kojevnikov's or Kozhevnikov's epilepsia) is a type of focal motor status epilepticus characterized by repeated stereotyped simple motor manifestations such as jerks, typically of a limb or the face, recurring every few seconds or minutes for extended periods (days or years).

Abnormal small intestinal contractions, such as spasms and intestinal paralysis related to the loss of the ability of the gut to coordinate muscular activity because of endogenous or exogenous causes.
A problem occurring during any phase of the female sexual response cycle that prevents the individual from experiencing satisfaction from the sexual activity

ET: Absent epiphysis of the distal phalanx of the 2nd toe
Ivory epiphysis of the distal phalanx of the 2nd toe
Absent epiphysis of the middle phalanx of the 2nd toe
Ivory epiphysis of the middle phalanx of the 2nd toe
Absent epiphysis of the proximal phalanx of the 2nd toe
Ivory epiphysis of the proximal phalanx of the 2nd toe
Absent epiphysis of the distal phalanx of the 3rd toe
Ivory epiphysis of the distal phalanx of the 3rd toe
Absent epiphysis of the middle phalanx of the 3rd toe
Ivory epiphysis of the middle phalanx of the 3rd toe
Absent epiphysis of the proximal phalanx of the 3rd toe
Ivory epiphysis of the proximal phalanx of the 3rd toe
Absent epiphysis of the distal phalanx of the 4th toe
Ivory epiphysis of the distal phalanx of the 4th toe
Absent epiphysis of the middle phalanx of the 4th toe
Ivory epiphysis of the middle phalanx of the 4th toe
Absent epiphysis of the proximal phalanx of the 4th toe
Ivory epiphysis of the proximal phalanx of the 4th toe
Absent epiphysis of the distal phalanx of the 5th toe
Ivory epiphysis of the distal phalanx of the 5th toe
Absent epiphysis of the middle phalanx of the 5th toe
Ivory epiphysis of the middle phalanx of the 5th toe
Absent epiphysis of the proximal phalanx of the 5th toe
Ivory epiphysis of the proximal phalanx of the 5th toe

DEF: The carpus consists of the scaphoid, lunate, triquetal, pisiform, captitate, hamate, trapezoid, and trapezium bones. The tarsus consists of the talus, calcaneus, navicular, cuboid, cuneiform, and navicular bones. This term applies if there is any fusion among the bones of the carpus or tarsus.
The presence of reduced conduction velocity of motor nerves on electromyography.
The presence of spontaneous bursts of rapidly firing potentials that recur at regular intervals of 2-10 per second and are unaffected by voluntary effort. This is an electromyographic (EMG) finding.
Immunological states where the immune system produces harmful responses upon reexposure to sensitising antigens.
Developmental hypoplasia of the phalanx of third toe.
Developmental hypoplasia of one or more phalanx of fourth toe.
Developmental hypoplasia of one or more phalanx of little toe.

ET: Aplasia of the distal phalanx of the 4th toe
Aplasia of the distal phalanx of the 5th toe
Aplasia of the proximal phalanx of the 4th toe
Aplasia of the proximal phalanx of the 5th toe
Curved middle phalanx of the 3rd toe
DEF: A deviation from the normal straight form of the middle phalanx of the third toe.

ET: Curved middle phalanx of the 4th toe
DEF: A deviation from the normal straight form of the middle phalanx of the fourth toe.

ET: Curved middle phalanx of the 5th toe
DEF: A deviation from the normal straight form of the middle phalanx of the fifth toe.

ET: Curved proximal phalanx of the 3rd toe
DEF: A deviation from the normal straight form of the proximal phalanx of the third toe.

ET: Curved proximal phalanx of the 4th toe
DEF: A deviation from the normal straight form of the proximal phalanx of the fourth toe.

ET: Curved proximal phalanx of the 5th toe
DEF: A deviation from the normal straight form of the proximal phalanx of the fifth toe.

ET: Curved distal phalanx of the 3rd toe
DEF: A deviation from the normal straight form of the distal phalanx of the third toe.

ET: Curved distal phalanx of the 4th toe
DEF: A deviation from the normal straight form of the distal phalanx of the fourth toe.

ET: Curved distal phalanx of the 5th toe
DEF: A deviation from the normal straight form of the distal phalanx of the fifth toe.

ET: Triangular shaped distal phalanx of the 5th toe

DEF: A fibrous cardiac diverticulum refers to an aneurysm and usually appears as an isolated congenital anomaly.
Inflammation of the urinary bladder.
Failure to close of the chest and abdominal wall likely caused by the failure of the ventral wall to close during week 4 of development.

JT: 先天性胸腹臓器ヘルニア(セロソミア)
DEF: Congenital protrusion of the abdominal or thoracic viscera, usually with a defect of the sternum and ribs as well as of the abdominal walls.
An abnormality of the pia mater.
An abnormality of the microglial cells. They are also known as brain-resident macrophages or hortega cells.
Vitamin K is a fat-soluble vitamin with a role in promoting the coagulation cascade.
Absence or underdevelopment of the eyebrow.
An abnormality of emotional behaviour.
An elevation in bone density in one or more phalanges of the second toe. Sclerosis is normally detected on a radiograph as an area of increased opacity.
An elevation in bone density in one or more phalanges of the third toe. Sclerosis is normally detected on a radiograph as an area of increased opacity.
An elevation in bone density in one or more phalanges of the fourth toe. Sclerosis is normally detected on a radiograph as an area of increased opacity.
An elevation in bone density in one or more phalanges of the fifth toe. Sclerosis is normally detected on a radiograph as an area of increased opacity.

JT: 中手骨骨端ブラケット

DEF: Shortening of a leg affecting only one side.
A facial appearance characterized by a permanently or nearly permanently opened mouth, in which the upper lip is tented in a way that the opened mouth has the appearance of a triangle.
An increased lymphocyte count in the cerebrospinal fluid.
An abnormality of a buccal mucosa.
Any structural abnormality of a facial artery, one of the branches of the external carotid artery.
An abnormality of an ethmoid sinus.
Any structural anomaly of a lingual nerve.
Decreased functionality of the male gonad, i.e., of the testis, with reduced spermatogenesis or testosterone synthesis.
An abnormality of the clitoris.

JT: 性別不明の外性器,女性
DEF: Ambiguous genitalia in an individual with XX genetic gender.
Blockage of urine flow from the renal pelvis to the proximal ureter.
The presence of multiple cysts in both kidneys.
The presence of a gonadoblastoma of the ovary.
An abnormality of head and neck.

Hard-palate submucous clefts are characterized by bony defects in the midline of the bony palate that are covered by the mucous membrane of the roof of the mouth. It may be possible to detect a submucous cleft hard palate upon palpation as a notch in the bony palate.

Increased thickness of the lower lip, leading to a prominent appearance of the lower lip. The height of the vermilion of the lower lip in the midline is more than 2 SD above the mean. Alternatively, an apparently increased height of the vermilion of the lower lip in the frontal view (subjective).
An abnormality of the lingual frenulum, that is of the small fold of mucous membrane that attaches the tongue to the floor of the mouth, or the presence of accessory frenula in the oral cavity.

Height of the vermilion of the upper lip in the midline more than 2 SD above the mean. Alternatively, an apparently increased height of the vermilion of the upper lip in the frontal view (subjective).

An abnormal configuration of the lower lip such that it is turned outward i.e., everted, with the Inner aspect of the lower lip vermilion (normally opposing the teeth) being visible in a frontal view.
Any abnormality of the size of the skull.

Infants normally have two fontanels at birth, the diamond-shaped anterior fontanelle at the junction of the coronal and sagittal sutures, and the posterior fontanelle at the intersection of the occipital and parietal bones. The posterior fontanelle usually closes by the 8th week of life, and the anterior fontanel closes by the 18th month of life on average. This term applies if there is delay of closure of the fontanelles beyond the normal age.
Any abnormality of the mandible, the bone of the lower jaw.
An abnormality of the philtrum.
An anomaly of the forehead.
Telangiectasia of the nasal mucosa.
Telangiectasia of the nasal mucosa.

A thickening of the skin thickness in the posterior aspect of the fetal neck. A nuchal fold measurement is obtained in a transverse section of the fetal head at the level of the cavum septum pellucidum and thalami, angled posteriorly to include the cerebellum. The measurement is taken from the outer edge of the occiput bone to the outer skin limit directly in the midline. A measurement 6 mm or more is considered significant between 18 and 24 weeks and a measurement of 5 mm or more is considered significant at 16 to 18 weeks (PMID:16100637).
An abnormality in voluntary or involuntary eye movements or their control.

JT: 緩徐なサッカード性眼球運動
DEF: An abnormally slow velocity of the saccadic eye movements.
The presence of small (ca. 0.5-1.0 mm) dilated blood vessels near the surface of the mucous membranes of the conjunctiva.
An anomaly in the ability to discriminate between or recognize colors.

Retinal dystrophy is an abnormality of the retina associated with a hereditary process. Retinal dystrophies are defined by their predominantly monogenic inheritance and they are frequently associated with loss or dysfunction of photoreceptor cells as a primary or secondary event.
The palpebral fissure inclination is more than two standard deviations above the mean for age (objective); or, the inclination of the palpebral fissure is greater than typical for age.
An anomaly in the placement or shape of the hairline (trichion) on the forehead, that is, the border between skin on the forehead that has head hair and that does not.
The presence of an increased number of twists and turns of the retinal artery.
An anomaly of visually evoked potentials (VEP), which are electrical potentials, initiated by brief visual stimuli, which are recorded from the scalp overlying the visual cortex.
A developmental dysplasia of the dental enamel.

ET: Impaired ability to form peer relationships

DEF: Difficulty in social interactions related to an impairment of characteristics such as eye contact, smiling, appropriate facial expressions, and body postures and characterized by difficulty in forming peer relationships and forming friendships.

JT: 不安(褐色細胞腫を伴う)
DEF: Recurrent attacks of severe anxiety, whose occurence is not restricted to any particular situation or set of circumstances and is therefore unpredictable.
Peripheral neuropathy affecting the sensory nerves.
An anomaly of the adnexa, uterus, and vagina (in female) or seminal tract and prostate (in male).
Insufficient production of growth hormone, which is produced by the anterior pituitary gland. Growth hormone is a major participant in control of growth and metabolism.
A condition caused by a deficiency of parathyroid hormone characterized by hypocalcemia and hyperphosphatemia.
Excessive production of parathyroid hormone (PTH) by the parathyroid glands.

Acromegaly is a condition resulting from overproduction of growth hormone by the pituitary gland in persons with closed epiphyses, and consists chiefly in the enlargement of the distal parts of the body. The circumference of the skull increases, the nose becomes broad, the tongue becomes enlarged, the facial features become coarsened, the mandible grows excessively, and the teeth become separated. The fingers and toes grow chiefly in thickness.
An increased level of renin in the blood.
Overproduction of the mineralocorticoid aldosterone by the adrenal cortex.

The presence of abnormally increased levels of prolactin in the blood. Prolactin is a peptide hormone produced by the anterior pituitary gland that plays a role in breast development and lactation during pregnancy.

A pituitary functional deficit affecting all the anterior pituitary hormones (growth hormone, thyroid-stimulating hormone, follicle-stimulating hormone, luteinizing hormone, adrenocorticotropic hormone, and prolactin).
Any abnormality of the clavicles (collar bones).
Wide, concave anterior rib end.
Abnormally flat configuration of the glenoid fossa, also known as the glenoid cavity, which is the articular surface of the scapula that articulates with the head of the humerus.

Abnormally increased size of the costochondral junctions, which are located between the distal part of the ribs and the costal cartilages, which are bars of hyaline cartilage that connect the ribs to the sternum.
Wide, concave posterior rib end.
Hyperkeratosis affecting the palm of the hand and the sole of the foot.
Hemangioma, a benign tumor of the vascular endothelial cells with small endothelial spaces, occurring in the face.
A condition in which superficial veins (i.e., veins just under the skin) are more conspicuous or noticable than normal.
Absence of the distal interphalangeal flexion creases of the fingers.
Severe loss of visual acuity within hours or days. This is characteristic of Leber hereditary optic neuropathy.
Any abnormality of the size or morphology of the cornea.
An abnormality of the cornea that is characterized by opacity of one or parts of the cornea.
Spontaneous detachment (amputation) of an appendage from the body.
With the hand relaxed and the thumb in the plane of the palm, the axis of the thumb forms an angle of at least 90 degrees with the long axis of the hand.
A generalized disorder of peripheral nerves.

Absence of the corpus callosum as a result of the failure of the corpus callosum to develop, which can be the result of a failure in any one of the multiple steps of callosal development including cellular proliferation and migration, axonal growth or glial patterning at the midline.

Characteristic neurologic anomaly resulting form degeneration of dopamine-generating cells in the substantia nigra, a region of the midbrain, characterized clinically by shaking, rigidity, slowness of movement and difficulty with walking and gait.
A form of hydrocephalus in which there is no visible obstruction to the flow of the cerebrospinal fluid between the ventricles and subarachnoid space.

ET: Partial agenesis of the corpus callosum
DEF: A partial failure of the development of the corpus callosum.
Increase in amplitude of a long-loop response upon somatosensory evoked potential testing, representing an electrically evoked myoclonic response.

A mode of inheritance that is observed for traits related to a gene encoded on the mitochondrial genome. Because the mitochondrial genome is essentially always maternally inherited, a mitochondrial condition can only be transmitted by females, although the condition can affect both sexes. The proportion of mutant mitochondria can vary (heteroplasmy).
A tendency to hold the chin elevated by about 20 to 30 degrees to compensate for a limitation of eye movement.
Congenital non-progressive ophthalmoplegia with multiple extraocular muscle restrictions. Typically, there is ptosis and variable degrees of restriction of horizontal and vertical eye movements.
A morphological anomaly of the rib cage.

Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) is defined by the presence of increased ventricular wall thickness or mass in the absence of loading conditions (hypertension, valve disease) sufficient to cause the observed abnormality.

A type of subvalvular aortic stenosis resulting from thickening of the musculature of the interventricular septum, which results in obstruction to blood flow through the left-ventricular outflow tract.
A type of supraventricular tachycardia in which the atria are the principal site of electrophysiologic disturbance.
Double outlet right ventricle (DORV) is a type of ventriculoarterial connection in which both great vessels arise entirely or predominantly from the right ventricle.
An abnormality of the pancreas.
A contracture of the Achilles tendon.
Toenail changes apart from changes of the color of the toenail (nail dyschromia) that involve partial or complete disruption of the various keratinous layers of the nail plate.
Deeply placed nails.
Short distance from the end of the toe to the most distal interphalangeal crease or distal interphalangeal joint flexion point, i.e., abnormally short distal phalanx of toe.
Bending or curvature of a fifth toe in the tibial direction (i.e., towards the big toe).
An abnormality of platelets.
Any structural abnormality of erythrocytes (red-blood cells).

JT: 自己免疫性溶血性貧血
DEF: An autoimmune form of hemolytic anemia.
An elevation above the normal ratio of the volume of red blood cells to the total volume of blood.
Thrombocytopenia with congenital onset.
Any structural abnormality or abnormal count of granulocytes.

Metabolic acidosis (MA) is characterized by a fall in blood pH due to a reduction of serum bicarbonate concentration. This can occur as a result of either the accumulation of acids (high anion gap MA) or the loss of bicarbonate from the gastrointestinal tract or the kidney (hyperchloremic MA). By definition, MA is not due to a respirary cause.

JT: びまん性メサンギウム硬化症
DEF: Diffuse sclerosis of the mesangium, as manifestated by diffuse mesangial matrix expansion.

JT: 自己免疫性血小板減少
DEF: The presence of thrombocytopenia in combination with detection of antiplatelet antibodies.

ET: Morphological abnormality of the central nervous system
DEF: A structural abnormality of the central nervous system.
An abnormality of the glabella.
Any structural abnormality of the telencephalon, which is also known as the cerebrum.
Periodic spells of incoordination and imbalance, that is, episodes of ataxia typically lasting from 10 minutes to several hours or days.\n
The presence of calcium deposition affecting one or more structures of the basal ganglia.
An increased concentration of homocystine in the blood.
Individuals with Pseudobulbar signs often also demonstrate abnormal behavioral symptoms such as inappropriate emotional outbursts of uncontrolled laughter or weeping etc.
An increased susceptibility to respiratory infections as manifested by a history of recurrent respiratory infections.
Hemorrhage affecting the gastrointestinal tract.
Abnormal loss of protein from the digestive tract related to excessive leakage of plasma proteins into the lumen of the gastrointestinal tract.
An abnormality of the duodenum, i.e., the first section of the small intestine.
An abnormality resulting from a lack of intestinal ganglion cells (i.e., an aganglionic section of bowel) that results in bowel obstruction with enlargement of the colon.
An exaggerated startle reaction in response to a sudden unexpected visual or acoustic stimulus, or a quick movement near the face.

ET: Degeneration of the lateral corticospinal tracts
DEF: Deterioration of the tissues of the lateral corticospinal tracts.
Underdevelopment of the brainstem.
An abnormal appearance of the midbrain in axial magnetic resonance imaging in which the elongated superior cerebellar peduncles give the midbrain an appearance reminiscent of a molar or wisdom tooth.

ET: Eye of the tiger anomaly of globus pallidus
DEF: The presence, on T2-weighted magnetic resonance imaging, of markedly low signal intensity if the globus pallidus that surrounds a central region of high signal intensity in the anteromedial globus pallidus, producing an eye-of-the-tiger appearance.

A functional anomaly of the upper motor neuron. The upper motor neurons are neurons of the primary motor cortex which project to the brainstem and spinal chord via the corticonuclear, corticobulbar and corticospinal (pyramidal) tracts. They are involved in control of voluntary movements. Dysfunction leads to weakness, impairment of fine motor movements, spasticity, hyperreflexia and abnormal pyramidal signs.
A type of holoprosencephaly in which the left and right frontal and parietal lobes are fused and the interhemispheric fissure is only present posteriorly.

ET: Abnormality of the periventricular white matter

DEF: An abnormality of the gyri (i.e., the ridges) of the cerebral cortex of the brain.

ET: Patchy demyelination of subcortical white matter
DEF: Patchy loss of myelin from nerve fibers in the central nervous system.

ET: obsolete Malformation of the heart and great vessels

DEF: Angiectasia of lymph vessels (i.e., dilatation of lymphatic vessels) in the intestines.
Reduced intensity of muscle tendon reflexes in the lower limbs. Reflexes are elicited by stretching the tendon of a muscle, e.g., by tapping.

ET: Paresis of extensor muscles of the big toe

DEF: The presence of fibrosis of that part of the liver with congenital onset.
A type of hepatic necrosis that is concentrated around the necrosis of hepatocytes localized around the intrahepatic branch of portal vein.
Inflammation of a superficial vein associated with venous thrombosis (blood clot formation within the vein).

ET: Abnormality of pelvic girdle bone morphology
DEF: An abnormality of the bony pelvic girdle, which is a ring of bones connecting the vertebral column to the femurs.
Trilobar skull configuration when viewed from the front or behind.
Abnormality of the calvaria, which is the roof of the skull formed by the frontal bone, parietal bones, and occipital bone.
Unusual prominence of the median palatal raphe, which is the ridge formed by the fusion of the two plates of the skull that form the hard palate.
Increased depth of the median tongue furrow.
A morphological abnormality of the mouth in which the angle of the mouth is downturned. The oral commissures are positioned inferior to the midline labial fissure.
An increased susceptibility to abscess formation, as manifested by a medical history of recurrent abscesses.
Underdevelopment of frontal sinus.
Increased susceptibility to infections with Escherichia coli, as manifested by recurrent episodes of infection with this agent.
A thickened white patch on the oral mucosa that cannot be rubbed off.
A decreased rate of skeletal maturation. Delayed skeletal maturation can be diagnosed on the basis of an estimation of the bone age from radiographs of specific bones in the human body.
An increased susceptibility to lower respiratory tract infections as manifested by a history of recurrent lower respiratory tract infections.

An increased susceptibility to upper respiratory tract infections as manifested by a history of recurrent upper respiratory tract infections (running ears - otitis, sinusitis, pharyngitis, tonsillitis).
An anomaly of the rhythm or depth of breathing.

Disseminated multifocal hemangiomatous or lymphangiomatous lesions of the skeleton. The lesions are lytic, well-defined, round or oval lesions within the medullary cavity, and they have an intact cortex, and manifest variable peripheral sclerosis and may exhibit endosteal scalloping.

Disseminated multifocal hemangiomatous or lymphangiomatous lesions of the skeleton. The lesions are lytic, well-defined, round or oval lesions within the medullary cavity, and they have an intact cortex, and manifest variable peripheral sclerosis and may exhibit endosteal scalloping.
Abnormal function of a sphincter of the urinary bladder.
Increased susceptibility to fungal infections, as manifested by multiple episodes of fungal infection.
The presence of a medullary carcinoma of the thyroid gland.

A condition characterized by obstruction of the airway and by pauses in breathing during sleep occurring many times during the night. Obstructive sleep apnea is related to a relaxation of muscle tone (which normally occurs during sleep) leading to partial collapse of the soft tissues in the airway with resultant obstruction of the air flow.
A tumor that develops in the retrostyloid compartment of the parapharyngeal space, arising from an island of paraganglion tissue derived from the neural crest that is located on the vagus nerve.
The presence of a papillary adenocarcinoma of the thyroid gland.
Increased concentration of methylmalonic acid in the blood.
An abnormally decreased magnesium concentration in the blood.
An abnormally increased magnesium concentration in the blood.
Increased concentration of protein in the cerebrospinal fluid.

JT: アルデヒド・オキシダーゼ欠乏症
DEF: A reduction in aldehyde oxidase level.
Congenital absence of a part of the vermis of cerebellum.
An abnormality of the shoulder, which is defined as the structures surrounding the shoulder joint where the humerus attaches to the scapula.
An increased concentration of potassium(1+) in the urine.
An increased tendency to fractures of the long bones (Mainly, the femur, tibia, fibula, humerus, radius, and ulna).
An abnormal buildup of lactic acid in the body, leading to acidification of the blood and other bodily fluids.
An abnormality of the myelination of motor and sensory peripheral nerves. These are axons for motor nerves and dendrites for sensory nerves in the strict anatomic sense.
An abnormality of the conduction of electrical impulses by peripheral (motor or sensory) nerves. This finding is elicited by a nerve conduction study (NCS).
A increased concentration of serotonin in the blood.

JT: アデノシルコバラミンの減少
DEF: Decreased concentration of adenosylcobalamin. Adenosylcobalamin is one of the active forms of vitamin B12.
A type of chromosomal aberration characterised by reduced resistance of chromosomes to change or deterioration.
A decreased concentration of carnitine in the blood.
An increased concentration of methionine in the blood.
Underdevelopment of part or all of the external reproductive organs.
An increased amount of creatinine in the blood.

JT: 新生児高ビリルビン血症
DEF: A type of hyperbilirubinemia with neonatal onset.

JT: ズダン好性ロイコジストロフィー

DEF: An abnormality of the hip bone.
Abnormal raised concentration of ferritin, a ubiquitous intracellular protein that stores iron, in the blood.
An increased concentration of cystathionine in the blood.
Generalized weakness or decreased strength of the muscles, affecting both distal and proximal musculature.
Weakness of the limb-girdle muscles (also known as the pelvic and shoulder girdles), that is, lack of strength of the muscles around the shoulders and the pelvis.
An decreased level of renin in the blood.
An increased concentration of cystine within cells. This finding can be demonstrated on leukocytes, but is not specific to blood cells.

Repeated episodes of segmental demyelination and remyelination lead to the accumulation of supernumerary Schwann cells around axons, which is referred to as onion bulb formation. This finding affects peripheral nerves.

ET: Abnormal synaptic transmission at the neuromuscular junction
DEF: Any abnormality of the neuromuscular junction, which is the synapse between the motor end plate of a motor neuron and the skeletal muscle fibers.
An abnormal prolongation of the miniature endplate potentials, i.e. the postsynaptic response to transmitter released from an individual vesicle at the neuromuscular junction.
Absence of the Achilles reflex (also known as the ankle jerk reflex), which can normally be elicited by tapping the tendon is tapped while the foot is dorsiflexed.
A heterogeneous increase in IgM immunoglobulins characterized by a diffuse band on serum electrophoresis.
Defective structure and function of myelin sheaths. Dysmyelination is distinguished from demyleination where there is destruction or damage of previously normal myelination.
An abnormally increased diphosphate(4-) concentration in the urine. Diphosphate(4-), as ester with two phosphate groups, is also known as pyrophosphate.
A kind of short stature in which different regions of the body are shortened to a comparable extent.
A type of disproportionate short stature characterized by a short trunk but a average-sized limbs.
An increased amount of 3-methylglutaconic acid in the urine.
An increased concentration of pyruvate in the blood.
Atrophy (wasting) affecting primary type 2 muscle fibers. This feature in general can only be observed on muscle biopsy.
A decreased concentration of citrulline in the blood.
Lack of urothione (the urinary metabolite of molybdenum cofactor) in the urine.
If positive, the ferric chloride test indicates an increased concentration of phenols in the urine or blood.
The presence of circulating autoantibodies to phospholipids.
Increased concentration of trimethylamine in the urine.
Hypertrophy (increase in size) of muscle cells (as opposed to hyperplasia, which refers to an increase in the number of muscle cells).
Myofibrillar structural changes characterized by abnormal intracellular accumulation of the intermediate filament desmin and other proteins.
Excessive production of saliva.
Developmental hypoplasia (shortening) of middle phalanx of toe.

ET: Wide epiphyseal plates of the upper limbs
Cortical diaphyseal thickening of the upper limbs

DEF: Ossification of the humeral epiphysis at an earlier age than normal.
A delay in the process of formation and maturation of the humeral epiphysis.
Increased width of the humeral epiphyseal growth plate.

DEF: Flaring (increase of width with a splayed appearance) of the humeral metaphysis.

DEF: Abnormally reduced levels of aldosterone.
Abnormality of an amino acid metabolic process.
A reduction of bone mineral density, that is, of the amount of matter per cubic centimeter of bones.
Any deviation from the normal circulation of leucine in the blood circulation.
Repeated episodes of inflammation of a vein associated with venous thrombosis (blood clot formation within the vein).
A combined immunodeficiency primary immune deficiency that is characterized by a more severe defect in both the T- and B-lymphocyte systems.
A kind of craniosynostosis affecting the lambdoidal suture.
An abnormally increased width of the cranial fontanelles and sutures.
Anterior tongue-like protrusions of the vertebral bodies.
A lack of ossification of the vertebral bodies.
Increased size of the vertebral pedicle.
A reduced degree of voluntary and involuntary facial movements involved in responded to others or expressing emotions.
Narrow, paramedian longitudinal depressions in the plantar skin of the forefoot.

A developmental anomaly in which the kidneys are fused and localized on the same side of the midline. This anomaly is thought to result from disruption of the normal embryologic migration of the kidneys.

A developmental anomaly in which the kidneys are fused and localized on the same side of the midline. This anomaly is thought to result from disruption of the normal embryologic migration of the kidneys.
Complete and diffuse scarring of glomerulus.

Myxomatous mitral valve is defined as the presence of excess leaflet tissue and leaflet thickening greater than 5 mm, resulting in a prolapse greater than 2 mm into the left atrium on parasternal long axis view.
Presence of multiple polyps in the duodenum.
The presence of multiple areas of atresia affecting the small intestine.

DEF: Recurrent infection of the gastrointestinal tract.
A form of hemolytic anemia with congenital onset.
Repeated episodes of obstruction of blood flow due to an embolus, i.e., blood clot that has traveled from its point of origin within the blood stream.
A type of anemia characterized by an abnormally low concentration of hemoglobin in the erythrocytes and lower than normal size of the erythrocytes.

Decreased activity of coagulation factor XII. Factor XII (fXII) is part of the intrinsic coagulation pathway and binds to exposed collagen at site of vessel wall injury, activated by high-MW kininogen and kallikrein, thereby initiating the coagulation cascade.

Decreased activity of coagulation factor XII. Factor XII (fXII) is part of the intrinsic coagulation pathway and binds to exposed collagen at site of vessel wall injury, activated by high-MW kininogen and kallikrein, thereby initiating the coagulation cascade.
A type of hemolytic anemia in which the Coombs test is positive.
A type of anemia characterized by an normal concentration of hemoglobin in the erythrocytes and lower than normal size of the erythrocytes.
A type of anemia characterized by abnormally large erythrocytes with abnormally high amounts of haemoglobin.
A type of sideroblastic anemia that is not responsive to treatment.
Lack of strength of the intercostal muscles, i.e., of the muscle groups running along the ribs that create and move the chest wall.
Increased susceptibility to respiratory infections in early life, as manifested by recurrent episodes of respiratory infections.

JT: 代謝性アシドーシスエピソード
DEF: Repeated transient episodes of metabolic acidosis, that is, of the buildup of acid or depletion of base due to accumulation of metabolic acids.
An intermittent (discontinuous) form of lactic acidemia.
An abnormal widening of the diameter of the pulmonary artery.
Arteriosclerosis (increased thickness, increased stiffness, loss of elasticity) of the small arteries of the brain.

A separation of the layers within the wall of the ascending aorta. Tears in the intimal layer result in the propagation of dissection (proximally or distally) secondary to blood entering the intima-media space.

Atherosclerosis which occurs in a person with certain risk factors (e.g., SLE, diabetes, smoking, hypertension, hypercholesterolaemia, family history of early heart disease) at an earlier age than would occur in another person without those risk factors.
A separation (dissection) of the layers of the extracranial portion of the internal carotid artery wall.

Narrowing of peripheral arteries with reduction of blood flow to the limbs. This feature may be quantified as an ankle-brachial index of less than 0.9, and may be manifested clinically as claudication.

Underdevelopment of the pulmonary artery.

Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy with an symmetrical and concentric pattern of hypertrophy.
Subvalvular stenosis is caused by a diaphragm-like membrane. The stenosis is clinically manifested like any other form of aortic stenosis but is often associated with some aortic insufficiency.
An abnormal dilatation of lymph vessels in the pericardium.

A sensation of stiffness in the joints that occurs following waking up in the morning.
Absence of gastric intrinsic factor, which is normally produced by the parietal cells of the stomach, and is required for the absorption of vitamin B12.

DEF: Peripheral arterial stenosis with onset before the age of 50 years.

An arterial lesion that is characterized by either intimal fibroplasia, with neointimal lesions of cells and matrix deposition, or medial fibroplasia, in which there is loss of smooth muscle cells and increased deposition of collagen and proteoglycans in the medial layer.
A degree of wrinkling of the facial skin that is more than expected for the age of the individual, leading to a prematurely aged appearance.
A general term referring to a defect in immunity resulting from impaired antibody production.
Recurrent infections by Neisseria meningitidis (one of the most common causes of bacterial meningitis), which is also known as meningococcus.
A reduced ability of a B cell to become activated, i.e., the change in morphology and behavior of

Increased susceptibility to opportunistic infections, as manifested by recurrent episodes of infection by opportunistic agents, i.e., by microorganisms that do not usually cause disease in a healthy host, but are able to infect a host with a compromised immune system.
An abnormal reduction of the cell motility of neutrophils.
Decreased or impaired activation of T cells in response to a mitogen, cytokine, chemokine, cellular ligand, or an antigen for which it is specific.
An abnormality of the functioning of any aspect of the alternative complement pathway.
Hypoplasia of the maxillozygomatic complex.
Abnormally increased density of craniofacial bone tissue.
Vertical bony ridge positioned in the midline of the forehead.
A transient reduction in the number of erythroblasts in the circulation.
A reduced number of hematopoietic cells present in the bone marrow relative to marrow fat.
A form of poikilocytosis in which the abnormally shaped erythrocytes have notches that results in projections that look like horns.
Proliferation (excess production) of hemopoietically active tissue or of tissue which has embryonic hemopoietic potential.
A form of neutropenia with congenital onset.

A chronic lymphocytic/lymphatic/lymphoblastic leukemia (CLL) is a neoplastic disease characterized by proliferation and accumulation (blood, marrow and lymphoid organs) of morphologically mature but immunologically dysfunctional lymphocytes. A CLL is always a B-cell lymphocytic leukemia as there are no reports of cases of T-cell lymphocytic leukemias.

ET: Abnormality of bone marrow cell morphology
DEF: An anomaly of the form or number of cells in the bone marrow.
A lack of differentiation between renal cortex and medulla on diagnostic imaging.

A progressive detrimental connective tissue deposition (fibrosis) on the kidney parenchyma involving the tubules and interstitial tissue of the kidney. Tubulointerstitial injury in the kidney is complex, involving a number of independent and overlapping cellular and molecular pathways, with renal interstitial fibrosis and tubular atrophy (IF/TA) as the final common pathway. However, IF and TA are separable, as shown by the profound TA in renal artery stenosis, which characteristically has little or no fibrosis (or inflammation). For new annotations it is preferable to annotate to the specific HPO terms for Renal interstitial lfibrosis and/or Renal tubular atrophy.
A duplication of the renal pelvis.
DIsruption and breaking up of the basement membrane of the tubules of the kidney.
Loss of all scalp hair with congenital onset.
The ability of the joints of the hand to move beyond their normal range of motion.
A soft tissue continuity in the anteroposterior axis between the second to the fifth fingers that extends distally to at least the level of the proximal interphalangeal joints.
Deposition of calcium salts on both sides of the brain.
Partial dislocation of the head of the radius in the posterior direction.
An abnormally small and flat configuration of the posterior cranial fossa.
A soft tissue continuity in the anteroposterior axis between the toes 2, 3, and 4.

DEF: Abnormally short distal phalanx of toe of all toes.
Bending or curvature of a second toe in the tibial direction (i.e., towards the big toe).
A type of dysharmonic skeletal maturation in which there is a delay in skeletal maturation whose degree differs markedly in different bones.

DEF: Generalized deposition of calcium salts within the brain.
The presence of bone fractures in the prenatal period that are diagnosed at birth or before.

ET: Absent ossification of cervical vertebral bodies
DEF: A lack of bone mineralization of one or more body of cervical vertebra.

An abnormality of corticomedullary differentiation (CMD) on diagnostic imaging such as magnetic resonance imaging, computer tomography, or sonography. CMD is a difference in the visualization of cortex and medulla.

Fusion of the epiphysis and metaphysis of one or more phalanges prior to the normal age or stage of growth.

ET: Shortening of all proximal phalanges of the fingers
DEF: Congenital hypoplasia of proximal phalanx of finger or all fingers.

A central Y-shaped metacarpal is the result of a partial fusion of two central metacarpals (i.e., metacarpals 2-4) of the hand, with the two arms of the Y pointing in the distal direction. Central Y-shaped metacarpals may be seen as a result of a central polydactyly with partial fusion of the duplicated metacarpal.

Agenesis of one or more central incisors, i.e., of lower secondary incisor, lower primary incisor, upper secondary incisor, or of upper central primary incisor.
The presence of discolored lateral incisors.
Developmental hypoplasia of the dental enamel.
Developmental hypoplasia of the dental enamel.
Prolonged bleeding post dental extraction sufficient to require medical intervention.
Increased space between the primary teeth. Note this phenotype should be distinguished from increased space due purely to microdontia.
Underdevelopment of the alveolar process (also known as alveolar bone).

Underdevelopment of the distal epiphysis of the radius.
Overconstriction, or narrowness of the diaphysis and metaphysis of long bones.
The presence of asymmetric developmental dysplasia of the radius.
The presence of asymmetric developmental dysplasia of the radius.

Slipped capital femoral epiphysis is defined as a posterior and inferior slippage of the proximal epiphysis of the femur onto the metaphysis (femoral neck), occurring through the physeal plate during the early adolescent growth spurt.
An anomaly of the femoral metaphysis.
Accumulation of amorphous PAS-positive material in the space betweem alveolar macrophages, sometimes as condensed form (oval bodies) are typically found in alveolar proteinosis.
A lymphocyte-predominant infiltration of the lungs characterized by bibasilar pulmonary infiltrates with dense interstitial accumulations of lymphocytes and plasma cells.

Neonatal jaundice refers to a yellowing of the skin and other tissues of a newborn infant as a result of increased concentrations of bilirubin in the blood. Neonatal jaundice affects over half of all newborns to some extent in the first week of life. Prolonged neonatal jaundice is said to be present if the jaundice persists for longer than 14 days in term infants and 21 days in preterm infants.
Repeated occurrences of acute noninflammatory encephalopathy and fatty degenerative liver failure.
Lack of formation and mineralization of the ribs in utero.
Deposition of calcium salts in point-like foci within the anterior portion of one or more ribs.
Breast carcinoma that is bilateral or otherwise multifocal.
Lack of formation of mineralized bony tissue of the sternum.
Underdevelopment of the glenoid fossa, which is the cavity in the lateral part of the scapula which articulates with the head of the humerus.
A form of acute leukemia characterized by excess lympoblasts.
A rare subtype of acute myeloid leukemia evolving from primitive megakaryoblasts.
The presence of a malignant neoplasm of the genital system.
A hemangioblastoma of the cerebellum.

Brain damage related to a lowering of blood glucose below a critical level (around 30 mg/dl), which may lead to confusion, lethargy and delirium followed by seizures and coma. Prolonged hypoglycemia may lead to irreversible brain damage.

An abnormality of the auditory evoked potentials, which are used to trace the signal generated by a sound, from the cochlear nerve, through the lateral lemniscus, to the medial geniculate nucleus, and to the cortex.
A type of holoprosencephaly characterized by the presence of a single ventricle and no separation of the cerebral hemisphere. The single midline ventricle is often greatly enlarged.
A type of gliosis that occurs in the vicinity of injured neurons.
A morphological abnormality of the metencephalon.

Stiffness of the limbs (a condition in which muscles cannot be moved quickly without accompanying pain or spasm) occurring in an asymmetric pattern.
Episodic bouts of involuntary movements with dystonic, choreic, ballistic movements, or a combination thereof. There is no loss of consciousness during the attacks.
A complete lack of the ability to track objects with the ocular smooth pursuit system, a class of rather slow eye movements that minimizes retinal target motion.
Reduced amount of myelin in the nervous system resulting from defective myelinogenesis in the peripheral nervous system.
Atherosclerosis (HP:0002621) of a cerebral artery.

Defective structure and function of myelin sheaths of the white matter of the brain.

Abnormal development (dysgenesis) of the anterior segment of the eye globe. These structures are mainly of mesenchymal origin.

DEF: Pigment migration into the retina in a bone-spicule configuration (resembling the nucleated cells within the lacuna of bone).

An impairment of the ability to track objects with the ocular smooth pursuit system, a class of rather slow eye movements that minimizes retinal target motion.
Mottled (spotted or blotched with different shades) pigmentary abnormality of the macula lutea.
Mottled (spotted or blotched with different shades) pigmentary abnormality of the macula lutea.
The presence of whitish deposits in the conjunctiva resembling salt. May be related to calcinosis.
Nystagmus consisting of horizontal to-and-fro eye movements of equal velocity.

The presence of one or more dendritic corneal epithelial ulcers characterized by a treelike branching linear pattern with feathery edges and terminal bulbs. Herpetiform corneal ulcers can be identified by fluorescein staining.

A supranuclear gaze palsy is an inability to look in a horizontal direction as a result of cerebral impairment. There is a loss of the voluntary aspect of eye movements, but, as the brainstem is still intact, all the reflex conjugate eye movements are normal.
Inability to see well at night or in poor light with onset in adulthood.

A shape created by an acute downward arching of the upper eyelid and upward arching of the lower eyelid, toward the medial canthus, which gives the outline of the palpebral fissures the configuration of an almond. Thus, the maximum distance between the fissures is offset from, and medial to, the center point.
Allergic Conjunctivitis is an allergic inflammation of the conjunctiva.

JT: 先天性両側性眼瞼下垂
網状網膜ジストロフィー
DEF: A type of of patterned retinal dystrophy that shows a reticular pattern of pigmentation.
A form of stapes ankylosis with congenital onset.
A form of stapes ankylosis with congenital onset.

A subtype of retinitis pigmentosa in which, instead of the pathology starting in the mid-periphery like typical retinitis pigmentosa, the disease starts in the near periphery closer to the vascular arcades and tends to spare the far periphery.

JT: 網膜色素性ジストロフィー

DEF: Absence of the anterior chamber of the eye owing to a developmental defect.

ET: obsolete Abnormality of the retinal pigment epithelium

DEF: Delayed maturation and calcification of any of the tarsal bones, seven bones of the foot comprising the calcaneus, talus, cuboid, navicular, and the cuneiform bones.
Bending or curvature of a third toe in the tibial direction (i.e., towards the big toe).
Defective ossification in an irregular pattern of the seven bones of the foot comprising the calcaneus, talus, cuboid, navicular, and the cuneiform bones.

JT: 高アポβリポタンパク血症
DEF: Hyperapobetalipoproteinemia is defined as the combination of a normal low density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol in the face of an increased LDL apolipoprotein B (apoB) protein.

JT: 無症候性高アンモニア血症
DEF: An increased concentration of ammonia in the blood not associated with symptoms such as encephalopathy.

Reduced activity of coagulation factor VII. Factor VII is part of the extrinsic coagulation pathway, which is initiated at the site of injury in response to the release of tissue factor (fIII). Tissue factor and activated factor VII catalyze the activation of factor X.

Reduced activity of coagulation factor VII. Factor VII is part of the extrinsic coagulation pathway, which is initiated at the site of injury in response to the release of tissue factor (fIII). Tissue factor and activated factor VII catalyze the activation of factor X.
The onset of puberty before the age of 9 years in boys.
The onset of puberty before the age of 9 years in boys.

JT: 原発性副甲状腺機能亢進症
DEF: A type of hyperparathyroidism caused by a primary abnormality of the parathyroid glands (e.g., adenoma, carcinoma, hyperplasia). Primary hyperparathyroidism is associated with hyercalcemia.

A reduced level of prolactin in the blood circulation. Prolactin is a protein hormone that is secreted by lactotrophs in the anterior pituitary and that stimulates mammary gland development and milk production.
The presence of lymphangiectasis of the thyroid gland.

JT: 視床下部甲状腺機能低下症
DEF: A type of hypothyroidism that results from a defect in thyrotropin-releasing hormone activity.

JT: 甲状腺機能正常性高サイロキシン血症
DEF: An abnormality of thyroid physiology (HP:0002926) characterized by increased levels of thyroxine without evidence of clinical thyroid disease.

The presence of intracellular inclusion bodies (aggregates of stainable substances, usually proteins) in neutrophils. Cytoplasmic neutrophil inclusions (oval, basophilic) are also known as Doehle bodies.

Abnormal morphology of collagen fibers in cartilage. In cartilage, collagen II, actually a collagen II:IX:XI heterofibril, is by far the most important type of collagen. A number of abnormalities may be appreciated by electron micrography or biochemical investigations, including sparse collagen fibers in the cartilage matrix.

Abnormal morphology of collagen fibers in cartilage. In cartilage, collagen II, actually a collagen II:IX:XI heterofibril, is by far the most important type of collagen. A number of abnormalities may be appreciated by electron micrography or biochemical investigations, including sparse collagen fibers in the cartilage matrix.

An increase in the level of medium chain dicarboxylic acid in the urine.
An anomaly of the toenail.
The presence of misshapen or partially destroyed nail plates, often with accumulation of soft, yellow keratin between the dystrophic nail plate and nail bed, resulting in elevation of the nail plate.
Chronic infection of the nails by Candida species.
A thickening of the stratum corneum, the outer layer of the skin, in the region surrounding the nails.
Any abnormality of the atlas and the axis.
The presence of one or more herniated nucleus pulposus of intervertebral disk.
Agenesis of one or more vertebrae of the cervical vertebral column.
A reduction of the distance between the lower thoracic vertebral pedicles.
A reduction of the distance between thoracolumbar vertebral pedicles.
Cleft lip or palate affecting the midline region of the palate.
Underdevelopment of the helix that either affects the entire helix, or is localized.
A form of sensorineural hearing impairment with onset after the acquisition of speech.

DEF: The presence of a partially duplicated kidney.
The presence of a longitudinal vaginal septum, thereby creating a vaginal duplication.
An abnormality of the prostate.
Abnormally wide morphology of the proximal epiphysis of the femur.

Impaired feeding performance of an infant as manifested by difficulties such as weak and ineffective sucking, brief bursts of sucking, and falling asleep during sucking. There may be difficulties with chewing or maintaining attention.
A type of disproportionate short stature characterized by a short limbs but an average-sized trunk.
Truncal obesity with onset during childhood, defined as between 2 and 10 years of age.
A generalized form of lymphadenopathy.
A generalized form of lymphadenopathy.
Muscular hypotonia (abnormally low muscle tone) manifesting in infancy.
Underdevelopment of the pectoralis major.
An abnormal increase in the amount of intramuscular fat tissue.

The presence of an abnormally increased amount of connective tissue.

Severe hypertrophy (increase in size) of muscle cells.
Muscular hypotonia (abnormally low muscle tone) affecting the musculature of the trunk and with onset in infancy.
Progressive spinal muscular atrophy, i.e., muscular weakness and atrophy related to loss of the motor neurons of the spinal cord and brainstem.
Decreased intensity of the Achilles reflex (also known as the ankle jerk reflex), which can be elicited by tapping the tendon is tapped while the foot is dorsiflexed.

ET: Midline notch of upper alveolar ridge

DEF: Chronic accumulation and overgrowth of the fungus Candida albicans on the mucous membranes of the mouth, generally manifested as associated with creamy white lesions on the tongue or inner cheeks, occasionally spreading to the gums, tonsils, palate or oropharynx.
Degenerative changes of the fat tissue.
A triangular appearance of the epiphyses of the metacarpals. Thess epiphyses are located at the distal end of the metacarpals.
Displacement of the 5th finger from its normal position.
Fragmented appearance of the epiphyses of the metacarpals.
Absence of the epiphyses of the metacarpal bones, which are normally located at the distal ends of the metacarpals.
Displacement of the 4th finger from its normal position.
Displacement of the 3rd finger from its normal position.
Displacement of the 2nd finger from its normal position.
Divergence of the longitudinal axis of the hand at the wrist in a posterior (ulnar) direction (i.e., towards the little finger).

The hairline refers to the outline of hair of the head. An abnormality of the hairline can refer to an unusually low or high border between areas of the scalp with and without hair or to abnormal projections of scalp hair.

A vestibular Schwannoma (also known as acoustic neuroma, acoustic neurinoma, or acoustic neurilemoma) is a benign, usually slow-growing tumor that develops from the VIIIth cranial nerve supplying the inner ear.
Abnormality of the vestibulocochlear nerve, the eighth cranial nerve, which is involved in transmitting sound and equilibrium information from the inner ear to the brain.
Neurofibromas present in a smaller number than usually seen in neurofibromatosis type 1.

ET: Bifid distal phalanx of the thumb
DEF: Partial duplication of the distal phalanx of the thumb. Depending on the severity, the appearance on x-ray can vary from a notched phalanx (the duplicated bone is almost completely fused with the phalanx) to a partially fused appearance of the two bones.

ET: Bifid proximal phalanx of the thumb
DEF: This term applies if the proximal phalanx of the thumb is partially duplicated. Depending on the severity, the appearance on x-ray can vary from a notched phalanx (the duplicated bone is almost completely fused with the phalanx) to a partially fused appearance of the two bones. In contrast to the proximal phalanges of the digits 2-5, the proximal phalanx of the thumb is embryologically equivalent to the middle phalanges of the other digits, whereas the first metacarpal is embryologically of phalangeal origin and as such equivalent to the proximal phalanges of the other digits.
Proximal mislocalization of the thumb.

ET: Curved proximal phalanx of the thumb
DEF: A deviation from the normal straight shape of the proximal phalanx of the thumb.
Fusion of a phalanx of the thumb with another bone.

ET: Triangular shaped proximal phalanx of the thumb
DEF: Triangular shaped proximal phalanx of the thumb.

ET: Curved distal phalanx of the thumb
DEF: A deviation from the normal straight shape of the distal phalanx of the thumb.

ET: Triangular shaped distal phalanx of the thumb
DEF: Triangular shaped distal phalanx of the thumb. A triangular or so called delta shaped phalanx is a typical result after a bracket epiphysis of the affected phalanx.
An abnormal morphology of one or more phalanges of the thumb, with a short and wide phalanx that tapers distally. Bullet-shaped phalanges lack the normal diaphyseal constriction.
Congenital fusion (ankylosis) of the interphalangeal joint of the thumb.

ET: Absent epiphysis of the proximal phalanx of the thumb
DEF: Absence of the epiphysis located at the proximal end of the proximal phalanx of the thumb. In contrast to the proximal phalanges of the digits 2-5, the proximal phalanx of the thumb is embryologically equivalent to the middle phalanges of the other digits, whereas the first metacarpal is embryologically of phalangeal origin and as such equivalent to the proximal phalanges of the other digits.

ET: Ivory epiphysis of the proximal phalanx of the thumb
DEF: Sclerosis of the epiphysis of the proximal phalanx of the thumb, leading to an increased degree of radiopacity (white or ivory appearance) in X-rays.

ET: Absent epiphysis of the distal phalanx of the thumb
DEF: Absence of the epiphysis located at the proximal end of the distal phalanx of the thumb.

ET: Ivory epiphysis of the distal phalanx of the thumb
DEF: Sclerosis of the epiphysis of the distal phalanx of the thumb, leading to an increased degree of radiopacity (white or ivory appearance) in X-rays.
Chronic cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) lymphocytosis is defined as the finding, in at least two serial CSF examinations, of more than 5 cells per cubic millimeter.
A benign or malignant neoplasm (tumour) originating in striated muscle, either skeletal muscle or cardiac muscle.
Developmental hypoplasia of the antihelix.
Increased width of the phalanges of the hand.

ET: Symphalangism affecting the phalanges of the hand
DEF: Fusion of two or more phalangeal bones of the hand.
A focal lesion of a single peripheral nerve. Damage to a sensory nerve is accompanied by sensory impairment of all modalities in the affected anatomic distribution.

ET: Bullet-shaped distal phalanges of the hand

A complete duplication affecting one or more of the phalanges of the thumb. As opposed to a partial duplication were there is still a variable degree of fusion between the duplicated bones, a complete duplication leads to two separate bones appearing side to side (radio-ulnar axis) as seen on x-rays. A duplication leading to an accesory bone appearing in the proximo-distal axis on x-rays, this is actually a different entity called a Pseudoepiphyses (see according terms) sometimes also referred to as Hyperphalangism.

A partial duplication, depending on severity leading to a broad or bifid appearance, affecting one or more of the phalanges of the thumb. As opposed to a complete duplication there is still a variable degree of fusion between the duplicated bones.

ET: Partial duplication of the proximal phalanges of the hand
DEF: A partial duplication, depending on severity leading to a broad or bifid appearance, affecting one or more of the proximal phalanges of the hand. As opposed to a complete duplication there is still a variable degree of fusion between the duplicated bones.

DEF: A partial duplication, depending on severity leading to a broad or bifid appearance, affecting one or more of the distal phalanges of the hand. As opposed to a complete duplication there is still a variable degree of fusion between the duplicated bones.
Developmental defect associated with absence of one or more metacarpal bones.

A deviation from the normal straight form of one or more distal toe phalanges.

A deviation from the normal straight form of one or more middle toe phalanges.

DEF: A deviation from the normal straight shape of a proximal phalanx of one or more toes.
A deviation from the normal straight shape of a proximal phalanx of one or more toes.

Enlarged epiphyses of the phalanges of the hand
DEF: Abnormally large size of the epiphyses of the phalanges of the fingers with respect to age-dependent norms.

ET: Small epiphyses of the phalanges of the hand

Absent epiphyses of the distal phalanges of the hand

DEF: Distal epiphyses of the hand are hard and dense like ivory. Such an epiphysis has a uniformly dense appearance on radiographs.

Ivory epiphyses of the middle phalanges of the hand
DEF: Epiphyses of the middle phalanges of the hand are hard and dense like ivory. Such an epiphysis has a uniformly dense appearance on radiographs.
