DEF: Epiphyses of the proximal phalanges of the hand are hard and dense like ivory. Such an epiphysis has a uniformly dense appearance on radiographs.

In contrast to forms of polydactyly where the supernumerary digit (this can either be a rudimentary or a completely 'normal' digit) is either located postaxial (on the fibular side of the foot, next top the little toe), preaxial (on the tibial side of the foot, next to the big toe) or mesoaxial (somewhere central, between big and little toe), a supernumerary digit may also be placed ectopically, meaning anywhere else except post-,meso- or preaxial. In the literature this is sometimes referred to as Disorganisation-like Syndrome (OMIM223200).

In contrast to forms of polydactyly where the supernumerary digit (this can either be a rudimentary or a completely 'normal' digit) is either located postaxial (on the ulnar side of the hand, next to the little finger), preaxial (on the radial side of the hand, next to the thumb) or mesoaxial (somewhere central, between thumb and little finger), a supernumerary digit may also be placed ectopically, meaning anywhere else except post-,meso- or preaxial. In the literature this is sometimes referred to as Disorganisation-like Syndrome (OMIM223200).

JT: 一次孔心房中隔欠損症
DEF: An ostium primum atrial septal defect is located in the most anterior and inferior aspect of the atrial septum. The ostium primum refers to an anterior and inferior opening (ostium) within the septum primum, which divides the rudimentary atrium during fetal development. The ostium primum is normally sealed by fusion of the superior and inferior endocardial cushions around 5 weeks' gestation. Ostium primum defects result from a failure of the fusion of the embryologic endocardial cushion and septum primum.

ET: Abnormality of the greater sacrosciatic notch
DEF: An abnormality of the sacrosciatic notch, i.e., the deep indentation in the posterior border of the hip bone at the point of union of the ilium and ischium.
The onset of puberty before the age of 8 years in girls.
The ability of the elbow joint to move beyond its normal range of motion.
An abnormal limitation of knee joint mobility.
An abnormality of dermatoglyphs on the toes and soles, i.e., an abnormality of the patterns of ridges of the skin of sole of foot.
Absence of the tarsal bones.
An ability of the toe joints to move beyond their normal range of motion.
Palatal myoclonus is characterized by myoclonic (rhythmic involuntary jerky) movements of the soft palate.

Spinal myoclonus is generally due to a tumor, infection, injury, or degenerative process of the spinal cord, and is characterized by involuntary rhythmic muscle contractions, usually at a rate of more than one per second. Myoclonus occurs synchronously in several muscles and can be increased in severity and frequency by fatigue or stress, but is usually unaffected by sensory stimuli. Spinal myoclonus ceases during sleep or anesthesia.
Sleep apnea resulting from a transient abolition of the central drive to the ventilatory muscles.
A degree of pneumatization that is increased compared to age-related norms.

A soft tissue continuity in the A/P axis between two fingers that extends distally to at least the level of the proximal interphalangeal joints, or a soft tissue continuity in the A/P axis between two fingers that lies significantly distal to the flexion crease that overlies the metacarpophalangeal joint of the adjacent fingers.

ET: Abnormality of the epiphysis of the femoral head
DEF: Any abnormality of the proximal epiphysis of the femur.

ET: Abnormality of the proximal tibial epiphysis
DEF: Any abnormality of the proximal epiphysis of the tibia.

ET: Abnormality of the distal tibial epiphysis

DEF: Any abnormality of the proximal epiphysis of the ulna.

Any abnormal increase or reduction in skin elasticity.
An abnormality of the Meninges, including any abnormality of the Dura mater, the Arachnoid mater, and the Pia mater.
A developmental defect characterized by aplasia of the Falx cerebri.

A nuclear cataract with a triangular form.
An abnormality of the texture of the hair.
An abnormality of the distribution of hair growth.
Abnormal prominence of the corneal nerve fibers.
Fibrous dysplasia of the bones were lesions are localized in many bones throughout of the body. Polyostotic fibrous dysplasia is a cardinal feature of McCune-Albright syndrome.
An anomaly of the temporomandibular joint.
Lack of paramedian peaks and median notch of the upper lip vermilion.
Inner aspect of the upper lip vermilion (normally apposing the teeth) visible in a frontal view, i.e., the presence of an everted upper lip.
Hair growth from a single point on the scalp in any location other than lateral to the midline and close to the vertex of the skull.

Complexes of spikes (<70 ms) and sharp waves (70-200 ms), which are sharp transient waves that have a strong association with epilepsy, in cerebral electrical activity recorded along the scalp by electroencephalography (EEG).

DEF: Periodically occurring generalized periodic complexes.
A delay in the acquisition of the ability to understand the speech of others.
Any deviation from the normal concentration of glycine in the blood circulation.
Any deviation from the normal concentration of proline or a proline metabolite in the blood circulation.
An increased concentration of isoleucine in the blood.
An abnormality of an alanine metabolic process.
Any deviation from the normal concentration of tyrosine in the blood circulation.
A cataract that affects the posterior part of the cortex of the lens.
An abnormality of a nucleobase metabolic process.

A finding of a focus of increased echogenicity upon prenatal ultrasound examination of the fetus. The foci may be present in one or both ventricles. Echogenic intracardiac focus (EICF) is defined as a focus of echogenicity comparable to bone, in the region of the papillary muscle in either or both ventricles of the fetal heart.

ET: Abnormality of the fetal cardiovascular system
DEF: An abnormality of the fetal circulation system or fetal echocardiogram.

A kind of ventriculomegaly occurring in the fetal period and usually diagnosed by prenatal ultrasound. Cerebral ventriculomegaly is defined by atrial measurements 10 mm or more. Mild ventriculomegaly (MVM) is defined as measurements between 10 and 15 mm. Measurements are obtained from an axial plane at the level of the thalamic nuclei just below the standard image to measure the BPD (PMID:16100637).

A kind of ventriculomegaly occurring in the fetal period and usually diagnosed by prenatal ultrasound. Cerebral ventriculomegaly is defined by atrial measurements 10 mm or more. Mild ventriculomegaly (MVM) is defined as measurements between 10 and 15 mm. Measurements are obtained from an axial plane at the level of the thalamic nuclei just below the standard image to measure the BPD (PMID:16100637).
An abnormality of liposaccharide metabolism.
Involuntary urine leakage synchronous with exertion, or actions such as sneezing, or coughing.
Abnormality of the striatum, which is the largest nucleus of the basal ganglia, comprising the caudate, putamen and ventral striatum, including the nucleus accumbens.
Abnormal functionality of the cardiovascular system.

ET: Agenesis of primary maxillary central incisor
DEF: Agenesis of upper central primary incisor.

ET: Agenesis of primary mandibular central incisor
DEF: Agenesis of lower primary incisor.

ET: Agenesis of permanent maxillary lateral incisor
DEF: Agenesis of one or more upper lateral secondary incisor.
Agenesis of secondary molar tooth.
The presence of an altered number of the incisor teeth.
A developmental defect of tooth color.
A form of hypomineralization of enamel characterized by a chalky appearance of the enamel with orange, brown, or white color.

A sudden flexion, extension, or mixed extension-flexion of predominantly proximal and truncal muscles that is usually more sustained than a myoclonic movement but not as sustained as a tonic seizure. Limited forms may occur: Grimacing, head nodding, or subtle eye movements. Epileptic spasms frequently occur in clusters. Infantile spasms are the best known form, but spasms can occur at all ages

JT: 両側性胎児性腎盂拡張症
DEF: A bilateral form of fetal pyelectasis.
Absence of the sweat glands.
A type of age-related cataract that primarily affects the nucleus of the lens.
An autonomic seizure is a type of focal non-motor seizure characterized by alteration of autonomic nervous system function as the initial semiological feature.
Focal seizure with eyelid myoclonia, not eyelid myoclonias in the context of absence seizures.

Generalized clonic seizure is a type of generalized motor seizure characterised by sustained bilateral jerking, either symmetric or asymmetric, that is regularly repetitive and involves the same muscle groups.

A febrile seizure that has any of the following features: focal semiology (or associated with post-ictal neurologic abnormalities beyond drowsiness, such as a Todd's paresis), prolonged seizure beyond 15 minutes, or recurring (occurring more than once) in a 24 hour period.
A type of focal motor seizure characterised by sustained, forced conjugate ocular, cephalic, and/or truncal rotation or lateral deviation from the midline as the initial semiological manifestation.

Epileptiform activity refers to distinctive EEG waves or complexes distinguished from background activity found in in a proportion of human subjects with epilepsy, but which can also be found in subjects without seizures. Interictal epileptiform activity refers to such activity that occurs in the absence of a clinical or subclinical seizure.

Epileptiform activity refers to distinctive EEG waves or complexes distinguished from background activity found in in a proportion of human subjects with epilepsy, but which can also be found in subjects without seizures. Interictal epileptiform activity refers to such activity that occurs in the absence of a clinical or subclinical seizure.

Slowing in occipital areas of the scalp EEG.

EEG with sharp waves in the central region, i.e., sharp transient waves of a duration between 80 and 200 msec.
EEG with sharp waves in the parietal region, i.e., sharp transient waves of a duration between 80 and 200 msec.

DEF: A short humerus length is defined as a length below the 2.5th percentile for gestational age or as a measurement less than 0.9 of that predicted by the measured biparietal diameter. DEF: Sensorineural hearing impairment with childhood onset.
Persistence of the stapedial artery, which normally regresses during embryonic life.
Persistence of the stapedial artery, which normally regresses during embryonic life.
A increased anteroposterior thickness of the cornea.
Abnormal migration of corneal endothelium.
Progressive maculopathy characterized by concentric regions of hyper- and hypo-pigmentation.
Abnormality of the spatial relationship of the atria to other components of the heart.

ET: Abnormal connection of the cardiac segments
DEF: A deviance in the normal connections between two cardiac segements.
A defect where there is no connection between the left atrium and left ventricle.
A defect where there is no connection between the right atrium and right ventricle.
The condition in which both atria are joined to a single ventricle each by its own atrioventricular valve.

The condition in which both atria are joined to the left ventricle each by its own atrioventricular valve. Usually there is a hypoplastic right ventricle, which may be on the opposite side of the heart as usual.
The left atrio-ventricular connection consists of two anatomically distinct orifices separated by accessory fibrous tissue.
Abnormality of the mitral valve apparatus, whereby chordae attach to a single papillary muscle or hypoplastic papillary muscles.
Congenital defect characterized by underdevelopment of the tricuspid valve.
A tricuspid valve that has failed to open.

Anatomic features of unbalanced atrioventricular septal defect (AVSD) include varying amounts of ventricular hypoplasia, as well as malalignment of the atrioventricular junction. In complete AVSD, the common AV valve can be situated either equally over the right and left ventricles (balanced) or unequally over the ventricles (unbalanced).
A congenital defect of heart development characterized by origin of both pulmonary artery and aorta from the morphological left ventricle.

Truncus arteriosus (single great artery leaving the base of the heart, giving rise to the coronary, pulmonary, and systemic arteries) whereby one of the two pulmonary artery branched does not arise from the common pulmonary trunk, but instead from the ductus arteriosus or directly from the aorta.
A ventricular septal defect that involves the inlet of the right ventricular septum immediately inferior to the AV valve apparatus.
No pericardium over the diaphragmatic surface of the heart. It is a congenital defect, not the result of a pericardectomy. Pericardium is present on other parts of the heart.

ET: Complete right sided absence of pericardium
DEF: No pericardium is present on the righthand side of the heart. It is a congenital absence of pericardium rather than the result of a pericardectomy.

ET: Complete left sided absence of pericardium
DEF: A congenital anomaly with complete lack of the pericardium on the lefthand side of the heart.
A venous pouch within the left ventricular wall, with a neck opening into the coronary sinus.
The presence of both a left and a right ductus arteriosus.
A ventricular septal defect that lies beneath the semilunar valve(s) in the conal or outlet septum.
Any ventricular septal defect (VSD) that is small enough to restrict flow across it such that a pressure gradient exists between the two sides of the VSD.
An abnormal path of a coronary artery.

ET: Cardiac total anomalous pulmonary venous connection
DEF: Type 2 total anomalous pulmonary venous connection.
An hormonally active adrenocortical adenoma, that is, an adenoma that secretes excessive amounts of adrenal hormones.

An abnormal anatomical location of the posterior lobe of the hypophysis, also known as the neurohypophysis. The posterior pituitary is normally present in the dorsal portion of the sella turcica, but when ectopic is usually near the median eminence. This defect is likely to be due to abnormal migration during embryogenesis.
A type of pituitary adenoma that is of unknown cellular origin and that lacks immunocytochemical or fine structural markers. Null cell adenomas are not associated with hormone excess.
A type of pituitary adenoma that is of unknown cellular origin and that lacks immunocytochemical or fine structural markers. Null cell adenomas are not associated with hormone excess.
Neoplasm categorized according to type of histological abnormality.

JT: 解剖学的位置による新生物
DEF: Neoplasm categorized according to the anatomical site of origin of the neoplasm.
Atrophy (wasting) affecting primary type 1 muscle fibers. This feature in general can only be observed on muscle biopsy.
A reduced ability to identify precisely the site of a touch. This test is usually carried out by asking a patient, whose eyes are closed or covered, to touch the same site with a fingertip.
A cleft of the muscular (soft) portion of the palate that is covered by mucous membrane. Soft-palate submucous clefts are characterized by a midline deficiency or lack of muscle tissue.

JT: 水平のヒダを伴う下顎
DEF: Horizontal crease or fold situated below the vermilion border of the lower lip and above the fatty pad of the chin, with the face at rest.
Narrow ridge in the midline of the philtral groove.
Narrow ridge in the midline of the philtral groove.
A deviation from the normal count of T cells.
An abnormality of the appendicular skeletal system, consisting of the of the limbs, shoulder and pelvic girdles.
Accumulation of serous fluid (pale yellow and transparent fluid) in the pericardial sac.
Accumulation of serous fluid (pale yellow and transparent fluid) in the pericardial sac.
An abnormally increased diphosphate(4-) concentration in the blood. Diphosphate(4-), as ester with two phosphate groups, is also known as pyrophosphate.
Average platelet volume above the upper limit of the normal reference interval.
Abnormal bleeding of the umbilical stump following separation of the cord at approximately 7-10 days after birth.
Prolonged or protracted bleeding following an invasive procedure or intervention.

Hemoglobin F (HbF) contains two globin alpha chains and two globin gamma chains. It is the main form of hemoglobin in the fetus during the last seven months of intrauterine development and in the half year of postnatal life. In adults it normally makes up less than one percent of all hemoglobin. This term refers to an increase in HbF above this limit. In beta thalassemia major, it may represent over 90 percent of all hemoglobin, and in beta thalassemia minor it may make up between 0.5 to 4 percent.
An anomaly of the glenoid fossa, also known as the glenoid cavity, which is the articular surface of the scapula that articulates with the head of the humerus.
Bending or curvature of a fourth toe in the tibial direction (i.e., towards the big toe).
A soft tissue continuity in the A/P axis between fingers 3 and 4.
Increased concentration of thiosulfate(2-) in the urine.
An infection of the upper or lower respiratory tract.

A lymphoproliferative abnormality of the intestine characterized by numerous visible mucosal nodules measuring up to, and rarely exceeding, 0.5 cm in diameter Histologically, hyperplastic lymphoid follicles with large germinal centres are seen in the lamina propria and superficial submucosa. There is enlargement of the mucosal B cell follicles caused by hyperplasia of the follicle centres; surrounded by a normal appearing mantle zone. Disease may involve the stomach, the entire small intestine, and the large intestine.

ET: Unilateral hypoplasia of pectoralis major muscle
DEF: Hypoplasia (underdevelopment) of the pectoralis minor on only one side of the chest.

Absence of any measurable level of sperm in his semen, resulting from a defect in the production of spermatozoa in the testes. This can be differentiated from obstructive azoospermia on the basis of testicular biopsy.
An increased concentration of citrulline in the blood.

JT: 大脳アミロイド血管症
DEF: Amyloid deposition in the walls of leptomeningeal and cortical arteries, arterioles, and less often capillaries and veins of the central nervous system.
Gallstones composed primarily of cholesterol, usually about 2-3 cm in length with an oval form and a yellow or green/brown color.
Formation of abnormal bony tissue within muscle tissue.
Formation of abnormal bony tissue within tendon tissue.

JT: 全般性棘波を伴う脳波
DEF: EEG with generalized sharp transient waves of a duration less than 80 msec.
Elevated concentration of galactose in the blood.
An abnormal concentration of a hormone in the urine.
Increased concentration of disaccharide in the urine.

A personality disorder characterized by shallow and labile affectivity, self-dramatization, theatricality, exaggerated expression of emotions, suggestibility, egocentricity, self-indulgence, lack of consideration for others, easily hurt feelings, and continuous seeking for appreciation, excitement and attention.
Blockade of impulses at a focal site along the course of a motor axon.
A functional anomaly of the acinar gland portion of the pancreas that secretes digestive enzymes.
A function abnormality of the endocrine pancreas.

ET: Edema of the dorsum of feet
DEF: An abnormal accumulation of fluid beneath the skin on the back of the feet.

An anomaly of the mitochondrion, the membranous cytoplasmic organelle the interior of which is subdivided by cristae. The mitochondrion is a self replicating organelle that is the site of tissue respiration.

JT: 原発性開放隅角緑内障
DEF: A type of glaucoma defined by an open, normal appearing anterior chamber angle and raised intraocular pressure,

ET: Abnormality of cells of the erythroid lineage
DEF: An anomaly of erythroid lineage cells, that is, of the erythropoietic cells in the lineage leading to and including erythrocytes.

ET: Abnormality of cells of the granulocytic lineage
DEF: An anomaly of cells involved in the formation of a granulocytes, that is, of the granulocytopoietic cell.

ET: Abnormality of cells of the lymphoid lineage
Abnormality of cells of the megakaryocyte lineage
DEF: Any structural anomaly of megakaryocytes. Mature blood platelets are released from the cytoplasm of megakaryocytes, which are bone-marrow resident cells.
Abnormality/dysplasia of a single myeloid cell (erythroid, granulocytic, or megakaryocytic).
Reduced ability of the cornea to respond to stimulation.
A separation (dissection) of the layers of the intracranial portion of the internal carotid artery wall.
Habitual clasping and squeezing of the hands.

A form of focal dystonia affecting the face and especially the jaw that is induced by the act of speaking. It is an involuntary contraction of the masticatory muscles, resulting in dysarthria or dysphagia.

Increased plasma concentrations of chylomicrons, the large lipid droplet (up to 100 mm in diameter) of reprocessed lipid synthesized in epithelial cells of the small intestine and containing triacylglycerols, cholesterol esters, and several apolipoproteins.

An abnormal increase in intracellular lipid droplets In a muscle. The number and size of these drops can increase with somd disorders of lipid metabolism affecting muscle. See PMID 20691590 for histological images.

Absence of the outer dynein arms of respiratory motile cilia, which normally are situated outside of the peripheral microtubules of motile cilia. This feature is usually appreciated by electron microscopy.

Absence of the inner dynein arms of respiratory motile cilia, which normally are situated within the peripheral microtubules of motile cilia. This feature is usually appreciated by electron microscopy.

Inflammation of the flexor digitorum tendon, often associated with the Kanavel signs: (i) finger held in slight flexion, (ii) fusiform swelling, (iii) tenderness along the flexor tendon sheath, and (iv) pain with passive extension of the digit.
A form of amyloidosis that affects the liver.
Reduced size of the proximal epiphysis of the tibia.
An abnormal functionality of the hypothalamus.
Any structural anomaly of the hypothalamus.
A severe virus infection of the central nervous system by the herpes simplex virus (HSV).
A vascular tumor of the skin and subcutaneous tissues and characterized by slow angiomatous proliferation.
A structural abnormality of the autonomic nervous system.
A functional abnormality of the autonomic nervous system.
An abnormal regulation of the sweat glands by the sympathetic nervous system associated with abnormal perspiration.
Any anomaly in the utilization of energy (calories).
Any anomaly in the utilization of energy (calories).
Abnormally reduced concentration of ferritin, a ubiquitous intracellular protein that stores iron, in the blood.
A decreased concentration of potassium(1+) in the urine.
Reduced intensity of muscle tendon reflexes in the upper limbs. Reflexes are elicited by stretching the tendon of a muscle, e.g., by tapping.

An abnormal concentration of aldolase in the serum. Aldolase is an enzyme responsible for converting fructose 1,6-bisphosphate into the triose phosphates dihydroxyacetone phosphate and glyceraldehyde 3-phosphate.
Coronary disease that has not progressed to the point of causing significant occlusion (blockage) of the coronary arteries.
A structural anomaly of the inferior portion of the vermis of cerebellum.
Involuntary and irregular twitches of the chin.
Bony fusion of the mandibular condyle to the base of the skull, resulting in limitation of jaw opening.
An arachnoid cyst located at the margin of the cerebellum and pons.
A pale yellow discoloration of the temporal (lateral) portion of the optic disc.
An abnormally decreased amount of catalase level.
A deviation from the normal count of dense granules per thrombocyte.

An anomaly in the communication from a neuron to a target across a synapse. This is a four step process, comprising (i) synthesis and storage of neurotransmitters; (ii) neurotransmitter release; (iii) activation of postsynaptic receptors by the neurotransmitter; and (iv) inactivation of the neurotransmitter. Thus, this term is defined as an anomaly of neurotransmitter metabolic process.
An increased concentration of fructose 1,6-bisphosphate aldolase in the serum.
Anomalous movements of the eyes that occur without the subject wanting them to happen.

A type of proximal renal tubulopathy characterized by resorption defects leading to glycosuria, aminoaciduria, tubular proteinuria, renal hypophosphatemia, and urate tubular hyporeabsorption with bicarbonate loss and resulting acidosis.

A type of proximal renal tubulopathy characterized by resorption defects leading to glycosuria, aminoaciduria, tubular proteinuria, renal hypophosphatemia, and urate tubular hyporeabsorption with bicarbonate loss and resulting acidosis.
Reduction in thickness of the basal lamina of the glomerulus of the kidney.
The presence of minimal changes visible by light microscopy but flattened and fused podocyte foot processes on electron microscopy in a person with nephrotic range proteinuria.
One sided hypoplasia of the kidney.
An abnormality in the concentration of electrolytes in the urine.

JT: ネフローゼ範囲の蛋白尿
DEF: Severely increased amount of excretion of protein in the urine, defined as 3.5 grams per day or more in adults and 40 mg per meter-squared body surface area per hour in children.
An abnormally increased sodium concentration in the urine in the presence of hyponatremia.
Abnormal concentration of sulfate in the urine.

ET: Pigment deposition in the trabecular meshwork
DEF: Accumulation of abnormal amounts of pigment within the trabecular meshwork.
Shedding of the pigment granules that normally adhere to the back of the iris into the aqueous humor.
High urine calcium in the presence of hypocalcemia.
An elevated concentration of lactate in the caudate nucleus. This finding can be elicited by magnetic resonance spectroscopy imaging.

JT: 異常な中枢神経ドパミン値
DEF: Abnormal concentration of dopamine in the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF).
Increased concentration of dopamine in the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF).
Increased concentration of dopamine in the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF).
Decreased concentration of dopamine in the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF).
A medium reduction in the fraction of blood pumped from the left ventricle with each cardiac cycle.
A failure to develop of the upper vagina.
A failure to develop of the lower part of the vagina.
A delay in the process of formation and maturation of the epiphysis of one or more vertebrae.
The presence of a moderate form of hearing impairment.
A profound (essentially complete) form of hearing impairment.

A reduced ability to participate in the back and forth flow of social interaction, which is normally characterized by an influence of the behavior of one person on the behavior of another person who is in conversation with the first.

A reduced ability to participate in the back and forth flow of social interaction, which is normally characterized by an influence of the behavior of one person on the behavior of another person who is in conversation with the first.
A glial tumor of the retinal nerve fiber layer arising from a retinal astrocyte.
A type of nephrogenic rest usually representing single lesions within the renal lobe, renal sinus, or calyceal walls.
Underdevelopment of the heel bone.

ET: Absent ossification of thoracic vertebral bodies
DEF: A lack of bone mineralization of one or more body of thoracic vertebra.
Multiple areas of darker than expected signal on magnetic resonance imaging emanating from the cerebral white matter that surrounds the cerebral ventricles.

An elevation in the ratio of the diameter of the cup of the optic disc to the total diameter of the disc. The optic disc has an orange-pink rim with a pale centre (the cup) that does not contain neuroretinal tissue. An increase in this ratio therefore may indicate a decrease in the quantity of healthy neuroretinal cells.
Insertion of the posterior columella superior to the nasal base.
Underdevelopment of the breast on both sides.
A type of cardiomyopathy characterized anatomically by deep trabeculations in the ventricular wall, which define recesses communicating with the main ventricular chamber.
Decreased strength of the vocal fold on one side.
Decreased strength of the vocal fold on both sides.
The presence of an increased number of twists and turns of the retinal blood vessels.

Epilepsia partialis continua (also called Kojevnikov's or Kozhevnikov's epilepsia) is a type of focal motor status epilepticus characterized by repeated stereotyped simple motor manifestations such as jerks, typically of a limb or the face, recurring every few seconds or minutes for extended periods (days or years).
A white patch or plaque occurring on the surface of the esophageal mucous membranes that cannot be rubbed off and cannot be characterized clinically as any other disease.
A cystic tumor of the ovary, containing thin, clear, yellow serous fluid and varying amounts of solid tissue.
Muscle hypertrophy affecting the scapular muscles.

An anomaly identified by motor evoked potentials (MEPs). MEPs are measured following single-pulse or repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation and can be used for the assessment of the excitability of the motor cortex and the integrity of conduction along the central and peripheral motor pathways.
A cataract which is found in the back outer layer of the lens. This type often develops more rapidly.
The presence of inclusion bodies within the cytoplasm of muscle cells. Inclusion bodies are aggregates (deposits) or stainable material, usually misfolded proteins.
An anomaly in the metabolism of a vitamin.
The presence of a neoplasm of the gallbladder.
Telangiectasia of the mucosa, the mucous membranes which are involved in absorption and secretion that line cavities that are exposed to the external environment and internal organs.

ET: Displacement of the external urethral meatus
DEF: A displacement of the external urethral orifice from its normal position (in males normally placed at the tip of glans penis, in females normally placed about 2.5 cm behind the glans clitoridis and immediately in front of that of the vagina).
A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the oral cavity.
A decreased anteroposterior thickness of the cornea.
An increase in the degree of curvature of the cornea compared to normal.

Swelling of lymph nodes within the mediastinum, the central compartment of the thoracic cavities that contains the heart and the great vessels, the esophagus, and trachea and other structures including lymph nodes.
An abnormality of the placenta, the organ that connects the developing fetus to the uterine wall to enable nutrient uptake, waste elimination, and gas exchange.
Increased level of cryoglobulins in the blood. Cryoglobulins are abnormal immunoglobulins, especially IGG or IGM, that precipitate spontaneously when serum is cooled below 37 degrees Celsius.

ET: Benign neoplasm of the central nervous system
Malignant neoplasm of the central nervous system
DEF: A tumor that originates in the pineal gland, has moderate cellularity and tends to form rosette patterns.
An increased susceptibility to cutaneous abscess formation, as manifested by a medical history of recurrent cutaneous abscesses.

Congenital mesoblastic nephroma is a type of kidney tumor that is usually found before birth by ultrasound or within the first 3 months of life. It contains fibroblastic cells (connective tissue cells), and may spread to the other kidney or to nearby tissue.
An elevation in bone density in one or more phalanges of the fingers. Sclerosis is normally detected on a radiograph as an area of increased opacity.
An elevation in bone density in one or more phalanges of the big toe. Sclerosis is normally detected on a radiograph as an area of increased opacity.
An increase in size of the subarachnoid space associated with the lateral cerebral sulcus (Sylvian fissure).
Decreased width of the foramen obturatorium. The foramen obturatorium (also known as the obturator foramen) is a hole located between the ischium and pubis bones of the pelvis.
A type of dysharmonic skeletal maturation in which there is an acceleration in skeletal maturation whose degree differs markedly in different bones.
Shortening of a leg affecting only one side.
A type of vitreoretinal degeneration with manifestations that are concentrated at the periphery of the retina.
Intermittent episodes of paralysis of all four limbs.
An increased lymphocyte count in the cerebrospinal fluid.
Any structural anomaly of an inner ear epithelium.
An abnormality of a risorius muscle.
An abnormality of a ciliary ganglion.

ET: Abnormality of bony orbit of skull
DEF: An abnormality of an orbit of skull.
An abnormality of a central retinal artery.

ET: Abnormality of cartilage of nasal septum
DEF: An abnormality of a cartilage of nasal septum.
Any structural abnormality of a jugular vein.
An abnormality of a hyoglossus muscle.

ET: Abnormality of inferior rectus extraocular muscle
DEF: An abnormality of an inferior rectus extraocular muscle.
An abnormality of a lacrimal sac.

ET: Abnormality of lateral rectus extra-ocular muscle
DEF: An abnormality of a lateral rectus extra-ocular muscle.
Deviation from the norm of height with respect to that which is expected according to age and gender norms.
An abnormality of the urinary bladder.

Hermaphroditism refers to a discrepancy between the morphology of the gonads and that of the external genitalia. In male pseudohermaphroditism, the genotype is male (XY) and the external genitalia are imcompletely virilized, ambiguous, or complete female. If gonads are present, they are testes.
Any abnormality of the gingiva (also known as gums).
Limitation in the ability to open the mouth.
Presence of telangiectases in the oral cavity.
An abnormality of the mastoid process, which is the conical prominence projecting from the undersurface of the mastoid portion of the temporal bone.

An anomaly of the midface, which is a region and not an anatomical term. It extends, superiorly, from the inferior orbital margin to, inferiorly, the level of nasal base. It is formed by the maxilla (upper jaw) and zygoma and cheeks and malar region. Traditionally, the nose and premaxilla are not included in the midface.
An abnormality of the Maxilla (upper jaw bone).
Abnormality of the choanae (the posterior nasal apertures).

A thickening of the skin thickness in the posterior aspect of the fetal neck. A nuchal fold measurement is obtained in a transverse section of the fetal head at the level of the cavum septum pellucidum and thalami, angled posteriorly to include the cerebellum. The measurement is taken from the outer edge of the occiput bone to the outer skin limit directly in the midline. A measurement 6 mm or more is considered significant between 18 and 24 weeks and a measurement of 5 mm or more is considered significant at 16 to 18 weeks (PMID:16100637).
The presence of recurrent corneal epithelial erosions. Although most corneal epithelial defects heal quickly, some may show recurrent ulcerations.
Any abnormality of the electrical responses of various cell types in the retina as measured by electroretinography.
An abnormality of the eyebrow.
An anomaly of the pharynx, i.e., of the tubular structure extending from the base of the skull superiorly to the esophageal inlet inferiorly.
Any structural abnormality of the choroid.
An abnormality of the Incisor tooth.
An anomaly of the sternum, also known as the breastbone.
Any abnormality of the scapula, also known as the shoulder blade.
An abnormality of the urethra, i.e., of the tube which connects the urinary bladder to the outside of the body.
An abnormality of the tricarboxylic acid cycle.
A form of diabetes insipidus related to a failure of vasopressin (AVP) release from the hypothalamus.

An increased sensitivity of the skin to light. Photosensitivity may result in a rash upon exposure to the sun (which is known as photodermatosis). Photosensitivity can be diagnosed by phototests in which light is shone on small areas of skin.

Dryness of the eye related to deficiency of the tear film components (aqueous, mucin, or lipid), lid surface abnormalities, or epithelial abnormalities. Keratoconjunctivitis sicca often results in a scratchy or sandy sensation (foreign body sensation) in the eyes, and may also be associated with itching, inability to produce tears, photosensitivity, redness, pain, and difficulty in moving the eyelids.
Supernumerary digits located at the ulnar side of the hand (that is, on the side with the fifth finger).

A delay in the achievement of motor or mental milestones in the domains of development of a child, including motor skills, speech and language, cognitive skills, and social and emotional skills. This term should only be used to describe children younger than five years of age.
A mode of inheritance that depends on a mixture of major and minor genetic determinants possibly together with environmental factors. Diseases inherited in this manner are termed complex diseases.
Failure to thrive (FTT) refers to a child whose physical growth is substantially below the norm.
Diffuse thickening of the ventricular endocardium and by associated myocardial dysfunction

Restrictive left ventricular physiology is characterized by a pattern of ventricular filling in which increased stiffness of the myocardium causes ventricular pressure to rise precipitously with only small increases in volume, defined as restrictive ventricular physiology in the presence of normal or reduced diastolic volumes (of one or both ventricles), normal or reduced systolic volumes, and normal ventricular wall thickness.

Polydactyly of the foot most commonly refers to the presence of six toes on one foot. Postaxial polydactyly affects the lateral ray and the duplication may range from a well-formed articulated digit to a rudimentary digit.
A neutrophil abnormality.
An abnormal count or structure of eosinophils.
An abnormality of the process of blood coagulation. That is, altered ability or inability of the blood to clot.
Decreased activity of coagulation factor XI. Factor XI, also known as plasma thromboplastin antecedent, is a serine proteinase that activates factor IX.
Decreased activity of coagulation factor XI. Factor XI, also known as plasma thromboplastin antecedent, is a serine proteinase that activates factor IX.

Glucose intolerance (GI) can be defined as dysglycemia that comprises both prediabetes and diabetes. It includes the conditions of impaired fasting glucose (IFG) and impaired glucose tolerance (IGT) and diabetes mellitus (DM).

JT: 慢性代謝性アシドーシス
DEF: Longstanding metabolic acidosis.

A condition in which there is increased production of gastrin by a gastrin-secreting tumor (usually located in the pancreas, duodenum, or abdominal lymph nodes) that stimulates the gastric mucosa to maximal activity, with consequent gastrointestinal mucosal ulceration.

A condition in which there is increased production of gastrin by a gastrin-secreting tumor (usually located in the pancreas, duodenum, or abdominal lymph nodes) that stimulates the gastric mucosa to maximal activity, with consequent gastrointestinal mucosal ulceration.
Abnormal loss of protein from the digestive tract related to excessive leakage of plasma proteins into the lumen of the gastrointestinal tract.

Arnold-Chiari malformation consists of a downward displacement of the cerebellar tonsils and the medulla through the foramen magnum, sometimes causing hydrocephalus as a result of obstruction of CSF outflow.
An abnormality of the gyri (i.e., the ridges) of the cerebral cortex of the brain.
An abnormality of the stomach.
A form of chronic gastritis associated with atrophic gastric mucous membrane.
A structural anomaly of the trachea.
Impaired production of memory cells, the B cells that persist for years or an entire lifetime and which confer rapid and enhanced response to secondary challenge.
The presence in the serum of an autoantibody directed against the Fc portion of IgG.
An abnormality of the lower arm.
Abnormality of the patella (knee cap).
An abnormality of the humerus (i.e., upper arm bone).
An anomaly of the ischium, which forms the lower and back part of the hip bone.
A decreased concentration of carnitine in the blood.

JT: 寒冷誘発性筋けいれん(こむらがえり)
DEF: Sudden and involuntary contractions of one or more muscles brought on by exposure to cold temperatures.
The presence in the serum of autoantibodies directed against thrombocytes.
Weakness of the muscles of the arms.
Reduced ability to climb stairs.
Abnormally reduced sulfite oxidase level.
Muscular atrophy in the distribution of shoulder girdle and peroneal muscles.
Weakness of the quadriceps muscle (that is, of the muscle fasciculus of quadriceps femoris).
Muscular atrophy affecting the muscles of the limb girdle.
The presence of a splayed (i.e.,flared) metaphyseal segment of one or more long bones of the arm.

JT: 傾斜のある上腕骨骨幹端

DEF: Irregularity of the normally smooth surface of the metaphysis at the distal end of the humerus (at the elbow).
Osteosclerosis (increased density related to increased bone mass) of the ulna.
This term groups together three conditions that presumably represent different degrees of severity of a midline defect of the nose or nasal tip.

The bone-in-bone sign is a radiographic finding produced by increased sclerosis (abnormally dense bone) occurring intermittently with zones of relatively normal bone density. This term should be used to describe such a finding in the carpal bones.

JT: マクロファージの異常
DEF: An abnormality of macrophages.
An abnormal increase or decrease of weight or an abnormal distribution of mass in the body.
Severe weight loss, wasting of muscle, loss of appetite, and general debility related to a chronic disease.
An abnormality of lymphocytes.
Deposition of calcium salts in the aortic valve.
Abnormal calcification of the mitral valve.
Congenital atresia of the pylorus.
An abnormality of the pylorus.
Repeated episodes of inflammation of a vein associated with venous thrombosis (blood clot formation within the vein).

JT: 反復性ウイルス感染症
DEF: Increased susceptibility to viral infections, as manifested by recurrent episodes of viral infection.
Pits in the earlobes at the location where ears are typically pierced for earrings.
An enlargement of the posterior fontanelle relative to age-dependent norms.
Generalized excessive, abnormal hairiness.
Increased top to bottom height of vertebral bodies.
Exaggerated concavity of the anterior or posterior surface of the vertebral body, i.e., the upper and lower vertebral endplates are hollowed inward.
The closed form of spina bifida with incomplete closure of the vertebra L5 with intact overlying skin.
The closed form of spina bifida with incomplete closure of S1 with intact overlying skin.
Decreased number of head hairs per unit area on the anterior region of the scalp.
A deviation from the normal rotation of the midgut during embryologic development with mislocalization of the small bowel.

JT: プロテインS活性の減少
DEF: An abnormality of coagulation related to a decreased concentration of vitamin K-dependent protein S. Protein S is a cofactor of protein C.

JT: 持続性乳酸性アシドーシス
DEF: A continuous form of lactic acidemia.

JT: 先天性乳酸性アシドーシス
DEF: A form of lactic acidemia with congenital onset.
Excessive bending, twisting, and winding of a cerebral artery.
Calcification, that is, pathological deposition of calcium salts in the aorta.

A ventircular escape rhythm occurs whenever higher-lever pacemakers in AV junction or sinus node fail to control ventricular activation. Escape rate is usually 20-40 bpm, often associated with broad QRS complexes (at least 120 ms).
A congenital malformation of the pulmonary valve characterized by leaflet deformation.
Arteriosclerosis occurring at an age that is younger than usual.
Abnormally flat shape of the heads of the metatarsal bones.
The presence of degenerative changes of the liver.
An abnormality of the jejunum, i.e., of the middle section of the small intestine.
Formation of a blood clot (thrombus) inside a cerebral vein, causing the obstruction of blood flow.

A type of craniofacial dysostosis associated with abnormalities of the external ears, mirognathia, macrostomia, coloboma of the lower eyelid, and cleft palate. This is a bundled term that is left in the HPO now for convenience with legacy annotations but should not be used for new annotations.
A primary immune deficiency that is characterized by defects or deficiencies of T-lymphocytes that causes specific susceptibility to intracellular micro-organisms.

JT: キニノーゲン活性の減少
DEF: Reduction in the amount of kininogen, which functions as a cofactor in the contact phase of the intrinsic blood coagulation cascade.
A form of hemolytic anemia that can be triggered by exertion.
Congenital onset of a marked decrease in the number of granulocytes.

JT: プロテインC活性の減少
DEF: An abnormality of coagulation related to a decreased concentration of vitamin K-dependent protein C. Protein C is activated to protein Ca by thrombin bound to thrombomodulin. Activated protein C degrades factors VIIIa and Va.

A chronic lymphocytic/lymphatic/lymphoblastic leukemia (CLL) is a neoplastic disease characterized by proliferation and accumulation (blood, marrow and lymphoid organs) of morphologically mature but immunologically dysfunctional lymphocytes. A CLL is always a B-cell lymphocytic leukemia as there are no reports of cases of T-cell lymphocytic leukemias.
Underdevelopment of the ulna on both sides.
Multiple exostoses originating in the fingers and toes.
An abnormally small and flat configuration of the posterior cranial fossa.
An abnormal increase of bone mineral density with generalized involvement of the skeleton.
One or more bent (flexed) toe joints that cannot be straightened actively or passively.
Progressive bending or abnormal curvature of the forearm skeleton.

JT: 乳児期の無呼吸エピソード
DEF: Recurrent episodes of apnea occurring during infancy.
Increased side-to-side width of the metacarpal epiphyses.
The presence of a supernumerary finger (not a thumb) involving the third or fourth metacarpal with associated osseous syndactyly.

JT: α-フェトプロテイン上昇
DEF: An increased concentration of alpha-fetoprotein.
A small/hypoplastic or absent/aplastic 5th finger.
A small/hypoplastic or absent/aplastic 2nd finger.
Premature tooth eruption, which can be defined as tooth eruption more than 2 SD earlier than the mean eruption age.
A type of dental misalignment with crowded central incisors, i.e., of maxillary secondary incisor, or of maxillary central primary incisor.
An abnormal conical morphology of the primary or permanent mandibular incisors.
An abnormal conformation of the femur that becomes gradually enlarged towards the proximal end. This feature affects the proximal femoral metaphysis and epiphysis.
Partial dislocation of the ulna in the dorsal direction.
Substantial narrowing or blockage of small pulmonary veins as a result of disorganized smooth muscle hypertrophy and collagen matrix deposition.

Abnormal dilatation of the pulmonary lymphatic vessels. Lymphatic fluid in the lung is derived from normal leakage of fluid out of the blood capillaries in the lung. In pulmonary lymphangiectasia, the pulmonary lymphatics are not properly connected and become dilated with fluid.

JT: 不規則な肋骨端のフレア

DEF: Underdevelopment of the paranasal sinuses.

ET: Loss of ability to walk in first decade

DEF: A type of Horner syndrome with congenital onset.
A type of encephalopathy (brain disease, damage, or malfunction accompanied by an altered mental state) that is characterized by evidence of necrosis of brain tissue.

Dysplasia and dysgenesis of the corpus callosum are nonspecific descriptions that imply defective development of the corpus callosum. The term dysplasia is applied when the morphology of the corpus callosum is altered as a congenital trait. For instance, the corpus callosum may be hump-shaped, kinked, or a striped corpus callosum that lacks an anatomically distinct genu and splenium.

Paralysis of the fourth cranial (trochlear) nerve manifested as weakness of the superior oblique muscle which causes vertical diplopia that is maximal when the affected eye is adducted and directed inferiorly.
Underdevelopment of the inferior portion of the vermis of cerebellum.

JT: 発作性舞踏病様アテトーゼ
DEF: Episodes of choreoathetosis that can occur following triggers such as quick voluntary movements.

Atrophy of the interosseus muscles (including the palmar interossei that lie on the anterior aspect of the metacarpals, the dorsal interosseus muscles of the hand, which lie between the intercarpals, the plantar interosseus muscles, which lie underneath the metatarsal bones, and the dorsal interossei, which are located between the metatarsal bones.
Reduced amount of myelin in the nervous system resulting from defective myelinogenesis in the peripheral nervous system.

JT: 先天性顔面神経両麻痺
DEF: Facial diplegia (that is, bilateral facial palsy) with congenital onset.
Weakness of the muscles of the legs.
A type of tremors that is triggered by holding an arm in a fixed position.
Photosensitivity of the skin occurring early in life.
An abnormally increased perspiration on palms and soles.

JT: 非典型的神経線維腫症

DEF: Deposition of calcium salts in subcutaneous tissue (i.e., the the lowermost layer of the integument).

JT: 先天性原発性無水晶体
DEF: Absence of the crystalline lens of the eye as a result of a developmental defect.
A cataract that affects the anterior part of the cortex of the lens.

JT: 顆粒性角膜ジストロフィー
DEF: The presence of central, fine, whitish granular lesions in the stroma of the cornea. This type of corneal dystrophy is usually asymptomatic and begins in childhood and shows a slow progression. Later in the course, the corneal epithelium and Bowman's layer may be affected. Histologically, the cornea shows a uniform deposition of hyaline material.

JT: 両側性網膜コロボーマ
点状角膜ジストロフィー
角膜辺縁ジストロフィー
緩徐な水平サッカード
DEF: An abnormally slow velocity of horizontal saccadic eye movements.
Congenital absence of the extraocular muscles.

JT: 斑紋状角膜ジストロフィー

DEF: Abnormal pigmentation of the iris.

JT: 母体血清エストリオール低値
DEF: An abnormally high concentration of serum conjugated estriol as compared to normal values for gestational-age.
Limitation of the ability to bend the toes.

JT: プロトロンビン時間遷延
DEF: Increased time to coagulation in the prothrombin time test, which is a measure of the extrinsic pathway of coagulation. The results of the prothrombin time test are often expressed in terms of the International normalized ratio (INR), which is calculated as a ratio of the patient's prothrombin time (PT) to a control PT standardized for the potency of the thromboplastin reagent developed by the World Health Organization (WHO) using the formula: INR is equal to Patient PT divided by Control PT.
An abnormal reduction in the Arden ratio, which is the ratio between the light peak and the dark trough of the smoothed (physiologic) EOG record.
The presence of multiple pancreatic islet cell adenomas.

JT: 代償性甲状腺機能低下症
DEF: Condition associated with a raised serum concentration of thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH) but a normal serum free thyroxine (FT4).

An abnormality of adhesion of thrombocytes. Normally, platelets adhere to collagen in the vascular subendothelium within seconds of injury via a receptor made up of glycoprotein Ia and IIa and GPVI and to vWF via receptor GPIb/IX/V. The adherent platelets then release granules that lead to platelet activation and aggregation.

The presence of an abnormally increased concentration of neutral amino acids in the urine. The neutral amino acids are tryptophan, alanine, asparagine, glutamine, histidine, isoleucine, leucine, phenylalanine, serine, threonine, tyrosine and valine.

JT: 先天性爪ジストロフィー

DEF: Thickened toenails.
Complete bilateral fractures of the pars interarticularis resulting in the anterior slippage of the fifth lumbar vertebral body (L5) onto the sacrum (level S1).
Absence of the acoustic reflex, an involuntary contraction of the stapedius muscle that occurs in response to high-intensity sound stimuli.
A type of hearing impairment affecting primarily the low frequencies of sound (125 Hz to 1000 Hz).
Complete lack of functioning of the vestibular apparatus.
A unilateral form of developmental dysplasia of the kidney.

The presence of one or more obsessive-compulsive personality traits. Obsessions refer to persistent intrusive thoughts, and compulsions to intrusive behaviors, which the affected person experiences as involuntary, senseless, or repugnant.

JT: 幅広く,小さい仙坐骨切痕
DEF: The sacroiliac joint in the bony pelvis connects the sacrum and the ilium of the pelvis, which are joined by strong ligaments. The notch is located directly superior to the joint. This term refers to a increase in the lateral dimension of the notch.
Underdevelopment of muscles of the shoulder.
A small/hypoplastic or absent/aplastic 4th (ring) finger.
A small/hypoplastic or absent/aplastic 3rd (middle) finger.

ET: Broad middle phalanx of the 3rd finger
DEF: Increased width of the middle phalanx of the 3rd finger.
Bending or curvature of a finger toward the radial side (i.e., towards the thumb). The deviation is at the metacarpal-phalangeal joint, and this finding is distinct from clinodactyly.
Congenital fusion (ankylosis) of the interphalangeal joint of the thumb.
Hypoplastic (short) thumb phalanx.
Areas of the retina lacking pigmentation. Punched out areas of chorioretinal hypopigmentation less than 1 disc diameter in size and tending to be located in the midperiphery of the retina.

Annular constrictions around the digits, limbs, or trunk, occurring congenitally (sometimes causing intrauterine autoamputation) and also associated with a wide variety of disorders. Constrictive amniotic bands are the result of primary amniotic rupture, which can lead to entanglement of fetal tissue (especially limbs) in fibrous amniotic strands.
The presence of a supernumerary toe (not a hallux) involving the third or fourth metatarsal with associated osseous syndactyly.

ET: Pseudoepiphyses of the distal phalanges of the hand
DEF: A secondary ossification center in the distal phalanges of the hand that is distinct from the normal epiphysis that does not contribute to the longitudinal growth of a tubular bone.

ET: Pseudoepiphyses of the middle phalanges of the hand
DEF: A secondary ossification center in the middle phalanges of the hand that is distinct from the normal epiphysis that does not contribute to the longitudinal growth of a tubular bone.

ET: Pseudoepiphyses of the proximal phalanges of the hand
DEF: A secondary ossification center in the proximal phalanges of the hand that is distinct from the normal epiphysis that does not contribute to the longitudinal growth of a tubular bone.
An anomaly of the second toe.
An anomaly of the third toe.
An anomaly of the fourth toe.
An anomaly of the little toe.
Abnormality of the urachus.
Elevated 7-dehydrocholesterol levels.
A cystic lesion originating within the brain.
A benign biphasic tumor of the breast with epithelial and stromal components.
An abnormal lack of stability of the cervical spine.
Webbing or fusion of the toes, involving soft parts and including fusion of individual bones of the toes. Bony fusions are referred to as \
Insertion of the posterior columella below the nasal base.
Increased pigmentation, either focal or generalized, of the skin surrounding the vermilion of the lips.

JT: テント状上口唇唇紅部
DEF: Triangular appearance of the oral aperture with the apex in the midpoint of the upper vermilion and the lower vermilion forming the base.

A generalized tonic seizure is a type of generalized motor seizure characterised by bilateral limb stiffening or elevation, often with neck stiffening without a subsequent clonic phase. The tonic activity can be a sustained abnormal posture, either in extension or flexion, sometimes accompanied by tremor of the extremities.
A reduced sense of touch (tactile sensation). This is usually tested with a wisp of cotton or a fine camel's hair brush, by asking patients to say 'now' each time they feel the stimulus.
Spontaneous pain is a kind of neuropathic pain which occurs without an identifiable trigger.

JT: 群発‐抑制交代を伴う脳波
DEF: The burst suppression pattern in electroencephalography refers to a characteristic periodic pattern of low voltage (<10 microvolts) suppressed background and a relatively shorter pattern of higher amplitude slow, sharp, and spiking complexes.

JT: 焦点性棘波を伴う脳波
DEF: EEG with focal sharp transient waves of a duration between 80 and 200 msec.

JT: 焦点性棘波を伴う脳波
DEF: EEG with focal sharp transient waves of a duration less than 80 msec followed by a slow wave.
Slowing in occipital areas of the scalp EEG.
An eyebrow that extends laterally beyond the orbital rim rather than turning gently downward at that location.

JT: 左単一冠状縫合早期癒合
DEF: Synostosis affecting only the left coronal suture.
An abnormality of the fontanelle.
An abnormality of the outline, configuration, or contour of the mouth.
Increased size of the cochlear duct, i.e., of a duct that communicates between the perilymphatic space and the subarachnoid space, and transmits a vein from the cochlea to join the internal jugular.

Fetal choroid plexus cysts (CPCs) are sonographically discrete, small cysts found in the choroid plexus within the lateral cerebral ventricles of the developing fetus at 14 to 24 weeks gestation. Imaging of the choroid plexus is performed in the transverse plane of the fetal head at the same level that the lateral cerebral ventricle is evaluated. The choroid plexus should be inspected bilaterally for the presence of cysts. The size of CPCs is not of clinical relevance (PMID:16100637).

A short humerus length is defined as a length below the 2.5th percentile for gestational age or as a measurement less than 0.9 of that predicted by the measured biparietal diameter. The humerus should be measured with the bone perpendicular to the ultrasound beam and with epiphyseal cartilages visible but not included in the measurement (PMID:16100637).
An abnormality of the malleus, an ossicle in the middle ear.
Ingrowth of new blood vessels into the cornea.
Mitral stenosis with congenital onset.

Truncus arteriosus (single great artery leaving the base of the heart, giving rise to the coronary, pulmonary, and systemic arteries) with each pulmonary artery arising separate from each other on the posterior or lateral aspect of the truncus.

Truncus arteriosus (single great artery leaving the base of the heart, giving rise to the coronary, pulmonary, and systemic arteries) whereby the aortic arch is hypoplastic or interrupted, and a large patent ductus arteriosus is present.
Abnormal outpouching or sac-like dilatation of one of the anatomic dilations of the ascending aorta, which occurs just above the aortic valve.

JT: 心房リエントリ性頻拍
原発性高アルドステロン症
DEF: A form of hyperaldosteronism caused by a defect within the adrenal gland.

JT: 二次性副腎皮質機能亢進症
DEF: Hypercortisolemia associated with a overproduction of ACTH (often from a tumor), leading secondarily to overproduction of cortisol.
An abnormal growth of parafollicular (C-cells) cells.
Absence of the normal opening of the choana (the posterior nasal aperture) as a result of an obstructing choanal membrane that may be thin and strandlike or thick and pluglike.
Absence of the usual parallel position of philtral ridges.
Abnormality of the oral mucosa.
Delayed maturation and calcification of the talus.
Any anomaly in the formation of bone or of a bony substance, or the conversion of fibrous tissue or of cartilage into bone or a bony substance.
Decreased activity of coagulation factor IX. Factor IX, which itself is activated by factor Xa or factor VIIa to form factor IXa, activates factor X into factor Xa.
Decreased activity of coagulation factor IX. Factor IX, which itself is activated by factor Xa or factor VIIa to form factor IXa, activates factor X into factor Xa.
Any anomaly in the function of thrombocytes.
An anomaly of alpha or dense granules or platelet lysosomes.
Bleeding beneath the mucous membrane that lines the inner surface of the eyelid.
Abnormally flat shape of the heads of the metacarpal bones.

A type of pleural effusion with a exudate (extravascular fluid that has exuded out of a tissue or its capillaries due to injury or inflammation). Pleural effusions can be classified as transudates or exudates based on Light's criteria, which classify an effusion as exudate if one or more of the following are present: (1) the ratio of pleural fluid protein to serum protein is greater than 0.5, (2) the ratio of pleural fluid lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) to serum LDH is greater than 0.6, or (3) the pleural fluid LDH level is greater than two thirds of the upper limit of normal for serum LDH.
Abnormal outpouching or sac-like dilatation in the wall of the inferior mesenteric artery or superior mesenteric artery .
Acute inflammation of the lung due to an infection.
An acute episode of pneumonia due to the aspiration (breathing in) of food, liquid, or gastric contents into the upper respiratory tract.
An increased concentration of citrulline in the blood.

Increased activity of coagulation factor V, Factor V, which is activated to factor Va by means of minute amounts of thrombin (and inactivated by larger amounts of thrombin). Activated factor V (fVa) is a cofactor in the formation of the prothrombinase complex.
Abnormally increased level of blood lactate following a meal.
An increased concentration of glucose in the blood following a meal.

A type of cutaneous melanoma localized to the palm, sole, or beneath the nail (subungual melanoma). Acral lentiginous melanoma starts as a slowly-enlarging flat patch of discoloured skin and usually displays a size above 6 mm and often several centimetres or more in diameter upon diagnosis and variable pigmentation with a mixutre of colors including brown, and blue-grey, black and red. The surface of the lesion is initially smooth but later in the course may become thicker and irregular, and may ulcerate or bleed.
Dislocation of many joints.

JT: 血清クレアチニン減少
DEF: An abnormally reduced amount of creatinine in the blood.
Atrophy of the occipital cortex.
Increased width of the cross sectional diameter of the fibula.
Habitual repetitive movement of the body.
A type of T-cell lymphoma that exhibits malignant infiltration of the skin.

JT: 若年性結腸ポリープ症
DEF: The presence of more than 5 juvenile polyps of the colon. The term juvenile polyps refer to a special histopathology and not the age of onset as the polyp might be diagnosed at all ages. The juvenile polyp has a spherical appearance and is microscopically characterized by overgrowth of an oedematous lamina propria with inflammatory cells and cystic glands.

JT: プロトロンビンの異常
DEF: An anomaly of clotting factor II, which is known as prothrombin, a vitamin K-dependent proenzyme that functions in the blood coagulation cascade.

JT: 胞巣状軟部横紋筋肉腫
DEF: A type of soft tissue sarcoma with a histological appearance reminiscent of alveoli because of its reticulated fibrous stroma enclosing groups of sarcoma cells, which resemble epithelial cells and are enclosed in alveoli walled with connective tissue.
Anomaly of primary or secondary sexual development or characteristics.
An abnormality of the malar surface of the zygomatic bone and including the frontal process of maxilla.
The deposition of calcium salts in the parenchyma of the renal medulla (innermost part of the kidney).
A failure to meet one or more age-related milestones of social behavior.
Inflammation of the synovial membrane of the sacroiliac joint.

JT: 急性呼吸性アシドーシス
DEF: Sudden onset of impairment in ventilation such that the removal of carbon dioxide by the respiratory system is less than the production of carbon dioxide in the tissues, leading to an elevation of the partial pressure of carbon dioxide (PaCO2) above the normal limits (more than 45 mm Hg) with an accompanying acidemia (pH less than 7.35).

An ophthalmologic sign in young children resulting from upward-gaze paresis. In this condition, the eyes appear driven downward, the sclera may be seen between the upper eyelid and the iris, and part of the lower pupil may be covered by the lower eyelid.

An arachnoid cyst that progressively enlarges from an abnormality in the membrane of Liliequist or in the interpeduncular cistern, and typically, expands from the prepontine space, displacing the floor of the third ventricle upwards, the pituitary stalk and optic chiasm upwards and forwards, and the mammillary bodies upwards and backwards.
A pale yellow discoloration of the temporal (lateral) portion of the optic disc.
An anomalous location and arrangement of platelet alpha granules.
A structural anomaly of the nephron.
Two sided hypoplasia of the kidney.

JT: 傍シルビウス裂多小脳回
DEF: Polymicrogyria (an excessive number of small gyri or convolutions) that is maximal in perisylvian regions (the regions that surround the Sylvian fissures), which may be symmetric or asymmetric and may extend beyond perisylvian regions. The Sylvian fissures often extend posteriorly and superiorly.
Decreased concentration of dopamine in the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF).
An abnormal build up of iron (Fe) in brain tissue.
Accumulation of calcium salts in the pineal gland.
An increase in size of the anatomic space between the arachnoid membrane and pia mater.

JT: 異常なニューロン形態
DEF: A structural anomaly of a neuron.
A type of hearing impairment affecting primarily the middle frequencies of sound (1000 Hz to 3000 Hz).
A type of nephrogenic rest associated with multiple lesions in the periphery of the renal lobe.
Increased number or density of the folded ridges (wrinkles) of skin of the scrotum.
Decreased number or density of the folded ridges (wrinkles) of skin of the scrotum.
The presence of a supernumerary Fallopian tube.
A cystic tumor of the ovary, containing thin, clear, yellow serous fluid and varying amounts of solid tissue.
Slowed relaxation of muscles in the leg.
Slowed relaxation of muscles in the arm.
An anomalous configuration of blood vessels that shunts arterial blood directly into veins without passing through the capillaries.
Ectopic respiratory epithelium presenting as a superficial lesion in the skin usually localised unilateral in the skin of the forearm and associated with ipsilateral hand malformations.
An abnormality of the structure or form of the tendons, also often called sinews.
Diffuse unlocalised atrophy affecting the cerebellum.
The presence of reduced conduction velocity of motor nerves on electromyography.
Fusion involving carpal and metacarpal bones.
Presence of small, permanently dilated blood vessels near the surface of the skin, visible as small focal red lesions.
Optic neuritis that occurs in the section of the optic nerve located behind the eyeball.
The presence of Neurofibromas in the subcutis.
A form of loss of vision caused by damage to the visual cortex rather than a defect in the eye.
An abnormality of the tonsils.
A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the middle ear.
Abnormal anatomical location of the stomach. This feature may be due to intestinal malrotation.
Absence of the musculature.
An abnormality of a facial vein.

A structural anomaly of the hypopharyx, which is the most inferior portion of the pharynx. The hypopharynx continues from the oropharynx at the pharyngoepiglottic fold superiorly and extends inferiorly to the level of the inferior aspect of the cricoid cartilage, which marks the beginning of the cervical esophagus.
The presence of a gonadoblastoma of the testis.

JT: 性別不明の外性器,男性
DEF: Ambiguous genitalia in an individual with XY genetic gender.
An anomaly of the testicle (the male gonad).
Lack of external genitalia in a male or female individual.
An abnormality of the ureter. The ureter is the duct by which urine passes from the kidney to the bladder.
An abnormality of the kidney.
A unilateral form of agenesis of the kidney.

Abnormal function of the renal tubule. The basic functional unit of the kidney, the nephron, consists of a renal corpuscle attached to a renal tubule, with roughly 0.8 to 1.5 nephrons per adult kidney. The functions of the renal tubule include reabsorption of water, electrolytes, glucose, and amino acids and secretion of substances such as uric acid.
An abnormality of the uterus.
Any structural abnormality of the vagina.
Any abnormality of the tongue.
Any abnormality of the palate, i.e., of roof of the mouth.

Increased thickness of the lower lip, leading to a prominent appearance of the lower lip. The height of the vermilion of the lower lip in the midline is more than 2 SD above the mean. Alternatively, an apparently increased height of the vermilion of the lower lip in the frontal view (subjective).

Height of the vermilion of the upper lip in the midline more than 2 SD above the mean. Alternatively, an apparently increased height of the vermilion of the upper lip in the frontal view (subjective).
Abnormally decreased size of the anterior fontanelle with respect to age-dependent norms.
Any abnormality of the size of the skull.

Abnormally small dimension of the Maxilla. Usually creating a malocclusion or malalignment between the upper and lower teeth or resulting in a deficient amount of projection of the base of the nose and lower midface region.
Abnormal location of the ear.
Thinned, deficient, or excessively arched ala nasi.
A structural abnormality of the retina.
Any abnormality of the cornea, which is the transparent tissue at the front of the eye that covers the iris, pupil, and anterior chamber.
An abnormality of the eyelids.
An abnormality of the choroid and retina.
An abnormality in the process of focusing of light by the eye in order to produce a sharp image on the retina.
Reduced ability to move the eye in the direction of the nose.
An abnormality of the sclera.
An impaired ability of the eye to move in the outward direction (towards the side of the head).
Difficulty with discriminating red and green hues.
Delayed tooth eruption, which can be defined as tooth eruption more than 2 SD beyond the mean eruption age.
Radiolucency (reflecting a reduction in the bony substance) around the apex (the tip of the dental root).
Developmental dysplasia of dentin.

JT: フラストレーション耐性低下
DEF: The feeling of frustration can be defined as an emotional reaction that occurs if a desired goal is not achieved. Frustration intolerance is defined as an age-inappropriate response to frustration characterized by crying or temper tantrums (in children) or aggressive or other undesirable behaviors.
Any abnormality of the thorax (the region of the body formed by the sternum, the thoracic vertebrae and the ribs).
An abnormality of the breast.
Abnormality of the thymus, an organ located in the upper anterior portion of the chest cavity just behind the sternum and whose main function is to provide an environment for T lymphocyte maturation.
The presence of uric acid-containing calculi (stones) in the kidneys.
Insufficient production of growth hormone, which is produced by the anterior pituitary gland. Growth hormone is a major participant in control of growth and metabolism.

JT: 先天性甲状腺機能低下症
DEF: A type of hypothyroidism with congenital onset.
Pectus carinatum affecting primarily the superior part of the sternum.
An abnormal appearance of the long bones with resemblance to a dumbbell, a short bar with a weight at each end. That is, the long bone is shortened and displays flaring (widening) of the metaphyses.
Atypically scarred skin .
An abnormality of the biliary tree.
Any structural abnormality of the fundus of the eye.
A structural abnormality of the macula lutea, which is an oval-shaped highly pigmented yellow spot near the center of the retina.

JT: 格子性角膜ジストロフィー
DEF: The presence of fine, branching linear opacities in Bowman's layer in the central area that may spread to the periphery in the clinical course. The deep corneal stroma may be involved but the process does not reach Descemet's membrane. Recurrent corneal erosion may occur. Histologic examination reveals amyloid deposits in the collagen fibers of the cornea.

Supernumerary digits located at the radial side of the hand. Polydactyly (supernumerary digits) involving the thumb occurs in many distinct forms of high variability and severity. Ranging from fleshy nubbins over varying degrees of partial duplication/splitting to completely duplicated or even triplicated thumbs or preaxial (on the radial side of the hand) supernumerary digits.
A chronic loss of wrist joint motion due to structural changes in muscle, tendons, ligaments, or skin that prevent normal movement of the joints of the wrist.

A congenital brain malformation typically characterized by incomplete formation of the cerebellar vermis, dilation of the fourth ventricle, and enlargement of the posterior fossa. In layman's terms, Dandy Walker malformation is a cyst in the cerebellum (typically symmetrical) that is involved with the fourth ventricle. This may interfere with the ability to drain cerebrospinal fluid from the brain, resulting in hydrocephalus. Dandy Walker cysts are formed during early embryonic development, while the brain forms. The cyst in the cerebellum typically has several blood vessels running through it connecting to the brain, thereby prohibiting surgical removal.
An abnormal structure or form of the joints, i.e., one or more of the articulations where two bones join.

A mode of inheritance that is observed for traits related to a gene encoded on the mitochondrial genome. Because the mitochondrial genome is essentially always maternally inherited, a mitochondrial condition can only be transmitted by females, although the condition can affect both sexes. The proportion of mutant mitochondria can vary (heteroplasmy).

JT: 在胎月齢より小さい児
DEF: Smaller than normal size according to sex and gestational age related norms, defined as a weight below the 10th percentile for the gestational age.

JT: 在胎月齢より大きい児
DEF: The term large for gestational age applies to babies whose birth weight lies above the 90th percentile for that gestational age.
Infections of the skin that happen multiple times.
An abnormality of the larynx.
Any structural anomaly of the heart.
A hole between the two bottom chambers (ventricles) of the heart. The defect is centered around the most superior aspect of the ventricular septum.
A type of supraventricular tachycardia in which the atria are the principal site of electrophysiologic disturbance.

Reduced ability of the right ventricle to perform its function (to receive blood from the right atrium and to eject blood into the pulmonary artery), often leading to pitting peripheral edema, ascites, and hepatomegaly.
An abnormality of the spleen.
A type of hydrops fetalis in which there is no identifiable circulating antibody to red blood cell antigens .
Duplication of all or part of the first ray.
This term applies for all abnormalities of the big toe, also called hallux.

JT: 遠位指趾関節癒合症(足)

DEF: An abnormality of leukocytes.
Abnormal increased number of megaloblasts in the bone marrow.
Absence or hypoplasia of toes.
An abnormaltiy of the rectum, the final segment of the large intestine that stores solid waste until it passes through the anus.
An abnormality of the pulmonary pleura, the thin, transparent membrane which covers the lungs and lines the inside of the chest walls.
Atrophy of the cortex of the cerebrum.
Development of gray hair at a younger than normal age.
Progressively reduced or lacking hair growth.
Compression of the spinal cord in the cervical region, generally manifested by paresthesias and numbness, weakness, difficulty walking, abnormalities of coordination, and neck pain or stiffness.
Loss of previously present mental and motor abilities.
A delay in the acquisition of the ability to use language to communicate needs, wishes, or thoughts.
Presence of a thickened, fibrotic pericardium that forms a non-compliant shell around the heart, and resulting from chronic inflammation of the pericardium.
An abnormal connection (fistula) between the esophagus and the trachea.
An abnormality of the radius.
An increased concentration of all types of amino acid in the urine.
An abnormal reduction in sensation in the distal portions of the extremities.
An abnormal accentuation of the inward curvature of the spine in the lumbar region.
A chronic loss of elbow joint motion due to structural changes in muscle, tendons, ligaments, or skin that prevent normal movement of the joints of the elbow.
An anomaly of the calf bone (fibula), one of the two bones of the calf.
A increased concentration of serotonin in the blood.
Increased concentration of taurine in the urine.

JT: メチルコバラミンの減少
DEF: Decreased concentration of methylcobalamin. Methylcobalamin is a form of vitamin B12.
Decreased activity of coagulation factor V.
Decreased activity of coagulation factor V.

Hepatic failure refers to the inability of the liver to perform its normal synthetic and metabolic functions, which can result in coagulopathy and alteration in the mental status of a previously healthy individual. Hepatic failure is defined as fulminant if there is onset of encephalopathy within 4 weeks of the onset of symptoms in a patient with a previously healthy liver.
Excessive growth of the craniofacial bones.

Reduced strength of the frontalis muscle (which is located on the forehead).

Cysts of microscopic size confined to the cortex of the kidney.

An atypical absence seizure is a type of generalised non-motor (absence) seizure characterised by interruption of ongoing activities and reduced responsiveness. In comparison to a typical absence seizure, changes in tone may be more pronounced, onset and/or cessation may be less abrupt, and the duration of the ictus and post-ictal recovery may be longer. Although not always available, an EEG often demonstrates slow (<3 Hz), irregular, generalized spike-wave activity.
