An abnormality of the clivus, which is the inclined bony region of the posterior cranial fossa located between the sella turcica and the foramen magnum.
Absence or underdevelopment of the toenail.
Absence of the premaxilla, which is the embryonic structure that forms the anterior part of the maxilla.
Oral commissures positioned superior to the midline labial fissure.
Gentle upward curve of the upper lip vermilion such that the center is placed well superior to the commissures.
A kind of breech presentation in which the hips are flexed and the knees are extended.

A joint disorder caused by blood deprivation in the subchondral bone causing the subchondral bone to die in a process called avascular necrosis. The bone is then reabsorbed by the body, leaving the articular cartilage it supported prone to damage. The result is fragmentation (dissection) of both cartilage and bone, and the free movement of these osteochondral fragments within the joint space, causing pain and further damage.
Absence of the nasal bone.
The presence of a dilated urinary bladder.

An abnormal functioning of phagocytosis. Phagocytosis is an elegant but complex process for the ingestion and elimination of pathogens, but it is also important for the elimination of apoptotic cells and hence fundamental for tissue homeostasis. Phagocytosis can be divided into four main steps: (i) recognition of the target particle, (ii) signaling to activate the internalization machinery, (iii) phagosome formation, and (iv) phagolysosome maturation.
Aplasia or developmental hypoplasia of the cervical vertebral column.
A generalized form of periodontitis.
The presence of a supernumerary, i.e., extra, tooth or teeth.
An abnormal conical morphology of either maxillary primary incisor tooth or maxillary permanent incisor tooth or both.

A condition characterized by necrosis of the mucosal and submucosal layers of the esophagus not related to ingestion of caustic or other injurious agents. Endoscopically, there is a dark lesion ('black esophagus') distributed in a circumferential manner in the distal one-third of the esophagus with or without exudates. There is involvement of the distal esophagus ending sharply at the gastroesophageal junction.
Absence or developmental hypoplasia of the sweat glands.

JT: ミオクローヌス性無緊張性発作
DEF: A generalized myoclonic-atonic seizure is a type of generalized motor seizure characterized by a myoclonic jerk followed by an atonic motor component.
Vertical soft tissue creases in the midline of the forehead, often extending from the hairline to the brow, and seen with facial expression or when the face is at rest.
Reduction in the anterosuperior prominence of the area between the bottom of the incisura and the inner margin of the antihelix.
Curving course of the crus of the helix, approaching or joining the antitragus.
The absence of a phalangeal segment of a finger.
Formation of excess fibrous connective tissue in the tunica intima (innermost layer) of arteries.
Absence or underdevelopment of the cochlea, a spiral shaped cavity in the inner ear, owing to a developmental defect.
An abnormally low concentration of serum PAPP-A (pregnancy associated plasma protein A), as compared to normal values for gestational-age.
Absence or underdevelopment of the gallbladder.
A developmental anomaly characterized by abnormal smallness of one eye.
Developmental abnormality in which the lens and cornea are not separated.
Increased amount of pigmentation in the macula lutea.

A benign tumor of the retina that appears as a grouping of blood-filled saccules within the inner retinal layers or on the surface of the optic disc. Retinal cavernous angioma are described as having a 'cluster of grapes' appearance.
An abnormal shape of the lens.

A type of ventricular septal defect communicating directly between the left ventricle and right atrium. This is anatomically possible because the normal tricuspid valve is more apically displaced than the mitral valve.

A conduction block of the right branch of the bundle of His. This manifests as a prolongation of the QRS complex (greater than 0.12 s) with delayed activation of the right ventricle and terminal delay on the EKG.
A type of papillary renal cell carcinoma that is characterized by small cuboidal cells covering thin papillae with a single line of uniform nuclei and small nucleoli.
Decreased intensity of the patellar reflex (also known as the knee jerk reflex).
H-shaped crease in the fat pad of the chin.
Pit in the midline of the philtral groove.

Hemoglobin F (HbF) contains two globin alpha chains and two globin gamma chains. It is the main form of hemoglobin in the fetus during the last seven months of intrauterine development and in the half year of postnatal life. In adults it normally makes up less than one percent of all hemoglobin. This term refers to an increase in HbF above this limit. In beta thalassemia major, it may represent over 90 percent of all hemoglobin, and in beta thalassemia minor it may make up between 0.5 to 4 percent.

Hemoglobin A (HbA) contains two globin alpha chains and two globin beta chains. HbA is normally the main adult hemoglobin, representing about 96-98 percent of all hemoglobin. This term represents a decreased in the proportion of HbA below this limit, and can be seen in various forms of thalassemia.
Missing radius bone on one side only associated with congenital failure of development.
Underdeveloped nails of the fifth toes.
Increased concentration of SO3(2-), i.e., sulfite, in the urine.

Absence of any measurable level of sperm in his semen, due to a hypothalamic or pituitary abnormality diagnosed with hypo-gonadotropic-hypogonadism. The diagnosis is made on the basis of low LH and FSH levels and low or normal testosterone levels.
An increased concentration of dopamine in the urine.

JT: 頭蓋内類皮嚢胞(デルモイド嚢胞)
DEF: A congenital inclusion cysts that arises from the inclusion of ectodermally committed cells at the time of neural tube closure (3rd-5th week of embryogenesis). The capsule of dermoid cysts consists of simple epithelium supported by collagen. In thicker parts, the lining is supplemented with dermis containing hair follicles, sebaceous glands, and apocrine glands.
Atrophy of the parietal cortex.

JT: 四肢近位短縮性下肢短縮
DEF: Disproportionate shortening of the proximal segment of the leg (i.e. the femur).
A separation (dissection) of the layers of the carotid artery wall.
An elevated concentration of high-density lipoprotein cholesterol (HDL) in the blood.
A type of T-cell lymphoma that exhibits malignant infiltration of the skin.

An abnormal pattern of respiration characterized by cycles of respiration that are increasingly deeper then shallower with possible periods of apnea. Affected patients may display a 10 to 20 second episode of hypoventilation or apnea, followed by respiration of increased depth and frequency over the course of about one minute. The cycle repeats every 45 seconds to 3 minutes.
Any structural anomaly of the kidney.
An abnormal functionality of the kidney.
The deposition of calcium phosphate microliths within the seminiferous tubules.
The presence of multiple hemangiomas in the arachnoid.

Any anomaly of the normal motility of motile cilia. Evaluation of ciliary beat frequency and ciliary beat pattern requires high-speed videomicroscopy of freshly obtained ciliary biopsies that are maintained in culture media under controlled conditions.
A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the head and neck region with origin in the lip, oral cavity, nasal cavity, paranasal sinuses, pharynx, or larynx.
An anomaly of the process of rib bone formation.
Compression of the celiac artery.
The deposition of calcium salts in the parenchyma of the renal cortex (the outer portion of the kidney between the renal capsule and the renal medulla).

JT: びまん性視神経杯蒼白
DEF: A pale yellow discoloration of the entire optic disc.
An abnormally decreased amount of catalase level.
A lack of platelet alpha granules. This typically results in the grey appearance of platelets in giemsa stained blood smears.
A bilateral form of developmental dysplasia of the kidney.
Elevated concentration of SO4(2-), i.e., sulfate, in the urine.
Increase in size of a peripheral nerve. This finding can be appreciated by palpation along the axis of the nerve.
A diminution of the volumetric fraction of blood pumped out of the ventricle with each cardiac cycle.
A reduction in the quantity of space occupied by the thalamus.
A severe form of hearing impairment.
Absence of a testis from the scrotum on one side owing to failure of the testis or testes to descend through the inguinal canal to the scrotum.

ET: Abnormal upper to lower segment ratio
DEF: A deviation from normal of the relation between the upper and the lower segment of the body, where the lower segment is defined as the length between the top of pubic symphysis to floor, and the upper segment is defined as the top of head to top of pubic symphysis.

ET: Reduced upper to lower segment ratio
DEF: Decreased ratio between the upper and the lower segment of the body, where the lower segment is defined as the length between the top of pubic symphysis to floor, and the upper segment is defined as the top of head to top of pubic symphysis. Consider the term Disproportionate tall stature (HP:0001519) if tall stature is also present.

ET: Increased upper to lower segment ratio
DEF: Elevated ratio between the upper and the lower segment of the body, where the lower segment is defined as the length between the top of pubic symphysis to floor, and the upper segment is defined as the top of head to top of pubic symphysis.
A benign or malignant neoplasm arising from the lymphatic vessels.
The narrowing or partial blockage of a portion of the small intestine.
Bleeding from the small intestine.
Hepatic fibrosis that reaches from a portal area to another portal area.
Increased pigmentation (skin color) of the scrotum.
Anomaly of the folded ridges (wrinkles) of skin of the scrotum.
A structural anomaly of sperm.
Overgrowth of the outer labia.
Hypertrophy of one or more muscles innervated by the facial nerve (the seventh cranial nerve).
An Abnormality of cortical bone leading to an abnormal thickness of the cortex of affected bones.

Juvenile aseptic necrosis comprises a group of orthopedic diseases characterized by interruption of the blood supply of a bone, followed by localized bony necrosis most often of the epiphyses of bones of children or teenagers.

DEF: An abnormal morphology of the distal phalanx of the fifth toe, with a short and wide phalanx that tapers distally. Bullet-shaped phalanges lack the normal diaphyseal constriction.

Any structural anomaly of mast cells, which are found in almost all tissues and contain numerous basophilic granules and are capable of releasing large amounts of histamine and heparin upon activation.
An abnormality of fascia.
Unilateral atrophy (reduction in size) of a leg.
Unilateral atrophy (reduction in size) of an arm.
A partial or complete positional exchange between the penis and the scrotum, with positioning of the scrotum superior to the penis.
The presence of many cysts in the glomerulus of the kidney related to dilatation of the Bowman's capsule.
An anomaly of the color of the nail.
Formation of abnormal lobules (small masses of tissue) in the liver.

Symmetrical vermiform facial atrophy that affects mainly the forehead, the chin, the ear lobes and helices. Atrophodermia vermiculata is characterized by erythema and follicular plugs on the cheeks, developing into painless reticular impressions.

DEF: Thickening of the heart walls in both ventricles.
An abnormality of a hyoid bone.

A mode of inheritance that is observed for traits related to a gene encoded on one of the autosomes (i.e., the human chromosomes 1-22) in which a trait manifests in heterozygotes. In the context of medical genetics, an autosomal dominant disorder is caused when a single copy of the mutant allele is present. Males and females are affected equally, and can both transmit the disorder with a risk of 50% for each child of inheriting the mutant allele.

A mode of inheritance that is observed for traits related to a gene encoded on one of the autosomes (i.e., the human chromosomes 1-22) in which a trait manifests in individuals with two pathogenic alleles, either homozygotes (two copies of the same mutant allele) or compound heterozygotes (whereby each copy of a gene has a distinct mutant allele).
Repeated infections of the urinary tract.
Underdevelopment of the uterus.
The presence of a gonadoblastoma of the testis.
Underdevelopment of part or all of the male external reproductive organs (which include the penis, the scrotum and the urethra).
An anomaly of the labia, the externally visible portions of the vulva.
Undergrowth of the outer labia.

A genital phenotype that is not clearly assignable to a single gender. Ambiguous genitalia can be evaluated using the Prader scale: Prader 0: Normal female external genitalia. Prader 1: Female external genitalia with clitoromegaly. Prader 2: Clitoromegaly with partial labial fusion forming a funnel-shaped urogenital sinus. Prader 3: Increased phallic enlargement. Complete labioscrotal fusion forming a urogenital sinus with a single opening. Prader 4: Complete scrotal fusion with urogenital opening at the base or on the shaft of the phallus. Prader 5: Normal male external genitalia. The diagnosis of ambiguous genitalia is made for Prader 1-4.
Congenital anomaly characterized by closure or failure to develop an opening in the urethra in females.

Nephrotic syndrome is a collection of findings resulting from glomerular dysfunction with an increase in glomerular capillary wall permeability associated with pronounced proteinuria. Nephrotic syndrome refers to the constellation of clinical findings that result from severe renal loss of protein, with Proteinuria and hypoalbuminemia, edema, and hyperlipidemia.
The presence of multiple cysts in both kidneys.

Abnormal function of the renal tubule. The basic functional unit of the kidney, the nephron, consists of a renal corpuscle attached to a renal tubule, with roughly 0.8 to 1.5 nephrons per adult kidney. The functions of the renal tubule include reabsorption of water, electrolytes, glucose, and amino acids and secretion of substances such as uric acid.
High urine potassium in the presence of hypokalemia.
An abnormality of the ovary.
An abnormality of head and neck.
An abnormality of the mouth.
Any abnormality of the teeth.
Abnormality of the uvula, the conic projection from the posterior edge of the middle of the soft palate.
An abnormality of the upper lip.
An abnormality of the lower lip.
Telangiectasia (that is, the presence of small dilated superficial blood vessels) of the lips.
Height of the vermilion of the upper lip in the midline more than 2 SD below the mean. Alternatively, an apparently reduced height of the vermilion of the upper lip in the frontal view (subjective).
Height of the vermilion of the upper lip in the midline more than 2 SD below the mean. Alternatively, an apparently reduced height of the vermilion of the upper lip in the frontal view (subjective).
Presence of telangiectases in the oral cavity.

An abnormal configuration of the lower lip such that it is turned outward i.e., everted, with the Inner aspect of the lower lip vermilion (normally opposing the teeth) being visible in a frontal view.
Progressive microcephaly is diagnosed when the head circumference falls progressively behind age- and gender-dependent norms.
An increased amount of subcutaneous fat tissue in the face.
Loss of normal subcutaneous fat tissue in the face.

A type of abnormal location of the ears in which the position of the ears is characterized by posterior rotation (the superior part of the ears is rotated towards the back of the head, and the inferior part of the ears towards the front).
An abnormality of the pinna, which is also referred to as the auricle or external ear.
A type of hearing loss resulting from a combination of conductive hearing impairment and sensorineural hearing impairment.
Decreased distance from the nasal tip to the nasal base.
Lack of prominence of the nose resulting from a posteriorly-placed nasal ridge.
An abnormality of the fovea centralis, the central area of the macula that mediates central, high resolution vision and contains the largest concentration of cone cells in the retina.
The presence of recurrent corneal epithelial erosions. Although most corneal epithelial defects heal quickly, some may show recurrent ulcerations.
The presence of small (ca. 0.5-1.0 mm) dilated blood vessels near the surface of the mucous membranes of the conjunctiva.
Paralysis of the external ocular muscles.
Any deviation from the normal motor coordination of the eyes that allows for bilateral fixation on a single object.
A cleft of the optic nerve that extends inferiorly.
Initial bilateral ptosis followed by limitation of eye movements in all directions and slowing of saccades.
Reduced depth of the anterior chamber, i.e., the anteroposterior distance between the cornea and the iris is decreased.
An abnormality of the pupil.
A short discontinuity of the margin of the upper eyelid.
A short discontinuity of the margin of the lower eyelid.
An abnormality of the dental enamel.
A grey discoloration of the dental enamel.
Agenesis of one or more maxillary lateral incisor, comprising the maxillary lateral primary incisor and maxillary lateral secondary incisor.

A structural abnormality of the peripheral nervous system, which is composed of the nerves that lead to or branch off from the central nervous system. This includes the cranial nerves (olfactory and optic nerves are technically part of the central nervous system).
Progressive deterioration of peripheral axons.
Underdevelopment of the thymus.
The presence of xanthine-containing calculi (stones) in the kidneys.
The presence of xanthine-containing calculi (stones) in the kidneys.
A severe form of hypospadias in which the urethral opening is located at the junction of the penis and scrotum.
Deficiency of thyroid hormone.

JT: 下垂体前葉機能低下症
DEF: A condition of reduced function of the anterior pituitary gland characterized by decreased secretion of one or more of the pituitary hormones growth hormone, thyroid-stimulating hormone, adrenocorticotropic hormone, prolactin, luteinizing hormone, and follicle-stimulating hormone.
An abnormality of thyroid physiology characterized by excessive secretion of the thyroid hormones thyroxine (i.e., T4) and/or 3,3',5-triiodo-L-thyronine zwitterion (i.e., triiodothyronine or T3).
An increased concentration of insulin in the blood.

JT: 偽性副甲状腺機能低下症
DEF: A condition characterized by resistance to the action of parathyroid hormone, in which there is hypocalcemia, hyperphosphatemia, and (appropriately) high levels of parathyroid hormone.
Increased resistance towards insulin, that is, diminished effectiveness of insulin in reducing blood glucose levels.
Abnormally high variation in the amount of time between periods.
Malformation of the rib cage.
Abnormal outward curving (protuberance) of the junction of ribs and costal cartilage.
The presence of wide, concave anterior rib ends.
Pectus excavatum (defect of the chest wall characterized by depression of the sternum) affecting primarily the inferior region of the sternum.

Any anomaly of the costochondral junction. The costochondral junctions are located between the distal part of the ribs and the costal cartilages, which are bars of hyaline cartilage that connect the ribs to the sternum.
An abnormality of the skull, the bony framework of the head which is comprised of eight cranial and fourteen facial bones.
An abnormal appearance of the long bones with resemblance to a dumbbell, a short bar with a weight at each end. That is, the long bone is shortened and displays flaring (widening) of the metaphyses.
Abnormal thickening of the skin of the palms of the hands and the soles of the feet.
Atypically scarred skin .
A oval and round, colored (usually medium-to dark brown, reddish brown, or flesh colored) lesion. Typically, a melanocytic nevus is less than 6 mm in diameter, but may be much smaller or larger.
An abnormality of the dermatoglyphs, i.e., an abnormality of the patterns of ridges of the skin of palm of hand.
A hyperpigmented circumscribed area of change in normal skin color without elevation or depression of any size.

Atopic dermatitis (AD) or atopic eczema is an itchy, inflammatory skin condition with a predilection for the skin flexures. It is characterized by poorly defined erythema with edema, vesicles, and weeping in the acute stage and skin thickening (lichenification) in the chronic stage.

A developmental defect resulting in the congenital absence of skin in multiple or solitary non-inflammatory, well-demarcated, oval or circular ulcers with a diameter of about 1 to 2 cm. Aplasia cutis congenita most commonly occurs on the scalp, but may present in the face, trunk, or limbs.

Irregular lines in the deep retina that are typically configured in a radiating fashion and emanate from the optic disc. Angioid streaks are crack-like dehiscences in abnormally thickened and calcified Bruch's membrane, resulting in atrophy of the overlying retinal pigment epithelium. They may be associated with a number of endocrine, metabolic, and connective tissue abnormalities but are frequently idiopathic.

DEF: A polar cataract that affects the posterior pole of the lens.

A benign tumor typically found at the junction of the cornea and sclera (limbal epibullar dermoid).
Severe reduction of the ability to see defined as visual acuity less than 6/60 (20/200 in US notation; 0.1 in decimal notation) but at least 3/60 (20/400 in US notation; 0.05 in decimal notation).
An abnormal structure of the first digit of the hand.

Involuntary movements characterized by both athetosis (inability to sustain muscles in a fixed position) and chorea (widespread jerky arrhythmic movements).

Muscular hypotonia (abnormally low muscle tone) manifesting in the neonatal period.
Absence of the septum pellucidum.
An abnormality of the liver.
A kind of neoplasm of the liver that originates in hepatocytes and presents macroscopically as a soft and hemorrhagic tan mass in the liver.
A form of hepatic steatosis characterized by the presence of large, lipid-laden vesicles in the affected hepatocytes.
Impairment of bile flow due to obstruction in the small bile ducts within the liver.
Reduced ability of the liver to perform its functions.

DEF: An abnormality of fetal movement.
An abnormal reduction in quantity or strength of fetal movements.

DEF: Hypercortisolemia associated with a primary defect of the adrenal gland leading to overproduction of cortisol.
Infections of the skin that happen multiple times.
Agenesis specifically affecting one of the classes incisor, premolar, or molar.

The presence of an abnormality of cardiac function that is responsible for the failure of the heart to pump blood at a rate that is commensurate with the needs of the tissues or a state in which abnormally elevated filling pressures are required for the heart to do so. Heart failure is frequently related to a defect in myocardial contraction.

In utero, the ductus arteriosus (DA) serves to divert ventricular output away from the lungs and toward the placenta by connecting the main pulmonary artery to the descending aorta. A patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) in the first 3 days of life is a physiologic shunt in healthy term and preterm newborn infants, and normally is substantially closed within about 24 hours after bith and completely closed after about three weeks. Failure of physiologcal closure is referred to a persistent or patent ductus arteriosus (PDA). Depending on the degree of left-to-right shunting, PDA can have clinical consequences.

Uncontrolled contractions of muscles fibers in the left ventricle not producing contraction of the left ventricle. Ventricular fibrillation usually begins with a ventricular premature contraction and a short run of rapid ventricular tachycardia degenerating into uncoordinating ventricular fibrillations.
Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy with an asymmetrical pattern of hypertrophy, with a predilection for the interventricular septum and myocyte disarray.
A congenital heart defect characteizred by a specific combination of heart defects with a common atrioventricular valve, primum atrial septal defect and inlet ventricular septal defect.
An abnormality of the aorta.
One or more of the leaflets (cusps) of the tricuspid valve bulges back into the right atrium upon contraction of the right ventricle.
Diffuse thickening of the ventricular endocardium and by associated myocardial dysfunction
A type of hydrops fetalis in which there is no identifiable circulating antibody to red blood cell antigens .

This is a postural deformity in which the foot is positioned up against the tibia. The heel (calcaneus) is positioned downward (that is, the ankle is flexed upward), and the heel is turned outward (valgus).
A widely spaced gap between the first toe (the great toe) and the second toe.
A reduced number of reticulocytes in the peripheral blood.
The presence of an increased mass of red blood cells in the circulation.
Thrombocytopenia with congenital onset.
Any structural abnormality or abnormal count of basophils.
An elevation in the number of reticulocytes (immature erythrocytes) in the peripheral blood circulation.

A type of hearing impairment prominently characterized by a difficulty in understanding speech, rather than an inability to hear speech. Poor speech discrimination is a very common symptom of high frequency hearing loss.
Any anomaly of the scalp, the skin an subcutaneous tissue of the head on which head hair grows.
An abnormality of the mesangium, i.e., of the central part of the renal glomerulus between capillaries.
A form of inflammation of the kidney affecting the interstitium of the kidneys surrounding the tubules.
The presence of an abnormal number of fragmented red blood cells (schistocytes) in the blood.
A decreased concentration of glucose in the blood associated with a reduced concentration of ketone bodies.
A decreased concentration of glucose in the blood associated with a reduced concentration of ketone bodies.
An increased concentration of ammonia in the blood.
Acidosis resulting from accumulation of ketone bodies.
Bilateral bulging of the lateral frontal bone prominences with relative sparing of the midline.

ET: Morphological abnormality of the pyramidal tract
DEF: Any structural abnormality of the pyramidal tract, whose chief element, the corticospinal tract, is the only direct connection between the brain and the spinal cord. In addition to the corticospinal tract, the pyramidal system includes the corticobulbar, corticomesencephalic, and corticopontine tracts.

A type of ataxia characterized by the impairment of the ability to perform rapidly alternating movements, such as pronating and supinating his or her hand on the dorsum of the other hand as rapidly as possible.

A type of migraine in which there is an aura characterized by focal neurological phenomena that usually proceed, but may accompany or occur in the absence of, the headache. The symptoms of an aura may include fully reversible visual, sensory, and speech symptoms but not motor weakness. Visual symptoms may include flickering lights, spots and lines and/or loss of vision and/or unilateral sensory symptoms such as paresthesias or numbness. At least one of the symptoms of an aura develops gradually over 5 or more minutes and/or different symptoms occur in succession.

Repeated headache attacks lasting 4-72 h fulfilling at least two of the following criteria: 1) unilateral location, 2) pulsating quality, 3) moderate or severe pain intensity, and 4) aggravation by or causing avoidance of routine physical activity such as climbing stairs. Headache attacks are commonly accompanied by nausea, vomiting, photophobia, or phonophobia.
Increased susceptibility to aspiration pneumonia, defined as pneumonia due to breathing in foreign material, as manifested by a medical history of repeated episodes of aspiration pneumonia.
Pneumothorax occurring without traumatic injury to the chest or lung.

A dementia associated with degeneration of the frontotemporal lobe and clinically associated with personality and behavioral changes such as disinhibition, apathy, and lack of insight. The hallmark feature of frontotemporal dementia is the presentation with focal syndromes such as progressive language dysfunction, or aphasia, or behavioral changes characteristic of frontal lobe disorders.

ET: Impaired vibration sensation in the lower limbs
DEF: A decrease in the ability to perceive vibration in the legs.
Pathological protein aggregates formed by hyperphosphorylation of a microtubule-associated protein known as tau, causing it to aggregate in an insoluble form.
Profound mental retardation is defined as an intelligence quotient (IQ) below 20.
A type of motor delay characterized by a delay in acquiring the ability to control the large muscles of the body for walking, running, sitting, and crawling.
An abnormal dilatation of the fourth cerebral ventricle.

Pseudobulbar signs result from injury to an upper motor neuron lesion to the corticobulbar pathways in the pyramidal tract. Patients have difficulty chewing, swallowing and demonstrate slurred speech (often initial presentation) as well as abnormal behavioral symptoms such as inappropriate emotional outbursts of uncontrolled laughter or weeping etc.
A focal clonic seizure is a type of focal motor seizure characterized by sustained rhythmic jerking, that is regularly repetitive.
A form of dystonia characterized by episodes of dystonia (often hemidystonia or generalized) lasting from minutes to hours. There are no dystonic symptoms between episodes.
Loss of previously present mental and motor abilities.

Lack of observable abnormal electroencephalographic (EEG) patterns in an individual with a history of seizures. About half of individuals with epilepsy show interictal epileptiform discharges upon the first investigation. The yield can be increased by repeated studies, sleep studies, or by ambulatory EEG recordings over 24 hours. Normal interictal EEG is a sign that can be useful in the differential diagnosis.
Loss of developmental skills, as manifested by loss of developmental milestones.

No consensus exists on what a stroke-like episode is, but these episodes can be functionally defined as a new neurological deficit, occurring with or without the context of seizures, which last longer than 24 hours.
Abnormality of the corticospinal tract, which is the chief element of the pyramidal system (the principle motor tract) and is the only direct connection between the cerebrum and the spinal cord.
Diffuse unlocalised atrophy affecting the cerebrum.
Diffuse unlocalised atrophy affecting the cerebrum.

Hypsarrhythmia is abnormal interictal high amplitude waves and a background of irregular spikes. There is continuous (during wakefulness), high-amplitude (>200 Hz), generalized polymorphic slowing with no organized background and multifocal spikes demonstrated by electroencephalography (EEG).
Inability to elicit tendon reflexes in the lower limbs.
Abnormal intestinal contractions, such as spasms and intestinal paralysis, related to the loss of the ability of the gut to coordinate muscular activity because of endogenous or exogenous causes.
Telangiectasia affecting the gastrointestinal tract.
Aplasia of the paranasal sinuses.
An abnormality of the process of ossification of the skull.
The presence of small (ca. 0.5-1.0 mm) dilated blood vessels near the surface of the mucous membranes of the palate.
Increased susceptibility to bacterial infections, as manifested by recurrent episodes of bacterial infection.
A chronic, relapsing, inflammatory, and often febrile multisystemic disorder of connective tissue, characterized principally by involvement of the skin, joints, kidneys, and serosal membranes.
Cleft lip and cleft palate affecting both sides of the face.
Joint hypermobility (ability of a joint to move beyond its normal range of motion) affecting many or all joints of the body.
Increased resistance to the passage of air in the upper airway.
Weakness of the cartilage in the trachea and the bronchi, resulting in a floppy (non-rigid) airway. Affected persons may have difficulties to maintain patency of the airways.
Any abnormality of bones of the arms or legs.
Any anomaly of the structure of the femur.
Increased susceptibility to fungal infections, as manifested by multiple episodes of fungal infection.
An abnormality of the ilium, the largest and uppermost bone of the pelvis.
Episodes of very rapid breathing.
A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the pancreas.
An abnormally decreased calcium concentration in the blood.
An abnormally decreased sodium concentration in the blood.
An increased amount of bilirubin in the blood.
An abnormality of chromosome segregation.
The presence in the serum of an autoantibody directed against the Fc portion of IgG.
A congenital anomaly characterized by a joining (fusion) of two or more cervical vertebral bodies with one another.
Decreased ability to react to a delayed hypersensitivity skin test.
Underdevelopment of the radius.
Abnormality of the tibia (shinbone).
Abnormality of the wrist, the structure connecting the hand and the forearm.
Metaphyseal cupping refers to an inward bulging of the metaphyseal profile giving the metaphysis a cup-like appearance.
Irregularity of the normally smooth surface of the metaphyses.
An abnormally increased calcium concentration in the blood.
Reduction in the concentration of albumin in the blood.
An increased concentration of potassium(1+) in the urine.
Small hands and feet.
An abnormal increase in the carrying angle, which is the angle he long axis of the extended forearm as it lies lateral to the long axis of the arm.

ET: Protuberances at ends of long bones
DEF: The presence of multiple protuberances (bulges, or knobs) at the ends of the long bones.

An abnormality of the spinocerebellar tracts, a set of axonal fibers originating in the spinal cord and terminating in the ipsilateral cerebellum. The spinocerebellar tract convey information to the cerebellum about limb and joint position (proprioception). They comprise the ventral spinocerebellar tract, the anterior spinocerebellar tract, and the posterior spinocerebellar tract.

JT: 汎低ガンマグロブリン血症
DEF: A reduction in the circulating levels of all the major classes of immunoglobulin. is characterized by profound decreases in all classes of immunoglobulin with an absence of circulating B lymphocytes.
An elevated concentration of low-density lipoprotein cholesterol in the blood.
An elevated urinary concentration of cystathionine.

The sacroiliac joint in the bony pelvis connects the sacrum and the ilium of the pelvis, which are joined by strong ligaments. The notch is located directly superior to the joint. This term refers to a reduction in the height of the notch.
It is characterized by one or more symptoms including sneezing, itching, nasal congestion, and rhinorrhea.

An abnormal appearance of muscle fibers observed on muscle biopsy. Ragged red fibers can be visualized with Gomori trichrome staining as irregular and intensely red subsarcolemmal zones, whereas the normal myofibrils are green. The margins of affect fibers appear red and ragged. The ragged-red is due to the accumulation of abnormal mitochondria below the plasma membrane of the muscle fiber, leading to the appearance of a red rim and speckled sarcoplasm.
An increased concentration of glutamine in the blood.
An increased concentration of ethylmalonic acid in the urine.
An abnormally increased sodium concentration in the blood.
An decreased concentration of high-density lipoprotein cholesterol in the blood.
Abnormal raised concentration of ferritin, a ubiquitous intracellular protein that stores iron, in the blood.

JT: アルカリホスファターゼ低値
DEF: Abnormally reduced serum levels of alkaline phosphatase.
A decreased concentration of leptin in the blood.
An irregular surface of the vertebral end plates, which are normally relatively smooth.
An increased concentration of threonine in the blood.
A reduction in the level of thymic horomone.
A reduction in the level of thymic horomone.
An increased concentration of tryptophan in the urine.
A left-right reversal (or \
An abnormality of the femoral neck (which is the process of bone, connecting the femoral head with the femoral shaft).
A narrowing of the sacrosciatic notch, i.e., the deep indentation in the posterior border of the hip bone at the point of union of the ilium and ischium.
Atrophic changes of axons of the peripheral nervous system.
An abnormal reduction in the amplitude of the miniature endplate potentials, i.e. the postsynaptic response to transmitter released from an individual vesicle at the neuromuscular junction.
An anomaly of the atlantoaxial joint, i.e., of the joint between the first (atlas) and second (axis) cervical vertebrae.
Partial dislocation of the atlantoaxial joint.

JT: 寒冷誘発性手けいれん(こむらがえり)

DEF: The presence of characteristic findings of denervation on electromyography (fibrillations, positive sharp waves, and giant motor unit potentials).
The presence of autoantibodies in the serum that react against neutrophils.
Abnormally increased movement at the junction between the first cervical (atlas) and the second cervical (axis) vertebrae as a result of either a bony or ligamentous anomaly.
Formation of crystals owing to an increased concentration of orotic acid in the urine.
Formation of crystals owing to an increased concentration of orotic acid in the urine.
An increased concentration of glutaric acid in the blood.
An increased concentration of pyruvate in the blood.

The term dystrophy means abnormal growth. However, muscular dystrophy is used to describe primary myopathies with a genetic basis and a progressive course characterized by progressive skeletal muscle weakness and wasting, defects in muscle proteins, and histological features of muscle fiber degeneration (necrosis) and regeneration. If possible, it is preferred to use other HPO terms to describe the precise phenotypic abnormalities.
Increased concentration of total (conjugated and unconjugated) bilirubin in the blood.
Lack of urothione (the urinary metabolite of molybdenum cofactor) in the urine.
Increased cytoplasmic staining of fibroblasts with toluidine blue.
Increased cytoplasmic staining of fibroblasts with toluidine blue.
Congenital lack of development of the muscles, which are then replaced by a mixture of dense fat and fibrous tissue.
A decreased concentration of methionine in the blood.
An abnormality in which the nuclei of sarcomeres take on an abnormally central localization (or in which this feature is found in an increased proportion of muscle cells).
Lack of strength of the proximal musculature occurring late in the clinical course.
Muscular atrophy in the distribution of shoulder girdle and peroneal muscles.
A lack of strength of the proximal muscles.
Weakness of the quadriceps muscle (that is, of the muscle fasciculus of quadriceps femoris).

The lysosomal-vacuolar pathway has a role in the controlled intracellular digestion of macromolecules such as protein complexes and organelles. This feature refers to the presence of an abnormally increased number of autophagic vacuoles in muscle tissue.
The occurrence of an unusually high amount of muscle pain following exercise.
A reduced amount of fat tissue in the lowest layer of the integument. This feature can be appreciated by a reduced skinfold thickness.
A situation in which phenotypic abnormalities become evident with age.
A delay in the process of formation and maturation of the epiphysis of one or more long bones of the upper limbs.

ET: Fragmented epiphyses of the upper limbs
Small epiphyses of the upper limbs
Cupped metaphyses of the upper limbs
Sclerosis of metaphyses of the upper limbs

DEF: Increased width (breadth) of metaphyses of the arms.
An anomaly of the humeral epiphysis.
Increased width of the humeral epiphysis.

ET: Wide epiphyses of the upper limbs

DEF: An anomaly of the humeral diaphysis.
Increased width of the humeral diaphysis.

ET: Sclerotic foci of metaphyses of the elbow
Cortical thickening of the forearm bones

DEF: Abnormal increase in width of the epiphyseal growth plate of the radius.
The presence of a splayed (i.e.,flared) metaphyseal segment of the radius.
The presence of a splayed (i.e.,flared) metaphyseal segment of the radius.
Increase in width (breadth) of the radial metaphysis.

ET: Bony spikule of ulnar epiphyseal plate

JT: 傾斜のある尺骨骨幹端
DEF: A sloped configuration of the metaphysis (shaft) of the ulna.
Increase in width (breadth) of the ulnar metaphysis.

JT: 近位に位置する月状骨

DEF: Osseous fusion of the lunate and triquetrum.
Formation of bone tissue of trapezium is less than expected for age.

ET: Delayed ossification of the trapezoid bone
DEF: Formation of bone tissue of trapezoid is less than expected for age.

ET: Subluxation of the small joints of the hand
DEF: A partial dislocation of some or all of the small joints of the hand.
A reticulocyte abnormality.
The presence of excessive redundant myelin in the peripheral nerve sheath.
Any deviation from the normal concentration of a purine in the blood circulation.
A deviation from the normal concentration of a fatty acid in the blood circulation.
An abnormality of the balance or maintenance of the balance of acids and bases in bodily fluids, resulting in an abnormal pH.
A type of dystonia that is localized to a specific part of the body.
A pathological narrowing in the region above the aortic valve associated with restricted left ventricular outflow.
An abnormality of the cheek- one of two bilateral soft tissue facial structures in the region of the face inferior to the eyes and between the nose and the ear. \

Deficiency of secretory IgA (polymers of 2-4 IgA monomers are linked by two additional chains) and is the primary antibody response at the mucosal level, where it forms immune complexes with pathogens and allergens.
Premature closure of the coronal suture of skull.
Premature closure of the coronal suture of skull.
A kind of craniosynostosis affecting the sagittal suture.
A kind of craniosynostosis affecting the lambdoidal suture.
The presence of abnormally shaped erythrocytes.
A groove of the skin immediately in front of the ear.

ET: Abnormality of the middle ear ossicles
DEF: An abnormality of the middle-ear ossicles (three small bones called malleus, incus, and stapes) that are contained within the middle ear and serve to transmit sounds from the air to the fluid-filled labyrinth (cochlea).
Lack of measurable response to stimulation of auditory evoked potentials.
The progressive development of an abnormally large skull.
Stagnation of head growth seen as flattening of the head circumference curve.
Bilateral absence (atresia) of the posterior nasal aperture (choana).
Hyperplasia of the islets of Langerhans, i.e., of the regions of the pancreas that contain its endocrine cells.
Increased bone density affecting the bones of the spine (vertebral column).
Anterior tongue-like protrusions of the vertebral bodies.
Butterfly vertebrae have a cleft through the body of the vertebrae and a funnel shape at the ends.
Increased size of the vertebral pedicle.
A progressive form of decreased height of the intervertebral disk.
Reduced size of cervical vertebrae.
Acute renal failure with resolution of manifestations.
An abnormality of the normal developmental rotation of the kidney leading to an abnormal axial orientation of the kidney.

ET: Thickening of the glomerular basement membrane
DEF: Increase in thickness of the basal lamina of the glomerulus of the kidney.
The presence of calcium-containing calculi (stones) in the kidneys.
Episodes of ventricular tachycardia that have a sudden onset and ending.
An episodic form of supraventricular tachycardia with abrupt onset and termination.
Polyp-like protrusions which are histologically hamartomas located in the stomach.
A form of hemolytic anemia with congenital onset.
A form of leukemia characterized by overproduction of an early myeloid cell.

Sudden onset of thrombocytopenia (reduced platelet count) within 5-10 days of the transfusion of blood products. The clinical presentation is post-transfusion purpura (PTP), wigth severe thrmbocytopenia, epistaxis, and hemorrhages.
The accumulation of transformed primitive hematopoietic blast cells, which lose their ability of normal differentiation and proliferation.
The accumulation of transformed primitive hematopoietic blast cells, which lose their ability of normal differentiation and proliferation.
Bleeding that persists longer than the normal time following a surgical procedure.
Reduced platelet count that occurs sporadically, i.e., it comes and goes.
An chronic form of hemolytic anemia.
Recurrent episodes of decreased concentration of glucose in the blood occurring during the infantile period.
A congenital anomaly with a narrowing or complete absence of the opening between the right ventricle and the pulmonary artery.
Excessive bending, twisting, and winding of a cerebral artery.
Calcification, that is, pathological deposition of calcium salts, affecting arteries distributed throughout the body.
An accumulation of calcium and phosphate in arteries with mineral deposits in the intimal or medial layer of the vessel wall in the thoracic aorta.
Missing radius bone on both sides associated with congenital failure of development.
Missing radius bone on both sides associated with congenital failure of development.

JT: 四肢中部短縮性下肢短縮
DEF: Shortening of the middle parts of the leg in relation to the upper and terminal segments.
Patellar dislocation occurring repeated times.
The humerus is shortened and displays flaring (widening) of the metaphyses.

JT: 四肢中部短縮性腕短縮
DEF: Shortening of the middle parts of the arm in relation to the upper and terminal segments.
Underdevelopment of the distal portion of the humerus.

ET: Shortening of all phalanges of the toes
DEF: Developmental hypoplasia (shortening) of all phalanges of the foot.
Underdevelopment of the ulna on only one side.
A dislocation of the head of the radius from its socket in the elbow joint in an anterolateral direction.
The presence of streaks (bands) of abnormally increased density of metaphyseal bone.
Absence of the proximal radial epiphysis.
Underdevelopment of the nasal septum.
Compression of the heart caused by rigid, thickened, or fused pericardial membranes.
Abnormal narrowing of the coronary artery.
Narrowing or constriction of the aorta localized proximal to the ductus arteriosus, i.e., to the preductal region of aortic arch.

JT: 好酸性顆粒細胞性心筋症
DEF: A type of cardiomyopathy characterized pathologically by hamartomatous lesions of cardiac Purkinje cells.

Total anomalous pulmonary venous return refers to a congenital malformation in which all four pulmonary veins do not connect normally to the left atrium, but instead drain abnormally to the right atrium.

Inability of the left ventricle to perform its normal physiologic function. Failure is either due to an inability to contract the left ventricle or the inability to relax completely and fill with blood during diastole.
Arteriosclerosis occurring at an age that is younger than usual.
Reduction of the diameter of the coronary arteries as the result of an accumulation of atheromatous plaques within the walls of the coronary arteries before age of 45.
The presence of a bicuspid pulmonary valve.

JT: 肛門粘膜ロイコプラキア
DEF: Leukoplakia is a precancerous dermatosis of mucous membranes analogous Leukoplakia is basically a chronic inflammatory hypertrophy in which anaplasia and malignant dyskeratosis may develop and subsequently advance to an invasive squamous cell cancer. The clinical diagnosis of primary anal leukoplakia is indicated by single or multiple slightly raised,irregular, marginated, grayish-white keratinized' patches in the anal canal. Tissue biopsy is necessary for confirmation.
The presence of abnormal calcium deposition lesions in the pancreas.
A form of chronic pancreatitis that is characterized by calcification.
Failure to form of portions of the abdominal musculature.

ET: Unilateral absence of pectoralis major muscle
DEF: Aplasia (congenital absence) of the pectoralis minor on only one side of the chest.
Posterior positioning of the nasal root in relation to the overall facial profile for age.
Abnormality of the nostril.
A rare congenital vascular anomaly that results when the left superior cardinal vein caudal to the innominate vein fails to regress.
Formation of excess fibrous connective tissue in the tunica intima (innermost layer) of arteries in the pulmonary circulation.

ET: Anomalous branches of internal carotid artery

DEF: A degree of wrinkling of the facial skin that is more than expected for the age of the individual, leading to a prematurely aged appearance.
Recurrent partial dislocations of the mandible.
Complete inability of T cells to perform their functions in cell-mediated immunity.
A severe form of B lymphocytopenia in which the count of B cells is very low or absent.
Increased susceptibility to protozoan infections, as manifested by recurrent episodes of protozoan infection.
An abnormally low count of T cells.
Persistent overgrowth of Candida albicans in the gastrointestinal tract.

An abnormally increased level of circulationg alpha-globulin. Alpha globulins are a group of serum proteins defined by their mobility on serum electrophoresis. The alpha1-protein fraction is comprised of alpha1-antitrypsin, thyroid-binding globulin, and transcortin. Ceruloplasmin, alpha2-macroglobulin, and haptoglobin contribute to the alpha2-protein band. The alpha2 component is increased as an acute-phase reactant.
Recurrent infections by bacteria of the genus Neisseria, including N. meningitidis (one of the most common causes of bacterial meningitis).
Abnormally reduced ability of T cells to perform their functions in cell-mediated immunity.
An increased density in the cranial sutures following obliteration.

Abnormally flat (obtuse) angle of the mandible. The angle of the mandibular, located at the junction between the body and the ramus of the mandible, is normally close to being a right angle. This terms describes an abnormal increase of this angle such that the mandible appears flatter than normal.
An increase in bone density affecting the calvaria (roof of the skull).
Lack (aplasia) of the ethmoidal sinus.
Abnormally increased density of craniofacial bone tissue.

ET: Abnormality of the alternate complement pathway
DEF: A deviation in any aspect of the alternative complement pathway.
A myeloproliferative disorder characterized by increased proliferation of the granulocytic cell line without the loss of their capacity to differentiate.
A type of T-cell lymphoma in which cancerous T-cells may present in the blood (leukemia), lymph nodes (lymphoma), skin or in multiple areas.

Disseminated intravascular coagulation is characterized by the widespread activation of coagulation, which results in the intravascular formation of fibrin and ultimately thrombotic occlusion of small and midsize vessels.
Congenital onset of a marked decrease in the number of granulocytes.
An abnormal prolongation (delay) in the time required by whole blood to produce a visible clot.

A progressive detrimental connective tissue deposition (fibrosis) on the kidney parenchyma involving the tubules and interstitial tissue of the kidney. Tubulointerstitial injury in the kidney is complex, involving a number of independent and overlapping cellular and molecular pathways, with renal interstitial fibrosis and tubular atrophy (IF/TA) as the final common pathway. However, IF and TA are separable, as shown by the profound TA in renal artery stenosis, which characteristically has little or no fibrosis (or inflammation). For new annotations it is preferable to annotate to the specific HPO terms for Renal interstitial lfibrosis and/or Renal tubular atrophy.
Underdevelopment of the ulna on both sides.
Osteomyelitis caused by infection with the bacteria, salmonella.
Osteomyelitis caused by infection with the bacteria, salmonella.
A bilateral form of triphalangeal thumb.
The presence of bone fractures in the prenatal period that are diagnosed at birth or before.
A dislocation of the head of the radius from its socket in the elbow joint in an ulnar direction.

An enchondroma is a benign growth of cartilage that develops within the medullary cavity of bone. Enchondromatosis refers to the presence of multiple enchondromas, and this term refers to the presence of multiple enchondromas within the medulla of metaphyseal bone. Radiographically an enchondroma presents a an oval, linear, or pyramidal osteolytic (radiolucent) lesion with well defined margins.
An abnormality of skeletal development characterized by a disturbance of the metaphysis and its histological structure with relatively normal epiphyses and vertebrae.
Combined syndactyly and polydactyly of the great toe.
Multiple bent (flexed) finger joints that cannot be straightened actively or passively.
Duplication of the metacarpal I bones.

ET: Delayed pneumatization of the mastoid process
DEF: An abnormally reduced degree of pneumatization (i.e., formation of air cells) in the mastoid process with respect to age-dependent norms.

ET: Abnormality of the epiphyses of the phalanges of the hand
DEF: Abnormality of one or all of the epiphyses of the phalanges of the hand. Note that this includes the epiphysis of the 1st metacarpal. In contrast to the metacarpals 2-5, the first metacarpal is embryologically of phalangeal origin and as such equivalent to the proximal phalanges of the digits 2-5 (whereas the proximal phalanx of the thumb is equivalent to the middle phalanges of the other digits).
Any structural anomaly of the hand.

Diffuse filling of the distal airsspaces of the lungs, the alveoli, with macrophages. Desquamative interstitial pneumonitis (DIP) is characterized additionally by thickend alveolar septa and by a sparse inflammatory infiltrate that often includes plasma cells and occasional eosinophils. The alveoli are lined by plump cuboidal pneumocytes. Lymphoid aggregates may be present.
Abnormal shortening of the larynx in the anteroposterior (front to back) axis.
An impairment of gluconeogenesis.
A decreased concentration of arginine in the blood.
Episodes of reduced body termperature.
Enlargement of the thyroid gland related to multiple nodules in the thyroid gland.
Abnormal increase in width of the distal region of the metacarpal bones.
Absence of the proximal interphalangeal flexion creases of the fingers.

JT: 指パッドの毛細血管拡張
DEF: Telangiectasia (small dilated blood vessels) located in the fingerpads at the tips of the fingers.
Absence of one or more interphalangeal creases (i.e., of the transverse lines in the skin between the phalanges of the fingers).
The presence of multiple creases on the palm of the hand (more than the normal three major creases (distal transverse crease, proximal transverse crease, and thenar crease).
Abnormally large size of the metaphyseal epiphyses.
Increased side-to-side width of the metacarpal epiphyses.

The term proximal symphalangism refers to a bony fusion of the middle and proximal phalanges of the digits of the hand, in other words the proximal interphalangeal joint (PIJ) is missing which can be seen either on x-rays or as an absence of the proximal interphalangeal finger creases.
Bending or curvature of a thumb towards the ulnar side (towards the ring finger).
Poorly defined or shallow palmar creases.
The middle phalanx of finger resembles a thimble, a small metal cap to protect the finger while sewing that has a broad (proximal) base and narrower top, whereby both base and top are flat.
Intermittently increased size of the spleen.
The presence of multiple embedded tooth germs which have failed to erupt.
Dagger-shaped calcifications in the dental pulp.
The presence of a single, median maxillary incisor, affecting both the primary maxillary incisor and the permanent maxillary incisor.
Irregular distribution of the teeth along the dental arch, i.e., and irregular spatial pattern of teeth.
A type of dental misalignment with crowded central incisors, i.e., of maxillary secondary incisor, or of maxillary central primary incisor.
Premature tooth eruption of the permanent dentition.
Premature loss of the permanent teeth.

An crumpled radiographic appearance of the long bones, as if the long bone had been crushed together producing irregularities. This feature is the result of multiple fractures and repeated rounds of ineffective healing, as can be seen for instance in severe forms of osteogenesis imperfecta.
Increased width of the diaphysis of long bones.
The femur is shortened and displays flaring (widening) of the metaphyses.
A bent (flexed) knee joint that cannot be straightened actively or passively.
Progressive bending or abnormal curvature of a long bone.
An abnormal conformation of the femur that becomes gradually enlarged towards the distal end. This feature affects the distal femoral metaphysis and epiphysis.
An abnormal conformation of the femur that becomes gradually enlarged towards the distal end. This feature affects the distal femoral metaphysis and epiphysis.
Overconstriction, or narrowness of the diaphysis and metaphysis of long bones.
An abnormal increase in the bone density of the long bones.
An abnormal conformation of the femur that becomes gradually enlarged towards the proximal end. This feature affects the proximal femoral metaphysis and epiphysis.
Increased density of the compact bone of long bone.
An abnormally wide femoral neck (which is the process of bone, connecting the femoral head with the femoral shaft).
Partial dislocation of the ulna in the dorsal direction.

ET: Periosteal thickening of long tubular bones
DEF: Thickening of the periosteum of long bone.
Decreased width of the diaphysis of long bones.
An abnormal anterior curvature of a long bone.

ET: Abnormality of the pancreatic islet cells
DEF: An abnormality of the islet of Langerhans, i.e., of the regions of the pancreas that contain its endocrine cells. These are the alpha cells, which produce glucagon, the beta cells, which produce insulin and amylin, the delta cells, which produce somatostatin, the PP cells, which produce pancreatic polypeptide, and the epsilon cells, which produce ghrelin.
The presence of an altered number of of teeth.
A bending or abnormal curvature of a long bone.
An anomaly of a growth plate of a femur.
An anomaly that is characterized progressive airflow obstruction that is only partly reversible, inflammation in the airways, and systemic effects or comorbities.
Substantial narrowing or blockage of small pulmonary veins as a result of disorganized smooth muscle hypertrophy and collagen matrix deposition.
An abnormality of the pulmonary lymphatic chain.
Obstruction of conducting airways of the lung.
Intermittently increased size of the liver.
An abnormal increase in the amount of intracellular lipid droplets in hepatocytes.
A type of cirrhosis characterized by the presence of large regenerative nodules.

Neonatal jaundice refers to a yellowing of the skin and other tissues of a newborn infant as a result of increased concentrations of bilirubin in the blood. Neonatal jaundice affects over half of all newborns to some extent in the first week of life. Prolonged neonatal jaundice is said to be present if the jaundice persists for longer than 14 days in term infants and 21 days in preterm infants.

The two portions of the clavicle (corresponding to the two primary ossification centers of the clavicle) are connected by a fibrous bridge that is contiguous with the periosteum, and a synovial membrane develops, resulting in a clavicle with a bipartite appearance radiographically. Congenital pseudarthrosis of the clavicle generally presents as a painless mass or swelling over the clavicle.
Lack of development of the glenoid fossa, also known as the glenoid cavity, which is the articular surface of the scapula that articulates with the head of the humerus.
Bony fusion between the humerus and scapula, leading to an impairment in mobility of the affected shoulder joint.
Early ossification of the costochondral junction, which is the joint between the ribs and costal cartilage in the front of the rib cage.
Underdevelopment of the middle portion of the clavicle.
A larger than usual distance between the left and right nipple.
Underdevelopment of the glenoid fossa, which is the cavity in the lateral part of the scapula which articulates with the head of the humerus.

JT: 肋骨のコートハンガーサイン
DEF: An abnormal morphology of the ribs consisting of shorted, abnormally curved ribs. On posteroanterior chest radiography, the ribs show a curvature resembling that of a coat hanger (clothes hanger).

Inflammation of the coronary arteries involving a granulomatous response, i.e., a non-specific inflammatory response involving granulomas, defined as a compact organized collection of mature mononuclear phagocytes including epithelioid and giant cells.

Although not always available, an EEG often demonstrates slow (<3 Hz), irregular, generalized spike-wave activity.
A cessation of the development of a child in the areas of motor skills, speech and language, cognitive skills, and social and/or emotional skills.

A hand or foot with more than five digits that has a recognizable A/P axis of symmetry. The axis can lie within a normally formed or partially duplicated digit resembling a middle finger, index finger, thumb, toe, or hallux. Alternatively, the axis can be in an interdigital space with a flanking pair of digits that resemble a middle finger, index finger, thumb, toe or hallux. The most lateral digits on each side of the hand typically resemble fifth fingers/toes.

Tumor-like growths that consist of replacement of the medullary bone with fibrous tissue, causing the expansion and weakening of the areas of bone involved. Especially when involving the skull or facial bones, the lesions can cause externally visible deformities. The skull is often, but not necessarily, affected, and any other bone or bones may be involved. Fibrous dysplasia can either effect isolated bones (Monostotic fibrous dysplasia) or also generalized all bones of the body (Polyostotic fibrous dysplasia).
Fibrous dysplasia of the bones were lesions are localized in only one bone.

The tonic activity can be a sustained abnormal posture, either in extension or flexion, sometimes accompanied by tremor of the extremities.
Intermittent clonic or tonic contraction of muscles supplied by facial nerve. Muscles are relaxed in between contractions.
A pattern of sensory loss with selective loss of touch sensation and proprioception without loss of pain and temperature, or vice-versa.
A type of motor delay characterized by a delay in acquiring the ability to control the fingers and hands.

An elevated plasma concentration of sarcosine.

Echogenic bowel is defined as fetal bowel with homogenous areas of echogenicity that are equal to or greater than that of surrounding bone.

A type of cataract (opacification of the lens) that forms during the course of aging.

A typical absence seizure is a type of generalised non-motor (absence) seizure characterised by its sudden onset, interruption of ongoing activities, a blank stare, possibly a brief upward deviation of the eyes. Usually the patient will be unresponsive when spoken to. Duration is a few seconds to half a minute with very rapid recovery. Although not always available, an EEG would usually show 3 Hz generalized epileptiform discharges during the event.
Typical absence seizures starting before the age of 4 years.
An autonomic seizure is a type of focal non-motor seizure characterized by alteration of autonomic nervous system function as the initial semiological feature.

JT: 焦点性ミオクロニー発作
DEF: A type of focal motor seizure characterized by sudden, brief (<100 ms) involuntary single or multiple contraction(s) of muscles(s) or muscle groups of variable topography (axial, proximal limb, distal). Myoclonus is less regularly repetitive and less sustained than is clonus.
A type of focal motor seizure characterized by sustained increase in muscle contraction, lasting a few seconds to minutes.

Generalized clonic seizure is a type of generalized motor seizure characterised by sustained bilateral jerking, either symmetric or asymmetric, that is regularly repetitive and involves the same muscle groups.

A short generalized seizure, of a duration of <15 min, not recurring within 24 h, occurring during a febrile episode not caused by an acute disease of the nervous system intracranial infection or severe metabolic disturbance.

A febrile seizure that has any of the following features: focal semiology (or associated with post-ictal neurologic abnormalities beyond drowsiness, such as a Todd's paresis), prolonged seizure beyond 15 minutes, or recurring (occurring more than once) in a 24 hour period.
An abnormal shape of occiput.
