Delay of conduction through the atrioventricular node, which is manifested as prolongation of the PR interval in the electrocardiogram (EKG). All atrial impulses reach the ventricles.

An intermittent atrioventricular block with failure of some atrial impulses to conduct to the ventricles, i.e., some but not all atrial impulses are conducted through the atrioventricular node and trigger ventricular contraction.
Absent development of the adrenal gland.
Abnormal embryonic development of the parathyroid gland.

JT: 中枢性甲状腺機能低下症
DEF: A type of hypothyroidism due to an insufficient stimulation of an otherwise normal thyroid gland. Central hypothyroidism is caused by either pituitary (secondary hypothyroidism) or hypothalamic (tertiary hypothyroidism) defects.
An encephalocele located between bregma and lambda.
Detectable but decreased IgA levels that are more than 2 standard deviations below normal age-adjusted means.
A functional anomaly of T cells.
Significant maternal haemorrhage/blood loss following deilvery of a child.
A reduced concentration of vitamin K.
An abnormality of the shape of the lumbar vertebra L2 such that it is wedge-shaped (narrow towards the front).

The presence of multiple granulomas in the liver as based on pathological examination. Granulomas are small 0.5 to 2 mm collections of modified macrophages called epithelioid cells usually surrounded by lymphocytes.
Gallstones composed primarily of cholesterol, usually about 2-3 cm in length with an oval form and a yellow or green/brown color.

A bulging of the interatrial septum towards one side. In adults, atrial septal aneurysm can be defined as a protrusion of the aneurysm of >10 mm beyond the plane of the atrial septum as measured by transesophageal echocardiography.

Increased activity of coagulation factor V, Factor V, which is activated to factor Va by means of minute amounts of thrombin (and inactivated by larger amounts of thrombin). Activated factor V (fVa) is a cofactor in the formation of the prothrombinase complex.
A benign tumor of the liver of presumably epithelial origin.

JT: アスピリン誘発性喘息
DEF: A type of asthma in which aspirin and other nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) that inhibit cyclooxygen-ase 1 (COX-1) exacerbate bronchoconstriction.
A kind of focal dystonia characterized by forceful contractions of the face, jaw, and/or tongue causing difficulty in opening and closing the mouth and often affecting chewing and speech.

JT: アスパルチルグルコサミン尿
DEF: Excretion of excess amounts of aspartylglucosamine in the urine.
Blockade of impulses at a focal site along the course of a motor axon.
An abnormal color of the urine, that is, the color of the urine appears different from the usual straw-yellow color.
A deviation from the normal size of the pancreas.
Underdevelopment of the pons.
Deviation from normal concentration of albumin in the blood.
Increased concentration of methylmalonic acid in the urine.
Death of cells in the basal ganglia.

A disorder of large arteries, in particular the aorta, characterized by an accumulation of basophilic ground substance in the media with cyst-like lesions associated with degenerative changes of collagen, elastin and the vascular smooth muscle cells.
Excessive vomiting in early pregnancy, leading to the loss of 5% or more of body weight.
An abnormal reduction in the mobility of ejaculated sperm.
Blood clot formed within muscle tissue following leakage of blood into the tissue.
Reduced ability to control the movement of the eye associated with damage to the third cranial nerve (the oculomotor nerve).
An anomaly of a glycosylation process, i.e., a process involved in the covalent attachment of a glycosyl residue to a substrate molecule.

Abnormally anterior positioning of the infraorbital and perialar regions, or increased convexity of the face, or increased nasolabial angle. The midface includes the maxilla, the cheeks, the zygomas, and the infraorbital and perialar regions of the face
Pattern of blood flow in the heart that deviates from the normal circuit of the circulatory system from the left side of the heart to the right.
Muscular hypotonia of one or more limbs.
The presence of atheromas or atherosclerotic plaques in the aorta.
Reduced motility of the gallbladder with reduced emptying fraction.
Increased width of the skin of vermilion border region of upper lip.
A venous angioma of the frontal lobe of the brain.
A type of lymphoma characterized microscopically by the absence of multinucleated Reed-Sternberg cells.
An decreased concentration of fructose 1,6-bisphosphate aldolase in the serum.
The presence of an aortic valve with one instead of the normal three cusps (flaps).
A type of glomerulonephropathy characterized by thickening of the basement membrane and deposition of immune complexes in the subepithelial space.
High urine chloride in the presence of hypochloridemia.
Functional anomaly of the kidney persisting for at least three months.
Blockage of the retinal vein.
An abnormal increase or decrease in the quantity of three-dimensional space taken up by the pineal gland.
Deviation from the normal range of size of the thalamus.
A discrete abnormal tissue mass that protrudes into the lumen of the small intestine and is attached to the intestinal wall either by a stalk, pedunculus, or a broad base.
An uncontrolled autonomous cell-proliferation originating in a hair follicle, which is an epidermal adnexal structures responsible for hair growth.
A white patch or plaque occurring on the surface of the esophageal mucous membranes that cannot be rubbed off and cannot be characterized clinically as any other disease.
The emission of semen and seminal fluid into the bladder instead of through the penis during orgasm.
A twisting of the Fallopian tube. Sudden onset with sharp, colicky pelvic pain associated with nausea, vomiting, bowel, and bladder symptoms is the usual presentation.

JT: 子宮頚部エンドメトリオーシス
DEF: Abnormal growth of endometrial cells (which are normally limited to the uterus) within the cervix.

JT: 陳旧性|子宮内膜症ORエンドメトリオーシス

DEF: Malignant mesothelioma is a form of cancer that originates from the cells of the mesothelium, a thin tissue layer surrounding the body's internal organs. Malignant mesothelioma is almost exclusively caused by asbestos exposure, pleural mesothelioma beeing the most common form, affecting the lining of the lungs called the pleura. Other forms such as perioneal-, percardial- or testicular- mesothelioma are much rarer.
A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the breast.
A recurrent form of pancreatitis.
Nonmidline cleft palate on the left and right sides.

ET: Absent distal phalanx of the 3rd toe
DEF: Developmental aplasia of the distal phalanx of third toe.

ET: Absent middle phalanx of the 3rd toe
DEF: Developmental aplasia of the middle phalanx of third toe.

ET: Absent proximal phalanx of the 3rd toe
DEF: Absence of proximal phalanx of third toe, owing to a congenital defect of development.

ET: Short distal phalanx of the 3rd toe
DEF: Developmental hypoplasia of the distal phalanx of third toe.

ET: Short distal phalanx of the 4th toe
DEF: Developmental hypoplasia of the distal phalanx of fourth toe.

ET: Short distal phalanx of the 5th toe
DEF: Developmental hypoplasia of the distal phalanx of little toe.

ET: Short middle phalanx of the 3rd toe
DEF: Developmental hypoplasia of the middle phalanx of third toe.

ET: Short middle phalanx of the 4th toe
DEF: Developmental hypoplasia of the middle phalanx of fourth toe.

ET: Short middle phalanx of the 5th toe
DEF: Developmental hypoplasia of the middle phalanx of the 5th toe.

ET: Short proximal phalanx of the 3rd toe
DEF: Abnormal reduction in length of proximal phalanx of third toe.

ET: Short proximal phalanx of the 4th toe
DEF: Developmental hypoplasia of the proximal phalanx of fourth toe.

ET: Short proximal phalanx of the 5th toe
DEF: Developmental hypoplasia of the proximal phalanx of fifth toe.

ET: Duplication of the distal phalanx of the 3rd toe
DEF: Partial or complete duplication of distal phalanx of third toe.

ET: Duplication of the distal phalanx of the 4th toe
DEF: Partial or complete duplication of the distal phalanx of fourth toe.

ET: Duplication of the distal phalanx of the 5th toe
DEF: Partial or complete duplication of the distal phalanx of little toe.

ET: Duplication of the middle phalanx of the 3rd toe
DEF: Partial or complete duplication of middle phalanx of third toe.

ET: Duplication of the middle phalanx of the 4th toe
DEF: Partial or complete duplication of middle phalanx of fourth toe.

ET: Duplication of the middle phalanx of the 5th toe
DEF: Partial or complete duplication of the middle phalanx of the 5th toe.

ET: Duplication of the proximal phalanx of the 3rd toe
DEF: Partial or complete duplication of proximal phalanx of third toe.

ET: Duplication of the proximal phalanx of the 4th toe
DEF: Partial or complete duplication of the proximal phalanx of fourth toe.

ET: Duplication of the proximal phalanx of the 5th toe
DEF: Partial or complete duplication of the proximal phalanx of fifth toe.
A reduced concentration of Vitamin C.
A reduced concentration of Vitamin D.
A reduced concentration of vitamin E in the blood circulation. Vitamin E is a lipophilic vitamin that is also known as alpha-tocopherol.
The presence of a neoplasm of the ureter.
A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the thymus.
A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the biliary system.
The presence of a neoplasm of the testis with origin in a Sertoli cell.
A multidimensional but common male sexual dysfunction that involves an alteration in any of the components of the erectile response, including organic, relational and psychological.
A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the tongue.
A developmental disorder in which there is a duplication the entire intestine or of a portion of the intestine.
A developmental disorder in which there is a duplication of a portion of the muscle and submucosa of the esophagus without epithelial duplication.
An abnormality of Sharpey's fibers (bone fibers, or perforating fibers), which are a matrix of connective tissue consisting of bundles of strong collagenous fibres connecting periosteum to bone.
A type of Macrodactyly affecting one or several fingers.
A hamartoma (disordered proliferation of mature tissues) of the conjunctiva.
A congenital underdevelopment (aplasia or hypoplasia) of the pancreas.
Abnormal outpouching or sac-like dilatation in the wall of the celiac artery.
Telangiectases (small dilated blood vessels) located on the skin of sole of foot.

A scoliosis which is the results of a difference in leg length (which might be due to hemihypertrophy or hemihypotrophy of a leg) and the resulting tilting of the pelvis. If untreated this will lead to the development of scoliosis over time.
Persistence of the embryonic dorsal or sciatic vein system that normally should have involuted around the tenth to twelfth week of intrauterine life.
Connective tissue nevi are hamartomas in which one or several components of the dermis is altered.
An elevation in bone density in one or more phalanges of the second finger. Sclerosis is normally detected on a radiograph as an area of increased opacity.
An elevation in bone density in one or more phalanges of the third finger. Sclerosis is normally detected on a radiograph as an area of increased opacity.
An elevation in bone density in one or more phalanges of the fourth finger. Sclerosis is normally detected on a radiograph as an area of increased opacity.
An elevation in bone density in one or more phalanges of the fifth finger. Sclerosis is normally detected on a radiograph as an area of increased opacity.
An elevation in bone density in one or more foot bones. Sclerosis is normally detected on a radiograph as an area of increased opacity.
An elevation in bone density in one or more phalanges of the second toe. Sclerosis is normally detected on a radiograph as an area of increased opacity.
An elevation in bone density in one or more phalanges of the third toe. Sclerosis is normally detected on a radiograph as an area of increased opacity.
An elevation in bone density in one or more phalanges of the fourth toe. Sclerosis is normally detected on a radiograph as an area of increased opacity.
An elevation in bone density in one or more phalanges of the fifth toe. Sclerosis is normally detected on a radiograph as an area of increased opacity.
Low set, steeply sloping shoulders.
Multifocal dense infiltrates of mast cells in cutaneous tissue.

Multicystic dysplasia of the kidney is characterized by multiple cysts of varying size in the kidney and the absence of a normal pelvicaliceal system. The condition is associated with ureteral or ureteropelvic atresia, and the affected kidney is nonfunctional.
An abnormality of the female internal genitalia.
An abnormality of the male internal genitalia.
An abnormality of male external genitalia.

Hermaphroditism refers to a discrepancy between the morphology of the gonads and that of the external genitalia. In male pseudohermaphroditism, the genotype is male (XY) and the external genitalia are imcompletely virilized, ambiguous, or complete female. If gonads are present, they are testes.
Congenital anomaly characterized by closure or failure to develop an opening in the urethra in males.
An abnormality of the female external genitalia.
Congenital anomaly characterized by closure or failure to develop an opening in the urethra in females.
Abnormal (retrograde) movement of urine from the bladder into ureters or kidneys related to inadequacy of the valvular mechanism at the ureterovesicular junction or other causes.
The presence of multiple cysts at the border between the renal cortex and medulla.
Dysfunction of the proximal tubule, which is the portion of the duct system of the nephron of the kidney which leads from Bowman's capsule to the loop of Henle.
The presence of any abnormality of the genitourinary system.
A unilateral form of agenesis of the kidney.
A decreased functionality of the gonad.
Aplasia of the uterus.
The presence of fibrosis of the gingiva.

Hard-palate submucous clefts are characterized by bony defects in the midline of the bony palate that are covered by the mucous membrane of the roof of the mouth. It may be possible to detect a submucous cleft hard palate upon palpation as a notch in the bony palate.
Uvula separated into two parts most easily seen at the tip.
Pierre Robin malformation is a sequence of developmental malformations characterized by micrognathia (mandibular hypoplasia), glossoptosis and cleft palate.
Inability of velopharyngeal sphincter to sufficiently separate the nasal cavity from the oral cavity during speech.
Telangiectasia (that is, the presence of small dilated superficial blood vessels) of the tongue.
Telangiectasia (that is, the presence of small dilated superficial blood vessels) of the tongue.

Height of the vermilion of the medial part of the lip more than 2 SD below the mean, or apparently reduced height of the vermilion of the lip in the frontal view. The vermilion is the red part of the lips (and confusingly, the vermilion itself is also often referred to as being equivalent the lips).
An abnormality of the mastoid process, which is the conical prominence projecting from the undersurface of the mastoid portion of the temporal bone.

Distance between the hairline (trichion) and the glabella (the most prominent point on the frontal bone above the root of the nose), in the midline, more than two SD below the mean. Alternatively, an apparently decreased distance between the hairline and the glabella.

Distance between the hairline (trichion) and the glabella (the most prominent point on the frontal bone above the root of the nose), in the midline, more than two SD below the mean. Alternatively, an apparently decreased distance between the hairline and the glabella.
Reduced muscle tone of a muscle that is innervated by the facial nerve (the seventh cranial nerve).
Abnormal prominence of the chin related to increased length of the mandible.

An anomaly of the midface, which is a region and not an anatomical term. It extends, superiorly, from the inferior orbital margin to, inferiorly, the level of nasal base. It is formed by the maxilla (upper jaw) and zygoma and cheeks and malar region. Traditionally, the nose and premaxilla are not included in the midface.
Greater than average forward and/or lateral protrusion of the supraorbital portion of the frontal bones.
Abnormal location of the ear.
A rudimentary tag of skin often containing ear tissue including a core of cartilage and located just anterior to the auricle (outer part of the ear).
A rudimentary tag of skin often containing ear tissue including a core of cartilage and located just anterior to the auricle (outer part of the ear).
A form of sensorineural deafness with either congenital onset or infantile onset, i.e., before the acquisition of speech.
A progressive form of sensorineural hearing impairment.
Lack of prominence of the nose resulting from a posteriorly-placed nasal ridge.
Dysplasia affecting the vasculature of the gastrointestinal tract.
A notch or cleft of the retina.
A form of astigmatism in which one meridian is hyperopic while the one at a right angle to it has no refractive error.
An eye that is more deeply recessed into the plane of the face than is typical.
Abnormality of eyesight (visual perception).
Distance between the inner canthi more than two standard deviations above the mean (objective); or, apparently increased distance between the inner canthi.
A reduction of previously attained ability to see.
An abnormality of the choroid and retina.
Atrophy of the choroid and retinal layers of the fundus.
Atrophy of the choroid and retinal layers of the fundus.
An abnormality of the uvea, the vascular layer of the eyeball.

A developmental disorder of the lacrimal drainage system that most often affects the lacrimal ostium and resulting in non-opening of the nasolacrimal duct. It usually results from a non-canalization of the nasolacrimal duct.
An abnormality of eye movement characterized by impairment of fast (saccadic) eye movements.

A supranuclear gaze palsy is an inability to look in a particular direction as a result of cerebral impairment. There is a loss of the voluntary aspect of eye movements, but, as the brainstem is still intact, all the reflex conjugate eye movements are normal.
An abnormality of the region situated around the orbit of the eye.
A vertical gaze palsy with inability to direct the gaze of the eyes downwards.
A posterior embryotoxon is the presence of a prominent and anteriorly displaced line of Schwalbe.
Increase in periorbital soft tissue.
Abnormally decreased lacrimation, that is, reduced ability to produce tears.
A short discontinuity of the margin of the upper eyelid.
Nystagmus made apparent by looking to the right or to the left.
Nystagmus made apparent by looking to the right or to the left.
A short discontinuity of the margin of the lower eyelid.

Ocular motor apraxia is a deficiency in voluntary, horizontal, lateral, fast eye movements (saccades) with retention of slow pursuit movements. The inability to follow objects visually is often compensated by head movements. There may be decreased smooth pursuit, and cancellation of the vestibulo-ocular reflex.
Abnormal alignment, positioning, or spacing of the teeth, i.e., misaligned teeth.
Delayed tooth eruption affecting the secondary dentition.
Developmental dysplasia of dentin.

JT: フロンタルリリースサイン
DEF: Primitive reflexes traditionally held to be a sign of disorders that affect the frontal lobes.
A reduction in goal-directed behavior, that is, motivation, the determinant of behavior and adaptation that allows individuals to get started, be energized to perform a sustained and directed action.
A reduction in goal-directed behavior, that is, motivation, the determinant of behavior and adaptation that allows individuals to get started, be energized to perform a sustained and directed action.
Congenital absence of the normal opening of a structure of the urinary tract.

Adrenogenital syndrome is also known as congenital adrenal hyperplasia, which results from disorders of steroid hormone production in the adrenal glands leading to a deficiency of cortisol. The pituitary gland reacts by increased secretion of corticotropin, which in turn causes the adrenal glands to overproduce certain intermediary hormones which have testosterone-like effects.

Acromegaly is a condition resulting from overproduction of growth hormone by the pituitary gland in persons with closed epiphyses, and consists chiefly in the enlargement of the distal parts of the body. The circumference of the skull increases, the nose becomes broad, the tongue becomes enlarged, the facial features become coarsened, the mandible grows excessively, and the teeth become separated. The fingers and toes grow chiefly in thickness.
Insufficient production of steroid hormones (primarily cortisol) by the adrenal glands.
Developmental hypoplasia of the parathyroid gland.
A chronic, autoimmune type of thyroiditis associated with hypothyroidism.
An excessive upward convexity of the lateral clavicle.
Wide, concave posterior rib end.

ET: Abnormality of the posterior cranial fossa
DEF: An abnormality of the fossa cranii posterior (the posterior fossa), which is made up primarily of the occipital bone and which surrounds to the foramen magnum.
Abnormal thickening of the cortex of long bones.
Cafe-au-lait spots are hyperpigmented lesions that can vary in color from light brown to dark brown with smooth borders and having a size of 1.5 cm or more in adults and 0.5 cm or more in children.
Ectodermal dysplasia is a group of conditions in which there is abnormal development of the skin, hair, nails, teeth, or sweat glands.

An increased sensitivity of the skin to light. Photosensitivity may result in a rash upon exposure to the sun (which is known as photodermatosis). Photosensitivity can be diagnosed by phototests in which light is shone on small areas of skin.
Bluish-grey, spongy nodules associated with scars over pressure points and easily traumatized areas like the elbows and knees.
Hemangioma, a benign tumor of the vascular endothelial cells with small endothelial spaces, occurring in the face.
An abnormality of the pigmentation of the skin.
A condition in which superficial veins (i.e., veins just under the skin) are more conspicuous or noticable than normal.
A hyperpigmented circumscribed area of change in normal skin color without elevation or depression of any size.
Jaundice that is sometimes present, sometimes not.
Seborrheic dermatitis is a form of eczema which is closely related to dandruff. It causes dry or greasy peeling of the scalp, eyebrows, and face, and sometimes trunk.
Intermittent episodes of abnormally increased perspiration.
Thin (atrophic) and wide scars.
Thin (atrophic) and wide scars.
The presence of developmental dysplasia of the optic nerve.
Increased pigmentation of the skin in the region surrounding the orbit of the eye.

A congenital defect of the macula distinct from coloboma associated with optic fissure closure defects. Macular coloboma is characterized by a sharply defined, rather large defect in the central area of the fundus that is oval or round, and coarsely pigmented.
The presence of an increased number of twists and turns of the retinal arterioles.
Esotropia in which either eye may be used for fixation.
An anomaly of a finger.
Ossification of carpal bones occurs later than age-adjusted norms.
Syndactyly with fusion of fingers two and three.
A chronic loss of wrist joint motion due to structural changes in muscle, tendons, ligaments, or skin that prevent normal movement of the joints of the wrist.
Underdevelopment of the thenar eminence with reduced palmar soft tissue mass surrounding the base of the thumb.
Mild intellectual disability is defined as an intelligence quotient (IQ) in the range of 50-69.

A delay in the achievement of motor or mental milestones in the domains of development of a child, including motor skills, speech and language, cognitive skills, and social and emotional skills. This term should only be used to describe children younger than five years of age.
Generalized muscular hypotonia (abnormally low muscle tone).
Sustained involuntary muscle contractions that produce twisting and repetitive movements of the body.
Fasciculations or fibrillation affecting the tongue muscle.
Fasciculations or fibrillation affecting the tongue muscle.
Underdevelopment of the vermis of cerebellum.
Underdevelopment of the cerebellum.

Impairment of certain skills such as reading or writing, coordination, self-control, or attention that interfere with the ability to learn. The impairment is not related to a global deficiency of intelligence.
Very brief, involuntary random muscular contractions occurring at rest, in response to sensory stimuli, or accompanying voluntary movements.
The presence of fibrosis affecting the interlobular stroma of liver.
Impairment of bile flow due to obstruction in the small bile ducts within the liver.

JT: エンテロウイルス肝炎
DEF: Inflammation of the liver due to infection with enterovirus.
A type of cirrhosis characterized by the presence of small regenerative nodules.

The presence of genetically distinct populations of somatic cells in a given organism caused by DNA mutations, epigenetic alterations of DNA, chromosomal abnormalities or the spontaneous reversion of inherited mutations.
Osteolysis involving metatarsal bones.

ET: Delayed closure of the anterior fontanelle
DEF: A delay in closure (ossification) of the anterior fontanelle, which generally undergoes closure around the 18th month of life.
A tendency to hold the chin elevated by about 20 to 30 degrees to compensate for a limitation of eye movement.
An abnormal restriction of fetal growth with fetal weight below the tenth percentile for gestational age.

A tall and slim body build with increased arm span to height ratio (>1.05) and a reduced upper-to-lower segment ratio (<0.85), i.e., unusually long arms and legs. The extremities as well as the hands and feet are unusually slim.
A morphological anomaly of the rib cage.
Increased distance between the maxillary central permanent incisor tooth.
The presence of a fistula connecting the urinary bladder to the vagina.
Agenesis specifically affecting one of the classes incisor, premolar, or molar.
Decreased size of the maxillary permanent incisor.
One or both of the leaflets (cusps) of the mitral valve bulges back into the left atrium upon contraction of the left ventricle.

The presence of an abnormality of cardiac function that is responsible for the failure of the heart to pump blood at a rate that is commensurate with the needs of the tissues or a state in which abnormally elevated filling pressures are required for the heart to do so. Heart failure is frequently related to a defect in myocardial contraction.
Any structural abnormality of the pulmonary valve.
Any abnormality of the aortic valve.

The presence of an aortic valve with two instead of the normal three cusps (flaps). Bicuspid aortic valvue is a malformation of a commissure (small space between the attachment of each cusp to the aortic wall) and the adjacent parts of the two corresponding cusps forming a raphe (the fused area of the two underdeveloped cusps turning into a malformed commissure between both cusps; the raphe is a fibrous ridge that extends from the commissure to the free edge of the two underdeveloped, conjoint cusps).

The presence of an aortic valve with two instead of the normal three cusps (flaps). Bicuspid aortic valvue is a malformation of a commissure (small space between the attachment of each cusp to the aortic wall) and the adjacent parts of the two corresponding cusps forming a raphe (the fused area of the two underdeveloped cusps turning into a malformed commissure between both cusps; the raphe is a fibrous ridge that extends from the commissure to the free edge of the two underdeveloped, conjoint cusps).
The presence of a stenosis (narrowing) of the aortic valve.
Increased time between the start of the Q wave and the end of the T wave as measured by the electrocardiogram (EKG).

Necrosis of the myocardium caused by an obstruction of the blood supply to the heart and often associated with chest pain, shortness of breath, palpitations, and anxiety as well as characteristic EKG findings and elevation of serum markers including creatine kinase-MB fraction and troponin.
A fixed form of obstruction to blood flow across the left-ventricular outflow tract related to stenosis (narrowing) below the level of the aortic valve.
An obstruction to the forward flow of blood in the outflow tract of the right ventricle.

A congenital malformation of the outflow tract of the heart. Conotruncal defects are thought to result from a disturbance of the outflow tract of the embryonic heart, and comprise truncus arteriosus, tetralogy of Fallot, interrupted aortic arch, transposition of the great arteries, and double outlet right ventricle.
An accumulation of calcium and phosphate in arteries with mineral deposits in the intimal or medial layer of the vessel wall in a coronary artery.
A cerebrovascular accident (stroke) that occurs because of thromboembolism.
A cerebrovascular accident (stroke) that occurs because of thromboembolism.
Impaired function of the exocrine pancreas associated with a reduced ability to digest foods because of lack of digestive enzymes.
A contracture of the Achilles tendon.
Bilateral clubfoot deformity (see HP:0001762).
Congenital occlusion of a tube in the genital tract.
The presence of both a prominent heel and a convex contour of the sole.
The presence of unusually deep creases (ridges/wrinkles) on the skin of sole of foot.
A reduced number of lymphocytes in the blood.
Anemia characterized by the presence of erythroblasts that are larger than normal (megaloblasts).
Anemia with varying degrees of erythrocytic hypoplasia without leukopenia or thrombocytopenia.
Any structural abnormality or abnormal count of basophils.
Aplastic anemia is defined as pancytopenia with a hypocellular marrow.

A form of amyloidosis that affects the kidney. On hematoxylin and eosin stain, amyloid is identified as extracellular amorphous material that is lightly eosinophilic. These deposits often stain weakly for periodic acid Schiff (PAS), demonstrate a blue-to-gray hue on the trichrome stain and are typically negative on the Jones methenamine silver (JMS) stain. These tinctorial properties contrast with the histologic appearance of collagen, a major component of basement membranes, mesangial matrix and areas of sclerosis, which demonstrates strong positivity for PAS and JMS (See Figure 1 of PMID:25852856).
The presence of stenosis of the renal artery.
The presence of clear, sharply defined vacuoles in the lymphocyte cytoplasm.
Acanthocytosis is a type of poikilocytosis characterized by the presence of spikes on the cell surface. The cells have an irregular shape resembling many-pointed stars.
Depletion of acid or accumulation base in the body fluids.

JT: 低カリウム血症性アルカロージス
活性減少アルカローシス
DEF: Alkalosis due to excess loss of carbon dioxide from the body.

JT: 糖尿病性ケトアシドーシス
DEF: A type of diabetic metabolic abnormality with an accumulation of ketone bodies.
Periodic (episodic or recurrent) bouts of fever.
An abnormality of the mesangium, i.e., of the central part of the renal glomerulus between capillaries.
An abnormality that involves the tubules and interstitial tissue of the kidney.
Abnormal increased number of megaloblasts in the bone marrow.
An abnormal morphology (form) of the face or its components.
An abnormality of the viscera of the abdomen.

A facial appearance characteristic of myopathic conditions. The face appears expressionless with sunken cheeks, bilateral ptosis, and inability to elevate the corners of the mouth, due to muscle weakness.
Spasticity (velocity-dependent increase in tonic stretch reflexes with increased muscle tone and hyperexcitable tendon reflexes) in the muscles of the lower limbs, hips, and pelvis

Repeated headache attacks lasting 4-72 h fulfilling at least two of the following criteria: 1) unilateral location, 2) pulsating quality, 3) moderate or severe pain intensity, and 4) aggravation by or causing avoidance of routine physical activity such as climbing stairs. Headache attacks are commonly accompanied by nausea, vomiting, photophobia, or phonophobia.

ET: Restrictive deficit on pulmonary function testing

DEF: Abnormality of the cerebral ventricles.
An increased concentration of proteins in the blood.
An abnormally increased potassium concentration in the blood.
An elevated concentration of glycine in the blood.
An increased concentration of homocystine in the urine.
Hair on the neck extends more inferiorly than usual.
Defective development of the vermis of cerebellum.

JT: 低カルシウム血症性発作

DEF: Inability to move the muscles of respiration.
Development of gray hair at a younger than normal age.
Hair whose growth is slower than normal.
Excessive, increased hair growth located in the facial region.
Abnormally increased hair growth over much of the entire body.
An abnormality of the duodenum, i.e., the first section of the small intestine.
An abnormality resulting from a lack of intestinal ganglion cells (i.e., an aganglionic section of bowel) that results in bowel obstruction with enlargement of the colon.
Repeated episodes of diarrhea separated by periods without diarrhea.
A focal clonic seizure is a type of focal motor seizure characterized by sustained rhythmic jerking, that is regularly repetitive.

ET: Abnormality of the autonomic nervous system
DEF: An abnormality of the autonomic nervous system.
Attacks of disabling daytime drowsiness and low alertness.
An anomaly of the vermis of cerebellum.
Congenital absence of the vermis of cerebellum.
An anomaly of the brainstem.

Lack of observable abnormal electroencephalographic (EEG) patterns in an individual with a history of seizures. About half of individuals with epilepsy show interictal epileptiform discharges upon the first investigation. The yield can be increased by repeated studies, sleep studies, or by ambulatory EEG recordings over 24 hours. Normal interictal EEG is a sign that can be useful in the differential diagnosis.
