A type of gait ataxia displaying progression of clinical severity.

ET: Severe demyelination of the white matter
DEF: A severe loss of myelin from nerve fibers in the central nervous system.
A form of lissencephaly characterized by an uneven cortical surface with a so called 'cobblestone' appearace. There are no distinguishable cortical layers.
Atrophy affecting the cerebellum and the spinocerebellar tracts of the spinal cord.
Multiple areas of darker than expected signal on magnetic resonance imaging emanating from the deep cerebral white matter.

ET: Abnormal morphology of the limbic system
DEF: Any structural anomaly of the limbic system, a set of midline structures surrounding the brainstem of the mammalian brain, originally described anatomically, e.g., hippocampal formation, amygdala, hypothalamus, cingulate cortex. Although the original designation was anatomical, the limbic system has come to be associated with the system in the brain subserving emotional functions. As such, it is very poorly defined and doesn't correspond closely to the anatomical meaning any longer. [BirnLex].
A type of tremors that is triggered by holding an arm in a fixed position.
An abnormality of the septum pellucidum, which is a thin, triangular, vertical membrane separating the lateral ventricles of the brain.
An abnormality of the choroid plexus, which is the area in the cerebral ventricles in which cerebrospinal fluid is produced by modified ependymal cells.
Telangiectases (small dilated blood vessels) located near the surface of the skin of the face.
Naevus flammeus localised in the skin of the forehead.
Spontaneous development of hematomas (hematoma) or bruises without significant trauma.
Prominent thoracic and abdominal veins.
Cutis gyrata of palms and soles.
An abnormality of dermatoglyphs (fingerprints), which are present on fingers, palms, toes, and soles.
Lack of subcutaneous adipose tissue.
Loose, wrinkled skin of hands and feet.

JT: 低タンパク血症性浮腫
DEF: An abnormal accumulation of fluid beneath the skin, or in one or more cavities of the body because of decreased osmotic pressure of plasma (hypoproteinemia).

ET: Spinous keratoses of palms and soles

DEF: Naevus flammeus localised in the skin of the neck. This is one of the most common birthmarks and present in approximately 25% of all newborns.
Abnormally curly or curved eyelashes.

Degenerative changes of the peripheral retina consisting of close-packed tiny cystic spaces at the outer plexiform/inner nuclear retinal level. The degeneration is very common in adult eyes and starts adjacent to the ora serrata and extends circumferentially and posteriorly.
A functional abnormality of the pupil.
A unilateral form of ptosis.
Abnormal development (dysgenesis) of the anterior segment of the eye globe. These structures are mainly of mesenchymal origin.
Presence of multiple dilatations (sac-like outpouchings) in the blood vessels of the conjunctiva.
An abnormal reduction in the amount of pigmentation of the iris.
Increased depth of the anterior chamber, i.e., the anteroposterior distance between the cornea and the iris is increased.
Underdevelopment of the optic disc, that is of the optic nerve head, where ganglion cell axons exit the eye to form the optic nerve.
Underdevelopment of the optic disc, that is of the optic nerve head, where ganglion cell axons exit the eye to form the optic nerve.
Ocular abnormality characterised by premature degeneration of the vitreous and the retina that may be associated with increased risk of retinal detachment.
Fibrous connective tissue resulting from incomplete healing of a wound (i.e., a scar) located in the choroid and retina or the eye.
A type of cataract characterized by punctate, dust-like opacities within the cortical region of the lens.
Abnormal largeness of the eye with an axial length > 2.5 standard deviations from population mean.
The presence of distinct colors in the central (pupillary) zone of the iris than in the mid-peripheral (ciliary) zone.
Paralysis of both the extrinsic and intrinsic ocular muscles.
Inability to see well at night or in poor light with onset in adulthood.
A progressive form of ptosis.
Punched out lesions in the pigmented layer of the retina.
Punched out lesions in the pigmented layer of the retina.
Deposition of calcium salts in the retina.
The presence of multiple hemangiomas in the choroid. These are generally reddish or orange or can have increased pigmentation maiking them difficult to distinguish from choroidal melanomas.
Failure of attachment of the retina during development.

A type of retinal detachment arising due to a combination of contracting retinal membranes, abnormal vitreoretinal adhesions, and vitreous changes. It is usually seen in the context of diseases that induce a fibrovascular response, e.g. diabetes.
A congenital defect resulting in absence of the lacrimal duct.
Regional increase in the width (height) of the lateral eyebrow.
Regional increase in the width (height) of the lateral eyebrow.
A type of retinal reticular pigmentation that forms a polygonal, netlike arrangement of hyperpigmented lines forming geometric patterns in the fundus.

ET: obsolete Concentric narrowing of visual field

DEF: Blockage of retinal arteriole, generally associated with interruption of blood flow and oxygen delivery to affected regions of the retina.
Underdevelopment of the stroma of iris.
Abnormality of macular or foveal pigmentation.
Inherited progressive cone degeneration.

Retinitis pigmentosa inversa is form of retinal degeneration characterized by areas of retinal/chorioretinal degeneration with pigment migration in the macular area (in contrast to retinitis pigmentosa which, at early disease stages, predominantly affects the retinal periphery).
Decreased retinal arteriolar diameters, which may decrease blood flow and slow oxygen delivery to regions of the retina.
A structural abnormality of retinal vasculature.
A wrinkle of retinal tissue projecting outward from the surface of the retina and visible as a line on fundoscopy.

ET: Abnormality of the vasculature of the conjunctiva
DEF: Any abnormality of the blood vessels of the conjunctiva.
The presence of one or more bullae on the skin, defined as fluid-filled blisters more than 5 mm in diameter with thin walls.
Increased blood pressure during a pregnancy.
The development of Pes cavus that is progressive with age.
Reduction in bone mineral density affecting any or all of the tarsal bones, seven bones of the foot comprising the calcaneus, talus, cuboid, navicular, and the cuneiform bones.
Delayed maturation and calcification of any of the tarsal bones, seven bones of the foot comprising the calcaneus, talus, cuboid, navicular, and the cuneiform bones.
Precocious (accelerated) maturation and calcification of any of the tarsal bones, seven bones of the foot comprising the calcaneus, talus, cuboid, navicular, and the cuneiform bones.
Synostosis of the calcaneus with the navicular bone.
A congenital deformity characterized by a dorsiflexed, inverted, and adducted foot, i.e., a combination of talipes calcaneus and talipes varus.

ET: Medial rotation of the medial malleolus

DEF: Excessive amounts of mucopolysaccharide in the urine.
Decreased sensitivity toward insulin.
Insufficient production of steroid hormones (primarily cortisol) by the adrenal glands as a result of a primary defect in the glands themselves.
Hyperplasia of the parathyroid gland.

Amenorrhea due to loss of ovarian function before the age of 40. Primary ovarian inssuficiency (POI) is a state of female hypergonadotropic hypogonadism. It can manifest as primary amenorrhea with onset before menarche or secondary amenorrhea.
Aplasia of the parathyroid gland.
Developmental hypoplasia of the adrenal medulla.
An enlargement of the thyroid gland with congenital onset.
The presence of an adenoma of the pancreas with origin in a pancreatic B cell.
Degeneration of the olivary bodies, prominent oval structures in the medulla oblongata.
An abnormally decreased concentration of vitamin B6 in the blood circulation.
The presence of microscopic crystalline calcium precipitates in the form of oxalate and/or phosphate in the renal parenchyma.

An abnormality of adhesion of thrombocytes. Normally, platelets adhere to collagen in the vascular subendothelium within seconds of injury via a receptor made up of glycoprotein Ia and IIa and GPVI and to vWF via receptor GPIb/IX/V. The adherent platelets then release granules that lead to platelet activation and aggregation.
An increased concentration of proline in the blood.
An abnormality of the formation and mineralization of any of the tarsal bones, seven bones of the foot comprising the calcaneus, talus, cuboid, navicular, and the cuneiform bones.

Any abnormal process of ossification of the metatarsal bones, which normally are each ossified from two centers: one for the body, and one for the head (metatarsal II,III,IV, and V) and one for the body and one for the base (metatarsal I). The ossification process begins in the center of the body about the ninth week, and extends toward either extremity. The center for the base of the first metatarsal appears about the third year, and the centers for the heads of the other bones between the fifth and eighth years. They join the bodies between the eighteenth and twentieth years.
A thickening of the stratum corneum, the outer layer of the skin, in the region surrounding the nails.
Detachment of the distal fingernails from the nail bed.
The presence of punctiform calcification of the bone of the vertebral bodies.

Narrowing (becoming gradually narrower) of the distance between vertebral pedicles that gets progressively more severe towards to caudal (lower) end of the vertebral column. Note that normally, the interpedicular distances get progressively wider as one proceeds down the spine.
Narrowing (becoming gradually narrower) of the distance between lumbar vertebral pedicles that gets progressively more severe towards to caudal (lower) end of the vertebral column.
Cleft lip or palate affecting the midline region of the palate.
A bilateral type of conductive hearing impairment.
A type of hearing impairment caused by an abnormal functionality of the cochlear nerve with congenital onset.
The presence of a malformed cochlea.
The presence of a mild form of sensorineural hearing impairment.
A type of conductive deafness with congenital onset.
A mild form of conductive hearing impairment.
A progressive type of conductive deafness.

ET: Morphological abnormality of the middle ear
DEF: An abnormality of the morphology or structure of the middle ear.
A bilateral form of sensorineural hearing impairment.
An abnormality of the stapes, a stirrup-shaped ossicle in the middle ear.
Absence of sex glands (gonads are the organs that produce gametes; testis in males and ovary in females).
A developmental defect characterized by absence or poor development of proximal renal tubules.
A developmental disturbance with extreme ureteral dilatation.
A developmental disturbance with extreme ureteral dilatation.

Coagulative necrosis of tubular epithelial cells, defined as cells with increased cytoplasmic eosinophilia and nucleus that has a condensed chromatin pattern with fuzzy nuclear contour or has barely visible nuclear basophilic staining. The extent of cortical tubular necrosis is scoredsemiquantitatively as none, mild (less than 25% tubules with necrosis), moderate (25-50 percent), and severe (over 50%).
Increase in size of the folds of skin between the outer labia.
Absence of both testes from the scrotum owing to failure of the testis or testes to descend through the inguinal canal to the scrotum.
Deposition of calcium salts in gonadal tissue.
A unilateral form of developmental dysplasia of the kidney.
The presence of a diverticulum (sac or pouch) in the wall of the urethra.
Renal hypophosphatemia is defined as reduced serum phosphate (e.g., below 0.70 mmol/l) and an inappropriately high renal phosphate excretion.
Reduced volume of the testicle (the male gonad).
A loss of the ability to move the vocal fold on one side.
Delayed maturation and calcification of the rami (branches) of the pubic bone.
Irregularities of the iliac crest that produce the appearance of a lace border around it.
A decreased ability to move the femur at the hip joint associated with a decreased range of motion of the hip.
Underdevelopment of the femoral head.
Increased width of the femoral head.
An abnormally flattened femoral head.
An abnormally reduced diameter of the femoral neck (which is the process of bone, connecting the femoral head with the femoral shaft).
Underdevelopment of the body of ilium.
Developmental delay of ossification of the proximal epiphysis of the femur.
Slow or limited growth after birth.
An acute form of rhabdomyolysis.
Muscular atrophy of distal leg muscles.
Atrophy of the muscles of the pelvic girdle (also known as hip girdle), i.e., the gluteal muscles, the lateral rotators, the adductors, the psoas major and the iliacus muscle.
Muscular atrophy affecting proximally located muscles of the arms.
Muscular atrophy affecting proximally located muscles of the legs, i.e., of the thigh.
Reduced strength of the distal musculature of the arms.
Muscular atrophy that does not display a progression in severity with time.
An abnormal increase in the amount of intramuscular fat tissue.

Muscular atrophy affecting the muscles that attach to the pelvic girdle (the gluteal muscles, the lateral rotators, adductor magnus, adductor brevis, adductor longus, pectineus, and gracilis muscles).
An abnormal increase in the amount of intraabdominal fat tissue.
Underdevelopment of the pectoral muscle.
Atrophy of the muscles of the ankle.
Muscular atrophy involving the quadriceps muscle.
Reduced strength of the distal musculature of the legs.
Chronic muscle inflammation accompanied by muscle weakness.

ET: Weakness of long finger extensor muscles

DEF: Increased width of the alveolar ridges.
An abnormality of the formation and mineralization of any bone of the bony pelvis.
Congenital absence of the left half of the diaphragm.
An abnormality of adipose tissue, which is loose connective tissue composed of adipocytes.
Muscular atrophy involving the muscles of the upper limbs.

ET: Duplication of bones involving the upper extremities

DEF: Any structural anomaly of a cerebral artery. The cerebral arteries comprise three main pairs of arteries and their branches, which supply the cerebrum of the brain. These are the anterior cerebral artery, the middle cerebral artery, and the posterior cerebral artery.
Sclerosis of the epiphyses of the metacarpals, leading to an increased degree of radiopacity (white or ivory appearance) in X-rays.
Absence of the epiphyses of the metacarpal bones, which are normally located at the distal ends of the metacarpals.

ET: Deviation of the hand or of fingers of the hand
DEF: Displacement of the hand or of fingers of the hand from their normal position.

A vestibular Schwannoma (also known as acoustic neuroma, acoustic neurinoma, or acoustic neurilemoma) is a benign, usually slow-growing tumor that develops from the VIIIth cranial nerve supplying the inner ear.

JT: 末梢神経シュワン細胞腫
DEF: The presence of a peripheral schwannoma.
Abnormality of one or all of the epiphyses of the proximal, and distal phalanges of the thumb and/or the 1st metacarpal.
A structural anomaly of one or more phalanges of the thumb.

ET: Duplication of the distal phalanx of the thumb
DEF: Complete or partial duplication of the distal phalanx of the thumb. Depending on the severity, the appearance on x-ray can vary from a notched phalanx (the duplicated bone is almost completely fused with the phalanx), a partially fused appearance of the two bones, or two separate bones appearing side to side.

ET: Duplication of the proximal phalanx of the thumb
DEF: Complete or partial duplication of the proximal phalanx of the thumb. Depending on the severity, the appearance on x-ray can vary from a notched phalanx (the duplicated bone is almost completely fused with the phalanx), a partially fused appearance of the two bones, or two separate bones appearing side to side. In contrast to the proximal phalanges of the digits 2-5, the proximal phalanx of the thumb is embryologically equivalent to the middle phalanges of the other digits, whereas the first metacarpal is embryologically of phalangeal origin and as such equivalent to the proximal phalanges of the other digits.
Insertion of thumb at a more distal location than normal.
Fusion of a phalanx of the thumb with another bone.

Absence of the proximal phalanx of the thumb. In contrast to the proximal phalanges of the digits 2-5, the proximal phalanx of the thumb is embryologically equivalent to the middle phalanges of the other digits, whereas the first metacarpal is embryologically of phalangeal origin and as such equivalent to the proximal phalanges of the other digits.

Hypoplastic (short) proximal phalanx of the thumb. In contrast to the proximal phalanges of the digits 2-5, the proximal phalanx of the thumb is embryologically equivalent to the middle phalanges of the other digits, whereas the first metacarpal is embryologically of phalangeal origin and as such equivalent to the proximal phalanges of the other digits.

ET: Short distal phalanx of the thumb
DEF: Hypoplastic (short) distal phalanx of the thumb.
An abnormal morphology of one or more phalanges of the thumb, with a short and wide phalanx that tapers distally. Bullet-shaped phalanges lack the normal diaphyseal constriction.
The absence of a phalangeal segment of a thumb.

A cone-shaped appearance of the epiphyses of the thumb, producing a 'ball-in-a-socket' appearance. The related entity 'angel-shaped' epiphysis refers to a pronounced cone-shaped epiphysis in combination with a pseudoepiphysis at the distal end of a phalanx.
Abnormally large size of the epiphyses of the thumb with respect to age-dependent norms.
Abnormally small size of one or more of the epiphyses of the thumb with respect to age-dependent norms.
Abnormally small size of one or more of the epiphyses of the thumb with respect to age-dependent norms.

Fusion involving two or more metacarpal bones (A synostosis of the first metacarpal and the proximal phalanx of the thumb can also be observed, note that the first metacarpal bone corresponds to a proximal phalanx).
The presence of small depressions in the dental enamel.
A neurofibroma in which Schwann cells proliferate inside the nerve sheath, producing an irregularly thickened, distorted, tortuous structure.
Neurofibromas originating in the spine.

ET: Abnormality of the spinal dura mater
DEF: An abnormality of the spinal dura mater, which is the outermost of the three layers of the meninges surrounding the spinal cord.
Presence of arachnoid cysts of the spinal canal extradurally in the epidural space.
Abnormally increased hair growth in the lumbosacral region.
Complete or nearly complete soft tissue fusion of the alveolar ridges.
A pterygium (or pterygia) in the intercrural (groin) region.
Pterygium affecting the elbow. This is a cutaneous web that can lead to severe flexion contracture of the elbow joint. Antecubital pterygium can be unilateral, bilateral, symmetric, or asysmmetric.
Anterior schisis (cleft or cleavage) of vertebral bodies.

JT: 低い垂れ下がった鼻小柱
DEF: Columella extending inferior to the level of the nasal base, when viewed from the side.
Increased width of the phalanges of the hand.
A type of sacrococcygeal teratoma located anterior to the sacrum and entirely inside the body (Altman type IV).

Cholesteatoma is a benign but potentially destructive growth consisting of keratinizing epithelium located in the middle ear and/or mastoid process. In cholesteatoma, a skin cyst grows into the middle ear and mastoid. The cyst is not cancerous but can erode tissue and cause destruction of the ear.
The presence of two or more accessory spleens.

Missing or malformed long bones of the upper limbs with the distal parts (the hands) connected to the variably shortened or even absent upper extremity, leading to a flipper-like appearance, as opposed to other forms of limb malformations were either the whole limb is missing (such as amelia), or the distal part of a limb is absent (peromelia).

Missing or malformed long bones of the upper limbs with the distal parts (the hands) connected to the variably shortened or even absent upper extremity, leading to a flipper-like appearance, as opposed to other forms of limb malformations were either the whole limb is missing (such as amelia), or the distal part of a limb is absent (peromelia).
Phocomelia affecting only the lower limbs.
Phocomelia affecting only the lower limbs.

JT: 末梢神経ニューロパチー
DEF: Peripheral neuropathy is a general term for any disorder of the peripheral nervous system. The main clinical features used to classify peripheral neuropathy are distribution, type (mainly demyelinating versus mainly axonal), duration, and course.
Abnormally wide (broad) distal phalanx of finger.

ET: Broad proximal phalanges of the hand
DEF: Increased width of the proximal phalanges of the finger.

ET: Bullet-shaped proximal phalanges of the hand
DEF: Short and wide proximal phalanges that taper distally . Bullet-shaped phalanges lack the normal diaphyseal constriction.
An abnormality of the cerebral cortex with fewer gyri but with normal cortical thickness. This pattern is usually often associated with congenital microcephaly.

ET: Duplication of the distal phalanx of hand
DEF: This term applies if one or more of the distal phalanges of the hand are either partially duplicated, depending on severity leading to a broad or bifid appearance of the phalanges, or completely duplicated.
An abnormality of hair pigmentation (color).

Abnormality of the growth of secondary sexual hair, which normally ensues during puberty. In males, secondary sexual hair usually comprises body hair, including underarm, abdominal, chest, and pubic hair. In females, secondary sexual hair usually comprises a lesser degree of body hair, most prominently underarm and pubic hair.

Distance between the hairline (trichion) and the glabella (the most prominent point on the frontal bone above the root of the nose), in the midline, more than two SD above the mean. Alternatively, an apparently increased distance between the hairline and the glabella.
Flatness of the supraorbital portion of the frontal bones.

ET: Abnormality of the crus of the helix
DEF: An abnormality of the crus of the helix, which is the horizontal piece of cartilage located outside the ear canal that divides the upper and lower parts of the ear.
Distortion of the course of the normal folds of the ear and the appearance of supernumerary crura and folds.

ET: Vascular remnant arising from the disc
DEF: Persistence of the hyaloid artery, which is the embryonic artery that runs from the optic disk to the posterior lens capsule may persist; the site of attachment may form an opacity. The hyaloid artery is a branch of the ophthalmic artery, and usually regresses completely before birth.
Abnormally increased lacrimation, that is, excessive tearing (watering eye).

ET: Complete duplication of phalanx of hand
DEF: A complete duplication affecting one or more of the phalanges of the hand. As opposed to a partial duplication were there is still a variable degree of fusion between the duplicated bones, a complete duplication leads to two separate bones appearing side to side (radio-ulnar axis) as seen on x-rays. A duplication leading to an accesory bone appearing in the proximo-distal axis on x-rays, is a different entity called a Pseudoepiphyses (see according terms) sometimes also referred to as Hyperphalangism.
A deviation from the normal straight shape of the first metacarpal.

ET: Abnormality of the epiphyses of the hallux
Abnormality of the phalanges of the hallux

DEF: An increase in width in one or more phalanges of the big toe.
An abnormal morphology of one or more phalanges of the big toe, with a short and wide phalanx that tapers distally. Bullet-shaped phalanges lack the normal diaphyseal constriction.
A deviation from the normal straight form of one or more phalanges of the big toe.
A deviation from the normal straight shape of a proximal phalanx of the 1st metatarsal bone.

ET: Duplication of the distal phalanx of the hallux
Duplication of the proximal phalanx of the hallux
DEF: Partial or complete duplication of the proximal phalanx of big toe.
Underdevelopment (hypoplasia) of the distal phalanx of big toe.
Underdevelopment (hypoplasia) of the proximal phalanx of big toe.

ET: Aplasia of the phalanges of the hallux
Fragmentation of the epiphyses of the toes

DEF: A morphological anomaly of one or more proximal phalanges of one or more toes.

ET: Duplication of distal phalanx of toe
DEF: A partial or complete duplication of one or more distal phalanx of toe.

ET: Duplication of middle phalanx of toe
DEF: Partial or complete duplication of a middle phalanx of toe.
An increase in width of one ore more proximal toe phalanges.
An abnormal morphology of one or more of the proximal phalanges of the toes, with a short and wide phalanx that tapers distally. Bullet-shaped phalanges lack the normal diaphyseal constriction.

ET: Duplication of proximal phalanx of toe
DEF: Partial/complete duplication of a proximal phalanx of toe.
Congenital hypoplasia of one or more proximal phalanx of finger.
Increased size and/or number of soft tissue folds on the palatal side of the maxillary alveolar ridge.
Any abnormality of dentin.
An abnormally low-pitched voice.
Any abnormality of the spinal meninges, the system of membranes (dura mater, the arachnoid mater, and the pia mater) which envelops the spinal cord.
Absence (aplasia) of the sacrum.
A bifid or bifurcated appearance of the femur as seen on x-rays, possible appearing as a more or less severe bowing of the upper leg. Might be associated with hip dysplasia on the affected side.
An abnormal (non-anatomic) location of the spleen.
Pelvic asymmetry refers to asymmetric positioning of landmarks on the two sides of the pelvis and may have a structural or functional etiology.
An exaggeration of the normal arched form of the acetabular roof such that it takes on a steep appearance.

Hermaphroditism refers to a discrepancy between the morphology of the gonads and that of the external genitalia. In female pseudohermaphroditism, the genotype is female (XX) and the gonads are ovaries, but the external genitalia are virilized.
Abnormally increased excretion of porphyrins in the urine.
Shortening of the arms predominantly affecting terminal parts of the arm in relation to the upper and middle limb segments.
The absence of the major creases of the palm (distal transverse crease, proximal transverse crease, or thenar crease).
Shortening of the legs predominantly affecting terminal parts of the leg in relation to the upper and middle arm segments.
Amniotic constriction rings affecting the legs.
A developmental defect that occurs if the two halves of the patella fail to fuse in early childhood.
An abnormal limitation of the mobility of the ankle joint.
Calcification within the adrenal glands.

The presence of ectopic thymus tissue. Normally, cells of the ventral bud of the third pharyngeal pouch detach and migrate in the eighth gestational week caudally and medially towards the location of the mature thyroid. They migrate further retrosternally into the superior mediastinum. There are two main ways ectopic thymus tissue can develop. Either cells detach along the descensus path and proliferate, thereby forming accessory thymus tissue, or the entire gland fails to descend.

The presence of ectopic thymus tissue. Normally, cells of the ventral bud of the third pharyngeal pouch detach and migrate in the eighth gestational week caudally and medially towards the location of the mature thyroid. They migrate further retrosternally into the superior mediastinum. There are two main ways ectopic thymus tissue can develop. Either cells detach along the descensus path and proliferate, thereby forming accessory thymus tissue, or the entire gland fails to descend.

Inability to recognize the form of objects by touch without visual input. That is, an impairment in the recognition of objects based only on the texture, size, weight and three-dimensional form of the object in the absence of any major somatosensory deficit.
An abnormally small sella turcica.

The presence of convoluted folds and furrows formed from thickened skin of the scalp, resembling cerebriform pattern. The scalp has convoluted and elevated folds, 1 to 2 cm in thickness. The convolutions generally cannot be flattened by traction.
Bursts of large-amplitude multidirectional saccades without intersaccadic interval
The presence of developmental dysplasia of the femoral head.
A cystic lesion originating within the brain.

Cone-shaped epiphyses (also known as coned epiphyses) are epiphyses that invaginate into cupped metaphyses. That is, the epiphysis has a cone-shaped distal extension resulting from increased growth of the central portion of the epiphysis relative to its periphery.
Any abnormal increase or reduction in skin elasticity.
The presence of abnormal punctate (speckled, dot-like) calcifications in one or more epiphyses.
An abnormality of the thalamus.

ET: Abnormality of the curvature of the vertebral column
DEF: The presence of an abnormal curvature of the vertebral column.

A hand or foot with more than five digits that has a recognizable A/P axis of symmetry. The axis can lie within a normally formed or partially duplicated digit resembling a middle finger, index finger, thumb, toe, or hallux. Alternatively, the axis can be in an interdigital space with a flanking pair of digits that resemble a middle finger, index finger, thumb, toe or hallux. The most lateral digits on each side of the hand typically resemble fifth fingers/toes.
Syndactyly with fusion of fingers two to five.
A Lamellar cataract with a pulverulent (punctate, \
A nuclear cataract with a triangular form.
Syndactyly with fusion of fingers one and two.
Syndactyly with fusion of fingers four and five.
Syndactyly with fusion of fingers one to three.
Syndactyly with fusion of fingers one to four.
Syndactyly with fusion of fingers one to five (complete syndactyly of all fingers of the hand).
Syndactyly with fusion of the fingers two to four.
Syndactyly with fusion of fingers three to five.
An abnormality of the distribution of hair growth.
An asymmetriy, i.e., difference in size, shape or position between the left and right ear.
A developmental defect characterized by absence of the retina.

Blepharochalasis is characterized by recurrent, non-painful, nonerythematous episodes of eyelid edema. It has been divided into hypertrophic and atrophic forms. In the hypertrophic form recurrent edema results in orbital fat herniation through a weakened orbital septum. Most patients who have blepharochalasis present in an atrophic condition with atrophy of redundant eyelid skin and superior nasal fat pads.
Absence of the premaxilla, which is the embryonic structure that forms the anterior part of the maxilla.

An abnormality of the premaxilla, the most anterior part of the maxilla that usually bears the central and lateral incisors and includes the anterior nasal spine and inferior aspect of the piriform rim. The premaxilla contains the bone and teeth of the primary palate.
Hyperkeratosis affecting the palm of the hand.
Deposition of calcium salts in a tissue or location in which calcification does not normally occur.
The presence of a cyst, fistula, or abscess in the sacrococcygeal region (gluteal crease) characteristically accompanied by hair and skin folds.

A developmental defect characterized by abnormal connection of one or more pulmonary veins to the superior or inferior vena cava, the right atrium, or the coronary sinus, resulting in a left-to-right shunt of oxygenated blood.
Marked widening of the trachea and major bronchi that may be predispose to chronic respiratory tract infection.
Underdevelopment of the interstitial (Leydig) cells of the testis. These cells produce testosterone.
Hypertrophy or overdevelopment of the interstitial (Leydig) cells of the testis. These cells produce testosterone.

Reduced bulkiness of the crease or fold of skin running from the lateral margin of the nose, where nasal base meets the skin of the face, to a point just lateral to the corner of the mouth (cheilion or commissure).
More than two clockwise hair whorls.
A type of nevus sebaceous with a linear form, raised borders and yellowish color.

A scintillating scotoma is a common visual aura that can preced a migraine, whereby a spot of flickering light near the center of the visual fields occurs. The spot prevents vision, and is thus termed scotoma. The scotoma can extend into one or more shimmering arcs of white or colored flashing lights.
An overlap of the bony plates of the skull in an infant, with or without early closure.
A pattern of sensory loss with selective loss of touch sensation and proprioception without loss of pain and temperature, or vice-versa.
An increased concentration of copper in the urine.
A kind of breech presentation in which the hips are flexed and the knees are extended.
Severe mental retardation is defined as an intelligence quotient (IQ) in the range of 20-34.

An enduring pattern of uncooperative, defiant, and hostile behavior toward authority figures that does not involve major antisocial violations, is not accounted for by the child's developmental stage, and results in significant functional impairment. A certain level of oppositional behavior is common in children and adolescents.
An incomplete closure of the abdominal wall.
An inversion of the T-wave (which is normally positive).

A type of strabismus in which the fixating eye is always the same one, while the other eye is constantly deviated. Monocular strabismus is to be distinguished from alternating strabismus, in which either of the eyes 'squints' at different times.
The presence of an abnormally large hypoechoic space in the posterior fetal neck (usually detected on prenatal ultrasound examination).

A joint disorder caused by blood deprivation in the subchondral bone causing the subchondral bone to die in a process called avascular necrosis. The bone is then reabsorbed by the body, leaving the articular cartilage it supported prone to damage. The result is fragmentation (dissection) of both cartilage and bone, and the free movement of these osteochondral fragments within the joint space, causing pain and further damage.
An elevated urinary concentration of sarcosine.
An increased concentration of leucine in the blood.
A 'coral-like' pattern of opacity in the lens of the eye. That is, a cataract with an irregular, stellate form.
A cataract that affects the posterior part of the cortex of the lens.
Echogenic bowel is defined as fetal bowel with homogenous areas of echogenicity that are equal to or greater than that of surrounding bone.
A form of hydrocephalus in which the flow of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) within the cerebral ventricular system or in the outlets of the CSF to the arachnoid space is obstructed.
A bilateral form of agenesis of the kidney.
The presence of microscopic cystic masses of nonfunctioning pulmonary tissue that lack an obvious communication with the tracheobronchial tree.
A kind of bronchopulmonary sequestration that is completely discrete from the normal lung and is surrounded by separate pleura.
An abnormality of an erythrocyte cell surface molecule.

An abnormal functioning of phagocytosis. Phagocytosis is an elegant but complex process for the ingestion and elimination of pathogens, but it is also important for the elimination of apoptotic cells and hence fundamental for tissue homeostasis. Phagocytosis can be divided into four main steps: (i) recognition of the target particle, (ii) signaling to activate the internalization machinery, (iii) phagosome formation, and (iv) phagolysosome maturation.
An abnormal increase in the level of lipoprotein cholesterol in the blood.
An abnormal decrease in the level of lipoprotein cholesterol in the blood.
A type of multifactorial inheritance governed by the simultaneous action of many (more than three) gene loci.
A type of multifactorial inheritance governed by the simultaneous action of many (more than three) gene loci.
A mode of inheritance that is observed for traits related to a gene encoded on the sex chromosomes.
An abnormality of the morphology or counts of the cells that make up the immune system.
Involuntary urine leakage synchronous with exertion, or actions such as sneezing, or coughing.
An abnormality of the concentration of glucose in the blood.
An abnormality in a cellular process.
An abnormality of the cell cycle.
An abnormality of blood circulation.
An abnormality of the regulation of body fluids.

ET: Abnormality of the intrahepatic bile duct
DEF: An abnormality of the intrahepatic bile duct.
The presence of an altered number of of permanent teeth.
An abnormality of morphology of the incisor tooth.
An abnormality of morphology of molar tooth.
An abnormality of canine tooth.
An abnormal conical morphology of the primary incisor.
An abnormal conical morphology of either maxillary primary incisor tooth or maxillary permanent incisor tooth or both.
Maxillary teeth cover the mandibular teeth when biting to an increased degree.
An increase in the amount of intravascular fluid, particularly in the volume of the circulating blood.
An decrease in the amount of intravascular fluid, particularly in the volume of the circulating blood.
A recurrent form of sinusitis.
Any morphological abnormality of the skin.
Any abnormality of the physiological function of the skin.
Pale reddish slightly elevated papules and plaques of 0.5-3 cm in diameter and not accompanied by pruritus.
A seizure that occurs in the context of a brain insult (systemic, toxic, or metabolic) and may not recur when the underlying cause has been removed or the acute phase has elapsed.

A typical absence seizure is a type of generalised non-motor (absence) seizure characterised by its sudden onset, interruption of ongoing activities, a blank stare, possibly a brief upward deviation of the eyes. Usually the patient will be unresponsive when spoken to. Duration is a few seconds to half a minute with very rapid recovery. Although not always available, an EEG would usually show 3 Hz generalized epileptiform discharges during the event.
A type of focal-onset seizure characterized by a motor sign as its initial semiological manifestation.
A seizure characterized by sensory phenomena including tingling, numbness, electric-shock like sensation, pain, sense of movement, or desire to move as its first clinical manifestation.
A sensation consistent with involvement of the autonomic nervous system, including cardiovascular, gastrointestinal, sudomotor, vasomotor and thermoregulatory functions.
A type of focal non-motor seizure characterized by an arrest or pause of activities, freezing, or immobilization as the predominant semiological feature throughout the seizure.

A focal seizure characterized at onset by predominantly proximal limb or axial muscles producing irregular sequential ballistic movements, such as pedaling, pelvic thrusting, thrashing, rocking movements.

JT: 焦点性棘波を伴う脳波
DEF: EEG with focal sharp transient waves of a duration less than 80 msec.
Increased protrusion of the antihelical ridge, proximal to its bifurcation, relative to the prominence of the helix.
Posterior curving of the antihelix from its origin at the antitragus, traveling initially almost perpendicular to the descending helix and obscuring some of the concha.
Decreased protrusion of the antihelical ridge, proximal to its bifurcation, relative to the prominence of a normal helix.
An abnormality of the stem of the antihelix, which is the part below the bifurcation of the antihelix into the inferior and superior crura.
Small defect of the helical fold that lies at the junction of the superior and descending portions of the helix.
Decreased posterolateral protrusion of the tragus.
Abnormally increased variability in the size of erythrocytes.
An abnormality of the hindbrain, also known as the rhombencephalon.
A crease that connects the proximal and distal transverse palmar creases.

JT: 単一冠状縫合早期癒合
DEF: Synostosis affecting only one of the coronal sutures.
Premature synostosis of both lambdoid sutures.
Any anomaly of a cranial suture, that is one of the six membrane-covered openings in the incompletely ossified skull of the fetus or newborn infant.
Unilateral underdevelopment of the facial tissues, including muscles and bones.
Unilateral underdevelopment of the facial tissues, including muscles and bones.
Asymmetry observed in the face of a neonate or infant whose face appears symmetric at rest and asymmetric during crying as the mouth is pulled downward on one side while not moving on the other side.
Bilateral temporal scarlike defects, which are said to resemble forceps marks.

ET: Incomplete cleft of the upper lip
DEF: A subtle unilateral cleft of the upper lip, which may appear as a small indentation.
A mild delay in the acquisition of the ability to use language to communicate needs, wishes, or thoughts.
Formation of excess fibrous connective tissue in the tunica intima (innermost layer) of arteries.
An abnormality of the skin that is not localized to any one particular region.
A lesion of the skin that is located in a specific region rather than being generalized.
A lesion of the skin that is located in a specific region rather than being generalized.

ET: Hypoplasia of the vestibule of the inner ear
DEF: Underdevelopment of the vestibule of the inner ear.
Absence of the semicircular canal.
Underdevelopment of the semicircular canal.

ET: Morphological abnormality of the inner ear
DEF: A structural anomaly of the internal part of the ear.
Absence of the vestibular nerve
Underdevelopment of the vestibular nerve.

ET: Abnormality of the dorsal column of the spinal cord
DEF: An abnormality of the dorsal columns, i.e., of the dorsal portion of the gray substance of the spinal cord. The dorsal column consists of the fasciculus gracilis and fasciculus cuneatus and itself is part of the dorsal funiculus.
An abnormality of the placenta in which there are numerous cystic spaces within the placenta as well as placental enlargement.
An abnormally increased chloride concentration in the blood.

On prenatal ultrasound, the nasal bone is a thin echogenic line within the bridge of the fetal nose. The fetus is imaged facing the transducer with the fetal face strictly in the midline. The angle of insonation is 90 degrees, with the longitudinal axis of the nasal bone as the reference line. Calibres are placed at each end of the nasal bone. Absence of the nasal bone or measurements below 2.5th percentile are considered significant (PMID:16100637).
A lack of intestinal ganglion cells (i.e., an aganglionic section of bowel) affecting the small intestine.
Complete loss of hearing related to a sensorineural defect.

ET: Anterior synechiae of the anterior chamber
DEF: Adhesions between the iris and the cornea.

ET: Posterior synechiae of the anterior chamber
DEF: Adhesions between the iris and the lens.
Developmental abnormality in which the lens and cornea are not separated.
An abnormal anteroposterior thickness of the cornea.
A increased anteroposterior thickness of the cornea.
Abnormality of the corneal endothelium, that is, the single layer of cells on the inner surface of the cornea.
An abnormality of the stroma of cornea, also known as the substantia propria of cornea.
Reduced transparency of the central portion of the corneal stroma.
Abnormality of the corneal epithelium, that is of the epithelial tissue that covers the front of the cornea.
A conical projection of the anterior surface of the lens, occurring as a developmental anomaly.
A conical projection of the posterior surface of the lens, occurring as a developmental anomaly.
Cystoid macular edema (CME) is any type of macular edema that involves cyst formation.
Individuals with anomalous trichromacy possess three types of cones, but one of the three types of cones has an abnormal spectral sensitivity compared to normal cones.
Exaggerated curvature of the lens of the eye, producing an anterior or posterior spherical bulging.
The appearance of yellow/white crystalline-like (hence the name) spots in the retina and thickening of the peripheral part of the vitreous.
Abnormality of the spatial relationship of the atria to other components of the heart.
In left atrial isomerism there is a bilateral small finger-shaped morphologically left atrial appendage joining the atrial chamber along a narrow front without an internal terminal crest.
Mirror image atrial arrangement, with morphologic right atrium on the left hand side and morphologic left atrium on the right hand side.
An abnormality of the circulatory connection between atria and ventricles.
Connection of the right atrium to the left ventricle and of the left atrium to the right ventricle in a biventricular heart.

The condition in which both atria are joined to the left ventricle each by its own atrioventricular valve. Usually there is a hypoplastic right ventricle, which may be on the opposite side of the heart as usual.
The condition in which both atria are joined to the right ventricle each by its own atrioventricular valve. Usually, the left ventricle is hypoplastic.
An atrioventricular valve that empties into both ventricles. The valve overrides the interventricular septum above a ventricular septum defect.
A type of ectopia cordis with the heart partially in the cervical region with a defect of the superior portion of the sternum.
Congenital malformation of the ventral wall with partial or total evisceration of the heart outside the thoracic cavity and displacement partially into the abdominal cavity.
Mesocardia is an abnormal location of the heart in which the heart is in a midline position and the longitudinal axis of the heart lies in the mid-sagittal plane.
Abnormal plane of direction of the heart from the base to the apex in the midline. Left sided is normal.
A congenital anomaly with an abnormal connection between the aorta and the main pulmonary artery resulting in an aortopulmonary shunt.
A congenital anomaly with an abnormal connection between the aorta and the main pulmonary artery resulting in an aortopulmonary shunt.
The presence of a single coronary artery ostium from which both coronary arteries arise.
A venous pouch within the left ventricular wall, with a neck opening into the coronary sinus.
Narrowing or constriction of the aorta localized at the insertion of the ductus arteriosus, i.e., to the juxtaductal region of aortic arch.

Absence of the right superior vena cava (RSVC). An absent RSVC is always associated with a persistent left superior vena cava (PLSVC). During normal fetal development, the left-sided anterior venous cardinal system regresses, leaving the coronary sinus (CS) and the ligament of Marshall. Failure of the closure of the left anterior cardinal vein results in PLSVC. In general, PLSVC is associated with the right superior vena cava (RSVC) and drains into the RA via a dilated CS. When developmental arrest occurs at an earlier stage, the CS is absent and the PLSVC drains into the left atrium.
A type of supraventricular tachycardia that originates in the atrioventricular node.
Hemorrhage into the parenchyma of the cerebellum.
Chronic supraventricular tachycardia predominantly seen in childhood.
Multifocal atrial tachycardia is a rare supraventricular arrhythmia in neonates and young infants that is characterized by multiple P waves with varying P wave morphology and is usually asymptomatic.
Conduction block in the anterior division of the left bundle branch of the bundle of His.

ET: Congenital malformation of the right heart
DEF: Defect or defects of the morphogenesis of the right heart identifiable at birth.

Systemic desaturation of a liveborn baby resulting from persistent pulmonary hypertension with a patent ductus arteriosus and patent foramen ovale, such that the circulation in postnatal life follows the fetal course.
A form of adrenal insufficiency related to a lack of ACTH, which leads to a decrease in the production of cortisol by the adrenal glands. Aldosterone production is not usually affected.
Abnormal anatomical location of the adrenal gland.
An abnormality of the adenohypophysis, which is also known as the anterior lobe of the pituitary gland.
An abnormality of the neurohypophysis, which is also known as the posterior lobe of the hypophysis.
Abnormal embryonic development of the parathyroid gland.
An abnormal anatomical location of the parathyroid gland.
A structural abnormality of the thyroid gland.
Neoplasm categorized according to type of histological abnormality.
The presence of an embryonal neoplasm of the kidney that primarily affects children.
Decreased intensity of the patellar reflex (also known as the knee jerk reflex).
A cleft of the muscular (soft) portion of the palate that is covered by mucous membrane. Soft-palate submucous clefts are characterized by a midline deficiency or lack of muscle tissue.
Absence of the normal opening of the choana (the posterior nasal aperture) as a result of an obstructing choanal membrane that may be thin and strandlike or thick and pluglike.
Absence of the usual parallel position of philtral ridges.
Positioning of the nasal tip inferior to the nasal base.
Detectable but decreased IgA levels that are more than 2 standard deviations below normal age-adjusted means.
An abnormality of the form, structure, or size of the skeletal system.
A bone tumor composed of cellular spindle-cell stroma containing scattered multinucleated giant cells resembling osteoclasts.
The presence of spots or rounded patches of abnormally increased density of metaphyseal bone.
Both lungs have three lobes. Normally, the left lung has two lobes, whereas the right lung has three lobes.
Abnormal number of platelets per volume of blood. In a healthy adult, a normal platelet count is between 150,000 and 450,000 per microliter of blood.

Anomalous size of platelets. Most normal sized platelets are 1.5 to 3 micrometers in diameter. Large platelets are 4 to 7 micrometers. Giant platelets are larger than 7 micrometers and usually 10 to 20 micrometers.
Bleeding from vessels of the various tissues of the eye.
Number of leukocytes per volume of blood beyond normal limits.
Abnormally flat shape of the heads of the metacarpal bones.
Excessive, increased hair growth located in the lumbar region.

ET: Abnormality of the superior cerebellar peduncle
DEF: An anomaly of the superior cerebellar peduncle.
Acute inflammation of the lung due to an infection.
An acute episode of pneumonia due to the aspiration (breathing in) of food, liquid, or gastric contents into the upper respiratory tract.

Absence of any measurable level of sperm in his semen, resulting from post-testicular obstruction or retrograde ejaculation. This can be differentiated from obstructive azoospermia on the basis of testicular biopsy.

An exaggerated whealing tendency when the skin is stroked, that is, formation of red, itchy bumps and lines on the skin as a result of pressure on the skin (for instance, stroking the skin with a pen or tongue depressor).
A deviation from the normal range of neutrophil cell counts in the circulation.
An abnormality of the interatrial septum.

A bulging of the interatrial septum towards one side. In adults, atrial septal aneurysm can be defined as a protrusion of the aneurysm of >10 mm beyond the plane of the atrial septum as measured by transesophageal echocardiography.
Abnormally increased level of blood lactate following a meal.
Elevated concentration of galactose in the urine.

Multiple, localized or widespread, asymptomatic or inflammatory dermal cysts involving the pilosebaceous units. Lesions can appear anywhere on the body, but steatocystoma multiplex is more commonly involved with those areas of the skin with a high density of developed pilosebaceous units (e.g., the axilla, groin, neck, and proximal extremities).
Wasting of the pectoral muscles, i.e., of the pectoralis major and pectoralis minor.

Presence of folds in the Descemet membrane, which is the basement membrane of the endothelial (inner) cell layer of the cornea. Descemet membrane folds are generally a manifestation of inflammation or edema of the cornea.
Abnormal accumulation of fluid and swelling of the stroma of cornea.

A form of focal dystonia that affects the vocal cords, associated with involuntary contractions of the vocal cords causing interruptions of speech and affecting the voice quality and often leading to patterned, repeated breaks in speech.
Hypoglycermia following a meal (or more generally, after intake of glucose).
A reduced concentration of calcifediol in the blood. Calcifediol is also known as calcidiol, 25-hydroxycholecalciferol and 25-Hydroxyvitamin D3.
Malignant tumor of melanocytes of the ciliary body.

A subtype of melanoma in situ that typically develops on sun-damaged skin. The lesion is typically a large, irregularly pigmented macule that has developed from an ordinary lentigo (a small pigmented spot on the skin with a clearly-defined edge). Change to a malignant lentigo typically takes place over 20 years or more, and many patients accept the change as a consequence of aging.
Atrophy of the cerebellum affecting primarily the granular cell layer.
A deviation from the normal odor of the urine.
A deviation from the normal size of the pancreas.
Dislocation of many joints.
Atrophy of the parietal cortex.
Atrophy of the occipital cortex.
Increased width of the cross sectional diameter of the fibula.
A carcinoma of the endometrium, the mucous lining of the uterus.
Inflammation of the uveal tract in which the primary site of inflammation is the anterior chamber.
Inflammation of the uveal tract in which the primary site of inflammation is the retina or choroid.
Inflammation of the uveal tract in which the primary site of inflammation is the vitreous.
Increased count of erythroid precursor cells, that is, erythroid lineage cells in the bone marrow.
Increased count of erythroid precursor cells, that is, erythroid lineage cells in the bone marrow.
Decreased count of erythroid precursor cells, that is, erythroid lineage cells in the bone marrow.
Atrophy of the cerebral subcortical white and gray matter, termed subcortical atrophy, reflects loss of nerve cells in the basal ganglia or fibers in the deep white matter.
Repetitive and compulsive picking of skin which results in tissue damage.
Habitual repetitive movement of the body.

A form of focal dystonia affecting the face and especially the jaw that is induced by the act of speaking. It is an involuntary contraction of the masticatory muscles, resulting in dysarthria or dysphagia.

A disorder of large arteries, in particular the aorta, characterized by an accumulation of basophilic ground substance in the media with cyst-like lesions associated with degenerative changes of collagen, elastin and the vascular smooth muscle cells.
Malfunction of a peripheral nerve resulting from mechanical compression of the nerve roots from internal or external causes and leading to a conduction block or axonal loss.
Uneven rhythm of breathing.
A type of tumor of the pancreatic beta cells that secretes excess insulin and can result in hypoglycemia.
Any structural anomaly of the acrosome resulting in a round sperm head.
The deposition of calcium phosphate microliths within the seminiferous tubules.
The presence of multiple hemangiomas in the arachnoid.

A type of headache that last hours with continuous pain of mild or moderate intensity, bilateral location, a pressing/tightening (non-pulsating) quality and that is not aggravated by routine physical activity such as walking or climbing stairs.

A type of retinal detachment associated with a retinal tear, that is, with a break in the retina that allows fluid to pass from the vitreous space into the subretinal space between the sensory retina and the retinal pigment epithelium.

A type of retinal detachment arising from damage to the outer blood-retinal barrier that allows fluid to access the subretinal space and separate the neurosensory retina from the retinal pigment epithelium.
Decreased time between the start of the Q wave and the end of the T wave as measured by the electrocardiogram (EKG).
An increased concentration of urocanic acid in the urine.
Atrophy of the levator palpebrae superioris, the extraocular muscle that elevates the superior eyelid.
Increased time for the PR interval (beginning of the P wave to the beginning of the QRS complex).
An electrocardiographic anomaly in which the ST segment is observed to be located inferior to the isoelectric line.
A liposarcoma that contains myxomatous tissue.
An abnormally reduced concentration of glycine in the blood.
Reduced diameter of the middle phalanx of finger.
Reduced diameter of the distal phalanx of finger.
Reduced diameter of the proximal phalanx of finger.
An anomaly of the arch of aorta.
Underdevelopment of the arch of aorta.

JT: 皮膚アミロイドーシス
DEF: The presence of amyloid deposition in the superficial dermis.
Any neoplasm composed of fibrous tissue.
An anomaly of the celiac artery.
Impairment of bile flow due to obstruction in large bile ducts outside the liver.
An abnormality of the metabolism of folic acid, which is also known as vitamin B9.
The deposition of calcium salts in the parenchyma of the renal medulla (innermost part of the kidney).
The deposition of calcium salts in the parenchyma of the renal cortex (the outer portion of the kidney between the renal capsule and the renal medulla).

A type of anemia resulting from suppression of erythropoiesis with little or no abnormality of leukocyte or platelet production. Erythroblasts are virtually absent in bone marrow; however, leukocyte and platelet production show little or no reduction.
An abnormality of the partial pressure of oxygen or carbon dioxide in the arterial blood.
Abnormally elevated blood carbon dioxide (CO2) level.
Abnormally reduced blood carbon dioxide (CO2) level.
Congenital lack of the skin of prepuce of penis, that is, of the double-layered fold of skin and mucous membrane that covers the glans penis.
Underdevelopment of the cerebral white matter.
Intermittent and recurrent bouts of a subjective feeling of tiredness characterized by a lack of energy and motivation.
Reduction in length of the ventral (lower) skin of prepuce of penis.
A structural anomaly of the gallbladder.
A functional anomaly of the gallbladder.
A functional abnormality of the biliary tree.
A structural abnormality of the biliary tree.
Any anomaly in the process by which myelin sheaths are formed and maintained around neurons.
Inflammation of the synovial membrane of the sacroiliac joint.
Calcification, that is, pathological deposition of calcium salts in the tunica media of arteries.
An increased level of iron in liver tissues.
Increased width of the skin of vermilion border region of upper lip.
An anomaly of cerebral veins.

A congenital malformation of veins which drain normal brain characterized by a caput medusae or an umbrellalike convergence of multiple venules on a single, or occasionally multiple, enlarged parenchymal or medullary vein, like the trunk of a tree or the shank of an umbrella. This dilated terminal vein penetrates the cortex to drain either (a) superficially to cortical veins or sinuses, (b) deeply to subependymal veins of the lateral ventricle and then into the galenic system, (c) to the fourth ventricle and then to the pontomesencephalic vein, or (d) to the precentral cerebellar vein and into the galenic system.
A venous angioma of the frontal lobe of the brain.

Defective structure, size or content of dense granules, platelet organelles that contain granules proaggregatory factors such as adenosine diphosphate (ADP), adenosine triphosphate (ATP), ionized calcium , histamine and serotonin.

An arachnoid cyst that progressively enlarges from an abnormality in the membrane of Liliequist or in the interpeduncular cistern, and typically, expands from the prepontine space, displacing the floor of the third ventricle upwards, the pituitary stalk and optic chiasm upwards and forwards, and the mammillary bodies upwards and backwards.
Narrowing or constriction of the inner surface (lumen) of the anterior cerebral artery.
Narrowing or constriction of the inner surface (lumen) of the posterior cerebral artery.
A decrease in the maximum amount of negative pressure a person can generate during an inhalation.
A decrease in the maximum amount of pressure of expired air achieved by a person after a full inspiration.

A separation of the layers within the wall of the descending aorta. Tears in the intimal layer result in the propagation of dissection (proximally or distally) secondary to blood entering the intima-media space.

ET: Abnormality of the brainstem white matter
DEF: An anomaly of the white matter of brainstem.
An abnormally decreased size of the pituitary gland.
A deviation from the normal discoid platelet shape.
A detrimental reaction to the presence of gluten in food, which may include abdominal pain, fatigue, headaches and paresthesia, or celiac disease.
The presence of hemosiderin in the urine.
Muscle fibers degeneration resulting in fatty replacement of skeletal muscle fibers
A thumbnail that is diminished in length and width, i.e., underdeveloped thumb nail.
Absent nail of big toe.
A ratio of serum triiodothyronine (T3) to thyroxine (T4) in the blood that is higher than normal.
A ratio of serum triiodothyronine (T3) to thyroxine (T4) in the blood that is lower than normal.
The presence of an aortic valve with one instead of the normal three cusps (flaps).
A bilateral form of developmental dysplasia of the kidney.
One sided hypoplasia of the kidney.
Two sided hypoplasia of the kidney.
Hematuria that is visible upon inspection of the urine.
An abnormal amount of urine production.
An abnormally decreased sodium concentration in the urine.
An increased concentration of sodium(1+) in the urine.
Elevated concentration of SO4(2-), i.e., sulfate, in the urine.
Presence of leukocyte casts (cylindrical structures produced by the kidney in certain disease states) in the urine.
Presence of a many diverticula (sac or pouch) in the wall of the urinary bladder.
Developmental anomaly in which the vagina, bladder, and rectum fuse resulting in a common channel.
An anomaly in the amount of force per unit area exerted by the intraocular fluid within the eye.
A difference in the amount of intraocular pressure in the right and left eye.
High urine calcium in the presence of hypocalcemia.
A deviation from the norm of the intracranial pressure.

Any anomaly of the inflammatory response, a response to injury or infection characterized by local vasodilation, extravasation of plasma into intercellular spaces and accumulation of white blood cells and macrophages.
Asthma attacks following exercise.
An exaggerated response to carotid sinus baroreceptor stimulation resulting in syncope from transient diminished cerebral perfusion.
An exaggerated response to carotid sinus baroreceptor stimulation resulting in syncope from transient diminished cerebral perfusion.
An abnormal build up of iron (Fe) in the globus pallidus.
A structural abnormality of the pineal gland.
A functional abnormality of the pineal gland.
A functional anomaly of the large intestine.
Excessive growth of a nail laterally into the nail fold.

ET: Functional abnormality of the gastrointestinal tract
DEF: Abnormal functionality of the gastrointestinal tract.
Low blood glucose is accompanied by elevated levels of ketone bodies in the body.
Absence of a testis from the scrotum on one side owing to failure of the testis or testes to descend through the inguinal canal to the scrotum.
A sudden attack of dyspnea that occurs while the affected person is at rest.
A type of nephrogenic rest associated with multiple lesions in the periphery of the renal lobe.
A type of nephrogenic rest usually representing single lesions within the renal lobe, renal sinus, or calyceal walls.
Repeated episodes of pyelonephritis.
An anomaly of the process of formation of bone in the humerus.
A morphological abnormality of the optic disc, i.e., of the portion of the optic nerve clinically visible on fundoscopic examination.
A benign or malignant neoplasm arising from the lymphatic vessels.
One-sided weakness of the muscles of facial expression and eye closure.
A loss of the ability to move the vocal fold on both sides.
A benign or malignant neoplasm that arises from the hair follicles, sebaceous glands, or sweat glands.
Presence of multiple trichilemmomata, a benign tumour originating from the outer root sheath of the hair follicle.
Hepatic fibrosis that reaches from a portal area to another portal area.
Spermatozoa with very small cranial ends devoid of any nuclear material, that is, lacking a typical sperm head.
A structural anomaly of the secretory duct of the testicle that carries spermatozoa from the epididymis to the prostatic urethra where it terminates to form ejaculatory duct.
An abnormal functionality of the male genital system.
The emission of semen and seminal fluid during the act of preparation for sexual intercourse, i.e. before there is penetration, or shortly after penetration.
An abdominal mass formed by bleeding into a follicular ovarian cyst or corpus luteum cyst.
Difficulty releasing one's grip associated with prolonged first handgrip relaxation times.
Slowed relaxation of muscles in the jaw.
Slowed relaxation of muscles in the leg.
Slowed relaxation of muscles in the arm.
A problem occurring during any phase of the female sexual response cycle that prevents the individual from experiencing satisfaction from the sexual activity

JT: 陳旧性|薄いOR細いOR希薄OR薄めるOR間引く|足指爪
廃盤フラットミッドフェイス
DEF: An abnormally increased head circumference in a growing child. Head circumference is measured with a nonelastic tape and comprises the distance from above the eyebrows and ears and around the back of the head. The measured HC is then plotted on an appropriate growth chart.

ET: Neoplasm of the central nervous system
DEF: A neoplasm of the central nervous system.

ET: Neoplasm of the peripheral nervous system
DEF: A benign or malignant neoplasm (tumour) of the peripheral nervous system.
A benign nerve sheath tumor composed of Schwann cells.
Scalp hair whose growth is slower than normal.

ET: Bracket epiphysis of the proximal phalanx of the 4th toe
Lipomas of the central neryous system
DEF: The presence of mulitple lipomas located in the central nervous system.

ET: Stenosis of the medullary cavity of the long bones

DEF: The presence of dysplastic regions in metaphyseal regions.
A form of polydactyly in which the extra digit or digits are localized on the side of the thumb or great toe.
A form of polydactyly in which the extra digit or digits are localized on the side of the fifth finger or fifth toe.
A form of polydactyly in which the extra digit or digits are localized on the side of the fifth finger or fifth toe.
The presence of a supernumerary finger or toe (not a thumb or hallux) involving the third or fourth metacarpal/tarsal with associated osseous syndactyly.
The presence of a supernumerary finger or toe (not a thumb or hallux) involving the third or fourth metacarpal/tarsal with associated osseous syndactyly.
Depression located paramedially on the vermilion of a lip.

Gustatory lacrimation results from an aberrant innervation of fibres from the seventh cranial nerve to the pterygopalatine ganglion which are destined originally for the submandibular ganglion. This aberrant innervation leads to uncontrollable tearing while eating or in anticipation of a meal.
Benign congenital lesions of the periauricular soft tissue consisting of a blind-ending narrow tube or pit.
Immunological states where the immune system produces harmful responses upon reexposure to sensitising antigens.
Hypersensitivity in form of an adverse immune reaction against cow milk protein.
Clefting of the upper lip affecting the lateral portions of the upper lip rather than the midline/median region.

ET: Joint contractures involving the joints of the feet
DEF: Contractures of one ore more joints of the feet meaning chronic loss of joint motion due to structural changes in non-bony tissue.

Any structural anomaly of mast cells, which are found in almost all tissues and contain numerous basophilic granules and are capable of releasing large amounts of histamine and heparin upon activation.
A reduced concentration of vitamin B1.
A reduced concentration of vitamin B2.
A reduced concentration of vitamin B5.
A reduced concentration of vitamin B8.

Epileptic encephalaopathy is characterized by (1) electrographic EEG paroxysmal activity that is often aggressive, (2) seizures that are usually multiform and intractable, (3) cognitive, behavioral and neurological deficits that may be relentless, and (4) sometimes early death.

A condition in which the skin can be stretched beyond normal, and then returns to its initial position.
The presence of a cavernous hemangioma. A hemangioma characterized by large endothelial spaces (caverns) is called a cavernous hemangioma.

Loss of previously present mental abilities, generally in adults.
Spastic weakness affecting all four limbs.

Inflammatory changes in the synovial membranes and articular structures with widespread fibrinoid degeneration of the collagen fibers in mesenchymal tissues, as well as atrophy and rarefaction of bony structures.
A mode of inheritance that is observed for traits related to a gene encoded on the X chromosome.
A mode of inheritance that is observed for traits related to a gene encoded on the Y chromosome.
A loss of the ability to move the vocal folds.
Atrial septal defect (ASD) is a congenital abnormality of the interatrial septum that enables blood flow between the left and right atria via the interatrial septum.
The heart suddenly and unexpectedly stops beating resulting in death within a short time period (generally within 1 h of symptom onset).
An abnormality of the mitral valve characterized by insufficiency or incompetence of the mitral valve resulting in retrograde leaking of blood through the mitral valve upon ventricular contraction.
Failure of the foramen ovale to seal postnatally, leaving a potential conduit between the left and right cardiac atria.
An insufficiency of the aortic valve, leading to regurgitation (backward flow) of blood from the aorta into the left ventricle.
Coarctation of the aorta is a narrowing or constriction of a segment of the aorta.
Accumulation of fluid within the pericardium.
A deformity of foot and ankle in which the foot is bent down and outwards.
An abnormality of the morphology of the toes, such that the tips of the toes are prominent and bulbous.
Underdevelopment of the toenail.
Camptodactyly is a painless flexion contracture of the proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joint that is usually gradually progressive. This term refers to camptodactyly of one or more toes.
The presence of unusually deep creases (ridges/wrinkles) on the skin of sole of foot.
Anemia characterized by the presence of erythroblasts that are larger than normal (megaloblasts).
An elevation above the normal ratio of the volume of red blood cells to the total volume of blood.

Sideroblastic anemia results from a defect in the incorporation of iron into the heme molecule. A sideroblast is an erythroblast that has stainable deposits of iron in cytoplasm (this can be demonstrated by Prussian blue staining).
A pathological narrowing of the esophagus that is caused by the development of a ring of scar tissue that constricts the esophageal lumen.

Difficulty in breathing. The physical presentation of respiratory distress is generally referred to as labored breathing, while the sensation of respiratory distress is called shortness of breath or dyspnea.

JT: 高トリグリセリド血症
DEF: An abnormal increase in the level of triglycerides in the blood.
Inward advance of skin over the nail plate.

A tendency to fall or the inability to keep oneself from falling; imbalance. The retropulsion test is widely regarded as the gold standard to evaluate postural instability, Use of the retropulsion test includes a rapid balance perturbation in the backward direction, and the number of balance correcting steps (or total absence thereof) is used to rate the degree of postural instability. Healthy subjects correct such perturbations with either one or two large steps, or without taking any steps, hinging rapidly at the hips while swinging the arms forward as a counterweight. In patients with balance impairment, balance correcting steps are often too small, forcing patients to take more than two steps. Taking three or more steps is generally considered to be abnormal, and taking more than five steps is regarded as being clearly abnormal. Markedly affected patients continue to step backward without ever regaining their balance and must be caught by the examiner (this would be called true retropulsion). Even more severely affected patients fail to correct entirely, and fall backward like a pushed toy soldier, without taking any corrective steps.

A generalized-onset seizure is a type of seizure originating at some point within, and rapidly engaging, bilaterally distributed networks. The networks may include cortical and subcortical structures but not necessarily the entire cortex.
Reduced number or density of axillary hair.
Absence of axillary hair.
Unlocalized atrophy of the brain with decreased total brain matter volume and increased ventricular size.
Progressive loss of hair.
Loss of all hair on the entire body.

No consensus exists on what a stroke-like episode is, but these episodes can be functionally defined as a new neurological deficit, occurring with or without the context of seizures, which last longer than 24 hours.
Presence of more than two nipples.

Budd-Chiari syndrome (BCS) is caused by obstruction of hepatic venous outflow at any level from the small hepatic veins to the junction of the inferior vena cava (IVC) with the right atrium, 1 and occurs in 1/100,000 of the general population worldwide. The most common presentation is with ascites, but can range from fulminant hepatic failure (FHF) to asymptomatic forms. Obstruction of hepatic venous outflow is mainly caused by primary intravascular thrombosis, which can occur suddenly or be repeated over time, accompanied by some revascularization, accounting for the variable parenchymal hepatic damage and histologic presentation. Budd-Chiari syndrome is thus a disease, but since it occurs as a manifestation of several other diseases, this term is kept for the present for convenience.

Budd-Chiari syndrome (BCS) is caused by obstruction of hepatic venous outflow at any level from the small hepatic veins to the junction of the inferior vena cava (IVC) with the right atrium, 1 and occurs in 1/100,000 of the general population worldwide. The most common presentation is with ascites, but can range from fulminant hepatic failure (FHF) to asymptomatic forms. Obstruction of hepatic venous outflow is mainly caused by primary intravascular thrombosis, which can occur suddenly or be repeated over time, accompanied by some revascularization, accounting for the variable parenchymal hepatic damage and histologic presentation. Budd-Chiari syndrome is thus a disease, but since it occurs as a manifestation of several other diseases, this term is kept for the present for convenience.
The presence of a basal cell carcinoma of the skin.
An abnormal narrowing of the foramen magnum.
An abnormal increase in the size of the foramen magnum.
Increased susceptibility to infections.
An increased susceptibility to bronchitis as manifested by a history of recurrent bronchitis.
An abnormal accentuation of the inward curvature of the spine in the lumbar region.
Altered immune function characterized by lymphoid proliferation, immune activation, and excessive autoreactivity often leading to autoimmune/inflammatory complications.

JT: 異常ガンマグロブリン血症
DEF: Selective deficiency of one or more, but not all, classes of immunoglobulins.
The kneecap normally is located within the groove termed trochlea on the distal femur and can slide up and down in it. Patellar dislocation occurs if the patella fully dislocates out of the groove.
Abnormal widening of the metaphyseal regions of long bones.
An elevation in bone density in one or more diaphyses. Sclerosis is normally detected on a radiograph as an area of increased opacity.
Trophic changes occurring in a limb.

JT: 高コレステロール血症
DEF: An increased concentration of cholesterol in the blood.
