DEF: An increased level of a dibasic amino acid in the urine. Dibasic amino acids are usually refered to simply as basic aminoacids because they contain basic side chains at neutral pH. These are arginine (Arg), lysine (Lys), and histidine (His).

Flattening of the superior part of the acetabulum, which is a cup-shaped cavity at the base of the hipbone into which the ball-shaped head of the femur fits. The acetabular roof thereby appears horizontal rather than arched, as it normally does.
Abnormally increased width of the pubic symphysis is the midline cartilaginous joint uniting the superior rami of the left and right pubic bones.
Distention of the abdomen.
The closed form of spina bifida with incomplete closure of a vertebral body with intact overlying skin.
A partial dislocation of one or more intervertebral joints in the cervical vertebral column.

Repeated episodes of segmental demyelination and remyelination lead to the accumulation of supernumerary Schwann cells around axons, which is referred to as onion bulb formation. This finding affects peripheral nerves.
A severe degree of short stature, more than -4 SD from the mean corrected for age and sex.
A functional motor deficit where individuals whose responses to the challenges of exercise fail to achieve levels considered normal for their age and gender.
Reduced strength and weakness of the muscles of the arms and legs.
Weakness of the muscles involved in neck flexion (sternocleidomastoid, longus capitus, longus colli, and scalenus anterior).
A mode of inheritance in which the severity of a disorder increases or the age of onset decreases as the disorder is passed from one generation to the next.
Excessive production of saliva.
A displacement or misalignment of the humerus with respect to the other bones of the should joint. Note that a subluxation is a partial dislocation.
A partial dislocation of the shoulder joint.

Presence of more than one exostosis originating in one or noth humerus bones. An exostosis is a benign growth the projects outward from the bone surface. It is capped by cartilage, and arises from a bone that develops from cartilage.

JT: 上腕骨モデリング不全

DEF: Osteosclerosis (increased density related to increased bone mass) of the ulna.
An abnormal groove on the midline of the nose that may extend to the nasal tip.
Underdevelopment of the trapezoid.
A narrowing of the biparietal diameter (i.e., of the transverse distance between the protuberances of the two parietal bones of the skull).
Excessive growth of the bones of cranium, i.e., of the skull.
A discontinuity of the vertebral arch, i.e., of the posterior part of a vertebra.
Excessive, increased hair growth located in the elbow region.
An anatomical anomaly that results from an abnormal rotation of the gut as it returns to the abdominal cavity during embryogenesis.
A reduced concentration of vitamin A.
An abnormality of the Achilles tendon.
An abnormal reduction in the ability to masticate (chew), i.e., in the ability to crush and ground food in preparation for swallowing.
The presence of multiple diverticula of the intestine.
The presence of developmental dysplasia of the pancreas.
A pregnancy that ends at a stage in which the fetus is incapable of surviving on its own, defined as the spontaneous loss of a fetus before the 20th week of pregnancy.
Underdevelopment of the philtrum.
A reduced level of the complement component C3 in circulation.
The presence of many cysts in the kidney.
A type of carcinoma of the kidney with origin in the epithelium of the proximal convoluted renal tubule.
The presence of a bilobed gallbladder, related to a duplication of the gallbladder primordium.
This type of brachydactyly is characterized by short and broad terminal phalanges of the thumbs and big toes.
A flattened vertebral body shape with reduced distance beween the vertebral endplates affecting the lumbar spine.

Y-shaped metacarpals are the result of a partial fusion of two metacarpal bones, with the two arms of the Y pointing in the distal direction. Y-shaped metacarpals may be seen in combination with polydactyly.
An increased resorption of bone matrix by osteoclasts leading to bony defects involving the tarsal bones.
A chronic form of pancreatitis.
A bending or abnormal curvature of the distal portion of the tibia.
Accumulation of amorphous PAS-positive material in the space betweem alveolar macrophages, sometimes as condensed form (oval bodies) are typically found in alveolar proteinosis.

According to the definitions of the American and British Thoracic Societies, including pulmonary functional tests, X-rays, and CT scans for items such as fibrosis, bronchiectasis, bullae, emphysema, nodular or lymphomatous abnormalities.
Lack of development of the glenoid fossa, also known as the glenoid cavity, which is the articular surface of the scapula that articulates with the head of the humerus.
Osteosclerosis of ribs (increased density related to increased bone mass).
The presence of excessive connective tissue in the endocardium.
Steatosis in the myocardium.
A localized outpouching of ventricular cavity that is generally associated with dyskinesia and paradoxical expansion during systole.
A benign renal neoplasm composed of fat, vascular, and smooth muscle elements.

A form of lissencephaly in which the cortex is thickened and has four more or less disorganized layers rather than six normal layers resulting from incomplete neuronal migration during brain development. At neuropathological examination, a 4-layered cortex consists of an upper molecular layer, a second thin cellular layer containing pyramidal neurons usually observed in layer V, a third pale poorly cellular layer and a fourth thick deep layer made up of neurons which had failed to migrate. Radiologocally would manifest as agyria or pachygyria with cortical thickness greater than 10 mm.
Nystagmus dating from or present at birth.
An increased susceptibility to meningitis as manifested by a medical history of recurrent episodes of meningitis.

The presence of dysplasia (abnormal growth or development) of the cerebellum. Cerebellar dysplasia is a neuroimaging finding that describes abnormalities of both the cerebellar cortex and white matter and is associated with variable neurodevelopmental outcome.
A particular type of dementia characterized by a pattern of mental defects consisting prominently of forgetfulness, slowness of thought processes, and personality or mood change.

JT: 運動性ポリニューロパチー

DEF: Agenesis of the midbrain.
A discrete posterior fossa cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) collection that does not communicate directly with the fourth ventricle.
A type of dystonia that affects all or most of the body.

JT: 遠視性サッケード(断続性運動)
DEF: A saccade that overshoots the target with the dynamic saccade.

JT: 運動ニューロン萎縮/変性
DEF: Wasting involving the motor neuron.
A malignant melanoma originating within the eye. The tumor originates from the melanocytes in the uvea (which comprises the iris, ciliary body, and choroid).
A kind of cataract that progresses with age.
Increased length of the upper eyelashes.
The presence of multiple hemangiomas in the choroid. These are generally reddish or orange or can have increased pigmentation maiking them difficult to distinguish from choroidal melanomas.
Blindness with onset at birth.
Retinal exudate within the retinal tissue itself.

ET: Abnormality of the line of Schwalbe
DEF: An abnormality of the line of Schwalbe.
A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the skin.
Reduction in bone mineral density affecting any or all of the tarsal bones, seven bones of the foot comprising the calcaneus, talus, cuboid, navicular, and the cuneiform bones.
An absence of low-density lipoprotein cholesterol in the blood.

A reduced level of prolactin in the blood circulation. Prolactin is a protein hormone that is secreted by lactotrophs in the anterior pituitary and that stimulates mammary gland development and milk production.
Aplasia of the parathyroid gland.

JT: 急性高アンモニア血症
DEF: An increased concentration of ammonia in the blood with sudden onset.
Degeneration of the olivary bodies, prominent oval structures in the medulla oblongata.

Absence of one half of the vertebral body in the lumbar spine.
The presence of arthrosis, i.e., of degenerative joint disease, affecting the cervical vertebral column.
Vestibular areflexia can be measured as the absence of the caloric nystagmus response in electronystagmography.
Increased anterosuperior prominence of the area between the bottom of the incisura and the inner margin of the antihelix.
Hypertrophy of the clitoris.
Underdevelopment of the larynx.
A decreased ability to move the femur at the hip joint associated with a decreased range of motion of the hip.
The presence of developmental dysplasia of the acetabular part of hip bone.
An acute form of rhabdomyolysis.

ET: Osteolysis involving bones of the feet

DEF: A pseudoepiphysis is a secondary ossification center distinct from the normal epiphysis. The normal metacarpal epiphyses are located at the distal ends of the metacarpal bones. Accessory epiphyses (which are also known as pseudoepiphyses) can also occasionally be observed at the proximal ends of the metacarpals, usually involving the 2nd metacarpal bone.
A deviation from the normal straight shape of a thumb phalanx.
An abnormal union between bones or parts of bones of the fingers. The synonymous term \

Small nodular masses which originate in the subependymal region of the lateral ventricles and protrude into the ventricular cavity. They may represent subependymal hamartomas of tuberous sclerosis or nodular heterotopia of grey matter.
Hypomelanotic macules (\
The presence of a hamartoma of the cerebrum.
Neurofibromas originating in the spine.
Presence of arachnoid cysts of the spinal canal extradurally in the epidural space.
Peromelia affecting only the upper limbs. That is, the distal parts of the arm are missing leading to stump formation.
Peromelia affecting only the lower limbs. That is, the distal parts of the leg are missing leading to stump formation.

Trichorrhexis nodosa is the formation of nodes along the hair shaft through which breakage readily occurs. It is thus a focal defect in the hair fiber that is characterized by thickening or weak points (nodes) that cause the hair to break off easily. The result is defective, abnormally fragile hair.

Increased width of the 1st metacarpal. In contrast to the proximal phalanges of the digits 2-5, the proximal phalanx of the thumb is embryologically equivalent to the middle phalanges of the other digits, whereas the first metacarpal is embryologically of phalangeal origin and as such equivalent to the proximal phalanges of the other digits.
A developmental defect characterized by reduced length of the first metacarpal (long bone) of the hand.
Short second metacarpal bone because of developmental hypoplasia.
Short third metacarpal bone.
Short fourth metacarpal bone.
Short fifth metacarpal bone.
An increase in width in one or more phalanges of the big toe.

A gap (cleft) affecting one of the alveolar ridges, which are the protuberances in the mouth that contain the sockets (alveoli) of the teeth. An alveolar cleft can affect all structures of the alveolar ridge, including the gingiva, other mucosa, periosteum, alveolar bone, and teeth.
The presence of both ovarian and testicular tissues either in the same or in opposite gonads. Affected persons have ambiguous genitalia and may have 46,XX or 46,XY karyotypes or 46,XX/XY mosaicism.
Aplasia, that is failure to develop, of the ovary.
The presence of more than two testes.
The absence of the major creases of the palm (distal transverse crease, proximal transverse crease, or thenar crease).

The kneecap normally is located within the groove termed trochlea on the distal femur and can slide up and down in it. Patellar subluxation refers to an unstable kneecap that does not slide centrally within its groove, i.e., a partial dislocation of the patella.
An abnormally increased width of the cranial sutures for age-related norms (generally resulting from delayed closure).
Nystagmus due to disturbance of the vestibular system; eye movements are rhythmic, with slow and fast components.

Y-shaped metatarsals are the result of a partial fusion of two metatarsal bones, with the two arms of the Y pointing in the distal direction. Y-shaped metatarsals may be seen in combination with polydactyly.
A hamartoma (disordered proliferation of mature tissues) which can originate from any tissue of the eye.
The presence of abnormal punctate (speckled, dot-like) calcifications in one or more epiphyses.
The presence of bilateral coxa valga.
A kind of congenital cataract that is characterized by a hollow sphere of punctate opacities involving the fetal nucleus and that usually occurs bilaterally.
The presence of xanthomas (intra-and extra-cellular accumulations of cholesterol) extensor tendons (typically over knuckles, Achilles tendon, knee, and elbows).

The presence during the prenatal period of a cystic mass with multiple septa with multiple, asymmetric, thin-walled cysts near the posterior aspect of the neck. Fetal cystic hygroma can be defined as nuchal translucency with or without septations measuring greater than 3.0 mm.
A congenital disorder of the aortic valve in which the orifice of the valve fails to develop.
A 'coral-like' pattern of opacity in the lens of the eye. That is, a cataract with an irregular, stellate form.
An abnormal increase in the level of lipoprotein cholesterol in the blood.
Agenesis of premolar tooth.
An abnormality of molar tooth.

A furuncle (boil) is a skin infection involving an entire hair follicle and nearby skin tissue. Chronic furunculosis refers to recurrent episodes of furuncles, often caused by recurrent staphylococcus infection.
A type of cataract (opacification of the lens) that forms during the course of aging.
A seizure that occurs in the context of a brain insult (systemic, toxic, or metabolic) and may not recur when the underlying cause has been removed or the acute phase has elapsed.
A type of focal-onset seizure characterized by a motor sign as its initial semiological manifestation.
A type of focal motor seizure characterized by sustained increase in muscle contraction, lasting a few seconds to minutes.
A type of focal non-motor seizure characterized by an arrest or pause of activities, freezing, or immobilization as the predominant semiological feature throughout the seizure.
Continuum between the tragus and ascending helix, without any evidence of a posterior extension (crus) towards the concha.
A morphological abnormality of a digit, i.e., of a finger or toe.
Synostosis affecting the right and the left coronal suture.
Thickening of the epidermal layer of the skin.

JT: 死OR死亡|インジウム|青年期OR思春期
DEF: Death during adolescence, the period between childhood and adulthood (roughly between the ages of 10 and 19 years).
An increased consentration of zinc in the blood.
A type of rigidity in which the arms are in flexion and adduction and the legs are extended. This signifies a lesion in the cerebral white matter, internal capsules, or thalamus.
The presence of a carcinoma of the esophagus.
A conical projection of the posterior surface of the lens, occurring as a developmental anomaly.
Congenital absence of the fovea.
The aortic arch extends into the soft tissues of the neck before turning down into to become the descending aorta.
Abnormal outpouching or sac-like dilatation of one of the anatomic dilations of the ascending aorta, which occurs just above the aortic valve.
A type of supraventricular tachycardia that originates in the atrioventricular node.
Libman-Sacks valvular lesions are sterile fibrofibrinous vegetations that favor the left-sided heart valves and usually form on the ventricular surface of the mitral valve.
Absence of a lobe of the thyroid gland related to a failure of its embryologic development.
A type of myotonia that worsens with repeated muscle contractions.
The presence of spots or rounded patches of abnormally increased density of metaphyseal bone.
A reduced concentration of vitamin K.

Hemoglobin A (HbA) contains two globin alpha chains and two globin beta chains. HbA is normally the main adult hemoglobin, representing about 96-98 percent of all hemoglobin. This term represents a decreased in the proportion of HbA below this limit, and can be seen in various forms of thalassemia.
Accumulation of pus in the pleural cavity.
Pneumonia due to the aspiration (breathing in) of food, liquid, or gastric contents into the upper respiratory tract.
Impaired ability to eat related to problems gathering food and getting ready to suck, chew, or swallow it.
Formation of abnormal, extraskeletal bony tissue, i.e., the presence of bone in soft tissue where bone normally does not exist.
A reduced concentration of calcitriol in the blood. Calcitriol is also known as 1,25-dihydroxycholecalciferol or 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D3.
Radiographic features include a dilated, radiolucent lesion typically located eccentrically within the metaphyseal portion of the bone, with fluid levels visible on magnetic resonance imaging.
A benign fluid filled simple cyst of bone filled with serous fluid.

An abnormality of mental functioning affecting the personality and behavioural tendencies of an individual and characterized by a rigid and unhealthy pattern of thinking and behavior. The definition of a personal disorder implies that the abnormality is not the result of damage or insult to the brain or from another psychiatric disorder.
Inflammation of the uveal tract in which the primary site of inflammation is the vitreous.
Decreased count of erythroid precursor cells, that is, erythroid lineage cells in the bone marrow.
A type of lymphoma that originates in T-cells.
A type of lymphoma that originates in B-cells.
A type of blistering that affects the skin of the tibial region.

Increased plasma concentrations of chylomicrons, the large lipid droplet (up to 100 mm in diameter) of reprocessed lipid synthesized in epithelial cells of the small intestine and containing triacylglycerols, cholesterol esters, and several apolipoproteins.
An electrocardiographic anomaly in which the ST segment is observed to be located superior to the isoelectric line.
A malignant tumor of the bone which always arises in the medullary tissue, occurring more often in cylindrical bones.
A reduced level of the complement component C9 in circulation.
Bony swelling of the distal interphalangeal joint (DIP) associated with the formation of osteophytes (calcific spurs) of the articular (joint) cartilage that are visible radiographically.
Bony swelling of the proximal interphalangeal joint (PIP) associated with the formation of osteophytes (calcific spurs) of the articular (joint) cartilage that are visible radiographically.
Inflammation of the sacroiliac joint, generally accompanied by lower back pain.

JT: ホメオスターシス異常
DEF: An anomaly in the processes involved in the maintenance of an internal equilibrium.

Projection of the tip of the dens more than 5 mm above a line joining the hard palate to the posterior lip of the foramen magnum (Chamberlain's line) or the tip of the dens is greater than 7 mm above McGregor's line (the back of the hard palate to the lowest point of the occipital squama).

JT: 副腎皮質性思春期早発
DEF: Onset of adrenarche at an earlier age than usual.
Any anomaly in the process by which myelin sheaths are formed and maintained around neurons.
Constipation for longer than three months with fewer than 3 bowel movements per week, straining, lumpy or hard stools, and a sensation of anorectal obstruction or incomplete defecation.
A deviation from the normal count of alpha granules per thrombocyte.
A type of lymphoma characterized microscopically by the absence of multinucleated Reed-Sternberg cells.
A ratio of serum triiodothyronine (T3) to thyroxine (T4) in the blood that deviates from normal.
Moderately increased levels of protein in the urine (500-1000 mg per day in adults).
An abnormally increased sodium concentration in the urine in the presence of hyponatremia.
Tumor (An abnormal mass of tissue resulting from abnormally dividing cells) of the nasal cavity.

A soft tissue continuity in the A/P axis between two digits that extends distally to at least the level of the proximal interphalangeal joints, or a soft tissue continuity in the A/P axis between two digits that lies significantly distal to the flexion crease that overlies the metacarpophalangeal or metatarsophalangeal joint of the adjacent digits.

JT: 低カリウム血症エピソード
DEF: An abnormally decreased potassium concentration in the blood occurring periodically with a return to normal between the episodes.
Low blood glucose is accompanied by elevated levels of ketone bodies in the body.
A darker than expected T2 signal on magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the basal ganglia. This term refers to a diffuse hypointensity affecting all of the basal ganglia.

JT: 中枢神経髄鞘形成過剰
DEF: Increased amount of myelin in the central nervous system.
Presence of a unitary trichilemmoma, a benign tumour originating from the outer root sheath of the hair follicle.
Hypospadias with location of the urethral meatus in the middle of the inferior shaft of the penis.
Abnormality in the process of ejection of semen (usually carrying sperm) from the male reproductive tract.
Difficulty of a male in achieving orgasm.
Slowed relaxation of muscles in the face.
A closed sac located in the spleen.
A malignant mesothelioma originating from cells of the pleura (the thin layer of mesothelium lining the lungs). Pleural mesothelioma is the most common form of mesothelioma.
Fragmented appearance of the epiphyses.
The abnormal fusion of neighboring bones across a joint.
A form of polydactyly in which the extra digit or digits are localized on the side of the thumb or great toe.

A chronic granulomatous inflammatory disease of the intestines that may affect any part of the gastrointestinal tract from mouth to anus, causing a wide variety of symptoms. It primarily causes abdominal pain, diarrhea which may be bloody, vomiting, or weight loss, but may also cause complications outside of the gastrointestinal tract such as skin rashes, arthritis, inflammation of the eye, tiredness, and lack of concentration. Crohn's disease is thought to be an autoimmune disease, in which the body's immune system attacks the gastrointestinal tract, causing inflammation.
A non-midline cleft of the upper lip on one side only.
A reduced concentration of Vitamin C.
A reduced concentration of Vitamin D.
A reduced concentration of vitamin E in the blood circulation. Vitamin E is a lipophilic vitamin that is also known as alpha-tocopherol.
Tumor of the lung.
Abnormality in the process of thought including the ability to process information.
A difference in length or diameter between the left and right leg.
Difference in length or size between the right and left arm.
A cardiac diverticulum is a rare congenital malformation which is either fibrous or muscular.
Patients who routinely have greater than 20 leukocytes per microliter, but have abacterial urine, are said to have sterile pyuria.
Pregnancy-induced toxic reactions of the mother that can be as harmless as slight Maternal hypertension or as life threatening as Eclampsia.
Neoplasm involving odontogenic cells, an odontogenic tumor.
A congenital malformation with a cleft (gap or opening) in the midline of the face.
A rare paranglioma of the lung, tumors that arise from extra-adrenal chromaffin cells.
A neuropathic disorder characterized by episodes of intense pain in the face, originating from the trigeminal nerve. One, two, or all three branches of the nerve may be affected.
Varicosity of veins in the vulval region.
An abnormality of the development of the fingernails.
An outpouching of the gastric wall.
A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the nail.
Skin crease extending from below the inner canthus laterally along the malar process of the maxilla and zygoma.
An increase in bone density within the clavicle.
Increase in size of the hippocampus.
Different levels of maturation of different bones.
The presence of multiple polyps in the intestine.
Multiple abnormal growths that arise from the lining of the large intestine (colon or rectum) and protrude into the intestinal lumen.
Chronic hepatitis characterized by parenchymal inflammation with formation of large multinucleated hepatocytes in response to a variety of insults to the liver.

JT: モードOR型OR機序OR方法OR最頻値|遺伝OR遺産
DEF: The pattern in which a particular genetic trait or disorder is passed from one generation to the next.
Developmental hypoplasia of the clitoris.

A genital phenotype that is not clearly assignable to a single gender. Ambiguous genitalia can be evaluated using the Prader scale: Prader 0: Normal female external genitalia. Prader 1: Female external genitalia with clitoromegaly. Prader 2: Clitoromegaly with partial labial fusion forming a funnel-shaped urogenital sinus. Prader 3: Increased phallic enlargement. Complete labioscrotal fusion forming a urogenital sinus with a single opening. Prader 4: Complete scrotal fusion with urogenital opening at the base or on the shaft of the phallus. Prader 5: Normal male external genitalia. The diagnosis of ambiguous genitalia is made for Prader 1-4.

A reduction in the level of performance of the kidneys in areas of function comprising the concentration of urine, removal of wastes, the maintenance of electrolyte balance, homeostasis of blood pressure, and calcium metabolism.
Decreased functionality of the female gonads, i.e., of the ovary.

Hyperplasia of the gingiva (that is, a thickening of the soft tissue overlying the alveolar ridge. The degree of thickening ranges from involvement of the interdental papillae alone to gingival overgrowth covering the entire tooth crown.
An abnormality of the sensory perception of sound.
The presence of an abnormally prominent antihelix.
Decreased distance from the nasal tip to the nasal base.
Decreased width of the bony bridge of the nose.
A cataract that occurs congenitally as the result of a developmental defect, in contrast to the majority of cataracts that occur in adulthood as the result of degenerative changes of the lens.
A fold of skin starting at or just below the medial aspect of the lower lid and arching upward to cover, extend in front of and lateral to the medial canthus.

JT: 測定過少性サッケード(断続性運動)
DEF: Saccadic undershoot, i.e., a saccadic eye movement that has less than the magnitude that would be required to gain fixation of the object.
A scotoma (area of diminished vision within the visual field) located between the central point of fixation and the blind spot with a roughly horizontal oval shape.
An abnormal bluish coloration of the sclera.
Developmental hypoplasia of teeth.
Increased spaces (diastemata) between most of the teeth in the same dental arch.

Dental malocclusion refers to an abnormality of the occlusion, or alignment, of the teeth and the way the upper and lower teeth fit together, resulting in overcrowding of teeth or in abnormal bite patterns.
Aggressive behavior can denote verbal aggression, physical aggression against objects, physical aggression against people, and may also include aggression towards oneself.
An abnormal shift in patterns of thinking, acting, or feeling.
Excessive production of parathyroid hormone (PTH) by the parathyroid glands.
The presence of wide, concave anterior rib ends.
Presence of an unusually high number of lentigines (singular: lentigo), which are flat, tan to brown oval spots.
The presence of subcutaneous lipoma.
Glaucoma which forms during the early years of a child's life is called developmental or congenital glaucoma.
Degeneration of retinal ganglion cells and their axons.
A thumb with three phalanges in a single, proximo-distal axis. Thus, this term applies if the thumb has an accessory phalanx, leading to a digit like appearance of the thumb.
Involuntary movements of one hand that accompany and mirror intentional movements of the opposite hand.
Hemorrhage into the parenchyma of the brain.

A flexion contracture is a bent (flexed) joint that cannot be straightened actively or passively. It is thus a chronic loss of joint motion due to structural changes in muscle, tendons, ligaments, or skin that prevents normal movement of joints.
The ability of a joint to move beyond its normal range of motion.
The presence of fibrosis affecting the interlobular stroma of liver.
Increased pressure in the portal vein.

A mode of inheritance that is observed for recessive traits related to a gene encoded on the X chromosome. In the context of medical genetics, X-linked recessive disorders manifest in males (who have one copy of the X chromosome and are thus hemizygotes), but generally not in female heterozygotes who have one mutant and one normal allele.

A mode of inheritance that is observed for dominant traits related to a gene encoded on the X chromosome. In the context of medical genetics, X-linked dominant disorders tend to manifest very severely in affected males. The severity of manifestation in females may depend on the degree of skewed X inactivation.
A mode of inheritance that is observed for traits related to a gene encoded on the Y chromosome.
Slightly elevated lesions on or in the skin with a diameter of over 5 mm.
A thrusting or bulging out of the abdomen.
Abnormally prominent umbilicus (belly button).
A rounded, bulging chest that resembles the shape of a barrel. That is, there is an increased anteroposterior diameter and usually some degree of kyphosis.
A position of the fetus at delivery in which the fetus enters the birth canal with the buttocks or feet first.

A congenital cardiac malformation comprising pulmonary stenosis, overriding aorta, ventricular septum defect, and right ventricular hypertrophy. The diagnosis of TOF is made if at least three of the four above mentioned features are present.

Myocardial fibrosis is characterized by dysregulated collagen turnover (increased synthesis predominates over unchanged or decreased degradation) and excessive diffuse collagen accumulation in the interstitial and perivascular spaces as well as by phenotypically transformed fibroblasts, termed myofibroblasts.
Pattern of blood flow in the heart that deviates from the normal circuit of the circulatory system from the right side of the heart to the left.
Pattern of blood flow in the heart that deviates from the normal circuit of the circulatory system from the right side of the heart to the left.
Irreversible damage to heart tissue (myocardium) due to lack of oxygen after a heart attack (myocardial infarction).

Talipes equinovarus (also called clubfoot) typically has four main components: inversion and adduction of the forefoot; inversion of the heel and hindfoot; equinus (limitation of extension) of the ankle and subtalar joint; and internal rotation of the leg.
Increased side-to-side width of a metatarsal bone.
The metatarsals are deviated medially (tibially), that is, the bones in the front half of the foot bend or turn in toward the body.
Sudden loss of renal function, as manifested by decreased urine production, and a rise in serum creatinine or blood urea nitrogen concentration (azotemia).
Venous or arterial thrombosis (formation of blood clots) of spontaneous nature and which cannot be fully explained by acquired risk (e.g. atherosclerosis).

Nausea is a commonly encountered symptom that has been defined as an unpleasant painless subjective feeling that one will imminently vomit. Vomiting has been defined as the forceful expulsion of the contents of the stomach, duodenum, or jejunum through the oral cavity. While nausea and vomiting are often thought to exist on a temporal continuum, this is not always the case. There are situations when severe nausea may be present without emesis and less frequently, when emesis may be present without preceding nausea.
An increased concentration of homocystine in the blood.
A cyst occurring within the choroid plexus within a cerebral ventricle.
Meckel's diverticulum is a congenital diverticulum located in the distal ileum.
The presence of multiple diverticula of the colon.
A form of dystonia characterized by episodes of dystonia (often hemidystonia or generalized) lasting from minutes to hours. There are no dystonic symptoms between episodes.

Arnold-Chiari malformation consists of a downward displacement of the cerebellar tonsils and the medulla through the foramen magnum, sometimes causing hydrocephalus as a result of obstruction of CSF outflow.
Loss of previously present motor (i.e., movement) abilities.
This term describes abnormality of the white matter of the cerebrum resulting from damage to the myelin sheaths of nerve cells.
A focal dystonia of the fingers, hand, and/or forearm that appears when the affected person attempts to do a task that requires fine motor movements such as writing or playing a musical instrument.

Stenosis of the cerebral aqueduct (also known as the mesencephalic duct, aqueductus mesencephali, or aqueduct of Sylvius), which connects the third cerebral ventricle in the diencephalon to the fourth ventricle, which is between the pons and cerebellum.
Proliferation of astrocytes in the area of a lesion of the central nervous system.

Language impairment is a deficit in comprehension or production of language that includes reduced vocabulary, limited sentence structure or impairments in written or spoken communication. Language abilities are substantially and quantifiably below age expectations.

A developmental structural anomaly of the stalk-like part of the brain that comprises the midbrain (aka mesencephalon), the pons (aka pons Varolii), and the medulla oblongata, and connects the cerebral hemispheres with the cervical spinal cord.
Spastic paralysis affecting all four limbs.
Underdevelopment of the nipple.
Bleeding from the intestines.
Vomiting that ejects the gastric contents with great force.

A deformity of the sella turcica whereby the sella extends further anterior than normal such that the anterior clinoid process appears to overhang it, giving the appearance of the letter J on imaging of the skull.
An abnormal enlargement of the sella turcica.
The presence of a high and narrow palate.
A depression located at an oral commissure.

A pathologic fracture occurs when a bone breaks in an area that is weakened secondarily to another disease process such as tumor, infection, and certain inherited bone disorders. A pathologic fracture can occur without a degree of trauma required to cause fracture in healthy bone.
The repeated occurrence of bone fractures (implying an abnormally increased tendency for fracture).
A severe form of respiratory insufficiency characterized by inadequate gas exchange such that the levels of oxygen or carbon dioxide cannot be maintained within normal limits.
A tumor that develops in the retrostyloid compartment of the parapharyngeal space, arising from an island of paraganglion tissue derived from the neural crest that is located on the vagus nerve.
A benign tumor of the parathyroid gland that can cause hyperparathyroidism.
Metaphyseal cupping refers to an inward bulging of the metaphyseal profile giving the metaphysis a cup-like appearance.
Abnormal increase in size of one or more metaphyses.
Underdevelopment of the patella.
Abnormal flatness (decreased height) of epiphyses.

JT: 低コレステロール血症
DEF: An decreased concentration of cholesterol in the blood.
A shift from the normally round (convex) appearance of the iliac wing towards a square-like appearance.
Intrapelvic bulging of the medial acetabular wall.

An abnormal appearance of muscle fibers observed on muscle biopsy. Ragged red fibers can be visualized with Gomori trichrome staining as irregular and intensely red subsarcolemmal zones, whereas the normal myofibrils are green. The margins of affect fibers appear red and ragged. The ragged-red is due to the accumulation of abnormal mitochondria below the plasma membrane of the muscle fiber, leading to the appearance of a red rim and speckled sarcoplasm.
An abnormally increased overall level of immunoglobulin E in blood.
An abnormally increased level of immunoglobulin G in blood.
An abnormally increased level of immunoglobulin A in blood.

A butterfly vertebra (sagittal cleft vertebra or anterior rachischisis) is a sagittal defect in the vertebral body caused by failure of fusion of the two lateral chondrification centers during embryogenesis. The name is based on the appearance of the two hemivertebrae emerging as butterfly wings from the central cleft on x-ray.
A pattern of simultaneous degeneration and regeneration of axons (see comment).

JT: 中枢神経髄鞘形成低下
DEF: Reduced amount of myelin in the central nervous system resulting from defective myelinogenesis.
The presence of axonal regeneration following a previous axonal lesion.

JT: 低カルシウム血症性テタニー
DEF: Hyperexcitability of the neuromuscular system related to abnormally low level of calcium in the blood, resulting in carpopedal or generalized spasms.
An abnormally increased level of immunoglobulin M in blood.
Atrophy (wasting) affecting primary type 2 muscle fibers. This feature in general can only be observed on muscle biopsy.

JT: 歩調ORペース|進行OR悪化OR増悪OR級数ORプログレッション

DEF: The lysosomal-vacuolar pathway has a role in the controlled intracellular digestion of macromolecules such as protein complexes and organelles. This feature refers to the presence of an abnormally increased number of autophagic vacuoles in muscle tissue.
An abnormal predominance of type I muscle fibers (in general, this feature can only be observed on muscle biopsy).
Absence of one or more forearm bones associated with congenital failure of development.
A bending or abnormal curvature affecting either the radius, the ulna, or both.
Abnormally wide bone of the skeleton of forearm.

Deviated fingers is a term that should be used if one or more fingers of the hand are deviated from their normal position, either to the radial or ulnar side. A deviation of a finger can be caused by an abnormal form of one or more of the phalanges of the affected finger, or by a deviation or displacement of one or more phalanges.
An abnormal indentation of the skin in the region of the nasal tip.
Congenital absence of a carpal bone.
A family of tumours arising in the embryonal remnants of the sympathetic nervous system, which includes neuroblastoma, ganglioneuroblastoma, and ganglioneuroma.
The formation of a blood clot inside an artery.

Fusion of cervical vertebrae at C2 and C3, caused by a failure in the normal segmentation or division of the cervical vertebrae during the early weeks of fetal development, leading to a short neck with a low hairline at the back of the head, and restricted mobility of the upper spine.
Fusion of the C5 and C6 cervical vertebrae.
Underdevelopment of the Third metatarsal bone leading to a short (hypoplastic) third metatarsal bone.
Short fourth metatarsal bone.
Short (hypoplastic) fifth metatarsal bone.
Acute hepatitis complicated by acute liver failure with hepatic encephalopathy occurring less than 8 weeks after the onset of jaundice.
An inability to digest lactose.

JT: 大小不同生奇形赤血球(Anisopoikilocytosis)
DEF: A type of poikilocytosis characterized by the presence in the blood of erythrocytes of varying sizes and abnormal shapes.
Abnormal twisting of arteries or veins.

An atrial arrhythmia characterized by disorganized atrial activity without discrete P waves on the surface EKG, but instead by an undulating baseline or more sharply circumscribed atrial deflections of varying amplitude an frequency ranging from 350 to 600 per minute.
Abnormal tortuous (i.e., twisted) form of arteries.
Hypertrophy of the stomach.
The presence of a fistula (abnormal tunnel) between the anal canal and the perineum.
A separation (dissection) of the layers of an artery.
Inflammation of the blood vessels within the brain.
Inspiratory stridor is a high pitched sound upon inspiration that is generally related to laryngeal abnormalities.

Reduced functionality of the process in which a precursor cell type acquires the specialized features of a B cell. A B cell is a lymphocyte of B lineage with the phenotype CD19-positive and capable of B cell mediated immunity.
Abnormally reduced ability of T cells to perform their functions in cell-mediated immunity.
Excessive growth (overgrowth) of the facial bones, that is of the facial skeleton.
Supernumerary digits located at the ulnar side of the hand with a complete extra finger and extra metacarpal.
Duplication of the metacarpal I bones.

ET: Abnormality of the epiphyses of the hand
DEF: Any abnormality of the epiphyses of the phalanges or metacarpal bones.
The presence of multiple lung cysts.
Enlargement of the thyroid gland related to multiple nodules in the thyroid gland.
Excess skin around the neck, often lying in horizontal folds.
Severely shortened metacarpal with a cuboidal appearance.
Metacarpal that becomes thinner toward the distal end.
Alteration of the normally smooth radiographic contour of phalanges producing an irregular appearance.
Decreased width of the metacarpal bones (that is, reduced diameter).

An crumpled radiographic appearance of the long bones, as if the long bone had been crushed together producing irregularities. This feature is the result of multiple fractures and repeated rounds of ineffective healing, as can be seen for instance in severe forms of osteogenesis imperfecta.
Agenesis of incisor.
An increased susceptibility to pneumonia as manifested by a history of recurrent episodes of pneumonia.
Hyperplasia of the biliary tree, as manifested by increased size of bile ducts, dilated lumen, and histologically by an increased number of epithelial cells or hyperplasia.
A type of focal clonic seizure characterized by sustained rhythmic jerking rapidly involves one side of the body at seizure onset.
Underdevelopment of the cerebrum.

Paralysis of the fourth cranial (trochlear) nerve manifested as weakness of the superior oblique muscle which causes vertical diplopia that is maximal when the affected eye is adducted and directed inferiorly.
Increased size of the basal ganglia.
Amyotrophy (muscular atrophy) affecting the proximal musculature.
A congenital absence of the convolutions of the cerebral cortex and a poorly formed sylvian fissure that affects a particular part of the cortex.
Fasciculations affecting the musculature of the arms and legs.
Focal seizure characterized at onset by clonic movements affecting half of the face.
The presence of atrophy (wasting) of the cerebrum, also known as the telencephalon, the largest and most highly developed part of the human brain.
The presence of leiomyoma of the skin.
A scotoma (area of diminished vision within the visual field) that surrounds the central fixation point.
Presenile cataract is a kind of cataract that occurs in early adulthood, that is, at an age that is younger than usual.
Bleeding within the vitreous compartment of the eye.
A developmental abnormality characterized by the absence of the fifth metatarsal bone.
Osteolysis affecting the talus.
A two-part calcaneus, a finding that probably results from delayed coalescence of two primary calcaneal centers of ossification.
Enlargement of the adrenal gland.
Hyperplasia of the thyroid gland.
A nail of the fifth finger that is diminished in length and width, i.e., underdeveloped nail of little finger.
Permanent indentation on the posteromedial aspect of the helix that may be sharply or indistinctly delineated.
Underdevelopment of the helix, i.e., of the outer rim of the pinna.
A developmental anomaly of the ureter.

Presence of persistent islands of renal blastema in the postnatal kidney. Nephroblastomatosis represents a complex abnormality of nephrogenesis and has been defined as the persistence of metanephricblastema into infancy and childhood.
A mild form of hypospadias in which the urethra opens just under the corona glandis.
An abnormally reduced diameter of the femoral neck (which is the process of bone, connecting the femoral head with the femoral shaft).
A loss of adipose tissue.
Cleft palate of the midline of the palate.
A cleft of the lip with overlying mucous membrane.
Muscular atrophy involving the muscles of the hand.

Chronic loss of joint motion in the 5th finger due to structural changes in non-bony tissue. The term camptodactyly of the 5th finger is used if the distal and/or proximal interphalangeal joints are affected.

Chronic loss of joint motion in the 4th finger due to structural changes in non-bony tissue. The term camptodactyly of the 4th finger is used if the distal and/or proximal interphalangeal joints are affected.
Displacement of the 4th finger towards the radial side (i.e., towards the thumb).

Chronic loss of joint motion in the 3rd finger due to structural changes in non-bony tissue. The term camptodactyly of the 3rd finger is used if the distal and/or proximal interphalangeal joints are affected.
Absence of one or more epiphyses of the 5th finger.
Sclerosis of the epiphyses of the 5th finger, leading to an increased degree of radiopacity (white or ivory appearance) in X-rays.
Absence of one or more epiphyses of the 4th finger.
Sclerosis of the epiphyses of the 4th finger, leading to an increased degree of radiopacity (white or ivory appearance) in X-rays.
Absence of the epiphyses of the 3rd finger.
Sclerosis of the epiphyses of the 3rd finger, leading to an increased degree of radiopacity (white or ivory appearance) in X-rays.
Displacement of the 3rd finger towards the radial side (i.e., towards the thumb).
Displacement of the 2nd finger towards the radial side.
Absence of the epiphyses of the 2nd finger.
Sclerosis of the epiphyses of the 2nd finger, leading to an increased degree of radiopacity (white or ivory appearance) in X-rays.

Chronic loss of joint motion in the 2nd finger due to structural changes in non-bony tissue. The term camptodactyly of the 2nd finger is used if the distal and/or proximal interphalangeal joints are affected.
Partail or complete duplication of the first metacarpal bone.
A benign tumor of cardiac striated muscle.
A bony defect in the skull base.
A pterygium (or pterygia) occurring in the popliteal region (the back of the knee).
Forearm shortening because of underdevelopment of one or more bones of the forearm.
Abnormally increased hair growth with a localized distribution.
A unilateral absence of sensory perception of sound.
Presence of nodules in the conjunctiva of the eye.
Abnormally prominent ear helix.
Complete absence of all nasal structures.
The presence of more than two nostrils.
Abnormally narrow nasal septum.

This term applies if one or more of the phalanges of the 2nd finger are either partially duplicated, depending on severity leading to a broad or bifid appearance of the phalanges, or completely duplicated.

This term applies if one or more of the phalanges of the 3rd finger are either partially duplicated, depending on severity leading to a broad or bifid appearance of the phalanges, or completely duplicated.

This term applies if one or more of the phalanges of the 4th finger are either partially duplicated, depending on severity leading to a broad or bifid appearance of the phalanges, or completely duplicated.

This term applies if one or more of the phalanges of the 5th finger are either partially duplicated, depending on severity leading to a broad or bifid appearance of the phalanges, or completely duplicated.
A developmental defect characterized by reduced length of the first metacarpal (long bone) of the hand.
Short second metacarpal bone because of developmental hypoplasia.
Short third metacarpal bone.
Short fourth metacarpal bone.
Short fifth metacarpal bone.
A developmental defect consisting in the duplication of the first metatarsal bone.
A developmental defect characterized by the absence of the first metatarsal bone.
Short first metatarsal bone.
Premature development of the breasts.

ET: Abnormality of phalanx of the 2nd toe
DEF: An anomaly of a phalanx of second toe.
One or more bent (flexed) joints of the second toe that cannot be straightened actively or passively.
One or more bent (flexed) joints of the third toe that cannot be straightened actively or passively.
One or more bent (flexed) joints of the fourth toe that cannot be straightened actively or passively.
One or more bent (flexed) joints of the fifth toe that cannot be straightened actively or passively.

ET: Duplication of the phalanges of the 2nd toe
DEF: Partial or complete duplication of a phalanx of second toe.

ET: Duplication of phalanx of the 3rd toe
DEF: Partial or complete duplication of phalanx of third toe.

ET: Duplication of phalanx of the 4th toe
DEF: Partial or complete duplication of phalanx of fourth toe.

ET: Duplication of the phalanges of the 5th toe
DEF: Partial or complete duplication of one or more phalanx of little toe.

ET: Aplasia of the phalanges of the 2nd toe

DEF: Reduced length of one or more phalanx of second toe as a result of developmental hypoplasia.
An abnormal narrowing of the lumen of the esophagus.
Duplication of the fibula. This may occur as a part of diplopodia (accessory tarsal or metatarsal bone). Diplopodia with double fibula is an extremely rare condition.
Sleep apnea resulting from a transient abolition of the central drive to the ventilatory muscles.
An abnormally small sella turcica.

Fine, rapid twitching of individual muscle fibers with little or no movement of the muscle as a whole. If a motor neuron or its axon is destroyed, the muscle fibers it innervates undergo denervation atrophy. This leads to hypersensitivity of individual muscle fibers to acetyl choline so that they may contract spontaneously. Isolated activity of individual muscle fibers is generally so fine it cannot be seen through the intact skin, although it can be recorded as a short-duration spike in the EMG.
A localized myotonic contraction in a muscle in reaction to percussion (tapping with the examiner's finger, a rubber percussion hammer, or a similar object).
A finger resting on the dorsal surface of an adjacent digit when the hand is at rest.
An alteration of the normally smooth contour of the epiphysis leading to an irregular appearance.
An abnormal predominance of type II muscle fibers (in general, this feature can only be observed on muscle biopsy).
An abnormally increased ability of the skin to permit light to pass through (translucency) such that subcutaneous structures such as veins display an increased degree of visibility.
An abnormal hair whorl (that is, a patch of hair growing in the opposite direction of the rest of the hair).

A lamellar pattern visible on radiographs and mainly localized at the metaphyses of the long tubular bones. Pathologic-anatomical studies revealed that these benign signs on x-rays are the result of a juvenile metaphyseal bone necrosis. Calcifications in the necrotic marrow lead to this lamellar or lattice-like appearance.
Marked widening of the trachea and major bronchi that may be predispose to chronic respiratory tract infection.
The presence of a neoplasm of the testis.
Morbus Osgood-Schlatter is a Juvenile aseptic necrosis affecting the Tuberositas tibiae.
A form of cataract in which the lens substance has shrunk, leaving a collapsed, flattened capsule with little or no cortex or epithelium on the lens.
A kind of nuclear cataract characterized by fiberglasslike or needlelike crystals projecting in different directions, through or close to the axial region of the lens.
An abnormality of the fourth ventricle.
An abnormality of the third ventricle.
A deviation from the normal count of B cells, i.e., the cells that are formed in the bone marrow, migrate to the peripheral lymphatic system, and mature into plasma cells or memory cells.
An abnormal decrease in the level of lipoprotein cholesterol in the blood.
A type of multifactorial inheritance governed by the simultaneous action of two gene loci.
The presence of hemorrhage within the body.
Increased size of the incisor tooth.
Unilateral paresis (weakness) with spasticity of the affected muscles and increased tendon reflexes.
A recurrent form of sinusitis.
Nasal ridge curving posteriorly to an imaginary line that connects the nasal root and tip.
Gastric duplication is a usually cystic malformation of gastrointestinal tract, usually attached to the greater curvature of the stomach and has no communication with the stomach.
A seizure characterized by sensory phenomena including tingling, numbness, electric-shock like sensation, pain, sense of movement, or desire to move as its first clinical manifestation.
Eyelashes that draw the attention of the viewer due to increased density and/or length and/or curl without meeting the criteria of trichomegaly.
Antihelical ridge that forms an acute angle between the antitragus and its bifurcation (stem) instead of a gently curving arc.
A soft tissue prominence of the ventral aspects of the fingertips or toe tips.
Congenital deep dermal melanosis in the sacral area.
Increased length of the umbilical cord.
Separation of the placenta from the uterus wall before delivery.

Fifth finger clinodactyly is defined by a hypoplastic or absent mid-phalanx of the fifth digit. Ultrasound identification of the fetal hand must first be undertaken and then appropriate magnification accomplished. The evaluation requires stretching of the 5 fingers. The diagnosis is established when the middle phalanx of the fifth finger is markedly smaller than normal or absent, which often causes the finger to be curved inward (PMID:16100637).
Regurgitation of milk through the nose.
A conical projection of the anterior surface of the lens, occurring as a developmental anomaly.
Inability to make fine depth discriminations from parallax provided by the two eyes' different positions on the head.

Anomalous mitral valve arcade is diagnosed based on the following features (1) An adequately sized mitral valve orifice; (2) short, thick, and poorly differentiated chordae with direct union of the papillary muscles to the anterior leaflet; (3) narrow or nearly nonexistent spaces between the abnormal chordae; and (4) greater differentiation of the chordae attached to the posterior papillary muscle.

An abnormality involving the generation of the action potential by the sinus node and is characterized by an atrial rate inappropriate for physiological requirements. Manifestations include severe sinus bradycardia, sinus pauses or arrest, sinus node exit block, chronic atrial tachyarrhythmias, alternating periods of atrial bradyarrhythmias and tachyarrhythmias, and inappropriate responses of heart rate during exercise or stress.
Block of conduction of electrical impulses along the Bundle of His or along one of its bundle branches.
Abnormal conduction in all three divisions of the intraventricular conducting tissue.

A pituitary tumor with subarachnoid, brain, or systemic metastasis. The diagnosis of a pituitary carcinoma requires evidence of metastatic disease, either outside the central nervous system (CNS) or as separate noncontiguous foci within the CNS.
An abnormal anatomical location of the parathyroid gland.
A benign (noncancerous) tumorlike malformation made up of an abnormal mixture of cells and tissues that originates in the tongue.
Atrophy (wasting) affecting primary type 1 muscle fibers. This feature in general can only be observed on muscle biopsy.

Basal encephalocele is an encephalocele that occurs along the cribriform plate or through the sphenoid bone. The mass may appear in the nasal cavity, nasopharynx, epipharynx, sphenoid sinus, posterior orbit, or pterygopalatine fossa. The important distinction from other types is that no external tumor is visible except in those rare instances of herniations so large that they protrude through the mouth or nares.
A noninflammatory, progressive occlusion of the intracranial carotid arteries owing to the formation of netlike collateral arteries arising from the circle of Willis.
A deviation from the normal count of T cells.
A potentially lethal cardiac arrhythmia characterized by an extremely rapid, hemodynamically unstable ventricular tachycardia (150-300 beats/min) with a large oscillating sine-wave appearance.
Short (hypoplastic) second metatarsal bone.

JT: 高フィブリノーゲン血症
DEF: Increased concentration of fibrinogen in the blood.
Anomaly in the level or the function of hemoglobin, the oxygen-carrying protein of erythrocytes.
Hemoglobin H (HbH) contains four beta-globin chains. It is normally not present at all in blood, but may make up about 1-40 percent of all hemoglobin in HbH disease, a subform of alpha thalassemia.
Underdeveloped nails of the fifth toes.
A small hole through the whole thickness of the retina.
Repeated episodes of sudden-onset and transient lethargy.
Failure of formation of the lumen of the gallbladder, often associated with gallbladder hypoplasia.
Auras with creation of composite perceptions without corresponding external stimuli involving visual, auditory, somatosensory, olfactory and/or gustatory phenomena.
Abnormal accumulation of fluid and swelling of the stroma of cornea.
An abnormally increased size of the cerebellum compared to other brain structures.
A carcinoma of the larynx.

JT: 低トリグリセリド血症
DEF: An decrease in the level of triglycerides in the blood.
A type of lymphoma characterized microscopically by multinucleated Reed-Sternberg cells.
Transient episodes of weakness of the arm, leg, and in some cases the face on one side of the body.

An abnormal pattern of respiration characterized by cycles of respiration that are increasingly deeper then shallower with possible periods of apnea. Affected patients may display a 10 to 20 second episode of hypoventilation or apnea, followed by respiration of increased depth and frequency over the course of about one minute. The cycle repeats every 45 seconds to 3 minutes.

An electrocardiographic anomaly of the ST segment, which is the segment that connects the QRS complex and the T wave. The ST segment normally has a duration of 80 to 120 ms, is flat and at the same level (isoelectric) as the PR and TP segment.
A form of amyloidosis that affects the liver.
A distinct type of headache characterized by piercing, throbbing, or electric-shock-like chronic pain in the upper neck, back of the head, and behind the ears, usually on one side.
Pattern of blood flow in the heart that deviates from the normal circuit of the circulatory system from the left side of the heart to the right.
Pattern of blood flow in the heart that deviates from the normal circuit of the circulatory system from both right side of the heart to the left and vice versa.
Protruding heel bone, or calcaneus.
Delayed myelination.
Reduced ability to flex the femur, that is, to pull the knee upward.

Increased dimensions of the Virchow-Robin spaces (also known as perivascular spaces), which surround the walls of vessels as they course from the subarachnoid space through the brain parenchyma. Perivascular spaces are commonly microscopic, and not visible on conventional neuroimaging. This term refers to an increase of size of these spaces such that they are visible on neuroimaging (usually magnetic resonance imaging). The dilatations are regular cavities that always contain a patent artery.
Congenital absence of the optic nerve.
A lipoma (a benign tumor composed of adipose tissue) located in the conjunctiva.
Increased concentration of beta-alanine in the blood.
A ratio of serum triiodothyronine (T3) to thyroxine (T4) in the blood that deviates from normal.
An isolated cyst of the kidney.
A developmental anomaly associated with the failure of rectum, vagina, and bladder to separate.
Lack of development of the cerebellum.
Syncope following a quick change in position from lying down to standing.
Decreased size of the basal ganglia.

A vascular malformation resulting from a developmental error of venous tissue composed of dysmorphic channels lined by flattened endothelium and exhibiting slow turnover. A venous malformation may present as a blue patch on the skin ranging to a soft blue mass. Venous malformations are easily compressible and usually swell in thewhen venous pressure increases (e.g., when held in a dependent position or when a child cries). They may be relatively localized or quite extensive within an anatomic region.
A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the ear.
An anomaly of the nasal base, which can be conceived of as an imaginary line between the most lateral points of the external inferior attachments of the alae nasi to the face.
Hypospadias with location of the urethral meatus in the scrotum.
Formation of excess connective tissue in the testicle.
Aplasia (congenital absence) of the vas deferens.
A fluid filled sac located in the Fallopian tube.
Slowed relaxation of muscles in the jaw.
A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the eye.

An epiretinal membrane is a thin sheet of fibrous tissue that can develop on the surface of the macular area of the retina and cause a disturbance in vision. An epiretinal membrane area can develop on the thin macular area of the retin. An epiretinal membrane is also sometimes called a macular pucker, premacular fibrosis, surface wrinkling retinopathy or cellophane maculopathy.
Involuntary sounds produced by moving air through the nose, mouth, or throat. The vocal cords are not involved in all tics that produce sound.
Epiphyses of the 2nd toe are hard and dense like ivory. Such an epiphysis has a uniformly dense appearance on radiographs.
Epiphyses of the 3rd toe are hard and dense like ivory. Such an epiphysis has a uniformly dense appearance on radiographs.
Epiphyses of the 4th toe are hard and dense like ivory. Such an epiphysis has a uniformly dense appearance on radiographs.
Epiphyses of the 5th toe are hard and dense like ivory. Such an epiphysis has a uniformly dense appearance on radiographs.

A contraction of the diaphragm that repeats several times per minute. In humans, the abrupt rush of air into the lungs causes the epiglottis to close, creating a hic sound. Also known as synchronous diaphragmatic flutter (SDF), or singultus, from the Latin singult, the act of catching one's breath while sobbing. The hiccup is an involuntary action involving a reflex arc.
Hemorrhage occurring between the dura mater and the arachnoid mater.
Hemorrhage occurring between the dura mater and the skull.
A non-midline cleft of the upper lip on the left and right sides.

ET: Aplasia of the phalanges of the 3rd toe
Aplasia of the phalanges of the 4th toe
Aplasia of the phalanges of the 5th toe

DEF: Developmental hypoplasia of the phalanx of third toe.
Developmental hypoplasia of one or more phalanx of fourth toe.
Developmental hypoplasia of one or more phalanx of little toe.
A rupture of the cornea through which a portion of the iris protrudes.
A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the lip.
The presence of a teratoma of the testis.
The presence of a seminoma, an undifferentiated germ cell tumor of the testis.
A type of Macrodactyly affecting one or several toes.
A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the esophagus.
Terminal broadening of the fingers (distal phalanges of the fingers).
Grey-green or brownish-pigmented ring in the deep epithelial layers at the outer border of the cornea.
Inflammation of the cartilage of the external ear.

JT: 代謝性アルカローシス
DEF: Metabolic alkalosis is defined as a disease state where the pH is elevated to greater than 7.45 secondary to some metabolic process.
Dysfunction of the urinary bladder.

A type of bladder dysfunction caused by neurologic damage. Neurogenic bladder can be flaccid or spastic. Common manifestatios of neurogenic bladder are overflow incontinence, frequency, urgency, urge incontinence, and retention.

A type of bladder dysfunction caused by neurologic damage. Neurogenic bladder can be flaccid or spastic. Common manifestatios of neurogenic bladder are overflow incontinence, frequency, urgency, urge incontinence, and retention.
Protrusion of the contents of the abdominal cavity through the inguinal canal.
Wasting (atrophy) of the testicle (the male gonad) manifested by a decrease in size and potentially by a loss of fertility.
Hypospadias with location of the urethral meatus in the perineal region.
Undergrowth of the outer labia.
Fusion of the labia minora as a result of labial adhesions resulting in vaginal obstruction.
Abnormal (retrograde) movement of urine from the bladder into ureters or kidneys related to inadequacy of the valvular mechanism at the ureterovesicular junction or other causes.
An abnormal functionality of the genital system.
An abnormality of the renal tubules.
Accumulation of scar tissue within the glomerulus.
Accumulation of scar tissue within the glomerulus.
Inflammation of the renal glomeruli.

Nephrotic syndrome is a collection of findings resulting from glomerular dysfunction with an increase in glomerular capillary wall permeability associated with pronounced proteinuria. Nephrotic syndrome refers to the constellation of clinical findings that result from severe renal loss of protein, with Proteinuria and hypoalbuminemia, edema, and hyperlipidemia.
High urine phosphate in the presence of hypophosphatemia.
A high concentration of one or more electrolytes in the urine in the presence of low serum concentrations of the electrolyte(s).
A high concentration of one or more electrolytes in the urine in the presence of low serum concentrations of the electrolyte(s).
The presence of a leiomyoma of the uterus.
An abnormality of the ovulation cycle.
The presence of a gonadoblastoma, a neoplasm of a gonad that consists of aggregates of germ cells and sex cord elements.
A severe form of periodontitis.
The presence of fibrosis of the gingiva.
Abnormality of the uvula, the conic projection from the posterior edge of the middle of the soft palate.
An abnormality of the upper lip.
An abnormality of the lower lip.
An abnormality of the lingual frenulum, that is of the small fold of mucous membrane that attaches the tongue to the floor of the mouth, or the presence of accessory frenula in the oral cavity.
An abnormality of the appearance of the face caused by constant contraction of the lips leading to a puckered or pursed appearance.
Telangiectasia (that is, the presence of small dilated superficial blood vessels) of the lips.
Hyperkeratosis of the gingiva.

Height of the vermilion of the medial part of the lip more than 2 SD below the mean, or apparently reduced height of the vermilion of the lip in the frontal view. The vermilion is the red part of the lips (and confusingly, the vermilion itself is also often referred to as being equivalent the lips).
An abnormality of the anterior fontanelle, i.e., the cranial fontanelle that is located at the intersection of the coronal and sagittal sutures.
Abnormally decreased size of the anterior fontanelle with respect to age-dependent norms.
Abnormal vertical height of the skull and a shortening of its anterior-posterior length, frequently combined with malformations of the occipital region.

Abnormality of the paranasal (cranial) sinuses, which are air-filled spaces that are located within the bones of the skull and face and communicate with the nasal cavity. They comprise the maxillary sinuses, the frontal sinuses, the ethmoid sinuses, and the sphenoid sinuses.
An acute form of sinusitis.
Enlargement of the anterior fontanelle with respect to age-dependent norms.

ET: obsolete Abnormality of the ocular region

DEF: Coarse facial features reminiscent of those of a boxer.

A type of abnormal location of the ears in which the position of the ears is characterized by posterior rotation (the superior part of the ears is rotated towards the back of the head, and the inferior part of the ears towards the front).
A decreased magnitude of the sensory perception of sound.
Acute otitis media is a short and generally painful infection of the middle ear.

Stapes ankylosis refers to congenital or acquired fixation of the stapes (the stirrup-shaped small bone or ossicle in the middle ear), which is associated with conductive hearing resulting from impairment of the sound-conduction mechanism (the external auditory canal, tympanic membrane, and/or middle-ear ossicles).
The presence of an abnormally prominent antihelix.
Increased susceptibility to otitis media, as manifested by recurrent episodes of otitis media.
Abnormality of the choanae (the posterior nasal apertures).
Decreased width of the nasal ridge.
An abnormality of the nasal septum.
Reduced superior to inferior length of the nasal septum.
Nasal ridge curving anteriorly to an imaginary line that connects the nasal root and tip. The nose appears often also prominent, and the columella low.
A splitting of the nasal tip. Visually assessable vertical indentation, cleft, or depression of the nasal tip.

Anteriorly-facing nostrils viewed with the head in the Frankfurt horizontal and the eyes of the observer level with the eyes of the subject. This gives the appearance of an upturned nose (upturned nasal tip).
An abnormality of the fovea centralis, the central area of the macula that mediates central, high resolution vision and contains the largest concentration of cone cells in the retina.
An abnormality in voluntary or involuntary eye movements or their control.
The presence of an increased number of twists and turns of the conjunctival blood vessels.

An inherited retinal disease subtype in which the rod photoreceptors appear to be more severely affected than the cone photoreceptors. Typical presentation is with nyctalopia (due to rod dysfunction) followed by loss of mid-peripheral field of vision, which gradually extends and leaves many patients with a small central island of vision due to the preservation of macular cones.

An inherited retinal disease subtype in which the rod photoreceptors appear to be more severely affected than the cone photoreceptors. Typical presentation is with nyctalopia (due to rod dysfunction) followed by loss of mid-peripheral field of vision, which gradually extends and leaves many patients with a small central island of vision due to the preservation of macular cones.
Any abnormality of the electrical responses of various cell types in the retina as measured by electroretinography.
An abnormality of the lens.
A cataract that occurs congenitally as the result of a developmental defect, in contrast to the majority of cataracts that occur in adulthood as the result of degenerative changes of the lens.
A fold of skin starting at or just below the medial aspect of the lower lid and arching upward to cover, extend in front of and lateral to the medial canthus.
An abnormality in the process of focusing of light by the eye in order to produce a sharp image on the retina.
Separation of the inner layers of the retina (neural retina) from the pigment epithelium.
Reduced ability to move the eye in the direction of the nose.
A pale yellow discoloration of the optic disk (the area of the optic nerve head in the retina). The optic disc normally has a pinkish hue with a central yellowish depression.
Hemorrhage occurring within the retina.

An abnormality of the retina characterized by pigment deposition. It is typically associated with migration and proliferation of macrophages or retinal pigment epithelial cells into the retina; melanin from these cells causes the pigmentary changes. Pigmentary retinopathy is a common final pathway of many retinal conditions and is often associated with visual loss.
Abnormality of the optic nerve.
Ophthalmoplegia is a paralysis or weakness of one or more of the muscles that control eye movement.
Underdevelopment of the optic nerve.
Any structural abnormality of the choroid.
An abnormality of the nasolacrimal drainage system, which serves as a conduit for tear flow from the external eye to the nasal cavity.
The presence of an increased number of twists and turns of the retinal artery.
An impaired ability of the eye to move in the outward direction (towards the side of the head).

JT: 測定障害性断続性眼球運動
DEF: The controller signal for saccadic eye movements has two components: the pulse that moves the eye rapidly from one point to the next, and the step that holds the eye in the new position. When both the pulse and the step are not the correct size, a dysmetric refixation eye movement results.
A focal dystonia that affects the muscles of the eyelids and brow, associated with involuntary recurrent spasm of both eyelids.

Ocular motor apraxia is a deficiency in voluntary, horizontal, lateral, fast eye movements (saccades) with retention of slow pursuit movements. The inability to follow objects visually is often compensated by head movements. There may be decreased smooth pursuit, and cancellation of the vestibulo-ocular reflex.

A creamy appearance of the retinal blood vessels that occurs when the concentration of lipids in the blood are extremely increased, with pale pink to milky white retinal vessels and altered pale reflexes from choroidal vasculature.
Delayed tooth eruption affecting the primary dentition.
Increased space between two adjacent teeth in the same dental arch.
An abnormality of the nervous system.
Unstable emotional experiences and frequent mood changes; emotions that are easily aroused, intense, and/or out of proportion to events and circumstances.
Reduced attention span characterized by distractibility and impulsivity but not necessarily satisfying the diagnostic criteria for attention deficit hyperactivity disorder.
Peripheral neuropathy affecting the sensory nerves.
Any abnormality of the diaphragm, the sheet of skeletal muscle that separates the thoracic cavity from the abdominal cavity.
Any abnormality of the scapula, also known as the shoulder blade.
Inability to develop or maintain an erection of the penis.
Difficulty in looking at another person in the eye.
An abnormality of the endocrine system.

The onset of secondary sexual characteristics before a normal age. Although it is difficult to define normal age ranges because of the marked variation with which puberty begins in normal children, precocious puberty can be defined as the onset of puberty before the age of 8 years in girls or 9 years in boys.
An abnormality of the parathyroid gland.
A condition caused by a deficiency of parathyroid hormone characterized by hypocalcemia and hyperphosphatemia.
Developmental hypoplasia of the adrenal glands.

A type of reduced stature with normal proportions related to dysfunction of the pituitary gland related to either an isolated defect in the secretion of growth hormone or to panhypopituitarism, i.e., a deficit of all the anterior pituitary hormones.

A type of reduced stature with normal proportions related to dysfunction of the pituitary gland related to either an isolated defect in the secretion of growth hormone or to panhypopituitarism, i.e., a deficit of all the anterior pituitary hormones.
Increased resistance towards insulin, that is, diminished effectiveness of insulin in reducing blood glucose levels.
Overproduction of the mineralocorticoid aldosterone by the adrenal cortex.
A form of diabetes insipidus related to a failure of vasopressin (AVP) release from the hypothalamus.

A pituitary functional deficit affecting all the anterior pituitary hormones (growth hormone, thyroid-stimulating hormone, follicle-stimulating hormone, luteinizing hormone, adrenocorticotropic hormone, and prolactin).
A chronic, autoimmune type of thyroiditis associated with hypothyroidism.

A state of excessive water intake and hypotonic (dilute) polyuria. Diabetes insipidus may be due to failure of vasopressin (AVP) release (central or neurogenic diabetes insipidus) or to a failure of the kidney to respond to AVP (nephrogenic diabetes insipidus).
Underdeveloped scapula.
A bifid rib refers to cleavage of the sternal end of a rib, usually unilateral. Bifid ribs are usually asymptomatic, and are often discovered incidentally by chest x-ray.
A row of beadlike prominences at the junction of a rib and its cartilage (i.e., enlarged costochondral joints), resembling a rosary.
Abnormally flat configuration of the glenoid fossa, also known as the glenoid cavity, which is the articular surface of the scapula that articulates with the head of the humerus.
Complete or partial merging of the posterior part of adjacent ribs.
The presence of multiple exostoses on the scapula. An exostosis is a benign growth the projects outward from the bone surface. It is capped by cartilage.
The presence of multiple exostoses on the scapula. An exostosis is a benign growth the projects outward from the bone surface. It is capped by cartilage.

The bones of the skeleton undergo a series of characteristic changes in size, shape, and calcification from fetal life until puberty. An abnormality of this process can include delayed or accelerated skeletal maturation, or deviation of some, but not all bones from the expected patterns of maturation.
An abnormality of the skull, the bony framework of the head which is comprised of eight cranial and fourteen facial bones.

Radiographic evidence of articular calcification that represent calcium pyrophosphate depositions in soft tissue surrounding joints and at the insertions of tendons near joints (Entheses/Sharpey fibers) .
An abnormality of the structure or form of the diaphysis, i.e., of the main or mid-section (shaft) of a long bone.
An abnormality of one or more metaphysis, i.e., of the somewhat wider portion of a long bone that is adjacent to the epiphyseal growth plate and grows during childhood.
Hyperkeratosis affecting the palm of the hand and the sole of the foot.
Subjective impression of increased softness upon palpitation of the skin.
The presence in the axillary region (armpit) of an increased number of freckles, small circular spots on the skin that are darker than the surrounding skin because of deposits of melanin.
Localized fluid retention and tissue swelling caused by a compromised lymphatic system.

Telangiectasias refer to small dilated blood vessels located near the surface of the skin or mucous membranes, measuring between 0.5 and 1 millimeter in diameter. Telangiectasia are located especially on the tongue, lips, palate, fingers, face, conjunctiva, trunk, nail beds, and fingertips.
The presence of multiple lipomas (a type of benign tissue made of fatty tissue).

Eruptive xanthomas are yellow-orange-to-red-brown papules that are often surrounded by an erythematous halo. They appear in crops on the buttocks, extensor surfaces of the extremities, and flexural creases. Acutely, variable amounts of pruritus and pain occur.

Eruptive xanthomas are yellow-orange-to-red-brown papules that are often surrounded by an erythematous halo. They appear in crops on the buttocks, extensor surfaces of the extremities, and flexural creases. Acutely, variable amounts of pruritus and pain occur.
The presence of a cavernous hemangioma. A hemangioma characterized by large endothelial spaces (caverns) is called a cavernous hemangioma.
Seborrheic dermatitis is a form of eczema which is closely related to dandruff. It causes dry or greasy peeling of the scalp, eyebrows, and face, and sometimes trunk.
A reduced ability to heal cutaneous wounds.
Patchy and irregular skin pigmentation.

Dislocation or malposition of the crystalline lens of the eye. A partial displacement (or dislocation) of the lens is described as a subluxation of the lens, while a complete displacement is termed luxation of the lens. A complete displacement occurs if the lens is completely outside the patellar fossa of the lens, either in the anterior chamber, in the vitreous, or directly on the retina. If the lens is partially displaced but still contained within the lens space, then it is termed subluxation.
