Glaucoma which forms during the early years of a child's life is called developmental or congenital glaucoma.
The presence of developmental dysplasia of the optic nerve.
A type of anterior uveitis, in which there is Inflammation of the iris and the ciliary body.
Underdevelopment of the macula lutea.
A polar cataract that affects the posterior pole of the lens.
A type of cataract that is not apparent at birth but that arises in childhood or adolescence.
Partial dislocation of the lens of the eye.
Esotropia in which either eye may be used for fixation.
Severe reduction of the ability to see defined as visual acuity less than 6/60 (20/200 in US notation; 0.1 in decimal notation) but at least 3/60 (20/400 in US notation; 0.05 in decimal notation).
Supernumerary digits located at the ulnar side of the hand (that is, on the side with the fifth finger).
An abnormality of the metacarpal bones.

Supernumerary digits located at the radial side of the hand. Polydactyly (supernumerary digits) involving the thumb occurs in many distinct forms of high variability and severity. Ranging from fleshy nubbins over varying degrees of partial duplication/splitting to completely duplicated or even triplicated thumbs or preaxial (on the radial side of the hand) supernumerary digits.
The ability of the finger joints to move beyond their normal range of motion.
An abnormality affecting the carpal bones of the wrist (scaphoid, lunate, triquetral, pisiform, trapezium, trapezoid, capitate, hamate).
Single umbilical artery (SUA) is the absence of one of the two umbilical arteries surrounding the fetal bladder and in the fetal umbilical cord.
The distal interphalangeal joint and/or the proximal interphalangeal joint of the second to fifth fingers cannot be extended to 180 degrees by either active or passive extension.
An abnormality of the thenar eminence, i.e., of the muscle on the palm of the human hand just beneath the thumb.
Abnormally broad metacarpal bones.
Underdevelopment of the thenar eminence with reduced palmar soft tissue mass surrounding the base of the thumb.

Muscular hypotonia is an abnormally low muscle tone (the amount of tension or resistance to movement in a muscle), often involving reduced muscle strength. Hypotonia is characterized by a diminished resistance to passive stretching. Muscular hypotonia may be related to defects in skeletal muscle, neuromuscular junction, or peripheral nerve.
Spasticity and weakness of the leg and hip muscles.
Loss of strength in the arm, leg, and sometimes face on one side of the body. Hemiplegia refers to a complete loss of strength, whereas hemiparesis refers to an incomplete loss of strength.
A type of Developmental delay characterized by a delay in acquiring motor skills.
Atrophy (wasting) of the cerebellum.
A form of hypotension characterized by a sudden fall in blood pressure that occurs when a person assumes a standing position.
Structural abnormality affecting one or more of the cranial nerves, which emerge directly from the brain stem.

A congenital brain malformation typically characterized by incomplete formation of the cerebellar vermis, dilation of the fourth ventricle, and enlargement of the posterior fossa. In layman's terms, Dandy Walker malformation is a cyst in the cerebellum (typically symmetrical) that is involved with the fourth ventricle. This may interfere with the ability to drain cerebrospinal fluid from the brain, resulting in hydrocephalus. Dandy Walker cysts are formed during early embryonic development, while the brain forms. The cyst in the cerebellum typically has several blood vessels running through it connecting to the brain, thereby prohibiting surgical removal.
Muscular hypotonia (abnormally low muscle tone) manifesting in the neonatal period.
Absence of the septum pellucidum.
A form of hydrocephalus in which there is no visible obstruction to the flow of the cerebrospinal fluid between the ventricles and subarachnoid space.
Involuntary movements of one hand that accompany and mirror intentional movements of the opposite hand.
An abnormal structure or form of the joints, i.e., one or more of the articulations where two bones join.

Inflammatory changes in the synovial membranes and articular structures with widespread fibrinoid degeneration of the collagen fibers in mesenchymal tissues, as well as atrophy and rarefaction of bony structures.
A reduction in the freedom of movement of one or more joints.
The presence of developmental dysplasia of the hip.
A form of hepatic steatosis characterized by the presence of small, lipid-laden vesicles in the affected hepatocytes.
A mode of inheritance that depends on a mixture of major and minor genetic determinants possibly together with environmental factors. Diseases inherited in this manner are termed complex diseases.
A mode of inheritance in which a trait or disorder results from a de novo mutation occurring after conception, rather than being inherited from a preceding generation.
Simultaneous enlargement of the liver and spleen.

ET: Abnormality of the shoulder girdle musculature

DEF: An anomaly of the musculature of foot.

ET: Abnormality of the musculature of the lower limbs
Abnormality of the musculature of the thigh
Abnormality of the musculature of the upper limbs
Abnormality of the musculature of the upper arm

DEF: Syndactyly with fusion of toes one to three.

ET: Abnormality of the musculature of the pelvis

DEF: Osteolysis involving metatarsal bones.
Increased density of the bony tissue of the scapula.
Increased density of the bony tissue of the scapula.
Repetitive pressing, poking, and/or rubbing in the eyes.
An area of the retina that is buckled so that a sector-shaped sheet of retina lies in front of the normal retina. This feature is of congenital onset.
Underdevelopment of one or more carpal bones.
A midline anterior incomplete closure of the abdominal wall in which there is herniation of the abdominal viscera into the base of the abdominal cord.
The presence of multiple impacted teeth.

The rib cage has the shape of a wide mouthed bell. That is, the superior portion of the rib cage is constricted, followed by a convex region, and the inferior portion of the rib cage expands again to have a large diameter.
Stricture or narrowing of the larynx that may be associated with symptoms of respiratory difficulty depending on the degree of laryngeal narrowing.
Decreased strength of the vocal folds.
Decreased strength of the vocal folds.
An abnormal increase in the pitch (frequency) of the voice.
Any structural anomaly of the heart.
A hole between the two bottom chambers (ventricles) of the heart. The defect is centered around the most superior aspect of the ventricular septum.
Atrial septal defect (ASD) is a congenital abnormality of the interatrial septum that enables blood flow between the left and right atria via the interatrial septum.
Any structural anomaly of the mitral valve.

Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) is defined by the presence of increased ventricular wall thickness or mass in the absence of loading conditions (hypertension, valve disease) sufficient to cause the observed abnormality.

In utero, the ductus arteriosus (DA) serves to divert ventricular output away from the lungs and toward the placenta by connecting the main pulmonary artery to the descending aorta. A patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) in the first 3 days of life is a physiologic shunt in healthy term and preterm newborn infants, and normally is substantially closed within about 24 hours after bith and completely closed after about three weeks. Failure of physiologcal closure is referred to a persistent or patent ductus arteriosus (PDA). Depending on the degree of left-to-right shunting, PDA can have clinical consequences.

Dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM) is defined by the presence of left ventricular dilatation and left ventricular systolic dysfunction in the absence of abnormal loading conditions (hypertension, valve disease) or coronary artery disease sufficient to cause global systolic impairment. Right ventricular dilation and dysfunction may be present but are not necessary for the diagnosis.
The presence of a stenosis (narrowing) of the aortic valve.
A single arterial trunk arises from the cardiac mass. The pulmonary arteries, aorta and coronary arteries arise from this single trunk with no evidence of another outflow tract.

JT: トルサードドポアンツ(Torsadedepointes)
DEF: A type of ventricular tachycardia characterized by polymorphioc QRS complexes that change in amplitue and cycle length, and thus have the appearance of oscillating around the baseline in the EKG.
Delayed or lack of conduction of atrial depolarizations through the atrioventricular node to the ventricles.
An abnormality of the aorta.
A fixed form of obstruction to blood flow across the left-ventricular outflow tract related to stenosis (narrowing) below the level of the aortic valve.
An abnormality of the pericardium, i.e., of the fluid filled sac that surrounds the heart and the proximal ends of the aorta, vena cava, and the pulmonary artery.
Accumulation of fluid within the pericardium.
Any structural anomaly of the tricuspid valve.

A congenital malformation of the outflow tract of the heart. Conotruncal defects are thought to result from a disturbance of the outflow tract of the embryonic heart, and comprise truncus arteriosus, tetralogy of Fallot, interrupted aortic arch, transposition of the great arteries, and double outlet right ventricle.

Restrictive left ventricular physiology is characterized by a pattern of ventricular filling in which increased stiffness of the myocardium causes ventricular pressure to rise precipitously with only small increases in volume, defined as restrictive ventricular physiology in the presence of normal or reduced diastolic volumes (of one or both ventricles), normal or reduced systolic volumes, and normal ventricular wall thickness.
A acute form of pancreatitis.
A structural anomaly of the nasopharynx.
An abnormality of the functioning of the vestibular apparatus.
Reduced functioning of the vestibular apparatus.
A form of sensorineural hearing impairment that affects primarily the higher frequencies.
An anomaly of a toe.
Toenail changes apart from changes of the color of the toenail (nail dyschromia) that involve partial or complete disruption of the various keratinous layers of the nail plate.

Polydactyly of the foot most commonly refers to the presence of six toes on one foot. Postaxial polydactyly affects the lateral ray and the duplication may range from a well-formed articulated digit to a rudimentary digit.
Abnormalities of the metatarsal bones (i.e. of five tubular bones located between the tarsal bones of the hind- and mid-foot and the phalanges of the toes).
The presence of both a prominent heel and a convex contour of the sole.
Duplication of all or part of the first ray.

This is a postural deformity in which the foot is positioned up against the tibia. The heel (calcaneus) is positioned downward (that is, the ankle is flexed upward), and the heel is turned outward (valgus).
An abnormality of the tarsus are the cluster of seven bones in the foot between the tibia and fibula and the metatarsus, including the calcaneus (heel) bone and the talus (ankle) bone.
Short distance from the end of the toe to the most distal interphalangeal crease or distal interphalangeal joint flexion point, i.e., abnormally short distal phalanx of toe.
An abnormality of platelets.
A neutrophil abnormality.
An abnormally low number of neutrophils in the peripheral blood.
An abnormal reduction in numbers of all blood cell types (red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets).
Any structural abnormality of erythrocytes (red-blood cells).
An abnormal count or structure of eosinophils.
Increased count of eosinophils in the blood.
An abnormality of leukocytes.
An abnormal decreased number of leukocytes in the blood.

JT: 感覚ニューロパチーによる遠位の骨髄炎又は壊死(足)
DEF: An infection of bone of the foot.
Increased numbers of platelets in the peripheral blood.
Anemia with varying degrees of erythrocytic hypoplasia without leukopenia or thrombocytopenia.
Any structural abnormality or abnormal count of granulocytes.
An abnormally reduced number of granulocytes in the blood.

Sideroblastic anemia results from a defect in the incorporation of iron into the heme molecule. A sideroblast is an erythroblast that has stainable deposits of iron in cytoplasm (this can be demonstrated by Prussian blue staining).
A type of anemia characterized by an abnormally low concentration of hemoglobin in the erythrocytes.
A type of anemia characterized by an abnormally low concentration of hemoglobin in the erythrocytes.
Abnormal acid accumulation or depletion of base.

Metabolic acidosis (MA) is characterized by a fall in blood pH due to a reduction of serum bicarbonate concentration. This can occur as a result of either the accumulation of acids (high anion gap MA) or the loss of bicarbonate from the gastrointestinal tract or the kidney (hyperchloremic MA). By definition, MA is not due to a respirary cause.
Episodes of fever for which no infectious cause can be identified.
An abnormal increase in the number of leukocytes in the blood.
Venous or arterial thrombosis (formation of blood clots) of spontaneous nature and which cannot be fully explained by acquired risk (e.g. atherosclerosis).

An abnormality of histiocytes, in which the cells take on a sea blue appearance due to abnormally increased lipid content. Histiocytes are a type of macrophage. Sea-blue histiocytes are typically large macrophages from 20 to 60 micrometers in diameter with a single eccentric nucleus whose cytoplasm if packed with sea-blue or blue-green granules when stained with Wright-Giemsa.
Recurrent episodes of decreased concentration of glucose in the blood.
An abnormal morphology (form) of the face or its components.
A developmental defect resulting in complete obliteration of the lumen of the esophagus such that the esophagus ends in a blind pouch rather than connecting to the stomach.
The presence of a hernia in which the upper part of the stomach, i.e., mainly the gastric cardia protrudes through the diaphragmatic esophageal hiatus.
Malignant hyperthermia is characterized by a rapid increase in temperature to 39-42 degrees C in response to inhalational anesthetics such as halothane or to muscle relaxants such as succinylcholine.
Forward protrusion of the glabella.

A type of ataxia characterized by the impairment of the ability to perform rapidly alternating movements, such as pronating and supinating his or her hand on the dorsum of the other hand as rapidly as possible.

A type of migraine in which there is an aura characterized by focal neurological phenomena that usually proceed, but may accompany or occur in the absence of, the headache. The symptoms of an aura may include fully reversible visual, sensory, and speech symptoms but not motor weakness. Visual symptoms may include flickering lights, spots and lines and/or loss of vision and/or unilateral sensory symptoms such as paresthesias or numbness. At least one of the symptoms of an aura develops gradually over 5 or more minutes and/or different symptoms occur in succession.
An abnormality of the respiratory system, which include the airways, lungs, and the respiratory muscles.

ET: Abnormality of the upper respiratory tract
DEF: An abnormality of the upper respiratory tract.

A functional defect characterized by reduced total lung capacity (TLC) not associated with abnormalities of expiratory airflow or airway resistance. Spirometrically, a restrictive defect is defined as FEV1 (forced expiratory volume in 1 second) and FVC (forced vital capacity) less than 80 per cent. Restrictive lung disease may be caused by alterations in lung parenchyma or because of a disease of the pleura, chest wall, or neuromuscular apparatus.
A developmental defect in the formation of pulmonary lobes.
Atrophy of the cortex of the cerebrum.

Status epilepticus is a type of prolonged seizure resulting either from the failure of the mechanisms responsible for seizure termination or from the initiation of mechanisms which lead to abnormally prolonged seizures (after time point t1). It is a condition that can have long-term consequences (after time point t2), including neuronal death, neuronal injury, and alteration of neuronal networks, depending on the type and duration of seizures.

Status epilepticus is a type of prolonged seizure resulting either from the failure of the mechanisms responsible for seizure termination or from the initiation of mechanisms which lead to abnormally prolonged seizures (after time point t1). It is a condition that can have long-term consequences (after time point t2), including neuronal death, neuronal injury, and alteration of neuronal networks, depending on the type and duration of seizures.
Abnormality of the basal ganglia.
The presence of calcium deposition affecting one or more structures of the basal ganglia.
Hemorrhage occurring between the arachnoid mater and the pia mater.

Abnormally increased level of blood lactate (2-hydroxypropanoic acid). Lactate is produced from pyruvate by lactate dehydrogenase during normal metabolism. The terms lactate and lactic acid are often used interchangeably but lactate (the component measured in blood) is strictly a weak base whereas lactic acid is the corresponding acid. Lactic acidosis is often used clinically to describe elevated lactate but should be reserved for cases where there is a corresponding acidosis (pH below 7.35).
An increased concentration of lysine in the blood.
Inward advance of skin over the nail plate.
A cyst occurring within the choroid plexus within a cerebral ventricle.

Pseudobulbar signs result from injury to an upper motor neuron lesion to the corticobulbar pathways in the pyramidal tract. Patients have difficulty chewing, swallowing and demonstrate slurred speech (often initial presentation) as well as abnormal behavioral symptoms such as inappropriate emotional outbursts of uncontrolled laughter or weeping etc.

An embolus (that is, an abnormal particle circulating in the blood) located in the pulmonary artery and thereby blocking blood circulation to the lung. Usually the embolus is a blood clot that has developed in an extremity (for instance, a deep venous thrombosis), detached, and traveled through the circulation before becoming trapped in the pulmonary artery.
Replacement of normal lung tissues by fibroblasts and collagen.
A developmental defect resulting in complete obliteration of the duodenal lumen, that is, an abnormal closure of the duodenum.
Weakness of all four limbs.
Heterotopia or neuronal heterotopia are macroscopic clusters of misplaced neurons (gray matter), most often situated along the ventricular walls or within the subcortical white matter.
Unlocalized atrophy of the brain with decreased total brain matter volume and increased ventricular size.
Progressively reduced or lacking hair growth.
Loss of previously present motor (i.e., movement) abilities.
Any structural abnormality of the caudate nucleus.
A form of hydrocephalus characterized by enlarged cerebral ventricles and normal cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) pressure upon lumbar puncture.
Reduced ability to walk (ambulate).
A type of gait (walking) characterized by by dragging one's feet along or without lifting the feet fully from the ground.

A febrile seizure is any type of seizure (most often a generalized tonic-clonic seizure) occurring with fever (at least 38 degrees Celsius) but in the absence of central nervous system infection, severe metabolic disturbance or other alternative precipitant in children between the ages of 3 months and 6 years.

Fasciculations are observed as small, local, involuntary muscle contractions (twitching) visible under the skin. Fasciculations result from increased irritability of an axon (which in turn is often a manifestation of disease of a motor neuron). This leads to sporadic discharges of all the muscle fibers controlled by the axon in isolation from other motor units.

If the two laminae of the septum pellucidum are not fused then a fluid-filled space or cavum is present. The cavum septum pellucidum is present at birth but usually obliterates by the age of 3 to 6 months. It is up to 1cm in width and the walls are parallel. It is an enclosed space and is not part of the ventricular system or connected with the subarachnoid space.
A type of dysmetria involving the limbs.

Cerebral cysts, usually located in the wall of the caudate nucleus or in the caudothalamic groove. They are found in up to 5.2% of all neonates, using transfontanellar ultrasound in the first days of life.
An abnormality of the globus pallidus.

A type of dysarthria related to bilateral damage of the upper motor neuron tracts of the pyramidal and extra- pyramidal tracts. Speech of affected individuals is slow, effortful, and has a harsh vocal quality.

A type of dysarthria related to bilateral damage of the upper motor neuron tracts of the pyramidal and extra- pyramidal tracts. Speech of affected individuals is slow, effortful, and has a harsh vocal quality.
Increased concentration of lactate in the cerebrospinal fluid.
Spastic paralysis affecting all four limbs.

Weakness of the hip girdle and upper thigh muscles, for instance in myopathies, leads to an instability of the pelvis on standing and walking. If the muscles extending the hip joint are affected, the posture in that joint becomes flexed and lumbar lordosis increases. The patients usually have difficulties standing up from a sitting position. Due to weakness in the gluteus medius muscle, the hip on the side of the swinging leg drops with each step (referred to as Trendelenburg sign). The gait appears waddling. The patients frequently attempt to counteract the dropping of the hip on the swinging side by bending the trunk towards the side which is in the stance phase (in the German language literature this is referred to as Duchenne sign). Similar gait patterns can be caused by orthopedic conditions when the origin and the insertion site of the gluteus medius muscle are closer to each other than normal, for instance due to a posttraumatic elevation of the trochanter or pseudarthrosis of the femoral neck.
Electron-dense granules within double membrane-bound cytoplasmic vacuoles.
Involuntary flexion or extension of the arms and legs.
The presence of developmental dysplasia of the cerebral cortex.
Absence of facial hair.
Presence of more than two nipples.
An erosion of the mucous membrane in a portion of the duodenum.
Reduced intensity of muscle tendon reflexes in the lower limbs. Reflexes are elicited by stretching the tendon of a muscle, e.g., by tapping.
Involuntary fecal soiling in adults and children who have usually already been toilet trained.

Celiac disease (CD) is an autoimmune condition affecting the small intestine, triggered by the ingestion of gluten, the protein fraction of wheat, barley, and rye. Clinical manifestations of CD are highly variable and include both gastrointestinal and non-gastrointestinal features. The hallmark of CD is an immune-mediated enteropathy. This term is included because the occurence of CD is seen as a feature of a number of other diseases.
Progressive destruction of the small-to-medium bile ducts of the intrahepatic biliary tree, which leads to progressive cholestasis and often end-stage liver disease.
An anomaly of vein.
Abnormality of the absorption of fat from the gastrointestinal tract.

In type IV atherosclerotic lesions a dense accumulation of extracellular lipid occupies an extensive but well-defined region of the intima. This type of extracellular lipid accumulation is known as the lipid core. A fibrous tissue increase is not a feature, and complications such as defects of the lesion surface and thrombosis are not present. The type IV lesion is also known as atheroma. Type IV is the first lesion considered advanced in this classification because of the severe intimal disorganization caused by the lipid core. The characteristic core appears to develop from an increase and the consequent confluence of the small isolated pools of extracellular lipid that characterize type III lesions. The increase in lipid is believed to result from continued insudation from the plasma. Type IV lesions, when they first appear in younger people, are found in the same locations as adaptive intimal thickenings of the eccentric type. Thus, atheroma is, at least initially, an eccentric lesion.
The presence of extra bones within a cranial suture. Wormian bones are irregular isolated bones which appear in addition to the usual centers of ossification of the cranium.
A general term describing features characterized by abnormal development of bones and connective tissues.
Increased width of the skull.
Abnormality of the calvaria, which is the roof of the skull formed by the frontal bone, parietal bones, and occipital bone.
The presence of an abnormally thick calvaria.
The presence of an abnormally thick calvaria.
An abnormality of the frontal sinus, one of the mucosa-lined, normally air-filled paranasal sinuses of the bones of the skull. The frontal sinus is located within the frontal bone.

An abnormality of the base of the skull, which forms the floor of the cranial cavity and separates the brain from other facial structures. The skull base is made up of five bones: the ethmoid, sphenoid, occipital, paired frontal, and paired parietal bones, and is subdivided into 3 regions: the anterior, middle, and posterior cranial fossae. The petro-occipital fissure subdivides the middle cranial fossa into 1 central component and 2 lateral components.
Increased bone density of the skull base without significant changes in bony contour.
Any abnormality of the parietal bone of the skull.
An abnormality of the immune system.
Enlargment (swelling) of a lymph node.
Increased susceptibility to infections.
Underdevelopment of frontal sinus.
A decreased rate of skeletal maturation. Delayed skeletal maturation can be diagnosed on the basis of an estimation of the bone age from radiographs of specific bones in the human body.
Presence of more than one exostosis. An exostosis is a benign growth the projects outward from the bone surface. It is capped by cartilage, and arises from a bone that develops from cartilage.
Presence of more than one exostosis. An exostosis is a benign growth the projects outward from the bone surface. It is capped by cartilage, and arises from a bone that develops from cartilage.
Any morphological abnormality of cartilage.
Weakness or softness of the cartilage in the walls of the bronchial tubes.
Any anomaly of the structure of the femur.
An abnormal punctate (speckled, dot-like) pattern of calcifications in soft tissues within or surrounding bones (as observed on radiographs).
The presence of a medullary carcinoma of the thyroid gland.
Underdevelopment of the ilium ala.
Decreased width of the wing (or ala) of the ilium (which is the large expanded portion which bounds the greater pelvis laterally).
Widening of the ilium ala, that is of the wing of the ilium, combined with external rotation, leading to a flared appearance of the iliac wing.
Widening of the ilium ala, that is of the wing of the ilium, combined with external rotation, leading to a flared appearance of the iliac wing.
Apnea resulting from depression of the respiratory centers in the medulla oblongata. There is a lack of respiratory effort rather than obstruction of airflow.
Episodes of very rapid breathing.
The presence of a papillary adenocarcinoma of the thyroid gland.
A benign tumor of the parathyroid gland that can cause hyperparathyroidism.
An increased amount of bilirubin in the blood.
An increased concentration of all types of amino acid in the urine.
An increased concentration of chloride in the urine.
An increased concentration of histidine in the urine.
Ventral hernia refers to a condition in which abdominal contents protrude through a weakened portion of the abdominal wall.
An abnormal reduction in sensation in the distal portions of the extremities.
Altered immune function characterized by lymphoid proliferation, immune activation, and excessive autoreactivity often leading to autoimmune/inflammatory complications.
A bending or abnormal curvature affecting a long bone of the leg.
A benign neoplasm that usually arises from the sympathetic trunk in the mediastinum, representing a tumor of the sympathetic nerve fibers arising from neural crest cells.
A morphological abnormality of epiphyses whereby they are abnormally outwardly curving (protuberant).
The presence of a splayed (i.e.,flared) metaphyseal segment of one or more long bones.
Abnormality of the wrist, the structure connecting the hand and the forearm.
Shortening of the middle parts of the limbs (forearm and lower leg) in relation to the upper and terminal segments.
Underdevelopment of the fibula.
Abnormality of the patella (knee cap).
Partial dislocation of the head of the radius.
Abnormal increase in size of one or more metaphyses.
An abnormality of the humerus (i.e., upper arm bone).
Underdevelopment of the patella.

An anomaly related to partial closure, or failure of development of the ulnar side of the distal radial growth plate, which results in an arrest of epiphyseal growth of the medial and volar portions of the distal radius. This leads to shortening of the radius and relative overgrowth of the ulna.
Relatively increased growth of the fibula compared to that of the tibia.
An increased concentration of glycine in the urine.
A contrqacture (chronic loss of joint motion due to structural changes in muscle, tendons, ligaments, or skin) that prevent normal movement of one or more joints of the limbs.
An increased concentration of glutaric acid in the urine.
An increased concentration of carnosine in the urine.
An abnormality of the acetabulum, i.e., the Acetabular part of hip bone, which together with the head of the femur forms the hip joint.
Underdevelopment of the ischium, which forms the lower and back part of the hip bone.
Decreased superior-inferior length of the nasal bridge, which is the saddle-shaped area that includes the nasal root and the lateral aspects of the nose.
An increased concentration of orotic acid in the urine.
An increased concentration of methionine in the blood.
Underdevelopment of part or all of the external reproductive organs.
Location of the urethral opening on the inferior aspect of the penis.
Location of the urethral opening on the inferior aspect of the penis.
An abnormality of the process of DNA repair, that is, of the process of restoring DNA after damage.
Underdeveloped acetabulae.
Reduced side to side width of the pelvis.
An abnormally squared appearance of the bony pelvis, a normally rounded or basin-shaped structure.
Complete bilateral fractures of the pars interarticularis resulting in the anterior slippage of the vertebra.
Generalized weakness or decreased strength of the muscles, affecting both distal and proximal musculature.
A left-right reversal (or \
Wasting of thenar muscles, which are located on palm of the hand at the base of the thumb.
An abnormality related to a defect of vertebral separation during development.
Abnormally increased movement at the junction between the first cervical (atlas) and the second cervical (axis) vertebrae as a result of either a bony or ligamentous anomaly.
A type of weakness that occurs after a muscle group is used and lessens if the muscle group has some rest. That is, there is diminution of strength with repetitive muscle actions.

An abnormality of the primary sensation that is mediated by peripheral nerves (pain, temperature, touch, vibration, joint position). The word hypoesthesia (or hypesthesia) refers to a reduction in cutaneous sensation to a specific type of testing.
The presence of autoantibodies in the serum that react against nuclei or nuclear components.
A mild degree of short stature, more than -2 SD but not more than -3 SD from mean corrected for age and sex.
A mild degree of short stature, more than -2 SD but not more than -3 SD from mean corrected for age and sex.
A severe degree of short stature, more than -4 SD from the mean corrected for age and sex.
An increased concentration of ornithine in the urine.
Any abnormality of the soft tissues, including both connective tissue (tendons, ligaments, fascia, fibrous tissues, and fat).

The term dystrophy means abnormal growth. However, muscular dystrophy is used to describe primary myopathies with a genetic basis and a progressive course characterized by progressive skeletal muscle weakness and wasting, defects in muscle proteins, and histological features of muscle fiber degeneration (necrosis) and regeneration. If possible, it is preferred to use other HPO terms to describe the precise phenotypic abnormalities.

ET: Amyotrophy of the musculature of the pelvis
DEF: Muscular atrophy affecting the muscles of the pelvis.
Generalized (diffuse, unlocalized) amyotrophy (muscle atrophy) affecting multiple muscles.
Hypertrophy (increase in size) of muscle cells in a generalized (not localized) distribution.
Amyotrophy affecting the muscles of the shoulder girdle.

JT: 筋電図:ミオトニア反応
DEF: Spontaneous, repetitive electrical activity demonstrated by electromyography (EMG).
An abnormal, increased fatiguability of the musculature.
Episodes of muscle weakness.
Developmental hypoplasia (shortening) of middle phalanx of toe.

Nemaline rods are abnormal bodies that can occur in skeletal muscle fibers. The rods can be observed on histological analysis of muscle biopsy tissue or upon electron microscopy, where they appear either as extensions of sarcomeric Z-lines, in random array without obvious attachment to Z-lines (often in areas devoid of sarcomeres) or in large clusters localized at the sarcolemma or intermyofibrillar spaces.

JT: 死OR死亡|インジウム|幼児期OR小児期
DEF: Death in during childhood, defined here as between the ages of 2 and 10 years.

ET: Narrow joint spaces of the elbow
Abnormality of the epiphyses of the elbow

DEF: Abnormally wide bone of the skeleton of forearm.

ET: Advanced ossification of the hand bones
DEF: Ossification of hand bones at an earlier age than normal.

ET: Delayed ossification of the hand bones
DEF: Ossification of hand bones is less advanced than would be expected according to age-adjusted norms.
Congenital absence of a carpal bone.
Increased size of carpal bones.
Increased size of carpal bones.
Underdevelopment of the scaphoid.

JT: 切痕のある手骨粗鬆症

DEF: An abnormality of the gastric mucous membrane.
An abnormality of the biliary system.
The presence of a hernia in the abdominal wall.

Any abnormality of the skeletal muscle cell. Muscle fibers are subdivided into two types. Type I fibers are fatigue-resistant and rich in oxidative enzymes (they stain light with the myosin ATPase reaction), and type II fibers are fast-contracting, fatigue-prone, and rich in glycolytic enzymes (these fibers stain darkly). Normal muscle tissue has a random distribution of type I and type II fibers.
An abnormality of the endocardium.
An abnormality in which the cardiac ventricles depolarize too early as a result of an abnormality of cardiac conduction pathways such as an accessory pathway.

ET: Abnormality of the anterior segment of the globe
DEF: An abnormality of the anterior segment of the eyeball (which comprises the structures in front of the vitreous humour: the cornea, iris, ciliary body, and lens).

ET: Abnormality of the posterior segment of the globe

DEF: The presence of foam cells in the bone marrow, generally demonstrated by bone-marrow aspiration or biopsy. Foam cells have a vacuolated appearance due to the presence of complex lipid deposits, giving them a foamy or soap-suds appearance.
The presence of excessive redundant myelin in the peripheral nerve sheath.

Abnormally elevated concentration of a purine compound. Purine compounds are aromatic heterocyclic compounds containing a purine moiety, which is formed a pyrimidine-ring ring fused to an imidazole ring.

Abnormally reduced concentration of a purine compound. Purine compounds are aromatic heterocyclic compounds containing a purine moiety, which is formed a pyrimidine-ring ring fused to an imidazole ring.
Abnormal calcification of the mitral valve.
An abnormality of the pulmonary artery.
Inflammation of a vein associated with venous thrombosis (blood clot formation within the vein).
A narrowing of the biparietal diameter (i.e., of the transverse distance between the protuberances of the two parietal bones of the skull).

JT: 無ガンマグロブリン血症
DEF: A lasting absence of total IgG and total IgA and total IgM in the blood circulation, whereby at most trace quantities can be measured.
Excessive growth of the bones of cranium, i.e., of the skull.
The presence of erythrocytes that are sphere-shaped.
The presence of elliptical, cigar-shaped erythrocytes on peripheral blood smear.
A groove of the skin immediately in front of the ear.

ET: Exostosis of the external auditory canal
DEF: A benign bony growth projecting outward from a bone surface within the external auditory canal.
Pits in the earlobes at the location where ears are typically pierced for earrings.

An abnormality of the C-shaped rings of hyaline cartilage, normally 16 to 20 in number, that occupy the anterior two-thirds of the circumference of the trachea (the posterior portion of the ring is completed by fibrous and smooth muscle tissue).
Chronic inflammation of the bronchi.
Chronic inflammation of the bronchi.
The presence of an abnormally large skull with onset at birth.
Excessive growth of the calvaria.
An enlargement of the posterior fontanelle relative to age-dependent norms.
Reduced or lacking hair growth in the temporal region (i.e., around the temples on the side of the skull).
Reduced or lacking hair growth in a generalized distribution.
Excessive, increased hair growth located in the sacral region.
Anterior cervical hypertrichosis (ACH) or 'hairy throat' refers to the presence of a tuft of terminal hair on the anterior neck, just above the laryngeal prominence.
Generalized excessive, abnormal hairiness.
A flattened vertebral body shape with reduced distance between the vertebral endplates affecting the cervical spine.
Bulbous appearance of the anterior vertebral bodies, such that the vertebral bodies have the greatest vertical height anteriorly as well as bulbous anterior superior-inferior contours.
Increased top to bottom height of vertebral bodies.
Exaggerated concavity of the anterior or posterior surface of the vertebral body, i.e., the upper and lower vertebral endplates are hollowed inward.
A flattened vertebral body shape with reduced distance beween the vertebral endplates affecting the thoracic spine.
A lack of ossification of the vertebral bodies.
Presence of abnormal convexity of the upper and lower end plates of the vertebrae, i.e., an exaggerated bulging out of the upper and lower vertebral end plates.
An abnormality related to a defect of vertebral separation of cervical vertebrae during development.
Underdevelopment of one or more muscles innervated by the facial nerve (the seventh cranial nerve).
Syndactyly with fusion of toes two and three.
Syndactyly with fusion of toes four and five.
The presence of abnormal punctate (speckled, dot-like) calcifications in the epiphysis of the calcaneus.
Acute renal failure with resolution of manifestations.
A defect in the ability to concentrate the urine.

ET: Abnormality of the renal collecting system
DEF: An abnormality of the renal collecting system.
Decreased number of head hairs per unit area on the anterior region of the scalp.
Fragile, easily breakable scalp hair.
Presence of multiple polyps in the duodenum.
An anatomical anomaly that results from an abnormal rotation of the gut as it returns to the abdominal cavity during embryogenesis.
A deviation from the normal rotation of the midgut during embryologic development with mislocalization of the small bowel.
The presence of erythrocytes that are sphere-shaped and reduced in size.
A form of severe hemolytic anemia characterized by erythrocyte morphology reminiscent of that seen in patients after a thermal burn.
An abdominal hernia that occurs at a site of weakness in the abdominal wall resulting from an incompletely-healed surgical wound.
Episodic hyperventilation.
An abnormally elevated blood pressure in the circulation of the pulmonary artery.

Narrowing of peripheral arteries with reduction of blood flow to the limbs. This feature may be quantified as an ankle-brachial index of less than 0.9, and may be manifested clinically as claudication.
Calcification, that is, pathological deposition of calcium salts in the aorta.
Underdevelopment of the pulmonary artery.
Abnormally increased density of metaphyseal bone.
An elevation in bone density of the cortex of one or more diaphyses. Sclerosis is normally detected on a radiograph as an area of increased opacity.
The ability of the wrist joints to move beyond their normal range of motion.
Underdevelopment of the nasal septum.
An abnormality of the intervertebral disk.
An abnormal localized widening (dilatation) of the aortic arch.
A type of arrhythmia that originates above the ventricles, whereby the electrical impulse propagates down the normal His Purkinje system similar to normal sinus rhythm.
Refers to the specific combination of defects with a severely dysplastic pulmonary valve and massively dilated branch pulmonary arteries.
The dividing wall between left and right sides of the heart, thickens and bulges into the left ventricle.
Abnormal calcification of a cardiac valve.
Any defect in the valve connecting the heart and the pulmonary artery.

Inability of the left ventricle to perform its normal physiologic function. Failure is either due to an inability to contract the left ventricle or the inability to relax completely and fill with blood during diastole.

A longer than normal interval (corrected for heart rate) between the Q and T waves in the heart's cycle. Prolonged QTc can cause premature action potentials during late phase depolarizations thereby leading to ventricular arrhythmias and ventricular fibrillations.

ET: Aplasia of the abdominal wall musculature
DEF: Absence of the abdominal musculature.
The occurrence of the full-thickness tear (perforation) of the wall of the esophagus.
Watery voluminous diarrhea resulting from an imbalance between ion and water secretion and absorption.
The presence of cyst of the intrahepatic bile duct.
The presence of a fistula (abnormal tunnel) between the anal canal and the perineum.
Absence of gastric intrinsic factor, which is normally produced by the parietal cells of the stomach, and is required for the absorption of vitamin B12.
Atresia in the extrahepatic bile duct.

ET: Hypoplasia of the abdominal wall musculature
DEF: Underdevelopment of the abdominal musculature.
Atresia in the intrahepatic bile duct.
Aplasia (congenital absence) of the pectoralis minor.

Pseudocoarctation is a congenital anomaly of kinking, or buckling, of the aorta without a pressure gradient across the lesion. It is characterized by elongation and kinking of the aorta at the level of the ligamentum arteriosum.
A type of vasculitis (inflammation of blood vessel walls) affecting large arteries such as the aorta and branches of the aorta.
Unilateral overgrowth of facial tissues, including muscles, bones and skin.
Decreased density/number and/or decreased diameter of lateral eyebrow hairs.
An abnormality of the complement system.
Any structural abnormality of the carotid arteries, including the common carotid artery and its' arterial branches.
An abnormality of the structure of the veins that return deoxygenated blood from the body into the heart, i.e., the superior vena cava and the inferior vena cava.
An immunodeficiency characterized by defective cell-mediated immunity or humoral immunity.
The presence of a coronal suture (the cranial suture that separates the frontal and parietal bones) that is not ossified but rather wide open at an age when it is normally closed.
Abnormal increased size of the posterior cranial fossa.
The presence of calcium deposition in the falx cerebri.
Underdevelopment of the frontal bone.
The presence of a sagittal suture (the cranial suture that separates the left and right parietal bones) that is not ossified but rather wide open at an age when it is normally closed.
An abnormality of the epiglottis.
Increased megakaryocyte number, i.e., of platelet precursor cells, present in the bone marrow.
Larger than normal size of erythrocytes.
A reduced count of megakaryocytes.
A reduced count of megakaryocytes.
An abnormality of the zygomatic arch, also known as the cheek bone.
The presence of many cysts in the kidney.
Loss of all scalp hair with congenital onset.
Increased cross-section (diameter) of the long bones. Note that widening may primarily affect specific regions of long bones (e.g., diaphysis or metaphysis), but this should be coded separately.
The ability of the joints of the hand to move beyond their normal range of motion.
The presence of abnormal calcium deposition of the intervertebral disk.
Sclerosis (abnormal hardening) of cortical bone, characterized by increased radiodensity.
A tongue-like protusion from the anterior aspect of lumbar vertebral bodies.

An inherited primary limb malformation disorder characterized by congenital contractures of two or more different body areas and without primary neurologic and/or muscle disease that affects limb function.
Patchy (irregular) increase in bone density. This can take on many forms depending on severity and distribution as can be seen on x-rays.
Abnormal reduction in length of all metacarpal bones.
An abnormal irregularity of cortical bone.

ET: Contractures of the joints of the lower limbs

DEF: Abnormal elevation of the floor of the posterior fossa including occipital condyles and foramen magnum.
A flattened vertebral body shape with reduced distance beween the vertebral endplates affecting the lumbar spine.
The presence of more than 12 rib pairs.
Short (hypoplastic) middle phalanx of finger, affecting one or more fingers.
Abnormal mineralization of the metaphyseal area of bones.

ET: obsolete Abnormal ossification of hand bones
Abnormalities of the metaphyses of the hand
Abnormalities of the cortex of hand bones
DEF: An anomaly of the outer shell (cortex) of a hand bone.
The presence of multiple lung cysts.
Episodes of reduced body termperature.
Developmental hypoplasia of the thyroid gland.
Developmental hypoplasia of the thyroid gland.

ET: Hypotrophy of the small hand muscles

DEF: Absence of one or more interphalangeal creases (i.e., of the transverse lines in the skin between the phalanges of the fingers).
Increased length of the proximal phalanx of finger.
The presence of a supernumerary finger (not a thumb) involving the third or fourth metacarpal with associated osseous syndactyly.
Excessively deep creases of the palm.
Phalanges of the fingers becoming thinner toward the distal end.
Underdevelopment of the spleen.
The presence of pancreatic tissue outside the normal pancreas, in many cases along the foregut and proximal midgut.
Irregular distribution of the teeth along the dental arch, i.e., and irregular spatial pattern of teeth.
Short dental root.
A congenital defect characterized by the absence of one or more permanent teeth, including oligodontia, hypodontia, and adontia of the of permanent teeth.
An alteration of the normally relatively smooth margins of the kneecap in radiographic images leading to an irregular contour.
Absent or nearly absent fibula. (Does not include aplastic)
An abnormal anterior bending or curvature of the tibia.
A bending or abnormal curvature of the distal portion of the tibia.
An abnormally wide femoral neck (which is the process of bone, connecting the femoral head with the femoral shaft).
Premature loss of teeth not related to trauma or neglect.
The presence of an altered number of of teeth.

Hypersensitivity pneumonitis involves inhalation of an antigen. This leads to an exaggerated immune response and a following inflammation of the alveoli within the lungs. The main feature of chronic hypersensitivity pneumonitis on lung biopsies is expansion of the interstitium by lymphocytes accompanied by an occasional multinucleated giant cell or loose granuloma. After exposure to the provoking antigen, following symptoms can be seen: fever, chills, malaise, cough, hemoptysis, chest tightness, dyspnea, rash, swelling and headache and can be completely reversible, based on the duration of the illness, categorized as acute (HP:0011009), subacute (HP:0011011), and chronic (HP:0011010).
Abnormality of the lung parenchyma extending to the pulmonary interstitium and leading to diffuse pulmonary fibrosis.
Obstruction of conducting airways of the lung.
A type of pulmonary sequestration that is completely enclosed in its own pleural sac, occurring above, within, or below the diaphragm, and without communication with the tracheobronchial tree.

Pulmonary arteriovenous malformation, a condition most commonly associated with hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia, is an abnormal communication between the pulmonary artery and pulmonary vein without an intervening capillary communication. HRCT images usually show a coarse spidery appearance of the peripheral vascular markings in the lungs. More specific findings are obtained in the pulmonary angiogram where the normally invisible capillary phase is replaced by irregular vascular channels bridging the peripheral branches of pulmonary arteries and veins.
An abnormally straight configuration of the clavicle, a tubular bone which normally is doubly curved .
Breast carcinoma that is bilateral or otherwise multifocal.
Lack of formation of mineralized bony tissue of the sternum.

Calcification of the costal cartilages, which are bars of hyaline cartilage found at the anterior ends of the ribs which serve to prolong the ribs forward and contribute to the elasticity of the walls of the thorax.
Chest wall pain in the area of the costochondral junctions.
Absence of the clavicles as a developmental defect.
Increased time for the complex comprised of the Q wave, R wave, and S wave as measured by the electrocardiogram (EKG).. In adults, normal values are 0.06 - 0.10 sec.
The presence of excessive connective tissue in the endocardium.
Abnormal tortuous (i.e., twisted) form of the aorta.
Any structural abnormality of the coronary arteries.
An abnormality of an atrioventricular valve.
An abnormality of the hepatic vasculature.
The presence of a papillary adenocarcinoma of the ovary.
A malignant plasma cell tumor growing within soft tissue or within the skeleton.
Underdevelopment of the paranasal sinuses.
Underdevelopment of the ventral portion of the pons.
Wasting (atrophy) of the vermis of cerebellum.
A hemangioblastoma of the cerebellum.

Brain damage related to a lowering of blood glucose below a critical level (around 30 mg/dl), which may lead to confusion, lethargy and delirium followed by seizures and coma. Prolonged hypoglycemia may lead to irreversible brain damage.

A reduced sense of touch (tactile sensation) on the skin of the distal limbs. This is usually tested with a wisp of cotton or a fine camel's hair brush, by asking patients to say 'now' each time they feel the stimulus.
An increased susceptibility to meningitis as manifested by a medical history of recurrent episodes of meningitis.
Inability to perceive painful stimuli.
A morphological abnormality of the metencephalon.
Increased size of the basal ganglia.
A particular type of dementia characterized by a pattern of mental defects consisting prominently of forgetfulness, slowness of thought processes, and personality or mood change.
Enlargement of all or parts of one cerebral hemisphere.
Muscular weakness and atrophy related to loss of the motor neurons of the spinal cord and brainstem.
A loss of myelin from nerve fibers in the central nervous system.
Focal seizure characterized at onset by clonic movements affecting half of the face.
Underdevelopment of the frontal lobe of the cerebrum.
A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the gastrointestinal tract.

Cutaneous lesion that develops as a dry, scaly, red patch that evolves to an indurated and hyperpigmented plaque with adherent scale. Scarring may result in central white patches (loss of pigmentation) and skin atrophy.
Lichenification affecting primarily flexural areas of the skin.
Reduced number or density of facial hair.

A skin condition characterized by excessive development of keratin in hair follicles, resulting in rough, cone-shaped, elevated papules resulting from closure of hair follicles with a white plug of sebum.
Loose and sagging skin of the fingers.
Hyperkeratosis affecting the sole of the foot.
The presence of leiomyoma of the skin.
A developmental anomaly characterized by abnormal smallness of both eyes.
Vitelliform maculopathy is a sharply demarcated lesion caused by the accumulation of material, often lipofuscin in the subretinal space underlying the macula.
Underdevelopment of the lower eyelid.
A malignant melanoma originating within the eye. The tumor originates from the melanocytes in the uvea (which comprises the iris, ciliary body, and choroid).
Underdevelopment of the fovea centralis.
Fibrous connective tissue resulting from incomplete healing of a wound (i.e., a scar) located in the choroid and retina or the eye.
A type of cataract affecting the posterior pole of lens immediately adjacent to ('beneath') the Lens capsule.
A cataract that affects the anterior part of the cortex of the lens.

Mottling (spots or blotches with different shades) of the retinal pigment epithelium, i.e., localized or generalized fundal pigment granularity associated with processes at the level of the retinal pigment epithelium.
Presenile cataract is a kind of cataract that occurs in early adulthood, that is, at an age that is younger than usual.
A kind of cataract that progresses with age.
A progressive form of ptosis.
Punctate opacification (reduced transparency) of the corneal stroma.
Intraocular pressure that is 2 standard deviations above the population mean.
Separation of the inner layers of the retina (neural retina) from the pigment epithelium occuring near the outer limit (periphery) of the retina.
Retinal exudate within the retinal tissue itself.
Loss of peripheral vision with retention of central vision, resulting in a constricted circular tunnel-like field of vision.

An abnormally reduced response to stimulation of the cornea (by touch, foreign body, blowing air). The corneal reflex (also known as the blink reflex, normally results in an involuntary blinking of the eyelids.
Increased amount of pigmentation in the fovea centralis.
Abnormal pigmentation of the iris.

ET: Abnormality of the vasculature of the eye

DEF: An abnormality of an extraocular muscle.
An anomaly of the space between the medial and lateral canthi of the two open eyelids.
An overall widening of the spaces between the digits.
A two-part calcaneus, a finding that probably results from delayed coalescence of two primary calcaneal centers of ossification.
Delayed maturation and calcification of the calcaneus.
No secondary sexual characteristics are present at puberty.
The congenital absence of the thyroid gland.
Hyperplasia of the thyroid gland.
Adrenocortical adenomas are benign tumors of the adrenal cortex.

The presence of intracellular inclusion bodies (aggregates of stainable substances, usually proteins) in neutrophils. Cytoplasmic neutrophil inclusions (oval, basophilic) are also known as Doehle bodies.
Atrophy (wasting) of the cerebellar cortex.
An increased urine level of any amino acid carrying two amino groups (Asparagine, glutamine and lysine, cystine, ornithine).

ET: Contractures involving the joints of the feet

DEF: Synostosis (bony fusion) involving one or more bones of the tarsus (calcaneus, talus, cuboid, navicular, cuneiiform bones).
Nails whose growth is slower than normal.
Nails whose growth is slower than normal.
A thickening of the stratum corneum in the region beneath the nails.
Thickened toenails.
Longitudinal, linear prominences in the fingernail plate.
Schisis (cleft or cleavage) of vertebral bodies.
An abnormality related to a defect of vertebral separation of sacral vertebrae during development.
Decreased ossification of the cervical vertebral bodies, i.e., of the Cervical vertebrae set.
Permanent indentation on the posteromedial aspect of the helix that may be sharply or indistinctly delineated.
Absence of the acoustic reflex, an involuntary contraction of the stapedius muscle that occurs in response to high-intensity sound stimuli.
Complete lack of functioning of the vestibular apparatus.
A form of sensorineural hearing impairment that affects primarily the lower frequencies.
Increased anterosuperior prominence of the area between the bottom of the incisura and the inner margin of the antihelix.
Benign congenital lesion of the supraauricular soft tissue consisting of a blind-ending narrow tube or pit.
A form of sensorineural hearing impairment with infantile onset.
A severe form of sensorineural hearing impairment.

Pulsatile tinnitus is generally classified a kind of objective tinnitus, meaning that it is not only audible to the patient but also to the examiner on auscultation of the auditory canal and/or of surrounding structures with use of an auscultation tube or stethoscope. Usually, pulsatile tinnitus is heard as a lower pitched thumping or booming, a rougher blowing sound which is coincidental with respiration, or as a clicking, higher pitched rhythmic sensation. Pulsatile tinnitus may be associated with vascular abnormalities such as arterioevenous shunts or glomus tumors or the jugular vein, arterial bruits related to a high-riding carotid artery (close to the auditory areas) or carotid stenosis, or venous abnormalities such as a dehiscent jugular bulb or to hypertension. Finally, in some patients, mechanical abnormalities such a spatulous eustachian tubes, palatomyoclonus (small spasms of muscles in the soft palate area), or idiopathic stapedial muscle spasm may represent the underlying cause of pulsatile tinnitus.
Absence of sex glands (gonads are the organs that produce gametes; testis in males and ovary in females).
Incomplete maturation or aberrant formation of the male gametes.
Presence of a single diverticulum (sac or pouch) in the wall of the urinary bladder.
A unilateral form of atrophy of the kidney.
The presence of a partially duplicated kidney.
A mild form of hypospadias in which the urethra opens just under the corona glandis.
Ossification affecting the set of cartilages of larynx.
A malformation of the laryngeal cartilage.
Absence of the epiglottis.
Delayed maturation and calcification of the pubic bone.
Underdevelopment of the lesser trochanter.
Increased width of the femoral head.
The presence of developmental dysplasia of the acetabular part of hip bone.
Increased size of the ilium ala.
Joint dislocation of the femoral head.
Underdevelopment of the bony pelvis.
A moderate degree of short stature, more than -3 SD but not more than -4 SD from mean corrected for age and sex.
A loss of adipose tissue.
Disproportionate shortening of the proximal segment of limbs (i.e. the femur and humerus).
Underdevelopment of the pectoralis major.
Atrophy of the intrinsic muscle groups of the hand, comprising the thenar and hypothenar muscles; the interossei muscles; and the lumbrical muscles.
Underdevelopment of the muscuklature of the calf.
Underdevelopment of muscles of the neck.
Congenital lack, i.e., aplasia of the diaphragm.

ET: Weakness of the intrinsic hand muscles

DEF: Underdevelopment of the biceps muscle.
Underdevelopment of the serratus anterior muscle, which is involved in abduction, upward Rotation, and elevation of the scapula.
Underdevelopment of muscles of the arm.
Underdevelopment of the latissimus dorsi muscle, which is involved in adduction, extension, internal rotation, and transverse extension of the shoulder and assists in movement of the scapula.

Weakness of the muscles responsible for dorsiflexion of the foot, that is, of the movement of the toes towards the shin. The foot dorsiflexors include the tibialis anterior, the extensor hallucis longus, the extensor digitorum longus, and the peroneus tertius muscles.
Severe hypertrophy (increase in size) of muscle cells.
Reduced ability to run.
An abnormal accumulation of lipids in skeletal muscle.
Atrophy of the muscles that are responsible for moving the scapula, which are the levator scapulae, the infraspinatus muscle, the teres major, the teres minor, and the supraspinatus muscle.
Impairment in the physical production of speech sounds.
A cleft of the lip with overlying mucous membrane.

ET: Abnormal ossification of the pubic bone
DEF: Abnormal ossification (bone tissue formation) affecting the pubic bone, also known as the pubis.

An increase in adipose tissue mass by hyperplastic growth (increase in the number of adipocytes) or by hypertrophic growth (increase in the size of adipocytes occurring primarily by lipid accumulation within the cell).

ET: Abnormality of the musculature of the limbs
Abnormality of the musculature of the thorax
DEF: A disease or lesion affecting the muscles of the thorax.

ET: Duplication involving bones of the feet
Synostosis involving bones of the lower limbs
DEF: An abnormal union between bones or parts of bones lower limbs.
A secondary ossification center in the fifth finger that is distinct from the normal epiphysis that does not contribute to the longitudinal growth of a tubular bone.
A secondary ossification center in the fourth finger that is distinct from the normal epiphysis that does not contribute to the longitudinal growth of a tubular bone.
A secondary ossification center in the third finger that is distinct from the normal epiphysis that does not contribute to the longitudinal growth of a tubular bone.
Bending or curvature of a finger toward the ulnar side (i.e., away from the thumb). The deviation is at the metacarpal-phalangeal joint, and this finding is distinct from clinodactyly.
Bending or curvature of a finger toward the radial side (i.e., towards the thumb). The deviation is at the metacarpal-phalangeal joint, and this finding is distinct from clinodactyly.
An abnormal position of the hand in which the wrist is bent toward the radius (i.e., toward the thumb).
Divergence of the longitudinal axis of the hand at the wrist in a posterior (ulnar) direction (i.e., towards the little finger).
A secondary ossification center in the second finger that is distinct from the normal epiphysis that does not contribute to the longitudinal growth of a tubular bone.

The hairline refers to the outline of hair of the head. An abnormality of the hairline can refer to an unusually low or high border between areas of the scalp with and without hair or to abnormal projections of scalp hair.
Chronic loss of joint motion in the thumb due to structural changes in non-bony tissue. The term camptodactyly is used if the distal and/or proximal interphalangeal joints are affected.
Insertion of thumb at a more distal location than normal.
Hypoplastic (short) thumb phalanx.
Absence of one or more epiphyses of the thumb.
Sclerosis of one or more of the epiphyses of the thumb, leading to an increased degree of radiopacity (white or ivory appearance) in X-rays.
A benign vascular tumor of the retina without any neoplastic characteristics.
A hemangioblastoma of the spinal cord.
An abnormality of the epididymis.
The presence of small depressions in the dental enamel.
The presence of fibromata beneath finger or toenails.
Areas of the retina lacking pigmentation. Punched out areas of chorioretinal hypopigmentation less than 1 disc diameter in size and tending to be located in the midperiphery of the retina.
A benign or malignant neoplasm (tumour) originating in striated muscle, either skeletal muscle or cardiac muscle.
An abnormality of the antihelix.
Developmental hypoplasia of the antihelix.
Absence of the parotid gland.
Abnormally increased thickness of the nasal septum.
Abnormally increased thickness of the nasal septum.

ET: Aplasia of the pectoralis major muscle
DEF: Absence of the pectoralis major muscle.
Complete or nearly complete soft tissue fusion of the alveolar ridges.
Syndactyly with fusion of toes three and four.
A zone of darker pigmentation around the central part of the iris with a roughly cloverleaf or flower shape.
Absence of the quadriceps muscle.
The presence of an abscess located around the anus.
Presence of a bifid sacral bone.
A type of sacrococcygeal teratoma located anterior to the sacrum and entirely inside the body (Altman type IV).
A form of diabetes insipidus caused by failure of the kidneys to respond to vasopressin (AVP).

ET: Anomaly of the upper limb diaphyses
DEF: A structural abnormality of a diaphysis of the arm.
Amelia of one or both upper limbs.
Leg shortening because of underdevelopment of one or more bones of the lower extremity.

ET: Aplasia involving bones of the lower limbs

DEF: Amelia of one or both legs.
Forearm shortening because of underdevelopment of one or more bones of the forearm.

ET: Aplasia involving bones of the upper limbs

DEF: Arm shortening because of underdevelopment of one or more bones of the upper extremity.

ET: Aplasia involving bones of the extremities

DEF: Limb shortening because of underdevelopment of one or more bones of the extremities.

Short distance from the end of the finger to the most distal interphalangeal crease or the distal interphalangeal joint flexion point. That is, hypoplasia of one or more of the distal phalanx of finger.

Trichorrhexis nodosa is the formation of nodes along the hair shaft through which breakage readily occurs. It is thus a focal defect in the hair fiber that is characterized by thickening or weak points (nodes) that cause the hair to break off easily. The result is defective, abnormally fragile hair.
An abnormality of the antitragus, which is a small tubercle opposite to the tragus of the ear. The antitragus and the tragus are separated by the intertragic notch.

An abnormal horizontal axis orientation of the crus of the helix. That is, the main axis of the crus of the helix is perpendicular to the medial longitudinal axis of the ear, instead of sloping inferoposteriorly.
Developmental hypoplasia of the crus of the helix. That is, flatter and/or shorter crus helix than average.
The presence of an abnormally prominent of the crus of the helix. That is, development of the crus helix to the same degree as an average antihelix stem or helix.
Attachment of the lobe to the side of the face at the lowest point of the lobe without curving upward.
Sharply demarcated, typically linear and approximately horizontal, indentations in the outer surface of the ear lobe.
Abnormality of the temporal bone of the skull, which is situated at the sides and base of the skull roughly underlying the region of the face known as the temple.
A tumor of the eye originating from cells of the retina.
An abnormality of the columella.
Absence of the mandible.

Complete or partial duplication of the phalanges of the thumb. Depending on the severity, the appearance on x-ray can vary from a notched phalanx (the duplicated bone is almost completely fused with the phalanx), a partially fused appearance of the two bones (bifid), two separate bones appearing side to side, or completely duplicated phalanges (proximal and distal phalanx of the thumb and/or 1st metacarpal). In contrast to the phalanges of the digits 2-5 (proximal, middle and distal), the proximal phalanx of the thumb is embryologically equivalent to the middle phalanges of the other digits, whereas the first metacarpal is embryologically of phalangeal origin and as such equivalent to the proximal phalanges of the other digits.

ET: Duplication of the middle phalanx of hand
DEF: This term applies if one or more of the middle phalanges of the hand are either partially duplicated, depending on severity leading to a broad or bifid appearance of the phalanges, or completely duplicated.
Developmental defect associated with absence of one or more metacarpal bones.
Partial or complete duplication of one or more phalanx of big toe.
Underdevelopment (hypoplasia) of a phalanx of big toe.
The presence of a supernumerary toe (not a hallux) involving the third or fourth metatarsal with associated osseous syndactyly.
Failure to form (agenesis) of one or more epiphyses of the big toe.

ET: Abnormality of the epiphyses of the toes

DEF: Absence of the epiphyses of the phalanges of the toes.
An abnormal morphology of one or more phalanges of the toes, with a short and wide phalanx that tapers distally. Bullet-shaped phalanges lack the normal diaphyseal constriction.
A deviation from the normal straight form of one or more toe phalanges.
A deviation from the normal straight form of one or more toe phalanges.

ET: Triangular shaped phalanges of the toes

DEF: One or more bent (flexed) joints of the first (big) toe that cannot be straightened actively or passively.

A foot deformity resulting due to an abnormality affecting the bones of the foot (as well as muscle and soft tissue). In contrast if only the muscle and soft tissue are affected the term positional foot deformity applies.

ET: Ivory epiphyses of the phalanges of the hand
DEF: Sclerosis of the epiphyses of the phalanges of the fingers, leading to an increased degree of radiopacity (white or ivory appearance) in X-rays.
Increased pigmentation, either focal or generalized, of the mucosa of the mouth.
Any abnormality of the salivary glands, the exocrine glands that produce saliva.
Any abnormality of the submandibular glands, which are the salivary glands that are located beneath the floor of the mouth, superior to the digastric muscles.
Any abnormality of the sublingual glands, which are the salivary glands that are located beneath the floor of the mouth anterior to the submandibular glands.
An outpouching of the spinal meninges.
The sternal cleft is a rare congenital anomaly resulting from a fusion failure of the sternum.
The presence of hypertrophy of the breast.
Premature development of the breasts.
Absence of the scapulae.
A structural abnormality of the interventricular septum.
A narrowing of the orifice of the tricuspid valve of the heart.
The presence of osteophytes (bone spurs), i.e., of bony projections originating from the acetabulum.
An exaggeration of the normal arched form of the acetabular roof such that it takes on a steep appearance.
Abnormality of the female genital system.
Increased urinary excretion of oligosaccharides (low molecular weight carbohydrate chains composed of at least three monosaccharide subunits), derived from a partial degradation of glycoproteins.
Cloacal exstrophy is a severe anterior abdominal wall defect in which the two hemibladders are visible and are separated by a midline intestinal plate, an omphalocele, and an imperforate anus.

The kneecap normally is located within the groove termed trochlea on the distal femur and can slide up and down in it. Patellar subluxation refers to an unstable kneecap that does not slide centrally within its groove, i.e., a partial dislocation of the patella.
An abnormal increase in the length of the tibia.
Absence of the tarsal bones.
Deposition of calcium salts in the pituitary gland.
Enlargement of the thymus.
An abnormality of the thyroid gland owing to the presence of a fibrous cyst resulting from the persistence of the thyroglossal duct.
Paroxysmal episodes of vertigo.

An intermittent cessation of airflow at the mouth and nose during sleep. Apneas of at least 10 seconds are considered important, but persons with sleep apnea may have apneas of 20 seconds to up to 2 or 3 minutes. Patients may have up to 15 events per hour of sleep.

Vertical nystagmus may present with either up-beating or down-beating eye movements or both. When present in the straight-ahead position of gaze it is referred to as upbeat nystagmus or downbeat nystagmus.
Downbeat nystagmus is a type of fixation nystagmus with the fast phase beating in a downward direction. It generally increases when looking to the side and down and when lying prone.

An acute dystonic reaction with blepharospasm, periorbital twitches, and protracted fixed staring episodes. There may be a maximal upward deviation of the eyes in the sustained fashion. Oculogyric crisis can be triggered by a number of factors including neuroleptic medications.

A soft tissue continuity in the A/P axis between two fingers that extends distally to at least the level of the proximal interphalangeal joints, or a soft tissue continuity in the A/P axis between two fingers that lies significantly distal to the flexion crease that overlies the metacarpophalangeal joint of the adjacent fingers.
An abnormally wavy surface or edge of the clavicles.
Increased size of epiphyses.
Increased size of epiphyses.
An alteration of the normally smooth contour of the epiphysis leading to an irregular appearance.

Hordeola externa are acute purulent infections affecting the sebaceous glands of Zeis or the apocrine sweat glands of Moll, often caused by staphylococcus infections. In contrast to chalazia, hordeola are extremely painfull and can cause extreme local swelling.

Hordeola interna are acute purulent infections affecting the meibomian sebacious glands, often caused by staphylococcus infections. In contrast to chalazia (chronic epithelioid cell granulomatous inflammation of the meibomian gland caused by inflammation of a blocked meibomian gland), hordeola are extremely painfull and can cause extreme local swelling.

A soft tissue continuity in the anteroposterior axis between adjacent foot digits that involves at least half of the proximodistal length of one of the two involved digits; or, a soft tissue continuity in the A/P axis between two digits of the foot that does not meet the prior objective criteria.

ET: Abnormality of the epiphyses of the feet
DEF: Any abnormality of the epiphyses of the feet.
Inability to perceive certain odorants (implies that the sense of smell is maintained for other classes of odorants).
Reduced ability to perceive certain odorants (implies that the sense of smell is maintained for other classes of odorants).
Abnormality of the midnasal cavity which includes the cavity between the nares and the choanae.

An abnormality of the premaxilla (the embryonic structure that forms the anterior part of the maxilla) causing it to appear relatively small in size compared to the other parts of the maxilla or other facial structures.
An abnormality of the Falx cerebri.
A developmental defect characterized by aplasia of the Falx cerebri.
An abnormality of the formation and mineralization of an epiphysis.
An abnormality of the formation and mineralization of any bone of the skeleton of hand.
The presence of bilateral coxa valga.

ET: Hypoplasia of the anterior nasal spine
DEF: Underdevelopment of the anterior nasal spine of maxilla.
An abnormality of the formation and mineralization of any bone of the skeleton of foot.
Mirror image duplication of digits affecting the hands only.
Mirror image duplication of digits affecting the feet.
A type of nuclear cataract involving congenital dust-like (pulverulent) opacity of the embryonal and fetal nucleus.
Syndactyly with fusion of toes one and two.
Syndactyly with fusion of toes one to four.
Syndactyly with fusion of toes one to five (complete syndactyly of all toes of the foot).
Syndactyly with fusion of toes two to four.
Syndactyly with fusion of toes two to five.
Syndactyly with fusion of toes three to five.
An abnormality of the texture of the hair.
An abnormal hair whorl (that is, a patch of hair growing in the opposite direction of the rest of the hair).
Rupture of the eyeball not due to trauma.
Increased width of the columella.
Hyperkeratosis affecting the palm of the hand.
Deposition of calcium salts in a tissue or location in which calcification does not normally occur.
A glioma affecting the brainstem.
Oral commissures positioned superior to the midline labial fissure.
Increased width of the uvula (subjective finding).

Focal emotional seizure with crying (dacrystic) is characterized by the presence of stereotyped crying, this may be accompanied by lacrimation, sad facial expression and sobbing. The subjective emotion of sadness may or may not be present.

Focal emotional seizure with crying (dacrystic) is characterized by the presence of stereotyped crying, this may be accompanied by lacrimation, sad facial expression and sobbing. The subjective emotion of sadness may or may not be present.
A kind of breech presentation in which one or both hips are extended and one or both of the fetus' feet are pointing down and entering the birth canal.

A type of ataxia characterized by the impairment of the ability to smoothly perform the elements of a voluntary movement in the appropriate order and speed. With dyssynergia, a voluntary movement appears broken down into its component parts.
A type of dyssynergia affecting eye movements and characterized by the inability to smoothly follow a visual target across the visual field.
A type of dyssynergy characterized by the lack of the ability to smoothly perform the elements of a voluntary movement in the appropriate order and speed.
A congenital disorder of the pulmonary valve in which the orifice of the valve fails to develop.
A congenital disorder of the aortic valve in which the orifice of the valve fails to develop.

A developmental growth retardation of the vertebral end plates that may lead to secondary destruction of the vertebral end plates and protrusion of the nucleus pulposus into the vertebral body (so called Schmorl's nodes as seen on x-rays).
An increased concentration of valine in the blood.
An increased concentration of isoleucine in the blood.
A type of cataract affecting the anterior pole of lens immediately adjacent to ('beneath') the lens capsule.
An increased concentration of xanthine in the urine.

ET: Abnormality of the upper urinary tract
DEF: An abnormality of the upper urinary tract.

ET: Abnormality of the lower urinary tract
DEF: An abnormality of the lower urinary tract.
An abnormality of the nasal skeleton.

Mild pyelectasis is defined as a hypoechoic spherical or elliptical space within the renal pelvis that measures at least 5mm and not more than 10 mm. The measurement is taken on a transverse section through the fetal renal pelvis using the maximum anterior-to-posterior measurement.
Fetal megacystis is an abnormally enlarged bladder identified at any gestational age.
A kind of bronchopulmonary sequestration that is incorporated into the normal surrounding lung.
Abnormality of the striatum, which is the largest nucleus of the basal ganglia, comprising the caudate, putamen and ventral striatum, including the nucleus accumbens.
A type of cirrhosis characterized by the presence of regenerative nodules of a variety of sizes.

ET: Abnormality of the musculature of the neck
DEF: An abnormality of the neck musculature.
An abnormality of the gastrointestinal tract.
An impairment of a fructose metabolic process.
An abnormality of renal absorption.
An abnormality of the helix. The helix is the outer rim of the ear that extends from the insertion of the ear on the scalp (root) to the termination of the cartilage at the earlobe.
Agenesis of premolar tooth.
A generalized form of periodontitis.
A localized form of periodontitis.
Misaligned incisor.
The presence of an altered number of the incisor teeth.
An abnormality of premolar tooth.
A loss of myelin from the internode regions along myelinated nerve fibers of the peripheral nervous system.
