An abnormal closure, or atresia of the tubular structure of the intestine.
A chronic form of sinusitis.
An abnormality of the morphology of the epidermis.

A condition characterized by necrosis of the mucosal and submucosal layers of the esophagus not related to ingestion of caustic or other injurious agents. Endoscopically, there is a dark lesion ('black esophagus') distributed in a circumferential manner in the distal one-third of the esophagus with or without exudates. There is involvement of the distal esophagus ending sharply at the gastroesophageal junction.
Any abnormality of the morphology of the major calices or minor calices of the kidney.
The presence of a rash (change of color and texture) of the perianal skin.
A dialeptic seizure is a type of seizure characterised predominantly by reduced responsiveness or awareness and with subsequent at least partial amnesia of the event.

JT: ミオクローヌス性欠伸発作
DEF: Myoclonic absence seizure is a type of generalized non-motor (absence) seizure characterised by an interruption of ongoing activities, a blank stare and rhythmic three-per-second myoclonic movements, causing ratcheting abduction of the upper limbs leading to progressive arm elevation, and associated with 3 Hz generalized spike-wave discharges on the electroencephalogram. Duration is typically 10-60 s. Whilst impairment of consciousness may not be obvious the ILAE classified this seizure as a generalized non-motor seizure in 2017.
Atypical absence status epilepticus is a type of generalized non-convulsive status epilepticus without coma that is semiologically a prolonged atypical absence seizure.

JT: 片側ヒプスアリスミア
DEF: Hypsarrhythmia occurring in one hemisphere.
Forward prominence of the entire forehead, due to protrusion of the frontal bone.
Posterior positioning of the glabella, i.e., of the midline forehead between the supraorbital ridges.
Linear vertical groove in the midline of the forehead, extending from hairline to glabella.
Linear vertical groove in the midline of the forehead, extending from hairline to glabella.
An eyebrow that extends straight across the brow, without curve.
Elevated ridge(s) of skin starting well below the medial aspect of the lower lid that curves gradually upward toward and/or across the nasal bridge.
Elevated ridge(s) of skin starting well below the medial aspect of the lower lid that curves gradually upward toward and/or across the nasal bridge.
Supernumerary ridge or crus of the ear arising from the antihelix.
Positioning of the antitragus at an angle perpendicular to the plane of the ear (oriented away from the plane of the ear).
Reduction in the anterosuperior prominence of the area between the bottom of the incisura and the inner margin of the antihelix.
Curving course of the crus of the helix, approaching or joining the antitragus.
Small defect of the helical fold that lies at the junction of the superior and descending portions of the helix.
Small expansion of the helical fold at the junction of the superior and descending portions of the helix.
Linear, circumferential indentation in the convexity of the outer surface of the helix.
Positioning of the anterior surface of the ear lobe in a more coronal plane than the remainder of the ear.

ET: Abnormality of the urinary system physiology

DEF: The absence of a phalangeal segment of a finger.
The absence of a phalangeal segment of a toe or hallux.
Premature fusion of the metopic suture.
Unilateral atrophy of facial tissues, including muscles, bones and skin.
Unilateral atrophy of facial tissues, including muscles, bones and skin.
An abnormality involving the movement of the eye outwards.
An abnormal amount of hair.

ET: Dilated vestibule of the inner ear
DEF: Dilatation of the vestibule of the inner ear.
Increased size of the semicircular canal.

ET: Abnormality of the internal auditory canal
DEF: An abnormality of the Internal acoustic meatus, i.e., of the canal in the petrous part of the temporal bone through which the cranial nerve VII and cranial nerve VIII traverse.
Increased size of the vestibular aqueduct.
Increased size of the cochlear duct, i.e., of a duct that communicates between the perilymphatic space and the subarachnoid space, and transmits a vein from the cochlea to join the internal jugular.

ET: Functional abnormality of the inner ear
DEF: An abnormality of the function of the inner ear.
An increased consentration of zinc in the blood.
A type of rigidity in which the arms are in flexion and adduction and the legs are extended. This signifies a lesion in the cerebral white matter, internal capsules, or thalamus.
Clonus is an involuntary tendon reflex that causes repeated flexion and extension of the foot. Ankle clonus is tested by rapidly flexing the foot upward.
Clonus is an involuntary tendon reflex that causes repeated flexion and extension of the foot. Knee clonus can be tested by rapidly pushing the patella towards the toes.
A type of infection of the central nervous system that can be regarded as a sign of a pathological susceptibility to infection.

ET: Functional abnormality of the middle ear
DEF: An abnormality of the function of the middle ear.
Aplasia of the stapes.
A developmental defect in which the gallbladder fails to form.
A developmental anomaly characterized by abnormal smallness of one eye.
Abnormality of Descemet's membrane, which is the basement membrane of the corneal endothelium.
Ingrowth of new blood vessels into the cornea.
New growth of vessels on the surface of the iris.
Congenital absence of the fovea.
An abnormality of binocular vision, that is of the ability to synthesize the visual inputs from both eyes to a single image with perception of depth.
A type of retinal exudate located in the subretinal space between the sensory retina and the retinal pigment epithelium.
A type of retinal exudate located in the subretinal space between the sensory retina and the retinal pigment epithelium.
Anomalous insertion of the chordae tendinae or papillary muscles into the contralateral ventricle in the presence of a ventricular septum defect.
The left atrio-ventricular connection consists of two anatomically distinct orifices separated by accessory fibrous tissue.
Congenital defect characterized by underdevelopment of the tricuspid valve.
Displacement of the heart outside the thoracic cavity and into the abdomen.
A type of ectopia cordis with the heart partially in the cervical region and without a defect of the sternum.
Congenital malformation of the thoracic wall with partial or total displacement of the heart outside the thoracic cavity. This feature is associated with sternal cleft or absence of the sternum.
The aortic arch extends into the soft tissues of the neck before turning down into to become the descending aorta.

A conenital abnormality of the aortic arch in which the two embryonic aortc arches form a vascular ring that surrounds the trachea or esophagus and then join to form the descending aorta. Double aortic arch can cause symptoms because of compression of the esophagus (dysphagia, cyanosis while eating) or trachea (stridor).

A conenital abnormality of the aortic arch in which the two embryonic aortc arches form a vascular ring that surrounds the trachea or esophagus and then join to form the descending aorta. Double aortic arch can cause symptoms because of compression of the esophagus (dysphagia, cyanosis while eating) or trachea (stridor).
Abnormal plane of direction of the heart from the base to the apex towards the right. Left sided is normal.

Truncus arteriosus (single great artery leaving the base of the heart, giving rise to the coronary, pulmonary, and systemic arteries) whereby one of the two pulmonary artery branched does not arise from the common pulmonary trunk, but instead from the ductus arteriosus or directly from the aorta.
Non-continuity of the arch of aorta with an atretic point or absent segment.

An abnormality of the pulmonary situs, i.e., of the sidedness of the morphological right and left lungs, which is defined by characteristics such as the number of lobes per lung and the relationship of the pulmonary arteries to their bronchi.
An abnormality of the abdominal situs, i.e., of the sidedness of the abdomen and its organs.
Right pulmonary venous return to the inferior vena cava.
No pericardium around the heart, occurring as a congenital defect, not the result of a surgical pericardectomy.
The presence of both a left and a right ductus arteriosus.

Transient left ventricular apical ballooning syndrome or takotsubo cardiomyopathy is characterized by transient regional systolic dysfunction involving the left ventricular apex and/or mid-ventricle in the absence of obstructive coronary disease on coronary angiography. Patients present with an abrupt onset of angina-like chest pain, and have diffuse T-wave inversion, sometimes preceded by ST-segment elevation, and mild cardiac enzyme elevation.
Abnormal proliferation of blood vessels within the cardiac cavities attached to the endocardium.

A conduction block of the right branch of the bundle of His. This manifests as a prolongation of the QRS complex (greater than 0.12 s) with delayed activation of the right ventricle and terminal delay on the EKG.
A conduction block of the left branch of the bundle of His. This manifests as a generalized disturbance of QRS morphology on EKG.
Libman-Sacks valvular lesions are sterile fibrofibrinous vegetations that favor the left-sided heart valves and usually form on the ventricular surface of the mitral valve.
An abnormality of the pulmonary veins.
Uhl anomaly of the right ventricle refers to the almost complete absence of right ventricular myocardium, normal tricuspid valve, and preserved septal and left ventricular myocardium.
Clonus at the elbow joint, i.e., an exaggerated phasic stretch reflex characterized by repetitive, rhythmic contractions at the elbow, generated by rapid passive stretch at the elbow joint.
Any structural anomaly of the adrenal glands.
A functional abnormality of the adrenal glands.

A solid, low grade, spindle cell, glial neoplasm of adults that originates in the neurohypophysis or infundibulum. Clinical signs and symptoms include visual disturbance, headache and features of hypopituitarism. Pituicytomas are well-circumscribed, solid masses that can measure up to several centimeters. Histologically, they show a compact architecture consisting of elongate, bipolar spindle cells arranged in interlacing fascicles or assuming a storiform pattern.
Presence of persistent islands of renal blastema in the postnatal kidney, anywhere within a renal lobe (a portion of a kidney consisting of a renal pyramid and the renal cortex above it).
Abnormally persistent foci of embryonal immature blastema located in the superficial cortical region (perilobar).
A renal tumor originating from an oncocyte, which is an epithelial cell characterized by an excessive amount of mitochondria, resulting in an abundant acidophilic, granular cytoplasm.
Posterior positions and/or vertical shortening of the infraorbital and perialar regions, or increased concavity of the face and/or reduced nasolabial angle.
A functional abnormality of a skeletal muscle.
A structural abnormality of a skeletal muscle.

A reduced ability to distinguish tactile sensations at points that are very close to one another. This can be tested by using special calipers whose points can be set from 2mm to several centimeters apart.
An abnormality of one or more of the set of bones that make up the facial skeleton.
Prominence of a triangular soft tissue area of the philtrum with the apex to the columella.
Abnormality of the oral mucosa.
Nasal tip positioned to one side of the midline.
A noninflammatory, progressive occlusion of the intracranial carotid arteries owing to the formation of netlike collateral arteries arising from the circle of Willis.
Delayed maturation and calcification of the talus.
Any anomaly in the formation of bone or of a bony substance, or the conversion of fibrous tissue or of cartilage into bone or a bony substance.
A type of keratitis characterized by inflammation in pinpoint areas of the corneal epithelium.
Any anomaly in the formation of the bony substance of the sternum.

ET: Abnormality of the wing of the ilium
DEF: An anomaly of the ilium ala. This is the large expanded portion of the ilum which bounds the greater pelvis laterally.
Hemorrhage from the vessels of the choroid.
Increased number of neutrophils circulating in blood.

JT: 低フィブリノーゲン血症
DEF: Decreased concentration of fibrinogen in the blood.
Abnormal calcification in the cardiovascular system.
Atrophy of the extensor digitorum longus muscles, which mediate extension of the toes.
Developmental hypoplasia (shortening) of proximal phalanx of toe.

An anomaly of the cerebellar peduncles. The superior, middle, and inferior cerebellar peduncles emerge from the cerebellum. The superior cerebellar penduncles connect the cerebellum to the midbrain, the middle cerebellar peduncles connect the cerebellum to the pons, and the inferior cerebellar peduncle connects the medulla spinalis and medulla oblongata with the cerebellum.
Increased length of the superior cerebellar peduncle.
Abnormal outpouching or sac-like dilatation in the wall of the inferior mesenteric artery or superior mesenteric artery .
Decreased concentration of urate in the urine.
A type of vasculitis (inflammation of blood vessel walls) that affects blood vessels that are smaller than arteries, i.e., arterioles, venules, and capilllaries.
Lung parenchymal involvement with lymphoma.
Focal proliferation of glial cells in the substantia nigra.
Impaired ability to eat related to problems gathering food and getting ready to suck, chew, or swallow it.
Abnormally low glucose concentration in the cerebrospinal fluid.
Repeated episodes of sudden-onset and transient lethargy.
Gallstones composed primarily of bilirubin and calcium salts (calcium bilirubinate) with a low cholesterol concentration.
A type of pigment gallstone that is hard and black, containing calcium carbonate and calcium phosphates.
A type of pigment gallstone that is brown, containing calcium fatty acids. These stones are softer than black pigment gallstones.
Affective, mnemonic or composite perceptual auras with subjective qualities similar to those experienced in life but are recognized by the subject as occurring outside of actual context.
Auras which reflect ictal dysmnesia such as: feelings as familiarity (deja-vu) and unfamiliarity (jamais-vu).
Presence of a lipoma in the region of the sacrum.
Rhythmic, involuntary sinusoidal oscillations of one or both eyes. The waveform of pendular nystagmus may occur in any direction.
Rhythmic, involuntary sinusoidal oscillations of one or both eyes. The waveform of pendular nystagmus may occur in any direction.

Seesaw nystagmus is a type of pendular nystagmus where a half cycle consists of the elevation and intorsion of one eye, concurrently with the depression and extortion of the fellow eye. In the other half cycle, there is an inversion of the ocular movements.

A form of focal dystonia that affects the vocal cords, associated with involuntary contractions of the vocal cords causing interruptions of speech and affecting the voice quality and often leading to patterned, repeated breaks in speech.
Hypoglycermia following a meal (or more generally, after intake of glucose).

Malignant tumor of melanocytes of the choroid. The classic appearance of choroidal melanoma is a pigmented dome-shaped or collar button-shaped tumor with an associated exudative retinal detachment. Choroidal melanoma is usually pigmented, but can be variably pigmented and even amelanotic (non-pigmented).

Malignant tumor of melanocytes of the choroid. The classic appearance of choroidal melanoma is a pigmented dome-shaped or collar button-shaped tumor with an associated exudative retinal detachment. Choroidal melanoma is usually pigmented, but can be variably pigmented and even amelanotic (non-pigmented).
Malignant tumor of melanocytes of the ciliary body.
The presence of a melanoma of the skin.
A type of melanoma that starts as a raised area that is usually dark blackish-blue or bluish-red but may not have any color.
Radiographic features include a dilated, radiolucent lesion typically located eccentrically within the metaphyseal portion of the bone, with fluid levels visible on magnetic resonance imaging.
A benign fluid filled simple cyst of bone filled with serous fluid.
Increased excretion of glycopeptides in the urine. Glycopeptides are peptides with carbohydrate moieties covalently attached to the side chains of the amino acid residues.
An anomaly of the function of the pancreas.
Inflammation of the uveal tract in which inflammation affects the anterior chamber, vitreous, retina or choroid.
Increased concentration of uracil in the urine.
Decreased number of granulocyte precursors in the bone marrow.
Splitting of the retinal layers in the macula.
Reduced ability of the cornea to respond to stimulation.
A separation (dissection) of the layers of the internal carotid artery wall.
A separation (dissection) of the layers of the external carotid artery wall.
A separation (dissection) of the layers of the common carotid artery wall.
A clinical sign indicating a lapse of posture and is usually manifest by a bilateral flapping tremor at the wrist, metacarpophalangeal, and hip joints.
Malfunction of a peripheral nerve resulting from mechanical compression of the nerve roots from internal or external causes and leading to a conduction block or axonal loss.
Uneven rhythm of breathing.
A type of headache characterized by repeated attacks of unilateral pain lasting 15 to 180 minutes and associated with local autonomic signs.
An anomaly of the mobility of ejaculated sperm.
An abnormal reduction in the mobility of ejaculated sperm.
A type of blistering that affects the skin of the tibial region.
Narrowing of the urethra associated with inflammation or scar tissue.
An increased white blood cell count in the cerebrospinal fluid.
A structural or developmental anomaly of any of the tissues involved in the genital system.
Anosmia for one particular odor.
A deviation from the normally well coordinated pattern of intracellular and intercellular synchrony of motile cilia. Dyskinetic cilia usually beat out of synchrony relative to neighboring cilia.
A liposarcoma that contains myxomatous tissue.
Reduced concentration of serine in the blood.
A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the head and neck region with origin in the lip, oral cavity, nasal cavity, paranasal sinuses, pharynx, or larynx.
An abnormal pigmentation pattern of the external genitalia.
Abnormality of the occipital bone of the skull.
Increased length of the middle phalanx of finger.
Increased length of the distal phalanx of finger.
An anomaly of the process of rib bone formation.

An anomaly in the number of monocytes, which are myeloid mononuclear recirculating leukocyte that can act as a precursor of tissue macrophages, osteoclasts and some populations of tissue dendritic cells.
Lack of skin pigmentation (coloring) of the abdomen.
Lack of skin pigmentation (coloring) of the arms and legs.
A leukemia that originates from a myeloid cell, that is the blood forming cells of the bone marrow.
Compression of the celiac artery.

Abnormally anterior positioning of the infraorbital and perialar regions, or increased convexity of the face, or increased nasolabial angle. The midface includes the maxilla, the cheeks, the zygomas, and the infraorbital and perialar regions of the face
A structural anomaly of the globe of the eye, or bulbus oculi.
A functional anomaly of the eye.
Inflammation of the large airways of the lung with rapid onset and short course usually associated with cough, mucus production, shortness of breath, wheezing, and chest tightness.
Reduced intensity of muscle tendon reflexes in the upper limbs. Reflexes are elicited by stretching the tendon of a muscle, e.g., by tapping.
Reduced intensity of muscle tendon reflexes in jaw.
A motility disorder characterized by biliary colic in the absence of gallstones with a reduced gallbladder ejection fraction.
A lower than normal concentration of citrate(3-) in the urine.
A greater than normal concentration of citrate(3-) in the urine.
The onset of growth of pubic hair at an earlier age than normal.
The presence of a V-shaped indentation (notch) in the primary central incisor.
Wasting or decrease in size of all or part of the duodenum.
An inflammation of the choroid and retina.
A structural abnormality of the brain, which has as its parts the forebrain, midbrain, and hindbrain.
Delayed myelination.
Constipation of sudden onset and lasting for less than three months.
A feeling of uneasiness and restlessness in the legs after going to bed (sometimes causing insomnia).
Infantile spasms represent a subset of \
Narrowing or constriction of the inner surface (lumen) of a cerebral artery.
Narrowing or constriction of the inner surface (lumen) of the middle cerebral artery.
An abnormally decreased size of the pituitary gland.
An increased amount of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) in the subarachnoid space.
An anomaly of the circle of Willis, also known as the cerebral arterial circle.
Congenital absence of the optic nerve.

A form of telangiectasis characterized by a central elevated red dot the size of a pinhead, representing an arteriole, with numerous small blood vessels that radiate out thereby resembling the legs of a spider. Characteristically, compression of the central arteriole causes the entire lesion to blanch, and the lesion quickly refills once the compression is released.
A detrimental reaction to the presence of gluten in food, which may include abdominal pain, fatigue, headaches and paresthesia, or celiac disease.
An epidermoid cyst in the armpit.
A thumbnail that is diminished in length and width, i.e., underdeveloped thumb nail.
Edema in the region of the Lower eyelid.
A structural anomaly of the nephron.
A two-sided form of atrophy of the kidney.
Increased concentration of albumin in the urine.
Mildly increased levels of protein in the urine (150-500 mg per day in adults).
Moderately increased levels of protein in the urine (500-1000 mg per day in adults).
Severely increased levels of protein in the urine (1000-3000 mg per day in adults).
An decreased concentration of chloride in the urine.
Elevated concentration of urate in the urine.
An anomalous finding in the examination of the urine for cells.
Presence of leukocyte casts (cylindrical structures produced by the kidney in certain disease states) in the urine.
Presence of erythrocyte casts (cylindrical structures produced by the kidney in certain disease states) in the urine.
A developmental anomaly associated with the failure of rectum, vagina, and bladder to separate.

An anomaly of the trabecular meshwork, which is the porelike structure surrounding the entire circumference of the anterior chamber at the base of the cornea and near the ciliary body. The trabecular mesh work is responsible for draining the aqueous humor into the canal of Schlemm.
Reduction in the amount of blood flow to the iris.
Blockage of the retinal vein.
A reduction of the pressure inside the cranium (skull) and thereby in the brain tissue and cerebrospinal fluid.
Decreased amount of pigmentation in the fovea centralis.
Increase in size of a peripheral nerve. This finding can be appreciated by palpation along the axis of the nerve.
An abnormal reduction in the inflammatory response to injury or infection.
A abnormal increase in the inflammatory response to injury or infection.
Severe asthma unresponsive to repeated courses of beta-agonist therapy such as inhaled albuterol, levalbuterol, or subcutaneous epinephrine.
A diminution of the volumetric fraction of blood pumped out of the ventricle with each cardiac cycle.
Akinetic mutism is essentially characterized by a total absence of spontaneous behavior and speech occurring in the presence of preserved visual tracking.
A failure to develop of the upper vagina.
A failure to develop of the lower part of the vagina.
An anomalous build up of iron (Fe) in the substantia nigra.
Accumulation of calcium salts in the pineal gland.
An abnormal reduction in the quantity of three-dimensional space taken up by the pineal gland.
An abnormal elevation in the quantity of three-dimensional space taken up by the pineal gland.
Failure to develop of the pineal gland, defined clinically as the absence of the pineal gland with no indication of the pineal gland even having been present.
A reduction in the quantity of space occupied by the thalamus.
Decreased size of the basal ganglia.
Focal proliferation of glial cells in the cerebellum.
Focal proliferation of glial cells in the cerebellum.
A structural abnormality of a diaphysis of the leg.
The presence of a moderate form of hearing impairment.
A severe form of conductive hearing impairment.
Disturbance in the atrial activation that is caused by transient failure of impulse conduction from the sinoatrial node to the cardiac atria.
Edema in the region of the upper eyelid.

A soft tissue continuity in the A/P axis between two digits that extends distally to at least the level of the proximal interphalangeal joints, or a soft tissue continuity in the A/P axis between two digits that lies significantly distal to the flexion crease that overlies the metacarpophalangeal or metatarsophalangeal joint of the adjacent digits.
An abnormal localized widening (dilatation) of the thoracic aorta.
An abnormality of the anus or rectum.
A discrete abnormal tissue mass that protrudes into the lumen of the small intestine and is attached to the intestinal wall either by a stalk, pedunculus, or a broad base.
Agenesis of canine tooth.
Failure of the femur to develop.
Abnormal increase in size of the brainstem.
A deviation from normal of the neurological development of a child, which may include any or all of the aspects of the development of personal, social, gross or fine motor, and cognitive abilities.
A developmental anomaly in which the mastoid process fails to form and is thus found to be congenitally absent.
The presence of atrophy (wasting) of the cerebral white matter.
A sudden attack of dyspnea that occurs while the affected person is at rest.

Increased length of the arm span (length from one end of an individual's arms measured at the fingertips to the other when raised parallel to the ground at shoulder height at a one-hundred eighty degree angle).
A structural anomaly of the ciliary body.
Repeated infections of the urinary bladder.
Repeated infections of the urinary bladder.
An anomaly in the process of intramembranous ossification by which flat bones (cranial bones of the skull, i.e., the frontal, parietal, occipital, and temporal bones, and the clavicles) are formed.
A kinked appearance of the brainstem, i.e., an exaggerated flexure.
A cranial suture that is in addition to canonical membrane-covered openings in the incompletely ossified skull of the fetus or newborn infant.
Disruption of the epithelial layer of the cornea with involvement of the underlying stroma.
Transmission of light through the iris as visualized upon slit lamp examination or infrared iris transillumination videography. The light passes through defects in the pigmentation of the iris.
An anomaly of the nasal base, which can be conceived of as an imaginary line between the most lateral points of the external inferior attachments of the alae nasi to the face.
Increased distance between the attachments of the alae nasi to the face.
The presence of an increased number of twists and turns of the retinal blood vessels.
Presence of a unitary trichilemmoma, a benign tumour originating from the outer root sheath of the hair follicle.

Abnormal small intestinal contractions, such as spasms and intestinal paralysis related to the loss of the ability of the gut to coordinate muscular activity because of endogenous or exogenous causes.
Hypospadias with location of the urethral meatus in the scrotum.
Hypospadias with location of the urethral meatus in the middle of the inferior shaft of the penis.
Increased pigmentation (skin color) of the scrotum.
Anomaly of the folded ridges (wrinkles) of skin of the scrotum.
Increased number or density of the folded ridges (wrinkles) of skin of the scrotum.
Decreased number or density of the folded ridges (wrinkles) of skin of the scrotum.
A structural anomaly of sperm.
A structural abnormality of the sperm head.
A structural abnormality of the sperm neck.
A structural abnormality of the sperm neck.
A structural abnormality of the sperm mid-piece.
A structural abnormality of the sperm tail.
A structural abnormality of the sperm tail.
An anomaly of the neck of the uterus (lower part of the uterus), called the uterine cervix.
Muscle hypertrophy affecting the paraspinal muscles.
Muscle hypertrophy affecting the scapular muscles.
Slowed relaxation of muscles in the face.
A Malignant mesothelioma originating from cells of the pericardium (the thin layer of mesothelium lining the heart).

Folds of membranous tissue (peritoneum, mesothelium) attached to the wall of the abdomen and enclosing viscera. Examples include the mesentery for the small intestine; the transverse mesocolon, which attaches the transverse portion of the colon to the back wall of the abdomen; and the mesosigmoid, which enfolds the sigmoid portion of the colon. Cells of the same embryologic origin also surround the other organs of the body such as the lungs (pleura) or the heart (pericardium).
A cataract that affects the capsule of the lens.

A form of hypersociability that presents as mostly inappropriate people-orientation and friendliness towards others on an inadequate level which might go as far as being dangerous considering for example young children following strangers without restriction.
Mislocalised thyroid gland.
A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the thyroid gland.
Movement-based tics affecting discrete muscle groups.
Fragmented appearance of the epiphyses.

ET: Enlarged epiphysis of the proximal phalanx of the 4th toe
Irregular epiphysis of the proximal phalanx of the 4th toe
Synostosis involving bones of the upper limbs
DEF: An abnormal union between bones or parts of bones of the upper limbs.
The abnormal fusion of neighboring bones across a joint.

Hemiballismus is a rare movement disorder that is caused primarily by damage to various areas in the basal ganglia. Hemiballismus is usually characterized by involuntary flinging motions of the extremities. The movements are often violent and have wide amplitudes of motion. They are continuous and random and can involve proximal and/or distal muscles on one side of the body, while some cases even include the facial muscles. The more a patient is active, the more the movements increase. With relaxation comes a decrease in movements.
The presence of dysplastic regions in metaphyseal regions.
Depression located paramedially on the vermilion of a lip.
Hyponasal speech is when there is an abnormally reduced nasal airflow during speech often in a setting of nasal obstruction or congestion.

A chronic inflammatory bowel disease that includes characteristic ulcers, or open sores, in the colon. The main symptom of active disease is usually constant diarrhea mixed with blood, of gradual onset and intermittent periods of exacerbated symptoms contrasting with periods that are relatively symptom-free. In contrast to Crohn's disease this special form of colitis begins in the distal parts of the rectum, spreads continually upwards and affects only mucose and submucose tissue of the colon.

A chronic inflammatory bowel disease that includes characteristic ulcers, or open sores, in the colon. The main symptom of active disease is usually constant diarrhea mixed with blood, of gradual onset and intermittent periods of exacerbated symptoms contrasting with periods that are relatively symptom-free. In contrast to Crohn's disease this special form of colitis begins in the distal parts of the rectum, spreads continually upwards and affects only mucose and submucose tissue of the colon.
Bands of scar-like tisssue that hve formed within a cerebral ventricle.
The presence of a germ cell tumor of the cerebrum.
The presence of a germ cell tumor of the cerebrum.

Cerebral inflammation involving a granulomatous response, i.e., a non-specific inflammatory response involving granulomas, defined as a compact organized collection of mature mononuclear phagocytes including epithelioid and giant cells.
Presence of abundant argyrophilic grains and coiled bodies on microscopic examination of brain tissue.
An abnormality of the dentate nucleus.
A non-midline cleft of the upper lip on one side only.
Clefting of the upper lip affecting the lateral portions of the upper lip rather than the midline/median region.
A non-midline cleft of the upper lip on the left and right sides.
Nonmidline cleft palate on the left and right sides.

ET: Contractures of the joints of the upper limbs

DEF: Edema affecting the region situated around the orbit of the eye.
A hernia which occurs just below the inguinal ligament, where abdominal contents pass through a naturally occurring weakness called the femoral canal.
A growth pattern that displays an abnormal difference between the left and the right side.
A tumor formed from the endocrine (argentaffin) cells of the mucosal lining of a variety of organs including the stomach and intestine. These cells are from neuroectodermal origin.
A fibrous cardiac diverticulum refers to an aneurysm and usually appears as an isolated congenital anomaly.
A transient visual disturbance that is typically caused by a circulatory, ocular or neurological underlying condition.

Polypoidal masses arising mainly from the mucous membranes of the nose and paranasal sinuses. They are freely movable and nontender overgrowths of the mucosa that frequently accompany allergic rhinitis.
The presence of a fistula affecting the genitourinary system.
The presence of a fistula affecting the genitourinary system.
The presence of an abscess of the peritoneum.
A partial or complete positional exchange between the penis and the scrotum, with positioning of the scrotum superior to the penis.
A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the respiratory system.
Bleeding at irregular intervals.
Neoplasm involving odontogenic cells, an odontogenic tumor.
The presence of a seminoma, an undifferentiated germ cell tumor of the testis.
A rare paranglioma of the lung, tumors that arise from extra-adrenal chromaffin cells.
A movement disorder which consists of effects including diminished voluntary movements and the presence of involuntary movements.
Varicosity of veins in the vulval region.
The presence of an increased degree of wrinkling (irregular folds and indentations) of the skin as compared with age-related norms.
A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of a salivary gland.
A form of malignant cancer of the connective tissue surrounding nerves. Given its origin and behavior, it is classified as a sarcoma.
An abnormality of the Arachnoid mater.
An abnormality of coagulation associated with an increased risk of thrombosis.
An abnormality of the soft palate.
Formation of abnormal lobules (small masses of tissue) in the liver.
An increased susceptibility to pharyngitis as manifested by a history of recurrent pharyngitis.
The loss of intercellular connections, such as desmosomes, resulting in loss of cohesion between keratinocytes.
Aplasia of the pancreas.
An abnormality of the region around the nails of the fingers or toes.
Testicular torsion is when the spermatic cord to a testicle twists, cutting off the blood supply. The most common symptom is acute testicular pain.
An abnormal connection between the gut and another hollow organ, such as the bladder, urethra, vagina, or other regions of the gastrointestinal tract.

JT: アナフィラキシーショック
DEF: An acute hypersensitivity reaction due to exposure to a previously encountered antigen.
Underdevelopment of the areola, the circular area of pigmented skin surrounding the nipple.
Hypoplasia of the triceps muscle.
Decreased ossification of the vertebral bodies.
An abnormally flat sella turcica.
An abnormally short femoral neck (which is the process of bone, connecting the femoral head with the femoral shaft).
The narrowing or partial blockage of a portion of the duodenum.
Cystic, urine-containing intrarenal cavities lined with transitional cell epithelium that communicate through a narrow channel with the collecting system.
A rare, benign soft tissue tumor that typically occurs within the first two years of life.
Hamartoma-like growth in the placenta consisting of blood vessels.
An abnormality in the placement of the ocular globe (eyeball).
An abnormality of the Common bile duct, a tube-like anatomic structure in the human gastrointestinal tract, formed by the union of the Common hepatic duct and the Cystic duct from the gall bladder.
An elevation in bone density in one or more phalanges of the toes. Sclerosis is normally detected on a radiograph as an area of increased opacity.
The presence of multiple polyps in the intestine.
A diffuse, non-pitting edema and thickening of the skin usually on the anterior aspect of the lower legs spreading to the dorsum of the feet.
Blisters arising in the mouth.
Lack of skin pigmentation (coloring).
An abnormality of a mandibular ramus.
An abnormality of a mentalis muscle.
An abnormality of the styloglossus muscle.
An abnormality of a temporalis muscle.
An abnormality of a zygomaticus major muscle.
An abnormality of a buccal mucosa.
An abnormality of an ethmoid sinus.
Any structural abnormality of a jugular vein.

A structural anomaly of the hypopharyx, which is the most inferior portion of the pharynx. The hypopharynx continues from the oropharynx at the pharyngoepiglottic fold superiorly and extends inferiorly to the level of the inferior aspect of the cricoid cartilage, which marks the beginning of the cervical esophagus.
An abnormality of a lacrimal artery.
Any structural abnormality of a lingual artery.
Any structural anomaly of a lingual nerve.
An abnormality of a lingual tonsil.
An abnormality of a mandible condylar process.
Inability to completely empty the urinary bladder during the process of urination.
Difficulty in beginning the process of urination.
Decreased functionality of the male gonad, i.e., of the testis, with reduced spermatogenesis or testosterone synthesis.
The presence of a stenotic, i.e., constricted ureter.
A congenital anomaly of the urinary tract, in which the kidney is duplicated and is drained via two separate renal pelves and ureters.
The presence of a leiomyoma of the uterus.

Cleft of the soft palate (also known as the velum, or muscular palate) as a result of a developmental defect occurring between the 7th and 12th week of pregnancy. Cleft soft palate can cause functional abnormalities of the Eustachian tube with resulting middle ear anomalies and hearing difficulties, as well as speech problems associated with hypernasal speech due to velopharyngeal insufficiency.
Hemorrhage affecting the gingiva.

In newborns, the two frontal bones, two parietal bones, and one occipital bone are joined by fibrous sutures, which form a small posterior fontanelle, and a larger, diamond-shaped anterior fontanelle. These regions allow for the skull to pass the birth canal and for later growth. The fontanelles gradually ossify, whereby the posterior fontanelle usually closes by eight weeks and the anterior fontanelle by the 9th to 16th month of age. Large fontanelles are diagnosed if the fontanelles are larger than age-dependent norms.
Asymmetry of the bones of the skull.
Increased convexity of the occiput (posterior part of the skull).
A form of developmental hypoplasia of the mandible in which the mandible is mislocalised posteriorly.
Hemangioma, a benign tumor of the vascular endothelial cells, occurring in the face.
Coarse facial features reminiscent of those of a boxer.
Frontal hairline with bilateral arcs to a low point in the midline of the forehead.
Increased thickness of the helix of the ear.
Increased breadth of the nasal bridge (and with it, the nasal root).

Visual impairment (or vision impairment) is vision loss (of a person) to such a degree as to qualify as an additional support need through a significant limitation of visual capability resulting from either disease, trauma, or congenital or degenerative conditions that cannot be corrected by conventional means, such as refractive correction, medication, or surgery.
Apparent optic disc swelling in the absence of increased intracranial pressure.
A pale yellow discoloration of the optic disk (the area of the optic nerve head in the retina). The optic disc normally has a pinkish hue with a central yellowish depression.

Retinal dystrophy is an abnormality of the retina associated with a hereditary process. Retinal dystrophies are defined by their predominantly monogenic inheritance and they are frequently associated with loss or dysfunction of photoreceptor cells as a primary or secondary event.

A creamy appearance of the retinal blood vessels that occurs when the concentration of lipids in the blood are extremely increased, with pale pink to milky white retinal vessels and altered pale reflexes from choroidal vasculature.
Persistent deficits in social interaction and communication and interaction as well as a markedly restricted repertoire of activity and interest as well as repetitive patterns of behavior.
The presence of a bicornuate uterus.
A group of abnormalities characterized by hyperglycemia and glucose intolerance.
Malformation of the rib cage.

Radiographic evidence of articular calcification that represent calcium pyrophosphate depositions in soft tissue surrounding joints and at the insertions of tendons near joints (Entheses/Sharpey fibers) .
Cafe-au-lait spots are hyperpigmented lesions that can vary in color from light brown to dark brown with smooth borders and having a size of 1.5 cm or more in adults and 0.5 cm or more in children.
A oval and round, colored (usually medium-to dark brown, reddish brown, or flesh colored) lesion. Typically, a melanocytic nevus is less than 6 mm in diameter, but may be much smaller or larger.

JT: 柔らかいパン生地様の皮膚
DEF: A skin texture that is unusually soft (and may feel silky), and has a malleable consistency resembling that of dough.

Atopic dermatitis (AD) or atopic eczema is an itchy, inflammatory skin condition with a predilection for the skin flexures. It is characterized by poorly defined erythema with edema, vesicles, and weeping in the acute stage and skin thickening (lichenification) in the chronic stage.
Presence of a cutaneous membrane (flap) in the armpit.
A type of cataract that is not apparent at birth but that arises in childhood or adolescence.
An abnormality of the cornea that is characterized by opacity of one or parts of the cornea.
A benign tumor typically found at the junction of the cornea and sclera (limbal epibullar dermoid).
A developmental defect resulting in the presence of fewer than the normal number of fingers.
Abnormally broad metacarpal bones.

Absence of the corpus callosum as a result of the failure of the corpus callosum to develop, which can be the result of a failure in any one of the multiple steps of callosal development including cellular proliferation and migration, axonal growth or glial patterning at the midline.
Holoprosencephaly is a structural anomaly of the brain in which the developing forebrain fails to divide into two separate hemispheres and ventricles.
Displacement or malalignment of joints.
Steatosis is a term used to denote lipid accumulation within hepatocytes.

The presence of genetically distinct populations of somatic cells in a given organism caused by DNA mutations, epigenetic alterations of DNA, chromosomal abnormalities or the spontaneous reversion of inherited mutations.
Osteolysis affecting carpal bones.
Failure to thrive (FTT) refers to a child whose physical growth is substantially below the norm.
A narrowing of the right ventricular outflow tract that can occur at the pulmonary valve (valvular stenosis) or just below the pulmonary valve (infundibular stenosis).
Increased time between the start of the Q wave and the end of the T wave as measured by the electrocardiogram (EKG).
Bradycardia related to a mean resting sinus rate of less than 50 beats per minute.
Reduced ability to pass air through the nasal cavity often leading to mouth breathing.
An abnormality of the birth process.
Absence of a fingernail.
A developmental defect resulting in the presence of fewer than the normal number of toes.
An abnormal susceptibility to bleeding, often referred to as a bleeding diathesis. A bleeding diathesis may be related to vascular, platelet and coagulation defects.
A reduced number of reticulocytes in the peripheral blood.
A kind of anemia in which the volume of the red blood cells is normal.

A form of amyloidosis that affects the kidney. On hematoxylin and eosin stain, amyloid is identified as extracellular amorphous material that is lightly eosinophilic. These deposits often stain weakly for periodic acid Schiff (PAS), demonstrate a blue-to-gray hue on the trichrome stain and are typically negative on the Jones methenamine silver (JMS) stain. These tinctorial properties contrast with the histologic appearance of collagen, a major component of basement membranes, mesangial matrix and areas of sclerosis, which demonstrates strong positivity for PAS and JMS (See Figure 1 of PMID:25852856).
A kind of anemia in which the volume of the red blood cells is reduced.
A type of anemia characterized by increased size of erythrocytes with increased mean corpuscular volume (MCV) and increased mean corpuscular hemoglobin (MCH).
Progressive loss of neural cells and tissue.
Decreased number of hairs per unit area of skin of the scalp.
Hair whose growth is slower than normal.
Reduced number or density of pubic hair.
An impairment of memory as manifested by a reduced ability to remember things such as dates and names, and increased forgetfulness.

An abnormality of sleep including such phenomena as 1) insomnia/hypersomnia, 2) non-restorative sleep, 3) sleep schedule disorder, 4) excessive daytime somnolence, 5) sleep apnea, and 6) restlessness.

A type of rigidity in which a muscle responds with cogwheellike jerks to the use of constant force in bending the limb (i.e., it gives way in little, repeated jerks when the muscle is passively stretched).
Difficulty to maintain correct position of the head while standing or sitting.

A degenerative disease of the brain characterized by the insidious onset of dementia. Impairment of memory, judgment, attention span, and problem solving skills are followed by severe apraxia and a global loss of cognitive abilities. The condition primarily occurs after age 60, and is marked pathologically by severe cortical atrophy and the triad of senile plaques, neurofibrillary tangles, and neuropil threads.
Incapability to ambulate.
Absence of pubic hair.
Paroxysmal, recurrent episodes of vomiting.
Progressive destruction of the small-to-medium bile ducts of the intrahepatic biliary tree, which leads to progressive cholestasis and often end-stage liver disease.
Abnormality of the absorption of fat from the gastrointestinal tract.
Aortic dissection refers to a tear in the intimal layer of the aorta causing a separation between the intima and the medial layers of the aorta.
The presence of symmetrical and circular openings (foramina) in the parietal bone ranging in size from a few millimeters to several centimeters wide.
Eversion of the posterior bladder wall through the congenitally absent lower anterior abdominal wall and anterior bladder wall.
The presence of a carcinoma of the urinary bladder.
The presence of a carcinoma of the thyroid gland.
A benign epithelial tumor derived from intrinsic cells of the adenohypophysis.
An abnormally increased phosphate concentration in the blood.
Over curvature of the thoracic region, leading to a round back or if sever to a hump.
Exaggerated convexity of the cervical vertebral column, causing the cervical spine to bow outwards and take on a rounded appearance.
A morphological abnormality of epiphyses whereby they are abnormally outwardly curving (protuberant).
The presence of a splayed (i.e.,flared) metaphyseal segment of one or more long bones.
Dislocation of the distal humerus out of the elbow joint, where the radius, ulna, and humerus meet.

JT: ヒドロキシプロリン尿
DEF: An increased concentration of 4-hydroxy-L-proline in the urine.
Reduced diameter of a long bone.
An increased excretion of phosphates in the urine.
An increased concentration of glutaric acid in the urine.
Underdevelopment of the breast.
It is characterized by one or more symptoms including sneezing, itching, nasal congestion, and rhinorrhea.
An increased concentration of glutamine in the blood.

JT: ヒドロキシプロリン血症
DEF: An increased concentration of hydroxyproline in the blood.
An increased concentration of threonine in the urine.
Complete bilateral fractures of the pars interarticularis resulting in the anterior slippage of the vertebra.
A partial dislocation of the atlantoaxial joints.
An increased concentration of threonine in the blood.
Increased susceptibility to fatigue.

Upturning of the big toe (and sometimes fanning of the other toes) in response to stimulation of the sole of the foot. If the Babinski sign is present it can indicate damage to the corticospinal tract.
An increased concentration of glutaric acid in the blood.
Increased concentration of trimethylamine in the urine.
A decreased concentration of methionine in the blood.
Muscular atrophy affecting muscles in the distal portions of the extremities.
Muscle hypertrophy affecting the thighs.
A body habitus that is tall, slim and underweight, with long legs and long arms (i.e., arm span exceeds height by 5 cm or more).

JT: ミニコア(マルチコア)ミオパチー
DEF: Multiple small zones of sarcomeric disorganization and lack of oxidative activity (known as minicores) in muscle fibers.
Death of the fetus in utero after at least 20 weeks of gestation.

Presence of more than one exostosis originating in one or noth humerus bones. An exostosis is a benign growth the projects outward from the bone surface. It is capped by cartilage, and arises from a bone that develops from cartilage.
Abnormal formation of new bone on the surface of a bone of the hand.
Benign congenital lesion of the postauricular soft tissue consisting of a blind-ending narrow tube or pit.

An abnormality of head shape characterized by the presence of a short, wide head as well as a pointy or conical form of the top of the head owing to premature closure of the coronal and lambdoid sutures.
An abnormality of the normal developmental rotation of the kidney leading to an abnormal orientation of the kidney.
An abdominal hernia that occurs at a site of weakness in the abdominal wall resulting from an incompletely-healed surgical wound.
Formation of a blood clot (thrombus) inside a vein, causing the obstruction of blood flow.
The presence of a localized dilatation or ballooning of a cerebral artery.
Bony outgrowths that extend laterally from the margin of the metaphysis.
Underdevelopment of the colon.
A chronic form of gastritis.
Lack of detectible CD8-positive T cells
Anemia characterized by abnormal intracellular inclusions, composed of denatured hemoglobin, found on the membrane of red blood cells.
Anemia characterized by abnormal intracellular inclusions, composed of denatured hemoglobin, found on the membrane of red blood cells.

A malignant lymphocytic neoplasm of B-cell or T-cell lineage involving primarily the bone marrow and the peripheral blood. This category includes precursor or acute lymphoblastic leukemias and chronic leukemias.
Webbing or fusion of the fingers, involving soft parts only or including bone structure. Bony fusions are referred to as \
Reduced number of beta cells in the pancreatic islets of Langerhans.
Shortening of the legs related to developmental hypoplasia of the bones of the leg.
A chronic loss of ankle joint motion due to structural changes in muscle, tendons, ligaments, or skin that prevent normal movement of the joints of the ankle.
A bending or abnormal curvature affecting a long bone of the arm.
An abnormal high-pitched noisy sound, occurring during inhalation or exhalation caused by the incomplete obstruction in the throat.
Abnormal tortuous (i.e., twisted) form of the aorta.
A loss of myelin from nerve fibers in the central nervous system.
Generalized abnormal accumulation of fluid beneath the skin, or in one or more cavities of the body.
A type of cataract with punctate opacities of the lens.
A unilateral form of ptosis.
Abnormal (non-physiological) constriction of the pupil of congenital onset.
Macular dystrophy is a nonspecific term for premature retinal cell aging and cell death, generally confied to the macula in which no clear extrinsic cause is evident.
Ocular abnormality characterised by premature degeneration of the vitreous and the retina that may be associated with increased risk of retinal detachment.
A congenital cataract in which opacity is limited to layers of the lens external to the nucleus (i.e., the perinuclear region), i.e., between the nuclear and cortical layers of the lens.
The presence of developmental dysplasia of the retina.

Cerulean cataracts are a kind of congenital cataract having peripheral bluish and white opacifications in concentric layers with occasional central lesions arranged radially. Although the opacities may be observed during fetal development and childhood, usually visual acuity is only mildly reduced until adulthood, when lens extraction is generally necessary.
Osteolysis affecting the talus.

Abnormal plantar flexion of the calcaneus relative to the longitudinal axis of the tibia. This results in the angle between the long axis of the tibia and the long axis of the heel bone (calcaneus) being greater than 90 degrees.
An enlargement of the thyroid gland with congenital onset.
Synostosis (bony fusion) involving one or more bones of the tarsus (calcaneus, talus, cuboid, navicular, cuneiiform bones).
Longitudinal, linear prominences in the fingernail plate.
An abnormal shape of the vertebral bodies whereby the vertebral bodies are thick on one side and taper to a thin edge at the other.
Any abnormality of the atlas and the axis.

A developmental defect of the sacrum characterized by partial or disordered development of the sacrum in which portions of the sacrum, which normally is formed by fusion of five sacral vertebrae S1-S5, fail to form or fail to form normally.
A partial dislocation of the intervertebral joint between the second and third cervical vertebrae.
Underdevelopment of the helix that either affects the entire helix, or is localized.
Abnormal narrowing of the urethra.
Congenital absence of the lumen of the larynx.
Increased size of the ilium ala.
A hamartoma (a benign, focal malformation consisting of a disorganized mixture of cells and tissues) of the retina.
Synostosis (bony fusion) involving one or more bones of the carpus (scaphoid, lunate, triquetrum, trapezium, trapezoid, capitate, hamate, pisiform).

Chilblains, also called perniosis, are an inflammatory skin condition related to an abnormal vascular response to the cold. We are unaware of a reliable estimate of incidence. It typically presents as tender, pruritic red or bluish lesions located symmetrically on the dorsal aspect of the fingers, toes, ears and nose. Less commonly, reports describe involvement of the thighs and buttocks. The lesions present hours after exposure to cold and usually resolve spontaneously in one to three weeks.
Congenital developmental defect arising from the primitive branchial apparatus.
A congenital fistula in the neck resulting from incomplete closure of a branchial cleft.

Maternal diabetes can either be a gestational, mostly type 2 diabetes, or a type 1 diabetes. Essential is the resulting maternal hyperglycemia as a non-specific teratogen, imposing the same risk of congenital malformations to pregnant women with both type 1 and type2 diabetes.
The presence of a size difference between the left and right cornea.

ET: Pseudoepiphyses of the phalanges of the hand
DEF: A secondary ossification center in the phalanges of the hand that is distinct from the normal epiphysis that does not contribute to the longitudinal growth of a tubular bone.

Distance between the labial point of the incisive papilla to the midline junction of the hard and soft palate more than 2 SD below the mean (objective) or apparently decreased length of the hard palate (subjective).
A heterogeneous group of congenital spinal anomalies that result from defective closure of the neural tube early in fetal life.
A neoplasm affecting the spinal cord.
Cloacal exstrophy is a severe anterior abdominal wall defect in which the two hemibladders are visible and are separated by a midline intestinal plate, an omphalocele, and an imperforate anus.
A developmental defect that occurs if the two halves of the patella fail to fuse in early childhood.
A condition in which the anterior part of the foot rotates outward away from the midline of the body and the heel remains straight.
An abnormality of the thyroid gland owing to the presence of a fibrous cyst resulting from the persistence of the thyroglossal duct.
Palatal myoclonus is characterized by myoclonic (rhythmic involuntary jerky) movements of the soft palate.

A type of paralysis in which a muscle becomes soft and yields to passive stretching, which results from loss of all or practically all peripheral motor nerves that innervated the muscle. Muscle tone is reduced and the affected muscles undergo extreme atrophy within months of the loss of innervation.

An acute dystonic reaction with blepharospasm, periorbital twitches, and protracted fixed staring episodes. There may be a maximal upward deviation of the eyes in the sustained fashion. Oculogyric crisis can be triggered by a number of factors including neuroleptic medications.
Abnormal narrowing (stenosis) of the midnasal cavity, i.e., of the middle nasal meatus, which in neonates can cause respiratory distress.
Enuresis occurring during sleeping hours.
A hair-containing cyst or sinus usually in the coccygeal region.
The presence of an abnormally large pelvis.
A glioma affecting the cerebellum.
Tongue extending beyond the alveolar ridges or teeth at rest.
Focal emotional seizure with laughing (gelastic) is characterized by bursts of laughter or giggling, usually without appropriate related emotion of happiness, and described as 'mirthless'.
An elevated plasma concentration of sarcosine.
An elevated urinary concentration of sarcosine.
An increased concentration of histidine in the blood.

Mild pyelectasis is defined as a hypoechoic spherical or elliptical space within the renal pelvis that measures at least 5mm and not more than 10 mm. The measurement is taken on a transverse section through the fetal renal pelvis using the maximum anterior-to-posterior measurement.
An abnormal decrease from the normal count of B cells.
Agenesis of molar tooth.
A chronic form of sinusitis.
Focal seizure with eyelid myoclonia, not eyelid myoclonias in the context of absence seizures.
EEG dominated by diffuse beta waves (>13 Hz) with occipitally localized alpha waves (8-13 Hz).
Antihelix protrusion directed more anteriorly than laterally, forming a shelf overlying the posterior concha.
Absence of the anterosuperior prominence of the area between the bottom of the incisura and the inner margin of the antihelix.
A type of cryptotia associated with reduction in size of the antihelix and inferior crus that are affected.
A complete or partial duplication of the tragus; expected to lie anterior to the normal tragus.
Excessive amount of hair growth on forehead.
Reduced muscle tone secondary to an abnormality of the central nervous system.
Delivery of a fetus through surgical incisions made through the abdominal wall (laparotomy) and the uterine wall (hysterotomy).
Delivery of newborn by means of a ventouse, a vacuum device used to assist the delivery of a baby when the second stage of labour has not progressed adequately.
Shoulder dystocia occurs when the fetal anterior shoulder impacts against the maternal symphysis following delivery of the vertex.
An abnormality of the placenta in which there are numerous cystic spaces within the placenta as well as placental enlargement.
This term refers to the loss of eyelashes that were previously present.

JT: 若年成人ORヤングアダルト|開始OR発生ORオンセットOR発症OR発病OR作用発現
DEF: Onset of disease at the age of between 16 and 40 years.
Absence of globe, optic nerve, chiasm and optic tracts. No evidence of ocular tissue on MRI scan or examination.
The condition of having both rods and cones, but only a single kind of cone. Affected individuals have good pattern vision in daylight, but cannot distinguish between colors.

Truncus arteriosus (single great artery leaving the base of the heart, giving rise to the coronary, pulmonary, and systemic arteries) with each pulmonary artery arising separate from each other on the posterior or lateral aspect of the truncus.

Truncus arteriosus (single great artery leaving the base of the heart, giving rise to the coronary, pulmonary, and systemic arteries) whereby the aortic arch is hypoplastic or interrupted, and a large patent ductus arteriosus is present.
Failure to develop of the tricuspid valve and thus lack of the normal connection between the right atrium and the right ventricle.
Heart rate of greater than 100 beats per minute.
Enlargement of the thyroid gland related to a singular nodule in the thyroid gland.
Posterior positions and/or vertical shortening of the infraorbital and perialar regions, or increased concavity of the face and/or reduced nasolabial angle.

JT: 異常フィブリノーゲン血症
DEF: Qualitatively abnormal fibrinogen.
Abnormally low glucose concentration in the cerebrospinal fluid.
Aorta descends on right instead of on the left.
Elevated concentration of galactose in the blood.
Increased concentration of ornithine in the blood.

JT: メトヘモグロビン血症
DEF: Abnormally increased levels of methemoglobin in the blood. In this form of hemoglobin, there is an oxidized ferric iron (Fe +3) rather than the reduced ferrous form (Fe 2+) that is normally found in hemoglobin. Methemoglobin has a reduced affinity for oxygen, resulting in a reduced ability to release oxygen to tissues.
Inflammation of the uveal tract in which the primary site of inflammation is the retina or choroid.
An increased concentration of urocanic acid in the urine.
Increased time for the PR interval (beginning of the P wave to the beginning of the QRS complex).

An exanthema consisting of widespread pink-to-red macules (flat spots of 2-10 mm in diameter) or papules (red bumps) that blanch with pressure. The macules and papules may cluster and merge to form sheets over several days.
Failure of the ureter to undergo development.

JT: マイクロプロラクチノーマ
DEF: A pituitary prolactin cell adenoma of less than 10 mm diameter.

JT: マクロプロラクチノーマ
DEF: A pituitary prolactin cell adenoma of more than 10 mm diameter.
Bony defects situated along the cranial suture lines or at the junction of the bone plates of the skull.

Optic disc drusen are acellular, calcified deposits within the optic nerve head. Optic disc drusen are congenital and developmental anomalies of the optic nerve head, representing hyaline-containing bodies that, over time, appear as elevated, lumpy irregularities on the anterior portion of the optic nerve.

A form of telangiectasis characterized by a central elevated red dot the size of a pinhead, representing an arteriole, with numerous small blood vessels that radiate out thereby resembling the legs of a spider. Characteristically, compression of the central arteriole causes the entire lesion to blanch, and the lesion quickly refills once the compression is released.
Severely increased levels of protein in the urine (1000-3000 mg per day in adults).
Developmental anomaly in which the vagina, bladder, and rectum fuse resulting in a common channel.
Deposition of fibrillar material that can be found on all anterior segment structures bathed by aqueous humor.

A testis that is located at the upper scrotum or lower inguinal canal and that can be made to descend completely into the scrotum without resistance by manual reduction but returns to its original position by the cremasteric reflex.
A darker than expected T2 signal on magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the thalamus. This term refers to a diffuse hypointensity affecting the entire thalamus.
An abnormality of the anus or rectum.
Excessive fat around the stomach and abdomen.
A darker than expected T2 signal on magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brainstem. This term refers to a diffuse hypointensity affecting the entire brainstem.
Respiratory failure in the newborn.

A deviation from normal of the length of the arm span (length from one end of an individual's arms measured at the fingertips to the other when raised parallel to the ground at shoulder height at a one-hundred eighty degree angle)
Decreased distance between the attachments of the alae nasi to the face.

JT: 臨床OR臨床的OR臨床上ORクリニカル|修飾因子OR変更因子ORモディファイヤー
DEF: This subontology is designed to provide terms to characterize and specify the phenotypic abnormalities defined in the Phenotypic abnormality subontology, with respect to severity, laterality, age of onset, and other aspects.
Difficulty releasing one's grip associated with prolonged first handgrip relaxation times.
A cataract that affects the capsule of the lens.
A cataract which affects the layer of the lens surrounding the nucleus, i.e., the lens cortex. It is identified by its unique wedge or spoke appearance.
A reduced circulating concentration of folic acid, which is also known as vitamin B9.
Edema affecting the region situated around the orbit of the eye.
Narrowing or constriction of the inner surface (lumen) of an artery.
A growth pattern that displays an abnormal difference between the left and the right side.

An abnormal change (metaplasia) in the cells of the inferior portion of the esophagus. The normal squamous epithelium lining of the esophagus is replaced by metaplastic columnar epithelium. Columnar epithelium refers to a cell type that is typically found in more distal parts of the gastrointestinal system.
A seizure during pregnancy.
A form of malignant cancer of the connective tissue surrounding nerves. Given its origin and behavior, it is classified as a sarcoma.
A rare congenital cystic lesion of the lungs in the mediastinum.
A benign or malignant neoplasm (tumour) originating in the vascular system.
A rare pediatric carcinoma of the pancreas.
An abnormality of the development of the toenails.
Deposits of various size, shape, consistency, refractive index, and motility within the eye's vitreous humour, which is normally transparent.
Underdevelopment of the iliac bones.
The narrowing or partial blockage of a portion of the duodenum.
A rare, benign soft tissue tumor that typically occurs within the first two years of life.
Flaring (widening) of the epiphysis.

An aberrant pupillary response characterized by (i) Constriction of pupils of both eyes when the light stimulus is applied to the normal eye, and (ii) Dilatation of pupils of both eyes when the light stimulus is rapidly transferred from the normal eye (after brief light exposure to the normal eye) to the affected eye.
Hepatitis that lasts for more than six months.
Accumulation of clear fluid in the between the layers of membrane (tunica vaginalis) surrounding the testis.
Congenital anomaly characterized by closure or failure to develop an opening in the urethra.
A connection of the right and left kidney by an isthmus of functioning renal parenchyma or fibrous tissue that crosses the midline.
Hypoplasia of the kidney.
Presence of cysts at the corticomedullary junction of the kidney in combination with tubulointerstitial fibrosis.
An abnormal increase in the size of the kidney.
Nephrocalcinosis is the deposition of calcium salts in renal parenchyma.
The presence of prolapse of the uterus.
A type of cleft lip presenting as a midline (median) gap in the upper lip.
Multiple indentations and/or elevations on the edge and/or surface of the tongue producing an irregular surface contour.
The presence of a triangular form of the mouth.
Parietal bossing is a marked prominence in the parietal region.
Underdevelopment of the malar prominence of the jugal bone (zygomatic bone in mammals), appreciated in profile, frontal view, and/or by palpation.
A characteristic facial appearance with a round facial form, full cheeks, a short nose, and a relatively small chin.
Reduced muscle tone of a muscle that is innervated by the facial nerve (the seventh cranial nerve).
A lack of facial expression often with staring eyes and a slightly open mouth.
An abnormal difference between the left and right sides of the face.

Inclination of the anterior surface of the forehead from the vertical more than two standard deviations above the mean (objective); or apparently excessive posterior sloping of the forehead in a lateral view.

Stapes ankylosis refers to congenital or acquired fixation of the stapes (the stirrup-shaped small bone or ossicle in the middle ear), which is associated with conductive hearing resulting from impairment of the sound-conduction mechanism (the external auditory canal, tympanic membrane, and/or middle-ear ossicles).

JT: 耳輪の過剰な巻き込み
DEF: A condition in which the helix is folded over to a greater degree than normal. That is, excessive curling of the helix edge, whereby the free edge is parallel to the plane of the ear.
Abnormal narrowing of the choana (the posterior nasal aperture).

Anteriorly-facing nostrils viewed with the head in the Frankfurt horizontal and the eyes of the observer level with the eyes of the subject. This gives the appearance of an upturned nose (upturned nasal tip).
A notch or cleft of the retina.
Lack of eyelashes.
A fixed reduction in the vertical distance between the upper and lower eyelids with short palpebral fissures.
An abnormality of the cornea characterized by the deposition of calcium in a band across the central cornea, leading to decreased vision, foreign body sensation, and ocular irritation.
Ophthalmoplegia is a paralysis or weakness of one or more of the muscles that control eye movement.
Decreased density/number of eyelashes.
Behavior characterized by an abnormal limitation to few interests and activities.
A defect of the chest wall characterized by a depression of the sternum, giving the chest (\
A deformity of the chest caused by overgrowth of the ribs and characterized by protrusion of the sternum.
Difficulty in looking at another person in the eye.
An increased concentration of insulin in the blood.

The presence of abnormally increased levels of prolactin in the blood. Prolactin is a peptide hormone produced by the anterior pituitary gland that plays a role in breast development and lactation during pregnancy.
Presence of only 11 pairs of ribs.
A congenital skeletal deformity characterized by the elevation of one scapula (thus, one scapula is located superior to the other).
Underdevelopment of the ilium.
The presence of multiple lipomas (a type of benign tissue made of fatty tissue).

Thinned, erythematous, depressed bands of atrophic skin. Initially, striae appear as flattened and thinned, pinkish linear regions of the skin. Striae tend to enlarge in length and become reddish or purplish. Later, striae tend to appear as white, depressed bands that are parallel to the lines of skin tension. Striae distensae occur most often in areas that have been subject to distension such as the lower back, buttocks, thighs, breast, abdomen, and shoulders.
The presence of whitish spots in a ring-like arrangement at the periphery of the iris.

A congenital defect of the macula distinct from coloboma associated with optic fissure closure defects. Macular coloboma is characterized by a sharply defined, rather large defect in the central area of the fundus that is oval or round, and coarsely pigmented.
Partial dislocation of the lens of the eye.

JT: 視神経ニューロパチー

DEF: A kind of polydactyly characterized by the presence of a supernumerary finger or fingers.
Spoon-shaped, broad thumbs.
With the hand relaxed and the thumb in the plane of the palm, the axis of the thumb forms an angle of at least 90 degrees with the long axis of the hand.
Spasticity (neuromuscular hypertonia) primarily in the muscles of the legs, hips, and pelvis.

The term gait disturbance can refer to any disruption of the ability to walk. In general, this can refer to neurological diseases but also fractures or other sources of pain that is triggered upon walking. However, in the current context gait disturbance refers to difficulty walking on the basis of a neurological or muscular disease.
Sustained involuntary muscle contractions that produce twisting and repetitive movements of the body.

A localized defect in the bone of the skull resulting from abnormal embryological development. The defect is covered by normal skin. In some cases, skull x-rays have shown underlying lytic bone lesions which have closed before the age of one year.

A localized defect in the bone of the skull resulting from abnormal embryological development. The defect is covered by normal skin. In some cases, skull x-rays have shown underlying lytic bone lesions which have closed before the age of one year.
The presence of excessive fibrous connective tissue in the liver. Fibrosis is a reparative or reactive process.
A mode of inheritance in which a trait or disorder results from a de novo mutation occurring after conception, rather than being inherited from a preceding generation.

Axenfeld's anomaly is a bilateral disorder characterized by a prominent, anteriorly displaced Schwalbe's line (posterior embryotoxon) and peripheral iris strands which span the anterior chamber angle to attach to Schwalbe's line.

JT: 死OR死亡|インジウム|乳児期
DEF: Death within the first 24 months of life.
Protrusion of abdominal contents through a defect in the abdominal wall musculature around the umbilicus. Skin and subcutaneous tissue overlie the defect.
A form of nystagmus in which the eyeball makes rotary motions around the axis.
A congenital anomaly in which the pancreas completely (or sometimes incompletely) encircles the second portion of duodenum and occasionally obstructs the more proximal duodenum.
A cyst of the pancreas that possess a lining of mucous epithelium.

An accessory spleen is a round, iso-echogenic, homogenic and smooth structure and is seen as a normal variant mostly on the medial contour of the spleen, near the hilus or around the lower pole. This has no pathogenic relevance.
The presence of only one working lower chamber in the heart, usually with a virtual absence of the ventricular septum and usually present in conjunction with double inlet left or right ventricle.
Increased side-to-side width of a metatarsal bone.
When viewed on end (with the digit tip pointing toward the examiner's eye) the curve of the nail forms a tighter curve of convexity.
A kind of polydactyly characterized by the presence of a supernumerary toe or toes.
Bending or curvature of a toe in the tibial direction (i.e., towards the big toe).
A reduction in the number of circulating thrombocytes.
A type of anemia caused by premature destruction of red blood cells (hemolysis).
An abnormally reduced number of granulocytes in the blood.
Excretion of non-amino organic acids in urine.
An abnormal narrowing of the pylorus.
The presence of chronic diarrhea, which is usually taken to mean diarrhea that has persisted for over 4 weeks.
Extreme dilation of the submucusoal veins in the lower portion of the esophagus.
The inability to maintain a comfortably body temperature in warm or hot weather.

A facial appearance characteristic of myopathic conditions. The face appears expressionless with sunken cheeks, bilateral ptosis, and inability to elevate the corners of the mouth, due to muscle weakness.
Atrophy (wasting, decrease in size of cells or tissue) affecting the cerebrum.

A type of kinetic tremor that occurs during target directed movement is called intention tremor. That is, an oscillatory cerebellar ataxia that tends to be absent when the limbs are inactive and during the first part of voluntary movement but worsening as the movement continues and greater precision is required (e.g., in touching a target such as the patient's nose or a physician's finger).
An increase in size of the ventricular system of the brain.

A generalized non-motor (absence) seizure is a type of a type of dialeptic seizure that is of electrographically generalized onset. It is a generalized seizure characterised by an interruption of activities, a blank stare, and usually the person will be unresponsive when spoken to. Any ictal motor phenomena are minor in comparison to these non-motor features.
An abnormal gait pattern in which persons stand and walk with their feet spaced widely apart. This is often a component of cerebellar ataxia.
An abnormally decreased phosphate concentration in the blood.
An increased concentration of proteins in the blood.
An abnormal dilatation of the fourth cerebral ventricle.
The presence of an excessive amount of fluid in the pleural cavity.
Hypopigmented hair that appears silver-gray.
Sparseness of the body hair.
A developmental defect resulting in complete obliteration of the duodenal lumen, that is, an abnormal closure of the duodenum.
Chronic inflammation of the nasal mucosa.

A febrile seizure is any type of seizure (most often a generalized tonic-clonic seizure) occurring with fever (at least 38 degrees Celsius) but in the absence of central nervous system infection, severe metabolic disturbance or other alternative precipitant in children between the ages of 3 months and 6 years.
Protrusion of the meninges and portions of the spinal cord through a defect of the vertebral column.

JT: 原始反射(掌頤,口とがらせ,眉間)
DEF: The primitive reflexes are a group of behavioural motor responses which are found in normal early development, are subsequently inhibited, but may be released from inhibition by cerebral, usually frontal, damage. They are thus part of a broader group of reflexes which reflect release phenomena, such as exaggerated stretch reflexes and extensor plantars. They do however involve more complex motor responses than such simple stretch reflexes, and are often a normal feature in the neonate or infant.
The presence of cell death (necrosis) affecting the liver.

An overriding aorta is a congenital heart defect where the aorta is positioned directly over a ventricular septal defect, instead of over the left ventricle. The result is that the aorta receives some blood from the right ventricle, which reduces the amount of oxygen in the blood. It is one of the four conditions of the Tetralogy of Fallot. The aortic root can be displaced toward the front (anteriorly) or directly above the septal defect, but it is always abnormally located to the right of the root of the pulmonary artery. The degree of override is quite variable, with 5-95% of the valve being connected to the right ventricle.
Sclerosis (hardening) of the arteries with increased thickness of the wall of arteries as well as increased stiffness and a loss of elasticity.

Pheochromocytomas (also known as chromaffin tumors) produce, store, and secrete catecholamines. Pheochromocytomas usually originate from the adrenal medulla but may also develop from chromaffin cells in or about sympathetic ganglia.
