A common symptom of pheochromocytoma is hypertension owing to release of catecholamines.
Trilobar skull configuration when viewed from the front or behind.
Failure of the immune system to protect the body adequately from infection, due to the absence or insufficiency of some component process or substance.
A thickened white patch on the oral mucosa that cannot be rubbed off.
Abnormal thinning of the cortical region of bones.
The presence of a tail-like skin appendage located adjacent to the sacrum.
An abnormality of T cells.
A structural abnormality of B cells.

Hyperventilation refers to an increased pulmonary ventilation rate that is faster than necessary for the exchange of gases. Hyperventilation can result from increased frequency of breathing, an increased tidal volume, or both, and leads to an excess intake of oxygen and the blowing off of carbon dioxide.
An increased concentration of chloride in the urine.
A developmental defect leading to the union of two adjacent vertebrae.
Inability to react to a delayed hypersensitivity skin test.
The presence of a carcinoma of the breast.
An elevated urinary concentration of cystathionine.
The presence of nipples that instead of pointing outward are retracted inwards.
An increased concentration of tyrosine in the blood.
An increased concentration of cystathionine in the blood.
The formation of bullae (blisters) with cleavage in the lamina lucida layer of the skin.
A condition in which muscles cannot be moved quickly without accompanying pain or spasm.

JT: 先天性OR先天的OR先天|開始OR発生ORオンセットOR発症OR発病OR作用発現
DEF: A phenotypic abnormality that is present at birth.

JT: 中年|開始OR発生ORオンセットOR発症OR発病OR作用発現
DEF: A type of adult onset with onset of symptoms at the age of 40 to 60 years.

JT: 緩徐OR遅いORゆっくりOR緩慢OR遅くする|進行OR悪化OR増悪OR級数ORプログレッション

DEF: Abnormal protrusion of the scapula away from the surface of the back.

JT: ミオクローヌス性スパスム

DEF: A malformation of the uterus in which the uterus is present as a paired organ as a result of the failure of fusion of the mullerian ducts during embryogenesis.
An injury of the wrist with displacement of any of the eight carpal bones.
Fusion of the hands and feet by a thin membrane of skin (scarring) seen in forms of dystrophic epidermolysis bullosa and leading to a \
Wrist is bent inward toward the thumb because of a congenital defect associated with shortening or absence of the radius.
An anomaly of the second finger, also known as the index finger.
An anomaly of the third finger.
An abnormality affecting one or both 5th fingers.

JT: 大菱形骨欠損/大菱形骨骨化欠損

DEF: Truncus arteriosus (single great artery leaving the base of the heart, giving rise to the coronary, pulmonary, and systemic arteries) with a short pulmonary trunk arises from the truncus arteriosus, giving rise to both pulmonary arteries.
Inflammation of a vein associated with venous thrombosis (blood clot formation within the vein).
Small indentation anterior to the insertion of the ear.
The presence of a fistula between the bowel and the perineum.
Accumulation of cell free, noninflammatony fluid within the wall of the intestinal tract producing uniform thickening of the mucosal folds.
Hemorrhage occurring within a joint.
A discrete abnormal tissue mass that protrudes into the lumen of the intestine and is attached to the intestinal wall either by a stalk, pedunculus, or a broad base.
An abnormal increase from the normal count of B cells.
A fontanelle that is small for age.

Normal adult hemoglobin is composed of two chains each of alpha and beta globin. Hb Barts (Hemoglobin Barts) is a tetramer with four gamma globin chains, and is essentially pathognomonic for one or another form of alpha thalassemia. Hb Barts has an extremely high affinity for oxygen, resulting in almost no oxygen delivery to the tissues.

A slowly progressing leukemia characterized by a clonal (malignant) proliferation of maturing and mature myeloid cells or mature lymphocytes. When the clonal cellular population is composed of myeloid cells, the process is called chronic myelogenous leukemia. When the clonal cellular population is composed of lymphocytes, it is classified as chronic lymphocytic leukemia, hairy cell leukemia, or T-cell large granular lymphocyte leukemia.
Increased cross-section (diameter) of the long bones. Note that widening may primarily affect specific regions of long bones (e.g., diaphysis or metaphysis), but this should be coded separately.
A developmental defect defined by the failure of the formation of the lumen (tube) of the ureter.

Y-shaped metacarpals are the result of a partial fusion of two metacarpal bones, with the two arms of the Y pointing in the distal direction. Y-shaped metacarpals may be seen in combination with polydactyly.
Increased length of the radius.

Radial dysplasia, also known as radial longitudinal deficiency, includes radial clubhand and is a disfiguring, and potentially disabling, congenital limb anomaly. The entire upper limb may be involved, although the defect is most evident in the forearm and hand. Affected children suffer a variable degree of hypoplasia or absence of the preaxial skeleton and soft tissues, in particular the thumb, radius, and dorsoradial soft tissues. The hand is usually radially deviated and subluxated off the distal aspect of the ulna, the ulna may be shortened and have a bow-shaped deformity, and there is no true wrist (radiocarpal) joint in Bayne2 type-III and IV radial dysplasia.
Absence of the patella.
A malignant plasma cell tumor growing within soft tissue or within the skeleton.
An increase in size of the third ventricle.
Complete loss of ability to move facial muscles innervated by the facial nerve (i.e., the seventh cranial nerve).
Loss of all scalp hair.
Absence of melanin pigment in various areas, which is found at birth and is permanent. The lesions are known as leucoderma and are often found on the face, trunk, or limbs.
A form of monochromacy in which vision is derived from the remaining preserved blue (S) cones and rod photoreceptors.
The presence of abnormal punctate (speckled, dot-like) calcifications in one or more tarsal bones.
The congenital absence of the thyroid gland.
The presence of developmental dysplasia of the vertebral column.
A developmental defect characterized by agenesis of one or more vertebral bodies.
Increased height of the wing (or ala) of the ilium (which is the large expanded portion which bounds the greater pelvis laterally).
Hypoplasia (congenital reduction in size) of the fifth finger, also known as the little finger.
Absent 5th (little) finger.
Hypoplasia (congenital reduction in size) of the fourth finger, also known as the ring finger.
Absent 4th finger.
Absent 3rd finger.
Hypoplastic/small 3rd (middle) finger.
Absent 2nd (index) finger.
Hypoplasia of the second finger, also known as the index finger.
The presence of a sebaceous adenoma with origin in the sebum secreting cells of the skin.
The presence of a neoplasm of the urinary bladder.
Excessive wrinkling of the skin of the face.
The presence of an abscess located around the anus.
A hemisacral defect involving the sacral vertebrae S2 to S5. In hemisacrum, the first sacral vertebra is intact and there is agenesis involving only S2-S5.

JT: 甲状腺機能正常性甲状腺腫
DEF: A goiter that is not associated with functional thyroid abnormalities.
Limb shortening because of underdevelopment of one or more bones of the extremities.
Attachment of the lobe to the side of the face at the lowest point of the lobe without curving upward.
An abnormal orientation of the earlobes such that they point out- and upward. That is, the lateral surface of ear lobe faces superiorly.
A malposition of the pupil owing to a developmental defect of the iris.
Increase in bulk of the ala nasi.
Excess facial hair.
Diminished length of one or more metacarpal bones in relation to the others of the same hand or to the contralateral metacarpal.
Absence of the scapulae.
An anomaly of the second toe.
An anomaly of the third toe.
An anomaly of the fourth toe.
An anomaly of the little toe.
The presence of osteophytes (bone spurs), i.e., of bony projections originating from the acetabulum.
The presence of an abnormal connection between the urethra and another organ or the skin.
An abnormally increased length of the metacarpal bones.

Hypersecretion of one or more pituitary hormones. This can occur in conditions in which deficiency in the target organ leads to decreased hormonal feedback, or as a primary condition most usually in connection with a pituitary adenoma.

Spinal myoclonus is generally due to a tumor, infection, injury, or degenerative process of the spinal cord, and is characterized by involuntary rhythmic muscle contractions, usually at a rate of more than one per second. Myoclonus occurs synchronously in several muscles and can be increased in severity and frequency by fatigue or stress, but is usually unaffected by sensory stimuli. Spinal myoclonus ceases during sleep or anesthesia.

A midline anterior-posterior cleft of the epiglottis that involves at least two-thirds of the epiglottic leaf. It is a useful feature for clinical diagnosis because it appears to be very rare in syndromes other than Pallister-Hall-Syndrome and is also rare as an isolated malformation.

Y-shaped metatarsals are the result of a partial fusion of two metatarsal bones, with the two arms of the Y pointing in the distal direction. Y-shaped metatarsals may be seen in combination with polydactyly.
Prominence of the malar process of the maxilla and infraorbital area appreciated in profile and from in front of the face.
Reduced ability to perceive certain odorants (implies that the sense of smell is maintained for other classes of odorants).
Absence or abnormal closure of the midnasal cavity.

ET: Absence of the third cerebral ventricle
DEF: A developmental defect characterized by the absence of the Third ventricle.
A type of congenital cataract in which the opacity follows the anterior or posterior Y suture.
Diminished length of a metatarsal bone, with resultant proximal displacement of the associated toe.

Blepharochalasis is characterized by recurrent, non-painful, nonerythematous episodes of eyelid edema. It has been divided into hypertrophic and atrophic forms. In the hypertrophic form recurrent edema results in orbital fat herniation through a weakened orbital septum. Most patients who have blepharochalasis present in an atrophic condition with atrophy of redundant eyelid skin and superior nasal fat pads.
The presence of an additional membrane in the left or right cardiac atrium which results in the subdivision of the affected atrium (and thus in total three atria, whence the name).
A subtype of skin dimples occurring in the shoulder region.
A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the uterus.
A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of a gonad.
A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the genital system.
A glioma affecting the brainstem.

A hemangioblastoma is a benign vascular neoplasm that arises almost exclusively in the central nervous system. Hemangioblastomas consist of a tightly packed cluster of small blood vessels forming a mass of up to 1 or 2 cm in diameter.
Intermittent clonic or tonic contraction of muscles supplied by facial nerve. Muscles are relaxed in between contractions.
An inversion of the T-wave (which is normally positive).
A disease where there is cellular death (necrosis) of bone components due to interruption of the blood supply.
Morbus Kienboeck is a Juvenile aseptic necrosis affecting the Os lunatum.
Zonular cataracts are defined to be cataracts that affect specific regions of the lens.
Fetal megacystis is an abnormally enlarged bladder identified at any gestational age.

JT: パターンOR様式OR型OR種類ORパターン形成
DEF: The speed at which disease manifestations appear and develop.

A sudden flexion, extension, or mixed extension-flexion of predominantly proximal and truncal muscles that is usually more sustained than a myoclonic movement but not as sustained as a tonic seizure. Limited forms may occur: Grimacing, head nodding, or subtle eye movements. Epileptic spasms frequently occur in clusters. Infantile spasms are the best known form, but spasms can occur at all ages
A type of focal autonomic seizure characterised by symptoms or signs pertaining to the gastrointestinal system as the initial semiological feature.
A sensation consistent with involvement of the autonomic nervous system, including cardiovascular, gastrointestinal, sudomotor, vasomotor and thermoregulatory functions.
A type of focal motor seizure characterised by sustained, forced conjugate ocular, cephalic, and/or truncal rotation or lateral deviation from the midline as the initial semiological manifestation.
EEG dominated by diffuse beta waves (>13 Hz) with occipitally localized alpha waves (8-13 Hz).
No discernible ridge between concha and triangular fossa and helix.
Double rather than single peak of the antitragus.
A type of cryptotia associated with reduction in size of the antihelix and superior crus.
Increase posterolateral protrusion of the tragus.
Absence of the cochlea, a spiral shaped cavity in the inner ear, owing to a developmental defect.
Atrophy of the tibialis muscle.

In primary position, the eyes drift slowly downward and then spontaneously beat upward. Upward gaze accentuates the nystagmus. The associated oscillopsias are often very irritating, but the symptoms are usually transient.
A condition where the retina contains no functional cone cells, so that in addition to the absence of color discrimination, vision in lights of normal intensity is difficult.
A congenital stenotic mitral valvular anomaly with a ring of tissue above the mitral valve.
Right pulmonary venous return to the inferior vena cava.

A teratoma within the heart. Most commonly, these tumors are detected in the pericardial cavity attached to the pulmonary artery and aorta. The tumour size within the heart varies from 2 to 9 cm in diameter, and intrapericardial tumors as large as 15 cm have been reported. Intracardiac tumors arise from the atrial or ventricular wall as nodular masses protruding into the cardiac chambers. Cardiac and pericardial teratomas are easily detected in the fetus and neonate by two-dimensional echocardiography as heterogeneous and encapsulated cystic masses. Histologically, cardiac teratomas contain multiple immature elements including epithelium, neuroglial tissue, thyroid, pancreas, smooth and skeletal muscle, cartilage and bone.
An abnormal growth of parafollicular (C-cells) cells.
A renal tumor originating from an oncocyte, which is an epithelial cell characterized by an excessive amount of mitochondria, resulting in an abundant acidophilic, granular cytoplasm.
Decrease in width of the nasal tip.

Accumulation of chyle (the whitish fluid taken up by the lacteals in the intestine, consisting of an emulsion of lymph and triglyceride fat thatpasses into the veins by the thoracic duct) in the pericardium. Chylopericardium is generally caused by obstruction of or trauma to the thoracic duct.
Abnormal accumulation of fluid leading to swelling of the pharynx.

Seesaw nystagmus is a type of pendular nystagmus where a half cycle consists of the elevation and intorsion of one eye, concurrently with the depression and extortion of the fellow eye. In the other half cycle, there is an inversion of the ocular movements.
A type of melanoma that starts as a raised area that is usually dark blackish-blue or bluish-red but may not have any color.
Elevation in the concentration of albumin in the blood.
Inflammation of the uveal tract in which the primary site of inflammation is the anterior chamber.
Phagocytosis by macrophages of erythrocytes, leukocytes, platelets, and their precursors in bone marrow and other tissues.
A type of lymphoma characterized microscopically by multinucleated Reed-Sternberg cells.
A type of headache characterized by repeated attacks of unilateral pain lasting 15 to 180 minutes and associated with local autonomic signs.
An erythematous eruption commonly associated with drug reactions or infection and characterized by inflammatory nodules that are usually tender, multiple, and bilateral.
The presence of a teratoma in the ovary.

JT: 無トランスフェリン血症
DEF: Absence of transferrin, a protein that transports iron, in the blood.
Anosmia for one particular odor.
A periodic beat-to-beat variation in the amplitude or shape of the T wave in an EKG.
Inflammation surrounding hair follicles.
A leukemia that originates from a myeloid cell, that is the blood forming cells of the bone marrow.
An abnormally decreased phosphate concentration in the urine.
Inflammation of the large airways of the lung with rapid onset and short course usually associated with cough, mucus production, shortness of breath, wheezing, and chest tightness.
Reduced intensity of muscle tendon reflexes in jaw.
An allergy experienced at a particular time of year when trees or grasses pollinate and elicit an allergic reaction.
An abnormal accumulation of interstitial fluid in the soft tissues of the limbs.
Wasting or decrease in size of all or part of the duodenum.
Intermittent and recurrent bouts of a subjective feeling of tiredness characterized by a lack of energy and motivation.
Longstanding abnormal acid accumulation or depletion of base.
Infantile spasms represent a subset of \
A wartlike (with multiple small elevated projections) papule.
A detrimental reaction to a food, beverage, food additive, or compound found in foods that produces symptoms in one or more body organs and systems that is not mediated by an immune reaction.
Absence of thumb nail.
First period after the age of 15 years.
A type of mesenchymal tissue cell tumor that exhibits epithelial differentiation, which most frequently arises in the extremities.
The presence of moderately increased concentrations of albumin in the urine, defined as and albumin-creatinine ratio (ACR) of 30 to 299 mg/gm (3.4 to 34 mg/mmol).
Mildly increased levels of protein in the urine (150-500 mg per day in adults).
An increased concentration of magnesium the urine.
Disturbance in the atrial activation that is caused by transient failure of impulse conduction from the sinoatrial node to the cardiac atria.

Decreased length of the arm span (length from one end of an individual's arms measured at the fingertips to the other when raised parallel to the ground at shoulder height at a one-hundred eighty degree angle).
A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the retina.
A kinked appearance of the brainstem, i.e., an exaggerated flexure.
Increased width of the nasal ridge.
A narrowing of a segment of colon whereby bowel continuity is maintained.

A condition which is considered to be due to the subsequent atrophy and disappearance in fetal life of an initially normal testis. In the presence of spermatic cord structures is evidence of the presence of the testis in early intrauterine life. When associated with a blind-ending spermatic cord, this entity is named as his absence of a testis in an otherwise normal 46XY male is usually unilateral and is assumed to be a consequence of intrauterine or perinatal torsion or infarction.

A nuclear cataract is an opacity or clouding that develops in the lens nucleus. That is, a nuclear cataract is one that is located in the center of the lens. The nucleus tends to darken changing from clear to yellow and sometimes brown.

A form of hypersociability that presents as mostly inappropriate people-orientation and friendliness towards others on an inadequate level which might go as far as being dangerous considering for example young children following strangers without restriction.

A band of bone material of decreased density forming alongside the surface of the cortical bone with thickening of the periosteum. Callus formation in the affected area is common and gives the appearance of a false fracture.
A broad appearance of the second toe.
A broad appearance of the third toe.
A broad appearance of the fourth toe.
A broad appearance of the fifth toe.
Hyponasal speech is when there is an abnormally reduced nasal airflow during speech often in a setting of nasal obstruction or congestion.
Thick, elongated, worm-like or corkscrew eosinophilic bundle that are found on H&E staining of the brain in the presence of long standing gliosis, occasional tumors, and some metabolic disorders.
Hypersensitivity in form of an adverse immune reaction against cow milk protein.
Congenital duplication of all or part of a limb.
Coexistence of two hemicords, at variable levels, causing splaying of the posterior vertebral elements. Results in neurological deficits in lower limb or perineum.
A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the ovary.
A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the vagina.
A congenital absence or considerable underdevelopment of the trachea such that communication between the larynx proximally and the alveoli of the lungs distally is lacking.
Terminal broadening of the toes (distal phalanges of the toes).
Excessively active peristalsis (wave of contraction of the tubular organs of the gastrointestinal tract) marked by excessive rapidity of the passage of food through the stomach and intestine.
Increased level of cryoglobulins in the blood. Cryoglobulins are abnormal immunoglobulins, especially IGG or IGM, that precipitate spontaneously when serum is cooled below 37 degrees Celsius.
Pain or discomfort of the scalp elicited by palpation.
An abnormal increase in the total number of T cells detected in the blood.
Absence of the liver owing to a failure of the liver to develop.
Increased length and width of one half of the tounge.
Abnormally persistent clusters of embryonal cells, representing microscopic malformations (dysplasias) of the developing kidney.
The presence of multiple rectal hyperplastic/adenomatous polyps.

JT: チアノーゼエピソード

DEF: An aberrant pupillary response characterized by (i) Constriction of pupils of both eyes when the light stimulus is applied to the normal eye, and (ii) Dilatation of pupils of both eyes when the light stimulus is rapidly transferred from the normal eye (after brief light exposure to the normal eye) to the affected eye.
Absence of nail of little finger.
Deviation from the norm of height with respect to that which is expected according to age and gender norms.
Urge incontinence is the strong, sudden need to urinate.
Underdevelopment of the uterus.
Protrusion of the contents of the abdominal cavity through the inguinal canal.
The presence of inflammation of the epididymis.
Lack of external genitalia in a male or female individual.
Developmental hypoplasia of the clitoris.
Fusion of the labia minora as a result of labial adhesions resulting in vaginal obstruction.

A duplication of the collecting system of the kidney, defined as a kidney with two (instead of, normally, one) pyelocaliceal systems. The pyelocaliceal system is comprised of the renal pelvis and calices. The duplicated renal collecting system can be associated with a single ureter or with double ureters. In the latter case, the two ureters empty separately into the bladder or fuse to form a single ureteral orifice.
Presence of cysts at the corticomedullary junction of the kidney in combination with tubulointerstitial fibrosis.
The presence of renal tubules with thick redundant basement membranes, or a reduction of greater than 50% in tubular diameter compared to surrounding non-atrophic tubules.
The presence of renal tubules with thick redundant basement membranes, or a reduction of greater than 50% in tubular diameter compared to surrounding non-atrophic tubules.
A structural anomaly of the glomerulus.
Inflammation of the renal glomeruli.
The presence of developmental dysplasia of the kidney.
Nephrocalcinosis is the deposition of calcium salts in renal parenchyma.
Congenital occlusion of the vagina or adhesion of the walls of the vagina causing occlusion.
Aplasia of the uterus.
An abnormality of the lip.
A type of cleft lip presenting as a midline (median) gap in the upper lip.
Abnormality of the oral cavity, i.e., the opening or hollow part of the mouth.
Any abnormality of the gingiva (also known as gums).
Any abnormality of the palate, i.e., of roof of the mouth.
Decreased width of the upper lip.
Decreased width of the upper lip.
Extra fold of tissue extending from the alveolar ridge to the inner surface of the upper or lower lip.
Depression located on the vermilion of the lower lip, usually paramedian.

Any abnormality of the parotid glands, which are the salivary glands that are located in the subcutaneous tissues of the face overlying the mandibular ramus and anterior and inferior to the external ear.
The presence of an abnormally short lingual frenulum.
A gap in the upper lip. This is a congenital defect resulting from nonfusion of tissues of the lip during embryonal development.
The presence of a triangular form of the mouth.

Hyperplasia of the gingiva (that is, a thickening of the soft tissue overlying the alveolar ridge. The degree of thickening ranges from involvement of the interdental papillae alone to gingival overgrowth covering the entire tooth crown.
Dryness of the mouth due to salivary gland dysfunction.
Accentuation of the grooves on the dorsal surface of the tongue.
An abnormality of the head.

In newborns, the two frontal bones, two parietal bones, and one occipital bone are joined by fibrous sutures, which form a small posterior fontanelle, and a larger, diamond-shaped anterior fontanelle. These regions allow for the skull to pass the birth canal and for later growth. The fontanelles gradually ossify, whereby the posterior fontanelle usually closes by eight weeks and the anterior fontanelle by the 9th to 16th month of age. Large fontanelles are diagnosed if the fontanelles are larger than age-dependent norms.
An abnormal increase of density of the bones making up the calvaria.
Progressive microcephaly is diagnosed when the head circumference falls progressively behind age- and gender-dependent norms.
An acute form of sinusitis.
Asymmetry of the bones of the skull.
Increased convexity of the occiput (posterior part of the skull).
Any abnormality of the mandible, the bone of the lower jaw.
A fold of skin starting above the medial aspect of the upper eyelid and arching downward to cover, pass in front of and lateral to the medial canthus.
An abnormality of the philtrum.

Distance between the philtral ridges, measured just above the vermilion border, more than 2 standard deviations above the mean, or alternatively, an apparently increased distance between the ridges of the philtrum.
A characteristic facial appearance with a round facial form, full cheeks, a short nose, and a relatively small chin.
A lack of facial expression often with staring eyes and a slightly open mouth.
An anomaly of a muscle that is innervated by the facial nerve (the seventh cranial nerve).
An abnormality of the chin, i.e., of the inferior portion of the face lying inferior to the lower lip and including the central prominence of the lower jaw.
A marked tapering of the lower face to the chin.

JT: 顔面筋波動症(ミオキミア)
DEF: Facial myokymia is a fine fibrillary activity of one or more muscles innervated by the facial nerve (the seventh cranial nerve).
Flat skin surface, with no ridge formation in the central region of the upper lip between the nasal base and upper vermilion border.
Flat skin surface, with no ridge formation in the central region of the upper lip between the nasal base and upper vermilion border.
An abnormal difference between the left and right sides of the face.
Facial contour, as viewed from the front, triangular in shape, with breadth at the temples and tapering to a narrow chin.
Facial contour, as viewed from the front, triangular in shape, with breadth at the temples and tapering to a narrow chin.
An abnormality of the Maxilla (upper jaw bone).

Abnormally small dimension of the Maxilla. Usually creating a malocclusion or malalignment between the upper and lower teeth or resulting in a deficient amount of projection of the base of the nose and lower midface region.
Hemangioma, a benign tumor of the vascular endothelial cells, occurring in the face.
Width of the forehead or distance between the frontotemporales is more than two standard deviations below the mean (objective); or apparently narrow intertemporal region (subjective).
An abnormality of the external ear.
An abnormality of the inner ear.
An abnormality of the lobule of pinna.
An abnormality of the middle ear.
Acute otitis media is a short and generally painful infection of the middle ear.
An abnormality of the External acoustic tube (also known as the auditory canal).
An abnormality of the cochlea.
An abnormality of the pinna, which is also referred to as the auricle or external ear.
Laterally protruding ear that lacks antihelical folding (including absence of inferior and superior crura).
Reduced volume of the earlobe.
Chronic otitis media refers to fluid, swelling, or infection of the middle ear that does not heal and may cause permanent damage to the ear.
Increased thickness of the helix of the ear.

ET: Stenosis of the external auditory canal
DEF: An abnormal narrowing of the external auditory canal.
A type of hearing loss resulting from a combination of conductive hearing impairment and sensorineural hearing impairment.

ET: Atresia of the external auditory canal
DEF: Absence or failure to form of the external auditory canal.
Reduced superior to inferior length of the nasal septum.

Abnormality of the nasal bridge, which is the saddle-shaped area that includes the nasal root and the lateral aspects of the nose. It lies between the glabella and the inferior boundary of the nasal bone, and extends laterally to the inner canthi.
Anterior positioning of the nasal root in comparison to the usual positioning for age.
An abnormality of the Ala of nose.
Thinned, deficient, or excessively arched ala nasi.
Increased breadth of the nasal bridge (and with it, the nasal root).
An abnormality of the nasal tip.
Abnormal narrowing of the choana (the posterior nasal aperture).
Absence or abnormal closure of the choana (the posterior nasal aperture).
Absence or abnormal closure of the choana (the posterior nasal aperture).
Increase in width of the nasal tip.
Increase in width of the nasal tip.
A splitting of the nasal tip. Visually assessable vertical indentation, cleft, or depression of the nasal tip.
An abnormality of the neck.
Decreased strength of the neck musculature.
Increased side-to-side width of the neck.
A cystic lymphatic lesion of the neck.
A structural abnormality of the retina.
Any abnormality of the cornea, which is the transparent tissue at the front of the eye that covers the iris, pupil, and anterior chamber.
A form of astigmatism in which one meridian is hyperopic while the one at a right angle to it has no refractive error.
An abnormality of the eyelids.
The palpebral fissure inclination is more than two standard deviations below the mean.
An abnormality of the eyelashes.
An abnormality of the conjunctiva.
Abnormality of eyesight (visual perception).
A cataract that affects the region of the lens directly beneath the capsule of the lens.
An abnormality of the iris, which is the pigmented muscular tissue between the cornea and the lens, that is perforated by an opening called the pupil.
An abnormality of the eyebrow.
Apparent optic disc swelling in the absence of increased intracranial pressure.
Paralysis of the external ocular muscles.
Inflammation of one or all portions of the uveal tract.
Increased density/number and/or increased diameter of eyebrow hairs.
Blockage of the lacrimal duct.
A fixed reduction in the vertical distance between the upper and lower eyelids with short palpebral fissures.
The palpebral fissure inclination is more than two standard deviations above the mean for age (objective); or, the inclination of the palpebral fissure is greater than typical for age.
An abnormality of the cornea characterized by the deposition of calcium in a band across the central cornea, leading to decreased vision, foreign body sensation, and ocular irritation.
A developmental defect characterized by a cleft of some portion of the eye or ocular adnexa.
An abnormality of the sclera.
Abnormality of the anterior chamber, which is the space in the eye that is behind the cornea and in front of the iris.
An anomaly of the pharynx, i.e., of the tubular structure extending from the base of the skull superiorly to the esophageal inlet inferiorly.
Paralysis of one or more extraocular muscles that are responsible for eye movements.
An area of depressed vision located at the point of fixation and that interferes with central vision.
A coloboma of the iris.
An abnormality of the pupil.
A posterior embryotoxon is the presence of a prominent and anteriorly displaced line of Schwalbe.
Distance between medial and lateral canthi is more than two standard deviations above the mean for age (objective); or, apparently increased length of the palpebral fissures.
Atrophy of the optic nerve. Optic atrophy results from the death of the retinal ganglion cell axons that comprise the optic nerve and manifesting as a pale optic nerve on fundoscopy.
Nystagmus consisting of horizontal to-and-fro eye movements.
An abnormality of the Incisor tooth.
Overlapping teeth within an alveolar ridge.
Delayed tooth eruption, which can be defined as tooth eruption more than 2 SD beyond the mean eruption age.
Abnormal alignment, positioning, or spacing of the teeth, i.e., misaligned teeth.
An abnormal conical form of the teeth, that is, a tooth whose sides converge or taper together incisally.
The presence of one or more embedded tooth germs which have failed to erupt.
Unstable emotional experiences and frequent mood changes; emotions that are easily aroused, intense, and/or out of proportion to events and circumstances.
Aggressive behavior can denote verbal aggression, physical aggression against objects, physical aggression against people, and may also include aggression towards oneself.
Recurrent obsessions or compulsions that are severe enough to be time consuming (i.e., they take more than 1 hour a day) or cause marked distress or significant impairment (DSM-IV).
Persistent deficits in social interaction and communication and interaction as well as a markedly restricted repertoire of activity and interest as well as repetitive patterns of behavior.
A type of anxiety disorder characterized by avoidance of public places, especially where crowds gather.
Any abnormality of the thorax (the region of the body formed by the sternum, the thoracic vertebrae and the ribs).
An anomaly of the sternum, also known as the breastbone.
An abnormality of the breast.
Abnormal development of large mammary glands in males resulting in breast enlargement.
An anomaly of the rib.
Abnormality of the thymus, an organ located in the upper anterior portion of the chest cavity just behind the sternum and whose main function is to provide an environment for T lymphocyte maturation.
Underdevelopment of the thymus.
The presence of calculi (stones) in the kidneys.
The presence of uric acid-containing calculi (stones) in the kidneys.
Abnormal fat accumulation in the kidneys.
Cysts of the cortex of the kidney.
An anomaly of the adnexa, uterus, and vagina (in female) or seminal tract and prostate (in male).
An abnormality of the thyroid gland.
Passing the age when puberty normally occurs with no physical or hormonal signs of the onset of puberty.
Passing the age when puberty normally occurs with no physical or hormonal signs of the onset of puberty.

The onset of secondary sexual characteristics before a normal age. Although it is difficult to define normal age ranges because of the marked variation with which puberty begins in normal children, precocious puberty can be defined as the onset of puberty before the age of 8 years in girls or 9 years in boys.
Developmental hypoplasia of the adrenal glands.
An abnormality of thyroid physiology characterized by excessive secretion of the thyroid hormones thyroxine (i.e., T4) and/or 3,3',5-triiodo-L-thyronine zwitterion (i.e., triiodothyronine or T3).
The presence of a adenoma of the thyroid gland.
The presence of a adenoma of the thyroid gland.
Increased width of ribs
A horizontal (flat) conformation of the ribs, the long curved bones that form the rib cage and normally progressively oblique (slanted) from ribs 1 through 9, then less slanted through rib 12.
Any abnormality of the clavicles (collar bones).
Reduced length of the clavicles.
Multiple circumscribed bony excrescences located in the ribs.
A row of beadlike prominences at the junction of a rib and its cartilage (i.e., enlarged costochondral joints), resembling a rosary.
Increased width (cross-sectional diameter) of the clavicles.
Increased width (cross-sectional diameter) of the clavicles.
Pectus carinatum affecting primarily the superior part of the sternum.
The presence of a row of multiple rounded expansions (beadlike prominences) at the junction of a rib and its cartilage.
An abnormality of the skeletal system.
Any abnormality of the vertebral column.
Underdevelopment of the ilium.
An abnormality of the skin.
A darkening of the skin related to an increase in melanin production and deposition.
A dermatosis characterized by thickened, hyperpigmented plaques, typically on the intertriginous surfaces and neck.
Skin characterized by the lack of natural or normal moisture.
A cutaneous indentation resulting from tethering of the skin to underlying structures (bone) of the intergluteal cleft.
Bluish discoloration of the skin and mucosa due to poor circulation or inadequate oxygenation of arterial or capillary blood.

A reticular discoloration of the skin with cyanotic (reddish-blue appearing) areas surrounding pale central areas due to dilation of capillary blood vessels and stagnation of blood within the vessels. Cutis marmorata, also called livedo reticularis, generally occurs on the legs, arms and trunk and is often more severe in cold weather.

A reticular discoloration of the skin with cyanotic (reddish-blue appearing) areas surrounding pale central areas due to dilation of capillary blood vessels and stagnation of blood within the vessels. Cutis marmorata, also called livedo reticularis, generally occurs on the legs, arms and trunk and is often more severe in cold weather.
Any structural abnormality of the sweat gland.
Wrinkled, redundant, inelastic and sagging skin.
A condition in which the skin can be stretched beyond normal, and then returns to its initial position.
Abnormal thickening of the skin of the palms of the hands and the soles of the feet.
The presence in the axillary region (armpit) of an increased number of freckles, small circular spots on the skin that are darker than the surrounding skin because of deposits of melanin.
Presence of an unusually high number of lentigines (singular: lentigo), which are flat, tan to brown oval spots.
A reduction of skin color related to a decrease in melanin production and deposition.

A vascular lesion defined histologically as one or more dilated blood vessels lying directly subepidermal and showing an epidermal proliferative reaction. Clinically, angiokeratoma presents as a small, raised, dark-red spot.
A type of pallor that is secondary to the presence of anemia.
The presence of subcutaneous lipoma.
Abnormal formation of the keratinocytes of the epidermis characterized by persistence of nuclei, incomplete formation of keratin, and moistness and swelling of the keratinocytes.
Redness of the skin of the face, caused by hyperemia of the capillaries in the lower layers of the skin.
Jaundice that is sometimes present, sometimes not.
A congenital vascular malformation consisting of superficial and deep dilated capillaries in the skin which produce a reddish to purplish discolouration of the skin.
A reduced ability to heal cutaneous wounds.
Presence of a cutaneous membrane (flap) in the armpit.
The presence of multiple cutaneous neurofibromas.
Laminar thickening of skin.
Scars that form a depression compared to the level of the surrounding skin because of damage to the collagen, fat or other tissues below the skin.
Any structural abnormality of the fundus of the eye.
Heterochromia iridis is a difference in the color of the iris in the two eyes.
A structural abnormality of the macula lutea, which is an oval-shaped highly pigmented yellow spot near the center of the retina.
Underdevelopment of the macula lutea.
Well-demarcated area(s) of partial or complete depigmentation in the fundus, reflecting atrophy of the retinal pigment epithelium with associated retinal photoreceptor loss.
An abnormal reduction in the amount of pigmentation (reduced or absent) of the iris and retina.

Cryptophthalmos is a condition of total absence of eyelids and the skin of forehead is continuous with that of cheek, in which the eyeball is completely concealed by the skin, which is stretched over the orbital cavity.
A polar cataract that affects the anterior pole of the lens.
A conical projection of the anterior or posterior surface of the lens, occurring as a developmental anomaly.

Fluid which has escaped from retinal blood vessels with a high concentration of lipid, protein, and cellular debris with a typically bright, reflective, white or cream colored appearance on the surface of the retina.

Fluid which has escaped from retinal blood vessels with a high concentration of lipid, protein, and cellular debris with a typically bright, reflective, white or cream colored appearance on the surface of the retina.

Digits that appear disproportionately short compared to the hand/foot. The word brachydactyly is used here to describe a series distinct patterns of shortened digits (brachydactyly types A-E). This is the sense used here.

For children from birth to 4 years of age the palm width is more than 2 SD above the mean; for children from 4 to 16 years of age the palm width is above the 95th centile; or, the width of the palm appears disproportionately wide for the length.
An abnormal structure of the first digit of the hand.
The gradual reduction in girth of the finger from proximal to distal.
A thumb with three phalanges in a single, proximo-distal axis. Thus, this term applies if the thumb has an accessory phalanx, leading to a digit like appearance of the thumb.
An abnormal structure of the tip (end) of a finger.
Spoon-shaped, broad thumbs.
An abnormality of the fingernails.
Syndactyly with fusion of fingers two and three.

Muscular hypotonia is an abnormally low muscle tone (the amount of tension or resistance to movement in a muscle), often involving reduced muscle strength. Hypotonia is characterized by a diminished resistance to passive stretching. Muscular hypotonia may be related to defects in skeletal muscle, neuromuscular junction, or peripheral nerve.
Spasticity and weakness of the leg and hip muscles.
Spasticity (neuromuscular hypertonia) primarily in the muscles of the legs, hips, and pelvis.
Involuntary movements characterized by both athetosis (inability to sustain muscles in a fixed position) and chorea (widespread jerky arrhythmic movements).
Abnormality of the corpus callosum.
A condition in which there is increased muscle tone so that arms or legs, for example, are stiff and difficult to move.
Diminution of tendon reflexes, which is an invariable sign of peripheral nerve disease.
Any structural abnormality of the cerebellum.
Underdevelopment of the cerebellum.
Reduced strength of muscles.
An abnormally increased muscular tone that causes fixed abnormal postures. There is a slow, intermittent twisting motion that leads to exaggerated turning and posture of the extremities and trunk.
Facial diplegia refers to bilateral facial palsy (bilateral facial palsy is much rarer than unilateral facial palsy).
Facial diplegia refers to bilateral facial palsy (bilateral facial palsy is much rarer than unilateral facial palsy).
Abnormal coordination of muscles involved in speech.
Holoprosencephaly is a structural anomaly of the brain in which the developing forebrain fails to divide into two separate hemispheres and ventricles.
Limited ability to straighten the arm at the elbow joint.
An abnormality of the hip joint.
Joint stiffness is a perceived sensation of tightness in a joint or joints when attempting to move them after a period of inactivity. Joint stiffness typically subsides over time.
Impairment of bile flow due to obstruction in bile ducts.
Increased pressure in the portal vein.
Reduced ability of the liver to perform its functions.

ET: Abnormality of the musculature of the hand

DEF: A structural abnormality of the abdomen ('belly'), that is, the part of the body between the pelvis and the thorax.
Syndactyly with fusion of toes one to three.
Separation of the vitreous humor from the retina.
Osteolysis affecting carpal bones.
Overgrowth of only one side of the body.
Protrusion of abdominal contents through a defect in the abdominal wall musculature around the umbilicus. Skin and subcutaneous tissue overlie the defect.
A separation of the rectus abdominis muscle into right and left halves (which are normally joined at the midline at the linea alba).
A separation of the rectus abdominis muscle into right and left halves (which are normally joined at the midline at the linea alba).
Anterior malposition of the anus.
Lack of symmetry between the left and right halves of the thorax.
Abnormality of the amniotic fluid, which is the fluid contained in the amniotic sac surrounding the developing fetus.
Diminished amniotic fluid volume in pregnancy.
An abnormality of the integument, which consists of the skin and the superficial fascia.
Loose and sagging skin often associated with loss of skin elasticity.
A form of nystagmus in which the eyeball makes rotary motions around the axis.
An abnormality of the hair.
An abnormality of the larynx.
Laryngomalacia is a congenital abnormality of the laryngeal cartilage in which the cartilage is floppy and prolapses over the larynx during inspiration.
The birth of a baby of less than 37 weeks of gestational age.
One or both of the leaflets (cusps) of the mitral valve bulges back into the left atrium upon contraction of the left ventricle.

A congenital cardiac malformation comprising pulmonary stenosis, overriding aorta, ventricular septum defect, and right ventricular hypertrophy. The diagnosis of TOF is made if at least three of the four above mentioned features are present.
A structural anomaly of the muscle layer of the heart wall.
A narrowing of the right ventricular outflow tract that can occur at the pulmonary valve (valvular stenosis) or just below the pulmonary valve (infundibular stenosis).
The heart suddenly and unexpectedly stops beating resulting in death within a short time period (generally within 1 h of symptom onset).
An abnormality of the mitral valve characterized by insufficiency or incompetence of the mitral valve resulting in retrograde leaking of blood through the mitral valve upon ventricular contraction.
Any structural abnormality of a cardiac valve.
Failure of the foramen ovale to seal postnatally, leaving a potential conduit between the left and right cardiac atria.
An insufficiency of the aortic valve, leading to regurgitation (backward flow) of blood from the aorta into the left ventricle.
A complex congenital heart defect in which the aorta arises from the morphologic right ventricle and the pulmonary artery arises from the morphologic left ventricle.
Reduction of the diameter of the coronary arteries as the result of an accumulation of atheromatous plaques within the walls of the coronary arteries, which increases the risk of myocardial ischemia.
Coarctation of the aorta is a narrowing or constriction of a segment of the aorta.
Paroxysmal chest pain that occurs with exertion or stress and is related to myocardial ischemia.

Myocardial fibrosis is characterized by dysregulated collagen turnover (increased synthesis predominates over unchanged or decreased degradation) and excessive diffuse collagen accumulation in the interstitial and perivascular spaces as well as by phenotypically transformed fibroblasts, termed myofibroblasts.
Pattern of blood flow in the heart that deviates from the normal circuit of the circulatory system.

One or more of the leaflets (cusps) of the tricuspid valve bulges back into the right atrium upon contraction of the right ventricle.
An abnormality of the right ventricle of the heart.
Any structural abnormality of the left ventricle of the heart.
An abnormality of a cardiac ventricle.
An abnormal narrowing of the orifice of the mitral valve.
An abnormal narrowing of the orifice of the mitral valve.
A progressive form of hearing impairment.
An abnormality of the morphology of the toes, such that the tips of the toes are prominent and bulbous.
An abnormality of the birth process.
The abnormal accumulation of fluid in two or more fetal compartments, including ascites, pleural effusion, pericardial effusion, and skin edema.
Underdevelopment of the toenail.
Underdevelopment of a fingernail.
Longitudinal, linear prominences in the nail plate.
Congenital occlusion of a tube in the genital tract.
The metatarsals are deviated medially (tibially), that is, the bones in the front half of the foot bend or turn in toward the body.
This term applies for all abnormalities of the big toe, also called hallux.
Describes a foot digit resting on the dorsal surface of an adjacent digit when the foot is at rest.
Describes a foot digit resting on the dorsal surface of an adjacent digit when the foot is at rest.
A reduction in the number of circulating thrombocytes.
A type of anemia caused by premature destruction of red blood cells (hemolysis).
An abnormal susceptibility to bleeding, often referred to as a bleeding diathesis. A bleeding diathesis may be related to vascular, platelet and coagulation defects.
A kind of anemia in which the volume of the red blood cells is normal.

Giant platelets are larger than 7 micrometers and usually 10 to 20 micrometers. The term giant platelet is used when the platelet is larger than the size of the average red cell in the field. (Description adapted from College of American Pathologists, Hematology Manual, 1998).

Giant platelets are larger than 7 micrometers and usually 10 to 20 micrometers. The term giant platelet is used when the platelet is larger than the size of the average red cell in the field. (Description adapted from College of American Pathologists, Hematology Manual, 1998).

The formation of a blood clot inside a blood vessel that subsequently travels through the blood stream from the site where it formed to another location in the body, generally leading to vascular occlusion at the distant site.

The formation of a blood clot inside a blood vessel that subsequently travels through the blood stream from the site where it formed to another location in the body, generally leading to vascular occlusion at the distant site.
Aplastic anemia is defined as pancytopenia with a hypocellular marrow.
Sudden loss of renal function, as manifested by decreased urine production, and a rise in serum creatinine or blood urea nitrogen concentration (azotemia).
The presence of stenosis of the renal artery.
An elevation in the number of reticulocytes (immature erythrocytes) in the peripheral blood circulation.
An abnormality of the process of blood coagulation. That is, altered ability or inability of the blood to clot.
A kind of anemia in which the volume of the red blood cells is reduced.

Glucose intolerance (GI) can be defined as dysglycemia that comprises both prediabetes and diabetes. It includes the conditions of impaired fasting glucose (IFG) and impaired glucose tolerance (IGT) and diabetes mellitus (DM).
Obesity located preferentially in the trunk of the body as opposed to the extremities.
Any anomaly of the scalp, the skin an subcutaneous tissue of the head on which head hair grows.
A malfunctioning of the spleen in which it prematurely destroys red blood cells.
A type of anemia characterized by increased size of erythrocytes with increased mean corpuscular volume (MCV) and increased mean corpuscular hemoglobin (MCH).
Reduced distance from the anterior border of the naris to the subnasale.
Reduced distance from the anterior border of the naris to the subnasale.
Bilateral bulging of the lateral frontal bone prominences with relative sparing of the midline.

Nausea is a commonly encountered symptom that has been defined as an unpleasant painless subjective feeling that one will imminently vomit. Vomiting has been defined as the forceful expulsion of the contents of the stomach, duodenum, or jejunum through the oral cavity. While nausea and vomiting are often thought to exist on a temporal continuum, this is not always the case. There are situations when severe nausea may be present without emesis and less frequently, when emesis may be present without preceding nausea.
A condition in which the stomach contents leak backwards from the stomach into the esophagus through the lower esophageal sphincter.
A structural abnormality of the esophagus.
An abnormaltiy of the rectum, the final segment of the large intestine that stores solid waste until it passes through the anus.
Protrusion of the rectal mucous membrane through the anus.
Inflammation, or an inflammatory state in the large intestine.
Extreme dilation of the submucusoal veins in the lower portion of the esophagus.
A pathological narrowing of the esophagus that is caused by the development of a ring of scar tissue that constricts the esophageal lumen.
Atrophy of the cortex of the kidney.
An abnormality of the glabella.
Forward protrusion of the glabella.
Any structural abnormality of the telencephalon, which is also known as the cerebrum.
Underdevelopment of the corpus callosum.
An abnormality of the pulmonary pleura, the thin, transparent membrane which covers the lungs and lines the inside of the chest walls.
Persistent abnormal dilatation of the bronchi owing to localized and irreversible destruction and widening of the large airways.
Periodic spells of incoordination and imbalance, that is, episodes of ataxia typically lasting from 10 minutes to several hours or days.\n
An abnormality of the spinal cord (myelon).
An abnormally decreased phosphate concentration in the blood.
An abnormally high level of uric acid in the blood.
An elevated concentration of glycine in the blood.
An increased concentration of nitrogen compounds in the blood.
A series of rhythmic and involuntary muscle contractions (at a frequency of about 5 to 7 Hz) that occur in response to an abruptly applied and sustained stretch.
Hemorrhage occurring within the skull.

A tendency to fall or the inability to keep oneself from falling; imbalance. The retropulsion test is widely regarded as the gold standard to evaluate postural instability, Use of the retropulsion test includes a rapid balance perturbation in the backward direction, and the number of balance correcting steps (or total absence thereof) is used to rate the degree of postural instability. Healthy subjects correct such perturbations with either one or two large steps, or without taking any steps, hinging rapidly at the hips while swinging the arms forward as a counterweight. In patients with balance impairment, balance correcting steps are often too small, forcing patients to take more than two steps. Taking three or more steps is generally considered to be abnormal, and taking more than five steps is regarded as being clearly abnormal. Markedly affected patients continue to step backward without ever regaining their balance and must be caught by the examiner (this would be called true retropulsion). Even more severely affected patients fail to correct entirely, and fall backward like a pushed toy soldier, without taking any corrective steps.
A type of tremors that is triggered by holding a limb in a fixed position.
A type of tremors that is triggered by holding a limb in a fixed position.
Spasticity that increases in degree with time.

A generalized-onset seizure is a type of seizure originating at some point within, and rapidly engaging, bilaterally distributed networks. The networks may include cortical and subcortical structures but not necessarily the entire cortex.
The presence of an excessive amount of fluid in the pleural cavity.
A triangular depigmented region of white hairs located in the anterior midline of the scalp.
Excessive, increased hair growth located in the facial region.

The term woolly hair refers to an abnormal variant of hair that is fine, with tightly coiled curls, and often hypopigmented. Optical microscopy may reveal the presence of tight spirals and a clear diameter reduction as compared with normal hair. Electron microscopy may show flat, oval hair shafts with reduced transversal diameter.
White color (lack of pigmentation) of the eyelashes.
Abnormally increased hair growth over much of the entire body.
Transient, non-scarring hair loss and preservation of the hair follicle located in in well-defined patches.
Uncombable hair.
An abnormality of the small intestine.
Any abnormality of the large intestine.
The presence of multiple diverticula of the colon.
Repeated episodes of diarrhea separated by periods without diarrhea.
An abnormality resulting from a lesion of the sympathetic nervous system characterized by a combination of unilateral ptosis, miosis, and often ipsilateral hypohidrosis and conjunctival injection.
An abnormality resulting from a lesion of the sympathetic nervous system characterized by a combination of unilateral ptosis, miosis, and often ipsilateral hypohidrosis and conjunctival injection.
Progressive loss of hair.
Absence of hair in the anterior midline and/or parietal areas.
Absence of hair in the anterior midline and/or parietal areas.

A slow, continuous, involuntary writhing movement that prevents maintenance of a stable posture. Athetosis involves continuous smooth movements that appear random and are not composed of recognizable sub-movements or movement fragments. In contrast to chorea, in athetosis, the same regions of the body are repeatedly involved. Athetosis may worsen with attempts at movement of posture, but athetosis can also occur at rest.
A resting tremor occurs when muscles are at rest and becomes less noticeable or disappears when the affected muscles are moved. Resting tremors are often slow and coarse.
A defect of development of the brain characterized by replacement of greater portions of the cerebral hemispheres and the corpus striatum by cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) and glial tissue.
Attacks of disabling daytime drowsiness and low alertness.
Abnormality observed by electroencephalogram (EEG), which is used to record of the brain's spontaneous electrical activity from multiple electrodes placed on the scalp.
Underdevelopment of the brainstem.
Weakness or partial paralysis in the lower limbs.

A type of rigidity in which a muscle responds with cogwheellike jerks to the use of constant force in bending the limb (i.e., it gives way in little, repeated jerks when the muscle is passively stretched).

Cerebral cysts, usually located in the wall of the caudate nucleus or in the caudothalamic groove. They are found in up to 5.2% of all neonates, using transfontanellar ultrasound in the first days of life.
Impairment of expressive language and relative preservation of receptive language abilities. That is, the patient understands language (speech, writing) but cannot express it.
A herniation of meninges through a congenital bone defect in the skull in the occipital region.
Reduced strength of the musculature of the distal extremities.
Protrusion of the meninges and portions of the spinal cord through a defect of the vertebral column.
An involuntary and painless delay in the relaxation of skeletal muscle following contraction or electrical stimulation.

A clonal (malignant) hematopoietic disorder with an acute onset, affecting the bone marrow and the peripheral blood. The malignant cells show minimal differentiation and are called blasts, either myeloid blasts (myeloblasts) or lymphoid blasts (lymphoblasts).
Spasticity of one or more muscles innervated by the facial nerve.

A decrease in the ability to perceive vibration. Clinically, this is usually tested with a tuning fork which vibrates at 128 Hz and is applied to bony prominences such as the malleoli at the ankles or the metacarpal-phalangeal joints. There is a slow decay of vibration from the tuning fork. The degree of vibratory sense loss can be crudely estimated by counting the number of seconds that the examiner can perceive the vibration longer than the patient.

A developmental structural anomaly of the stalk-like part of the brain that comprises the midbrain (aka mesencephalon), the pons (aka pons Varolii), and the medulla oblongata, and connects the cerebral hemispheres with the cervical spinal cord.
The presence of calcium deposition within brain structures.
Inability to elicit tendon reflexes in the lower limbs.
Involuntary flexion or extension of the arms and legs.
The presence of developmental dysplasia of the cerebral cortex.
A form of torticollis in which the head is drawn back, either due to a permanent contractures of neck extensor muscles, or to a spasmodic contracture.
Developmental dysplasia of the hair.
Developmental dysplasia of the hair.
Underdevelopment of the nipple.
Placement of the nipples at a lower than normal location.

An abnormality of the intestinal rotation and fixation that normally occurs during the development of the gut. This can lead to volvulus, or twisting of the intestine that causes obstruction and necrosis.

A disorder of esophageal motility characterized by the inability of the lower esophageal sphincter to relax during swallowing and by inadequate or lacking peristalsis in the lower half of the body of the esophagus.
An abnormal connection (fistula) between the esophagus and the trachea.
An abnormality of the intestine in which part of the intestine invaginates (telescopes) into another part of the intestine.
Decreased strength of the muscle layer of stomach, which leads to a decreased ability to empty the contents of the stomach despite the absence of obstruction.
An abnormality of the peritoneum.
Vomiting that ejects the gastric contents with great force.
An abnormality of the vasculature.
A head tremor of moderate speed (3 to 4 Hz) in the anterior-posterior direction.

A condition characterized by patchy atheromas or atherosclerotic plaques which develop in the walls of medium-sized and large arteries and can lead to arterial stenosis with reduced or blocked blood flow.

A condition characterized by patchy atheromas or atherosclerotic plaques which develop in the walls of medium-sized and large arteries and can lead to arterial stenosis with reduced or blocked blood flow.

An overriding aorta is a congenital heart defect where the aorta is positioned directly over a ventricular septal defect, instead of over the left ventricle. The result is that the aorta receives some blood from the right ventricle, which reduces the amount of oxygen in the blood. It is one of the four conditions of the Tetralogy of Fallot. The aortic root can be displaced toward the front (anteriorly) or directly above the septal defect, but it is always abnormally located to the right of the root of the pulmonary artery. The degree of override is quite variable, with 5-95% of the valve being connected to the right ventricle.
Abnormal outpouching or sac-like dilatation in an artery that originates from he abdominal aorta.
Aortic dissection refers to a tear in the intimal layer of the aorta causing a separation between the intima and the medial layers of the aorta.
A general term describing features characterized by abnormal development of bones and connective tissues.

Pheochromocytomas (also known as chromaffin tumors) produce, store, and secrete catecholamines. Pheochromocytomas usually originate from the adrenal medulla but may also develop from chromaffin cells in or about sympathetic ganglia. A common symptom of pheochromocytoma is hypertension owing to release of catecholamines.

A carotid body tumor (also called paraganglionoma or chemodectoma) is a tumor found in the upper neck at the branching of the carotid artery. They arise from the chemoreceptor organ (paraganglion) located in the adventitia of the carotid artery bifurcation.
The presence of a basal cell carcinoma of the skin.
An abnormal narrowing of the foramen magnum.
Aplasia of frontal sinus.
Aplasia of the paranasal sinuses.

A developmental malformation of the occipital bone and upper end of the cervical spine, in which the latter appears to have pushed the floor of the occipital bone upward such that there is an abnormal flattening of the skull base.
Any abnormality of the foramen magnum.
An abnormal increase in the size of the foramen magnum.
Enlargment (swelling) of a lymph node.
Lymphadenopathy (enlargement of lymph nodes) owing to hyperplasia of follicular (germinal) centers.
Abnormal thinning of the cortical region of bones.
The repeated occurrence of bone fractures (implying an abnormally increased tendency for fracture).
A structural anomaly of the trachea.
Increased resistance to the passage of air in the upper airway.
Calcification (abnormal deposits of calcium) in the tracheal tissues.
A reduction in the amount of air transported into the pulmonary alveoli by breathing, leading to hypercapnia (increase in the partial pressure of carbon dioxide).

An abnormal reduction on the vital capacity, which is defined as the total lung capacity (volume of air in the lungs at maximal inflation) less the residual volume (i.e., volume of air in the lungs following maximal exhalation) of the lung.
An abnormality of the leg.
An abnormally increased extension of the knee joint, so that the knee can bend backwards.
An abnormality of the arm.
An abnormality of the radius.
The presence of a tail-like skin appendage located adjacent to the sacrum.

An anomalous radiographic appearance of the developing pelvis, in which the greater ischiadic noth (incisura ischiadica major) is shallow and the pelvis takes on the appearance said to resemble a halberd (a weapon especially of the 15th and 16th centuries consisting typically of a battle-ax and pike mounted on a handle).
Displacement of the femur from its normal location in the hip joint.
Displacement of the femur from its normal location in the hip joint.
An abnormal punctate (speckled, dot-like) pattern of calcifications in soft tissues within or surrounding bones (as observed on radiographs).
Eversion of the posterior bladder wall through the congenitally absent lower anterior abdominal wall and anterior bladder wall.
Inflammation of a lymph node.
The presence of squamous cell carcinoma of the skin.
Clonal hematopoietic stem cell disorders characterized by dysplasia (ineffective production) in one or more hematopoietic cell lineages, leading to anemia and cytopenia.
An abnormality of the ilium, the largest and uppermost bone of the pelvis.
Decreased width of the wing (or ala) of the ilium (which is the large expanded portion which bounds the greater pelvis laterally).
Abnormally increased variability of the size of the vertebral bodies.

A rapidly growing embryonic tumor arising in the posterior part of the cerebellar vermis and neuroepithelial roof of the fourth ventricle in children. More rarely, medulloblastoma arises in the cerebellum in adults.
A benign epithelial tumor derived from intrinsic cells of the adenohypophysis.
An abnormally increased phosphate concentration in the blood.
An abnormally increased magnesium concentration in the blood.
An abnormality of the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF).
Decreased height of the intervertebral disk.
A developmental defect leading to the union of two adjacent vertebrae.
An abnormality of the lower arm.
An abnormal osseous union (fusion) between the radius and the ulna.
Bowing (abnormal curvature) of the femur.
An abnormality of the calf, i.e. of the posterior part of the lower leg.
Underdevelopment of the radius.
A chronic loss of elbow joint motion due to structural changes in muscle, tendons, ligaments, or skin that prevent normal movement of the joints of the elbow.
Absence of the fibula.
Absence of the fibula.
An anomaly of the calf bone (fibula), one of the two bones of the calf.
Abnormality of the tibia (shinbone).
An abnormality of the ulna bone of the forearm.
The kneecap normally is located within the groove termed trochlea on the distal femur and can slide up and down in it. Patellar dislocation occurs if the patella fully dislocates out of the groove.
Abnormal widening of the metaphyseal regions of long bones.
Underdevelopment of the ulna.
One or more abnormally short long bone.
One or more abnormally short long bone.
Increase in size of one or more joints.
Increase in size of one or more joints.
Underdevelopment of the fibula.
Chronic reduction in active and passive mobility of the shoulder joint due to structural changes in muscle, tendons, ligaments, or skin that prevents normal movement.
Abnormal flatness (decreased height) of epiphyses.
Reduction in the concentration of albumin in the blood.
A decreased concentration of protein in the blood.
A dislocation of the head of the radius from its socket in the elbow joint.
An increased tendency to fractures of the long bones (Mainly, the femur, tibia, fibula, humerus, radius, and ulna).
An abnormal shortening of the femur.
Relatively increased growth of the fibula compared to that of the tibia.
Reduced diameter of a long bone.
An increased concentration of glycine in the urine.
An abnormality of the composition of urine or the levels of its components.
Abnormal rhythm of the heart.
An abnormality detectable by sonography of the heart (echocardiography).
An abnormal buildup of lactic acid in the body, leading to acidification of the blood and other bodily fluids.
An increased concentration of cystine in the urine.
An increased concentration of proline in the urine.
An abnormally high level of uric acid in the urine.
An anomaly of the the pubic bone, i.e., of the ventral and anterior of the three principal components (publis, ilium, ischium) of the hip bone.
Underdevelopment of the pubis, which together with the ilium and the ischium, is one of the three bones that make up the hip bone.
An anomaly of the ischium, which forms the lower and back part of the hip bone.
Underdevelopment of the ischium, which forms the lower and back part of the hip bone.
A shift from the normally round (convex) appearance of the iliac wing towards a square-like appearance.
Intrapelvic bulging of the medial acetabular wall.
Underdevelopment of the breast.
A disorder of muscle unrelated to impairment of innervation or neuromuscular junction.
Breakdown of muscle fibers that leads to the release of muscle fiber contents (myoglobin) into the bloodstream.
Pathological deposition of calcium salts in one or more arteries.
An abnormality of the hip bone.
A benign growth the projects outward from the bone surface of the pelvis. Exostoses are capped by cartilage, and arise from a bone that develops from cartilage.
An abnormally squared appearance of the bony pelvis, a normally rounded or basin-shaped structure.
An increased concentration of lysine in the urine.
When viewed in lateral radiographs, vertebral bodies have a roughly rectangular configuration. This term applies if the vertebral body appears rounded or oval.
Spondylolysis is an osseous defect of the pars interarticularis, thought to be a developmental or acquired stress fracture secondary to chronic low-grade trauma.
Congenital synostosis between two or more adjacent vertebrae (partial or complete fusion of adjacent vertabral bodies).
Reduced ability to move the vertebral column with a resulting limitation of neck and trunk flexion.
A partial dislocation of one or more intervertebral joints in the cervical vertebral column.

A butterfly vertebra (sagittal cleft vertebra or anterior rachischisis) is a sagittal defect in the vertebral body caused by failure of fusion of the two lateral chondrification centers during embryogenesis. The name is based on the appearance of the two hemivertebrae emerging as butterfly wings from the central cleft on x-ray.
Any abnormality of the cervical vertebral column.
Weakness of the limb-girdle muscles (also known as the pelvic and shoulder girdles), that is, lack of strength of the muscles around the shoulders and the pelvis.
Reduced strength of the axial musculature (i.e., of the muscles of the head and neck, spine, and ribs).
Any anomaly in the composite material or the layered arrangement of the bony skeleton.
The formation of bullae (blisters) with cleavage in the lamina lucida layer of the skin.
An increased concentration of alanine in the blood.
An increased concentration of an amino acid in the urine.
A phenomenon whereby patients are not able to stand up without the use of the hands owing to weakness of the proximal muscles of the lower limbs.
Sudden and involuntary contractions of one or more muscles.
Dilated, glial-lined cavity in spinal cord. This cavity does not communicate with the central canal, and usually is between the dorsal columns unilaterally or bilaterally along the side of the cord.
An anomaly of the atlantoaxial joint, i.e., of the joint between the first (atlas) and second (axis) cervical vertebrae.
Partial dislocation of the atlantoaxial joint.
An abnormal narrowing of the spinal canal.
Frontal schisis (cleft or cleavage) of vertebral bodies.
Abnormal results of investigations using electromyography (EMG).
Abnormal results of investigations using electromyography (EMG).
An abnormality of one or more of the vertebrae.
A type of weakness that occurs after a muscle group is used and lessens if the muscle group has some rest. That is, there is diminution of strength with repetitive muscle actions.
Weakness of the muscles of the arms.
An abnormally low level of uric acid in the blood.
A functional motor deficit where individuals whose responses to the challenges of exercise fail to achieve levels considered normal for their age and gender.

The shoulder, or pectoral, girdle is composed of the clavicles and the scapulae. Shoulder-girdle weakness refers to lack of strength of the muscles attaching to these bones, that is, lack of strength of the muscles around the shoulders.

Fiber splitting or branching is a common finding in human and rat skeletal muscle pathology. Fiber splitting refers to longitudinal halving of the complete fiber, while branching originates from a regenerating end of a necrotic fiber as invaginations of the sarcolemma. In fiber branching, one end of the fiber remains intact as a single entity, while the other end has several branches.

An increased erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR). The ESR a test that measures the distance that erythrocytes have fallen after one hour in a vertical column of anticoagulated blood under the influence of gravity. The ESR is a nonspecific finding. An elevation may indicate inflammation or may be caused by any condition that elevates fibrinogen.

JT: 潜行性|開始OR発生ORオンセットOR発症OR発病OR作用発現
DEF: Gradual, very slow onset of disease manifestations.

JT: 乳児性OR乳児OR小児性OR小児型|開始OR発生ORオンセットOR発症OR発病OR作用発現
DEF: Onset of signs or symptoms of disease between 28 days to one year of life.

Metachromasia (also known as metachromacy) is a characteristic color change which certain aniline dyes exhibit when bound to particular substances or when concentrated in solution. For example, the basic dye toluidine blue becomes distinctly pink when bound to cartilage matrix. In the sense used here, the metachromasia refers to a change in color not observed with normal tissues, anomalous staining with the cationic dyes toluidine blue O and Alcian blue resulting from excessive amounts of the polyanionic glycosaminoglycans.
Reduced strength and weakness of the muscles of the arms and legs.
Abnormal protrusion of the scapula away from the surface of the back.
Muscular atrophy affecting muscles in the distal portions of the extremities.
A lack of strength of the proximal muscles.
Abnormal cell death involving muscle fibers usually associated with break in, or absence of, muscle surface fiber membrane and resulting in irreversible damage to muscle fibers.
Episodes of muscle weakness.
A body habitus that is tall, slim and underweight, with long legs and long arms (i.e., arm span exceeds height by 5 cm or more).
Muscular atrophy affecting the muscles of the limb girdle.

Nemaline rods are abnormal bodies that can occur in skeletal muscle fibers. The rods can be observed on histological analysis of muscle biopsy tissue or upon electron microscopy, where they appear either as extensions of sarcomeric Z-lines, in random array without obvious attachment to Z-lines (often in areas devoid of sarcomeres) or in large clusters localized at the sarcolemma or intermyofibrillar spaces.

Presence of abnormal vacuoles (membrane-bound organelles) in the sarcolemma. On histological staining with hematoxylin and eosin, rimmed vacuoles are popcorn-like clear vacuoles with a densely blue rim. The vacuoles are often associated with cytoplasmic and occasionally intranuclear eosinophilic inclusions.

Presence of abnormal vacuoles (membrane-bound organelles) in the sarcolemma. On histological staining with hematoxylin and eosin, rimmed vacuoles are popcorn-like clear vacuoles with a densely blue rim. The vacuoles are often associated with cytoplasmic and occasionally intranuclear eosinophilic inclusions.
Death within the first 28 days of life.
Missing humerus bone associated with congenital failure of development.
Reduction in diameter of the humerus.
Reduction in diameter of the humerus.
Absence of one or more forearm bones associated with congenital failure of development.
Bone fracture in the radius, ulna, or wrist.
Increased width of the radius.
Increased width of the ulna.
An injury of the wrist with displacement of any of the eight carpal bones.
Osteosclerosis affecting one or more bones of the hand.
Fusion of the hands and feet by a thin membrane of skin (scarring) seen in forms of dystrophic epidermolysis bullosa and leading to a \
Wrist is bent inward toward the thumb because of a congenital defect associated with shortening or absence of the radius.
This term groups together three conditions that presumably represent different degrees of severity of a midline defect of the nose or nasal tip.
An abnormal indentation of the skin in the region of the nasal tip.
Underdevelopment of the trapezium.

ET: Synostosis involving bones of the hand
DEF: An abnormal union between bones or parts of bones of the hand.
The presence of any abnormality affecting the abdominal wall.
Involuntary contractions of muscle leading to involuntary movements of extremities, neck, trunk, or face.
The presence of a fistula of the vagina.
The presence of a fistula connecting the urinary bladder to another organ or the skin. The fistula can involve the bowel, the vagina, or rarely, the skin.
An abnormal increase or decrease of weight or an abnormal distribution of mass in the body.

Reduced function of the muscles required to generate subatmospheric pressure in the thoracic cavity during breathing: the diaphragm, the external intercostal and the interchondral part of the internal intercostal muscles.
An abnormality of glycolysis.
A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the nervous system.
Abnormality of the anal canal.
Underdevelopment of the left side of the heart. May include atresia of the aortic or mitral orifice and hypoplasia of the ascending aorta.
An inflammation of the colon and small intestine. However, most conditions are either categorized as Enteritis (inflammation of the small intestine) or Colitis (inflammation of the large intestine).
