Abnormal displacement or malposition of the anus.
An ulcer of the gastrointestinal tract.
An abnormality of the pylorus.
An abnormality of the nipple.

ET: Abnormality of the sense of smell
DEF: An anomaly in the ability to perceive and distinguish scents (odors).
Positioning of the nasal septum to the right or left in contrast to the normal midline position of the nasal septum.
An abnormal narrowing or constriction of the pulmonary artery, in the main pulmonary artery and/or in the left or right pulmonary artery branches.

Intermittent claudication is a symptom of peripheral arterial occlusive disease. After having walked over a distance which is individually characteristic, the patients experience pain or cramps in the calves, feet or thighs which typically subsides on standing still.
The formation of a blood clot inside an artery.
An abnormality of the cheek- one of two bilateral soft tissue facial structures in the region of the face inferior to the eyes and between the nose and the ear. \
An immunodeficiency defined by the absent or suboptimal functioning of one of the complement system proteins.

Hepatic failure refers to the inability of the liver to perform its normal synthetic and metabolic functions, which can result in coagulopathy and alteration in the mental status of a previously healthy individual. Hepatic failure is defined as fulminant if there is onset of encephalopathy within 4 weeks of the onset of symptoms in a patient with a previously healthy liver.
The presence of a dilated inner part of external acoustic meatus.
Benign congenital lesion of the postauricular soft tissue consisting of a blind-ending narrow tube or pit.
Small indentation anterior to the insertion of the ear.
Hyperostosis (bony overgrowth) of the mandible.
The progressive development of an abnormally large skull.

A relatively mild degree of macrocephaly in which the head circumference is not above two standard deviations from the mean, but appears dysproportionately large when other factors such as body stature are taken into account.
Stagnation of head growth seen as flattening of the head circumference curve.
An abnormality of the shape of the thoracic vertebra T11 such that it is wedge-shaped (narrow towards the front).
Over curvature of the lower thoracic region, leading to a round back or if sever to a hump.
Underdevelopment of the nasal bone.
Reduced strength of the frontalis muscle (which is located on the forehead).
A reduced degree of voluntary and involuntary facial movements involved in responded to others or expressing emotions.
Syndactyly with fusion of toes two and three.
Syndactyly with fusion of toes four and five.
An abnormality of the normal developmental rotation of the kidney leading to an abnormal orientation of the kidney.
Supraventricular tachycardia (SVT) is an abnormally increased heart rate (over 100 beats per minute at rest) with origin above the level of the ventricles.
A tachycardia originating in the ventricles characterized by rapid heart rate (over 100 beats per minute) and broad QRS complexes (over 120 ms).
An inability to digest lactose.
Underdevelopment of the small intestine.
The presence of a fistula between the perineum and the rectum.
Lack of strength of the intercostal muscles, i.e., of the muscle groups running along the ribs that create and move the chest wall.
An abnormal widening of the diameter of the pulmonary artery.
Abnormal calcification of the vasculature.
A congenital anomaly with a narrowing or complete absence of the opening between the right ventricle and the pulmonary artery.
Formation of a blood clot (thrombus) inside a vein, causing the obstruction of blood flow.

Aortic dilatation refers to a dimension that is greater than the 95th percentile for the normal person age, sex and body size. In contrast, an aneurysm is defined as a localized dilation of the aorta that is more than 150 percent of predicted (ratio of observed to expected diameter 1.5 or more). Aneurysm should be distinguished from ectasia, which represents a diffuse dilation of the aorta less than 50 percent of normal aorta diameter.
The presence of a localized dilatation or ballooning of a cerebral artery.
A rare vascular anomaly with a direct communication between pulmonary artery and pulmonary vein without an intervening capillary bed.
A congenital defect with aplasia (absence) of one of the right or left pulmonary artery.
Reduction in density of metaphyseal bony tissue.
An abnormality of the sacral bone.
Any structural abnormality of a cardiac atrium.
Compression of the heart caused by rigid, thickened, or fused pericardial membranes.
An abnormality of the T wave on the electrocardiogram, which mainly represents the repolarization of the ventricles.
Abnormal narrowing of the coronary artery.
Underdeveloped, small left heart atrium
An abnormal increase in magnitude of the pressure in the right atrium.
Failure of the tricuspid valve to close sufficiently upon contraction of the right ventricle, causing blood to regurgitate (flow backward) into the right atrium.
Watery voluminous diarrhea resulting from an imbalance between ion and water secretion and absorption.
Underdevelopment of the colon.
An abnormal reduction in the ability to masticate (chew), i.e., in the ability to crush and ground food in preparation for swallowing.
The presence of a hypoplastic gallbladder.
A developmental defect resulting in abnormal closure, or atresia of the tubular structure of the jejunum.
The presence of degenerative changes of the liver.
An abnormality of the gallbladder.
An abnormality of the jejunum, i.e., of the middle section of the small intestine.
A discrete abnormal tissue mass that protrudes into the lumen of the intestine and is attached to the intestinal wall either by a stalk, pedunculus, or a broad base.
Abnormality of the nostril.
Abnormal tortuous (i.e., twisted) form of the carotid arteries.
Inflammation of the blood vessels within the brain.
An abnormality of the gestures or movements executed with the facial muscles with which emotions such as fear, joy, sadness, surprise, and disgust can be expressed.
Underdevelopment of the philtrum.
Underdevelopment of the urinary bladder.
Inspiratory stridor is a high pitched sound upon inspiration that is generally related to laryngeal abnormalities.
Absence of the thymus. This feature may be appreciated by the lack of a thymic shadow upon radiographic examination.
Lack (aplasia) of the ethmoidal sinus.
Excessive growth (overgrowth) of the facial bones, that is of the facial skeleton.
Reduced convexity of the occiput (posterior part of skull).
Head circumference which falls below 2 standard deviations below the mean for age and gender because of insufficient head growth after birth.
A fontanelle that is small for age.
The postnatal development of an abnormally large skull (macrocephaly).

A slowly progressing leukemia characterized by a clonal (malignant) proliferation of maturing and mature myeloid cells or mature lymphocytes. When the clonal cellular population is composed of myeloid cells, the process is called chronic myelogenous leukemia. When the clonal cellular population is composed of lymphocytes, it is classified as chronic lymphocytic leukemia, hairy cell leukemia, or T-cell large granular lymphocyte leukemia.
The presence of a bilobed gallbladder, related to a duplication of the gallbladder primordium.

An abnormally increased rate of skeletal maturation. Accelerated skeletal maturation can be diagnosed on the basis of an estimation of the bone age from radiographs of specific bones in the human body.
Hyperconvexity of the thoracolumbar spine producing a rounded or humped appearance.
A foot deformity resulting due to an abnormality affecting the muscle and soft tissue. In contrast if the bones of the foot are affected the term structural foot deformity applies.
Separation of the odontoid process from the body of the axis.
An abnormality of the hand resulting from contracture of the palmar fascia with a fixed flexion deformity of the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joints and the proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints.
Increased mobility and flexibility in the joint due to the tension in tissues such as ligaments and muscles.
The ability of the thumb joints to move beyond their normal range of motion.
Abnormal elevation of the floor of the posterior fossa including occipital condyles and foramen magnum.
Underdevelopment of the humerus.
Aplasia (absence) of the distal phalanges.
One or more bent (flexed) toe joints that cannot be straightened actively or passively.

A pathologic entity characterized by a developmental defect in a long bone leading to bending and pathologic fracture, with inability to form a normal bony callus with subsequent fibrous nonunion, leading to the pseudarthrosis (or \
The presence of an abnormal curvature of the cervical vertebral column.
Atresia of the biliary tree.
Abnormalities affecting the phalanx of finger.
Any structural anomaly of the hand.

ET: Abnormalities of the diaphyses of the hand

DEF: An anomaly of epiphysis, which is the expanded articular end of a long bone that developes from a secondary ossification center, and which during the period of growth is either entirely cartilaginous or is separated from the shaft by a cartilaginous disk.
A membrane-like structure that extends across the laryngeal lumen close to the level of the vocal cords.
An impairment of gluconeogenesis.
A decreased concentration of arginine in the blood.
Disordered thermoregulation characterized by an impaired ability to maintain a balance between heat production and heat loss, with resulting instability of body temperature.
Increased side-to-side width of one or more phalanges of the fingers or toes.
Syndactyly with fusion of fingers three and four.
Decreased width of the metacarpal bones (that is, reduced diameter).
Reduced size of the placenta.
Increased size of the placenta.
Intermittently increased size of the spleen.
Premature tooth eruption, which can be defined as tooth eruption more than 2 SD earlier than the mean eruption age.
Agenesis of one or more central incisors, i.e., of lower secondary incisor, lower primary incisor, upper secondary incisor, or of upper central primary incisor.
An abnormality of tooth eruption.
A generalized form of microdontia.
Increased space between the primary teeth. Note this phenotype should be distinguished from increased space due purely to microdontia.
Developmental hypoplasia of the primary teeth.
Decreased size of the primary teeth.
Obliteration of the pulp chambers owing to mineralization of the dental pulp.
Developmental hypoplasia of the tooth germ, i.e., of the structure that forms in odontogenesis that will develop into a tooth.
A bent (flexed) knee joint that cannot be straightened actively or passively.
Absent or nearly absent fibula. (Does not include aplastic)

Radial dysplasia, also known as radial longitudinal deficiency, includes radial clubhand and is a disfiguring, and potentially disabling, congenital limb anomaly. The entire upper limb may be involved, although the defect is most evident in the forearm and hand. Affected children suffer a variable degree of hypoplasia or absence of the preaxial skeleton and soft tissues, in particular the thumb, radius, and dorsoradial soft tissues. The hand is usually radially deviated and subluxated off the distal aspect of the ulna, the ulna may be shortened and have a bow-shaped deformity, and there is no true wrist (radiocarpal) joint in Bayne2 type-III and IV radial dysplasia.
A chronic loss of ankle joint motion due to structural changes in muscle, tendons, ligaments, or skin that prevent normal movement of the joints of the ankle.
A limitation of the range of movement of the shoulder joint.
An abnormality of the dental pulp.
Any abnormality of the primary tooth.
An abnormality of the morphology of the tooth.
Agenesis of incisor.
An abnormality of the dental root.
A bending or abnormal curvature of a long bone.
Adenocarcinoma of the Bronchus.

According to the definitions of the American and British Thoracic Societies, including pulmonary functional tests, X-rays, and CT scans for items such as fibrosis, bronchiectasis, bullae, emphysema, nodular or lymphomatous abnormalities.
An increased susceptibility to pneumonia as manifested by a history of recurrent episodes of pneumonia.

Hepatic failure refers to the inability of the liver to perform its normal synthetic and metabolic functions, which can result in coagulopathy and alteration in the mental status of a previously healthy individual. Hepatic failure is defined as acute if there is onset of encephalopathy within 8 weeks of the onset of symptoms in a patient with a previously healthy liver.
Hyperplasia of the biliary tree, as manifested by increased size of bile ducts, dilated lumen, and histologically by an increased number of epithelial cells or hyperplasia.
Inflammation of the liver due to infection with a virus.

ET: Malformation of the hepatic ductal plate

DEF: Intermittently increased size of the liver.
An acute form of hepatic steatosis.
Fibroblast proliferation and fiber expansion from the portal areas to the lobule.
Fibroblast proliferation and fiber expansion from the portal areas to the lobule.
The presence of a paralyzed diaphragm.
Absence of the clavicles as a developmental defect.
Calcium deposition in the myocardium.
Steatosis in the myocardium.
A defect of the atrioventricular septum of the heart.
The presence of an adenoma in the cortex of the kidney.
A malignant neoplasm of the adrenal cortex that may produce hormones such as cortisol, aldosterone, estrogen, or testosterone.
A subtype of renal cell carcinoma thought to originate from mature renal tubular cells in the proximal tubule of the nehpron.
A malignant epithelial tumor with a glandular organization that originates in the duodenum.
A malignancy of the parathyroid glands. Parathyroid carcinoma usually secretes parathyroid hormone, leading to hyperparathyroidism.
Absence of the knee jerk reflex, which can normally be elicited by tapping the patellar tendon with a reflex hammer just below the patella.
Underdevelopment of the cerebrum.
Atrophy affecting the pons and the cerebellum.
Stiffness (a condition in which muscles cannot be moved quickly without accompanying pain or spasm) of the axial musculature.
Nystagmus dating from or present at birth.
A type of encephalopathy (brain disease, damage, or malfunction accompanied by an altered mental state) that is characterized by evidence of necrosis of brain tissue.

Dysplasia and dysgenesis of the corpus callosum are nonspecific descriptions that imply defective development of the corpus callosum. The term dysplasia is applied when the morphology of the corpus callosum is altered as a congenital trait. For instance, the corpus callosum may be hump-shaped, kinked, or a striped corpus callosum that lacks an anatomically distinct genu and splenium.
Inability to perceive painful stimuli.

Bilateral impairment of the function of the cranial nerves 9-12, which control musculature involved in eating, swallowing, and speech. Pseudobulbar paralysis is characterized clinically by dysarthria, dysphonia, and dysphagia with bifacial paralysis, and may be accompanied by Pseudobulbar behavioral symptoms such as enforced crying and laughing.

The presence of dysplasia (abnormal growth or development) of the cerebellum. Cerebellar dysplasia is a neuroimaging finding that describes abnormalities of both the cerebellar cortex and white matter and is associated with variable neurodevelopmental outcome.
Partial or complete wasting (loss) of dentate nucleus.
Increased vertical dimension of the corpus callosum. This feature can be visualized by sagittal sections on magnetic resonance tomography imaging of the brain.
Amyotrophy (muscular atrophy) affecting the proximal musculature.
Neurodegeneration involving the globus pallidus,a part of the basal ganglia that is involved in the regulation of voluntary movement.

Atrophy of the interosseus muscles (including the palmar interossei that lie on the anterior aspect of the metacarpals, the dorsal interosseus muscles of the hand, which lie between the intercarpals, the plantar interosseus muscles, which lie underneath the metatarsal bones, and the dorsal interossei, which are located between the metatarsal bones.
A congenital absence of the convolutions of the cerebral cortex and a poorly formed sylvian fissure that affects a particular part of the cortex.
Enlargement of all or parts of one cerebral hemisphere.
Muscular atrophy affecting the lower limb.
A discrete posterior fossa cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) collection that does not communicate directly with the fourth ventricle.
Recurrent episodes of brain dysfunction that may be triggered by factors such as metabolic disturbances or infections.
Weakness of the muscles of the legs.

A focal-onset seizure is a type of seizure originating within networks limited to one hemisphere. They may be discretely localized or more widely distributed, and may originate in subcortical structures.
Underdevelopment of the sweat glands.
Well-demarcated area(s) of partial or complete depigmentation in the macula, reflecting atrophy of the retinal pigment epithelium with associated retinal photoreceptor loss.
An abnormally increased perspiration on palms and soles.
Spontaneous development of hematomas (hematoma) or bruises without significant trauma.
Generalized abnormal accumulation of fluid beneath the skin, or in one or more cavities of the body.
Absence of melanin pigment in various areas, which is found at birth and is permanent. The lesions are known as leucoderma and are often found on the face, trunk, or limbs.
The presence of fewer than normal sweat glands.
Increased pigmentation of the skin with a netlike (reticular) pattern.
Deposition of calcium salts in subcutaneous tissue (i.e., the the lowermost layer of the integument).
Osteomyelitis of the lower jaw.
A form of colorblindness in which only two of the three fundamental colors can be distinguished due to a lack of one of the retinal cone pigments.
Lack of eyelashes on the lower lid.
A type of cataract with punctate opacities of the lens.
A congenital defect of development characterized by absence of the lacrimal gland.
Abnormally curly or curved eyelashes.
Congenital underdevelopment of the iris.

Cornea plana is an abnormally flat shape of the cornea such that the normal protrusion of the cornea from the sclera is missing. The reduced corneal curvature can lead to hyperopia, and a hazy corneal limbus and arcus lipoides may develop at an early age.
Abnormal (non-physiological) constriction of the pupil of congenital onset.
An abnormal reduction in the amount of pigmentation of the iris.
Underdevelopment of the lacrimal gland.
A scotoma (area of diminished vision within the visual field) that surrounds the central fixation point.
The presence of distinct colors in the central (pupillary) zone of the iris than in the mid-peripheral (ciliary) zone.
Paralysis of both the extrinsic and intrinsic ocular muscles.
Increased length of the upper eyelashes.
Deposition of calcium salts in the retina.
Congenital absence of the extraocular muscles.
Underdevelopment of the lacrimal puncta.

Reduced pigmentation of the fundus, typically generalised. Fundoscopy may reveal a low level pigment in both RPE and choroid with clear visibility of choroidal vessels (pale/albinoid) or low pigment level in the RPE with deep pigment in choroid so that visible choroidal vessels are separated by deeply pigmented zones (tesselated/tigroid).
Failure of attachment of the retina during development.
Bleeding within the vitreous compartment of the eye.
A congenital defect resulting in absence of the lacrimal duct.
Paralysis of the iris and ciliary apparatus.
A reduction of corneal clarity.
A congenital cataract in which opacity is limited to layers of the lens external to the nucleus (i.e., the perinuclear region), i.e., between the nuclear and cortical layers of the lens.
The presence of developmental dysplasia of the retina.

Cerulean cataracts are a kind of congenital cataract having peripheral bluish and white opacifications in concentric layers with occasional central lesions arranged radially. Although the opacities may be observed during fetal development and childhood, usually visual acuity is only mildly reduced until adulthood, when lens extraction is generally necessary.
Decreased amount of pigmentation in the macula lutea.
A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the skin.
Increased blood pressure during a pregnancy.
The development of Pes cavus that is progressive with age.
Limitation of the ability to bend the toes.
Excessive amounts of mucopolysaccharide in the urine.
Abnormal development of the adrenal gland.
Enlargement of the adrenal gland.
An increased urine level of any amino acid carrying two amino groups (Asparagine, glutamine and lysine, cystine, ornithine).
An increased concentration of proline in the blood.
An abnormality of the calcaneus, also known as the heel bone, one of the or heel bone, one of the components of the tarsus of the foot which make up the heel.
An abnormality of the talus.
An anomaly of the toenail.
Small, underdeveloped vertebral bodies.
The presence of degenerative changes of intervertebral disk.
An abnormal shape of the vertebral bodies whereby the vertebral bodies are thick on one side and taper to a thin edge at the other.
The presence of developmental dysplasia of the vertebral column.
Absence of one half of the vertebral body in the lumbar spine.
Excessive growth of the bones of the vertebral bodies.
An abnormal narrowing of the cervical spinal canal.
Over curvature of the lumbar region.

A developmental defect of the sacrum characterized by partial or disordered development of the sacrum in which portions of the sacrum, which normally is formed by fusion of five sacral vertebrae S1-S5, fail to form or fail to form normally.
Agenesis of one or more vertebrae of the cervical vertebral column.
A developmental defect characterized by agenesis of one or more vertebral bodies.
Absence of one half of the vertebral body in the thoracic spine.
Dysplasia of the cervical vertebral column.
Any structural abnormality of the coccyx.

ET: Cleft at the superior portion of the pinna

DEF: Vestibular areflexia can be measured as the absence of the caloric nystagmus response in electronystagmography.
Developmental hypoplasia of the cochlea.
Underdevelopment of the helix, i.e., of the outer rim of the pinna.
Benign congenital lesion of the supraauricular soft tissue consisting of a blind-ending narrow tube or pit.

Pulsatile tinnitus is generally classified a kind of objective tinnitus, meaning that it is not only audible to the patient but also to the examiner on auscultation of the auditory canal and/or of surrounding structures with use of an auscultation tube or stethoscope. Usually, pulsatile tinnitus is heard as a lower pitched thumping or booming, a rougher blowing sound which is coincidental with respiration, or as a clicking, higher pitched rhythmic sensation. Pulsatile tinnitus may be associated with vascular abnormalities such as arterioevenous shunts or glomus tumors or the jugular vein, arterial bruits related to a high-riding carotid artery (close to the auditory areas) or carotid stenosis, or venous abnormalities such as a dehiscent jugular bulb or to hypertension. Finally, in some patients, mechanical abnormalities such a spatulous eustachian tubes, palatomyoclonus (small spasms of muscles in the soft palate area), or idiopathic stapedial muscle spasm may represent the underlying cause of pulsatile tinnitus.
A developmental anomaly of the ureter.
Increase in size of the folds of skin between the outer labia.
A disordered proliferation of mature tissues that are native to the kidneys.
Developmental hypoplasia of the fallopian tube.
Deposition of calcium salts in gonadal tissue.
Developmental hypoplasia of the ovary.
The presence of a longitudinal vaginal septum, thereby creating a vaginal duplication.
Underdevelopment of the larynx.
Presence of a gap in the posterior laryngotracheal wall with a continuity between the larynx and the esopahagus.
Calcification (abnormal deposits of calcium) in the laryngeal tissues.

The presence of one or more obsessive-compulsive personality traits. Obsessions refer to persistent intrusive thoughts, and compulsions to intrusive behaviors, which the affected person experiences as involuntary, senseless, or repugnant.
An abnormality of the prostate.
Any structural abnormality of the renal artery.
An abnormality of the vocal cord.
Irregularities of the iliac crest that produce the appearance of a lace border around it.
Increased height of the wing (or ala) of the ilium (which is the large expanded portion which bounds the greater pelvis laterally).
Underdevelopment of the bony pelvis.
Underdevelopment of muscles of the shoulder.
Muscle weakness affecting the tibialis anterior muscle.

ET: Muscle hypertrophy of the lower extremities
DEF: Muscle hypertrophy primarily affecting the legs.
Muscle hypertrophy affecting the calf muscles.
Underdevelopment of the pectoral muscle.
The presence of an abnormally increased amount of connective tissue.
Atrophy of the peroneous muscles, peroneus longus (also known as Fibularis longus), Peroneus brevis (also known as fibularis brevis, and Peroneus tertius (also known as fibularis tertius).
Cleft palate of the midline of the palate.
A congenital failure of muscular development of part or all of one or both hemidiaphragms, resulting in superior displacement of abdominal viscera and altered lung development.
A decrease in the strength of the diaphragm.
Muscular atrophy involving the muscles of the upper limbs.

ET: Synostosis involving bones of the feet

DEF: Contractures of one ore more joints of the hands meaning chronic loss of joint motion due to structural changes in non-bony tissue.
Underdevelopment of the pharynx.
Astrocytoma is a neoplasm of the central nervous system derived from astrocytes. Astrocytes are a type of glial cell, and thus astrocytoma is a subtype of glioma.
A hamartoma (a benign, focal malformation consisting of a disorganized mixture of cells and tissues) of the retina.
A pseudoepiphysis (which is a secondary ossification center distinct from the normal epiphysis) of one or more phalanges of the thumb.
An abnormal union between bones or parts of bones of the fingers. The synonymous term \

Fusion involving two or more metacarpal bones (A synostosis of the first metacarpal and the proximal phalanx of the thumb can also be observed, note that the first metacarpal bone corresponds to a proximal phalanx).
Synostosis (bony fusion) involving one or more bones of the carpus (scaphoid, lunate, triquetrum, trapezium, trapezoid, capitate, hamate, pisiform).

Small nodular masses which originate in the subependymal region of the lateral ventricles and protrude into the ventricular cavity. They may represent subependymal hamartomas of tuberous sclerosis or nodular heterotopia of grey matter.

Cortical tubers in the brain are hamartomatous lesions typically located at the gray-white matter interface, commonly in the frontal and parietal lobes. Cortical tubers are composed of abnormal glial and neural cells, and the size, number, and location vary among patients.
The presence of a sebaceous adenoma with origin in the sebum secreting cells of the skin.
A lesion located beneath a fingernail or toenail.
The presence of fibromata beneath finger or toenails.
The presence of a neoplasm of the urinary bladder.
A benign tumor of cardiac striated muscle.
The presence of a hamartoma of the cerebrum.
A glioma originating in the optic nerve or optic chiasm.
Pseudarthrosis, or \
Nephrosclerosis refers to thickening or scarring (\
Shoulder joint stiffness is a perceived sensation of tightness in shoulders when attempting to move them after a period of inactivity.
Abnormally increased hair growth in the lumbosacral region.
Increased volume of the earlobe, that is, abnormally prominent ear lobules.
Partial fusion of the upper and lower eyelid margins by single or multiple bands of tissue.
A pterygium (or pterygia) occurring in the popliteal region (the back of the knee).
A pterygium (or pterygia) in the intercrural (groin) region.
Pterygia affecting the neck.
Pterygium affecting the elbow. This is a cutaneous web that can lead to severe flexion contracture of the elbow joint. Antecubital pterygium can be unilateral, bilateral, symmetric, or asysmmetric.

Annular constrictions around the digits, limbs, or trunk, occurring congenitally (sometimes causing intrauterine autoamputation) and also associated with a wide variety of disorders. Constrictive amniotic bands are the result of primary amniotic rupture, which can lead to entanglement of fetal tissue (especially limbs) in fibrous amniotic strands.
Syndactyly with fusion of toes three and four.
A zone of darker pigmentation around the central part of the iris with a roughly cloverleaf or flower shape.
Absence of the triceps muscle.

Maternal diabetes can either be a gestational, mostly type 2 diabetes, or a type 1 diabetes. Essential is the resulting maternal hyperglycemia as a non-specific teratogen, imposing the same risk of congenital malformations to pregnant women with both type 1 and type2 diabetes.

ET: Aplasia of the phalanges of the hand
DEF: Absence of one or more of the phalanges of the hand.
Peromelia affecting only the upper limbs. That is, the distal parts of the arm are missing leading to stump formation.
Peromelia affecting only the lower limbs. That is, the distal parts of the leg are missing leading to stump formation.

Missing or malformed long bones of the extremities with the distal parts (such as hands and/or feet) connected to the variably shortened or even absent extremity, leading to a flipper-like appearance, as opposed to other forms of limb malformations were either the hole limb is missing (such as amelia), or the distal part of a limb is absent (peromelia).
Abnormally increased hair growth with a localized distribution.
A unilateral absence of sensory perception of sound.
Abnormally prominent ear helix.
An abnormality of the tragus.
The presence of a size difference between the left and right cornea.
The presence of remnants of a fetal membrane that persist as strands of tissue crossing the pupil.
Abnormally increased lacrimation, that is, excessive tearing (watering eye).
Increase in bulk of the ala nasi.
Asymmetry or size difference between the left and right nostril.
The presence of more than two nostrils.
Abnormally narrow nasal septum.
Absence of the mandible.
Lack of symmetry between the left and right mandible.
Diminished length of one or more metacarpal bones in relation to the others of the same hand or to the contralateral metacarpal.
Visible increase in width of the hallux without an increase in the dorso-ventral dimension.

ET: Abnormality of the phalanges of the toes

DEF: Increased width of phalanx of one or more toes.
A gap in the lower lip.

A gap (cleft) affecting one of the alveolar ridges, which are the protuberances in the mouth that contain the sockets (alveoli) of the teeth. An alveolar cleft can affect all structures of the alveolar ridge, including the gingiva, other mucosa, periosteum, alveolar bone, and teeth.

Distance between the labial point of the incisive papilla to the midline junction of the hard and soft palate more than 2 SD below the mean (objective) or apparently decreased length of the hard palate (subjective).
Lack of the uvula.
Tongue with a median apical indentation or fork.
Any abnormality of dentin.
The presence of asymmetrical breasts.
A narrowing of the orifice of the tricuspid valve of the heart.
A developmental defect resulting in complete obliteration of the lumen of the colon. That is, there is an abnormal closure, or atresia of the tubular structure of the colon.
Pelvic asymmetry refers to asymmetric positioning of landmarks on the two sides of the pelvis and may have a structural or functional etiology.
The presence of both ovarian and testicular tissues either in the same or in opposite gonads. Affected persons have ambiguous genitalia and may have 46,XX or 46,XY karyotypes or 46,XX/XY mosaicism.
Abnormality of the male genital system.
Aplasia, that is failure to develop, of the ovary.
Testis not palpable in the scrotum or inguinal canal.
Increased urinary excretion of oligosaccharides (low molecular weight carbohydrate chains composed of at least three monosaccharide subunits), derived from a partial degradation of glycoproteins.
Aplasia (absence) of the urinary bladder.
Abnormality of the urachus.
Persistence of the urachal canal resulting in a canal between the bladder and the umbilicus.
Amniotic constriction rings affecting the arms.
A narrow segment of significantly reduced circumference of a digit.
Webbing or fusion of the fingers, involving soft parts and including fusion of individual finger bones. Bony fusions are referred to as \
An abnormally increased length of the metacarpal bones.
An abnormal limitation of knee joint mobility.
A condition in which the anterior part of the foot rotates outward away from the midline of the body and the heel remains straight.
An ability of the toe joints to move beyond their normal range of motion.
Calcification within the adrenal glands.
Enlargement of the thymus.
Paroxysmal episodes of vertigo.
The presence of an abnormally thin calvarium.

The presence of convoluted folds and furrows formed from thickened skin of the scalp, resembling cerebriform pattern. The scalp has convoluted and elevated folds, 1 to 2 cm in thickness. The convolutions generally cannot be flattened by traction.
Nystagmus due to disturbance of the vestibular system; eye movements are rhythmic, with slow and fast components.
A finger resting on the dorsal surface of an adjacent digit when the hand is at rest.
An abnormality of the clivus, which is the inclined bony region of the posterior cranial fossa located between the sella turcica and the foramen magnum.
An abnormal vertical orientation of the clivus (which normally forms a kind of slope from the sella turcica down to the region of the foramen magnum).
An abnormally wavy surface or edge of the clavicles.
An abnormally wavy surface or edge of the ribs.

A midline anterior-posterior cleft of the epiglottis that involves at least two-thirds of the epiglottic leaf. It is a useful feature for clinical diagnosis because it appears to be very rare in syndromes other than Pallister-Hall-Syndrome and is also rare as an isolated malformation.
Sclerosis of the epiphyses, leading to an increased degree of radiopacity (white or ivory appearance) in X-rays.
Reduction in the size or volume of epiphyses.
Reduction in the size or volume of epiphyses.
Angiofibroma consist of many often dilated vessels.
A fibroma of the heart.
The presence of a fibroma of the ovary.
The presence of a fibroma of the ovary.
A benign biphasic tumor of the breast with epithelial and stromal components.
A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the skeleton.
Inability to perceive certain odorants (implies that the sense of smell is maintained for other classes of odorants).
Abnormality of the nasal cavity (the cavity includes and starts at the nares and reaches all the way through to the and includes the choanae, the posterior nasal apertures).
Absence or abnormal closure of the midnasal cavity.
Abnormal narrowing (stenosis) of the midnasal cavity, i.e., of the middle nasal meatus, which in neonates can cause respiratory distress.
An abnormal lack of stability of the cervical spine.
An abnormally increased ability of the skin to permit light to pass through (translucency) such that subcutaneous structures such as veins display an increased degree of visibility.

An abnormal degree of flatness of the Ala of nose, which can be defined as a reduced nasal elevation index (lateral depth of the nose from the tip of the nose to the insertion of the nasal ala in the cheek x 100 divided by the side-to-side breadth of the nasal alae).

An abnormal degree of flatness of the Ala of nose, which can be defined as a reduced nasal elevation index (lateral depth of the nose from the tip of the nose to the insertion of the nasal ala in the cheek x 100 divided by the side-to-side breadth of the nasal alae).
An abnormality of the Meninges, including any abnormality of the Dura mater, the Arachnoid mater, and the Pia mater.
An abnormality of the Dura mater.
An abnormality of the Diencephalon, which together with the cerebrum (telencephalon) makes up the forebrain.
A congenital defect characterized by absence of the Maxilla.
An abnormality of the zygomatic bone.
Underdevelopment of the zygomatic bone. That is, a reduction in size of the zygomatic bone, including the zygomatic process of the temporal bone of the skull, which forms part of the zygomatic arch.
Enuresis occurring during waking hours of the day.
Syndactyly with fusion of fingers two to five.
A kind of congenital cataract that is characterized by a hollow sphere of punctate opacities involving the fetal nucleus and that usually occurs bilaterally.
A type of congenital cataract in which the opacity follows the anterior or posterior Y suture.
Syndactyly with fusion of fingers one and two.
Syndactyly with fusion of fingers four and five.
Syndactyly with fusion of fingers one to three.
Syndactyly with fusion of fingers one to four.
Syndactyly with fusion of fingers one to five (complete syndactyly of all fingers of the hand).
Syndactyly with fusion of the fingers two to four.
Syndactyly with fusion of fingers three to five.
Syndactyly with fusion of toes one and two.
Syndactyly with fusion of toes one to four.
Syndactyly with fusion of toes one to five (complete syndactyly of all toes of the foot).
Syndactyly with fusion of toes two to four.
Syndactyly with fusion of toes two to five.
Syndactyly with fusion of toes three to five.
Webbing or fusion of the toes, involving soft parts and including fusion of individual bones of the toes. Bony fusions are referred to as \
A developmental defect characterized by absence of the retina.

Osteopoikilosis is a benign, asymptomatic sclerotic dysplasia of the bones. It affects both male and female and may be seen at any age. Radiographically sclerotic circular or ovoid lesions are usually symmetrically distributed in a periarticular location. Lesions can increase or decrease in size and number in serial radiographs or even disappear and do not have increased bone radiotracer uptake.
Diminished length of a metatarsal bone, with resultant proximal displacement of the associated toe.
A developmental abnormality characterized by the absence (aplasia) of a metatarsal bone.

ET: Aplasia of the phalanges of the toes
DEF: Absence of a digit or of one or more phalanges of a toe.

ET: Hypoplasia of the phalanges of the toes

DEF: Positioning of a lacrimal punctum other than at the medial margins of the eyelid.
Loss of elasticity of the upper and lower eyelids causing the skin to sag and bulge.
Asymmetry between the left and right sides of the maxilla.
Prominent positioning of the premaxilla in relation to the rest of the maxilla, the facial skeleton, or mandible. Not necessarily caused by an increase in size (hypertrophy of) the premaxilla.
Increased width of the columella.
Decreased length of the eyelashes (subjective).
A sinus in the coccygeal region (the region of the intergluteal cleft). A pilonidal sinus often contains hair and skin debris.
Marked widening of the major bronchi that may be predispose to chronic respiratory tract infection.
The presence of an abnormally large pelvis.
A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the uterus.
A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of a gonad.
The presence of a neoplasm of the urinary system.
A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the genital system.
The presence of a neoplasm of the testis.
Increased focal pigmentation of the vermilion of the lips.
Increased pigmentation, either focal or generalized, of the skin surrounding the vermilion of the lips.
Increased length of the uvula.
Decreased width of the uvula.
Decreased length of the uvula.

A congenital, hairless plaque consisting of overgrown epidermis, sebaceous glands, hair follicles, apocrine glands and connective tissue. They are a variant of epidermal naevi. Sebaceous naevi most often appear on the scalp, but they may also arise on the face, neck or forehead. At birth, a sevaceous nevus typically appears as a solitary, smooth, yellow-orange hairless patch. Sebaceous naevi become more pronounced around adolescence, often appearing bumpy, warty or scaly.
Epidermal naevi are due to an overgrowth of the epidermis and may be present at birth (50%) or develop during childhood.

Atonic seizure is a type of motor seizure characterized by a sudden loss or diminution of muscle tone without apparent preceding myoclonic or tonic event lasting about 1 to 2 seconds, involving head, trunk, jaw, or limb musculature.
A reduced ability to discriminate between different temperatures.
A loss or impairment of the sensation of the relative position of parts of the body and joint position.

Pain is an unpleasant sensation that can range from mild, localized discomfort to agony, whereby the physical part of pain results from nerve stimulation and is often accompanied by an emotional component. This term groups abnormalities in pain sensation presumed to result from abnormalities related to the specific nerve fibers that carry the pain impulses to the brain.
A kind of breech presentation in which the hips are flexed and the knees are flexed.
The presence of xanthomas (intra-and extra-cellular accumulations of cholesterol) extensor tendons (typically over knuckles, Achilles tendon, knee, and elbows).

A diagnostic reflex elicited by stimulation of the skin over the surface of the lateral malleolus of the foot. The Chaddock refelx is present if there is extension of one or more or all of the toes with or without fanning of them when the external inframalleolar skin is stimulated. The Chaddock sign, similar to the Babinski sign, is taken to be an indication of disease of the spinocortical (pyramidal) tract.

A type of strabismus in which the fixating eye is always the same one, while the other eye is constantly deviated. Monocular strabismus is to be distinguished from alternating strabismus, in which either of the eyes 'squints' at different times.
An abnormality of the umbilical cord, which is the cord connecting the developing embryo or fetus to the placenta.
A disease where there is cellular death (necrosis) of bone components due to interruption of the blood supply.
An increased concentration of leucine in the blood.
Zonular cataracts are defined to be cataracts that affect specific regions of the lens.
A form of cataract in which the lens substance has shrunk, leaving a collapsed, flattened capsule with little or no cortex or epithelium on the lens.
A kind of nuclear cataract characterized by fiberglasslike or needlelike crystals projecting in different directions, through or close to the axial region of the lens.
An abnormality of the external nose.
An abnormality of the nasal bone, comprising the left nasal bone and the right nasal bone.
Absence of the nasal bone.
Underdevelopment of the right-sided structures of the heart.
An abnormality of the abdominal musculature.
Abnormally increased formation of dense trabecular bone tissue. Despite the increased density of bone tissue, osteopetrotic bones tend to be more fracture-prone than normal.
A type of cirrhosis characterized by the presence of regenerative nodules of a variety of sizes.
An abnormality of the cortex of the kidney.
An altered ability of the kidneys to void urine and/or specific substances.
Agenesis of molar tooth.
An abnormality of the structure or composition of the teeth.
An abnormal conical morphology of the incisor tooth.
An abnormal conical morphology of the incisor tooth.
A developmental defect of tooth color.
An abnormality of molar tooth.
Increased size of the incisor tooth.
Mulberry molars are irregular teeth generally affecting the first molars and are characterized by a grossly deformed crown imitating, as the name implies, the surface of a mulberry.

A type of apraxia that is characterized by difficulty or inability to execute speech movements because of problems with coordination and motor problems, leading to incorrect articulation. An increase of errors with increasing word and phrase length may occur.
Unilateral paresis (weakness) with spasticity of the affected muscles and increased tendon reflexes.
An abnormality of the nasal dorsum, also known as the nasal ridge.
Nasal ridge curving posteriorly to an imaginary line that connects the nasal root and tip.
A type of eczema that occurs in the lips and perioral area.
A type of eczema that occurs in the lips and perioral area.
Mild fever that does not exceed 38.5 degree centrigrade.
Absence of the sweat glands.
A dialeptic seizure is a type of seizure characterised predominantly by reduced responsiveness or awareness and with subsequent at least partial amnesia of the event.
A type of focal autonomic seizure characterised by symptoms or signs pertaining to the gastrointestinal system as the initial semiological feature.
A seizure characterized by taste phenomena including acidic, bitter, salty, sweet, or metallic tastes as its first clinical manifestation.
Seizures characterized by olfactory phenomena as its first clinical manifestation.
Auras with affective, mnemonic or composite perceptual phenomena including illusory or composite hallucinatory events.

A seizure characterized by elementary visual hallucinations such as flashing or flickering lights/colours, or other shapes, simple patterns, scotomata, or amaurosis as its first clinical manifestation.
EEG with an amplitude less than 30 microvolts without observable occipital alpha rhythm (8-13 Hz).
Vertical soft tissue creases in the midline of the forehead, often extending from the hairline to the brow, and seen with facial expression or when the face is at rest.
Regional increase in the width (height) of the eyebrow.
Eyelashes that draw the attention of the viewer due to increased density and/or length and/or curl without meeting the criteria of trichomegaly.
No discernible ridge between concha and triangular fossa and helix.
Positioning of the antitragus at an angle perpendicular to the plane of the ear (oriented away from the plane of the ear).
Absence of the anterosuperior prominence of the area between the bottom of the incisura and the inner margin of the antihelix.
Double rather than single peak of the antitragus.
Continuum between the tragus and ascending helix, without any evidence of a posterior extension (crus) towards the concha.
Increase posterolateral protrusion of the tragus.
Decreased posterolateral protrusion of the tragus.
A type of pulmonary sequestration that occurs within the visceral pleura of normal lung tissue, usually without communication with the tracheobronchial tree.
An abnormality of the metencephalon. The metencephalon is the part of the hindbrain that consists of the pons and the cerebellum.
A morphological abnormality of a digit, i.e., of a finger or toe.
Increased width of the distal segment of a finger.
Increased width of the distal segment of a finger.
Increased thumb width without increased dorso-ventral dimension.
Divergence of digits along the anteroposterior axis (in the plane of the sole).
The gradual reduction in girth of the toe from proximal to distal.
Excessive amount of hair growth on forehead.
An abnormality of the outline, configuration, or contour of the mouth.
Increased width of the upper lip.
Malfunction of the abducens nerve as manifested by impairment of the ability of the affected eye to be moved outward.
Hair that lacks the lustre (shine or gleam) of normal hair.
Absence of the inner ear due to a developmental defect.
Absence of the cochlea, a spiral shaped cavity in the inner ear, owing to a developmental defect.
Complete absence of the vestibule of the inner ear.
Aplasia of the internal auditory canal.
Reduction in diameter of the internal auditory canal.
Atrophy of the tibialis muscle.
An abnormality of the medulla oblongata, the lower half of the brainstem.
Head circumference below 2 standard deviations below the mean for age and gender at birth.
An abnormality of the incus, an ossicle in the middle ear.
An abnormality of the malleus, an ossicle in the middle ear.

JT: 胚性OR胎生期OR胎児性|開始OR発生ORオンセットOR発症OR発病OR作用発現
DEF: Onset of disease at up to 8 weeks following fertilization (corresponding to 10 weeks of gestation).

JT: 幼児期OR小児期|開始OR発生ORオンセットOR発症OR発病OR作用発現
DEF: Onset of disease at the age of between 1 and 5 years.
Sudden, repetitive, nonrhythmic motor movements (spasms), involving the eyes and muscles of the face.
The enteric villi are atrophic or absent.
Absence of globe, optic nerve, chiasm and optic tracts. No evidence of ocular tissue on MRI scan or examination.
An abnormality of the lacrimal punctum, an opening on the eyelid close to the medial canthus that drains tears from the conjunctival sac into the lacrimal duct in the same eyelid.
An abnormality of the lacrimal duct, a duct that drain tears from the conjunctiva, via the lacrimal puncta, into the lacrimal sac.
Abnormality of the lacrimal gland, i.e., of the almond-shaped gland that secretes the aqueous layer of the tear film for each eye.
Progressive maculopathy characterized by concentric regions of hyper- and hypo-pigmentation.
Pale often indistinct lesions of the macula.
Increased amount of pigmentation in the macula lutea.
Splitting of the retina in the macular region.
Increased pigmentation of the fundus
Inability to make fine depth discriminations from parallax provided by the two eyes' different positions on the head.
Individuals affected by dichromacy possess only two types of cones, instead of three.
Malignant tumor of melanocytes affecting the iris.
Common atrium without defining morphologic features.
Crossing of the inflow streams of the two ventricles, due to an apparent twisting of the heart about its long axis.
A congenital defect with failure to open of the mitral valve orifice.

A congenital anomaly with partitioning of the right atrium to form a triatrial heart caused by persistence of the right valve of the sinus venosus. Typically, the right atrial partition is due to exaggerated fetal eustachian and thebesian valves, which together form an incomplete septum across the lower part of the atrium. This septum may range from a reticulum to a substantial sheet of tissue.
A congenital stenotic mitral valvular anomaly with a ring of tissue above the mitral valve.
An atrioventricular valve that has failed to open (atretic).
A tricuspid valve that has failed to open.
Mirror image arrangement of the mainstem bronchi with the right pulmonary artery posterior to the right upper lobe bronchus and the left pulmonary artery anterior to the left upper lobe bronchus.
An abnormality of the pulmonary situs, i.e., of the sidedness of the morphological right and left lungs, in which the morphology of both left and right lungs is the same.
Failure to develop of the tricuspid valve and thus lack of the normal connection between the right atrium and the right ventricle.
Right ventricular dysfunction (global or regional) with functional and morphological right ventricular abnormalities, with or without left ventricular disease.
Block of conduction of electrical impulses along the Bundle of His or along one of its bundle branches.
Abnormal anatomical location of the adrenal gland.
Absent development of the adrenal gland.
Increased size of the parotid gland.
Visually assessable vertical indentation, cleft, or depression of the nasal bridge, ridge and tip.
A reduced ability to identify precisely the site of a touch. This test is usually carried out by asking a patient, whose eyes are closed or covered, to touch the same site with a fingertip.
Impaired ability to recognize letters or numbers drawn by an examiner's fingertip on the patient's skin (the patients eyes are closed or covered throughout this examination).

Basal encephalocele is an encephalocele that occurs along the cribriform plate or through the sphenoid bone. The mass may appear in the nasal cavity, nasopharynx, epipharynx, sphenoid sinus, posterior orbit, or pterygopalatine fossa. The important distinction from other types is that no external tumor is visible except in those rare instances of herniations so large that they protrude through the mouth or nares.
Increased width of the midpoint of the mandible (mental protuberance) and overlying soft tissue.
Prominence of a triangular soft tissue area of the philtrum with the apex to the columella.
Pit in the midline of the philtral groove.

Distance between the philtral ridges, measured just above the vermilion border, more than 2 standard deviations below the mean. Alternatively, an apparently decreased distance between the ridges of the philtrum.
Congenital absence of the scaphoid..
Congenital absence of the scaphoid..
A type of abdominal pain that comes and goes in waves, most often starting and ending suddenly and being of severe intensity.
Accumulation of blood within the pericardial sac.

Accumulation of chyle (the whitish fluid taken up by the lacteals in the intestine, consisting of an emulsion of lymph and triglyceride fat thatpasses into the veins by the thoracic duct) in the pericardium. Chylopericardium is generally caused by obstruction of or trauma to the thoracic duct.
Accumulation of blood in the peritoneal cavity owing to internal hemorrhage.
A discrete mass of neoplastic monoclonal plasma cells either in the bone marrow or in an extramedullary location.
A type of keratitis characterized by inflammation in pinpoint areas of the corneal epithelium.
Pain in the lower back and hip radiating in the distribution of the sciatic nerve.
Hemorrhage from the vessels of the choroid.
Bleeding beneath the mucous membrane that lines the inner surface of the eyelid.
Excessive, increased hair growth located in the lumbar region.
Excessive, increased hair growth located in the thoracic region.
Accumulation of pus in the pleural cavity.
An abnormality of the shape of the thoracic vertebra T12 such that it is wedge-shaped (narrow towards the front).
An infection of the upper or lower respiratory tract.
Inflammation of the bronchioles.
Pneumonia due to the aspiration (breathing in) of food, liquid, or gastric contents into the upper respiratory tract.
Lung parenchymal involvement with lymphoma.

The presence of multiple granulomas in the liver as based on pathological examination. Granulomas are small 0.5 to 2 mm collections of modified macrophages called epithelioid cells usually surrounded by lymphocytes.

An abnormality of the pectoral muscle, comprising the pectoralis major, a thick, fan-shaped muscle of the anterior chest and the pectoralis minor, a thin, triangular muscle situated underneath the pectoralis major.
Replacement of bone marrow by fibrous tissue.
Gallstones composed primarily of bilirubin and calcium salts (calcium bilirubinate) with a low cholesterol concentration.
Formation of abnormal, extraskeletal bony tissue, i.e., the presence of bone in soft tissue where bone normally does not exist.
An increased concentration of glucose in the blood following a meal.
A persecutory delusion of supposed hostility of others.
Affective, mnemonic or composite perceptual auras with subjective qualities similar to those experienced in life but are recognized by the subject as occurring outside of actual context.
Affective auras with subjective qualities similar to those experienced in life but are recognized by the subject as occurring outside of actual context.
Auras with creation of composite perceptions without corresponding external stimuli involving visual, auditory, somatosensory, olfactory and/or gustatory phenomena.
Complete dislocation of the lens of the eye.
Aorta descends on right instead of on the left.
An abnormal accumulation of fluid and swelling in the tissues of the larynx.
A benign tumor of the liver of presumably epithelial origin.
Wasting of the pectoral muscles, i.e., of the pectoralis major and pectoralis minor.

Corneal guttata are droplet-like accumulations of non-banded collagen on the posterior surface of Descemet's membrane. The presence of focal thickenings of Descemet's membrane histologically named guttae. Cornea guttata can be easily diagnosed in vivo and ex vivo by means of specular microscopy as it gives dark areas where no endothelial cells are visible.
Presence of multiple yellowish-white lesions of various size and configuration on the retina not related to vascular lesions.
Inability to elicit tendon reflexes in the upper limbs.
An extreme form of generalized edema with widespread and massive edema due to effusion of fluid into the extracellular space.
The presence of a melanoma of the skin.
Increased excretion of glycopeptides in the urine. Glycopeptides are peptides with carbohydrate moieties covalently attached to the side chains of the amino acid residues.
A carcinoma of the endometrium, the mucous lining of the uterus.
A cancer of the prostate.
Death of cells in the basal ganglia.
A subtype of ductal pancreatic carcinoma that is thought to originate from squamous metaplasia of pancreatic ductal epithelium.
Phagocytosis by macrophages of erythrocytes, leukocytes, platelets, and their precursors in bone marrow and other tissues.
A separation (dissection) of the layers of the carotid artery wall.
An increase in heart rate with standing of 30 beats per minute or more.
A type of lymphoma that originates in T-cells.
A type of lymphoma that originates in B-cells.
Any structural anomaly of the acrosome resulting in a round sperm head.
A lack of mobility of ejaculated sperm.
Any structural anomaly of the kidney.
An abnormal functionality of the kidney.
An erythematous eruption commonly associated with drug reactions or infection and characterized by inflammatory nodules that are usually tender, multiple, and bilateral.
A breach of the capsule of the spleen.
Reduced number of primary teeth.
The presence of a teratoma in the ovary.
Narrowing of the urethra associated with inflammation or scar tissue.

A type of headache that last hours with continuous pain of mild or moderate intensity, bilateral location, a pressing/tightening (non-pulsating) quality and that is not aggravated by routine physical activity such as walking or climbing stairs.
An increased white blood cell count in the cerebrospinal fluid.
Marked decrease in the number of granulocytes.
Marked decrease in the number of granulocytes.
Atrophy of the superior rectus, the extraocular muscle whose primary function is to elevate the globe.
Anomaly of primary or secondary sexual development or characteristics.
Extravasation of chyle into the peritoneal cavity.
Extravasation of chyle into the peritoneal cavity.

An exanthema consisting of widespread pink-to-red macules (flat spots of 2-10 mm in diameter) or papules (red bumps) that blanch with pressure. The macules and papules may cluster and merge to form sheets over several days.
A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the face.
A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the face.
Failure of the ureter to undergo development.
Ribs that are increased in width and taper to the posterior ends.
An increased number of circulating monocytes.
An decreased number of circulating monocytes.
Inflammation of the sacroiliac joint, generally accompanied by lower back pain.
A distinct type of headache characterized by piercing, throbbing, or electric-shock-like chronic pain in the upper neck, back of the head, and behind the ears, usually on one side.
Inflammation surrounding hair follicles.

JT: 睡眠時ミオクローヌス
DEF: Myoclonus that occurs during the initial phases of sleep.
An odontogenic tumor of the cementum of tooth.
Isolated patches of hardened skin (scleroderma).

Projection of the tip of the dens more than 5 mm above a line joining the hard palate to the posterior lip of the foramen magnum (Chamberlain's line) or the tip of the dens is greater than 7 mm above McGregor's line (the back of the hard palate to the lowest point of the occipital squama).
An allergy is an immune response or reaction to substances that are usually not harmful.
An abnormal accumulation of interstitial fluid in the soft tissues of the limbs.
A greater than normal concentration of citrate(3-) in the urine.

A type of spastic paraparetic gait in which the muscle tone in the adductors is marked. It is characterized by hypertonia and flexion in the legs, hips and pelvis accompanied by extreme adduction leading to the knees and thighs hitting, or sometimes even crossing, in a scissors-like movement. The opposing muscles (abductors) become comparatively weak from lack of use.
An abnormally high level of blood oxygen.
The inability of the colon to modify stool to an acceptable consistency and move the stool from the cecum to the rectosigmoid area at least once every three days.
An inflammation of the choroid and retina.
An ulcer of the colon due to pressure and irritation from retained fecal masses.
An ulcer of the colon due to pressure and irritation from retained fecal masses.
Subjective feeling of tiredness characterized by a lack of energy and motivation that persists for six months or longer.
A headache disorder that occurs exclusively at night, waking the affected individual from sleep.
A headache disorder that occurs exclusively at night, waking the affected individual from sleep.

An ophthalmologic sign in young children resulting from upward-gaze paresis. In this condition, the eyes appear driven downward, the sclera may be seen between the upper eyelid and the iris, and part of the lower pupil may be covered by the lower eyelid.
Complete obstruction of a carotid artery.
A wartlike (with multiple small elevated projections) papule.
An anomaly of the internal capsule, which is an area of white matter in the brain that separates the caudate nucleus and the thalamus from the putamen and the globus pallidus.
An anomaly of the pituitary gland.
An abnormally increased size of the pituitary gland.
Reduced strength of the orbicularis oculi, the circumorbital muscle in the face that closes the eyelid.
An unpleasant sensation characterized by physical discomfort (such as pricking, throbbing, or aching) localized to the arm.
An unpleasant sensation characterized by physical discomfort (such as pricking, throbbing, or aching) localized to the leg.

Increased dimensions of the Virchow-Robin spaces (also known as perivascular spaces), which surround the walls of vessels as they course from the subarachnoid space through the brain parenchyma. Perivascular spaces are commonly microscopic, and not visible on conventional neuroimaging. This term refers to an increase of size of these spaces such that they are visible on neuroimaging (usually magnetic resonance imaging). The dilatations are regular cavities that always contain a patent artery.
A detrimental reaction to a food, beverage, food additive, or compound found in foods that produces symptoms in one or more body organs and systems that is not mediated by an immune reaction.
Hemorrhage between the skull and periosteum of a newborn resulting from rupture of blood vessels that cross the periosteum.
The presence of hemosiderin in the urine.
A lipoma (a benign tumor composed of adipose tissue) located in the conjunctiva.
The presence of varices (enlarged and convoluted blood vessels) in the colon.
The presence of varices (enlarged and convoluted blood vessels) in the colon.
Absence of thumb nail.
Absent nail of big toe.
Edema in the region of the Lower eyelid.
An isolated cyst of the kidney.
Hematuria that is visible upon inspection of the urine.
An decreased concentration of chloride in the urine.
An decreased concentration of magnesium the urine.
A cyst located along the allantois canal.
Functional anomaly of the kidney persisting for at least three months.
Tremulousness (trembling) of the lens of the eye.
Reduction in the amount of blood flow to the iris.
Lack of development of the cerebellum.
Syncope following a quick change in position from lying down to standing.
Akinetic mutism is essentially characterized by a total absence of spontaneous behavior and speech occurring in the presence of preserved visual tracking.
An abnormal build up of iron (Fe) in brain tissue.
An anomalous build up of copper (Cu) in the brain.
An anomaly of the pineal gland,a small endocrine gland in the brain that produces melatonin.
A glial uniloculated or multiloculated fluid-filled sac that either reside within or completely replace the pineal gland.
An increase in the quantity of space occupied by the thalamus.
The presence of a mild form of hearing impairment.
A profound (essentially complete) form of hearing impairment.
Impaired conduction of cardiac impulse occurring anywhere along the conduction pathway.
Edema in the region of the upper eyelid.
Agenesis of canine tooth.
Failure to develop of the small intestine.
Fingernail that appears thin when viewed on end.
Failure of the femur to develop.
Distance between the medial and lateral canthi is more than 2 SD below the mean for age (objective); or, apparently reduced length of the palpebral fissures.
Respiratory failure in the newborn.
A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the retina.
Hearing loss that occurs acutely and resolves completely.
Chronic loss of joint motion in a finger due to structural changes in non-bony tissue.
Underdevelopment of the heel bone.
Bigonial distance (lower facial width) more than 2 SD above the mean (objective); or an apparently increased width of the lower jaw (mandible) when viewed from the front (subjective).
Decreased distance between the attachments of the alae nasi to the face.
Increased distance between the attachments of the alae nasi to the face.
Increased width of the nasal ridge.

JT: 空間パターンOR空間分布
DEF: The pattern by which a phenotype affects one or more regions of the body.
An uncontrolled autonomous cell-proliferation originating in a hair follicle, which is an epidermal adnexal structures responsible for hair growth.
Formation of excess connective tissue in the testicle.
A structural abnormality of the sperm head.

A condition which is considered to be due to the subsequent atrophy and disappearance in fetal life of an initially normal testis. In the presence of spermatic cord structures is evidence of the presence of the testis in early intrauterine life. When associated with a blind-ending spermatic cord, this entity is named as his absence of a testis in an otherwise normal 46XY male is usually unilateral and is assumed to be a consequence of intrauterine or perinatal torsion or infarction.

A varicocele is a widening of the veins along the spermatic cord, leading to enlarged, twisted veins in the scrotum, and manifested clinically by a painless testicle lump, scrotal swelling, or bulge in the scrotum.
Aplasia (congenital absence) of the vas deferens.
The emission of semen and seminal fluid during the act of preparation for sexual intercourse, i.e. before there is penetration, or shortly after penetration.
The emission of semen and seminal fluid into the bladder instead of through the penis during orgasm.
An anomaly of the labia minora, the folds of skin between the outer labia.
An anomaly of the outer labia.
Overgrowth of the outer labia.
Posterior malposition of the anus.
Hypertrophy of one or more muscles innervated by the facial nerve (the seventh cranial nerve).
Muscle hypertrophy affecting the muscles of the neck.

Cholangiocarcinoma is a primary cancer originating in the biliary epithelium i.e., the cholangiocytes, of the extrahepatic and intrahepatic biliary ducts. It is extremely invasive, develops rapidly, often metastasizes, and has a very poor prognosis. They are slow growing tumors which spread longitudinally along the bile ducts with neural, perineural and subepithelial extension.

Malignant mesothelioma is a form of cancer that originates from the cells of the mesothelium, a thin tissue layer surrounding the body's internal organs. Malignant mesothelioma is almost exclusively caused by asbestos exposure, pleural mesothelioma beeing the most common form, affecting the lining of the lungs called the pleura. Other forms such as perioneal-, percardial- or testicular- mesothelioma are much rarer.
A malignant mesothelioma originating from cells of the pleura (the thin layer of mesothelium lining the lungs). Pleural mesothelioma is the most common form of mesothelioma.

A Malignant mesothelioma originating from cells of the peritoneum (the thin layer of mesothelium lining the abdomen). Peritoneal mesothelioma is the second most common form of mesothelioma after pleural mesothelioma.
A Malignant mesothelioma of the testis.
A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the breast.
A cataract which affects the layer of the lens surrounding the nucleus, i.e., the lens cortex. It is identified by its unique wedge or spoke appearance.
An abnormality of movement with a neurological basis characterized by changes in coordination and speed of voluntary movements.
A type of stereotypic behavior in which the affected individual repeatedly waves the hands up and down.
An anomalous configuration of blood vessels that shunts arterial blood directly into veins without passing through the capillaries.
A recurrent form of pancreatitis.
Mislocalised thyroid gland.
An aberrant thyroid gland or Ectopic thyroid located at the base of the tongue, just posterior to the foramen cecum as a result of a failure of the thyroid to descend.
An abnormality of the hair of head.
An Abnormality of cortical bone leading to an abnormal thickness of the cortex of affected bones.

ET: Abnormality of the epiphysis of the proximal phalanx of the 4th toe

DEF: Abnormality of the growth of the pubic hair. Pubic hair is part of the secondary sexual hair, which normally ensues during puberty.
Abnormality of the growth of the axillary hair. Axillary hair is part of the secondary sexual hair, which normally ensues during puberty.

ET: Triangular epiphysis of the proximal phalanx of the 4th toe
Synostosis involving bones of the toes

DEF: A smooth muscle connective tissue tumor, which is rare type of cancer that is a malignant neoplasm of smooth muscle. When such a neoplasm is benign, it is called a leiomyoma.
Calcium deposition affecting the Meninges.
An abnormality of the structure or form of the tendons, also often called sinews.
Depression located on the vermilion of the upper lip, usually paramedian.

A congenital branchial sinus is a remnant of the embryonic branchial arches and their intervening clefts and pouches that has failed to regress completely. Sinuses typically have their external orifice inferior to the ramus of the mandible. They may traverse the parotid gland, and run in close vicinity to the facial nerve in the external auditory canal.

Gustatory lacrimation results from an aberrant innervation of fibres from the seventh cranial nerve to the pterygopalatine ganglion which are destined originally for the submandibular ganglion. This aberrant innervation leads to uncontrollable tearing while eating or in anticipation of a meal.
A chronic inflammatory disease of the large intestine (colon, cecum and rectum).
A chronic inflammatory disease of the large intestine (colon, cecum and rectum).
An acute and self-limited inflammatory disease of the large intestine (colon, cecum and rectum).
Hemorrhage occurring between the dura mater and the arachnoid mater.
Hemorrhage occurring between the dura mater and the skull.
Nuclear or cytoplasmic aggregates of stainable substances within cells of the brain.
Cerebral eosinophilic, discrete, intracytoplasmatic inclusions of unknown significance.
Thick, elongated, worm-like or corkscrew eosinophilic bundle that are found on H&E staining of the brain in the presence of long standing gliosis, occasional tumors, and some metabolic disorders.
The presence of an increased number of mast cells and CD34+ mast cell precursors in the body.
A reduced circulating concentration of folic acid, which is also known as vitamin B9.
The presence of a neoplasm of the ureter.
The presence of a neoplasm of the urethra.
A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the thymus.
Persistence of the urachal canal with drainage of urine from the bladder through the persistent allantois canal to the umbilicus.
A rare cancer originating in the lung or pleural cavity that occurs most often in infants and young children but also has been reported in adults. Pleuropulmonary blastoma is regarded as malignant.
An abnormality of fascia.
Edema in the region of the eyelids.
An abnormal site of the kidney.
Narrowing of the carotid arteries.
A neoplasm of the trachea.
A difference in length or diameter between the left and right leg.
Difference in length or size between the right and left arm.
A tumor formed from the endocrine (argentaffin) cells of the mucosal lining of a variety of organs including the stomach and intestine. These cells are from neuroectodermal origin.
A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the biliary system.
The presence of a neoplasm of the gallbladder.
A transient visual disturbance that is typically caused by a circulatory, ocular or neurological underlying condition.
An abnormal enlargement of the renal calices, the system of ducts of the kidney that collect urine.

Polypoidal masses arising mainly from the mucous membranes of the nose and paranasal sinuses. They are freely movable and nontender overgrowths of the mucosa that frequently accompany allergic rhinitis.

Thin (2-3mm) membranes of normal esophageal tissue consisting of mucosa and submucosa that can be congenital or acquired. Congenital webs commonly appear in the middle and inferior third of the esophagus, and they are more likely to be circumferential with a central or eccentric orifice. Acquired webs are much more common than congenital webs and typically appear in the cervical area (postcricoid). Clinical symptoms of this condition are selective (solid more than liquids) dysphagia, thoracic pain, nasopharyngeal reflux, aspiration, perforation and food impaction (the last two are very rare).
Fluid accumulation in the lungs.
Two penile structures, separated from the tip to the base of the shaft.
Pregnancy-induced toxic reactions of the mother that can be as harmless as slight Maternal hypertension or as life threatening as Eclampsia.
A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the lip.
A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the ovary.
The presence of a teratoma of the testis.
A congenital malformation with a cleft (gap or opening) in the midline of the face.
A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the adrenal gland.
A neoplasm originating in the pharynx.
An anomaly of the color of the nail.
A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the oral cavity.
Failure to close of the chest and abdominal wall likely caused by the failure of the ventral wall to close during week 4 of development.
A neuropathic disorder characterized by episodes of intense pain in the face, originating from the trigeminal nerve. One, two, or all three branches of the nerve may be affected.

Rapid swelling (edema) of the dermis, subcutaneous tissue, mucosa and submucosal tissues of the skin of the face, normally around the mouth, and the mucosa of the mouth and/or throat, as well as the tongue during a period of minutes to several hours. The swelling can also occur elsewhere, typically in the hands. Angioedema is similar to urticaria, but the swelling is subcutaneous rather than on the epidermis.
The presence of a hernia of the vagina.
Excess deposit and expansion of adipose tissue in an unusual pattern which cannot be lost through diet and exercise .
An abnormality of the pia mater.
An extra-parenchymal and intra-arachnoidal collection of fluid with a composition similar to that of cerebrospinal fluid.
An abnormality of the thoracic vertebral column.
Any structural abnormality of the lumbar vertebral column.
Thickening and hardening of the epidermis seen with exaggeration of normal skin lines.
A rare congenital cystic lesion of the lungs in the mediastinum.
A horizontal cleft of the face, varying from slight widening of the mouth, to a cleft extending to the ear.
A benign or malignant neoplasm (tumour) originating in the vascular system.
A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the esophagus.

A mental disorder characterized by a disintegration of thought processes and of emotional responsiveness. It most commonly manifests as auditory hallucinations, paranoid or bizarre delusions, or disorganized speech and thinking, and it is accompanied by significant social or occupational dysfunction. The onset of symptoms typically occurs in young adulthood, with a global lifetime prevalence of about 0.3-0.7%.

Lymphangiomas are rare congenital malformations consisting of focal proliferations of well-differentiated lymphatic tissue in multi cystic or sponge like structures. Lymphangioma is usually asymptomatic due to its soft consistency but compression of adjacent structures can be seen due to the mass effect of a large tumor.
An abnormality of the tonsils.
An abnormality of the placenta, the organ that connects the developing fetus to the uterine wall to enable nutrient uptake, waste elimination, and gas exchange.

A malignant, trophoblastic and aggressive cancer, usually of the placenta. It is characterized by early hematogenous spread to the lungs and belongs to the far end of the spectrum of gestational trophoblastic disease (GTD), a subset of germ cell tumors.
Reduced or inadequate peristalsis, with resultant slow passage of contents through the digestive tract.
A hamartoma (disordered proliferation of mature tissues) of the conjunctiva.
Failure to develop and congenital absence of the breast.
A bony protrusion present on the midline of the hard palate.
An abnormality of the development of the toenails.
An abnormality of the development of the fingernails.
A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the middle ear.
Abnormal anatomical location of the stomach. This feature may be due to intestinal malrotation.
Pain or discomfort of the scalp elicited by palpation.
The presence of a neoplasm of the small intestine.
The presence of a neoplasm of the large intestine.
A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the scrotum.
A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the penis.
Underdevelopment of the areola, the circular area of pigmented skin surrounding the nipple.
Abnormal outpouching or sac-like dilatation in the wall of the celiac artery.
Increase in bone density of the vertebral body.
Increased width of the ischium, which forms the lower and back part of the hip bone.
An abnormality of the palm, that is, of the front of the hand.
Increased density of hairs, i.e., and elevated number of hairs per unit area.
Skin crease extending from below the inner canthus laterally along the malar process of the maxilla and zygoma.
Abnormally persistent clusters of embryonal cells, representing microscopic malformations (dysplasias) of the developing kidney.

A scoliosis which is the results of a difference in leg length (which might be due to hemihypertrophy or hemihypotrophy of a leg) and the resulting tilting of the pelvis. If untreated this will lead to the development of scoliosis over time.
Connective tissue nevi are hamartomas in which one or several components of the dermis is altered.
An elevation in bone density in one or more phalanges of the fingers. Sclerosis is normally detected on a radiograph as an area of increased opacity.
An increase in bone density within the clavicle.
