An inflammatory exfoliative dermatosis involving nearly all of the surface of the skin. Erythroderma develops suddenly. A patchy erythema may generalize and spread to affect most of the skin. Scaling may appear in 2-6 days and be accompanied by hot, red, dry skin, malaise, and fever.

JT: 多形皮膚萎縮症(ポイキロデルマ)
DEF: Poikiloderma refers to a patch of skin with (1) reticulated hypopigmentation and hyperpigmentation, (2) wrinkling secondary to epidermal atrophy, and (3) telangiectasias.
Skin that splits easily with minimal injury.
Skin that splits easily with minimal injury.
Redness of the skin of the face, caused by hyperemia of the capillaries in the lower layers of the skin.
An abnormality of the biliary tree.
Papilledema refers to edema (swelling) of the optic disc secondary to any factor which increases cerebral spinal fluid pressure.
Loss of iris tissue (atrophy)
Loss of iris tissue (atrophy)
Diffusely large eye (with megalocornea) without glaucoma.
No identifiable superior and/or inferior lacrimal punctum.
Inflammation of the cornea and conjunctiva.
Well-demarcated area(s) of partial or complete depigmentation in the fundus, reflecting atrophy of the retinal pigment epithelium with associated retinal photoreceptor loss.
An abnormal reduction in the amount of pigmentation (reduced or absent) of the iris and retina.
The presence of xanthomata in the skin of the eyelid.
Limbus-to-limbus corneal thinning, often greatest in the periphery, with globular protrusion of the cornea.
Limbus-to-limbus corneal thinning, often greatest in the periphery, with globular protrusion of the cornea.

Cryptophthalmos is a condition of total absence of eyelids and the skin of forehead is continuous with that of cheek, in which the eyeball is completely concealed by the skin, which is stretched over the orbital cavity.
Inversion and rubbing of the eyelashes against the globe of the eye.

An absolute or relative decrease in retinal sensitivity extending from edge (periphery) of the visual field in a concentric pattern. The visual field is the area that is perceived simultaneously by a fixating eye.

Presence of a cyst in the region of the periorbital tissues. Orbital cysts can be derived from epithelial or glandular tissue within or surrounding the orbit (lacrimal glands, salivary glands, conjunctival, oral, nasal, or sinus epithelium).

Presence of a cyst in the region of the periorbital tissues. Orbital cysts can be derived from epithelial or glandular tissue within or surrounding the orbit (lacrimal glands, salivary glands, conjunctival, oral, nasal, or sinus epithelium).
An abnormality affecting one or both hands.
Webbing or fusion of the fingers or toes, involving soft parts only or including bone structure. Bony fusions are referred to as \
An anomaly of a finger.

An abnormal hand position characterized by hyperextension of the fourth and fifth fingers at the metacarpophalangeal joints and flexion of the interphalangeal joints of the same fingers such that they are curled towards the palm.
In the resting position, the tip of the thumb is on, or near, the palm, close to the base of the fourth or fifth finger.
Decreased length of the umbilical cord.
Broadening of the soft tissues (non-edematous swelling of soft tissues) of the digital tips in all dimensions associated with an increased longitudinal and lateral curvature of the nails.
Subnormal intellectual functioning which originates during the developmental period. Intellectual disability, previously referred to as mental retardation, has been defined as an IQ score below 70.

Cerebellar ataxia refers to ataxia due to dysfunction of the cerebellum. This causes a variety of elementary neurological deficits including asynergy (lack of coordination between muscles, limbs and joints), dysmetria (lack of ability to judge distances that can lead to under- or overshoot in grasping movements), and dysdiadochokinesia (inability to perform rapid movements requiring antagonizing muscle groups to be switched on and off repeatedly).

Dysarthric speech is a general description referring to a neurological speech disorder characterized by poor articulation. Depending on the involved neurological structures, dysarthria may be further classified as spastic, flaccid, ataxic, hyperkinetic and hypokinetic, or mixed.
Reduction of neurologic reflexes such as the knee-jerk reaction.
Reduction of neurologic reflexes such as the knee-jerk reaction.
Loss of previously present mental abilities, generally in adults.
Atrophy (wasting) of the cerebellum.
A condition characterized by intermittent involuntary contraction of muscles (spasms) related to hypocalcemia or occasionally magnesium deficiency.

Bulbar weakness (or bulbar palsy) refers to bilateral impairment of function of the lower cranial nerves IX, X, XI and XII, which occurs due to lower motor neuron lesion either at nuclear or fascicular level in the medulla or from bilateral lesions of the lower cranial nerves outside the brain-stem. Bulbar weakness is often associated with difficulty in chewing, weakness of the facial muscles, dysarthria, palatal weakness and regurgitation of fluids, dysphagia, and dysphonia.

The term gait disturbance can refer to any disruption of the ability to walk. In general, this can refer to neurological diseases but also fractures or other sources of pain that is triggered upon walking. However, in the current context gait disturbance refers to difficulty walking on the basis of a neurological or muscular disease.

Characteristic neurologic anomaly resulting form degeneration of dopamine-generating cells in the substantia nigra, a region of the midbrain, characterized clinically by shaking, rigidity, slowness of movement and difficulty with walking and gait.

Pachygyria is a malformation of cortical development with abnormally wide gyri with sulci 1,5-3 cm apart and abnormally thick cortex measuring more than 5 mm (radiological definition). See also neuropathological definitions for 2-, 3-, and 4-layered lissencephaly.

A type of ataxia characterized by the inability to carry out movements with the correct range and motion across the plane of more than one joint related to incorrect estimation of the distances required for targeted movements.
Hemorrhage into the parenchyma of the brain.
Complete lack of development of speech and language abilities.
Hyperreflexia is the presence of hyperactive stretch reflexes of the muscles.

Tendon reflexes that are noticeably more active than usual (conventionally denoted 3+ on clinical examination). Brisk reflexes may or may not indicate a neurological lesion. They are distinguished from hyperreflexia by the fact that hyerreflexia is characterized by hyperactive repeating (clonic) reflexes, which are considered to be always abnormal.
Diffuse enlargement of the entire cerebral hemispheres leading to macrocephaly (with or without overlying cortical dysplasia).

A flexion contracture is a bent (flexed) joint that cannot be straightened actively or passively. It is thus a chronic loss of joint motion due to structural changes in muscle, tendons, ligaments, or skin that prevents normal movement of joints.
Displacement or malalignment of joints.
The ability of a joint to move beyond its normal range of motion.
Joint stiffness is a perceived sensation of tightness in a joint or joints when attempting to move them after a period of inactivity. Joint stiffness typically subsides over time.
Lack of stability of a joint.
Lack of stability of a joint.
An abnormality of the liver.
The presence of excessive fibrous connective tissue in the liver. Fibrosis is a reparative or reactive process.
A kind of neoplasm of the liver that originates in hepatocytes and presents macroscopically as a soft and hemorrhagic tan mass in the liver.
Proliferative changes of the bile ducts.
Slightly elevated lesions on or in the skin with a diameter of over 5 mm.
Increased width of a non-thumb digit of the hand.
Increased width of a non-thumb digit of the hand.
A deficiency or slowing down of growth pre- and postnatally.
A deficiency or slowing down of growth pre- and postnatally.
Overgrowth of only one side of the body.
Asthenic habitus refers to a slender build with long limbs, an angular profile, and prominent muscles or bones.
A thrusting or bulging out of the abdomen.

A type of congenital ventral incomplete closure of the abdominal wall in which the intestines and sometimes other organs extend freely into the amniotic fluid space through a small opening in the abdomen, usually to the right of the umbilicus.
An abnormality of the structure or appearance of the umbilicus.
An abnormal reduction in quantity or strength of fetal movements.
The presence of excess amniotic fluid in the uterus during pregnancy.
Diminished amniotic fluid volume in pregnancy.
Abnormally increased production of urine by the fetus resulting in polyhydramnios.
The presence of a fistula connecting the urinary bladder to the vagina.

The rib cage has the shape of a wide mouthed bell. That is, the superior portion of the rib cage is constricted, followed by a convex region, and the inferior portion of the rib cage expands again to have a large diameter.
Abnormality of the nail.
The natural longitudinal (posterodistal) convex arch is not present or is inverted.
Stricture or narrowing of the larynx that may be associated with symptoms of respiratory difficulty depending on the degree of laryngeal narrowing.
A loss of the ability to move the vocal folds.
Hoarseness refers to a change in the pitch or quality of the voice, with the voice sounding weak, very breathy, scratchy, or husky.
A type of speech characterized by the presence of an abnormally increased nasal airflow during speech.
A type of speech characterized by the presence of an abnormally increased nasal airflow during speech.
An impairment in the ability to produce voice sounds.
An abnormal increase in the pitch (frequency) of the voice.
Any abnormality of the cardiovascular system.
Increased size of the heart.
The heart is located in the right hand sided hemithorax. That is, there is a left-right reversal (or \

Necrosis of the myocardium caused by an obstruction of the blood supply to the heart and often associated with chest pain, shortness of breath, palpitations, and anxiety as well as characteristic EKG findings and elevation of serum markers including creatine kinase-MB fraction and troponin.
A single arterial trunk arises from the cardiac mass. The pulmonary arteries, aorta and coronary arteries arise from this single trunk with no evidence of another outflow tract.

Uncontrolled contractions of muscles fibers in the left ventricle not producing contraction of the left ventricle. Ventricular fibrillation usually begins with a ventricular premature contraction and a short run of rapid ventricular tachycardia degenerating into uncoordinating ventricular fibrillations.

In this case the right ventricle is more muscular than normal, causing a characteristic boot-shaped (coeur-en-sabot) appearance as seen on anterior- posterior chest x-rays. Right ventricular hypertrophy is commonly associated with any form of right ventricular outflow obstruction or pulmonary hypertension, which may in turn owe its origin to left-sided disease. The echocardiographic signs are thickening of the anterior right ventricular wall and the septum. Cavity size is usually normal, or slightly enlarged. In many cases there is associated volume overload present due to tricuspid regurgitation, in the absence of this, septal motion is normal.
Congenital malformation of the ventral wall with partial or total evisceration of the heart outside the thoracic cavity and through the defect in the ventral wall.
Bradycardia related to a mean resting sinus rate of less than 50 beats per minute.
Rapid and unexpected death.
Irreversible damage to heart tissue (myocardium) due to lack of oxygen after a heart attack (myocardial infarction).
Inflammation of the sac-like covering around the heart (pericardium).
Inflammation of the sac-like covering around the heart (pericardium).

Reduced ability of the right ventricle to perform its function (to receive blood from the right atrium and to eject blood into the pulmonary artery), often leading to pitting peripheral edema, ascites, and hepatomegaly.
Enlargement or increased size of the heart left ventricle.

Enlargement of the cardiac ventricular muscle tissue with increase in the width of the wall of the ventricle and loss of elasticity. Ventricular hypertrophy is clinically differentiated into left and right ventricular hypertrophy.
An abnormality of the pancreas.
The presence of inflammation in the pancreas.
A acute form of pancreatitis.
An abnormality of the spleen.
Abnormal increased size of the spleen.
An abnormality of the skeleton of foot.

Talipes equinovarus (also called clubfoot) typically has four main components: inversion and adduction of the forefoot; inversion of the heel and hindfoot; equinus (limitation of extension) of the ankle and subtalar joint; and internal rotation of the leg.
A foot for which the measured width is above the 95th centile for age; or, a foot that appears disproportionately wide for its length.
A deformity of foot and ankle in which the foot is bent down and outwards.
An anomaly of a toe.
Premature rupture of membranes (PROM) is a condition which occurs in pregnancy when the amniotic sac ruptures more than an hour before the onset of labor.
The abnormal accumulation of fluid in two or more fetal compartments, including ascites, pleural effusion, pericardial effusion, and skin edema.
Accumulation of fluid in the peritoneal cavity during the fetal period.
A nail that is diminished in length and width, i.e., underdeveloped nail.
Congenital absence of the toenail.
Nail that appears thick when viewed on end.
Detachment of the nail from the nail bed.
When viewed on end (with the finger tip pointing toward the examiner's eye) the curve of the fingernail forms a tighter curve of convexity.
Absence of a fingernail.

The nail disease paronychia is an often-tender bacterial or fungal hand infection or foot infection where the nail and skin meet at the side or the base of a finger or toenail. The infection can start suddenly (acute paronychia) or gradually (chronic paronychia).
Increased width of nail.
Lateral deviation of the great toe (i.e., in the direction of the little toe).
Reduction inexisting body weight.
Visible increase in width of the non-hallux digit without an increase in the dorso-ventral dimension.
Increased length of the big toe.
An abnormal reduction in numbers of all blood cell types (red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets).
Increased count of eosinophils in the blood.

Talipes calcaneovalgus is a flexible foot deformity (as opposed to a rigid congenital vertical talus foot deformity) that can either present as a positional or structural foot deformity depending on severity and/or causality. The axis of calcaneovalgus deformity is in the tibiotalar joint, where the foot is positioned in extreme hyperextension. On inspection, the foot has an \
Polycythemia is diagnosed if the red blood cell count, the hemoglobin level, and the red blood cell volume all exceed the upper limits of normal.
This term refers to an abnormally increased susceptibility to bruising (purpura, petechiae, or ecchymoses).
A decreased concentration of glucose in the blood.
Presence of elevated levels of ketone bodies in the body.
Obesity located preferentially in the trunk of the body as opposed to the extremities.
A sensation that the heart is pounding or racing, which is a non-specific sign but may be a manifestation of arrhythmia.
An abnormal increase in the number of leukocytes in the blood.
The process of hematopoiesis occurring outside of the bone marrow (in the liver, thymus, and spleen) in the postnatal organisms.
Excretion of non-amino organic acids in urine.
Acidosis resulting from accumulation of ketone bodies.
Accentuated, prominent philtral ridges giving rise to an exaggerated groove in the midline between the nasal base and upper vermillion border.
A congenital malformation with a cleft (gap or opening) in the face.
A facial appearance characteristic of a fetus or neonate due to oligohydramnios experienced in the womb, comprising ocular hypertelorism, low-set ears, receding chin, and flattening of the nose.
Difficulty in swallowing.
Infrequent or difficult evacuation of feces.
An abnormal narrowing of the pylorus.
Congenital absence of the anus, i.e., the opening at the bottom end of the intestinal tract.
Impaired ability to absorb one or more nutrients from the intestine.
Abnormal narrowing of the anal opening.
The presence of chronic diarrhea, which is usually taken to mean diarrhea that has persisted for over 4 weeks.
A developmental defect resulting in complete obliteration of the lumen of the esophagus such that the esophagus ends in a blind pouch rather than connecting to the stomach.
An inadequate sucking reflex, resulting in the difficult of newborns to be breast-fed.
Protrusion of the rectal mucous membrane through the anus.
A lack or loss of appetite for food (as a medical condition).
The inability to maintain a comfortably body temperature in warm or hot weather.
Atrophy (wasting, decrease in size of cells or tissue) affecting the cerebrum.
Spasticity (velocity-dependent increase in tonic stretch reflexes with increased muscle tone and hyperexcitable tendon reflexes) in the muscles of the lower limbs, hips, and pelvis

Spasticity is manifested by increased stretch reflex which is intensified with movement velocity. This results in excessive and inappropriate muscle activation which can contribute to muscle hypertonia. Spastic gait is characterized by manifestations such as muscle hypertonia, stiff knee, and circumduction of the leg.

Spasticity is manifested by increased stretch reflex which is intensified with movement velocity. This results in excessive and inappropriate muscle activation which can contribute to muscle hypertonia. Spastic gait is characterized by manifestations such as muscle hypertonia, stiff knee, and circumduction of the leg.

A type of ataxia characterized by the impairment of the ability to coordinate the movements required for normal walking. Gait ataxia is characteirzed by a wide-based staggering gait with a tendency to fall.

Bradykinesia literally means slow movement, and is used clinically to denote a slowness in the execution of movement (in contrast to hypokinesia, which is used to refer to slowness in the initiation of movement).

Bradykinesia literally means slow movement, and is used clinically to denote a slowness in the execution of movement (in contrast to hypokinesia, which is used to refer to slowness in the initiation of movement).
A kind of ataxia that affects movements of the extremities.
Truncal ataxia is a sign of ataxia characterized by instability of the trunk. It usually occurs during sitting.

A type of kinetic tremor that occurs during target directed movement is called intention tremor. That is, an oscillatory cerebellar ataxia that tends to be absent when the limbs are inactive and during the first part of voluntary movement but worsening as the movement continues and greater precision is required (e.g., in touching a target such as the patient's nose or a physician's finger).

A type of encephalocele (that is, a a protrusion of part of the cranial contents including brain tissue through a congenital opening in the cranium, typically covered with skin or mucous membrane) in the occipital region of the skull. Occipital encephalocele presents as a midline swelling over the occipital bone. It is usually covered with normal full-thickness scalp.
Any structural anomaly of the lung.

Pulmonary hypertension is defined mean pulmonary artery pressure of 25mmHg or more and pulmonary capillary wedge pressure of 15mmHg or less when measured by right heart catheterisation at rest and in a supine position.
Difficult or labored breathing.

Difficulty in breathing. The physical presentation of respiratory distress is generally referred to as labored breathing, while the sensation of respiratory distress is called shortness of breath or dyspnea.
Accumulation of air in the pleural cavity leading to a partially or completely collapsed lung.
Pneumothorax occurring without traumatic injury to the chest or lung.
An increase in size of the ventricular system of the brain.

A generalized non-motor (absence) seizure is a type of a type of dialeptic seizure that is of electrographically generalized onset. It is a generalized seizure characterised by an interruption of activities, a blank stare, and usually the person will be unresponsive when spoken to. Any ictal motor phenomena are minor in comparison to these non-motor features.
Polymicrogyria is a congenital malformation of the cerebral cortex characterized by abnormal cortical layering (lamination) and an excessive number of small gyri (folds).
A cavity within the cerebral hemisphere, filled with cerebrospinal fluid, that communicates directly with the ventricular system.
An abnormal gait pattern in which persons stand and walk with their feet spaced widely apart. This is often a component of cerebellar ataxia.

During normal embryological development, the spinal cord first occupies the entire length of the vertebral column but goes on to assume a position at the level of L1 due to differential growth of the conus medullaris and the vertebral column. The filum terminale is a slender, threadlike structure that remains after the normal regression of the distal embryonic spinal cord and attaches the spinal cord to the coccyx. A tethered cord results if there is a thickened rope-like filum terminale which anchors the cord at the level of L2 or below, potentially causing neurologic signs owing to abnormal tension on the spinal cord.
An abnormally increased potassium concentration in the blood.
The presence of developmental dysplasia of the nail.
Gliosis is the focal proliferation of glial cells in the central nervous system.
External mechanical compression of the spinal cord.
Progressive loss of neural cells and tissue.
Abnormal accumulation of fluid in the brain.
An abnormally heightened sensitivity to loud sounds.
Inability to move the muscles of respiration.

An embolus (that is, an abnormal particle circulating in the blood) located in the pulmonary artery and thereby blocking blood circulation to the lung. Usually the embolus is a blood clot that has developed in an extremity (for instance, a deep venous thrombosis), detached, and traveled through the circulation before becoming trapped in the pulmonary artery.
Replacement of normal lung tissues by fibroblasts and collagen.
Hair shafts are rough in texture.
Decreased number of hairs per unit area of skin of the scalp.
Hair that is fine or thin to the touch.
Reduced number or density of axillary hair.
Absence of axillary hair.
Absence of the eyebrow.
Reduced number or density of pubic hair.
White color (lack of pigmentation) of the eyebrow.
White color (lack of pigmentation) of the eyelashes.
Sparseness of the body hair.
Transient, non-scarring hair loss and preservation of the hair follicle located in in well-defined patches.
Uncombable hair.
Hemorrhage affecting the gastrointestinal tract.
Abnormally increased size of the liver.
An abnormality of the intestine. The closely related term enteropathy is used to refer to any disease of the intestine.
Meckel's diverticulum is a congenital diverticulum located in the distal ileum.
Chronic inflammation of the nasal mucosa.
Weakness of all four limbs.

Increase in size of the cisterna magna, one of three principal openings in the subarachnoid space between the arachnoid and pia mater, located between the cerebellum and the dorsal surface of the medulla oblongata.
Fragile, easily breakable hair, i.e., with reduced tensile strength.
Fragile, easily breakable hair, i.e., with reduced tensile strength.
A defect of development of the brain characterized by replacement of greater portions of the cerebral hemispheres and the corpus striatum by cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) and glial tissue.
Compression of the spinal cord in the cervical region, generally manifested by paresthesias and numbness, weakness, difficulty walking, abnormalities of coordination, and neck pain or stiffness.
A tremor present when the limbs are active, either when outstretched in a certain position or throughout a voluntary movement.
This term describes abnormality of the white matter of the cerebrum resulting from damage to the myelin sheaths of nerve cells.
Abnormality observed by electroencephalogram (EEG), which is used to record of the brain's spontaneous electrical activity from multiple electrodes placed on the scalp.
An impairment of memory as manifested by a reduced ability to remember things such as dates and names, and increased forgetfulness.
Reduced ability to walk (ambulate).

An abnormality of sleep including such phenomena as 1) insomnia/hypersomnia, 2) non-restorative sleep, 3) sleep schedule disorder, 4) excessive daytime somnolence, 5) sleep apnea, and 6) restlessness.

Abnormally diminished motor activity. In contrast to paralysis, hypokinesia is not characterized by a lack of motor strength, but rather by a poverty of movement. The typical habitual movements (e.g., folding the arms, crossing the legs) are reduced in frequency.
Loss of developmental skills, as manifested by loss of developmental milestones.

Stenosis of the cerebral aqueduct (also known as the mesencephalic duct, aqueductus mesencephali, or aqueduct of Sylvius), which connects the third cerebral ventricle in the diencephalon to the fourth ventricle, which is between the pons and cerebellum.
Incomplete closure of the embryonic neural tube, whereby some vertebral arches remain unfused and open. The mildest form is spina bifida occulta, followed by meningocele and meningomyelocele.
Incomplete closure of the embryonic neural tube, whereby some vertebral arches remain unfused and open. The mildest form is spina bifida occulta, followed by meningocele and meningomyelocele.
Difficulty to maintain correct position of the head while standing or sitting.
A defect in the motor ability that enables speech.
A specific learning disability involving mathematics and arithmetic.

Paralysis of all four limbs, and trunk of the body below the level of an associated injury to the spinal cord. The etiology of quadriplegia is similar to that of paraplegia except that the lesion is in the cervical spinal cord rather than in the thoracic or lumbar segments of the spinal cord.
Proliferation of astrocytes in the area of a lesion of the central nervous system.

Language impairment is a deficit in comprehension or production of language that includes reduced vocabulary, limited sentence structure or impairments in written or spoken communication. Language abilities are substantially and quantifiably below age expectations.
A delay in the acquisition of the ability to use language to communicate needs, wishes, or thoughts.

Central nervous system dysfunction in association with liver failure and characterized clinically (depending on degree of severity) by lethargy, confusion, nystagmus, decorticate posturing, spasticity, and bilateral Babinski reflexes.
Motor hyperactivity with excessive movement of muscles of the body as a whole.

A degenerative disease of the brain characterized by the insidious onset of dementia. Impairment of memory, judgment, attention span, and problem solving skills are followed by severe apraxia and a global loss of cognitive abilities. The condition primarily occurs after age 60, and is marked pathologically by severe cortical atrophy and the triad of senile plaques, neurofibrillary tangles, and neuropil threads.
Incapability to ambulate.
Absence of facial hair.
Absence of pubic hair.
Congenital failure to develop, and absence of, the nipple.
Placement of the nipples at a lower than normal location.
The passage of fresh (red) blood per anus, usually in or with stools. Most rectal bleeding comes from the colon, rectum, or anus.
The passage of fresh (red) blood per anus, usually in or with stools. Most rectal bleeding comes from the colon, rectum, or anus.
An abnormality of the stomach.
Hypoplasia of the pancreas.
Acute obstruction of the intestines preventing passage of the contents of the intestines.
An anomaly of vein.
Sclerosis (hardening) of the arteries with increased thickness of the wall of arteries as well as increased stiffness and a loss of elasticity.
A cancer originating in lymphocytes and presenting as a solid tumor of lymhpoid cells.

A malignant bone tumor that usually develops during adolescence and usually affects the long bones including the tibia, femur, and humerus. The typical symptoms of osteosarcoma comprise bone pain, fracture, limitation of motion, and tenderness or swelling at the site of the tumor.
The presence of a high and narrow palate.
A morphological abnormality of the mouth in which the angle of the mouth is downturned. The oral commissures are positioned inferior to the midline labial fissure.
Decreased levels of immunoglobulin A (IgA).
Failure of the immune system to protect the body adequately from infection, due to the absence or insufficiency of some component process or substance.

Osteomalacia is a general term for bone weakness owing to a defect in mineralization of the protein framework known as osteoid. This defective mineralization is mainly caused by lack in vitamin D. Osteomalacia in children is known as rickets.

Osteomalacia is a general term for bone weakness owing to a defect in mineralization of the protein framework known as osteoid. This defective mineralization is mainly caused by lack in vitamin D. Osteomalacia in children is known as rickets.

A pathologic fracture occurs when a bone breaks in an area that is weakened secondarily to another disease process such as tumor, infection, and certain inherited bone disorders. A pathologic fracture can occur without a degree of trauma required to cause fracture in healthy bone.

Degeneration (wear and tear) of articular cartilage, i.e., of the joint surface. Joint degeneration may be accompanied by osteophytes (bone overgrowth), narrowing of the joint space, regions of sclerosis at the joint surface, or joint deformity.
An abnormality of the knee joint or surrounding structures.
An abnormally decreased level of immunoglobulin M (IgM) in blood.
A severe form of respiratory insufficiency characterized by inadequate gas exchange such that the levels of oxygen or carbon dioxide cannot be maintained within normal limits.
The presence of a carcinoma of the thyroid gland.
A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the pancreas.
A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the liver.
An abnormally decreased calcium concentration in the blood.
An abnormally decreased sodium concentration in the blood.
Microscopic hematuria detected by dipstick or microscopic examination of the urine.
High levels of ketone bodies in the urine.
An increased concentration of histidine in the urine.
Over curvature of the thoracic region, leading to a round back or if sever to a hump.
Exaggerated convexity of the cervical vertebral column, causing the cervical spine to bow outwards and take on a rounded appearance.
A congenital anomaly characterized by a joining (fusion) of two or more cervical vertebral bodies with one another.

A granulomatous inflammation leading to multiple granuloma formation, which is a specific type of inflammation. A granuloma is a focal compact collection of inflammatory cells, mononuclear cells predominating, usually as a result of the persistence of a non-degradable product and of active cell mediated hypersensitivity.
The occurrence of an immune reaction against the organism's own cells or tissues.
The occurrence of an immune reaction against the organism's own cells or tissues.
A bending or abnormal curvature affecting a long bone of the leg.
A bending or abnormal curvature of the tibia.
A bending or abnormal curvature of the radius.

Neuroblastoma is a solid tumor that originate in neural crest cells of the sympathetic nervous system. Most neuroblastomas originate in the abdomen, and most abdominal neuroblastomas originate in the adrenal gland. Neuroblastomas can also originate in the thorax, usually in the posterior mediastinum.
Abnormality originating in one or more muscles, i.e., of the set of muscles of body.
Bending of the diaphysis (shaft) of the ulna.
Bending of the diaphysis (shaft) of the ulna.
An elevation in bone density in one or more diaphyses. Sclerosis is normally detected on a radiograph as an area of increased opacity.
An abnormality of the shoulder, which is defined as the structures surrounding the shoulder joint where the humerus attaches to the scapula.
An elevated lipid concentration in the blood.
Disproportionately long fibulae.
An increased excretion of phosphates in the urine.
Abnormal rhythm of the heart.
An abnormally high level of uric acid in the urine.
Increased excretion of oxalates in the urine.
An increased concentration of carnosine in the urine.
The presence of nipples that instead of pointing outward are retracted inwards.
Decreased superior-inferior length of the nasal bridge, which is the saddle-shaped area that includes the nasal root and the lateral aspects of the nose.
An abnormally increased overall level of immunoglobulin E in blood.
An abnormally increased level of immunoglobulin G in blood.
Aplasia of the vagina.
An abnormally increased level of immunoglobulin A in blood.
Distention of the abdomen.
Abnormal increased size of the viscera of the abdomen.
Reduced side to side width of the pelvis.
Reduced ability to move the vertebral column with a resulting limitation of neck and trunk flexion.
Joint pain affecting the hip.
Increased susceptibility to fatigue.
Abnormal sensations such as tingling, pricking, or numbness of the skin with no apparent physical cause.
An unpleasant sensation characterized by physical discomfort (such as pricking, throbbing, or aching) localized to the lower back.
A reduction in the number of axons in the peripheral nervous system.
The presence of axonal regeneration following a previous axonal lesion.

An abnormality of the primary sensation that is mediated by peripheral nerves (pain, temperature, touch, vibration, joint position). The word hypoesthesia (or hypesthesia) refers to a reduction in cutaneous sensation to a specific type of testing.
An abnormally increased level of immunoglobulin M in blood.
An increased concentration of ornithine in the urine.
An abnormally low level of uric acid in the blood.
Abnormally increased concentration of hydrogencarbonate in the urine.

The presence of foam cells, a type of macrophage that localizes to fatty deposits on blood vessel walls, where they ingest low-density lipoproteins and become laden with lipids, giving them a foamy appearance.
Muscle hypertrophy affecting the thighs.
A mode of inheritance in which the severity of a disorder increases or the age of onset decreases as the disorder is passed from one generation to the next.
A malformation of the uterus in which the uterus is present as a paired organ as a result of the failure of fusion of the mullerian ducts during embryogenesis.
Bruxism is characterized by the grinding of the teeth including the clenching of the jaw and typically occur during sleep.
A partial dislocation of the shoulder joint.
Missing radius bone associated with congenital failure of development.
Increased width of the radius.
Missing ulna bone associated with congenital failure of development.
Increased length of the ulna.
Reduction in diameter of the ulna.
Reduction in diameter of the ulna.

A hand in which the fingers are of nearly equal length and deflected at the first interphalangeal joint, so as to give a forklike shape consisting of separation of the first and second as well as the third and fourth digits.

A hand in which the fingers are of nearly equal length and deflected at the first interphalangeal joint, so as to give a forklike shape consisting of separation of the first and second as well as the third and fourth digits.

Significant increase in the length and girth of most or all of a digit compared to its contralateral digit (if unaffected) or compared to what would be expected for age/body build. The increased girth is accompanied by an increase in the dorso-ventral dimension AND the lateral dimension of the digit.
An abnormal groove on the midline of the nose that may extend to the nasal tip.
The presence of more than the normal number of carpal bones.
Short palm.

For children from birth to 4 years of age, the palm width is more than 2 SD below the mean; for children from 4 to 16 years of age the palm width is below the 5th centile; or, the width of the palm appears disproportionately narrow for its length.
An abnormally decreased level of immunoglobulin G (IgG) in blood.
Abnormally increased body weight.
Abnormally low body weight.
Partial or complete wasting (atrophy) of the skin.
Inflammation of the alimentary part of the gastrointestinal system.

A functional rather than mechanical obstruction of the intestines, associated with manifestations that resemble those caused by an intestinal obstruction, including distension, abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, constipation or diarrhea, in an individual in whom a mechanical blockage has been excluded.
Abnormal displacement or malposition of the anus.
An ulcer of the gastrointestinal tract.
A decreased sensitivity to odorants (that is, a decreased ability to perceive odors).
A forehead with abnormal flatness.

This is a description previously used to describe a facial form characterized by a short, upturned nose, wide mouth, widely spaced eyes, and full cheeks. Because of the imprecision in this definition it is preferable to describe these features precisely. This term is retained because it was often used in the past, but it should not be used for new annotations.

This is a description previously used to describe a facial form characterized by a short, upturned nose, wide mouth, widely spaced eyes, and full cheeks. Because of the imprecision in this definition it is preferable to describe these features precisely. This term is retained because it was often used in the past, but it should not be used for new annotations.

An abnormality of head shape characterized by the presence of a short, wide head as well as a pointy or conical form of the top of the head owing to premature closure of the coronal and lambdoid sutures.
Increased length of the hairs of the eyebrows.
Butterfly vertebrae have a cleft through the body of the vertebrae and a funnel shape at the ends.

A type of atrial arrhythmia characterized by atrial rates of between 240 and 400 beats per minute and some degree of atrioventricular node conduction block. Typically, the ventricular rate is half the atrial rate. In the EKG; atrial flutter waves are observed as sawtooth-like atrial activity. Pathophysiologically, atrial flutter is a form of atrial reentry in which there is a premature electrical impulse creates a self-propagating circuit.
Fragile, easily breakable scalp hair.
Excessive, increased hair growth located in the elbow region.
Acute hepatitis complicated by acute liver failure with hepatic encephalopathy occurring less than 8 weeks after the onset of jaundice.
Defect in the epithelium of the esophagus, essentially an open sore in the lining of the esophagus.
An aneurysm (severe localized balloon-like outward bulging) in the pulmonary artery.

Aortic dilatation refers to a dimension that is greater than the 95th percentile for the normal person age, sex and body size. In contrast, an aneurysm is defined as a localized dilation of the aorta that is more than 150 percent of predicted (ratio of observed to expected diameter 1.5 or more). Aneurysm should be distinguished from ectasia, which represents a diffuse dilation of the aorta less than 50 percent of normal aorta diameter.
An abnormal connection between an artery and vein.
Abnormal twisting of arteries or veins.
Bony outgrowths that extend laterally from the margin of the metaphysis.
A type of hearing impairment affecting primarily the higher frequencies of sound (3,000 to 6,000 Hz).
Deterioration or loss of the tissues of the cochlea.

An atrial arrhythmia characterized by disorganized atrial activity without discrete P waves on the surface EKG, but instead by an undulating baseline or more sharply circumscribed atrial deflections of varying amplitude an frequency ranging from 350 to 600 per minute.
Enlargement of the chamber of the right ventricle.
Cyst-like space not lined by epithelium and contained within the pancreas. Pancreatic pseudocysts are often associated with pancreatitis.
A collection of pus in the area of the rectum.
Obstruction affecting the biliary tree.
A chronic form of gastritis.
The presence of developmental dysplasia of the pancreas.
A developmental defect resulting in abnormal closure, or atresia of the tubular structure of the jejunum.
Developmental hypoplasia of the intestine.
Hemorrhage occurring within a joint.
A pregnancy that ends at a stage in which the fetus is incapable of surviving on its own, defined as the spontaneous loss of a fetus before the 20th week of pregnancy.
A separation (dissection) of the layers of an artery.

Abnormally flat (obtuse) angle of the mandible. The angle of the mandibular, located at the junction between the body and the ramus of the mandible, is normally close to being a right angle. This terms describes an abnormal increase of this angle such that the mandible appears flatter than normal.
Reduced convexity of the occiput (posterior part of skull).
An abnormally decreased level of immunoglobulin E (IgE) in blood.
A duplication of the renal pelvis.
A type of carcinoma of the kidney with origin in the epithelium of the proximal convoluted renal tubule.
Sclerosis (abnormal hardening) of cortical bone, characterized by increased radiodensity.
Underdevelopment (reduced size) of the tibia.
Underdevelopment of both forearm bones, the ulna and the radius, resulting in a shortened forearm.
Atresia of the biliary tree.
The presence of more than the normal number of metacarpal bones.
Blockage of the upper airway at the level of the larynx often accompanied by respiratory distress.
A developmental defect defined by the failure of the formation of the lumen (tube) of the ureter.
Obstruction of the flow of urine through the ureter.
Increased length of multiple or a single phalanx of finger.
Underdevelopment of the spleen.
Hyperplasia of the pancreas.
A chronic form of pancreatitis.
Persistence of the primary teeth beyond the age by which they normally are shed and replaced by the permanent teeth.
Short dental root.
Shortening of the legs related to developmental hypoplasia of the bones of the leg.
Increased length of the radius.
An abnormal high-pitched noisy sound, occurring during inhalation or exhalation caused by the incomplete obstruction in the throat.
The presence of abnormal calcium deposition in the liver.
Abnormally reduced diameter (cross section) of the clavicles.
Chest wall pain in the area of the costochondral junctions.
A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the stomach.
A slowly growing malignant neoplasm derived from cartilage cells.
Encephalopathy with onset in the infantile period.
Complete loss of ability to move facial muscles innervated by the facial nerve (i.e., the seventh cranial nerve).
Increased size of cerebral gyri, often associated with a moderate reduction in the number of sulci of the cerebrum.
Agenesis of the midbrain.
A cessation of the development of a child in the areas of motor skills, speech and language, cognitive skills, and social and/or emotional skills.
Reduced ability to perceive painful stimuli.
An abnormality of the pons.
The presence of atrophy (wasting) of the corpus callosum.
A type of blistering that affects the skin of the palms of the hands and the soles of the feet.
Reduced number or density of facial hair.
Narrowing of a tear duct (lacrimal duct).
Abnormally big lacrimal glands.
Increased depth of the anterior chamber, i.e., the anteroposterior distance between the cornea and the iris is increased.
Complete color blindness, a complete inability to distinguish colors. Affected persons cannot perceive colors, but only shades of gray.
Congenital absence or closure of the opening of the lacrimal punctum.
Blindness with onset at birth.
A reduction of corneal clarity.
Congenital malformation of the lacrimal duct associated with incomplete development of the bony nasolacrimal canal or craniofacial anomalies.
Absence of the anterior chamber of the eye owing to a developmental defect.
A wrinkle of retinal tissue projecting outward from the surface of the retina and visible as a line on fundoscopy.
Reduced density of hairs.
Medial deviation of the great toe owing to a deformity of the great toe joint causing the hallux to deviate medially.
Medial deviation of the great toe owing to a deformity of the great toe joint causing the hallux to deviate medially.
An overall widening of the spaces between the digits.
A congenital deformity characterized by a dorsiflexed, inverted, and adducted foot, i.e., a combination of talipes calcaneus and talipes varus.

Abnormal plantar flexion of the calcaneus relative to the longitudinal axis of the tibia. This results in the angle between the long axis of the tibia and the long axis of the heel bone (calcaneus) being greater than 90 degrees.
A morphological abnormality of the vertebral arch, i.e., of the posterior part of a vertebra.
Over curvature of the lumbar region.
A severe form of hypermetropia with over +5.00 diopters.
A type of hearing impairment affecting primarily the low frequencies of sound (125 Hz to 1000 Hz).
The presence of a malformed cochlea.
A malformation of the auricle of the ear.
Abnormal enlargement of the urinary bladder.

Presence of persistent islands of renal blastema in the postnatal kidney. Nephroblastomatosis represents a complex abnormality of nephrogenesis and has been defined as the persistence of metanephricblastema into infancy and childhood.
Abnormal narrowing of the urethra.
Hypertrophy of the clitoris.
A disordered proliferation of mature tissues that are native to the kidneys.
Congenital absence of the scrotum.
The presence of a fistula between the vagina and the urethra.
The presence of a diverticulum (sac or pouch) in the wall of the urethra.
Developmental hypoplasia of the vagina.
Congenital absence of the lumen of the larynx.
Bowing (abnormal curvature) of the vocal folds.
Underdevelopment of the musculature.
Decreased strength of the abdominal musculature.
Reduced ability to run.
Muscular atrophy involving the muscles of the hand.
Aplasia of one or more fingers.
Abnormally short finger associated with developmental hypoplasia.
Absence of the tibia.
Absence of the tibia.
Proximal mislocalization of the thumb.

Chilblains, also called perniosis, are an inflammatory skin condition related to an abnormal vascular response to the cold. We are unaware of a reliable estimate of incidence. It typically presents as tender, pruritic red or bluish lesions located symmetrically on the dorsal aspect of the fingers, toes, ears and nose. Less commonly, reports describe involvement of the thighs and buttocks. The lesions present hours after exposure to cold and usually resolve spontaneously in one to three weeks.

Cortical tubers in the brain are hamartomatous lesions typically located at the gray-white matter interface, commonly in the frontal and parietal lobes. Cortical tubers are composed of abnormal glial and neural cells, and the size, number, and location vary among patients.
The presence of a neoplasm of the kidney.
A benign tumor of striated muscle.
A glioma originating in the optic nerve or optic chiasm.
Nephrosclerosis refers to thickening or scarring (\
Double rows of eyelashes.
Double rows of eyelashes.
A bony defect in the skull base.
Partial fusion of the upper and lower eyelid margins by single or multiple bands of tissue.
Absent thumb, i.e., the absence of both phalanges of a thumb and the associated soft tissues.
Absent thumb, i.e., the absence of both phalanges of a thumb and the associated soft tissues.
Hypoplasia (congenital reduction in size) of the thumb.
Presence of a bifid sacral bone.
Short (hypoplastic) phalanx of finger, affecting one or more phalanges.
Increased thickness of the external ear.
Distortion of the course of the normal folds of the ear and the appearance of supernumerary crura and folds.
Presence of nodules in the conjunctiva of the eye.
Decreased thickness of the helix of the ear.
A dermal melanocytic hamartoma that presents as bluish hyperpigmentation on the face along the first or second branches of the trigeminal nerve. Nevus of Ota may involve the sclera.
A dermal melanocytic hamartoma that presents as bluish hyperpigmentation on the face along the first or second branches of the trigeminal nerve. Nevus of Ota may involve the sclera.
Complete absence of all nasal structures.
Increased aperture of the nostril.
The presence of only a single nostril.
The presence of only a single nostril.
Slender, slit-like aperture of the nostril.
Slender, slit-like aperture of the nostril.
Excess facial hair.
The presence of an asymmetric mouth.
This term applies if one or more of the phalanges of the hand are either partially duplicated, depending on severity leading to a broad or bifid appearance of the phalanges, or completely duplicated.

ET: Duplication of the proximal phalanx of hand
DEF: This term applies if one or more of the proximal phalanges of the hand are either partially duplicated, depending on severity leading to a broad or bifid appearance of the phalanges, or completely duplicated.
Visible increase in width of the hallux without an increase in the dorso-ventral dimension.
Underdevelopment (hypoplasia) of the big toe.
Underdevelopment (hypoplasia) of the big toe.
Partial/complete duplication of one or more phalanx of toe.
A gap in the lower lip.
Fibrous band between the mucosal surfaces of the upper and lower alveolar ridges.
Lack of the uvula.
Tongue with a median apical indentation or fork.
Glossy appearance of the entire tongue surface.
A heterogeneous group of congenital spinal anomalies that result from defective closure of the neural tube early in fetal life.
A neoplasm affecting the spinal cord.
Absence (aplasia) of the sacrum.
Reduced inferior to superior extent of the thorax.
Reduced inferior to superior extent of the thorax.
The presence of hypertrophy of the breast.
A congenital anomaly characterized by the presence of supernumerary fingers or toes.
An abnormal connection between the epithelialised surface of the anal canal and the perianal skin.
A developmental defect resulting in complete obliteration of the lumen of the colon. That is, there is an abnormal closure, or atresia of the tubular structure of the colon.
An abnormal narrowing of the lumen of the esophagus.
An abnormal (non-anatomic) location of the spleen.

A developmental disorder characterized by the progressive loss of primordial germ cells in the developing ovaries of an embryo, leading to hypoplastic ovaries composed of wavy connective tissue with occasional clumps of granulosa cells, and frequently mesonephric or hilar cells.

A developmental disorder characterized by the progressive loss of primordial germ cells in the developing ovaries of an embryo, leading to hypoplastic ovaries composed of wavy connective tissue with occasional clumps of granulosa cells, and frequently mesonephric or hilar cells.
Buildups of minerals that form in the urinary bladder.
Abnormal increase in size of the upper limbs (due to an increase of the size of cells).
The ability of the elbow joint to move beyond its normal range of motion.
Abnormal increase in size of the lower limbs (due to an increase of the size of cells).
The ability of the knee joint to extend beyond its normal range of motion (the lower leg is moved beyond a straight position with respect to the thigh).
A bending or abnormal curvature of the fibula.
Duplication of the fibula. This may occur as a part of diplopodia (accessory tarsal or metatarsal bone). Diplopodia with double fibula is an extremely rare condition.
A difference in size or shape between the left and right foot.
An abnormal increase in quantity or strength of fetal movements.
Gait apraxia affecting the ability to make walking movements with the legs.
Gait apraxia affecting the ability to make walking movements with the legs.

Inability to recognize objects not because of sensory deficit but because of the inability to combine components of sensory impressions into a complete pattern. Thus, agnosia is a neurological condition which results in an inability to know, to name, to identify, and to extract meaning from visual, auditory, or tactile impressions.

A writing disability in the absence of motor or sensory deficits of the upper extremities, resulting in an impairment in the ability to write regardless of the ability to read and not due to intellectual impairment.
Inability to recognize faces of familiar persons.
The tendency to repeat vocalizations made by another person.

Vertical nystagmus may present with either up-beating or down-beating eye movements or both. When present in the straight-ahead position of gaze it is referred to as upbeat nystagmus or downbeat nystagmus.
Downbeat nystagmus is a type of fixation nystagmus with the fast phase beating in a downward direction. It generally increases when looking to the side and down and when lying prone.
Severe or complete weakness of both lower extremities with sparing of the upper extremities.
An abnormal vertical orientation of the clivus (which normally forms a kind of slope from the sella turcica down to the region of the foramen magnum).
A hamartoma (disordered proliferation of mature tissues) which can originate from any tissue of the eye.

Cone-shaped epiphyses (also known as coned epiphyses) are epiphyses that invaginate into cupped metaphyses. That is, the epiphysis has a cone-shaped distal extension resulting from increased growth of the central portion of the epiphysis relative to its periphery.
Sclerosis of the epiphyses, leading to an increased degree of radiopacity (white or ivory appearance) in X-rays.

Hordeola externa are acute purulent infections affecting the sebaceous glands of Zeis or the apocrine sweat glands of Moll, often caused by staphylococcus infections. In contrast to chalazia, hordeola are extremely painfull and can cause extreme local swelling.

Hordeola interna are acute purulent infections affecting the meibomian sebacious glands, often caused by staphylococcus infections. In contrast to chalazia (chronic epithelioid cell granulomatous inflammation of the meibomian gland caused by inflammation of a blocked meibomian gland), hordeola are extremely painfull and can cause extreme local swelling.

Cutaneous skin tags also known as acrochorda or fibroepithelial polyps are small benign tumours that may either form secondarily over time primarily in areas where the skin forms creases, such as the neck, armpit or groin or may also be present at birth, in which case they usually occur in the periauricular region.
The presence of multiple pits (small, pinpoint-large indentations on the surface of the skin) located on the skin of sole of foot.
The presence of multiple pits (small, pinpoint-large indentations on the surface of the skin) located on the skin of sole of foot.
The presence of a lung fibroma, a benign neoplasm that can present as a mass causing airway obstruction, cough, and hemoptysis, or present without symptoms as a solitary pulmonary nodule.
The presence of a lung fibroma, a benign neoplasm that can present as a mass causing airway obstruction, cough, and hemoptysis, or present without symptoms as a solitary pulmonary nodule.
A fibroma of the heart.

Facial nerve palsy is a dysfunction of cranial nerve VII (the facial nerve) that results in inability to control facial muscles on the affected side with weakness of the muscles of facial expression and eye closure. This can either be present in unilateral or bilateral form.

Facial nerve palsy is a dysfunction of cranial nerve VII (the facial nerve) that results in inability to control facial muscles on the affected side with weakness of the muscles of facial expression and eye closure. This can either be present in unilateral or bilateral form.
Inability to detect any qualitative olfactory sensation.
Reduced ability to detect any qualitative olfactory sensation.
Enuresis occurring during waking hours of the day.
A type of Congenital cataract in which the opacities occupy the subcapsular cortex at the anterior or posterior pole of the lens.
An asymmetriy, i.e., difference in size, shape or position between the left and right ear.
This may present as a partial or complete duplication of the eyebrows.

A lamellar pattern visible on radiographs and mainly localized at the metaphyses of the long tubular bones. Pathologic-anatomical studies revealed that these benign signs on x-rays are the result of a juvenile metaphyseal bone necrosis. Calcifications in the necrotic marrow lead to this lamellar or lattice-like appearance.
Loss of elasticity of the upper and lower eyelids causing the skin to sag and bulge.
A persistent midline depression of the skin over the fat pad of the chin.
Decreased length of the eyelashes (subjective).
A hair-containing cyst or sinus usually in the coccygeal region.
The presence of an additional membrane in the left or right cardiac atrium which results in the subdivision of the affected atrium (and thus in total three atria, whence the name).
Marked widening of the trachea.
Over-sensitivity to certain frequency ranges of sound.
Skin dimples are cutaneous indentations that are the result of tethering of the skin to underlying structures (bone) causing an indentation.
Skin dimples are cutaneous indentations that are the result of tethering of the skin to underlying structures (bone) causing an indentation.
A glioma affecting the cerebellum.

A hemangioblastoma is a benign vascular neoplasm that arises almost exclusively in the central nervous system. Hemangioblastomas consist of a tightly packed cluster of small blood vessels forming a mass of up to 1 or 2 cm in diameter.
A neoplasm of the pineal gland.
Visible space between the dental arches in occlusion.
Decreased width of the uvula.

A congenital, hairless plaque consisting of overgrown epidermis, sebaceous glands, hair follicles, apocrine glands and connective tissue. They are a variant of epidermal naevi. Sebaceous naevi most often appear on the scalp, but they may also arise on the face, neck or forehead. At birth, a sevaceous nevus typically appears as a solitary, smooth, yellow-orange hairless patch. Sebaceous naevi become more pronounced around adolescence, often appearing bumpy, warty or scaly.
Epidermal naevi are due to an overgrowth of the epidermis and may be present at birth (50%) or develop during childhood.

Atonic seizure is a type of motor seizure characterized by a sudden loss or diminution of muscle tone without apparent preceding myoclonic or tonic event lasting about 1 to 2 seconds, involving head, trunk, jaw, or limb musculature.
Focal emotional seizure with laughing (gelastic) is characterized by bursts of laughter or giggling, usually without appropriate related emotion of happiness, and described as 'mirthless'.

A scintillating scotoma is a common visual aura that can preced a migraine, whereby a spot of flickering light near the center of the visual fields occurs. The spot prevents vision, and is thus termed scotoma. The scotoma can extend into one or more shimmering arcs of white or colored flashing lights.
A reduced sense of touch (tactile sensation). This is usually tested with a wisp of cotton or a fine camel's hair brush, by asking patients to say 'now' each time they feel the stimulus.
Spontaneous pain is a kind of neuropathic pain which occurs without an identifiable trigger.
An incomplete closure of the abdominal wall.

Incoordination of movement caused by a deficit in the sensory nervous system. Sensory ataxia can be distinguished from cerebellar ataxia by asking the patient to close his or her eyes. Persons with cerebellar ataxia show only a minimal worsening of symptoms, whereas persons with sensory ataxia show a marked worsening of symptoms.
Atrophy of the cervical segment of the spinal cord.
Shortening of the extremities affecting primarily the distal parts of the limbs (hands and feet) in relation to the other segments of the limbs.
Morbus Kienboeck is a Juvenile aseptic necrosis affecting the Os lunatum.
An abnormality of the renal pelvis.
The presence of dilatation of the renal pelvis.
The presence of a dilated urinary bladder.
A severe form of myopia with greater than -6.00 diopters.
An abnormality of the fallopian tube.
A decreased rate of urine production.
The presence of a supernumerary, i.e., extra, tooth or teeth.
A green staining of teeth.
An abnormality of canine tooth.
Talon cusp is an accessory cusp located near the cingulum (the portion of the lingual or palatal aspect of the tooth that forms a convex protuberance at the cervical third of the anatomic crown).
A dental anomaly characterized by the presence of a two fused teeth.
An abnormal closure, or atresia of the tubular structure of the ileum.
An increase in the amount of intravascular fluid, particularly in the volume of the circulating blood.
A significant descent of the kidney as the patient moves from the supine to the erect position.
A spherical hollow structure with a smooth muscle coat, lined by a mucous membrane, and attached to any part of the gastrointestinal tract, from the base of the tongue to the anus.
Atypical absence status epilepticus is a type of generalized non-convulsive status epilepticus without coma that is semiologically a prolonged atypical absence seizure.
A seizure characterized by elementary auditory phenomena including buzzing, ringing, drumming or single tones as its first clinical manifestation.
A seizure characterized by taste phenomena including acidic, bitter, salty, sweet, or metallic tastes as its first clinical manifestation.
Seizures characterized by olfactory phenomena as its first clinical manifestation.

A seizure characterized by elementary visual hallucinations such as flashing or flickering lights/colours, or other shapes, simple patterns, scotomata, or amaurosis as its first clinical manifestation.

A focal seizure characterized at onset by predominantly proximal limb or axial muscles producing irregular sequential ballistic movements, such as pedaling, pelvic thrusting, thrashing, rocking movements.
EEG with an amplitude less than 30 microvolts without observable occipital alpha rhythm (8-13 Hz).
Forward prominence of the entire forehead, due to protrusion of the frontal bone.
Redundant eyelid skin pressing the eyelashes against the cornea and/or conjunctiva.
Redundant eyelid skin pressing the eyelashes against the cornea and/or conjunctiva.
An eyebrow that extends straight across the brow, without curve.
Antihelix protrusion directed more anteriorly than laterally, forming a shelf overlying the posterior concha.
Lack of convexity or prominence of the contour of the ridge between the bottom of the incisura and the confluence of the ascending helix and crus helix.
Increased height of the tragal ridge with a shallow indentation at the apex, giving the appearance of a double peak.
Increased height of the tragal ridge with a shallow indentation at the apex, giving the appearance of a double peak.
A complete or partial duplication of the tragus; expected to lie anterior to the normal tragus.
Abnormally increased variability in the size of erythrocytes.
For children from birth to 16 years of age the length of the palm is more than the 97th centile; or, the length of the palm appears relatively long compared to the finger length or the limb length.
The contour of the foot in lateral profile has a convex shape.
Divergence of digits along the anteroposterior axis (in the plane of the sole).
Asymmetry of the anterior part of the skull.
Asymmetry of the posterior part of the skull.
An abnormality of the fontanelle.
Yellowish discoloration of the nails.
Thickening of the epidermal layer of the skin.
Delivery of a fetus through surgical incisions made through the abdominal wall (laparotomy) and the uterine wall (hysterotomy).
Delivery of newborn by means of a ventouse, a vacuum device used to assist the delivery of a baby when the second stage of labour has not progressed adequately.
Increased length of the umbilical cord.
Separation of the placenta from the uterus wall before delivery.

JT: 時間OR時OR時期OR期間OR?倍の|死OR死亡
DEF: The age group when the cessation of life happens.
Clonus is an involuntary tendon reflex that causes repeated flexion and extension of the foot. Ankle clonus is tested by rapidly flexing the foot upward.
Aplasia of the malleus.
This term refers to the loss of eyelashes that were previously present.
A developmental defect in which the gallbladder fails to form.
The enteric villi are atrophic or absent.

In primary position, the eyes drift slowly downward and then spontaneously beat upward. Upward gaze accentuates the nystagmus. The associated oscillopsias are often very irritating, but the symptoms are usually transient.
A macular hole is a small break in the macula, located in the center of the retina.
Individuals with anomalous trichromacy possess three types of cones, but one of the three types of cones has an abnormal spectral sensitivity compared to normal cones.

A type of anomalous trichromacy associated with abnormal M photopigment, such that the absorption spectrum is shifted toward L wavelengths. Affected individuals have difficulties distinguishing between red and green.
Complete lack of the M photopigment, which is replaced with the L photopigment. Affected individuals tend to confuse red and green.
Complete lack of the M photopigment, which is replaced with the L photopigment. Affected individuals tend to confuse red and green.
Blue and green cones only; no functional red cones.
An iris cyst is composed of a single cell layer of epithelium and is filled with fluid.
A benign brown pigmented area over the iris representing proliferation of melanocyte cells in the stromal layer of the iris. An iris nevus can be flat or occasionally slightly elevated.
A small break in the retina.
A small break in the retina.
Inflammation of the vitreous body, characterized by the presence of inflammatory cells and protein exudate in the vitreous cavity.
Right atrial isomerism is characterized by bilateral triangular, morphologically right atrial, appendages, both joining the atrial chamber along a broad front with internal terminal crest.
In left atrial isomerism there is a bilateral small finger-shaped morphologically left atrial appendage joining the atrial chamber along a narrow front without an internal terminal crest.
Mirror image atrial arrangement, with morphologic right atrium on the left hand side and morphologic left atrium on the right hand side.
A congenital malformation with abnormal connection between one of the coronary arteries and a heart chamber or another blood vessel.

A myxoma (tumor of primitive connective tissue) of the heart. Cardiac myxomas consist of stellate to plump, cytologically bland mesenchymal cells set in a myxoid stroma. Cardiac myxomas are of endocardial origina and general project from the endocardium into a cardiac chamber.
Abnormal proliferation of blood vessels within the cardiac cavities attached to the endocardium.

A teratoma within the heart. Most commonly, these tumors are detected in the pericardial cavity attached to the pulmonary artery and aorta. The tumour size within the heart varies from 2 to 9 cm in diameter, and intrapericardial tumors as large as 15 cm have been reported. Intracardiac tumors arise from the atrial or ventricular wall as nodular masses protruding into the cardiac chambers. Cardiac and pericardial teratomas are easily detected in the fetus and neonate by two-dimensional echocardiography as heterogeneous and encapsulated cystic masses. Histologically, cardiac teratomas contain multiple immature elements including epithelium, neuroglial tissue, thyroid, pancreas, smooth and skeletal muscle, cartilage and bone.
Hemorrhage into the parenchyma of the cerebellum.
Heart rate of greater than 100 beats per minute.

Atrioventricular (AV) dissociation is present if the atria and the ventricles are under the control of two separate pacemakers. AV dissociation can occur in the absence of a primary AV conduction disturbance.
Weakness of the peroneal muscles.
Clonus at the elbow joint, i.e., an exaggerated phasic stretch reflex characterized by repetitive, rhythmic contractions at the elbow, generated by rapid passive stretch at the elbow joint.

A pituitary tumor with subarachnoid, brain, or systemic metastasis. The diagnosis of a pituitary carcinoma requires evidence of metastatic disease, either outside the central nervous system (CNS) or as separate noncontiguous foci within the CNS.
A benign (noncancerous) tumorlike malformation made up of an abnormal mixture of cells and tissues that originates in the tongue.
An encephalocele located between bregma and lambda.

Distance between the philtral ridges, measured just above the vermilion border, more than 2 standard deviations below the mean. Alternatively, an apparently decreased distance between the ridges of the philtrum.
Nasal tip positioned to one side of the midline.
Decrease in width of the nasal tip.
A potentially lethal cardiac arrhythmia characterized by an extremely rapid, hemodynamically unstable ventricular tachycardia (150-300 beats/min) with a large oscillating sine-wave appearance.
A type of abdominal pain that comes and goes in waves, most often starting and ending suddenly and being of severe intensity.
Inflammation of the parotid gland.
Accumulation of blood within the pericardial sac.
Abnormal accumulation of fluid leading to swelling of the pharynx.
A discrete mass of neoplastic monoclonal plasma cells either in the bone marrow or in an extramedullary location.
Bleeding in the anterior chamber of the eye.
Significant maternal haemorrhage/blood loss following deilvery of a child.
Hemoglobin H (HbH) contains four beta-globin chains. It is normally not present at all in blood, but may make up about 1-40 percent of all hemoglobin in HbH disease, a subform of alpha thalassemia.
Proximal mislocalization of the big toe from its normal position.
One or more digit that appears disproportionately short compared to the hand/foot, whereby either the entire digit or a specific phalanx is shortened.
A small hole through the whole thickness of the retina.
A reduced concentration of copper in the blood.
A reduced concentration of copper in the blood.
Failure of formation of the lumen of the gallbladder, often associated with gallbladder hypoplasia.
Clay colored stools lacking bile pigment.
Affective auras with subjective qualities similar to those experienced in life but are recognized by the subject as occurring outside of actual context.
Auras with an alteration of actual percepts involving the visual, auditory, somatosensory, olfactory or gustatory systems.
Elevated concentration of galactose in the urine.
An abnormal accumulation of fluid and swelling in the tissues of the larynx.
Malignant neoplasms which probably originate in primitive mesenchymal stem cell populations differentiating down a lipomatous pathway.

Corneal guttata are droplet-like accumulations of non-banded collagen on the posterior surface of Descemet's membrane. The presence of focal thickenings of Descemet's membrane histologically named guttae. Cornea guttata can be easily diagnosed in vivo and ex vivo by means of specular microscopy as it gives dark areas where no endothelial cells are visible.

An abnormality of the pupillary light reaction characterized by a marked slowing of the light reaction of usually just one pupil. The pupil tends to be relatively dilated, and there is reduced accommodation.

An abnormality of mental functioning affecting the personality and behavioural tendencies of an individual and characterized by a rigid and unhealthy pattern of thinking and behavior. The definition of a personal disorder implies that the abnormality is not the result of damage or insult to the brain or from another psychiatric disorder.
An abnormally increased size of the cerebellum compared to other brain structures.
An abnormal color of the urine, that is, the color of the urine appears different from the usual straw-yellow color.
A deviation from the normal odor of the urine.
Underdevelopment of the pons.
A cancer of the prostate.
The presence of blood in the pleural space.
Splitting of the retinal layers in the macula.
Inability to experience pleasure activities usually found enjoyable.
A dilatation (balooning or bulging out of the vessel wall) of a carotid artery.
A developmental defect resulting in the presence of fewer than the normal number of digits.
A developmental defect resulting in the presence of fewer than the normal number of digits.
Repetitive and compulsive picking of skin which results in tissue damage.
A phenomenon in which persons repetitively pull out their own hair, resulting in noticeable hair loss.
Habitual striking of one's own head against a surface such as a mattress or wall of a crib.
Habitual striking of one's own head against a surface such as a mattress or wall of a crib.
Excessive vomiting in early pregnancy, leading to the loss of 5% or more of body weight.
A fungal infection of the toenails or fingernails that tends to cause the nails to thicken, discolor, disfigure, and split.
A lack of mobility of ejaculated sperm.
Blood clot formed within muscle tissue following leakage of blood into the tissue.
Development of the reproductive system is inconsistent with the chromosomal sex.
A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the mouth.
A congenital defect with an abnormal joining of the gums of the upper and lower jaw.
A neoplasm containing histiocytes.
A neoplasm containing histiocytes.
An inflammation of the kidney involving the parenchyma of kidney, the renal pelvis and the kidney calices.
An abnormally decreased phosphate concentration in the urine.
Absence of concavity or convexity of the face when viewed in profile.
An abnormality of the malar surface of the zygomatic bone and including the frontal process of maxilla.
Large or prominent malar surface of the zygomatic bone of the skull, which is convex and forms the prominence of the 'cheek bones'.
Edema (swelling) of the bulbar conjunctiva.
Abnormal smallness of the lens.
Aplasia of the hallux, that is, a development defect such that the big toe does not develop.
Inflammation of the large airways in the lung including any part of the bronchi from the primary bronchi to the tertiary bronchi.
A small tear in the thin, moist tissue (mucosa) that lines the anus. It appears as a crack or slit in the mucous membrane of the anus.

A type of spastic paraparetic gait in which the muscle tone in the adductors is marked. It is characterized by hypertonia and flexion in the legs, hips and pelvis accompanied by extreme adduction leading to the knees and thighs hitting, or sometimes even crossing, in a scissors-like movement. The opposing muscles (abductors) become comparatively weak from lack of use.
The onset of growth of pubic hair at an earlier age than normal.
The inability of the colon to modify stool to an acceptable consistency and move the stool from the cecum to the rectosigmoid area at least once every three days.
Protruding heel bone, or calcaneus.
Subjective feeling of tiredness characterized by a lack of energy and motivation that persists for six months or longer.
Constipation for longer than three months with fewer than 3 bowel movements per week, straining, lumpy or hard stools, and a sensation of anorectal obstruction or incomplete defecation.
Constipation of sudden onset and lasting for less than three months.
A turning outward of the lip or lips, that is, eversion of the lips.

A wavering, unsteady voice that reflects involuntary and approximately sinusoidal oscillation of motor unit firings of laryngeal muscles. Vocal tremor results in low frequency modulations of voice frequency or amplitude and intermittent voice instability.

A wavering, unsteady voice that reflects involuntary and approximately sinusoidal oscillation of motor unit firings of laryngeal muscles. Vocal tremor results in low frequency modulations of voice frequency or amplitude and intermittent voice instability.
Inflammation of adipose tissue.
Inflammation of adipose tissue.
A complication of pregnancy and delivery in which the umbilical cord wraps around the fetal neck once or multiple times.
Persistent pain, usually defined as pain that has lasted longer than 3 to 6 months.
Persistent pain, usually defined as pain that has lasted longer than 3 to 6 months.
Abnormal sensations with no apparent physical cause that are painful or unpleasant.
First period after the age of 15 years.
A type of mesenchymal tissue cell tumor that exhibits epithelial differentiation, which most frequently arises in the extremities.
A partial duplication of the ureter where the duplicated ureters fuse to a single ureter before their insertion into the bladder.
A complete duplication of the ureter, where the duplicated ureters have separate insertions into the bladder.
A type of glomerulonephropathy characterized by thickening of the basement membrane and deposition of immune complexes in the subepithelial space.
An abnormal amount of urine production.
A cyst located along the allantois canal.
Tremulousness (trembling) of the lens of the eye.

A testis that is located at the upper scrotum or lower inguinal canal and that can be made to descend completely into the scrotum without resistance by manual reduction but returns to its original position by the cremasteric reflex.
A severe form of gait ataxia such that an affected person cannot walk at all.
A sudden, irresistible need to have a bowel movement.
Excessive growth of a nail laterally into the nail fold.
A severe form of hearing impairment.
Tumor (An abnormal mass of tissue resulting from abnormally dividing cells) of the nasal cavity.

A vascular malformation resulting from a developmental error of venous tissue composed of dysmorphic channels lined by flattened endothelium and exhibiting slow turnover. A venous malformation may present as a blue patch on the skin ranging to a soft blue mass. Venous malformations are easily compressible and usually swell in thewhen venous pressure increases (e.g., when held in a dependent position or when a child cries). They may be relatively localized or quite extensive within an anatomic region.
Fingernail that appears thin when viewed on end.
Excessive fat around the stomach and abdomen.
Toenail that appears thin when viewed on end.
Toenail that appears thin when viewed on end.
Abnormal increase in size of the brainstem.
A sensation of breathlessness in the recumbent position, relieved by sitting or standing.

A deviation from normal of the length of the arm span (length from one end of an individual's arms measured at the fingertips to the other when raised parallel to the ground at shoulder height at a one-hundred eighty degree angle)

Decreased length of the arm span (length from one end of an individual's arms measured at the fingertips to the other when raised parallel to the ground at shoulder height at a one-hundred eighty degree angle).
