Increased length of the arm span (length from one end of an individual's arms measured at the fingertips to the other when raised parallel to the ground at shoulder height at a one-hundred eighty degree angle).
A lacy pattern or iris pigmentation that resembles the spokes of a bicycle wheel.
A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the ear.
A type of hearing impairment affecting primarily the middle frequencies of sound (1000 Hz to 3000 Hz).
Inflammation of the connective and adipose tissues surrounding the kidney.

Bigonial distance (lower facial width) more than 2 standard deviations below the mean (objective); or an apparently decreased width of the lower jaw (mandible) when viewed from the front (subjective).
Disruption of the epithelial layer of the cornea with involvement of the underlying stroma.
A benign tumour originating from the outer root sheath of the hair follicle.
The narrowing or partial blockage of a portion of the small intestine.
Bleeding from the small intestine.
A narrowing of a segment of colon whereby bowel continuity is maintained.
Spermatozoa with very small cranial ends devoid of any nuclear material, that is, lacking a typical sperm head.
Abnormality in the process of ejection of semen (usually carrying sperm) from the male reproductive tract.
Difficulty of a male in achieving orgasm.
Inability to ejaculate.
A fluid filled sac located in the Fallopian tube.
A twisting of the Fallopian tube. Sudden onset with sharp, colicky pelvic pain associated with nausea, vomiting, bowel, and bladder symptoms is the usual presentation.
The presence of a supernumerary Fallopian tube.
A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the eye.

An epiretinal membrane is a thin sheet of fibrous tissue that can develop on the surface of the macular area of the retina and cause a disturbance in vision. An epiretinal membrane area can develop on the thin macular area of the retin. An epiretinal membrane is also sometimes called a macular pucker, premacular fibrosis, surface wrinkling retinopathy or cellophane maculopathy.

A nuclear cataract is an opacity or clouding that develops in the lens nucleus. That is, a nuclear cataract is one that is located in the center of the lens. The nucleus tends to darken changing from clear to yellow and sometimes brown.

Cerebral palsy describes a group of permanent disorders of the development of movement and posture, causing activity limitation, that are attributed to nonprogressive disturbances that occurred in the developing fetal or infant brain. The motor disorders of cerebral palsy are often accompanied by disturbances of sensation, perception, cognition, communication, and behaviour, by epilepsy, and by secondary musculoskeletal problems.
An aberrant thyroid gland or Ectopic thyroid located at the base of the tongue, just posterior to the foramen cecum as a result of a failure of the thyroid to descend.
A fibroblastic sarcoma is a malignant tumor derived from fibrous connective tissue and characterized by immature proliferating fibroblasts or undifferentiated anaplastic spindle cells.
A fibroblastic sarcoma is a malignant tumor derived from fibrous connective tissue and characterized by immature proliferating fibroblasts or undifferentiated anaplastic spindle cells.
Deposition of calcium salts in muscle tissue.

A condition in which middle parts of the hands and/or feet (digits and meta-carpals and -tarsals) are missing giving a cleft appearance. The severity is very variable ranging from slightly hypoplastic 3rd toe/fingers over absent 2nd or 3rd toes/fingers as far as oligo- or monodactyl hands and/or feet.
A depression located on a lip.
A small, skin-lined tract that leads from the surface to deep within the tissues.

Ring fibers are formed by a bundle of peripheral myofibrils which are circumferentially oriented such that they encircle the internal portion of the sarcoplasm which is normal in structure and orientation.
Intracellular aggregates of actin and actin-associated proteins within nerve cells.
An intraneuronal inclusion body composed of acid mucopolysaccharides.
The presence of an increased number of mast cells and CD34+ mast cell precursors in the body.
Increased frequency of urination.
Painful or difficult urination.
Congenital duplication of all or part of a limb.
Persistence of the urachal canal with drainage of urine from the bladder through the persistent allantois canal to the umbilicus.
Tumor of the lung.
Inflammation of the episclera, a thin layer of tissue covering the white part (sclera) of the eye.
Inflammation of the episclera, a thin layer of tissue covering the white part (sclera) of the eye.
Edema in the region of the eyelids.
Abnormality in the process of thought including the ability to process information.
A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the heart.
Narrowing or constriction of the inner surface (lumen) of an artery.
Undergrowth of the limbs that affects only one side.
Duplication of the spinal cord.
Coexistence of two hemicords, at variable levels, causing splaying of the posterior vertebral elements. Results in neurological deficits in lower limb or perineum.
Triplication of the spinal cord - extremely rare.
Dilation of central canal from incomplete fusion of the posterior columns or persistence of the primitive large canal of the embryo.
Congenital absence of the spinal cord.
Inflammation of the urinary bladder.
Localized loss of fat tissue.
A rupture of the cornea through which a portion of the iris protrudes.
An inflammation of the endocardium, the inner layer of the heart, which usually involves the heart valves.
An inflammation of the endocardium, the inner layer of the heart, which usually involves the heart valves.
The foreskin becomes trapped behind the glans penis, and cannot be pulled back to its normal flaccid position covering the glans penis.
The foreskin becomes trapped behind the glans penis, and cannot be pulled back to its normal flaccid position covering the glans penis.
The presence of an abscess of the peritoneum.

An abnormal forward-flexed posture e.g. forward flexion of the spine, which is noticeable when standing or walking but disappears when lying down. It is becoming an increasingly recognized feature of Parkinson's disease and dystonic disorders.
The nostrils (the paired channels of the nose) are not present.
The nostrils (the paired channels of the nose) are not present.
Pregnancy-induced hypertension in association with significant amounts of protein in the urine.
Pregnancy-induced hypertension in association with significant amounts of protein in the urine.
Pain during menstruation that interferes with daily activities.
Pain during menstruation that interferes with daily activities.
Bleeding at irregular intervals.
A type of undifferentiated germ cell tumor that may be benign or malignant.
The presence of a dysgerminoma, i.e., an undifferentiated germ cell tumor of the ovary.
A seizure during pregnancy.
The presence of a diverticulum of the esophagus.

The presence of a piece lung tissue which is not attached to the pulmonary blood supply and does not communicate with the other lung tissue (not connected to the standard bronchial airways and not performing a function in respiration).
A multidimensional but common male sexual dysfunction that involves an alteration in any of the components of the erectile response, including organic, relational and psychological.
Presence of a cyst (sac-like structure) located in the larynx.
Brown or black discoloration of the nails.
Inflammation of the thyroid gland.
A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the tongue.
A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the vagina.
Inflammation of the optic nerve.
A bacterial infection and inflammation of the skin und subcutaneous tissues.

Coarse appearance of the components of the network of osseous tissue that makes up the cancellous structure of a bone, i.e., thickening of the (usually fine) white lines that are produced by trabeculae in radiograms.
A developmental disorder in which there is a duplication of a portion of the muscle and submucosa of the esophagus without epithelial duplication.
A congenital absence or considerable underdevelopment of the trachea such that communication between the larynx proximally and the alveoli of the lungs distally is lacking.
Tremulousness of the iris on movement of the eye, occurring in subluxation of the lens.
Tremulousness of the iris on movement of the eye, occurring in subluxation of the lens.
Tibial torsion is inward twisting (medial rotation) (PATO:0002155) of the tibia.
Aggression towards oneself.
An abnormality of coagulation associated with an increased risk of thrombosis.
An excessive number of histiocytes (tissue macrophages).
Bleeding into the biliary tree.

Lymphangiomas are rare congenital malformations consisting of focal proliferations of well-differentiated lymphatic tissue in multi cystic or sponge like structures. Lymphangioma is usually asymptomatic due to its soft consistency but compression of adjacent structures can be seen due to the mass effect of a large tumor.
Excessively active peristalsis (wave of contraction of the tubular organs of the gastrointestinal tract) marked by excessive rapidity of the passage of food through the stomach and intestine.
Reduced or inadequate peristalsis, with resultant slow passage of contents through the digestive tract.
Excessive growth or abnormal thickening of bone tissue.
Excessive growth or abnormal thickening of bone tissue.
A widening or ballooning of the dural sac surrounding the spinal cord usually at the lumbosacral level.
Lack of separation of the upper and lower lips.
The loss of intercellular connections, such as desmosomes, resulting in loss of cohesion between keratinocytes.
Aplasia of the pancreas.

The middle finger is more than 2 SD above the mean for newborns 27 to 41 weeks EGA or above the 97th centile for children from birth to 16 years of age AND the five digits retain their normal length proportions relative to each other (i.e., it is not the case that the middle finger is the only lengthened digit), or, Fingers that appear disproportionately long compared to the palm of the hand.
Testicular torsion is when the spermatic cord to a testicle twists, cutting off the blood supply. The most common symptom is acute testicular pain.
Increased inferior to superior extent of the thorax.
Inflammatory or noninflammatory diseases affecting the glomeruli of the nephron.
A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the nail.
Spontaneous flow of milk from the breast, unassociated with childbirth or nursing.
Spontaneous flow of milk from the breast, unassociated with childbirth or nursing.
Absence of the liver owing to a failure of the liver to develop.
A developmental anomaly wtih a small tubular or saccular midline stomach.
A chronic, relapsing, pustular eruption that is localized to the palms and soles.
Absence of the musculature.
Increased width of the ischium, which forms the lower and back part of the hip bone.
Underdevelopment of the iliac bones.
Increased length and width of one half of the tounge.
Persistence of the embryonic dorsal or sciatic vein system that normally should have involuted around the tenth to twelfth week of intrauterine life.
Increase in size of the hippocampus.
Flaring (widening) of the epiphysis.

A type of anomalous trichromacy associated with defective long-wavelength-sensitive (L) cones, causing the sensitivity spectrum to be shifted toward medium wavelengths. This leads to difficulties especially in distinguishing red and green.
A plaque is a solid, raised, plateau-like (flat-topped) lesion greater than 1 cm in diameter.
Morphologically similar to a papule, but greater than either 10mm in both width and depth, and most frequently centered in the dermis or subcutaneous fat.
A circumscribed, fluid-containing, epidermal elevation generally considered less than 10mm in diameter at the widest point.
A discontinuity of the skin exhibiting incomplete loss of the epidermis, a lesion that is moist, circumscribed, and usually depressed.
A discontinuity of the skin exhibiting complete loss of the epidermis and often portions of the dermis and even subcutaneous fat.
Disproportionately small hand.
Scar tissue in the macula.
Scar tissue in the macula.
Acute hepatic injury resulting from inflammation typically accompanied by increased serum alanine transaminase activity. Etiologies include viral hepatitis, drugs, toxins, and autoimmune disorders.
Hepatitis that lasts for more than six months.
Thickening of the heart walls in both ventricles.
The presence of inflammation of the prostate.
Absence of any measurable level of sperm in his semen.

Abnormal position of urethral meatus on the ventral penile shaft (underside) characterized by displacement of the urethral meatus from the tip of the glans penis to the ventral surface of the penis, scrotum, or perineum.
A ureterocele is a congenital saccular dilatation of the distal segment of the ureter.
The distention of the ureter with urine.
Increased levels of protein in the urine.
A nonspecific term referring to disease or damage of the kidneys.
Prolonged and excessive menses at regular intervals in excess of 80 mL or lasting longer than 7 days.
Uvula separated into two parts most easily seen at the tip.
An abnormality of the appearance of the face caused by constant contraction of the lips leading to a puckered or pursed appearance.
Height of the palate more than 2 SD above the mean (objective) or palatal height at the level of the first permanent molar more than twice the height of the teeth (subjective).

Bizygomatic (upper face) and bigonial (lower face) width are both more than 2 standard deviations below the mean (objective); or, an apparent reduction in the width of the upper and lower face (subjective).
Increased prominence or roundness of soft tissues between zygomata and mandible.
Facial contours, as viewed from the front, show a broad upper face/cranium and lower face/mandible, creating a square appearance.
Interalar distance more than 2 SD below the mean for age, or alternatively, an apparently decreased width of the nasal base and alae.

Pterygium colli is a congenital skin fold that runs along the sides of the neck down to the shoulders. It involves an ectopic fibrotic facial band superficial to the trapezius muscle. Excess hair-bearing skin is also present and extends down the cervical region well beyond the normal hairline.
Involuntary contractions of the neck musculature resulting in an abnormal posture of or abnormal movements of the head.
A congenital abnormality of the cornea in which the cornea and the anterior segment of the eye are smaller than normal. The horizontal diameter of the cornea does not reach 10 mm even in adulthood.
A type of astigmatism associated with abnormal curvatures on the anterior and/or posterior surface of the cornea.

Any noninflammatory disease of the retina. This nonspecific term is retained here because of its wide use in the literature, but if possible new annotations should indicate the precise type of retinal abnormality.
Inflammation of the eyelids.
Distance between the inner canthi more than two standard deviations above the mean (objective); or, apparently increased distance between the inner canthi.
Difficulty distinguishing between yellow and blue, possible related to dysfunction of the S photopigment.
Diffusely large eye (with megalocornea) associated with glaucoma.
A cone-shaped deformity of the cornea characterized by the presence of corneal distortion secondary to thinning of the apex.
Loss of visual acuity (implying that vision was better at a certain timepoint in life). Otherwise the term reduced visual acuity should be used (or a subclass of that).
Excessive sensitivity to light with the sensation of discomfort or pain in the eyes due to exposure to bright light.
A markedly blue coloration of the iris.
A developmental anomaly characterized by a reduced number of teeth, whereby more than 6 teeth are missing.
Increased volume of dental pulp of permanent molar.
Decreased size of the teeth, which can be defined as a mesiodistal tooth diameter (width) more than 2 SD below mean. Alternatively, an apparently decreased maximum width of tooth.
A type of dental dysplasia occurring in dentinogenesis imperfecta in which the pulp chambers are enlarged and there is a reduced amount of coronal dentin.
Erupted tooth or teeth at birth.
An exaggeration of emotional affects such as laughing crying, or yawning beyond what the person feels.
A type of anxiety disorder characterized by avoidance of public places, especially where crowds gather.
Presence of only 11 pairs of ribs.
Wide, concave rib end.
The presence of a row of multiple rounded expansions (beadlike prominences) at the junction of a rib and its cartilage.
Papilledema refers to edema (swelling) of the optic disc secondary to any factor which increases cerebral spinal fluid pressure.
The presence of xanthomata in the skin of the eyelid.
Loss of strength in the arm, leg, and sometimes face on one side of the body. Hemiplegia refers to a complete loss of strength, whereas hemiparesis refers to an incomplete loss of strength.
A type of Developmental delay characterized by a delay in acquiring motor skills.

Damage to cerebral nuclei caused in infants by highly increased levels of unconjugated bilirubin. The basal ganglia and brainstem nuclei could be shown to have a yellow staining historically in infants who died of kernicterus, that is, kernicterus is strictly speaking a pathological diagnosis. The presence of kernicterus may be inferred in infants with characteristic acute or chronic bilirubin-induced neurological dysfunction.
Impairment of bile flow due to obstruction in bile ducts.
A midline anterior incomplete closure of the abdominal wall in which there is herniation of the abdominal viscera into the base of the abdominal cord.
Increased size of the teeth, which can be defined as a mesiodistal tooth diameter (width) more than 2 SD above mean for age. Alternatively, an apparently increased maximum width of the tooth.
A rapid heartrate that exceeds the range of the normal resting heartrate for age.
A slower than normal heart rate (in adults, slower than 60 beats per minute).
Polysplenia is a congenital disease manifested by multiple small accessory spleens.
A foot for which the measured width is below the 5th centile for age; or, a foot that appears disproportionately narrow for its length.
Detachment of the nail from the nail bed.
Longitudinal, linear prominences in the nail plate.
White discoloration of the nails.
Reduction inexisting body weight.
Increased length of the big toe.
Gout affecting the Metatarsophalangeal joint of big toe.
An abnormally low number of neutrophils in the peripheral blood.
A reduced number of lymphocytes in the blood.
Reduced body temperature due to failed thermoregulation.

A type of ataxia characterized by the impairment of the ability to coordinate the movements required for normal walking. Gait ataxia is characteirzed by a wide-based staggering gait with a tendency to fall.
A kind of ataxia that affects movements of the extremities.
An abnormally heightened sensitivity to loud sounds.
Hair shafts are rough in texture.

The term woolly hair refers to an abnormal variant of hair that is fine, with tightly coiled curls, and often hypopigmented. Optical microscopy may reveal the presence of tight spirals and a clear diameter reduction as compared with normal hair. Electron microscopy may show flat, oval hair shafts with reduced transversal diameter.
The vomiting of blood.
Heterotopia or neuronal heterotopia are macroscopic clusters of misplaced neurons (gray matter), most often situated along the ventricular walls or within the subcortical white matter.

Anencephaly is a developmental anomaly characterized by a fetus that has no calvarium, with a lack of most or all of the fetus' brain tissue. Anencephaly belongs to a collective group known as neural tube defects (NTD) and is a result of the neural tube failing to close in its rostral end during fetal development.
An unintentional, oscillating to-and-fro muscle movement affecting head movement.

Abnormally diminished motor activity. In contrast to paralysis, hypokinesia is not characterized by a lack of motor strength, but rather by a poverty of movement. The typical habitual movements (e.g., folding the arms, crossing the legs) are reduced in frequency.
An unintentional, oscillating to-and-fro muscle movement affecting the hand.
Weakness or partial paralysis in the lower limbs.
Protrusion of the meninges through a defect of the vertebral column.
A specific learning disability involving mathematics and arithmetic.

Paralysis of all four limbs, and trunk of the body below the level of an associated injury to the spinal cord. The etiology of quadriplegia is similar to that of paraplegia except that the lesion is in the cervical spinal cord rather than in the thoracic or lumbar segments of the spinal cord.
A form of torticollis in which the head is drawn back, either due to a permanent contractures of neck extensor muscles, or to a spasmodic contracture.
Greater than normal amounts of fat in the feces. This is a result of malabsorption of lipids in the small intestine and results in frothy foul-smelling fecal matter that floats.
Inflammation of the peritoneum.
Low Blood Pressure, vascular hypotension.
Increased width of the skull.
The legs angle inward, such that the knees are close together and the ankles far apart.
An abnormally decreased potassium concentration in the blood.
Amelia of all four limbs.
Disproportionately long fibulae.
An abnormal shortening of the femur.
A increased concentration of arginine in the urine.
A phenomenon whereby patients are not able to stand up without the use of the hands owing to weakness of the proximal muscles of the lower limbs.
Abnormal sensations such as tingling, pricking, or numbness of the skin with no apparent physical cause.
A reduction in the number of axons in the peripheral nervous system.

JT: 成人OR成体OR大人OR成体型OR成人型OR大人OR成人性|開始OR発生ORオンセットOR発症OR発病OR作用発現
DEF: Onset of disease manifestations in adulthood, defined here as at the age of 16 years or later.
Multiple punctate calcifications in the dental pulp.
Missing ulna bone associated with congenital failure of development.
The total absence of the hand, with no bony elements distal to the radius or ulna.

For children from birth to 4 years of age, the palm width is more than 2 SD below the mean; for children from 4 to 16 years of age the palm width is below the 5th centile; or, the width of the palm appears disproportionately narrow for its length.
A kind of congenital defect of the anterior abdominal wall in which the intestines are evident through the thin, lax, and protruding abdominal wall in affected infants.
A reduced level of the complement component C8 in circulation.
Underdevelopment (reduced size) of the tibia.

Cornea plana is an abnormally flat shape of the cornea such that the normal protrusion of the cornea from the sclera is missing. The reduced corneal curvature can lead to hyperopia, and a hazy corneal limbus and arcus lipoides may develop at an early age.
Reduced density of hairs.
Astrocytoma is a neoplasm of the central nervous system derived from astrocytes. Astrocytes are a type of glial cell, and thus astrocytoma is a subtype of glioma.
A benign tumor of striated muscle.
The presence of pigmented, oval and dome-shaped raised hamartomatous nevi of the iris..
Hypoplasia (congenital reduction in size) of the thumb.

Horn-like malformations of the iliac crests with symmetrical bilateral central posterior iliac processes. A characteristic finding in the Nail-Patella syndrome. Iliac horns are visible on X-ray and may be palpable, but are asymptomatic.
A notched form of the helix of the ear. That is, a defect in the continuity of the helix, which may occur at any point along its length.
A condition associated with a limitation of the horizontal ocular movement with retraction of the globe and narrowing of the palpebral fissure on adduction
Accumulation of excessive amounts of lymphatic fluid (chyle) in the pleural cavity.
A congenital anomaly characterized by the presence of supernumerary fingers or toes.
A bifid or bifurcated appearance of the femur as seen on x-rays, possible appearing as a more or less severe bowing of the upper leg. Might be associated with hip dysplasia on the affected side.
A developmental defect in which the legs are fused together.

An intermittent cessation of airflow at the mouth and nose during sleep. Apneas of at least 10 seconds are considered important, but persons with sleep apnea may have apneas of 20 seconds to up to 2 or 3 minutes. Patients may have up to 15 events per hour of sleep.
A persistent midline depression of the skin over the fat pad of the chin.
Over-sensitivity to certain frequency ranges of sound.
Increased focal pigmentation of the vermilion of the lips.
Increased width of the uvula (subjective finding).
Decreased length of the uvula.

A type of ataxia characterized by the impairment of the ability to smoothly perform the elements of a voluntary movement in the appropriate order and speed. With dyssynergia, a voluntary movement appears broken down into its component parts.
An increased concentration of xanthine in the urine.
The presence of amyloid deposition in one or more tissues. Amyloidosis may be defined as the extracellular deposition of amyloid in one or more sites of the body.
A green staining of teeth.
The union of two separately developing tooth germs typically leading to one less tooth than normal in the affected dental arch.
An decrease in the amount of intravascular fluid, particularly in the volume of the circulating blood.
An inflammation of the tonsils.
The total absence of the foot, with no bony elements distal to the tibia or fibula.
Increased thumb width without increased dorso-ventral dimension.
Toes that are disproportionately narrow (reduced girth) for the hand/foot size or build of the individual.
The gradual reduction in girth of the toe from proximal to distal.
A nail plate that has a longitudinal separation with partially separated nails, each with a separate lateral radius of curvature.
Decreased width of nail.
Clonus is an involuntary tendon reflex that causes repeated flexion and extension of the foot. Knee clonus can be tested by rapidly pushing the patella towards the toes.

JT: 胎生期OR胎性OR胎児OR胎児性OR胎仔OR胎仔型|開始OR発生ORオンセットOR発症OR発病OR作用発現
DEF: Onset prior to birth but after 8 weeks of embryonic development (corresponding to a gestational age of 10 weeks).
Sudden, repetitive, nonrhythmic motor movements (spasms), involving the eyes and muscles of the face.
Exaggerated curvature of the lens of the eye, producing an anterior or posterior spherical bulging.

A solid, low grade, spindle cell, glial neoplasm of adults that originates in the neurohypophysis or infundibulum. Clinical signs and symptoms include visual disturbance, headache and features of hypopituitarism. Pituicytomas are well-circumscribed, solid masses that can measure up to several centimeters. Histologically, they show a compact architecture consisting of elongate, bipolar spindle cells arranged in interlacing fascicles or assuming a storiform pattern.

A congenital defect in the skull, whereby there is a protrusion of part of the cranial contents through a congenital defect in the cranium, usually covered with skin or mucous membrane. The term encephalocele refers to a subclass of these lesions in which brain tissue protrudes through the defect.
One or more digit that appears disproportionately short compared to the hand/foot, whereby either the entire digit or a specific phalanx is shortened.
Malignant neoplasms which probably originate in primitive mesenchymal stem cell populations differentiating down a lipomatous pathway.
A visual defect characterized by the inability to see as clearly in bright light as in dim light. The word hemeralopia literally means day blindness.

An abnormality of the pupillary light reaction characterized by a marked slowing of the light reaction of usually just one pupil. The pupil tends to be relatively dilated, and there is reduced accommodation.
Habitual biting of one's own body.
Habitual biting of one's own fingernails.
A malignant tumor of the bone which always arises in the medullary tissue, occurring more often in cylindrical bones.
An increased number of circulating monocytes.
Abnormal smallness of the lens.
Abnormally elevated blood carbon dioxide (CO2) level.
An abnormally high level of blood oxygen.
The presence of bacteria in the urine.
A complication of pregnancy and delivery in which the umbilical cord wraps around the fetal neck once or multiple times.
Abnormal sensations with no apparent physical cause that are painful or unpleasant.
Increased concentration of albumin in the urine.
The presence of renal casts (cylindrical, cigar-shaped structures produced by the kidney in certain disease states) in the urine.
A glial uniloculated or multiloculated fluid-filled sac that either reside within or completely replace the pineal gland.
Impaired conduction of cardiac impulse occurring anywhere along the conduction pathway.
Inflammation of the myocardium.

JT: 一般化OR全般的OR汎化OR全身性OR汎発性OR全般性
DEF: Affecting all regions without specificity of distribution.
Involuntary sounds produced by moving air through the nose, mouth, or throat. The vocal cords are not involved in all tics that produce sound.

Ring fibers are formed by a bundle of peripheral myofibrils which are circumferentially oriented such that they encircle the internal portion of the sarcoplasm which is normal in structure and orientation.
A chronic autoimmune phenomenon characterized by fibrosis (or hardening) and vascular alterations of the skin.
Undergrowth of the limbs that affects only one side.
Duplication of the spinal cord.
Dilation of central canal from incomplete fusion of the posterior columns or persistence of the primitive large canal of the embryo.
Localized loss of fat tissue.
Two penile structures, separated from the tip to the base of the shaft.
Inflammation of the esophagus.
Inflammation of the thyroid gland.

Acting on the spur of the moment in response to immediate stimuli; acting on a momentary basis without a plan or consideration of outcomes; difficulty establishing or following plans; a sense of urgency and self-harming behavior under emotional distress.

A systemic disease which can present with cutaneous lesions with or without internal involvement. Tumors are caused by Human herpesvirus 8 (HHV8), also known as Kaposi's sarcoma-associated herpesvirus (KSHV).
Collapse of part of a lung associated with absence of inflation (air) of that part.
Increased inferior to superior extent of the thorax.
The prolapse of the female urethra into the vagina.
Hamartoma-like growth in the placenta consisting of blood vessels.

A type of anomalous trichromacy associated with defective long-wavelength-sensitive (L) cones, causing the sensitivity spectrum to be shifted toward medium wavelengths. This leads to difficulties especially in distinguishing red and green.
An unpleasant sensation characterized by physical discomfort (such as pricking, throbbing, or aching) localized to the eye.
A plaque is a solid, raised, plateau-like (flat-topped) lesion greater than 1 cm in diameter.
Morphologically similar to a papule, but greater than either 10mm in both width and depth, and most frequently centered in the dermis or subcutaneous fat.
Dilatation of the bladder postnatally.
Displacement of the urethral opening on the dorsal (superior) surface of the penis.
Penile length more than 2 SD above the mean for age.
Abnormally small penis. At birth, the normal penis is about 3 cm (stretched length from pubic tubercle to tip of penis) with micropenis less than 2.0-2.5 cm.
A fluid filled sac in the kidney.
Absence of menses for an interval of time equivalent to a total of more than (or equal to) 3 previous cycles or 6 months.
Distance between the oral commissures more than 2 SD above the mean. Alternatively, an apparently increased width of the oral aperture (subjective).
Erosion of the mucous mebrane of the mouth with local excavation of the surface, resulting from the sloughing of inflammatory necrotic tissue.
A facial appearance characterized by a permanently or nearly permanently opened mouth.

The presence of a cleft in the oral cavity, the two main types of which are cleft lip and cleft palate. In cleft lip, there is the congenital failure of the maxillary and median nasal processes to fuse, forming a groove or fissure in the lip. In cleft palate, there is a congenital failure of the palate to fuse properly, forming a grooved depression or fissure in the roof of the mouth. Clefts of the lip and palate can occur individually or together. It is preferable to code each defect separately.
Dryness of the mouth due to salivary gland dysfunction.
Inflammation of the gingiva.
Oxycephaly (from Greek oxus, sharp, and kephalos, head) refers to a conical or pointed shape of the skull.
A face that is short (HP:0011219) and narrow (HP:0000275).
Bizygomatic (upper face) and bigonial (lower face) width greater than 2 standard deviations above the mean (objective); or an apparent increase in the width of the face (subjective).
A fold of skin starting above the medial aspect of the upper eyelid and arching downward to cover, pass in front of and lateral to the medial canthus.
The facial appearance is more circular than usual as viewed from the front.
Decreased vertical distance from the vermilion border of the lower lip to the inferior-most point of the chin.
Laterally protruding ear that lacks antihelical folding (including absence of inferior and superior crura).
Diminished length of the neck.
Increased side-to-side width of the neck.

A misalignment of the eyes so that the visual axes deviate from bifoveal fixation. The classification of strabismus may be based on a number of features including the relative position of the eyes, whether the deviation is latent or manifest, intermittent or constant, concomitant or otherwise and according to the age of onset and the relevance of any associated refractive error.
Difficulty distinguishing between yellow and blue, possible related to dysfunction of the S photopigment.
An abnormal white reflection from the pupil rather than the usual black reflection.
Inability to see well at night or in poor light.
A developmental anomaly characterized by a reduced number of teeth, whereby up to 6 teeth are missing.

Frequent feelings of being down, miserable, and/or hopeless; difficulty recovering from such moods; pessimism about the future; pervasive shame; feeling of inferior self-worth; thoughts of suicide and suicidal behavior.

A stereotypy is a repetitive, simple movement that can be voluntarily suppressed. Stereotypies are typically simple back-and-forth movements such as waving of flapping the hands or arms, and they do not involve complex sequences or movement fragments. Movement is often but not always rhythmic and may involve fingers, wrists, or more proximal portions of the upper extremity. The lower extremity is not typically involved. Stereotypies are more commonly bilateral than unilateral.
Reduced rib length.
Increased width of ribs
A bifid rib refers to cleavage of the sternal end of a rib, usually unilateral. Bifid ribs are usually asymptomatic, and are often discovered incidentally by chest x-ray.
Complete or partial merging of adjacent ribs.

Osteopenia is a term to define bone density that is not normal but also not as low as osteoporosis. By definition from the World Health Organization osteopenia is defined by bone densitometry as a T score -1 to -2.5.
Inability to sweat.
Wrinkled, redundant, inelastic and sagging skin.
Localized fluid retention and tissue swelling caused by a compromised lymphatic system.

A hemangioma is a benign tumor characterized by blood-filled spaces lined by benign endothelial cells. A hemangioma characterized by large endothelial spaces (caverns) is called a cavernous hemangioma (in contrast to a hemangioma with small endothelial spaces, which is called capillary hemangioma).
Increased susceptibility to erysipelas, as manifested by a medical history of repeated episodes of erysipelas, which is a superficial infection of the skin, typically involving the lymphatic system.
Diffusely large eye (with megalocornea) without glaucoma.
Inversion and rubbing of the eyelashes against the globe of the eye.
A conical projection of the anterior or posterior surface of the lens, occurring as a developmental anomaly.
Webbing or fusion of the fingers or toes, involving soft parts only or including bone structure. Bony fusions are referred to as \

For children from birth to 4 years of age the palm width is more than 2 SD above the mean; for children from 4 to 16 years of age the palm width is above the 95th centile; or, the width of the palm appears disproportionately wide for the length.

A condition in which middle parts of the hand (fingers and metacarpals) are missing giving a cleft appearance. The severity is very variable ranging from slightly hypoplastic middle fingers over absent middel fingers as far as oligo- or monodactyl hands.

An abnormal hand position characterized by hyperextension of the fourth and fifth fingers at the metacarpophalangeal joints and flexion of the interphalangeal joints of the same fingers such that they are curled towards the palm.
A motor disorder characterized by a velocity-dependent increase in tonic stretch reflexes with increased muscle tone, exaggerated (hyperexcitable) tendon reflexes.

Dysarthric speech is a general description referring to a neurological speech disorder characterized by poor articulation. Depending on the involved neurological structures, dysarthria may be further classified as spastic, flaccid, ataxic, hyperkinetic and hypokinetic, or mixed.
A condition in which there is increased muscle tone so that arms or legs, for example, are stiff and difficult to move.
Inflammation of the meninges.

Pachygyria is a malformation of cortical development with abnormally wide gyri with sulci 1,5-3 cm apart and abnormally thick cortex measuring more than 5 mm (radiological definition). See also neuropathological definitions for 2-, 3-, and 4-layered lissencephaly.
Repetitive pressing, poking, and/or rubbing in the eyes.
Excessive postnatal growth which may comprise increased weight, increased length, and/or increased head circumference.
Reduced intensity (volume) of speech.

A foot where the longitudinal arch of the foot is in contact with the ground or floor when the individual is standing; or, in a patient lying supine, a foot where the arch is in contact with the surface of a flat board pressed against the sole of the foot by the examiner with a pressure similar to that expected from weight bearing; or, the height of the arch is reduced.
A foot for which the measured width is above the 95th centile for age; or, a foot that appears disproportionately wide for its length.

A measured foot length that is more than 2 SD below the mean for a newborn of 27 - 41 weeks gestation, or foot that is less than the 3rd centile for individuals from birth to 16 years of age (objective). Alternatively, a foot that appears disproportionately short (subjective).
A nail that is diminished in length and width, i.e., underdeveloped nail.
Decreased length of nail.
Nail that appears thick when viewed on end.
A nail plate that has a longitudinal separation and the two sections of the nail share the same lateral radius of curvature.

The nail disease paronychia is an often-tender bacterial or fungal hand infection or foot infection where the nail and skin meet at the side or the base of a finger or toenail. The infection can start suddenly (acute paronychia) or gradually (chronic paronychia).
Increased width of nail.

A condition in which middle parts of the foot (toes and metatarsals) are missing giving a cleft appearance. The severity is very variable ranging from slightly hypoplastic 3rd toe over absent 2nd or 3rd toes as far as oligo- or monodactyl feet.
A widely spaced gap between the first toe (the great toe) and the second toe.
An abnormal decreased number of leukocytes in the blood.
Excessive thirst manifested by excessive fluid intake.
Coughing up (expectoration) of blood or blood-streaked sputum from the larynx, trachea, bronchi, or lungs.
Paralysis (complete loss of muscle function) in the arm, leg, and in some cases the face on one side of the body.
Lack of physical coordination resulting in an abnormal tendency to drop items or bump into objects.
Excessive daytime sleepiness.
A neurological anomaly with gross overeating associated with an abnormally strong desire or need to eat.
Inflammation of blood vessel.

Coxa valga is a deformity of the hip in which the angle between the femoral shaft and the femoral neck is increased compared to age-adjusted values (about 150 degrees in newborns gradually reducing to 120-130 degrees in adults).

A developmental malformation of the occipital bone and upper end of the cervical spine, in which the latter appears to have pushed the floor of the occipital bone upward such that there is an abnormal flattening of the skull base.
Osteolysis refers to the destruction of bone through bone resorption with removal or loss of calcium.
Joint pain.
Inspiration of a foreign object into the airway.
The presence of a meningioma, i.e., a benign tumor originating from the dura mater or arachnoid mater.
The presence of an ependymoma of the central nervous system.
A positional abnormality marked by outward bowing of the legs in which the knees stay wide apart when a person stands with the feet and ankles together.
The presence of abnormally small extremities.
An increased concentration of glucose in the urine.
An increased concentration of cystine in the urine.
An increased concentration of proline in the urine.
Distance from nasion to subnasale more than two standard deviations below the mean, or alternatively, an apparently decreased length from the nasal root to the nasal tip.
Widening of the femoral head and neck.

JT: 遅いOR遅発OR遅発型OR晩発OR後OR後期|開始OR発生ORオンセットOR発症OR発病OR作用発現
DEF: A type of adult onset with onset of symptoms after the age of 60 years.
Congenital lack of development of the muscles, which are then replaced by a mixture of dense fat and fibrous tissue.

The presence of foam cells, a type of macrophage that localizes to fatty deposits on blood vessel walls, where they ingest low-density lipoproteins and become laden with lipids, giving them a foamy appearance.
Formation of calcium deposits in any soft tissue.
Pili (from Latin pilus, hair) torti (from Latin tortus, twisted) refers to short and brittle hairs that appear flattened and twisted when viewed through a microscope.
Death of the fetus in utero after at least 20 weeks of gestation.
Increased width of the ulna.
Short palm.
A colon of abnormally small caliber.
Increased size of cerebral gyri, often associated with a moderate reduction in the number of sulci of the cerebrum.

JT: まだら症(パイボールディズム）
DEF: Piebaldism is characterized by stable and persistent, well-circumscribed depigmented patches present at birth affecting the skin of the face, trunk, and extremities in a symmetrical distribution.
An abnormality of the skin characterized the presence of excessive amounts of dry surface scales on the skin resulting from an abnormality of keratinization.
An outward deviation of the foot at the talocalcaneal or subtalar joint.
Disproportionate shortening of the proximal segment of limbs (i.e. the femur and humerus).
A hemisacral defect involving the sacral vertebrae S2 to S5. In hemisacrum, the first sacral vertebra is intact and there is agenesis involving only S2-S5.

Missing or malformed long bones of the extremities with the distal parts (such as hands and/or feet) connected to the variably shortened or even absent extremity, leading to a flipper-like appearance, as opposed to other forms of limb malformations were either the hole limb is missing (such as amelia), or the distal part of a limb is absent (peromelia).
Anisocoria, or unequal pupil size, may represent a benign physiologic variant or a manifestation of disease.
Stomatitis is an inflammation of the mucous membranes of any of the structures in the mouth.

A learning disorder characterized primarily by difficulties in learning to read and spell. Dyslectic children also exhibit a tendency to read words from right to left and to confuse letters such as b and d whose orientation is important for their identification. Children with dyslexia appear to be impaired in phonemic skills (the ability to associate visual symbols with the sounds they represent).

A writing disability in the absence of motor or sensory deficits of the upper extremities, resulting in an impairment in the ability to write regardless of the ability to read and not due to intellectual impairment.
Bursts of large-amplitude multidirectional saccades without intersaccadic interval
Severe or complete weakness of both lower extremities with sparing of the upper extremities.
Aplasia of a toe. That is, absence of all phalanges of a non-hallux digit of the foot and the associated soft tissues.
A digit with two nails, with at least some soft tissue between them.
Increased length of the uvula.
Morbus Koehler is a Juvenile aseptic necrosis affecting the Os naviculare pedis.
Talon cusp is an accessory cusp located near the cingulum (the portion of the lingual or palatal aspect of the tooth that forms a convex protuberance at the cervical third of the anatomic crown).
The development of two teeth from a single tooth bud, leading to a larger fused tooth.
Facial height (length) is more than two standard deviations below the mean (objective); or an apparent decrease in the height (length) of the face (subjective).
Absent eyelids.
Hypopigmented hair that appears white.
Individuals affected by dichromacy possess only two types of cones, instead of three.
Blue and green cones only; no functional red cones.
A benign brown pigmented area over the iris representing proliferation of melanocyte cells in the stromal layer of the iris. An iris nevus can be flat or occasionally slightly elevated.
Mesocardia is an abnormal location of the heart in which the heart is in a midline position and the longitudinal axis of the heart lies in the mid-sagittal plane.

Any cardiac rhythm other than the normal sinus rhythm. Such a rhythm may be either of sinus or ectopic origin and either regular or irregular. An arrhythmia may be due to a disturbance in impulse formation or conduction or both.
Visually assessable vertical indentation, cleft, or depression of the nasal bridge, ridge and tip.
Increased width of the midpoint of the mandible (mental protuberance) and overlying soft tissue.
Inflammation of the uveal tract in which inflammation affects the anterior chamber, vitreous, retina or choroid.
Increased concentration of uracil in the urine.
The presence of blood in the pleural space.
A type of tumor of the pancreatic beta cells that secretes excess insulin and can result in hypoglycemia.
Partial or complete loss of vision in one half of the visual field of one or both eyes.
Inflammation of the large airways in the lung including any part of the bronchi from the primary bronchi to the tertiary bronchi.
Abnormally reduced blood carbon dioxide (CO2) level.
Thickened nails without deformity.

Bigonial distance (lower facial width) more than 2 standard deviations below the mean (objective); or an apparently decreased width of the lower jaw (mandible) when viewed from the front (subjective).

JT: 境界線OR境界域OR境界ORボーダーライン
DEF: Having a minor degree of severity that is considered to be on the boundary between the normal and the abnormal ranges. For quantitative traits, a deviation of that is less than two standard deviations from the appropriate population mean.
The localization with respect to the side of the body of the specified phenotypic abnormality.

JT: 一側性OR一側OR片側性OR片側
DEF: Being present on only the left or only the right side of the body.

A varicocele is a widening of the veins along the spermatic cord, leading to enlarged, twisted veins in the scrotum, and manifested clinically by a painless testicle lump, scrotal swelling, or bulge in the scrotum.
A benign nerve sheath tumor composed of Schwann cells.
Movement-based tics affecting discrete muscle groups.
The presence of a fistula affecting the rectum.
A bacterial infection and inflammation of the skin und subcutaneous tissues.
A movement disorder which consists of effects including diminished voluntary movements and the presence of involuntary movements.
Inflammation of cartilage.

Rapid swelling (edema) of the dermis, subcutaneous tissue, mucosa and submucosal tissues of the skin of the face, normally around the mouth, and the mucosa of the mouth and/or throat, as well as the tongue during a period of minutes to several hours. The swelling can also occur elsewhere, typically in the hands. Angioedema is similar to urticaria, but the swelling is subcutaneous rather than on the epidermis.
An unpleasant sensation characterized by physical discomfort (such as pricking, throbbing, or aching) localized to the chest.
Lack of separation of the upper and lower lips.
Increased density of hairs, i.e., and elevated number of hairs per unit area.
A discontinuity of the skin exhibiting complete loss of the epidermis and often portions of the dermis and even subcutaneous fat.
Disproportionately small hand.
Ventral, lateral, or ventrolateral bowing of the shaft and glans penis of more than 30 degrees.
Abnormally small penis. At birth, the normal penis is about 3 cm (stretched length from pubic tubercle to tip of penis) with micropenis less than 2.0-2.5 cm.
A ureterocele is a congenital saccular dilatation of the distal segment of the ureter.
A congenital anomaly of the urinary tract, in which the kidney is duplicated and is drained via two separate renal pelves and ureters.
An abnormality of the kidney.

A reduction in the level of performance of the kidneys in areas of function comprising the concentration of urine, removal of wastes, the maintenance of electrolyte balance, homeostasis of blood pressure, and calcium metabolism.
A connection of the right and left kidney by an isthmus of functioning renal parenchyma or fibrous tissue that crosses the midline.
Increased levels of protein in the urine.
A height above that which is expected according to age and gender norms.
An abnormal increase in the size of the kidney.
A fluid filled sac in the kidney.
The presence of inflammation affecting the kidney.
A developmental defect in which a kidney is located in an abnormal anatomic position within the pelvis.
Severe distention of the kidney with dilation of the renal pelvis and calices.
Prolonged and excessive menses at regular intervals in excess of 80 mL or lasting longer than 7 days.
The presence of prolapse of the uterus.
Absence of menses for an interval of time equivalent to a total of more than (or equal to) 3 previous cycles or 6 months.
Any structural abnormality of the vagina.
Congenital occlusion of the vagina or adhesion of the walls of the vagina causing occlusion.
Distance between the commissures of the mouth more than 2 SD below the mean. Alternatively, an apparently decreased width of the oral aperture (subjective).
Cleft palate is a developmental defect of the palate resulting from a failure of fusion of the palatine processes and manifesting as a separation of the roof of the mouth (soft and hard palate).
Multiple indentations and/or elevations on the edge and/or surface of the tongue producing an irregular surface contour.

The presence of a cleft in the oral cavity, the two main types of which are cleft lip and cleft palate. In cleft lip, there is the congenital failure of the maxillary and median nasal processes to fuse, forming a groove or fissure in the lip. In cleft palate, there is a congenital failure of the palate to fuse properly, forming a grooved depression or fissure in the roof of the mouth. Clefts of the lip and palate can occur individually or together. It is preferable to code each defect separately.
Inflammation of the tongue.
Height of the palate more than 2 SD above the mean (objective) or palatal height at the level of the first permanent molar more than twice the height of the teeth (subjective).
Inflammation of the gingiva.

Hydrocephalus is an active distension of the ventricular system of the brain resulting from inadequate passage of CSF from its point of production within the cerebral ventricles to its point of absorption into the systemic circulation.
Inflammation of the paranasal sinuses owing to a viral, bacterial, or fungal infection, allergy, or an autoimmune reaction.
Tall head relative to width and length.
Oxycephaly (from Greek oxus, sharp, and kephalos, head) refers to a conical or pointed shape of the skull.

Bizygomatic (upper face) and bigonial (lower face) width are both more than 2 standard deviations below the mean (objective); or, an apparent reduction in the width of the upper and lower face (subjective).
Facial height (length) is more than 2 standard deviations above the mean (objective); or, an apparent increase in the height (length) of the face (subjective).
Facial height (length) is more than 2 standard deviations above the mean (objective); or, an apparent increase in the height (length) of the face (subjective).
A face with a rounded and slightly elongated outline.
The facial appearance is more circular than usual as viewed from the front.
A reduced degree of motion of the muscles beneath the skin of the face, often associated with reduced facial crease formation.

Inclination of the anterior surface of the forehead from the vertical more than two standard deviations above the mean (objective); or apparently excessive posterior sloping of the forehead in a lateral view.
Width of the forehead or distance between the frontotemporales is more than two standard deviations below the mean (objective); or apparently narrow intertemporal region (subjective).
An abnormally increased height of the forehead.
Frontal hairline with bilateral arcs to a low point in the midline of the forehead.
Inflammation or infection of the middle ear.
Epistaxis, or nosebleed, refers to a hemorrhage localized in the nose.
Epistaxis, or nosebleed, refers to a hemorrhage localized in the nose.
Interalar distance more than two standard deviations above the mean for age, i.e., an apparently increased width of the nasal base and alae.

An inability to perceive odors. This is a general term describing inability to smell arising in any part of the process of smelling from absorption of odorants into the nasal mucous overlying the olfactory epithelium, diffusion to the cilia, binding to olfactory receptor sites, generation of action potentials in olfactory neurons, and perception of a smell.
Interalar distance more than 2 SD below the mean for age, or alternatively, an apparently decreased width of the nasal base and alae.

Pterygium colli is a congenital skin fold that runs along the sides of the neck down to the shoulders. It involves an ectopic fibrotic facial band superficial to the trapezius muscle. Excess hair-bearing skin is also present and extends down the cervical region well beyond the normal hairline.
Increased inferior-superior length of the neck.
A congenital abnormality of the cornea in which the cornea and the anterior segment of the eye are smaller than normal. The horizontal diameter of the cornea does not reach 10 mm even in adulthood.

Any noninflammatory disease of the retina. This nonspecific term is retained here because of its wide use in the literature, but if possible new annotations should indicate the precise type of retinal abnormality.
Inflammation of the cornea.
Inflammation of the cornea.
Inflammation of the eyelids.
Glaucoma refers loss of retinal ganglion cells in a characteristic pattern of optic neuropathy usually associated with increased intraocular pressure.
Inflammation of the conjunctiva.
A cataract is an opacity or clouding that develops in the crystalline lens of the eye or in its capsule.
An eye that is protruding anterior to the plane of the face to a greater extent than is typical.
Absence of tear secretion.
Absence of the globe or eyeball.
A form of strabismus with one or both eyes turned inward ('crossed') to a relatively severe degree, usually defined as 10 diopters or more.
A form of strabismus with one or both eyes turned inward ('crossed') to a relatively severe degree, usually defined as 10 diopters or more.
A developmental anomaly characterized by abnormal smallness of one or both eyes.
A form of strabismus with one or both eyes deviated outward.
A form of strabismus with one or both eyes deviated outward.
Blindness is the condition of lacking visual perception defined as visual perception below 3/60 and/or a visual field of no greater than 10 degress in radius around central fixation.
Inflammation of the nasolacrimal sac.

An abnormal inversion (turning inward) of the eyelid (usually the lower) towards the globe. Entropion is usually acquired as a result of involutional or cicatricial processes but may occasionally be congenital.
A short discontinuity of the margin of the lower or upper eyelid.
Rhythmic, involuntary oscillations of one or both eyes related to abnormality in fixation, conjugate gaze, or vestibular mechanisms.
Reduced visual acuity that is uncorrectable by lenses in the absence of detectable anatomic defects in the eye or visual pathways.
An outward turning (eversion) or rotation of the eyelid margin.
Inability to see well at night or in poor light.
Meeting of the medial eyebrows in the midline.
Atrophy of the eyeball with blindness and decreased intraocular pressure due to end-stage intraocular disease.
A developmental anomaly characterized by a reduced number of teeth, whereby up to 6 teeth are missing.
The congenital absence of all teeth.
A developmental anomaly characterized by a reduced number of teeth, whereby more than 6 teeth are missing.
Overlapping teeth within an alveolar ridge.
Erupted tooth or teeth at birth.
Inflammation of the periodontium.
A condition characterized by changes of personality and thought patterns often accompanied by hallucinations and delusional beliefs.
A condition characterized by changes of personality and thought patterns often accompanied by hallucinations and delusional beliefs.
A state of exceeding restlessness and excessive motor activity associated with mental distress or a feeling of inner tension.

Autism is a neurodevelopmental disorder characterized by impaired social interaction and communication, and by restricted and repetitive behavior. Autism begins in childhood. It is marked by the presence of markedly abnormal or impaired development in social interaction and communication and a markedly restricted repertoire of activity and interest. Manifestations of the disorder vary greatly depending on the developmental level and chronological age of the individual (DSM-IV).
A lack of restraint manifested in several ways, including disregard for social conventions, impulsivity, and poor risk assessment.
A belief that is pathological and is held despite evidence to the contrary.
A defect of the chest wall characterized by a depression of the sternum, giving the chest (\
A deformity of the chest caused by overgrowth of the ribs and characterized by protrusion of the sternum.
The presence of calculi (stones) in the kidneys.
The presence of blood in the urine. Hematuria may be gross hematuria (visible to the naked eye) or microscopic hematuria (detected by dipstick or microscopic examination of the urine).
Inability to develop or maintain an erection of the penis.
A group of abnormalities characterized by hyperglycemia and glucose intolerance.
The presence of chronic increased pressure in the systemic arterial system.

A state of excessive water intake and hypotonic (dilute) polyuria. Diabetes insipidus may be due to failure of vasopressin (AVP) release (central or neurogenic diabetes insipidus) or to a failure of the kidney to respond to AVP (nephrogenic diabetes insipidus).
Ribs with a reduced diameter.
A broad chest.
Reduction in thickness of the skin, generally associated with a loss of suppleness and elasticity of the skin.
Abnormally diminished capacity to sweat.

Petechiae are pinpoint-sized reddish/purple spots, resembling a rash, that appear just under the skin or a mucous membrane when capillaries have ruptured and some superficial bleeding into the skin has happened. This term refers to an abnormally increased susceptibility to developing petechiae.
Inability to sweat.
Subjective impression of increased softness upon palpitation of the skin.
A red eruption of the skin.
Hypertrichosis is increased hair growth that is abnormal in quantity or location.
Any manifestation of a skin disease associated with the production of pus.
Abnormally increased hair growth referring to a male pattern of body hair (androgenic hair).

An inflammatory exfoliative dermatosis involving nearly all of the surface of the skin. Erythroderma develops suddenly. A patchy erythema may generalize and spread to affect most of the skin. Scaling may appear in 2-6 days and be accompanied by hot, red, dry skin, malaise, and fever.
An abnormal reduction in the amount of pigmentation (reduced or absent) of skin, hair and eye (iris and retina).
Raised, well-circumscribed areas of erythema and edema involving the dermis and epidermis. Urticaria is intensely pruritic, and blanches completely with pressure.
Raised, well-circumscribed areas of erythema and edema involving the dermis and epidermis. Urticaria is intensely pruritic, and blanches completely with pressure.

A hemangioma is a benign tumor characterized by blood-filled spaces lined by benign endothelial cells. A hemangioma characterized by large endothelial spaces (caverns) is called a cavernous hemangioma (in contrast to a hemangioma with small endothelial spaces, which is called capillary hemangioma).
Presence of multiple small cysts containing keratin (skin protein) and presenting as tiny pearly-white bumps just under the surface of the skin.
Pterygia are 'winglike' triangular membranes occurring in the neck, eyes, knees, elbows, ankles or digits.
Pterygia are 'winglike' triangular membranes occurring in the neck, eyes, knees, elbows, ankles or digits.

Thinned, erythematous, depressed bands of atrophic skin. Initially, striae appear as flattened and thinned, pinkish linear regions of the skin. Striae tend to enlarge in length and become reddish or purplish. Later, striae tend to appear as white, depressed bands that are parallel to the lines of skin tension. Striae distensae occur most often in areas that have been subject to distension such as the lower back, buttocks, thighs, breast, abdomen, and shoulders.
Hard, pebble-like deposits that form within the gallbladder.
The presence of inflammatory changes in the gallbladder.

A hazy, grayish-white ring about 2 mm in width located close to but separated from the limbus (the corneoscleral junction). Corneal arcus generally occurs bilaterally, and is related to lipid deposition in the cornea. Corneal arcus can occur in elderly persons as a part of the aging process but may be associated with hypercholesterolemia in people under the age of 50 years.

Dryness of the eye related to deficiency of the tear film components (aqueous, mucin, or lipid), lid surface abnormalities, or epithelial abnormalities. Keratoconjunctivitis sicca often results in a scratchy or sandy sensation (foreign body sensation) in the eyes, and may also be associated with itching, inability to produce tears, photosensitivity, redness, pain, and difficulty in moving the eyelids.
Inflammation of the iris.
The presence of a vaginal septum, thereby creating a vaginal duplication. The septum is longitudinal in the majority of cases.
A kind of polydactyly characterized by the presence of a supernumerary finger or fingers.
Abnormally long and slender fingers (\
A developmental defect resulting in the presence of fewer than the normal number of fingers.
An abnormal hand posture in which the hands are clenched to fists. All digits held completely flexed at the metacarpophalangeal and interphalangeal joints.
Fingers that are disproportionately narrow (reduced girth) for the hand/foot size or build of the individual.
A state of disinterestedness, listlessness, and indifference, resulting in difficulty performing simple tasks or concentrating.

Bulbar weakness (or bulbar palsy) refers to bilateral impairment of function of the lower cranial nerves IX, X, XI and XII, which occurs due to lower motor neuron lesion either at nuclear or fascicular level in the medulla or from bilateral lesions of the lower cranial nerves outside the brain-stem. Bulbar weakness is often associated with difficulty in chewing, weakness of the facial muscles, dysarthria, palatal weakness and regurgitation of fluids, dysphagia, and dysphonia.
Absence of neurologic reflexes such as the knee-jerk reaction.
Absence of neurologic reflexes such as the knee-jerk reaction.
Inflammation of the meninges.
Lack of clarity and coherence of thought, perception, understanding, or action.

A type of ataxia characterized by the inability to carry out movements with the correct range and motion across the plane of more than one joint related to incorrect estimation of the distances required for targeted movements.
Reduced strength of muscles.
Very brief, involuntary random muscular contractions occurring at rest, in response to sensory stimuli, or accompanying voluntary movements.

A spectrum of malformations of cortical development caused by insufficient neuronal migration that subsumes the terms agyria, pachygyria and subcortical band heterotopia. See also neuropathological definitions for 2-, 3-, and 4-layered lissencephaly.

Damage to cerebral nuclei caused in infants by highly increased levels of unconjugated bilirubin. The basal ganglia and brainstem nuclei could be shown to have a yellow staining historically in infants who died of kernicterus, that is, kernicterus is strictly speaking a pathological diagnosis. The presence of kernicterus may be inferred in infants with characteristic acute or chronic bilirubin-induced neurological dysfunction.
Inflammation of a joint.
Inflammation of a joint.
A chronic disorder of the liver in which liver tissue becomes scarred and is partially replaced by regenerative nodules and fibrotic tissue resulting in loss of liver function.
A chronic disorder of the liver in which liver tissue becomes scarred and is partially replaced by regenerative nodules and fibrotic tissue resulting in loss of liver function.
Steatosis is a term used to denote lipid accumulation within hepatocytes.
Simultaneous enlargement of the liver and spleen.
The presence of an increased number of freckles, small circular spots on the skin that are darker than the surrounding skin because of deposits of melanin.
The presence of an increased number of freckles, small circular spots on the skin that are darker than the surrounding skin because of deposits of melanin.
Abnormally prominent umbilicus (belly button).
Excessive postnatal growth which may comprise increased weight, increased length, and/or increased head circumference.
A rounded, bulging chest that resembles the shape of a barrel. That is, there is an increased anteroposterior diameter and usually some degree of kyphosis.
Increased size of the teeth, which can be defined as a mesiodistal tooth diameter (width) more than 2 SD above mean for age. Alternatively, an apparently increased maximum width of the tooth.
An impairment in the ability to produce voice sounds.
Reduced intensity (volume) of speech.
A position of the fetus at delivery in which the fetus enters the birth canal with the buttocks or feet first.

A myocardial disorder in which the heart muscle is structurally and functionally abnormal, in the absence of coronary artery disease, hypertension, valvular disease and congenital heart disease sufficient to cause the observed myocardial abnormality.
Increased size of the heart.
Right-sided heart failure resulting from chronic hypertension in the pulmonary arteries and right ventricle.
The heart is located in the right hand sided hemithorax. That is, there is a left-right reversal (or \
An anomaly of the intra-atrial or intraventricular septum.
Paroxysmal chest pain that occurs with exertion or stress and is related to myocardial ischemia.
An abrupt loss of heart function.
Rapid and unexpected death.
A congenital anomaly in which the pancreas completely (or sometimes incompletely) encircles the second portion of duodenum and occasionally obstructs the more proximal duodenum.
A cyst of the pancreas that possess a lining of mucous epithelium.
Absence (aplasia) of the spleen.
Polysplenia is a congenital disease manifested by multiple small accessory spleens.
The presence of only one working lower chamber in the heart, usually with a virtual absence of the ventricular septum and usually present in conjunction with double inlet left or right ventricle.
The presence of an unusually high plantar arch. Also called high instep, pes cavus refers to a distinctly hollow form of the sole of the foot when it is bearing weight.

A foot where the longitudinal arch of the foot is in contact with the ground or floor when the individual is standing; or, in a patient lying supine, a foot where the arch is in contact with the surface of a flat board pressed against the sole of the foot by the examiner with a pressure similar to that expected from weight bearing; or, the height of the arch is reduced.
Hyperextension of the metatarsal-phalangeal joint with hyperflexion of the proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joint.
Webbing or fusion of the toes, involving soft parts only or including bone structure. Bony fusions are referred to as \

A measured foot length that is more than 2 SD below the mean for a newborn of 27 - 41 weeks gestation, or foot that is less than the 3rd centile for individuals from birth to 16 years of age (objective). Alternatively, a foot that appears disproportionately short (subjective).
A foot for which the measured width is below the 5th centile for age; or, a foot that appears disproportionately narrow for its length.
Aplasia of the nail.
Aplasia of the nail.
Decreased length of nail.
Small (typically about 1 mm or less in size) depressions on the dorsal nail surface.
Small (typically about 1 mm or less in size) depressions on the dorsal nail surface.
A nail plate that has a longitudinal separation and the two sections of the nail share the same lateral radius of curvature.
Nail that appears thin when viewed on end.
Nail that appears thin when viewed on end.
White discoloration of the nails.
A kind of polydactyly characterized by the presence of a supernumerary toe or toes.
A toe that appears disproportionately short compared to the foot.
A toe that appears disproportionately short compared to the foot.
Increased back to front length of the foot.
Increased back to front length of the foot.
Visible increase in width of the non-hallux digit without an increase in the dorso-ventral dimension.
A developmental defect resulting in the presence of fewer than the normal number of toes.
Polycythemia is diagnosed if the red blood cell count, the hemoglobin level, and the red blood cell volume all exceed the upper limits of normal.
A cancer of the blood and bone marrow characterized by an abnormal proliferation of leukocytes.
A decreased concentration of glucose in the blood.
Depletion of acid or accumulation base in the body fluids.
Episodes of fever for which no infectious cause can be identified.
A congenital malformation with a cleft (gap or opening) in the face.
Difficulty in swallowing.
An inadequate sucking reflex, resulting in the difficult of newborns to be breast-fed.
Reduced body temperature due to failed thermoregulation.

Chorea (Greek for 'dance') refers to widespread arrhythmic involuntary movements of a forcible, jerky and restless fashion. It is a random-appearing sequence of one or more discrete involuntary movements or movement fragments. Movements appear random because of variability in timing, duration or location. Each movement may have a distinct start and end. However, movements may be strung together and thus may appear to flow randomly from one muscle group to another. Chorea can involve the trunk, neck, face, tongue, and extremities.
Migraine is a chronic neurological disorder characterized by episodic attacks of headache and associated symptoms.
Inflammation of any part of the lung parenchyma.
Inflammation of the pleura.
Inflammation of the pleura.
Lack of breathing with no movement of the respiratory muscles and no exchange of air in the lungs. This term refers to a disposition to have recurrent episodes of apnea rather than to a single event.
A cavity within the cerebral hemisphere, filled with cerebrospinal fluid, that communicates directly with the ventricular system.
A defect in the understanding of complex motor commands and in the execution of certain learned movements, i.e., deficits in the cognitive components of learned movements.
Hair that is fine or thin to the touch.
A lesser degree of hair pigmentation than would otherwise be expected.
Loss of all hair on the entire body.
Paralysis (complete loss of muscle function) in the arm, leg, and in some cases the face on one side of the body.
Inability to initiate changes in activity or movement and to perform ordinary volitional movements rapidly and easily.

A slow, continuous, involuntary writhing movement that prevents maintenance of a stable posture. Athetosis involves continuous smooth movements that appear random and are not composed of recognizable sub-movements or movement fragments. In contrast to chorea, in athetosis, the same regions of the body are repeatedly involved. Athetosis may worsen with attempts at movement of posture, but athetosis can also occur at rest.
Lack of physical coordination resulting in an abnormal tendency to drop items or bump into objects.

Anencephaly is a developmental anomaly characterized by a fetus that has no calvarium, with a lack of most or all of the fetus' brain tissue. Anencephaly belongs to a collective group known as neural tube defects (NTD) and is a result of the neural tube failing to close in its rostral end during fetal development.
An unintentional, oscillating to-and-fro muscle movement affecting head movement.
An unintentional, oscillating to-and-fro muscle movement affecting the hand.
An acquired language impairment of some or all of the abilities to produce or comprehend speech and to read or write.
A defect in the motor ability that enables speech.
Protrusion of the meninges through a defect of the vertebral column.
A sudden and transient episode of bilateral loss of muscle tone, often triggered by emotions.
Greater than normal amounts of fat in the feces. This is a result of malabsorption of lipids in the small intestine and results in frothy foul-smelling fecal matter that floats.

A disorder of esophageal motility characterized by the inability of the lower esophageal sphincter to relax during swallowing and by inadequate or lacking peristalsis in the lower half of the body of the esophagus.
An abnormality of the intestine in which part of the intestine invaginates (telescopes) into another part of the intestine.
Abnormal twisting of a portion of intestine around itself or around a stalk of mesentery tissue.

Colitis refers to an inflammation of the colon and is often used to describe an inflammation of the large intestine (colon, cecum and rectum). Colitides may be acute and self-limited or chronic, and broadly fit into the category of digestive diseases.
Bleeding from the intestines.
Inflammation of the peritoneum.
A neurological anomaly with gross overeating associated with an abnormally strong desire or need to eat.
An ulcer, that is, an erosion of an area of the gastric mucous membrane.
A head tremor of moderate speed (3 to 4 Hz) in the anterior-posterior direction.
The presence of cell death (necrosis) affecting the liver.
Involuntary fecal soiling in adults and children who have usually already been toilet trained.
Low Blood Pressure, vascular hypotension.
Abnormal outpouching or sac-like dilatation in the wall of an atery, vein or the heart.
Enlarged and tortuous veins.
Inflammation of blood vessel.
The presence of an abnormal lateral curvature of the spine.
An unpleasant sensation characterized by physical discomfort (such as pricking, throbbing, or aching) localized to bone.
An organ or organ-system abnormality that consists of uncontrolled autonomous cell-proliferation which can occur in any part of the body as a benign or malignant neoplasm (tumour).

A malignant bone tumor that usually develops during adolescence and usually affects the long bones including the tibia, femur, and humerus. The typical symptoms of osteosarcoma comprise bone pain, fracture, limitation of motion, and tenderness or swelling at the site of the tumor.

Coxa valga is a deformity of the hip in which the angle between the femoral shaft and the femoral neck is increased compared to age-adjusted values (about 150 degrees in newborns gradually reducing to 120-130 degrees in adults).
The presence of symmetrical and circular openings (foramina) in the parietal bone ranging in size from a few millimeters to several centimeters wide.

Rickets is divided into two major categories including calcipenic and phosphopenic. Hypophosphatemia is described as a common manifestation of both categories. Hypophosphatemic rickets is the most common type of rickets that is characterized by low levels of serum phosphate, resistance to ultraviolet radiation or vitamin D intake. There are several issues involved in hypophosphatemic rickets such as calcium, vitamin D, phosphorus deficiencies. Moreover, other disorder can be associated with its occurrence such as absorption defects due to pancreatic, intestinal, gastric, and renal disorders and hepatobiliary disease. Symptoms are usually seen in childhood and can be varied in severity. Severe forms may be linked to bowing of the legs, poor bone growth, and short stature as well as joint and bone pain. Hypophosphatemic rickets are associated with renal excretion of phosphate, hypophosphatemia, and mineral defects in bones. The familial type of the disease is the most common type of rickets.
An abnormal curvature of the spine in both a coronal (lateral) and sagittal (back-to-front) plane.
Osteomyelitis is an inflammatory process accompanied by bone destruction and caused by an infecting microorganism.
Very rapid breathing.
Very rapid breathing.
A reduction in the amount of air transported into the pulmonary alveoli by breathing, leading to hypercapnia (increase in the partial pressure of carbon dioxide).
Osteolysis refers to the destruction of bone through bone resorption with removal or loss of calcium.
Coxa vara includes all forms of decrease of the femoral neck shaft angle (the angle between the neck and the shaft of the femur) to less than 120 degrees.
Coxa vara includes all forms of decrease of the femoral neck shaft angle (the angle between the neck and the shaft of the femur) to less than 120 degrees.
An abnormally increased extension of the knee joint, so that the knee can bend backwards.
Joint pain.
The legs angle inward, such that the knees are close together and the ankles far apart.
The presence of a meningioma, i.e., a benign tumor originating from the dura mater or arachnoid mater.
