The presence of a melanoma, a malignant cancer originating from pigment producing melanocytes. Melanoma can originate from the skin or the pigmented layers of the eye (the uvea).
The presence of a carcinoma of the urinary bladder.

Hyperventilation refers to an increased pulmonary ventilation rate that is faster than necessary for the exchange of gases. Hyperventilation can result from increased frequency of breathing, an increased tidal volume, or both, and leads to an excess intake of oxygen and the blowing off of carbon dioxide.
A kind of neoplasm of the liver that originates from immature liver precursor cells and macroscopically is composed of tissue resembling fetal or mature liver cells or bile ducts.

A rapidly growing embryonic tumor arising in the posterior part of the cerebellar vermis and neuroepithelial roof of the fourth ventricle in children. More rarely, medulloblastoma arises in the cerebellum in adults.
The presence of an ependymoma of the central nervous system.
High levels of ketone bodies in the urine.
Absence of one half of the vertebral body.
Abnormal positioning in which the elbows are turned out.
A positional abnormality marked by outward bowing of the legs in which the knees stay wide apart when a person stands with the feet and ankles together.
The presence of abnormally small extremities.
The presence of a carcinoma of the breast.
Shortening of the middle parts of the limbs (forearm and lower leg) in relation to the upper and terminal segments.
Dislocation of the distal humerus out of the elbow joint, where the radius, ulna, and humerus meet.
An increased concentration of glucose in the blood.
An abnormally low urinary specific gravity, i.e., reduced concentration of solutes in the urine.
Distance from nasion to subnasale more than two standard deviations above the mean, or alternatively, an apparently increased length from the nasal root to the nasal base.
Distance from nasion to subnasale more than two standard deviations above the mean, or alternatively, an apparently increased length from the nasal root to the nasal base.
The presence of a notch in the margin of the ala nasi.
Distance from nasion to subnasale more than two standard deviations below the mean, or alternatively, an apparently decreased length from the nasal root to the nasal tip.
The presence of skeletal muscular atrophy (which is also known as amyotrophy).
Congenital synostosis between two or more adjacent vertebrae (partial or complete fusion of adjacent vertabral bodies).
An unpleasant sensation characterized by physical discomfort (such as pricking, throbbing, or aching) localized to the back.
An unpleasant sensation characterized by physical discomfort (such as pricking, throbbing, or aching) localized to the back.

Paralysis of voluntary muscles means loss of contraction due to interruption of one or more motor pathways from the brain to the muscle fibers. Although the word paralysis is often used interchangeably to mean either complete or partial loss of muscle strength, it is preferable to use paralysis or plegia for complete or severe loss of muscle strength, and paresis for partial or slight loss. Motor paralysis results from deficits of the upper motor neurons (corticospinal, corticobulbar, or subcorticospinal). Motor paralysis is often accompanied by an impairment in the facility of movement.
A condition in which muscles cannot be moved quickly without accompanying pain or spasm.
An increased concentration of lactic acid in the urine.
Hypertrophy (increase in size) of muscle cells (as opposed to hyperplasia, which refers to an increase in the number of muscle cells).
Cases of the disease in question occur without a previous family history, i.e., as isolated cases without being transmitted from a parent and without other siblings being affected.
Formation of calcium deposits in any soft tissue.
A skin abnormality characterized by redness and irritation, with thick, red skin that displays flaky, silver-white patches (scales).
Multiple punctate calcifications in the dental pulp.
Pili (from Latin pilus, hair) torti (from Latin tortus, twisted) refers to short and brittle hairs that appear flattened and twisted when viewed through a microscope.
A situation in which phenotypic abnormalities become evident with age.
A displacement or misalignment of the humerus with respect to the other bones of the should joint. Note that a subluxation is a partial dislocation.
Increased length of the ulna.
The total absence of the hand, with no bony elements distal to the radius or ulna.

Deviated fingers is a term that should be used if one or more fingers of the hand are deviated from their normal position, either to the radial or ulnar side. A deviation of a finger can be caused by an abnormal form of one or more of the phalanges of the affected finger, or by a deviation or displacement of one or more phalanges.

Significant increase in the length and girth of most or all of a digit compared to its contralateral digit (if unaffected) or compared to what would be expected for age/body build. The increased girth is accompanied by an increase in the dorso-ventral dimension AND the lateral dimension of the digit.
The presence of a fistula connecting the urinary bladder to another organ or the skin. The fistula can involve the bowel, the vagina, or rarely, the skin.
A height below that which is expected according to age and gender norms. Although there is no universally accepted definition of short stature, many refer to \
A colon of abnormally small caliber.
A discontinuity of the vertebral arch, i.e., of the posterior part of a vertebra.
Outward turning of the heel, resulting in clubfoot with the person walking on the inner part of the foot.
The presence of a fistula between the bowel and the perineum.
Hypertrophy of the stomach.
The presence of abnormal calcium deposition lesions in the pancreas.
Blockage or impairment of the normal flow of the contents of the intestine towards the anal canal.
The presence of multiple diverticula of the intestine.
Accumulation of cell free, noninflammatony fluid within the wall of the intestinal tract producing uniform thickening of the mucosal folds.
The presence of inflammation of the gastric mucous membrane.
The presence of more than 12 rib pairs.

A pathologic entity characterized by a developmental defect in a long bone leading to bending and pathologic fracture, with inability to form a normal bony callus with subsequent fibrous nonunion, leading to the pseudarthrosis (or \
Webbing or fusion of the fingers, involving soft parts only or including bone structure. Bony fusions are referred to as \
A bending or abnormal curvature affecting a long bone of the arm.
A localized outpouching of ventricular cavity that is generally associated with dyskinesia and paradoxical expansion during systole.
The presence of an adenocarcinoma of the pancreas.
The presence of a carcinoma in the renal pelvis.
Loss of all scalp hair.
An abnormality of the skin characterized the presence of excessive amounts of dry surface scales on the skin resulting from an abnormality of keratinization.
An outward deviation of the foot at the talocalcaneal or subtalar joint.
Schisis (cleft or cleavage) of vertebral bodies.
The presence of arthrosis, i.e., of degenerative joint disease, affecting the cervical vertebral column.
A sarcoma of the kidney.
Presence of a gap in the posterior laryngotracheal wall with a continuity between the larynx and the esopahagus.
Abnormally short finger associated with developmental hypoplasia.
Shoulder joint stiffness is a perceived sensation of tightness in shoulders when attempting to move them after a period of inactivity.
Excessive wrinkling of the skin of the face.
Chronic pain in the limbs with no clear focal etiology.
Chronic pain in the limbs with no clear focal etiology.

Horn-like malformations of the iliac crests with symmetrical bilateral central posterior iliac processes. A characteristic finding in the Nail-Patella syndrome. Iliac horns are visible on X-ray and may be palpable, but are asymptomatic.
The presence of a teratoma.
Congenital developmental defect arising from the primitive branchial apparatus.

A branchial cyst is a remnant of embryonic development resulting from a failure of obliteration of a branchial cleft and consists of a subcutaneous cystic mass. Cysts are located anterior or posterior to the ear or in the submandibular region.
An anomaly of the joint that connects the upper and the lower arm.
Congenital absence (aplasia) of one or more limbs.
The distal parts of the limbs are missing leading to a stump formation.
The distal parts of the limbs are missing leading to a stump formation.
A notched form of the helix of the ear. That is, a defect in the continuity of the helix, which may occur at any point along its length.
Stomatitis is an inflammation of the mucous membranes of any of the structures in the mouth.
A fistula which connects the oral cavity and the pharyngeal area via the aspects of the soft palate.
Short or anteriorly attached lingual frenulum, associated with limited mobility of the tongue.
The congenital absence of the sternum.
Accumulation of excessive amounts of lymphatic fluid (chyle) in the pleural cavity.
The retrograde (backwards) flow of blood through the pulmonary valve into the right ventricle during diastole.
An abnormal connection between the epithelialised surface of the anal canal and the perianal skin.
The presence of more than two testes.
The presence of an abnormal connection between the urethra and another organ or the skin.
The presence of an abnormal membrane obstructing the urethra.
A developmental defect in which the legs are fused together.
Toes that appear disproportionately long compared to the foot.
An acquired type of sensory aphasia where damage to the brain leads to the loss of the ability to read.
An inability or difficulty differentiating among the fingers of either hand as well as the hands of others.
The tendency to repeat vocalizations made by another person.

Fine, rapid twitching of individual muscle fibers with little or no movement of the muscle as a whole. If a motor neuron or its axon is destroyed, the muscle fibers it innervates undergo denervation atrophy. This leads to hypersensitivity of individual muscle fibers to acetyl choline so that they may contract spontaneously. Isolated activity of individual muscle fibers is generally so fine it cannot be seen through the intact skin, although it can be recorded as a short-duration spike in the EMG.

A type of paralysis in which a muscle becomes soft and yields to passive stretching, which results from loss of all or practically all peripheral motor nerves that innervated the muscle. Muscle tone is reduced and the affected muscles undergo extreme atrophy within months of the loss of innervation.

A disordered proliferation of mature tissues that is native to the site of origin, e.g., exostoses, nevi and soft tissue hamartomas. Although most hamartomas are benign, some histologic subtypes, e.g., neuromuscular hamartoma, may proliferate aggressively such as mesenchymal cystic hamartoma, Sclerosing epithelial hamartoma, Sclerosing metanephric hamartoma.

A disordered proliferation of mature tissues that is native to the site of origin, e.g., exostoses, nevi and soft tissue hamartomas. Although most hamartomas are benign, some histologic subtypes, e.g., neuromuscular hamartoma, may proliferate aggressively such as mesenchymal cystic hamartoma, Sclerosing epithelial hamartoma, Sclerosing metanephric hamartoma.

A chronic epithelioid cell granulomatous inflammation of the meibomian gland caused by inflammation of a blocked meibomian gland. A chalazion or meibomian cyst appears as a painless tuberous swelling in the upper lid without loss of eyelashes.

A chronic epithelioid cell granulomatous inflammation of the meibomian gland caused by inflammation of a blocked meibomian gland. A chalazion or meibomian cyst appears as a painless tuberous swelling in the upper lid without loss of eyelashes.

An acute purulent infection of the sebaceous glands of Zeis at the base of the eyelashes, of the apocrine sweat glands of Moll or the meibomian sebacious glands often caused by staphylococcus infections. Hordeola can either occur as Hordeola externa affecting the sebaceous glands of Zeis or the apocrine sweat glands of Moll or as Hordeola interna affecting the meibomian sebacious glands. In contrast to chalazia, hordeola are extremely painful and can cause extreme local swelling.

An acute purulent infection of the sebaceous glands of Zeis at the base of the eyelashes, of the apocrine sweat glands of Moll or the meibomian sebacious glands often caused by staphylococcus infections. Hordeola can either occur as Hordeola externa affecting the sebaceous glands of Zeis or the apocrine sweat glands of Moll or as Hordeola interna affecting the meibomian sebacious glands. In contrast to chalazia, hordeola are extremely painful and can cause extreme local swelling.

Cutaneous skin tags also known as acrochorda or fibroepithelial polyps are small benign tumours that may either form secondarily over time primarily in areas where the skin forms creases, such as the neck, armpit or groin or may also be present at birth, in which case they usually occur in the periauricular region.
Benign tumors that are composed of fibrous or connective tissue. They can grow in all organs, arising from mesenchyme tissue. The term \
Prominence of the malar process of the maxilla and infraorbital area appreciated in profile and from in front of the face.
The presence of a cleft in the cerebral cortex unilaterally or bilaterally, usually located in the frontal area.

Osteopoikilosis is a benign, asymptomatic sclerotic dysplasia of the bones. It affects both male and female and may be seen at any age. Radiographically sclerotic circular or ovoid lesions are usually symmetrically distributed in a periarticular location. Lesions can increase or decrease in size and number in serial radiographs or even disappear and do not have increased bone radiotracer uptake.
Midline deficiency of the mandible and some or all overlying tissues.
Aplasia of a toe. That is, absence of all phalanges of a non-hallux digit of the foot and the associated soft tissues.

A chordoma is a tumors that arises from embryonic remnants of the notochord along the length of the neuraxis. Chordomas generally occur in the sacrum, intracranially at the clivus, or along the spinal axis.
A sinus in the coccygeal region (the region of the intergluteal cleft). A pilonidal sinus often contains hair and skin debris.

A developmental defect of the aortic arch system in which the trachea and esophagus are completely encircled by connected segments of the aortic arch and its branches. This occurs if the normal process of regression and persistence of the bilateral embryonic aortic arches fails.
A subtype of skin dimples occurring in the shoulder region.
A digit with two nails, with at least some soft tissue between them.
A neoplasm of the pineal gland.
Visible space between the dental arches in occlusion.
Tongue extending beyond the alveolar ridges or teeth at rest.
A type of dyssynergy characterized by the lack of the ability to smoothly perform the elements of a voluntary movement in the appropriate order and speed.
Shortening of the extremities affecting primarily the distal parts of the limbs (hands and feet) in relation to the other segments of the limbs.
The presence of hemorrhage within the body.
The presence of a supernumerary tooth in the midline between the maxillary central incisors.
The presence of a supernumerary tooth in the midline between the maxillary central incisors.
The presence of an odontoma.
A tooth that has not erupted because of local impediments (overcrowding or fibrous gum overgrowth).
An abnormality of the incisor characterized by invagination of the enamel, giving a radiographic appearance that suggests a tooth within a tooth.
A dental anomaly characterized by the presence of a two fused teeth.
The union of two separately developing tooth germs typically leading to one less tooth than normal in the affected dental arch.
The development of two teeth from a single tooth bud, leading to a larger fused tooth.
An abnormal closure, or atresia of the tubular structure of the intestine.
An inflammation of the tonsils.
A significant descent of the kidney as the patient moves from the supine to the erect position.
Gastric duplication is a usually cystic malformation of gastrointestinal tract, usually attached to the greater curvature of the stomach and has no communication with the stomach.
EEG dominated by diffuse alpha-waves (8-13Hz).
EEG dominated by diffuse alpha-waves (8-13Hz).
EEG dominated by diffuse beta-waves (>13 Hz).
Facial height (length) is more than two standard deviations below the mean (objective); or an apparent decrease in the height (length) of the face (subjective).
Absent eyelids.
An abnormal elevation of the C-reactive protein level in serum.
Invagination of the superior part of the auricle under a fold of temporal skin.
Invagination of the superior part of the auricle under a fold of temporal skin.
Discontinuity in the convexity of the inferior margin of the lobe.
The total absence of the foot, with no bony elements distal to the tibia or fibula.
For children from birth to 16 years of age the length of the palm is more than the 97th centile; or, the length of the palm appears relatively long compared to the finger length or the limb length.
Toes that are disproportionately narrow (reduced girth) for the hand/foot size or build of the individual.
Extension of the proximal transverse crease (five finger crease) to the ulnar edge of the palm.
A nail plate that has a longitudinal separation with partially separated nails, each with a separate lateral radius of curvature.
Decreased width of nail.
Incomplete fusion of the chin, resulting from a developmental defect and manifesting as a midline cleft or fissure of the chin.
Yellowish discoloration of the nails.
Congenital deep dermal melanosis in the sacral area.
Shoulder dystocia occurs when the fetal anterior shoulder impacts against the maternal symphysis following delivery of the vertex.
The presence of a carcinoma of the esophagus.
Regurgitation of milk through the nose.
Abnormal dilatation of the iris.
Multiple pupils.
Multiple pupils.
A macular hole is a small break in the macula, located in the center of the retina.
Splitting of the retina in the macular region.
An iris cyst is composed of a single cell layer of epithelium and is filled with fluid.
Complete absence of the interatrial septum with common atrioventricular valve and two atrioventricular connections.

Any cardiac rhythm other than the normal sinus rhythm. Such a rhythm may be either of sinus or ectopic origin and either regular or irregular. An arrhythmia may be due to a disturbance in impulse formation or conduction or both.
Uhl anomaly of the right ventricle refers to the almost complete absence of right ventricular myocardium, normal tricuspid valve, and preserved septal and left ventricular myocardium.
Localized thickening and tightness of the skin of the fingers or toes.
A benign, painful, tumor of bone characterized by the formation of osteoid tissue, primitive bone and calcified tissue.
Inflammation of the parotid gland.
An appetite for and the persistent ingestion of non-food substances such as clay. In order to diagnose pica, this behavior must have persisted over a period of at least one month.
Bleeding from vessels of the various tissues of the eye.
A subjective feeling that an experience which is occurring for the first time has been experienced before.
A subjective feeling that an experience which has occurred before is being experienced for the first time.
A subjective feeling that an experience which has occurred before is being experienced for the first time.
Benign neoplasia derived from lipoblasts or lipocytes of white or brown fat. May be angiomatous or hibernomatous.
A fluid filled cavity that develops with a bone.
A fluid filled cavity that develops with a bone.
Excretion of urine with an acid pH.
Arterial inflammation.
Arterial inflammation.
Inflammation of the liver.
A carcinoma of the larynx.
Inability to experience pleasure activities usually found enjoyable.
A clinical sign indicating a lapse of posture and is usually manifest by a bilateral flapping tremor at the wrist, metacarpophalangeal, and hip joints.
A phenomenon in which persons repetitively pull out their own hair, resulting in noticeable hair loss.
Habitual biting of one's own body.
Habitual biting of one's own fingernails.
A breach of the capsule of the spleen.
Development of the reproductive system is inconsistent with the chromosomal sex.
An odontogenic tumor of the cementum of tooth.
Bony defects situated along the cranial suture lines or at the junction of the bone plates of the skull.
Absence of concavity or convexity of the face when viewed in profile.
A small tear in the thin, moist tissue (mucosa) that lines the anus. It appears as a crack or slit in the mucous membrane of the anus.

A type of ulcer that is caused when an area of skin is subject to pressure over a prolonged period of time, ranging in range in severity from patches of discolored skin to open wounds that expose the underlying bone or muscle. The most common sites are the sacrum, coccyx, heels and the hips.

JT: 低酸素血症への感受性の減少
DEF: An abnormally low level of blood oxygen.
Partial or complete wasting (loss) of brain tissue that was once present.
The presence of bacteria in the urine.
Wasting of the tongue.
Inflammation of the spinal cord.
A visual anomaly in which images appear distorted. A grid of straight lines appears wavy and parts of the grid may appear blank.
An unpleasant sensation characterized by physical discomfort (such as pricking, throbbing, or aching) localized to the arm.
An unpleasant sensation characterized by physical discomfort (such as pricking, throbbing, or aching) localized to the leg.

Reluctance or refusal of a child to be breastfed or eat, manifested as gagging, vomiting, turning head away from food, or avoidance of sensation in or around the mouth (i.e. toothbrushing or face-washing).
Pain due to a stimulus that does not normally provoke pain.
Pain due to a stimulus that does not normally provoke pain.
Thickened nails without deformity.
Atrophy of the kidney.
The presence of renal casts (cylindrical, cigar-shaped structures produced by the kidney in certain disease states) in the urine.
Deposition of fibrillar material that can be found on all anterior segment structures bathed by aqueous humor.
A tumor of the skin or mucous membrane with finger-like projections.
A tumor of the skin or mucous membrane with finger-like projections.
A sensation of breathlessness in the recumbent position, relieved by sitting or standing.
Bigonial distance (lower facial width) more than 2 SD above the mean (objective); or an apparently increased width of the lower jaw (mandible) when viewed from the front (subjective).
Inequality of refractive power of the two eyes.
A fleshy, tube-like structure usually located in the midline of the face or just to one side of the midline.
Inflammation of the myocardium.
The intensity or degree of a manifestation.
Being present on both sides of the body.

JT: 局在型OR局在的OR局在性OR限局性
DEF: Being confined or restricted to a particular location.
A gonad that contains both ovarian follicles and testicular tubular elements.
A gonad that contains both ovarian follicles and testicular tubular elements.
A closed sac located in the spleen.
The presence of a supernumerary, i.e. third, crus of the helix in the helix, arising at or above the normal bifurcation of the antihelix.

Repeated, individually recognizable, intermittent movements or movement fragments that are almost always briefly suppresable and are usually associated with awareness of an urge to perform the movement.

A band of bone material of decreased density forming alongside the surface of the cortical bone with thickening of the periosteum. Callus formation in the affected area is common and gives the appearance of a false fracture.

Benign, slow-growing tumors without any metastatic potential. Despite their benign nature, they can damage nearby structures causing organ dysfunction. Histologically they resemble low-grade fibrosarcomas, but they are very locally aggressive and tend to recur even after complete resection. There is a tendency for recurrence in the setting of prior surgery and the most common localisation of these tumors is intraabdominal from smooth muscle cells of the instestine.
Senile plaques are extracellular deposits of amyloid in the gray matter of the brain.
A chronic autoimmune phenomenon characterized by fibrosis (or hardening) and vascular alterations of the skin.
A tumor originating from the epithelial cells of the thymus.
The presence of an abscess of the liver.
Inflammation of the sclera.
Inflammation of the sclera.
Inflammation of fascia, the tissue under the skin and over the muscle.
Inflammation of fascia, the tissue under the skin and over the muscle.
Eversion of a hollow organ and exposure, inside out, and protruded through the abdominal wall.
Breakage (tear) of a tendon.
A cardiac diverticulum is a rare congenital malformation which is either fibrous or muscular.

An abnormal forward-flexed posture e.g. forward flexion of the spine, which is noticeable when standing or walking but disappears when lying down. It is becoming an increasingly recognized feature of Parkinson's disease and dystonic disorders.
Fluid accumulation in the lungs.

An acute and life-threatening complication of pregnancy, which is characterized by the appearance of tonic-clonic seizures, usually in a patient who had developed pre-eclampsia. Eclampsia includes seizures and coma that happen during pregnancy but are not due to preexisting or organic brain disorders.
A type of undifferentiated germ cell tumor that may be benign or malignant.
Inflammation of the esophagus.
Brown or black discoloration of the nails.
Anterior vaginal wall prolapse with bulging of the bladder into the vagina.
Anterior vaginal wall prolapse with bulging of the bladder into the vagina.

An autoimmune disease where the thyroid is overactive, producing an excessive amount of thyroid hormones (a serious metabolic imbalance known as hyperthyroidism and thyrotoxicosis). This is caused by autoantibodies to the TSH-receptor (TSHR-Ab) that activate that TSH-receptor (TSHR), thereby stimulating thyroid hormone synthesis and secretion, and thyroid growth (causing a diffusely enlarged goiter). The resulting state of hyperthyroidism can cause a dramatic constellation of neuropsychological and physical signs and symptoms, which can severely compromise the patients.
Inflammation of cartilage.
A congenital malformation characterized by the union or approximation of the ears in front of the neck, often accompanied by the absence or defective development of the lower jaw.
A developmental disorder in which there is a duplication the entire intestine or of a portion of the intestine.

Acting on the spur of the moment in response to immediate stimuli; acting on a momentary basis without a plan or consideration of outcomes; difficulty establishing or following plans; a sense of urgency and self-harming behavior under emotional distress.
Thickening and hardening of the epidermis seen with exaggeration of normal skin lines.

A form of anomalous eating behavior characterized by binge eating is followed by self-induced vomiting or other compensatory behavior intended to prevent weight gain (purging, fasting or exercising or a combination of these).
Collapse of part of a lung associated with absence of inflation (air) of that part.
A state of abnormally elevated or irritable mood, arousal, and or energy levels.
A rare pediatric carcinoma of the pancreas.
Terminal broadening of the fingers (distal phalanges of the fingers).
Terminal broadening of the toes (distal phalanges of the toes).
Bleeding into the biliary tree.

A malignant, trophoblastic and aggressive cancer, usually of the placenta. It is characterized by early hematogenous spread to the lungs and belongs to the far end of the spectrum of gestational trophoblastic disease (GTD), a subset of germ cell tumors.
An exostosis is a benign growth the projects outward from the bone surface. It is capped by cartilage, and arises from a bone that develops from cartilage.
An exostosis is a benign growth the projects outward from the bone surface. It is capped by cartilage, and arises from a bone that develops from cartilage.
Testicular inflammation.
Systemic inflammatory response to infection.

The middle finger is more than 2 SD above the mean for newborns 27 to 41 weeks EGA or above the 97th centile for children from birth to 16 years of age AND the five digits retain their normal length proportions relative to each other (i.e., it is not the case that the middle finger is the only lengthened digit), or, Fingers that appear disproportionately long compared to the palm of the hand.
An outpouching of the gastric wall.
Noticeably unpleasant odors exhaled in breathing.
The prolapse of the female urethra into the vagina.

A Rectocele results from a tear in the rectovaginal septum (which is normally a tough, fibrous, sheet-like divider between the rectum and vagina). Rectal tissue bulges through this tear and into the vagina as a hernia. There are two main causes of this tear: childbirth, and hysterectomy.

A Rectocele results from a tear in the rectovaginal septum (which is normally a tough, fibrous, sheet-like divider between the rectum and vagina). Rectal tissue bulges through this tear and into the vagina as a hernia. There are two main causes of this tear: childbirth, and hysterectomy.
Inflammation of the lip.
Inflammation of the lip.
Deposits of various size, shape, consistency, refractive index, and motility within the eye's vitreous humour, which is normally transparent.
Cystic, urine-containing intrarenal cavities lined with transitional cell epithelium that communicate through a narrow channel with the collecting system.
Low set, steeply sloping shoulders.
An unpleasant sensation characterized by physical discomfort (such as pricking, throbbing, or aching) localized to the mandible.
The presence of a characteristic high-pitched cry that sounds similar to the meowing of a kitten.
Abnormally increased production of urine during the night leading to an unusually frequent need to urinate.
An increased rate of urine production.
Tinnitus is an auditory perception that can be described as the experience of sound, in the ear or in the head, in the absence of external acoustic stimulation.

Median longitudinal ear length greater than two standard deviations above the mean and median ear width greater than two standard deviations above the mean (objective); or, apparent increase in length and width of the pinna (subjective).
Glaucoma refers loss of retinal ganglion cells in a characteristic pattern of optic neuropathy usually associated with increased intraocular pressure.
A cataract is an opacity or clouding that develops in the crystalline lens of the eye or in its capsule.
Absence of tear secretion.

Abnormality of the iris characterized by, typically bilateral, complete or partial iris hypoplasia. The phenotype ranges from mild defects of anterior iris stroma only to almost complete absence of the iris.
A developmental defect characterized by a cleft of some portion of the eye or ocular adnexa.
Diplopia is a condition in which a single object is perceived as two images, it is also known as double vision.
Increased space between two adjacent teeth in the same dental arch.

A loss of global cognitive ability of sufficient amount to interfere with normal social or occupational function. Dementia represents a loss of previously present cognitive abilities, generally in adults, and can affect memory, thinking, language, judgment, and behavior.

A loss of global cognitive ability of sufficient amount to interfere with normal social or occupational function. Dementia represents a loss of previously present cognitive abilities, generally in adults, and can affect memory, thinking, language, judgment, and behavior.
Lack of the ability to control the urinary bladder leading to involuntary urination at an age where control of the bladder should already be possible.
Yellow pigmentation of the skin due to bilirubin, which in turn is the result of increased bilirubin concentration in the bloodstream.
Skin characterized by the lack of natural or normal moisture.
Bluish discoloration of the skin and mucosa due to poor circulation or inadequate oxygenation of arterial or capillary blood.
Pruritus is an itch or a sensation that makes a person want to scratch. This term refers to an abnormally increased disposition to experience pruritus.
Any manifestation of a skin disease associated with the production of pus.
An abnormal reduction in the amount of pigmentation (reduced or absent) of skin, hair and eye (iris and retina).
Broadening of the soft tissues (non-edematous swelling of soft tissues) of the digital tips in all dimensions associated with an increased longitudinal and lateral curvature of the nails.

A seizure is an intermittent abnormality of nervous system physiology characterised by a transient occurrence of signs and/or symptoms due to abnormal excessive or synchronous neuronal activity in the brain.
A state of disinterestedness, listlessness, and indifference, resulting in difficulty performing simple tasks or concentrating.
An abnormally increased muscular tone that causes fixed abnormal postures. There is a slow, intermittent twisting motion that leads to exaggerated turning and posture of the extremities and trunk.
A noncongenital process of hair loss, which may progress to partial or complete baldness.
The male foreskin cannot be fully retracted from the head of the penis.
Absence (aplasia) of the spleen.
A cancer of the blood and bone marrow characterized by an abnormal proliferation of leukocytes.
Abnormal acid accumulation or depletion of base.
Forceful ejection of the contents of the stomach through the mouth by means of a series of involuntary spasmic contractions.
Abnormally increased frequency of loose or watery bowel movements.
A lack or loss of appetite for food (as a medical condition).

Continuous involuntary sustained muscle contraction. When an affected muscle is passively stretched, the degree of resistance remains constant regardless of the rate at which the muscle is stretched. This feature helps to distinguish rigidity from muscle spasticity.
Migraine is a chronic neurological disorder characterized by episodic attacks of headache and associated symptoms.
An increased concentration of nitrogen compounds in the blood.
Circumscribed depigmentation of the hair of the head or the eyelashes.
Inability to initiate changes in activity or movement and to perform ordinary volitional movements rapidly and easily.
Habitual flow of saliva out of the mouth.
Cephalgia, or pain sensed in various parts of the head, not confined to the area of distribution of any nerve.
Myokymia consists of involuntary, fine, continuous, undulating contractions that spread across the affected striated muscle.
An involuntary and painless delay in the relaxation of skeletal muscle following contraction or electrical stimulation.
Abnormal twisting of a portion of intestine around itself or around a stalk of mesentery tissue.
Abnormal outpouching or sac-like dilatation in the wall of an atery, vein or the heart.
An organ or organ-system abnormality that consists of uncontrolled autonomous cell-proliferation which can occur in any part of the body as a benign or malignant neoplasm (tumour).
A cancer originating in lymphocytes and presenting as a solid tumor of lymhpoid cells.
Exaggerated anterior convexity of the thoracic vertebral column.
The presence of a melanoma, a malignant cancer originating from pigment producing melanocytes. Melanoma can originate from the skin or the pigmented layers of the eye (the uvea).
A disorder of muscle unrelated to impairment of innervation or neuromuscular junction.
Cases of the disease in question occur without a previous family history, i.e., as isolated cases without being transmitted from a parent and without other siblings being affected.
Severe weight loss, wasting of muscle, loss of appetite, and general debility related to a chronic disease.
A decreased sensitivity to odorants (that is, a decreased ability to perceive odors).
Underdevelopment of the external ear.
The absence of all phalanges of all the digits of a limb and the associated soft tissues.
The presence of a teratoma.
Cyclopia is a congenital abnormality in which there is only one eye. That eye is centrally placed in the area normally occupied by the root of the nose.
The congenital absence of the sternum.
Toes that appear disproportionately long compared to the foot.

A learning disorder characterized primarily by difficulties in learning to read and spell. Dyslectic children also exhibit a tendency to read words from right to left and to confuse letters such as b and d whose orientation is important for their identification. Children with dyslexia appear to be impaired in phonemic skills (the ability to associate visual symbols with the sounds they represent).

A chordoma is a tumors that arises from embryonic remnants of the notochord along the length of the neuraxis. Chordomas generally occur in the sacrum, intracranially at the clivus, or along the spinal axis.
Redness of the skin, caused by hyperemia of the capillaries in the lower layers of the skin.
Somewhat rapid onset and change of disease manifestations.
The presence of an odontoma.
Maxillary teeth cover the mandibular teeth when biting to an increased degree.
EEG dominated by diffuse beta-waves (>13 Hz).
Hair that lacks the lustre (shine or gleam) of normal hair.
Inflammation of the vitreous body, characterized by the presence of inflammatory cells and protein exudate in the vitreous cavity.
Pain in the lower back and hip radiating in the distribution of the sciatic nerve.
A persecutory delusion of supposed hostility of others.
An extreme form of generalized edema with widespread and massive edema due to effusion of fluid into the extracellular space.
Excretion of urine with an acid pH.
Edema (swelling) of the bulbar conjunctiva.
Inflammation of the nasal mucosa with nasal congestion.
A turning outward of the lip or lips, that is, eversion of the lips.
Inflammation of the spinal cord.
The presence of complement 3 deposits in the glomerulus.
A repeated, painful urge to defecate without excreting stool.
Absence of the tongue owing to a developmental abnormality.
The intensity or degree of a manifestation.

JT: 中等度OR中等症OR中等OR中程度OR適度OR緩和
DEF: Having a medium degree of severity. For quantitative traits, a deviation of between three and four standard deviations from the appropriate population mean.

JT: 著明OR深刻OR根深いOR重度OR深在性
DEF: Having an extremely high degree of severity. For quantitative traits, a deviation of more than five standard deviations from the appropriate population mean.

JT: 位置OR立場OR状態OR地位ORポジションOR体位OR配置OR置く
DEF: The anatomical localization of the specified phenotypic abnormality.
Localized close to the central point of the body.
The presence of a supernumerary, i.e. third, crus of the helix in the helix, arising at or above the normal bifurcation of the antihelix.
A small, skin-lined tract that leads from the surface to deep within the tissues.

A chronic granulomatous inflammatory disease of the intestines that may affect any part of the gastrointestinal tract from mouth to anus, causing a wide variety of symptoms. It primarily causes abdominal pain, diarrhea which may be bloody, vomiting, or weight loss, but may also cause complications outside of the gastrointestinal tract such as skin rashes, arthritis, inflammation of the eye, tiredness, and lack of concentration. Crohn's disease is thought to be an autoimmune disease, in which the body's immune system attacks the gastrointestinal tract, causing inflammation.
Low output of urine, clinically classified as an output below 300-500ml/day.
A general term for inflammation of the muscles without respect to the underlying cause.
The presence of an extra auricle on one or both sides of the head.
Excess deposit and expansion of adipose tissue in an unusual pattern which cannot be lost through diet and exercise .
A serious and potentially life-threatening condition that arises when a considerable mass of body tissue dies (necrosis).
Testicular inflammation.
A painful and harmful medical condition in which the erect penis doesn't return to its flaccid state, despite the absence of both physical and psychological stimulation, within four hours.
Warts, benign growths on the skin or mucous membranes that cause cosmetic problems as well as pain and discomfort. Warts most often occur on the hands, feet, and genital areas.
Ventral, lateral, or ventrolateral bowing of the shaft and glans penis of more than 30 degrees.
Limitation in the ability to open the mouth.
Anterior and inferior folding of the upper portion of the ear that obliterates triangular fossa and scapha.

An inability to perceive odors. This is a general term describing inability to smell arising in any part of the process of smelling from absorption of odorants into the nasal mucous overlying the olfactory epithelium, diffusion to the cilia, binding to olfactory receptor sites, generation of action potentials in olfactory neurons, and perception of a smell.
Inflammation of one or all portions of the uveal tract.
A regional and pathological increase of the light detection threshold in any region of the visual field surrounded by a field of normal or relatively well-preserved vision.

Intense feelings of nervousness, tenseness, or panic, often in reaction to interpersonal stresses; worry about the negative effects of past unpleasant experiences and future negative possibilities; feeling fearful, apprehensive, or threatened by uncertainty; fears of falling apart or losing control.
Purpura (from Latin: purpura, meaning \

Syncope refers to a generalized weakness of muscles with loss of postural tone, inability to stand upright, and loss of consciousness. Once the patient is in a horizontal position, blood flow to the brain is no longer hindered by gravitation and consciousness is regained. Unconsciousness usually lasts for seconds to minutes. Headache and drowsiness (which usually follow seizures) do not follow a syncopal attack. Syncope results from a sudden impairment of brain metabolism usually due to a reduction in cerebral blood flow.
Accumulation of substantial excess body fat.
Accumulation of fluid in the peritoneal cavity.
Gout affecting the Metatarsophalangeal joint of big toe.
A deformity of foot and ankle that has different subtypes that are talipes equinovarus, talipes equinovalgus, talipes calcaneovarus and talipes calcaneovalgus.
Presence of elevated levels of ketone bodies in the body.
Difficult or labored breathing.
Gliosis is the focal proliferation of glial cells in the central nervous system.
A defect in the understanding of complex motor commands and in the execution of certain learned movements, i.e., deficits in the cognitive components of learned movements.
An abnormal sensation of spinning while the body is actually stationary.
An acquired language impairment of some or all of the abilities to produce or comprehend speech and to read or write.

Colitis refers to an inflammation of the colon and is often used to describe an inflammation of the large intestine (colon, cecum and rectum). Colitides may be acute and self-limited or chronic, and broadly fit into the category of digestive diseases.

Rickets is divided into two major categories including calcipenic and phosphopenic. Hypophosphatemia is described as a common manifestation of both categories. Hypophosphatemic rickets is the most common type of rickets that is characterized by low levels of serum phosphate, resistance to ultraviolet radiation or vitamin D intake. There are several issues involved in hypophosphatemic rickets such as calcium, vitamin D, phosphorus deficiencies. Moreover, other disorder can be associated with its occurrence such as absorption defects due to pancreatic, intestinal, gastric, and renal disorders and hepatobiliary disease. Symptoms are usually seen in childhood and can be varied in severity. Severe forms may be linked to bowing of the legs, poor bone growth, and short stature as well as joint and bone pain. Hypophosphatemic rickets are associated with renal excretion of phosphate, hypophosphatemia, and mineral defects in bones. The familial type of the disease is the most common type of rickets.
Pain in muscle.
Bruxism is characterized by the grinding of the teeth including the clenching of the jaw and typically occur during sleep.
Complete color blindness, a complete inability to distinguish colors. Affected persons cannot perceive colors, but only shades of gray.
Stridor is a high pitched sound resulting from turbulent air flow in the upper airway.

Inability to recognize objects not because of sensory deficit but because of the inability to combine components of sensory impressions into a complete pattern. Thus, agnosia is a neurological condition which results in an inability to know, to name, to identify, and to extract meaning from visual, auditory, or tactile impressions.
Benign tumors that are composed of fibrous or connective tissue. They can grow in all organs, arising from mesenchyme tissue. The term \
Slow, creeping onset, slow progress and long continuance of disease manifestations.
An abnormal anteroposterior extension of the maxillary teeth beyond the plane of the mandibular teeth upon jaw closure.

A furuncle (boil) is a skin infection involving an entire hair follicle and nearby skin tissue. Chronic furunculosis refers to recurrent episodes of furuncles, often caused by recurrent staphylococcus infection.
Bleeding in the anterior chamber of the eye.
A subjective feeling that an experience which is occurring for the first time has been experienced before.
Isolated patches of hardened skin (scleroderma).
A subjective feeling of tiredness characterized by a lack of energy and motivation.
An allergy is an immune response or reaction to substances that are usually not harmful.
A connective tissue neoplasm formed by proliferation of mesodermal cells. Bone and soft tissue sarcomas are the main types of sarcoma. Sarcoma is usually highly malignant.
Osteomas are bony growths found most commonly on the skull and mandible; however, they may occur in any bone of the body. Osteomas do not usually cause clinical problems and do not become malignant.
A depression located on a lip.
Painful or difficult urination.
A tumor originating from the epithelial cells of the thymus.
Congenital absence of the spinal cord.
A congenital malformation characterized by the union or approximation of the ears in front of the neck, often accompanied by the absence or defective development of the lower jaw.

A form of anomalous eating behavior characterized by binge eating is followed by self-induced vomiting or other compensatory behavior intended to prevent weight gain (purging, fasting or exercising or a combination of these).
A small elevation of the skin containing cloudy or purulent material usually consisting of necrotic inflammatory cells.
The presence of a characteristic high-pitched cry that sounds similar to the meowing of a kitten.
Inability to completely empty the urinary bladder during the process of urination.
Abnormally increased production of urine during the night leading to an unusually frequent need to urinate.
Loss of the ability to control the urinary bladder leading to involuntary urination.
An increased rate of urine production.
A nonspecific term referring to disease or damage of the kidneys.
The presence of inflammation affecting the kidney.
Increased length and width of the tongue.
Decreased length and width of the tongue.
A facial appearance characterized by a permanently or nearly permanently opened mouth.
Inflammation of the tongue.
Accentuation of the grooves on the dorsal surface of the tongue.

An abnormality of skull shape characterized by a decreased anterior-posterior diameter. That is, a cephalic index greater than 81%. Alternatively, an apparently shortened anteroposterior dimension (length) of the head compared to width.
Head circumference below 2 standard deviations below the mean for age and gender.
Occipitofrontal (head) circumference greater than 97th centile compared to appropriate, age matched, sex-matched normal standards. Alternatively, a apparently increased size of the cranium.

An abnormality of skull shape characterized by a increased anterior-posterior diameter, i.e., an increased antero-posterior dimension of the skull. Cephalic index less than 76%. Alternatively, an apparently increased antero-posterior length of the head compared to width. Often due to premature closure of the sagittal suture.
Developmental hypoplasia of the mandible.
Tinnitus is an auditory perception that can be described as the experience of sound, in the ear or in the head, in the absence of external acoustic stimulation.
A decreased magnitude of the sensory perception of sound.
Anterior and inferior folding of the upper portion of the ear that obliterates triangular fossa and scapha.

Median longitudinal ear length greater than two standard deviations above the mean and median ear width greater than two standard deviations above the mean (objective); or, apparent increase in length and width of the pinna (subjective).
Involuntary contractions of the neck musculature resulting in an abnormal posture of or abnormal movements of the head.
A type of astigmatism associated with abnormal curvatures on the anterior and/or posterior surface of the cornea.

A misalignment of the eyes so that the visual axes deviate from bifoveal fixation. The classification of strabismus may be based on a number of features including the relative position of the eyes, whether the deviation is latent or manifest, intermittent or constant, concomitant or otherwise and according to the age of onset and the relevance of any associated refractive error.
The upper eyelid margin is positioned 3 mm or more lower than usual and covers the superior portion of the iris (objective); or, the upper lid margin obscures at least part of the pupil (subjective).
An abnormality of refraction characterized by the ability to see objects in the distance clearly, while objects nearby appear blurry.
An abnormality of refraction characterized by the ability to see objects nearby clearly, while objects in the distance appear blurry.
An abnormality of refraction characterized by the ability to see objects nearby clearly, while objects in the distance appear blurry.
Diffusely large eye (with megalocornea) associated with glaucoma.
A regional and pathological increase of the light detection threshold in any region of the visual field surrounded by a field of normal or relatively well-preserved vision.
Excessive sensitivity to light with the sensation of discomfort or pain in the eyes due to exposure to bright light.
Abnormal (non-physiological) constriction of the pupil.
Abnormal (non-physiological) constriction of the pupil.
Rhythmic, involuntary oscillations of one or both eyes related to abnormality in fixation, conjugate gaze, or vestibular mechanisms.
Reduced visual acuity that is uncorrectable by lenses in the absence of detectable anatomic defects in the eye or visual pathways.
Diplopia is a condition in which a single object is perceived as two images, it is also known as double vision.
Caries is a multifactorial bacterial infection affecting the structure of the tooth. This term has been used to describe the presence of more than expected dental caries.
The congenital absence of all teeth.
Increased volume of dental pulp of permanent molar.
Decreased size of the teeth, which can be defined as a mesiodistal tooth diameter (width) more than 2 SD below mean. Alternatively, an apparently decreased maximum width of tooth.
A state of exceeding restlessness and excessive motor activity associated with mental distress or a feeling of inner tension.

Frequent feelings of being down, miserable, and/or hopeless; difficulty recovering from such moods; pessimism about the future; pervasive shame; feeling of inferior self-worth; thoughts of suicide and suicidal behavior.

Autism is a neurodevelopmental disorder characterized by impaired social interaction and communication, and by restricted and repetitive behavior. Autism begins in childhood. It is marked by the presence of markedly abnormal or impaired development in social interaction and communication and a markedly restricted repertoire of activity and interest. Manifestations of the disorder vary greatly depending on the developmental level and chronological age of the individual (DSM-IV).
Perceptions in a conscious and awake state in the absence of external stimuli which have qualities of real perception, in that they are vivid, substantial, and located in external objective space.

Intense feelings of nervousness, tenseness, or panic, often in reaction to interpersonal stresses; worry about the negative effects of past unpleasant experiences and future negative possibilities; feeling fearful, apprehensive, or threatened by uncertainty; fears of falling apart or losing control.
A belief that is pathological and is held despite evidence to the contrary.
Hyperactivity is a state of constantly being unusually or abnormally active, including in situations in which it is not appropriate.
The presence of blood in the urine. Hematuria may be gross hematuria (visible to the naked eye) or microscopic hematuria (detected by dipstick or microscopic examination of the urine).
Lack of the ability to control the urinary bladder leading to involuntary urination at an age where control of the bladder should already be possible.
An enlargement of the thyroid gland.
Yellow pigmentation of the skin due to bilirubin, which in turn is the result of increased bilirubin concentration in the bloodstream.

Eczema is a form of dermatitis. The term eczema is broadly applied to a range of persistent skin conditions and can be related to a number of underlying conditions. Manifestations of eczema can include dryness and recurring skin rashes with redness, skin edema, itching and dryness, crusting, flaking, blistering, cracking, oozing, or bleeding.

Eczema is a form of dermatitis. The term eczema is broadly applied to a range of persistent skin conditions and can be related to a number of underlying conditions. Manifestations of eczema can include dryness and recurring skin rashes with redness, skin edema, itching and dryness, crusting, flaking, blistering, cracking, oozing, or bleeding.
An abnormal accumulation of fluid beneath the skin, or in one or more cavities of the body.
Abnormal excessive perspiration (sweating) despite the lack of appropriate stimuli like hot and humid weather.
Purpura (from Latin: purpura, meaning \
Abnormally pale skin.
Abnormally pale skin.
Pruritus is an itch or a sensation that makes a person want to scratch. This term refers to an abnormally increased disposition to experience pruritus.
Abnormally increased hair growth referring to a male pattern of body hair (androgenic hair).
Increased susceptibility to erysipelas, as manifested by a medical history of repeated episodes of erysipelas, which is a superficial infection of the skin, typically involving the lymphatic system.
Inflammation of the iris.

A condition in which middle parts of the hand (fingers and metacarpals) are missing giving a cleft appearance. The severity is very variable ranging from slightly hypoplastic middle fingers over absent middel fingers as far as oligo- or monodactyl hands.

A seizure is an intermittent abnormality of nervous system physiology characterised by a transient occurrence of signs and/or symptoms due to abnormal excessive or synchronous neuronal activity in the brain.

Cerebellar ataxia refers to ataxia due to dysfunction of the cerebellum. This causes a variety of elementary neurological deficits including asynergy (lack of coordination between muscles, limbs and joints), dysmetria (lack of ability to judge distances that can lead to under- or overshoot in grasping movements), and dysdiadochokinesia (inability to perform rapid movements requiring antagonizing muscle groups to be switched on and off repeatedly).
A motor disorder characterized by a velocity-dependent increase in tonic stretch reflexes with increased muscle tone, exaggerated (hyperexcitable) tendon reflexes.
Complete absence of wakefulness and content of conscience, which manifests itself as a lack of response to any kind of external stimuli.
A state of abnormally strong desire for sleep during the daytime.

Syncope refers to a generalized weakness of muscles with loss of postural tone, inability to stand upright, and loss of consciousness. Once the patient is in a horizontal position, blood flow to the brain is no longer hindered by gravitation and consciousness is regained. Unconsciousness usually lasts for seconds to minutes. Headache and drowsiness (which usually follow seizures) do not follow a syncopal attack. Syncope results from a sudden impairment of brain metabolism usually due to a reduction in cerebral blood flow.
A condition characterized by intermittent involuntary contraction of muscles (spasms) related to hypocalcemia or occasionally magnesium deficiency.
Lack of clarity and coherence of thought, perception, understanding, or action.
Sudden impairment of blood flow to a part of the brain due to occlusion or rupture of an artery to the brain.
Sudden impairment of blood flow to a part of the brain due to occlusion or rupture of an artery to the brain.
Encephalopathy is a term that means brain disease, damage, or malfunction. In general, encephalopathy is manifested by an altered mental state.
An unintentional, oscillating to-and-fro muscle movement about a joint axis.
An unintentional, oscillating to-and-fro muscle movement about a joint axis.
Asymmetric head shape, which is usually a combination of unilateral occipital flattening with ipsilateral frontal prominence, leading to rhomboid cranial shape.
Accumulation of substantial excess body fat.
Accumulation of fluid in the peritoneal cavity.
A noncongenital process of hair loss, which may progress to partial or complete baldness.
The natural longitudinal (posterodistal) convex arch is not present or is inverted.
Hoarseness refers to a change in the pitch or quality of the voice, with the voice sounding weak, very breathy, scratchy, or husky.
The birth of a baby of less than 37 weeks of gestational age.
A rapid heartrate that exceeds the range of the normal resting heartrate for age.
A slower than normal heart rate (in adults, slower than 60 beats per minute).
The presence of inflammation in the pancreas.
The male foreskin cannot be fully retracted from the head of the penis.
Reduced ability to pass air through the nasal cavity often leading to mouth breathing.
Abnormal increased size of the spleen.

An accessory spleen is a round, iso-echogenic, homogenic and smooth structure and is seen as a normal variant mostly on the medial contour of the spleen, near the hilus or around the lower pole. This has no pathogenic relevance.
The presence of an unusually high plantar arch. Also called high instep, pes cavus refers to a distinctly hollow form of the sole of the foot when it is bearing weight.
Hyperextension of the metatarsal-phalangeal joint with hyperflexion of the proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joint.
When viewed on end (with the digit tip pointing toward the examiner's eye) the curve of the nail forms a tighter curve of convexity.
Camptodactyly is a painless flexion contracture of the proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joint that is usually gradually progressive. This term refers to camptodactyly of one or more toes.

A condition in which middle parts of the foot (toes and metatarsals) are missing giving a cleft appearance. The severity is very variable ranging from slightly hypoplastic 3rd toe over absent 2nd or 3rd toes as far as oligo- or monodactyl feet.
Bending or curvature of a toe in the tibial direction (i.e., towards the big toe).
A deformity of foot and ankle that has different subtypes that are talipes equinovarus, talipes equinovalgus, talipes calcaneovarus and talipes calcaneovalgus.
A reduction in erythrocytes volume or hemoglobin concentration.
A reduction in erythrocytes volume or hemoglobin concentration.
Elevated body temperature due to failed thermoregulation.
Excessive thirst manifested by excessive fluid intake.
A sensation that the heart is pounding or racing, which is a non-specific sign but may be a manifestation of arrhythmia.

Recurrent attacks of acute inflammatory arthritis of a joint or set of joints caused by elevated levels of uric acid in the blood which crystallize and are deposited in joints, tendons, and surrounding tissues.
Forceful ejection of the contents of the stomach through the mouth by means of a series of involuntary spasmic contractions.
Abnormally increased frequency of loose or watery bowel movements.
A sensation of unease in the stomach together with an urge to vomit.
A sensation of unease in the stomach together with an urge to vomit.
Infrequent or difficult evacuation of feces.
Congenital absence of the anus, i.e., the opening at the bottom end of the intestinal tract.
An unpleasant sensation characterized by physical discomfort (such as pricking, throbbing, or aching) and perceived to originate in the abdomen.

Continuous involuntary sustained muscle contraction. When an affected muscle is passively stretched, the degree of resistance remains constant regardless of the rate at which the muscle is stretched. This feature helps to distinguish rigidity from muscle spasticity.

Chorea (Greek for 'dance') refers to widespread arrhythmic involuntary movements of a forcible, jerky and restless fashion. It is a random-appearing sequence of one or more discrete involuntary movements or movement fragments. Movements appear random because of variability in timing, duration or location. Each movement may have a distinct start and end. However, movements may be strung together and thus may appear to flow randomly from one muscle group to another. Chorea can involve the trunk, neck, face, tongue, and extremities.
A neural tube defect characterized by sac-like protrusions of the brain and the membranes that cover it through openings in the skull.
Inflammation of any part of the lung parenchyma.
Asthma is characterized by increased responsiveness of the tracheobronchial tree to multiple stimuli, leading to narrowing of the air passages with resultant dyspnea, cough, and wheezing.
Asthma is characterized by increased responsiveness of the tracheobronchial tree to multiple stimuli, leading to narrowing of the air passages with resultant dyspnea, cough, and wheezing.
Coughing up (expectoration) of blood or blood-streaked sputum from the larynx, trachea, bronchi, or lungs.
Accumulation of air in the pleural cavity leading to a partially or completely collapsed lung.
A series of rhythmic and involuntary muscle contractions (at a frequency of about 5 to 7 Hz) that occur in response to an abruptly applied and sustained stretch.
Hypopigmented hair that appears silver-gray.
Abnormally increased size of the liver.
The vomiting of blood.

The passage of blackish, tarry feces associated with gastrointestinal hemorrhage. Melena occurs if the blood remains in the colon long enough for it to be broken down by colonic bacteria. One degradation product, hematin, imbues the stool with a blackish color. Thus, melena generally occurs with bleeding from the upper gastrointestinal tract (e.g., stomach ulcers or duodenal ulcers), since the blood usually remains in the gut for a longer period of time than with lower gastrointestinal bleeding.

The passage of blackish, tarry feces associated with gastrointestinal hemorrhage. Melena occurs if the blood remains in the colon long enough for it to be broken down by colonic bacteria. One degradation product, hematin, imbues the stool with a blackish color. Thus, melena generally occurs with bleeding from the upper gastrointestinal tract (e.g., stomach ulcers or duodenal ulcers), since the blood usually remains in the gut for a longer period of time than with lower gastrointestinal bleeding.
A lesser degree of hair pigmentation than would otherwise be expected.
Circumscribed depigmentation of the hair of the head or the eyelashes.
Habitual flow of saliva out of the mouth.
Cephalgia, or pain sensed in various parts of the head, not confined to the area of distribution of any nerve.
An abnormal sensation of spinning while the body is actually stationary.
Excessive daytime sleepiness.
A focal dystonia of the fingers, hand, and/or forearm that appears when the affected person attempts to do a task that requires fine motor movements such as writing or playing a musical instrument.
Motor hyperactivity with excessive movement of muscles of the body as a whole.
The presence of an abnormal lateral curvature of the spine.
An unpleasant sensation characterized by physical discomfort (such as pricking, throbbing, or aching) localized to bone.
Exaggerated anterior convexity of the thoracic vertebral column.
Inspiration of a foreign object into the airway.
An increased concentration of glucose in the urine.
Abnormally increased cuvature (anterior concavity) of the lumbar or cervical spine.
Pain in muscle.

An abnormal gait pattern that arises from weakness of the pretibial and peroneal muscles due to a lower motor neuron lesion. Affected patients have footdrop and are unable to dorsiflex and evert the foot. The leg is lifted high on walking so that the toes clear the ground, and there may be a slapping noise when the foot strikes the ground again.

Paralysis of voluntary muscles means loss of contraction due to interruption of one or more motor pathways from the brain to the muscle fibers. Although the word paralysis is often used interchangeably to mean either complete or partial loss of muscle strength, it is preferable to use paralysis or plegia for complete or severe loss of muscle strength, and paresis for partial or slight loss. Motor paralysis results from deficits of the upper motor neurons (corticospinal, corticobulbar, or subcorticospinal). Motor paralysis is often accompanied by an impairment in the facility of movement.
A nevus is a type of hamartoma that is a circumscribed stable malformation of the skin.
A skin abnormality characterized by redness and irritation, with thick, red skin that displays flaky, silver-white patches (scales).
The presence of a fistula of the vagina.
The presence of inflammation of the gastric mucous membrane.
A form of colorblindness in which only two of the three fundamental colors can be distinguished due to a lack of one of the retinal cone pigments.
Underdevelopment of the external ear.
Absence (due to failure to form) or underdevelopment of one or more components of the skeleton.
The presence of a glioma, which is a neoplasm of the central nervous system originating from a glial cell (astrocytes or oligodendrocytes).
The presence of a glioma, which is a neoplasm of the central nervous system originating from a glial cell (astrocytes or oligodendrocytes).
The absence of all phalanges of all the digits of a limb and the associated soft tissues.
A congenital fistula in the neck resulting from incomplete closure of a branchial cleft.
The presence of two or more accessory spleens.
Congenital absence (aplasia) of one or more limbs.
Complete absence of any auricular structures.
Complete absence of any auricular structures.
Cyclopia is a congenital abnormality in which there is only one eye. That eye is centrally placed in the area normally occupied by the root of the nose.
Stridor is a high pitched sound resulting from turbulent air flow in the upper airway.
An acquired type of sensory aphasia where damage to the brain leads to the loss of the ability to read.
Enuresis occurring during sleeping hours.
Redness of the skin, caused by hyperemia of the capillaries in the lower layers of the skin.
Mild fever that does not exceed 38.5 degree centrigrade.
A focal sensory seizure is a type seizure beginning with a subjective sensation.
Hypopigmented hair that appears white.
Abnormal dilatation of the iris.

JT: ドルーゼ(結晶腔;晶洞;脈絡膜硝子肬)
DEF: Drusen (singular, 'druse') are tiny yellow or white accumulations of extracellular material (lipofuscin) that build up in Bruch's membrane of the eye.

A congenital defect in the skull, whereby there is a protrusion of part of the cranial contents through a congenital defect in the cranium, usually covered with skin or mucous membrane. The term encephalocele refers to a subclass of these lesions in which brain tissue protrudes through the defect.
Benign neoplasia derived from lipoblasts or lipocytes of white or brown fat. May be angiomatous or hibernomatous.
A visual defect characterized by the inability to see as clearly in bright light as in dim light. The word hemeralopia literally means day blindness.

The presence of 10 or more white cells per cubic millimeter in a urine specimen, 3 or more white cells per high-power field of unspun urine, a positive result on Gram staining of an unspun urine specimen, or a urinary dipstick test that is positive for leukocyte esterase.

The presence of 10 or more white cells per cubic millimeter in a urine specimen, 3 or more white cells per high-power field of unspun urine, a positive result on Gram staining of an unspun urine specimen, or a urinary dipstick test that is positive for leukocyte esterase.
Inflammation of the liver.
A cancer arising in any part of the stomach.
The J wave is a positive convex deflection that occurs at the junction of the QRS complex and ST segment, the J-point.
Partial or complete loss of vision in one half of the visual field of one or both eyes.
A subjective feeling of tiredness characterized by a lack of energy and motivation.
Inflammation of the nasal mucosa with nasal congestion.
The distal interphalangeal joint and/or the proximal interphalangeal joint of the fingers or toes cannot be extended to 180 degrees by either active or passive extension.
An unpleasant sensory and emotional experience associated with actual or potential tissue damage, or described in terms of such damage.
Hemorrhage between the skull and periosteum of a newborn resulting from rupture of blood vessels that cross the periosteum.
A severe form of gait ataxia such that an affected person cannot walk at all.
Poverty of behavior and speech output, lack of initiative, loss of emotional responses, psychomotor slowing, and prolonged speech latency.
Poverty of behavior and speech output, lack of initiative, loss of emotional responses, psychomotor slowing, and prolonged speech latency.
Absence of the tongue owing to a developmental abnormality.
A flat, distinct, discolored area of skin less than 1 cm wide that does not involve any change in the thickness or texture of the skin.
A sudden, audible expulsion of air from the lungs through a partially closed glottis, preceded by inhalation.

JT: 激しいOR苛酷OR重症OR重篤OR重度OR重症型
DEF: Having a high degree of severity. For quantitative traits, a deviation of between four and five standard deviations from the appropriate population mean.

JT: 遠位OR遠心性OR末端OR遠位性
DEF: Localized away from the central point of the body.
A connective tissue neoplasm formed by proliferation of mesodermal cells. Bone and soft tissue sarcomas are the main types of sarcoma. Sarcoma is usually highly malignant.
Osteomas are bony growths found most commonly on the skull and mandible; however, they may occur in any bone of the body. Osteomas do not usually cause clinical problems and do not become malignant.

A condition in which middle parts of the hands and/or feet (digits and meta-carpals and -tarsals) are missing giving a cleft appearance. The severity is very variable ranging from slightly hypoplastic 3rd toe/fingers over absent 2nd or 3rd toes/fingers as far as oligo- or monodactyl hands and/or feet.

A congenital branchial sinus is a remnant of the embryonic branchial arches and their intervening clefts and pouches that has failed to regress completely. Sinuses typically have their external orifice inferior to the ramus of the mandible. They may traverse the parotid gland, and run in close vicinity to the facial nerve in the external auditory canal.
The distal interphalangeal joint and/or the proximal interphalangeal joint of the fingers cannot be extended to 180 degrees by either active or passive extension.
Increased frequency of urination.
Absence of urine, clinically classified as below 50ml/day.
Absence of urine, clinically classified as below 50ml/day.
Low output of urine, clinically classified as an output below 300-500ml/day.
Eversion of a hollow organ and exposure, inside out, and protruded through the abdominal wall.

An acute and life-threatening complication of pregnancy, which is characterized by the appearance of tonic-clonic seizures, usually in a patient who had developed pre-eclampsia. Eclampsia includes seizures and coma that happen during pregnancy but are not due to preexisting or organic brain disorders.
A general term for inflammation of the muscles without respect to the underlying cause.
The presence of an extra auricle on one or both sides of the head.
A type of Macrodactyly affecting one or several fingers.
A type of Macrodactyly affecting one or several toes.
An unpleasant sensation characterized by physical discomfort (such as pricking, throbbing, or aching) localized to the chest.
A serious and potentially life-threatening condition that arises when a considerable mass of body tissue dies (necrosis).
Systemic inflammatory response to infection.
Noticeably unpleasant odors exhaled in breathing.
An abnormal connection between the gut and another hollow organ, such as the bladder, urethra, vagina, or other regions of the gastrointestinal tract.
A developmental anomaly wtih a small tubular or saccular midline stomach.
An unpleasant sensation characterized by physical discomfort (such as pricking, throbbing, or aching) localized to the eye.
A circumscribed, solid elevation of skin with no visible fluid, varying in size from a pinhead to less than 10mm in diameter at the widest point.
A circumscribed, solid elevation of skin with no visible fluid, varying in size from a pinhead to less than 10mm in diameter at the widest point.
A small elevation of the skin containing cloudy or purulent material usually consisting of necrotic inflammatory cells.
Warts, benign growths on the skin or mucous membranes that cause cosmetic problems as well as pain and discomfort. Warts most often occur on the hands, feet, and genital areas.
An abnormal accumulation of fluid beneath the skin, or in one or more cavities of the body.
Presence of multiple small cysts containing keratin (skin protein) and presenting as tiny pearly-white bumps just under the surface of the skin.
Elevated body temperature due to failed thermoregulation.
Lack of breathing with no movement of the respiratory muscles and no exchange of air in the lungs. This term refers to a disposition to have recurrent episodes of apnea rather than to a single event.
Acute obstruction of the intestines preventing passage of the contents of the intestines.

JT: 開始OR発生ORオンセットOR発症OR発病OR作用発現
DEF: The age group in which disease manifestations appear.
A nevus is a type of hamartoma that is a circumscribed stable malformation of the skin.

DEF: Sudden appearance of disease manifestations over a short period of time.
A focal sensory seizure is a type seizure beginning with a subjective sensation.
A sudden, audible expulsion of air from the lungs through a partially closed glottis, preceded by inhalation.

JT: 右OR権利OR正しいOR右位OR直角
DEF: Being located on the right side of the body.
A state of abnormally elevated or irritable mood, arousal, and or energy levels.

A skin condition in which there is an increase in sebum secretion by the pilosebaceous apparatus associated with open comedones (blackheads), closed comedones (whiteheads), and pustular nodules (papules, pustules, and cysts).

A skin condition in which there is an increase in sebum secretion by the pilosebaceous apparatus associated with open comedones (blackheads), closed comedones (whiteheads), and pustular nodules (papules, pustules, and cysts).
Complete absence of wakefulness and content of conscience, which manifests itself as a lack of response to any kind of external stimuli.

Recurrent attacks of acute inflammatory arthritis of a joint or set of joints caused by elevated levels of uric acid in the blood which crystallize and are deposited in joints, tendons, and surrounding tissues.
An appetite for and the persistent ingestion of non-food substances such as clay. In order to diagnose pica, this behavior must have persisted over a period of at least one month.

An unpleasant sensory and emotional experience associated with actual or potential tissue damage, or described in terms of such damage.

A flat, distinct, discolored area of skin less than 1 cm wide that does not involve any change in the thickness or texture of the skin.
